58.description: Extremely authentic Si Chuan style restaurant. This small ma and pa shop reminds me of the local places I visited while living in China for several years during the 90's. Not only was it great cooking but wonderful service with a smile that you don't find in Chinatown.Highly recommended, give it a try and check out some of the unique things offered on the menu.

56.description: On an early Saturday afternoon, my friend and I paid visit to a near-empty Yan Bang Cai. They certainly deserve more attention than this. The menu is far from generic as is its competitors, the Lao empire. There are a vast amount of choices to select from and a few entrees even fared rabbit meat. For two, we shared the shredded pork with jalapeno peppers and spicy lamb with cumin. From the pictures, the lamb appear blazing hot but it's quite the contrary. The jalapeno peppers held most of the heat. Neither dishes sent us running in circles, screaming for water but do prepare yourself with napkins and at least one glass of ice water. They will come in handy. A minor deduction here and there lead to the four-star review. The paper covering our table was stained with grease as was a napkin that they gave us.

29.description: GOOD LUCK FORTUNENo fortune cookie was needed to find this place. It was all good luck. We were starving and had missed lunch. It's was 2pm and we were in Chinatown without a plan. We needed to be in the Gold Coast area by 3:30pm. We knew that our regular Chinese restaurants that we typically eat at were not very fast, so we through caution into the air. There was a parking spot directly in front of this restaurant and I grabbed it. We then saw the 3 red hot chili peppers on the awning and knew this place would be spicy enough for us. Our last check was the Yelp app which showed us a 4 star rating. This must be our lucky day. Look out Mega Millions I'm buying a lottery ticket tonight.  As I walked up, I loved all of the photos of food on the outside storefront window. Even the Hungry Hound had his headshot plastered on the front door. Honestly has Steve D eaten at every restaurant in Chicago? I'm starting to feel like he is watching me like Santa. Hopefully I'm not on the naughty food list. I loved the interior because it was warm and inviting. We were quickly greeted by Kevin who was also our waiter. Kevin is from a town near Beijing and has been living in Chicago for about a year. He loves his job and he loves the food here. After our lunch we spent some time talking to him and asking him what his favorite dishes were. He listed a whole bunch of his favorites and we are now ready for our next visit. He highly recommended the DanDan Noodles, which is one of my favorites, so I can hardly wait until my return visit. We ordered a cold appetizer of spicy chicken and noodles. It is the first time I've ever ordered cold noodles at a Chinese restaurant and it was really good. The dish was perfect with just the right amount of kick. I wish I had a slice of bread to wipe up all of the delicious chili oil on the bottom of the plate. I will definitely order this dish again. Do you like really spicy food? Then I recommend the Shredded pork with sliced jalapeño peppers. This Authentic Chinese Dish is from the city of Zigong, the third largest city in the Sichuan province of China. I promise that the dish will hurt you. If I was appearing on an episode of Man vs Food. I would have won at first but hours later the jalapeños came back roaring and beat me down. Yes food won and as much as I loved this dish I will not be ordering it ever again. The shredded pork was cooked perfectly and there were a ton of long sliced jalapeños that provided an amazing punch. There were also hints of fresh ginger in the dish. It was good but very spicy. A couple of things that I loved. The rice was free unlike another nearby Sichuan place that charges a $1 per person for rice and was recently shut down by the FBI. This place takes credit cards (see comment above). They also have free hot green tea and it was really good. It was perfect on a cold chilly fall day in Chicago. This may be a new favorite of ours and I can not wait to come back. There was authentic Chinese music playing in the background that went along with the soothing waterfall in the restaurant. I loved the interior which had a great authentic feel on the inside. Throw in some free wifi and I could hang out here all day long. If you do come here check out the walls for great info. There is a board that shows how much they love social media platforms encouraging customers to write reviews. By posting this it shows their confidence in the food they are serving. There was a community board with local info. Another board with letters and reviews written by real customers. It's like a Yelp review of the day but on the wall of the restaurant. There were also various magazine articles and great restaurant awards posted around. All I could see was an owner who cares about his customers, community and business by serving fantastic authentic food. I loved this business from when I first walked in the door and it did not disappoint me. The service and food were incredible and I hope I visit again soon. Chinatown in Chicago is starting to remind me of my trips to Beijing and it's only 3 miles from my house. So I have no excuses not to be a frequent diner here. See you again soon my new favorite but keep the shredded pork & jalapeños away from my belly.

42.description: The same location used to be Chongqing Lou, which is a very good place. We were a little bit disappointed when we arrived there and figured out it has changed to Yan Bang Cai.  Anyway, we decided to try. We ordered spice fish.  OMG.. what kind of fish they were using to make the spice fish? with bones and not fresh at all. I asked the waiter, and his answer was it is live fish.... I had nothing to say. The worst place in Chinatown, I would rank.

23.description: Totally not spicy enough. Beef tripe was alright, it was chewy and could be less beefy. The yushiang eggplant was texturally not too squishy but could udr some deep fried crunchy edges. It just didn't live up to its spicy counterparts at other restaurants.The mapo tofu was probably the best dish of the mix. The tofu seemed fresh. The cold spicy bean curd appetizer was covered in chili oil but it seemed prepared last minute as they used cold five spice dried tofu and none of it had taken on the chili oil flavor. Very disappointing.I would come here over Lao Sze Chuan but it is no comparison to Szechuan mala spice at chengdu impression.Props for having wifi though. Also don't sit near the annoying chimes at the door.

47.description: Bad bad bad. Unbelievable. Try to call for carry out on Sunday night, and have to call 8 times before someone answers. She said she was too busy, and tell me to place order later and hang up. Waited 20 minutes and walk in to the restaurant, only 5 tables was there. Placed my order and waited 45 mins to get my food. I am not even hungry any more. Only one waitress works there, OMG, please hire more people!

8.description: After coming here for so many times (9 times for now) I'm finally writing a review now.As a Sichuanese, where this type of food came from,  I think it is pretty authentic. Zigong is a city in Sichuan. The real Zigong food is very salty and very spicy. I like Yan Bang Cai kinda tone the heaviness of the favoring down a bit because even for local Sichuanese, Zigong food can be too spicy. Before coming in, I have some warnings for you. Don't expect American style Chinese food here (I don't know why would someone come to Chinatown for that. Panda Express has all they want). Don't expect food placed in fancy bone china and decorate too nicely. Food is priced quite cheaply here and appetizer portion is close to Entree size. If someone still want more than that, go out and turn left to Lao series restaurants. I usually roll my eyes when someone brings up Lao Sichuan after I mentioned that I grew up in Sichuan.I wouldn't say everything dish is equally good (I don't think any restaurant is like that). My favorites are: YiBing noodles, pork belly with bamboo, green beans with pork, pork belly appetizer (蒜泥白肉), poached spicy fish and 藤椒沸腾鱼。

31.description: Yibin noodles = soooo delicious!Salt miner's eggplant = perfectly fried crispy outside and tender inside. Only complaint is I burnt the crap out of my mouth because I got so excited to eat this that I didn't wait for it to cool!Spicy cumin lamb = spicy and delicious and tender.Eat in rather than get take out. Apparently, the boy had picked up take out here before (I didn't know where it came from) and it was completely unremarkable. However, after eating in, I can definitely say this is my new chinese food fav. Either we ordered better when we ate in or the food sat too long and lost its luster.

34.description: Yuk! We could not even eat our food . It was terrible , we ended up leaving and getting pizza

16.description: What is up with the SALT?????  Neither of us could eat it. We asked why it was so salty and if it was by design. The "more interested in his computer than us" waiter just looked at us and laughed. Not sure what that's all about.

13.description: We have been here 3 times already and have not been disappointed.  Portions are large for a fair price and food so far has been delicious.  We've had the salt miners fish, the crispy eggplant in fragrant sauce, side pork with garlic, spicy beef and tripe dressed in chili, Sichuan style small plate chicken, pork belly with mustard greens, and Sichuan lamb.  It's also BYOB.

11.description: Arrived in Chicago hungry. Where is my first stop? CHINATOWN! I take every opportunity to get authentic Chinese food which is hard to come by in the city I currently live in. Yea I know I'm so Chinese, lol! I had heard a lot about another restaurant Lao Sze Chuan in Chinatown but after reading mixed reviews, I decided to come to Yan Bang Cai instead. I parked just outside the restaurant on the street with no problem. Parking is $2 per hour which seems to be the norm in Chicago. The restaurant was very clean and well decorated. It was quite empty during lunch hour on a Thursday when I visited. Being the only customer, I was able to chat quite a bit with the server in Mandarin. She told me because of the Chinatown location most ppl live nearby are Chinese. Chinese ppl don't like spending money so they usually bring lunch to work and that's why there aren't many customers for lunch. But it usually gets very busy at dinner time. Hmm, that makes sense. Guess I'm not so Chinese after all b/c I eat out all the time, lol! She also told me the owner/chef came from Sichuan province in China so the dishes are very traditional Sichuan style. I studied the menu for a bit and ordered the pork in garlic sauce (Yu Xiang Rou Si) and a cold dish appetizer beef slice in chili sauce (Fu Qi Fei Pian). My order came quickly. And the portion was big enough for two people to share. I have to say the beef slice in chili sauce was the BEST! It was very authentic and addicting! I highly recommend it if you like spicy dishes! It was just like the flavor you would taste in China. The pork in garlic sauce was good but not great. I don't think I would order it again. But then again I think I might have ordered the wrong dish b/c it isn't really a Sichuan speciality to begin with. I'll deff have to try something else next time. My server was nice and attentive. My bill came to be around $18 plus tip. It was a bit steep for one person but I think it is actually reasonable if you consider the portion of the dishes. Overall, I was very satisfied with this restaurant. I'd totally come again on my next trip to Chicago!

39.description: Totally amazing! Do order the rabbit (什么鲜兔= =)and the steamed lamb (粉蒸羊肉)，the latter one will surprise you, and in a good way! The lamb is very tender and easy to chew, the flavor is very special. Steamed buns are not the best, but definitely enjoyable.

37.description: Food is great. Super spicy (if you ask, and confirm), flavors you haven't had before, nice atmosphere, Quick if you want.I was here twice and both times waitress tried very hard to sell "American" Chinese food (there is a separate menu - make sure you're NOT looking at that once - ask for the regular menu), and then up-sell whole duck for the two of us.  That said, the service is darling and sincere - just make it clear that you don't need tons of extras and you don't want the American menu.Hot pots, yup, yum; fat noodles, yum, and some super delicious rabbit dish that's on the first page.  You'll end up with way too much food - one dish per person is more than enough - but it's a good foodie experience.

0.description: I wasn't impressed with my first restaurant's lunch and so I opted for a second lunch at Yan Bang Cai.  Mind as well since I drove through the god awful traffic/construction to get to Chinatown.  This place is legit when it comes to Szechuan food.  I ordered braised pork belly with mustard greens, mapo tofu, and the chilled spiced rabbit for about 31 bucks.  The interior seems new and very clean which I appreciated even though I was just patiently waiting at the entrance for my food to be made while secretly spying on what other people ordered.  I wished I could have eaten everything there but even after the hour drive back everything was still hot and delicious.  The tofu was my least favorite but still decent.  There seemed to be lot of chili oil, but other than that, it didn't have much of a flavor.  It didn't make my mouth numb and wasn't that spicy.  The rabbit and braised pork belly however were knockouts! The rabbit was slightly chilled with a fantastic flavor that would be a great addition to any family meal.  It is a little bony, so be prepared to eat slower.  The pork belly with mustard greens is rich and fatty, just how I like my pork.  The menu does have English so don't be afraid to visit.  I will definitely "gently" force my guy to come here one day.

38.description: Great Sichuan food (zigong). Good service and reasonable portion. Remember to get 15% off if u pay by cash. Rabbit meat dishes are good! Xian guo Tu is spicy but very good.

51.description: Some of the best Chinese food I've had in Chicago. The soups--egg drop and hot and sour--were delicious but unsurprising. The real treat was the salt miner's eggplant: crispy, flavorful, satisfying. Make sure to put the rice down first, so the oil and salt soak into the rice. The shredded beef with green chilies had some heat and was another pleasing dish.

27.description: This is my new favorite restaurant in Chinatown and this is based on a single experience on a chilly Sunday at 2pm.As a new resident of Pilsen, it's been my goal to visit every restaurant in Chinatown, but now, that may not happen because this is the only place I want to go.I ordered just one dish, too, the $18 spicy shrimp large wok. The sauce reminded me of my favorite dish at San Francisco's Mission Chinese, the thrice cooked pork.On my next visit, if their pork is anything like that shrimp dish, I'm done. The FBI can shut down all of the Chinatown restaurants as long as they leave this one alone.

32.description: I'm always so pleased to find hidden gems in Chinatown, and Yan Bang Cai was definitely a delightful Sichuan surprise. Our meal was amazingly flavorful, well executed, and home-y, and it definitely beats going to tourist-ladden Lao Sze Chuan. The food hails from Zigong in the Sichuan province, which is known for their salt mines. Our server told us the chef has 6 restaurants in Michigan and this is his first venture in Chicago (so he definitely has his shit down). Our server made great recommendations on the following: Sichuan style small plate chicken: Winner winner chicken dinner, this dish definitely stole the show. A complex stew of bone-in chicken, carrots, potatoes, and hand pulled noodles in a sichuan pepper curry broth, this was unlike anything I've eaten before, and tasted like Mom made it. This is a must-try!Rabbit & Chili peppers (cold) & Dan Dan noodles: we had these as appetizers and both were greatly flavored without being too spicy Zigong salt miner eggplant: I always associate Sichuan food with eggplant, and this eggplant was perfectly fried, light creamy texture and dusted with cumin & sichuan spicesSquirrel fish in two sauces: This was a really interesting dish in that two fish filets were fried and covered in two sauces, one sweet & vinegary, another chili based. This is a great option if you like heavier sauces with fish Pork belly & bamboo shoots: Although this dish was tasty (how could pork belly not be?) I probably wouldn't order again since it was just an ok version of pork belly Overall, Yan Bang Cai was a great Sichuan food experience and I will definitely be back to try more.

54.description: It was the first time that we came to china town in Chicago. My wife wanted to eat Sìchuān cài and wanted to go to there.So I drove with her on holiday.We really enjoyed some delicious foods!They served authentic Chinese dishes and wait on the customers quite serviceably.We will come here sometime soon.

48.description: Very authentic food! Lao Sze Schuan is a bit too over rated and too many people. This place is more authentic and the waitress was SUPER NICE! I loved her service so much! She was so thoughtful and helpful. I think me and my friend just found a new favorite place to go to in chinatown. The portions are big too. We will definitely come back

44.description: This place is fantastic, I grabbed the ko shui ji (mouth watering chicken, a spicy appetizer traditionally served cold) and they killed it. The perfect amount of heat and flavor came together to make this dish amazing. Definitely recommended.

24.description: This restaurant was alright for me. The decor is unique, service pretty decent, food came out fast and hot, and prices are a little on the high side for Chinatown (closer to suburban pricing). The flavors are pretty good, but doesn't seem too distinguished from other similar restaurants - for one that boasts several pages on their menu about regional specialties. With that said, they do have a wide variety of spicy dishes that come in a good portion size with nice presentation. But really nothing stands out that would really pull me away from one of Tony's restaurants.Here are some of my notes on specific dishes:Song's Three-Bean and fish soup: Nice light soup with pea shoots and seasoned with just the right amount of white pepper. The fish is tender and lightly flavored. A bit pricey for a soup that doesn't contain more complexity and body.Quick-fried Seven-step duck: Probably the most skillfully prepared dish I tried. With the multiple cooking steps, in the end it tastes something like a mix between twice cooked pork and smoked duck with tender meat witht he flavors of onion and jalapeno coming through strongly. However, chopping it into pieces rather than slicing in a way to minimize the inconvience of bones while eating really took away from a great dish.Spicy cumin lamb: The lamb and its marination are flavorful and tender - salty with a light aroma. The cumin here is definitely noticable but not robust like preparations you find elsewhere although the flavor of the garlic was nice and strong. Not too spicy and good for a nice meal in the winter.Zigong Salt Miners Spicy Pork: The pork has a bouncy texture and the pepper flavor is noticable, however this dish really could've had stronger and more distinctive flavors.Crispy eggplant in fragrant sauce: The batter for the eggplant was definitely crispy, however it was fried fluffy like what you find in a Chinese Buffet rather than using a nice thin tempura-like batter. The eggplant flavor itself was barely noticable although the sweet vinegar sauce tasted great with the batter.Squirrel-shaped fish w. two flavors: Comes in two flavors. The orange sauce is tongue-numbing spicy but really has little depth to it. The brown sauce is a sweet vinegar. Both pieces of fish looked great with a real flower next to it, but it did not come out crispy at all.Pork belly with mustard greens: Pork belly come out very tender with a great amount of fat on it. But this dish tastes exactly the same as any other preparation in Chinatown for the same dish. I would've preferred maybe to see a slightly different type of pork used or a regional flair to it.Glutinous rice balls w. sesame stuffing: Strong egg flavor balanced with a light wine. A little on the sweeter side but not excessively so. Light hint of ginger and good body to the soup. The sesame filled rice balls are soft and provide just the right amount of chewiness. This one was the best executed dish of the ones I tried.In summary, the food here is pretty good however I put it at 3 instead of 4 stars because of its prices for the quality, lack of uniqueness, and inconsistent execution accross dishes.

7.description: As I write this, 4 hours later, I am still traumatized.Came in on a slow night, sat down, saw the menu that seemed pretty unique. The apathetic waiter took our order and then disappeared to his computer in the other room.Then I saw something move out of the corner of my eye. Something little and brown."Oh my God. I just saw a mouse"3 minutes later, 'Remy' scurried back out from under the booth.That was it. We ended up walking out. Kind of rude, I know, but I really was too traumatized to eat there after that, no matter how good the food is rumored to be.

49.description: This place is a good, more authentic alternative to Lao Sze Chuan, etc., and it has better service.  Very friendly wait staff.  I had the Zigong Rabbit in Spicy Ginger Sauce, and my friend had the Zigong Salt Miner's Poached Beef.  The Szechuan peppers really numbed our tongues!  Also, we had the Spicy Cucumber dish for an appetizer...the garlic and spicy red pepper oil sauce this was served in was fantastic...I wanted to lick my plate!It's hard to beat some of the intense flavors you find in the Lao chain of restaurants, but they don't have the real Szechuan peppercorns.  This place can definitely compete!  I will definitely be back.

40.description: Good food we had General Taos chicken and beef with jalapeños. Good stop to eat. Very calm quiet place. Waitress very accommodating. Very fast normally other places take forever to serve but they where good with time.

53.description: Went there with my girl and we had a great time. We ordered 鹽帮飄香魚，粉蒸羊肉，魚香茄子 and really enjoyed the food and service. However the portion sizes were larger than we had expected so if there are just 2 of you then we would recommend going with only 2 dishes. Food is very authentic just like we had back in Chengdu.

30.description: Stopped in for lunch today, and I was the only customer.  Had cold Szechuan noodles appetizer and ma po to fu.  Food was good.  Service was friendly.I give them extra credit for helpfulness.  I left a camera in the booth, called later about it, they found it and held it for me.  Honest and helpful.

46.description: Came here with group from work.  Excellent service and the food was even better.  Squirrel fish, eggplant, Sichuan chicken and pork in bamboo.  Even though the name means salt, the food was not but definitely spicy.  If you like Lao Sze Chuan, try the dishes at Yan Bang Cai that Lao doesn't have.  You will not be disappointed.

1.description: Yan Bang! You're Dead!It is no secret that I have an obsession with Chinatown. Every Sunday I dedicate a couple hours to visit the neighborhood for delicious authentic Asian cuisine and walk around and play in all of the little shops. I am on a mission to try every restaurant in the neighborhood. It will probably take me a solid year to do this but its okay.Location: Yan Bang Cai, with its loud moniker, had been on my radar for a few weeks. Located right on Cermak it is hard to miss. I decided to try all of the most popular restaurants first before trying the not so popular. Decor: Not too sure why I got a Hawaiian vibe from the interior of this place but it was still cool. There were lots of news articles on the walls. Thank God for the pictures though, because the majority of them were not in English. So I couldn't read them if I wanted to. Not too sure what the restaurant looks like in the middle dining section, but in the very front, it was very quaint.Food: Okay. I have such a huge issue with the menu and the food here. First of all, like the articles on the wall, everything was illegible - aside from a very basic description of the dish. It is a very uninspiring menu as well. Personally I am the type of food snob where I want the menu to motivate me to eat. YBC's did not. Because I could not really read the menu, I went with a chicken dish because I did not want to waste money experimenting with a dish where I was unsure of what was included. I ordered the spicy sichuan chicken dish. While the chicken was fantastic, WHY did they serve me a huge plate full of chilis?! I was not thrilled. Because no human being in their right mind would eat a plate of chilis with chicken on the side. Unless, of course, they had a death wish. There were times when I would bite the seeds of the chilis and my mouth would inflame. It was very uncomfortable. From that point I ordered egg rolls. Thank god, because surprisingly they were the best ive had in Chinatown thus far. Service: the waitress clearly spoke little English. That was okay though. She was very sweet. I wish I knew someone who could teach me Mandarin so I could better chat with folks in Chinatown.

55.description: When we first learned that Double Li closed, we were so sad. There are many good restaurants in Chinatown but very few that serve Sichuan cuisine (the delicious, spicy, fragrant variety of chinese food!) So we were so happy to hear that another Sichuan restaurant was moving into the space and we couldn't be happier with Yan Bang Cai. Everything we tried was the perfect combination of spicy and flavorful. And of course there are non-spicy options as well - the crispy eggplant with fragrant sauce was delicious. For those on the spicy side, we ordered the Xiaoping pork, sliced fish fillets in spicy broth, and the roasted green pepper plate (ie plate of jalapenos - so delicious!) This will be our new go to spot in Chinatown.

9.description: Weekday lunch. Was 1 of 2 tables there. Definitely get CA15, side pork with garlic sauce. It's thin slices pork belly in a garlic Szechuan oil. It was fantastic. Highly recommend the Salt Miner eggplant. Crispy exterior, sort of like a light tempura, no sauce. Very very good. The salt miner beef noodle was spot on. Tender beef tendon bites with very good (and long- literally about 3-4 ft long individually) noodles. I don't even like noodle dishes and this was on point. Got the sliced boiled beef L01. Very good too. The staff was very accommodating too, although it was basically just us in there. The only problem is that I ruined my shirt by getting oil drops on it from slurping the noodles and devouring all the oily saucy dishes. Great job Yan Bang Cai!

26.description: This is my favorite Chinese restaurant in the whole Chicago area. Number one, best, first choice.  I am married to someone who came from China,  and I have been to China several times, so I know and appreciate the difference in authentic Chinese food and the more common Americanized variety.  I particularly like good, spicy, and authentic Szechuan style food.  Yan Bang Cai is not a fancy place but the food is great and they have lots of good choices.  We always try something new so I don't even have a favorite dish.  Almost everything has been amazing.  The people working here are generally nice and will help you find something you like, and there are usually seversl groups of Chinese customers who will be happy to recommend something.So, in my humble opinion, if you like spicy food and are a little bit adventurous about eating, this is a place in Chicago that you have to try.

25.description: Amazing food, especially the fried eggplant and the lamb with sweet potato. I will definitely return!! Service was quick, friendly and informative. Food was hot, flavorful and eye-appealing. Just plain yum!!

12.description: Totally not spicy enough. Beef tripe was alright, it was chewy and could be less beefy. The yushiang eggplant was texturally not too squishy but could udr some deep fried crunchy edges. It just didn't live up to its spicy counterparts at other restaurants.The mapo tofu was probably the best dish of the mix. The tofu seemed fresh. The cold spicy bean curd appetizer was covered in chili oil but it seemed prepared last minute as they used cold five spice dried tofu and none of it had taken on the chili oil flavor. Very disappointing.I would come here over Lao Sze Chuan but it is no comparison to Szechuan mala spice at chengdu impression.Props for having wifi though. Also don't sit near the annoying chimes at the door.

59.description: Food is good. We came on Thursday night. Only few people were there. Our waitress is extremely nice and friendly. Price is very reasonable too. We came as a group of three. Ordered three entrees and shared their special noodles. Loved the flavor. Spicy in a wonderful way!

21.description: We had to get up and leave after being then totally ignored for over 20 minutes.  The one waitress was obviously overworked, but there were several other people there would could have at least given us menus or water.It's a shame, as the reviews seemed promising.

17.description: Date night at YBC. We yelped for a place "off the beaten path" from the square... there were only two other tables dining in an otherwise silent restaurant. Whispers seemed privy to the entire dining area. I figured this was only going to solidify it's "hidden gem" status. We ordered the kou shui chicken (aka "mouth-watering chicken"). It came out dubiously fast and tasted off to me, slightly sour, definitely not fresh. Since we also had szechuan the night before, we went with their "signature" squirrel fish. Do not fret-- it's only called that because the filleted , fried fish resembles the shape of a squirrel's tail. Like our chicken, the piece of fish tasted off as well. We didn't bother with the rest of it. Our green beans were super salty. I was really hoping for a great new find.. but alas we left indifferent. Maybe YBC was just having the case of the Mondays.

10.description: I'm always so pleased to find hidden gems in Chinatown, and Yan Bang Cai was definitely a delightful Sichuan surprise. Our meal was amazingly flavorful, well executed, and home-y, and it definitely beats going to tourist-ladden Lao Sze Chuan. The food hails from Zigong in the Sichuan province, which is known for their salt mines. Our server told us the chef has 6 restaurants in Michigan and this is his first venture in Chicago (so he definitely has his shit down). Our server made great recommendations on the following: Sichuan style small plate chicken: Winner winner chicken dinner, this dish definitely stole the show. A complex stew of bone-in chicken, carrots, potatoes, and hand pulled noodles in a sichuan pepper curry broth, this was unlike anything I've eaten before, and tasted like Mom made it. This is a must-try!Rabbit & Chili peppers (cold) & Dan Dan noodles: we had these as appetizers and both were greatly flavored without being too spicy Zigong salt miner eggplant: I always associate Sichuan food with eggplant, and this eggplant was perfectly fried, light creamy texture and dusted with cumin & sichuan spicesSquirrel fish in two sauces: This was a really interesting dish in that two fish filets were fried and covered in two sauces, one sweet & vinegary, another chili based. This is a great option if you like heavier sauces with fish Pork belly & bamboo shoots: Although this dish was tasty (how could pork belly not be?) I probably wouldn't order again since it was just an ok version of pork belly Overall, Yan Bang Cai was a great Sichuan food experience and I will definitely be back to try more.

5.description: GOOD LUCK FORTUNENo fortune cookie was needed to find this place. It was all good luck. We were starving and had missed lunch. It's was 2pm and we were in Chinatown without a plan. We needed to be in the Gold Coast area by 3:30pm. We knew that our regular Chinese restaurants that we typically eat at were not very fast, so we through caution into the air. There was a parking spot directly in front of this restaurant and I grabbed it. We then saw the 3 red hot chili peppers on the awning and knew this place would be spicy enough for us. Our last check was the Yelp app which showed us a 4 star rating. This must be our lucky day. Look out Mega Millions I'm buying a lottery ticket tonight.  As I walked up, I loved all of the photos of food on the outside storefront window. Even the Hungry Hound had his headshot plastered on the front door. Honestly has Steve D eaten at every restaurant in Chicago? I'm starting to feel like he is watching me like Santa. Hopefully I'm not on the naughty food list. I loved the interior because it was warm and inviting. We were quickly greeted by Kevin who was also our waiter. Kevin is from a town near Beijing and has been living in Chicago for about a year. He loves his job and he loves the food here. After our lunch we spent some time talking to him and asking him what his favorite dishes were. He listed a whole bunch of his favorites and we are now ready for our next visit. He highly recommended the DanDan Noodles, which is one of my favorites, so I can hardly wait until my return visit. We ordered a cold appetizer of spicy chicken and noodles. It is the first time I've ever ordered cold noodles at a Chinese restaurant and it was really good. The dish was perfect with just the right amount of kick. I wish I had a slice of bread to wipe up all of the delicious chili oil on the bottom of the plate. I will definitely order this dish again. Do you like really spicy food? Then I recommend the Shredded pork with sliced jalapeño peppers. This Authentic Chinese Dish is from the city of Zigong, the third largest city in the Sichuan province of China. I promise that the dish will hurt you. If I was appearing on an episode of Man vs Food. I would have won at first but hours later the jalapeños came back roaring and beat me down. Yes food won and as much as I loved this dish I will not be ordering it ever again. The shredded pork was cooked perfectly and there were a ton of long sliced jalapeños that provided an amazing punch. There were also hints of fresh ginger in the dish. It was good but very spicy. A couple of things that I loved. The rice was free unlike another nearby Sichuan place that charges a $1 per person for rice and was recently shut down by the FBI. This place takes credit cards (see comment above). They also have free hot green tea and it was really good. It was perfect on a cold chilly fall day in Chicago. This may be a new favorite of ours and I can not wait to come back. There was authentic Chinese music playing in the background that went along with the soothing waterfall in the restaurant. I loved the interior which had a great authentic feel on the inside. Throw in some free wifi and I could hang out here all day long. If you do come here check out the walls for great info. There is a board that shows how much they love social media platforms encouraging customers to write reviews. By posting this it shows their confidence in the food they are serving. There was a community board with local info. Another board with letters and reviews written by real customers. It's like a Yelp review of the day but on the wall of the restaurant. There were also various magazine articles and great restaurant awards posted around. All I could see was an owner who cares about his customers, community and business by serving fantastic authentic food. I loved this business from when I first walked in the door and it did not disappoint me. The service and food were incredible and I hope I visit again soon. Chinatown in Chicago is starting to remind me of my trips to Beijing and it's only 3 miles from my house. So I have no excuses not to be a frequent diner here. See you again soon my new favorite but keep the shredded pork & jalapeños away from my belly.

3.description: This restaurant deserves way more fame than it does. I'm so in love!! After seeing the pictures on Yelp, I showed my mom and we went to eat here. Honestly, Yan Bang Cai is better than Lao Sze Chuan and most of the restaurants here in Chinatown. Out of all the 6 dishes we ordered, I can confidently say that all of them were perfect. Will visit 1000000847373x more, lol.

35.description: Date night at YBC. We yelped for a place "off the beaten path" from the square... there were only two other tables dining in an otherwise silent restaurant. Whispers seemed privy to the entire dining area. I figured this was only going to solidify it's "hidden gem" status. We ordered the kou shui chicken (aka "mouth-watering chicken"). It came out dubiously fast and tasted off to me, slightly sour, definitely not fresh. Since we also had szechuan the night before, we went with their "signature" squirrel fish. Do not fret-- it's only called that because the filleted , fried fish resembles the shape of a squirrel's tail. Like our chicken, the piece of fish tasted off as well. We didn't bother with the rest of it. Our green beans were super salty. I was really hoping for a great new find.. but alas we left indifferent. Maybe YBC was just having the case of the Mondays.

19.description: This is my favorite Chinese restaurant in the whole Chicago area. Number one, best, first choice.  I am married to someone who came from China,  and I have been to China several times, so I know and appreciate the difference in authentic Chinese food and the more common Americanized variety.  I particularly like good, spicy, and authentic Szechuan style food.  Yan Bang Cai is not a fancy place but the food is great and they have lots of good choices.  We always try something new so I don't even have a favorite dish.  Almost everything has been amazing.  The people working here are generally nice and will help you find something you like, and there are usually seversl groups of Chinese customers who will be happy to recommend something.So, in my humble opinion, if you like spicy food and are a little bit adventurous about eating, this is a place in Chicago that you have to try.

28.description: The seven step duck is my favorite, spicy and crispy. I order that as my go to dish when I go here or get takeout. I do have to mention that you need to let them know not to put MSG on their food, but I guess that's the same all over Chinatown.

45.description: The food was just ok....The real problem was the service at the end. They refused to call a cab for us and it was freezing outside. We walked around and eventually went back and begged them to help but they would only say they couldn't help and we're sorry. Never had anything like this happen before.

33.description: I read some of the reviews after visiting this joint. To my surprise, I saw some people disliking what they had there and made some bad reviews. I can understand that, really, after all it is a very intense flavored cuisine and not every digs it even in the Motherland. Any if you are not an advocate to eating unusual meats and animal parts, do not come here. It was THE best hotpot I have ever had in the US. I mean, if you have had any good experience eating Chinese Hotpot, go there and get the Mala soup base along with your favorite veggies and meats, it will rock your world. The soup base was so spicy, peppery, mouth numbing and doesn't require any dipping sauce. It is just good. I have to warn you though, you would probably have some hard time the next morning....but it is completely normal after eating spicy food lol

43.description: I was craving spicy fried chicken in Chinatown and my husband and I wandered in here by accident and it was a lovely accident!  We arrived at the restaurant about 15 minutes before closing and was worried that they will half-a$$ make our food in a hurry, but that was not the case at all.  What did comfort me was that most of the dining guests were Mandarin speakersWe ordered the Sichuan Spicy Lamb and Zigong salt miner's fish for dinner last night.  Both dishes were absolutely delicious, authentic, and in generous portions.  The flavors were complex and the ingredients were very fresh.  This meal definitely made me forget about my fried chicken craving!I am excited to come back and try other dishes.  YBC is way better than 老四川 (Lao Sichuan) and much better value.  I will be bringing my parents and in-laws the next time they want to go to Chinatown for a meal!  Waitstaff was nice and their English was good.  This place also gets BONUS points for offering Wi-Fi in the restaurant!  Now I can watch K-Dramas and eat delicious food while avoiding most social interactions. Awesome!

2.description: Order the 松鼠鱼!!! (the fried sweet sour fish?) it's really good, definitely best I have had in the U.S. Lol my parents liked it so much that we went to this place twice in two days. Other fish and veggie stir fry dish is pretty good too. We also got the 7 step duck - the meat is kind of dry and mostly fat. And the pork stir fry - the pork was kind of tough but the celery is really good and crisp.The service is okay, dishes came out pretty fast. The interior is dated and feels dingy; I think they could attract a lot more clientele if they spend some money to modernize the interior. It's located at a nice spot easy to find. You can get two dollar parking credit if you dine in.

18.description: Excellent Food- must try Small Plate Chicken, Zing Zong Salt Merchant Chicken, Hot and Sour Soup

41.description: Arrived in Chicago hungry. Where is my first stop? CHINATOWN! I take every opportunity to get authentic Chinese food which is hard to come by in the city I currently live in. Yea I know I'm so Chinese, lol! I had heard a lot about another restaurant Lao Sze Chuan in Chinatown but after reading mixed reviews, I decided to come to Yan Bang Cai instead. I parked just outside the restaurant on the street with no problem. Parking is $2 per hour which seems to be the norm in Chicago. The restaurant was very clean and well decorated. It was quite empty during lunch hour on a Thursday when I visited. Being the only customer, I was able to chat quite a bit with the server in Mandarin. She told me because of the Chinatown location most ppl live nearby are Chinese. Chinese ppl don't like spending money so they usually bring lunch to work and that's why there aren't many customers for lunch. But it usually gets very busy at dinner time. Hmm, that makes sense. Guess I'm not so Chinese after all b/c I eat out all the time, lol! She also told me the owner/chef came from Sichuan province in China so the dishes are very traditional Sichuan style. I studied the menu for a bit and ordered the pork in garlic sauce (Yu Xiang Rou Si) and a cold dish appetizer beef slice in chili sauce (Fu Qi Fei Pian). My order came quickly. And the portion was big enough for two people to share. I have to say the beef slice in chili sauce was the BEST! It was very authentic and addicting! I highly recommend it if you like spicy dishes! It was just like the flavor you would taste in China. The pork in garlic sauce was good but not great. I don't think I would order it again. But then again I think I might have ordered the wrong dish b/c it isn't really a Sichuan speciality to begin with. I'll deff have to try something else next time. My server was nice and attentive. My bill came to be around $18 plus tip. It was a bit steep for one person but I think it is actually reasonable if you consider the portion of the dishes. Overall, I was very satisfied with this restaurant. I'd totally come again on my next trip to Chicago!

52.description: Came here with friends after skiing a whole day at Wilmot. Second time to be here, really love this place! One of my friends is from Chongqing, and she said the food is seriously AUTHENTIC and DELICIOUS! Just like those you could get on the streets in Chongqing or Chemgdu. Definitely will go there more later. My new favorite Sichuan restaurant!

50.description: I'd actually give this place 4.5 stars, the only reason I rounded down instead of up is because it's a bit more expensive (the portions are smaller). I came to this place with a friend looking for the Szechuan place that it replaced, and when we got here on a Sunday for lunch it was empty except for another table. We were apprehensive about the emptiness, but the food is pretty authentic and very good. We ordered a rabbit dish, a small plate chicken, and Szechuan dan dan noodles. Of the three, the chicken was the best. The flavor was very authentic, close to the kind I had in China, and it had delicious handmade noodles at the bottom. The Szechuan dan dan noodles had a good dan dan sauce, but it would've been better with better noodles (ideally handmade with good chew). The rabbit was also well flavored and a bit tougher than the chicken, but I think it's also because rabbit is a tougher meat. Overall I enjoyed all the dishes very much. Keeping in mind that I have pretty high standards for Chinese food (coming from the California Bay Area and having been to China often), this place is pretty authentic. I'm really just nitpicking here. The only main downside is that it's a bit more expensive than Chinese restaurants I'm used to as the portions are rather small, but the flavor makes up for it. This is probably about as authentic and good as you'll get in Chicago.Edit: I've come back way too many times for it to remain 4.5 stars.

4.description: BYOB alert! I recommend bringing sweeter white wines or lagers to offset the spiciness of the Sichuan food served at Yan Bang Cai.I was part of a group of ~10 people having dinner here on a Saturday night. We made a reservation in advance, which, after seeing the seating arrangements in the restaurant, I would say is necessary for groups larger than 6. Most of our group spoke Mandarin, which definitely made ordering easier because the English proficiency of the server varied from person to person.Yan Bang Cai gets 5 stars for food and 3 stars for service (thus my 4-star review). All of us were very familiar with Sichuan food, and we all agreed that the food was great and authentic. Dishes we had included the Zigong Salt Miner's Eggplant, Mapo Tofu, Squirrel-Shaped Fish with Two Flavors, Beef Noodles, and Green Beans with Pork. Service was so-so: first, we had to ask for water/tea refills, napkins, and extra bowls/plates, but when asked the servers brought the requested items promptly; and second, they were slow to clear the table. Street parking is difficult in Chinatown; you're much better off paying for parking in the lot by the El and walking over.

6.description: This restaurant was alright for me. The decor is unique, service pretty decent, food came out fast and hot, and prices are a little on the high side for Chinatown (closer to suburban pricing). The flavors are pretty good, but doesn't seem too distinguished from other similar restaurants - for one that boasts several pages on their menu about regional specialties. With that said, they do have a wide variety of spicy dishes that come in a good portion size with nice presentation. But really nothing stands out that would really pull me away from one of Tony's restaurants.Here are some of my notes on specific dishes:Song's Three-Bean and fish soup: Nice light soup with pea shoots and seasoned with just the right amount of white pepper. The fish is tender and lightly flavored. A bit pricey for a soup that doesn't contain more complexity and body.Quick-fried Seven-step duck: Probably the most skillfully prepared dish I tried. With the multiple cooking steps, in the end it tastes something like a mix between twice cooked pork and smoked duck with tender meat witht he flavors of onion and jalapeno coming through strongly. However, chopping it into pieces rather than slicing in a way to minimize the inconvience of bones while eating really took away from a great dish.Spicy cumin lamb: The lamb and its marination are flavorful and tender - salty with a light aroma. The cumin here is definitely noticable but not robust like preparations you find elsewhere although the flavor of the garlic was nice and strong. Not too spicy and good for a nice meal in the winter.Zigong Salt Miners Spicy Pork: The pork has a bouncy texture and the pepper flavor is noticable, however this dish really could've had stronger and more distinctive flavors.Crispy eggplant in fragrant sauce: The batter for the eggplant was definitely crispy, however it was fried fluffy like what you find in a Chinese Buffet rather than using a nice thin tempura-like batter. The eggplant flavor itself was barely noticable although the sweet vinegar sauce tasted great with the batter.Squirrel-shaped fish w. two flavors: Comes in two flavors. The orange sauce is tongue-numbing spicy but really has little depth to it. The brown sauce is a sweet vinegar. Both pieces of fish looked great with a real flower next to it, but it did not come out crispy at all.Pork belly with mustard greens: Pork belly come out very tender with a great amount of fat on it. But this dish tastes exactly the same as any other preparation in Chinatown for the same dish. I would've preferred maybe to see a slightly different type of pork used or a regional flair to it.Glutinous rice balls w. sesame stuffing: Strong egg flavor balanced with a light wine. A little on the sweeter side but not excessively so. Light hint of ginger and good body to the soup. The sesame filled rice balls are soft and provide just the right amount of chewiness. This one was the best executed dish of the ones I tried.In summary, the food here is pretty good however I put it at 3 instead of 4 stars because of its prices for the quality, lack of uniqueness, and inconsistent execution accross dishes.

22.description: The food was fantastic and predictably spicey.  The place was understaffed for my only visit, which led to some difficulty when ordering a beverage to cool down my mouth.  I think more people should give Sichuanese food a try!

15.description: Visiting from San Francisco and found this place after reading about it in the NY Times. It's a quaint and cosy little place across the street from the Gates of Chinatown.Never having had Zidong style food I was intrigued. We ordered 3 dishes- Fish w/ two flavors; rabbit w/ chili peppers; Salt miners eggplant. First off, the dishes are beautifully prepared. Having worked in a Chinese kitchen these folks make the extra effort to prepare both esthetically pleasing as well as deliciously flavored dishes. I would return in a heart beat.

57.description: I have been here twice and the food has been outstanding both times.  Branch out and get authentic Szechuan dishes.  The Chairman Mao pork is outstanding.

20.description: This was a horrible experience. The service was practically nonexistent, and we were completely ignored. It took an hour just to get out appetizers. The food was mediocre at best. Do not waste your time. This is the worst restaurant in Chinatown.

36.description: 好吃!Hiding in plain sight across from Old Chinatown, this restaurant serves up quality Szechuan authenticity at its best. We ordered the mouthwatering chicken, spicy fish fillet in broth, mapo tofu, and a pork dish with wood ear and peppers--varying degrees of spiciness, cooked to the same high standard of epicure. Each dish comes with white rice (bai fan)--and you'll definitely need lots of it, to temper the flaming delicacies you are about to consume. We also noticed a few brave, perhaps dedicated souls who came in, midday on a Saturday, just to feast by themselves.Perfect for clearing the sinuses, as my friend who came in with a cold remarked.

14.description: This is my new favorite restaurant in Chinatown and this is based on a single experience on a chilly Sunday at 2pm.As a new resident of Pilsen, it's been my goal to visit every restaurant in Chinatown, but now, that may not happen because this is the only place I want to go.I ordered just one dish, too, the $18 spicy shrimp large wok. The sauce reminded me of my favorite dish at San Francisco's Mission Chinese, the thrice cooked pork.On my next visit, if their pork is anything like that shrimp dish, I'm done. The FBI can shut down all of the Chinatown restaurants as long as they leave this one alone.

58.description: Continuing on our dim sum grand tour we came upon Won Kow! Not two, not three.Won Kow uses the "fill out a form, receive food" method of dim sum. While I prefer the rotating-carts-around-the-room method, you do get exactly what you want a lot faster this way. Armed with a trusty pen and menu, we ordered some of our usual items. BBQ pork bao, lotus leaf rice, shrimp and cilantro dumplings, custard bao, pot stickers and a bevy of other good dishes.The service was... awkward. The girl helping us spoke SO quickly and SO softly, in seemingly random staccato phrases. In the end we got most everything we wanted, when we wanted, but it was a journey.All in all I think the draw to Won Kow is more about being in Chinatown and experiencing everything that goes with it. I'm going to keep trying other places down there (OTH anyone?) until I've found my perfect dim sum locale. Until then, pass the plates and chow down!

56.description: Yummy and affordable!Our food came in fast and the service was great. We came here after the auto show and after walking for 4 hours, we were starving! We decided to go to Chinatown for dim sum and this place hit the spot.

29.description: went here with  a friend a few weeks ago & i was NOT impressed. she suggested it cuz her family has gone here often but ive never been here. we tried the fried oysters & there was too much breading.  i also tried some seafood with veggies dish & it was good but nothing spectacular.  i forgot what my friend ordered but she loved it. i guess my taste is different than heres cuz i would NOT come back to this place. good service and nice ambiance but the food was not that great.

42.description: I came here with a group of friends for Dim Sum before the Chinese New Year parade. It was...well...below my expectations. The crazy part is that we were given a menu for approximately 4 minutes, expected to order and memorize the menu for the rest of the meal, although we had 10 people in our party, and we weren't sure how much dim sum was enough for everyone. The service was a little poor, but it is expected since it's Chinatown. But it literally took 20 minutes to get a drink, and everytime we ordered food, the server would just drop it off at the table without telling us what it was (and we told her a few of us have dietary restrictions so not everyone can eat everything). So we would have to wait and wait until she came back again to find out what it is we are eating.On to the positive stuff! The dim sum was actually really delicious and seemed very fresh. The price is super reasonable for what we had. The dim sum is ordered through the check-off the paper way, versus the carts. This place is VERY great for large groups! And it was really cool to go to the oldest restaurant in Chinatown, to get that authentic feeling. Also, this place is right off the Chinatown red line stop, so it's easy access.I think I may try to go to the other side of Chinatown next time, just to try the newer restaurants.

23.description: My parents started taking us here in the 80's and I've been coming ever since. Rumor has it that Al Capone used to eat here. Their egg rolls are the best I've ever had. The lunch special is very cheap and you get a lot. My favorite dish has to be the egg foo young.

47.description: Ok not great

8.description: Went on Xmas day, very busy but worth the wait. Food was good and the wait staff was a little overwhelmed due to the crowd but they did a great job! Great place for a nice family time. Don't let the busy experience not make you come back!

31.description: Went here late craving good Chinese food. What I got was ok. The service was good, no complaints on that end. However, the food was bland, and was flavored to suit an untrained pallet. Translation: it was way to Americanized. Furthermore it just wasn't up to the standards I hold. There was often too much sauce, or the protein (whether shrimp, tofu, or beef) was over cooked by a minute or so. I also ordered an adult beverage (ok, it was a screwdriver) and paid $4 for what appeared to be orange juice, ice, and an alcoholic aftertaste. I did not feel I got my money's worth on food or drink. I won't be returning any time soon, especially with so many better places in the area.

34.description: Very friendly waitress. Quick service. Great dim sum. This is the only place my wife and I go to when we go to Chinatown.  Highly recommend the beef tripe with ginger. Very centralized with shops and bakery.  Close to cheap parking lot.

16.description: I had to think a while before rating. Why? The dim sum is solid, but not outstanding. The service is just fine, but not over the top. The location is convenient if you're at McCormick Place or are taking the Red Line train, but not convenient otherwise. I've eaten dim sum with Cantonese speakers in many cities in the US, including Flushing, Queens, and San Francisco. I think that makes it hard for me to truly enjoy dim sum unless it's nearly perfect. The way you can be if you see your favorite singer in your favorite opera (or rock concert or whatever you love). Afterwards, you find others just a little wanting.But I decided to put all that aside and settled on a 4 star rating. It's a great introduction to dim sum, with many traditional options, well prepared and fresh. It's a little annoying that the menu with pictures and descriptions doesn't line up with the paper menu you order from (no carts here). But you can just make that into something fun.Take it for what it is, don't expect the absolutely perfection of the cuisine, but do prepare to enjoy yourself and the very reasonable check.I've only ever eaten dim sum here, so can't speak to the rest of the menu.Note: the only way to the restaurant is up quite a long flight of stairs.

13.description: So, when I want to introduce my friends & family to the lovely world of Dim Sum, here's where I bring them. I've been a fan for over 20 years now.Why? Well, it is good, tasty food and a friendly place for a beginner to get acquainted with this different style of Chinese cuisine. The restaurant is not one of those huge, crowded open rooms with the metal carts crashing around. (I like that experience too, but it can be overwhelming at first.) It is a more intimate experience. The service is efficient and friendly with a cozy family restaurant vibe.The Dim Sum selection is not huge and exotic, but it is authentic and tends to focus on shrimp,seafood, chicken and pork. (They have the fun stuff like curried squid and chicken feet, too.)Also, you just order your choices from the Dim Sum menu (with pictures!) and they bring you what you want, hot and fresh from the kitchen. The fried items are just right, not greasy or lukewarm, like at some other places I've been.The Lotus Rice is excellent with large portions!  In my constant search for the perfect egg roll, they are in my all time top 5 list.

11.description: This place was a great surprise.  It is in Chicago's Chinatown.  This is the oldest Chinese restaurant in Chicago.  You walk up a flight of stairs to get to the restaurant.  The food is American-Chinese food, but oh so tasty.  The menu is enormous.  We had the shrimp almond ding, the vegetable hong sue tofu, and eight treasures duck.  All of it was great.  Giant size portions and we had plenty of left overs.  The staff was very nice and the owner/manager told us how Al Capone use to frequent the place.  Capone would sit at the table in the corner by the window with his back at the wall so he could so who was coming into the restaurant from the street.  His bodyguards would stand near the top of the stairs.  The manager was very happy to take multiple pictures of us at Al Capone's table.  No trip to Won Kow is complete without having a Volcano drink.  We chose the Long Island Ice Tea.  It was great, but that was not what made it so special.  The Volcano's are served in a very huge ceramic glass with fire in the middle of it.  Make sure you have a designated driver.

39.description: Food was wonderful. Service was with a smile. Decor was old school and reminded me of the 70's Chinese style. Could stand to be cleaner, but the food was fantastic and more than made up for any short comings. Not upscale dining, just great family style food.

37.description: Best Egg Drop You will find in Chicago !Go here before 3 PM for the lunch menu, it's very reasonable.Long climb up the stairs....you will be hungry when you get up there, but well worth the effort.

0.description: I dined at Won Kow (1/24/16) with one of my girlfriends on a Sunday afternoon. I am on a mission to try every restaurant in Chinatown. So this was the first time I tried Won Kow. We were shocked that in a restaurant in Chinatown on Sunday, we were the ONLY patrons! Wow. At first that concerned us, but (thankfully) we decided to try it out any way.Location/Decor - I have always enjoyed the decor of all the restaurants in Chinatown. They are all so unique to the other, yet each has their own special aesthetic and opulence. Won Kow seemed a little bit more grand than a few of its sister restaurants. The restaurant is on the second floor which makes for prime people watching down below on the busy Wentworth Avenue. Service - our servers were very prompt. We had one lady handling all of our food items, and one gentleman handling our tea and drinks. Both were very courteous and sincere with their service. They did not hover, but unlike other restaurants in the area, I did not have to hawk them down for a straw or refill. This is probably because we were the only diners in the place. But still. It was awesome.Drinks - the tea was hot and delicious! Very aromatic as well. My friend ordered this huge alcoholic beverage that costed $$ but, but it was huge. She couldn't finish it herself but she really tried! It tasted just like the beach!Food - was pretty impressive! We ordered egg rolls, pot stickers, walnut shrimp, and general tao's chicken. * Egg Rolls- I have definitely had better, but they were still great. It is kind of hard to screw up egg rolls, especially in Chinatown, but again, I have had better. I think the problem I had was that these did not seem as juicy as others I have had. Like, there wasn't any juicy shrimp or chicken or pork inside. the meat was dry. But still good. 3 stars.*Potstickers - hands down the BEST potstickers in Chinatown. period. 5 stars. Talk about juicy! These were not all the way fried. They were lightly fried, so mostly steamed. Absolutely perfect! When mixed with the various sauces on the table...oh my gosh. Heavenly.* Walnut Shrimp - very tasty! The broccoli was on point! The shrimp were huge and plump! The sauce was very unique! Coconuty-mayo flavored but hard to explain. Paired with the candied walnuts...it made a very great dish. 5 stars.* General Tao's Chicken - was supposed to be spicy but it wasnt. The chicken to veggie ratio was not okay. 3 stars.I cannot wait to return next year after I have tried out all of the others!

38.description: I came here on a Sunday afternoon with my friend and her family, a total of 15 people I would say.  We were rather tight at the seating table and it made for a uncomfortable   eating experience.  The staff is OVERLY friendly and sometimes a bit hard to understand since the language barrier is pretty apparent.  The food was EHHHH and I stress that in a way that it just wasn't that good and we had a variety of food at the table, From Mongolian beef, to sweet and sour pork. The rice was a bit too sweet tasting and didn't have much going for it.  Crab ragoons were  mostly dough and very little meat filling.  DON'T even get me started on the sweet and sour pork I ate a few pieces and let's say it was like eating a piece of fat that was breaded and fried just terrible. we had a chicken chow-mein that was probably the only decent thing at the table but still made me a bit squimish when I ate it.  We order hamburgers for the kids at the table and they couldn't even it and we weren't mad the meat was just terrible!. Overall I did not dig this place the waitresses were a bit too pushy on ordering beer and the food just was a hot mess!! The only thing I did enjoy was the eggroll and fortune cookies.Def a place I won't go OUT of my way into Chinatown to check out

51.description: Go for the Dim Sum.  We have never really ever ordered from the actual menu.  Nice staff.. service is ok.

27.description: So, when I want to introduce my friends & family to the lovely world of Dim Sum, here's where I bring them. I've been a fan for over 20 years now.Why? Well, it is good, tasty food and a friendly place for a beginner to get acquainted with this different style of Chinese cuisine. The restaurant is not one of those huge, crowded open rooms with the metal carts crashing around. (I like that experience too, but it can be overwhelming at first.) It is a more intimate experience. The service is efficient and friendly with a cozy family restaurant vibe.The Dim Sum selection is not huge and exotic, but it is authentic and tends to focus on shrimp,seafood, chicken and pork. (They have the fun stuff like curried squid and chicken feet, too.)Also, you just order your choices from the Dim Sum menu (with pictures!) and they bring you what you want, hot and fresh from the kitchen. The fried items are just right, not greasy or lukewarm, like at some other places I've been.The Lotus Rice is excellent with large portions!  In my constant search for the perfect egg roll, they are in my all time top 5 list.

32.description: The food was super salty totally disapointed with service and food. One good thing cookies were very good.

54.description: I really like Won Kow.  I think they have really good Chinese food.  Their service was fast and the waitresses are nice.  Sometimes when it is busy on the weekends, then the service is not the greatest though but I can understand that with being a busy time to come eat.  I'm a fan but I've had better Chinese food around where I'm from.  Have had crab rangoon, fried wontons, vegetarian egg rolls, shrimp toast, Won Kow chicken rolls, cashew chicken, moo shoo chicken, orange chicken, sweet and sour chicken, butterfly shrimp, sweet and sour shrimp, shrimp and scallops with vegetables, chicken lo mein, shrimp lo mein, and egg foo young.  Definitely try them out but try other places too and don't be like me and keep going back to the same places because I'm sure there are a ton of good Chinese restaurants in Chinatown.

48.description: I think I'll always have a small spot in my heart for this dim sum place especially since it was the last place that we went to before I went to Hong Kong. The owner was from Hong Kong as well and I felt a sort of solidarity with her.However, upon return, my taste buds have gotten a lot more refined and I was disappointed with the turnip cake which tasted chalky and potatoe-y; the zong zi was also not very fresh but the shrimp dumplings (piece de resistance) were good!

44.description: This has been our go-to place for a number of years.  Our family has made it a tradition, since the kids were little, to go out for dim sum on New Year's (not Chinese NY) day.  We have tried other dim sum restaurants, but we like this old place--you climb a flight of stairs, there's a huge lit-from-behind photo of Hong Kong, and the tables have huge lazy susans in the middle. Very kid-friendly, fast service, reasonable prices. Unfortunately, it seems like every chef in the world  is on a cilantro kick.  A decade ago, you couldn't find many cilantro-seasoned dishes anywhere; now you're hard-pressed to avoid the flavor. Won Kow also has jumped on the cilantro bandwagon, and our experience there today was very disappointing. Some people don't mind the taste of cilantro, but some of us are sensitive to it and it really ruins the dish. (I've been told there's a genetic element to those of us who find that cilantro enhances, or destroys, a recipe.) It has a "soapy" flavor, and if it's in EVERYTHING, you can't just avoid selections that are likely to have it. You're really limited. My husband is not a picky eater, but he dislikes cilantro, and he was not able to tolerate several of his old standby dim sum choices today.The service was also weirdly slow, unusual for Won Kow. I think they were short-handed and had to call in reinforcements, because when we arrived, there was practically no one else in the place, and it took forever to get our food. Then, suddenly, they had enough servers.We always order a LOT of dim sum, but it occurred to us today that we never check what we actually get against the order sheet. That's usually not a big deal, but today it seemed like we were missing several dishes but had extras of food we don't remember ordering. Oh well...I guess you could be OCD and request a second order sheet and then check it against what you're served, but with a large party, that's tricky. I should note that the bathrooms are really old and dingy, but seem as clean as possible. I try to avoid them anyway. I doubt we'll be dining here again, unless someone discovers that cilantro is carcinogenic and everyone stops using it. Otherwise we'll seek out a more CHINESE place for dim sum.They will validate parking.

24.description: When I think of this joint, my head brims with nostalgia. My family has been coming here since I was a young lad! I doubt this place has changed in the last fifty years, as we love the tiki drinks, the same little old owner sitting in the coat room, and the tasty Americanized Chinese cuisine. You won't get Lao's authentic Chinese creations here, but that's cool, because sometimes you need that traditional, spectacular, American-Chinese fare. We don't bother with Dim Sum here, but stick to the delightfully tacky, General Tso's Chicken, Moo Shu Pork, Orange Chicken, Egg Rolls, and even Sweet and Sour Pork. Top it off with a Buddha Beer and a few Zombie cocktails and you have a party. Never change, Won Kow. Just don't bring grandma and grandpa here because they might struggle with the multitude of stairs...

7.description: Food is ok but don't come here for the service. We went for Dim sum. They were fairly busy but not overwhelmingly so. After we got a table no one came to take our order. So we had to chase down someone to put in our order. They brought over Tea, water and the food and took away the empty dishes but other than that we were mainly just ignored. Then we had to flag down someone to pay the bill and made sure we had exact cash so we don't have to wait. If you want Dim Sum I'd go with Ming Hin where the food and service are A+.

49.description: I enjoy this spot very much... Portions are huge-go hungry! This place is not fancy just a old school Chinese spot with great food. Cheers!

40.description: One of my favorite Dim Sum restuarants in Chicago. It's one of the cheapest and generous portion. Beef with wide rice noodles is what I used to have for late night snack in China.

53.description: I wish I could give this place zero stars. Or even negative stars. Despite my many trips to Chicago, I had never been to Chinatown. A family member recommended this restaurant (I guess he hates me). The food was disgusting. I ordered garlic chicken but it tasted as though it had been bathed in perfume first. The orange chicken was off, and the dish that the other members of our party had ordered tasted like pure salt.This leads me to the poor service. The waitress was incredibly unhelpful when it came to our questions about the menu. In fact, she was downright impatient and clearly didn't want to be talking to us. My order, according to the menu, was supposed to include a soup. When we asked the waitress, she just shook her head and said no. No explanation. So we asked again the next time she came over and she said my order didn't come with a soup, which made no sense since what I ordered clearly stated that it came with soup. At this point, I realized she had given me the wrong order, and I didn't want the soup anyway, given how nasty the main dishes were. I just wanted to leave. And leave we did. We did not tip. Maybe that was harsh, but given the food and the attitude of the waitress (and the disgusting, unclean bathroom), I didn't feel it was deserved. We got halfway down the stairs when another waitress came running after us, telling us we have to leave 10% gratuity! I couldn't believe the nerve of this woman. We told her we didn't have to do any such thing, and we left. Avoid this place like the plague. There are other places in Chinatown that are probably a million times better than this one.

30.description: My husband, kids, and I met some friends of ours here for dinner today.  I will not come back here again.... Not even if you paid me.  Service was fine... No issues.  The food.... That's another story.  We ordered egg rolls, pot stickers, BBQ spare ribs, and crab Rangoons.  I'm not going to say they were horrible, but I'm not going to say they were particularly good in anyway either.  The crag Rangoons had about 1 tsp of filling.My 4 year old daughter ordered milk, took a sip, and said it tasted "different".  I don't drink milk, but my husband tried it and said it was the worst milk he'd ever had.... Really sour.  I saw white little things in the milk.... Yuck!The main entrees were OVERLOADED with sauce.  Why do this other than covering up bad food?! I ordered a cheeseburger and fries for my kids to split... And share some of my food (they aren't totally into Asian food yet.  Baby steps).  The hamburger was definitely from the freezer, which I assumed it would be but it was COLD.  They had to take it back and all they did was microwave it.I  am sad because I really was excited for Chinese and now I don't want it for a long time My advise... Go anywhere else!

46.description: Been here 4x in last year.  First few times ended up at Won Kow because every other restaurant had huge wait lists.  And I don't want to wait for food.  Water, in an apocalyptic emergency, OK I'll wait.  But not much else.  Anyway, despite the lack of crowds and the overwhelmingly non-Asian diners, I was really pleased. So last Sunday I went there deliberately.  Not because I was forced to by the Sunday crowds at other dim sum joints.  But because I made a conscious decision to enjoy dim sum there.Anyway, with the exception of stir fried vegetable plates, I've only ordered off the dim sum menu.  All is better than good, especially the duck.   And, to my surprise, I actually like that there are no carts.  Whatever you order comes out piping hot as it has not traveled a half mile while cooling down at every stop.  Service is about par compared to other places.  Meaning so-so verging on indifferent.   Bathrooms are also on par with most Chinatown restos. In other words, kind of grim just like 80% of them on Archer, Wentworh, or Cermak.  In a perfect world, I endeavor not to use them unless it is absolutely necessary. Having said that, I will be back yet again

1.description: OH YEAH....DUMPLINGS.....MAI TAI VOLCANO BOWL...MONGOLIAN BEEF...AND REPEAT!!!!!!!!!!My Lord we love this place. This is a guilty pleasure place. Its Western Style Chinese, no doubt. It is also kind of a throw back with the dishware, the ambiance, and the food. Boy do we love those Mai Tai Bowls!!!! The steamed dumplings are so great, especially with the red vinegar and hot mustard sauce. The ladies running the show are also great, they laugh at us once we start over ordering the drinks, but its the way to go. Big round tables, bring your pals, have volcano bowl races (do you see where I'm going with this)?!?!?!!? We have a tradition a couple of times a year where we do a Chinatown crawl, and this is always ALWAYS our first spot!

55.description: BUYER BEWARE, IF YOU WANT TO GET SCAMMED, EAT HERE!  Owner knowingly gives out expired parking validation tickets...Really wanted to rate ZERO stars, but this system won't allow it.  Coming from the burbs, we called the restaurant to verify their parking situation.  The owner answered informing us that they offer a validated rate of $2 per 3 hours for patrons.  So we thought, cool let's park in the lot and eat there.  I was feeling foolishly nostalgic as my very own wedding shower was held here 15 yrs ago...There are many establishments to choose from in the area that serve the same food.  The entree food here was just average, the dim sum is NOT very good at all.  Sticky, grimy lazy susans and dirty water glasses, disgusting bathroom that I won't let my kids even wash their hands in...Tea isn't even free, there is a surcharge of $2 for tea.Finally, to top it all off, back to the parking situation:  so we bring our ticket to the owner up front to be validated per our waitress' prompting.  The older gentleman (owner) in speaking in Cantonese-English presumably to the "Chinatown Chamber of Commerce" about some parking validation tickets...(hmmmmm, what an awfully strange coincidence!  I will let you know that I'm of Asian descent, so I'm thinking now after the fact, that he probably thought I could understand him.  He staged the whole thing).  I ask him for validation for my parking and he hands me a validation ticket that expires 12/31/10.  He tells me this is what he received from the Chamber of Commerce and that it should work.  He goes on to tell me that I should just talk to the person at the parking lot and that they should accept it.  He tells me that he gives this ticket to everyone and that they don't come back to him (...really?  I wonder why not...), except for one customer...I tell him ( my mistake) that if this doesn't work I'm coming back for the difference because I had even called prior to deciding where we would eat and that we were assured that they validated parking...Fast forward...ticket (of course) doesn't work.  Guy at booth says he can't help because obviously ticket's expired (really?  what a surprise!)...I head back to the restaurant, owner now conveniently gone...and they call him and reach him on the phone, and instead of instructing his waitresses to refund the now $8 difference in parking (total parking bill $10 instead of $2), he says for me to wait because he may be back in a few hours!  They call his son (other owner) who says that it's not his issue---call owner.  OK, ENOUGH, REALLY.  You've now lost a patron who really only came for the economical food and parking...but if you can't even provide parking as you advertise and say (just don't advertise and say that you do)---the economical food which has decreased in quality over the years  really isn't worth it.  You can still get economical, hot food (yes, food not so hot when served...hmmmmm...) on the other side of Chinatown (the newer part) and much better dim sum at Cai. That really sucked...so not worth it.  Stick to Cai for Dim Sum and any other Chinese place in Chinatown for food.  If you want economical, you can get pretty good lunch box sized portions at Gourmet Food Inc just across the street--fresh, hot & honest.
