9.description: I started coming here in the early to mid 90's and quickly became a favorite until I was here on March 21, 2015 with my wife  for Dim Sum...the place hasn't changed since the 90's! except the service was almost nonexistent there was no Dim Sum cart service in the area of the restaurant they seated us, so everything had to be ordered from the picture menu and none of the Dishes had any of the flavors I grew up teasing from any of the 100's of Dim sum shops in NYC or this restaurant once had back in the 90's The place had Americanized the flavors from that of true authentic Chinese Dim Sum! If I wanted slow over priced Americanized Chinese food I'd go to any of The Pizza Hut chain Restaurants(aka Panda Express)!!!! I will never be coming back to restaurant again and never recommending this place ever  either!!

26.description: We have been to Won Kow before and the food is pretty good. However, I am truly disturbed by what I just witnessed as I'm sitting here at the table. A bus boy went to the 3 tables near us that had just been vacated by their diners, he went around and pulled cookies off the plates, some with partially eaten cookies sitting on top, he'd shake them off and place them on a new plate and then took them to the back. Then came back to continue clearing the table. He's handling dirty tableware, then grabbing un-eaten food with his bare hands with what appears the intention of serving it to someone else later. Based on that and my now thorough disgust, I will never return here again. Beware!

25.description: I have this place 5 starts because it's really hard to find authentic Szechuan Chicken. This place nailed it! Will have to return on my next Chicago  vacation!

12.description: This is heaven I might wanna just skrrrrrrt up here at 9am tomorrow and leave at midnight tomorrow night and just drink zombies all day and eat egg rolls and almond cookies The mai tai was strong and amazing but the zombie was like ridiculously delicious

59.description: That's right, people. One measly star. A rare and cataclysmic combination of events have to coincide and mingle in a hot mess of crappiness for me to give a Chinese restaurant 1 star. I mean, it's Chinese food. You can't expect too much. You know it will be greasy, slight salty, and service will be passable at best. But this place? I gave a higher rating to a restaurant where I found a bug in a dish.We ordered a small soup, General Tso's chicken, and beef chow fun (or foon, as they call it). Those basic dishes usually signal to me whether a place is decent. "Kind of salty," I commented to my companion after taking a first taste of each dish. But as I continued, the saltiness intensified, and soon I found myself eating more rice to dilute the salt or eat just the noodles in the chow fun. After forcing down a third of each dish, we gave up because it was simply too salty. Minus three stars. Check please! And to go boxes. Maybe I can salvage this at home. Our waitress brought the boxes and then the check. My fiancé stares at the check, a puzzled look on his face. First of all, there's an unexplained $0.40 charge. I figured maybe they up charged for the beef in the chow fun. But the weird part was the addition. Yelp challenge of the day:  $1.95 + $7.50 + $8.50 + $0.40 = ? Asians are NOT all good at math, at least not the dude manning the register at Won Kow. Somehow he came up with $20.30. In his mind, 5+0=0. And he added another $2 to the bill, just for fun. Or maybe to fund his Kumon lessons. We inquired about the extra charge and sent the check back. Apparently, they charge $0.20 PER BOX if you want to take your food home. Lame. Super lame.So the waitress returns with the revised check. Guess what? STILL wrong! Now it came to $18.30. 5+0 still equals 0. But we gave up and paid and left. Another star off for being stupid. The highlight of the meal was the hot tea and them playing Whitney Houston over the speakers. I miss her too, Won Kow.

21.description: A must try for any Chicagoan. We have been coming to Won Kow for many years, and, it is in fact the oldest Chinese restaurant in Chinatown, and for good reason. Won Kow offers a large menu, and unlike some restaurants, every item on their menu is delectable. The portions are large, and every time we go, we leave full, and with plenty to take home and enjoy later. The cocktails at Won Kow are especially great, and they are hand-prepared. Some of the cocktails are presented in large, ceramic bowls with tropical detail, and served with a flaming center. You get long straws so that you can drink from the large bowls without having to lean over the drink too, it's a very fun experience. When we have visitors in from out of town, we bring them here, and every time, they are blown away by the food. The service is outstanding as well, and David Hoy, the manager, is a warm presence, and generally goes from table-to-table to check on diners to make sure everything is to their satisfaction; he also makes the cocktails when he's there, which is very often. There are several dishes that my wife and I order repeatedly, like the Steamed Sole, which was first recommended to us by David. It is a whole fish, and it is prepared exquisitely well so that it is incredibly tender, and the bones pull out from it so you can just enjoy the meat. Depending on what your tastes are, there is something on their menu that you will love. The atmosphere is warm, with paper lanterns hanging from the ceiling, and the larger tables have lazy Susan's in the center so that food can easily be shared with the entire table. The soups are stellar, and the tea is great, and abundant. The clientele is very diverse, and with many regulars. The Sizzling Beef is extraordinarily good, as are all of the seafood and chicken dishes. I love their Cuttlefish dishes, which are truly delicacies. The wait staff is attentive, but doesn't bother you while you're eating. The prices are also outstanding considering the quality and size of the portions. We try to go here at least once a month, but sometimes we go weekly when we have the ability. We were there this past Saturday night, and as usual, left full, and with bags of food to bring home to eat later. This is a tremendous Chicago resource, and if you love Chinese food that is authentic and delicious, you absolutely have to try this place, you won't regret it. First rate!

17.description: the best food in chinatown i've been coming here for 40 years i have great memories here david the man who run the place is also great

10.description: We went here last Christmas and it was wonderful. We tried it again yesterday and had the exact opposite experience. The young hostess looked totally lost and had no idea what she was doing.  We were told it would be a 20 minute wait for a table even though there were plenty that were open. The wait turned out to be only 10 minutes.  We received glasses of water right away, but the waitress did not come by until 15 minutes later, and only because I got up to complain that no one was waiting on us. She took our order right away, but our drinks never arrived. Our appetizers came out right away, which was fortunate because we were famished. But still no drinks. A family of 4 was seated at one point near us and got their drinks and dinner before we did. We saw the older man who was tending bar leave that station and start seating people, leaving the wait staff to make their own drinks.  Our drinks finally arrived at what seemed like an hour after we sat down.  Our food showed up a half an hour after that. My dish was frozen cold in parts. Another of our party got the Chicken version of his dish instead of the Shrimp he ordered.  The place was not that busy to be this disorganized. We saw several parties get seated and then get up and leave because of the same inattentiveness. When I complained to the staff about the horrible service we were receiving, they acted like they didn't care, and muttered unintelligibly. Never going back.

5.description: We came here on a lunch break and were pleasantly surprised with everything. I always judge a place based on the siu mai and it did not disappoint. A little bit of a hike to get up to the restaurant but all in all a really great place. Also be aware that grabbing a taxi in Chinatown is a little more on the difficult side. Great thing this guy was willing to flip a u-ey lol.

3.description: I've been here three times, both very late, but I'm always treated very well. The food is very good and very fresh. The drinks are great and i always crave eating here. Very good and highly recommended! Parking is very close by too!

35.description: We had lunch here last Friday. We were the only ones there! All our food was good. Their egg foo gravy was spectacular! However, the Mai Tai lacked any rum what so ever. Long, long staicase up to the 2nd floor. i believe this is one of Chinatown's oldest restaurants.

19.description: I've been coming to Won Kow for almost fifteen years now. And not a thing has changed. Whether that's a good thing or not... I will say that the food is reliable and it's always very affordable. Love the egg rolls here! The entrees are big, the drinks are frilly and it's a great place to pop into on a weeknight (not busy). If you're in the area, give Won Kow a try.

28.description: The oldest Chinese restaurant in goes Chinatown, it opened in 1928. Al Capone frequented Won Kow restaurant, he sat at the table in the front corner near the window. There are many interesting stories here, along with good food and great service! Be sure to have a good appetite when you come here portions are large and most customers take-home plenty of leftovers. Good egg rolls that are crisp without being greasy.The food is served hot and is displayed well on the platters. They are open at nine in the morning for dim sum and stay open until 10:00 PM Sunday through Thursday, on weekends they are open until 12.

45.description: I've honestly had great experiences with the food at this place. I mean, the place needs to be updated, but the food is great! I love their Orange Chicken and their Sa Tae Chicken is amazing. Service is not bad, and the prices are affordable. I don't know why people are giving this place such a low rating? Their food is great in my opinion.

33.description: Amazing dim sum, and great service. I'm not a fan of Americanized Chinese, and prefer the more traditional stuff. If you're like me, Won Kow for dim sum is the place to go. Everything is fresh and delicious!

43.description: Hunger overtook me, and I just chose the first restaurant I laid my eyes on. Boy I wish I looked further down the street. The staff is actually very friendly and attentive, actually a bit much as she was clearing the plates a little too quickly moving things over on to other plates that I might not have chosen to add together. Dim sum is ordered from a sheet here where you can check of what you want in the quantity that you want. I have always liked the traditional style of the carts. We ordered items for a family style lunch in addition to dim sum items. The dim sum items were overcooked. All the steamed items were so soft that it was mushy to the touch and taste. The lunch food items were too salty for my taste. I think the chef is kind of heavy handed on that end. The prices were reasonable, but not for the quality of food for me. Overall, I felt really unhappy about having eaten here like I wasted space in my stomach for less than mediocre food. I guess it helped with not overeating.

2.description: This is my third time here. I come once a year and have dim sum and a Mai tai. Very quiet place. Great dim sum.

18.description: Best Chinese food in China town  the fresh crab Cantonese style very tasty also can't go wrong with the dinner for two u start off with with dumplings soup with a lil hot sauce tasty also u get ribs ,egg roll , & fried shrimp then for meal u get a combo won kow ,shrimp kun po & shrimp fried rice  & white rice more than enough for two ppl doggy bag for sure the tea with almond cookies & fortune cookies  not bad at all with out breaking the bank under $30 definitely good stuff cheaper than ur neighbor hood delivery place and great atmosphere

41.description: Cons...wish main portions were bigger and they had no coffee even when shown on menu.Pros.....good food. Deep fried shrimp roll, potstickers, shrimp fried rice, mangolian beef, sweet sour chicken, and I think it's called happiness plate, were all delicious!!! Service was fast, enjoy the center lazy suzie, and complimentary hot tea. Great prices. Family atmosphere.

52.description: Won Kow holds a special place in my heart as it was my grannys favorite restaurant and we came here almost every year for my birthday and she would let me get a Shirley Temple. This place has been around FOREVER.I think the food is good, nothing earth shattering and I have never had anything bad. Portions are huge. Cocktails are cheap. Get the VOLCANO sized Mai-Tai!I like the decor...super cheesy...makes you feel like you walked into a bad karate movie and a fight scene will break out at any minute.Great place for groups. Prices are reasonable. Lots of stairs to climb to get to the restaurant. They also validate parking and I have never had any problems with that.

50.description: Antique and outdated place good for drunk days.This is the oldest restaurant in Chicago Chinatown. It felt like one. The lighting sucked and the service was barely decent. The food was okay, I have had better Chinese food. With so many other options in Chinatown, I'd explore other place before I'd go here again :- |Thumbs up:1. History: the oldest continuously running restaurant in Chicago's Chinatown2. Location: easily accessible from the Red LineThumbs down:1. Food: Mundane and bland2. Service: could be improved. Asking what people need in regular intervals helps?3. Lighting: it feels like we are eating in a dungeon ;)

4.description: Great food. Been coming here since I was a kid. Never disappointed. The stairs are a bit of an obstacle but worth the climb. The must haves are the egg foo young, fried rice and egg rolls. If this is your first time in Chinatown then this is the most go place. Friendly staff, large menu and affordable.

6.description: Last time I went to china town, I went to a restaurant that had really good ratings but unfortunately I wasn't that satisfied because I didn't really know what to order. Thankfully this time I went with someone who knew what to get. We obviously had to get their egg rolls-because come on now who doesn't love egg rolls? And I'm glad we did because they were yummy! I was craving beef so I ordered the Kung pao beef. It was good but I've definitely had better. We also got orange chicken. I liked how crispy and fresh it tasted. Not enough rice was given to us though. Overall, yeah it was good food so I'd go again. The service was good as well. We went on a Wednesday so wasn't busy at all.

22.description: Absolutely the nastiest Chinese food I have had in years. Ok the food was was OK (but cold),  but the service, the ambiance, the cleanliness of the restaurant wasn't absolutely rock bottom. I can only suggest that if you do wish to eat there, you pick any other restaurant in Chinatown, because in doing so you know that you will not have the worst food you can eat. Just one more thing the egg drop soup that really was terrible.  And to the restaurant owners, if the soup you serve is terrible and if the people politely ask for something in exchange, I highly recommend that you offered to do so, as a $2 cup of soup is far less costly then an angry customer at the end.

15.description: When I think of this joint, my head brims with nostalgia. My family has been coming here since I was a young lad! I doubt this place has changed in the last fifty years, as we love the tiki drinks, the same little old owner sitting in the coat room, and the tasty Americanized Chinese cuisine. You won't get Lao's authentic Chinese creations here, but that's cool, because sometimes you need that traditional, spectacular, American-Chinese fare. We don't bother with Dim Sum here, but stick to the delightfully tacky, General Tso's Chicken, Moo Shu Pork, Orange Chicken, Egg Rolls, and even Sweet and Sour Pork. Top it off with a Buddha Beer and a few Zombie cocktails and you have a party. Never change, Won Kow. Just don't bring grandma and grandpa here because they might struggle with the multitude of stairs...

57.description: Bad tofu, bad service. Decent atmosphere.

20.description: Best Chinese food in China town  the fresh crab Cantonese style very tasty also can't go wrong with the dinner for two u start off with with dumplings soup with a lil hot sauce tasty also u get ribs ,egg roll , & fried shrimp then for meal u get a combo won kow ,shrimp kun po & shrimp fried rice  & white rice more than enough for two ppl doggy bag for sure the tea with almond cookies & fortune cookies  not bad at all with out breaking the bank under $30 definitely good stuff cheaper than ur neighbor hood delivery place and great atmosphere

36.description: While I can't say I've ever had their dim sum, I've had a lot of their chicken dishes and have never been disappointed.  I love their fried rice.  Good flavors, healthy portions, reasonable prices.  Definitely one of the highlights of China Town in Chicago.

14.description: The oldest Chinese restaurant in goes Chinatown, it opened in 1928. Al Capone frequented Won Kow restaurant, he sat at the table in the front corner near the window. There are many interesting stories here, along with good food and great service! Be sure to have a good appetite when you come here portions are large and most customers take-home plenty of leftovers. Good egg rolls that are crisp without being greasy.The food is served hot and is displayed well on the platters. They are open at nine in the morning for dim sum and stay open until 10:00 PM Sunday through Thursday, on weekends they are open until 12.

1.description: Went here looking for a wok...though they had a decent selection I didn't see the same one I saw at Woks 'n' Things down the street.  The selection though was about half of what the other store had.  Sunlight's prices did seem slightly better on most things, though.They had an extensive selection of all things kitchen and food prep...pots, pans, dishes, utensils, trays, ...pretty much anything you might find in a restaurant was here and cheap.

0.description: What a spectacular find!  Like most things in Chinatown, you have to work your way through this place...and who's to say if the EXACT item you need will be here after hunting several very tall aisles. The lady in charge when I went didn't know specifically what they had, but instantly knew what it cost when she saw it!   In my case, as well as any owner of a Pyrex 9x13 baking pan, this trip was a major score.  They have a $6 10x18 pan grate that fits snugly secured to the handles of the pan so you can roast meats as drippings fall 2" into the Pyrex.   Also, the same "Winco" brand has a grate which fits inside the same glass Pyrex pan.  If you want to elevate a small roast inside the 9x13, this $4 grate fits perfectly too.  This stuff isn't easily found...just saying.

1.description: This gift shop sells a lot of martial arts goods.  Don't let your enemies know about this store!

0.description: Okay, so I haven't been here in years, but this is one of the most awesome shops in Chinatown to wander around and peruse the merchandise, because they have WEAPONS here.Like everything from the wooden bokken to the real training swords with the string that acts as the blade so you can practice your kendo to shelves and shelves of pocketknives.  They've even got nunchucks (the real and the training ones - and I think they have the three-link nunchucks too)!  They've also got some nice sets of swords with little holders/stands, too.So what was my purchase?  A cane-sword.  You know, it's a sword hidden inside a cane, I guess so you can walk around looking all feeble and then if some punks accost you on the street, you can unscrew the cane and whip out the sword and do some "self-defense".  Unless they brought guns - you should never bring a sword to a gunfight...Even better is that I selected the awesome type of cane sword that not only unscrews halfway down to become a sword, but it also unscrews at the top to be a dagger.  In case I wind up in a situation that requires stabbing/slicing people up with my sword and being able to main-gauche with the dagger.So yea, if you're as big of a dork as I am about weaponry, I recommend visiting this place.

29.description: What a surprise find! Came here on the recommendation of a friend for hotpot ingredients, they sure have a good selection of items, both prepackaged and from the meat counter. Even had a few items for tasting, which is rarely seen at Asian supermarkets. No wonder it was crazy packed. My only complaint were the bagged veggies, which weren't as fresh as I'd like (we ended up with a napa cabbage that's rotten in the core, not something you could check for when it's bagged). But the meat counter was reasonably clean, so I didn't feel squeamish buying from them.

42.description: Thanks to Vivian Y for her review of this place. I completely agree that this market is the best in the Chinatown area.  The location is off the strip of Chinatown but not hard to find. Its definitely accessible by the 62 archer bus.  They have a private lot so parking is free! One Star!The store is HUGE!!!! I was expecting to smell funky smells after reading some people's reviews, but this place didn't smell like fish or funky at all. If anything it smelled like a warehouse because it was so big and they have a ton of stuff here!  Lots of room to walk down the aisles and its not stuffy so you wont feel claustrophobic. One Star!Prices are cheap! Cheaper than Argyle or other stores in Chinatown! One Star!They have pre-made food that you can buy 3 for $10 or $3.99 each.  They didn't have a lot of options on a Saturday morning so I wasn't able to get a lot of variety.  I bought only the minced pork with salted vegetable and it tastes just like the stuff my mom would make when I was living back in SF. Delicious and affordable! i wish I had bought more! One Star!Lots of variety and many things to choose from! I got a little disoriented because I felt so overwhelmed by the choices! Definitely not something I'm used to in Chicago.  And being from San Francisco, I miss big grocery stores like Ranch 99. This is the closest thing I've seen in the Chinatown area! One Star!I have found my new go-to place for chinese stuff. Oh by the way, this place opens early. I was here at 8am on a Saturday morning! Hurray!

23.description: I was in Chicago for two weeks visiting from Seattle and had a hankering for at home hot pot.  My boyfriend & his crew (which who I was staying with) had never heard of hot pot or every really shopped in Chinatown -- so I had to outreach to my only other friend from Chicago, and this was the place he recommended.  Jackpot!It's not quite as big as I expected it to be, but it was bigger than any of the other Chinese grocery stores I went to in the area.  They had almost everything I wanted for my perfect personalized hot pot, including very delicious cut meat (beef, lamb, & pork).  I also enjoyed their dumpling bar (which I have never seen before).  Basically it's a bunch of frozen dumplings, beef balls, fish balls, ect.  They sell by the pound so you can mix and match -- though I don't completely recommend because it was hard to tell what was what later.    They also had a huge selection of hot pot base mixes, I went with my all time favorite - Little Sheep. yum yum!  They only had gas hot pots for sale here unfortunately (I was looking to buy an electric one, which I found elsewhere), but this will definitely be my first stop for Chinese groceries whenever I am in Chicago!

47.description: One of the best markets in Chinatown.  If you are not Chinese, you will not get used to the smell.  Luckily I am Chinese so the smell doesn't get to me :)  They have lots of fresh produce at cheap prices.  One thing I don't like though is that most the veggies are pre-bagged so you can't pick what you want, but at least they have the price tags on them so you know how much they cost.This place is huge, they have a large variety of sauces, spices, noodles, snacks, cookies, etc etc.  Lots of vegetarian items too.  I love the pre-packaged meat section - they have these great pre-marinated meat dishes that are $3.99-$4.99 regular price, and are on sale for 3 for $10.  I get these and freeze them, and have a wonderfully tasty, easy and cheap Chinese meal in minutes whenever I want!  I usually get the black bean spare ribs, ground pork with salted vegetables, or the lemon grass pork chops - YUM.  They also have precooked chicken and duck in the refrigerated area by the butcher.  There's usually a couple of stands giving away samples.  Oh, and buy $50 worth of groceries and you get a box of soy sauce chicken wings for free!  And parking!  It's not huge, but they have it!  And it's free, not pay.  During the Chinese holidays the parking lot can get packed, but just park on the street on 24th.  They have had a for lease sign out front for about a year, I really hope no one leases this because I love this market, I hope it never leaves!

8.description: Was looking for some sushi rice and some NON-GMO* chicken and I am not sure about this place. I was able to find some good rice. The price was modest, but that chicken I brought. I had it sitting in the fridge for one day and it was a very bad quality of meat. Was spoiled by the time I got ready to cook it. I will get my rice and drinks from there, but anything else is a no go. Will be back again, but for dry items only.

31.description: This store had a wonderful selection of ingredients for Asian cooking just as described in the search on Yelp. There was plenty of customer service and I will return again.

34.description: They carry all kinds of asian cooking ingrediants and supplies. I came here recently to stock up on my snack supplies and to buy some groceries. It has a big parking lot, great variety of items, and decent prices. It certainly is one of the biggest Chinese markets in the South Loop.

16.description: If you want to have your own hot pot at home, this is the place. Basic, plentiful and they have their own parking lot. Plus, sometimes they offer samples!

13.description: I absolutely love this place!!! They have everything! They need bigger carts though lol! I no longer go to other Chinese stores after I discovered this one.

11.description: Complaining about their greens. If you like to buy veggies once a week just like I do, this may NOT BE A GOOD PLACE for buying greens.They r too easy rotten. I bought some bean sprouts the day before yesterday, and I put them in the refrigerator as soon as I back home and they all rot away this morning.        Worse is, they DO NOT have ANY sell by information on their package so I just thought they would be able to stay in the fridge as the bean sprouts I bought from other markets. But they are not.        Similar things happened with the okra I bought from their market.        Well I have concerned that may be they have less chemical stuffs in the veggies, which means they are more organic than other markets I used to shop, so I gave them 3 stars instead of less. But it could also because their stuffs r not so fresh. And by all means, they should have some sell by information on the package, isn't it?         Besides, this is still a good place for shopping other Non easily rotten stuffs.

39.description: OK - Perspective time.1. From a Chicago point of view: Hong Kong Market is the best out of all of the Chinese grocery stores in the Chinatown area - hands down.  More square footage, larger aisles, better selection of vegies, better frozen section, better choice of groceries altogether, and they are next to an L stop, not to mention parking!It is also cleaner and more organized than the one's in Chinatown.What they lack...an inhouse BBQ station, a Chinese Bakery, they need a bigger selection of meats, and would do well to sell fresh live poultry, and live seafood (didn't see any live lobster on this particular visit).2. From a Montreal, Toronto, Vancouver, NYC (Queens), San Francisco point of view: this is small time and does not hold water versus some of the bohemouths in the Chinese grocery market world.  From this perspective I am disappointed at the selection for all the hype it gets on Yelp.  I've seen reviews describing this place as HUGE...in reality it's not that big.  In the end, I would go back to HKM without question...until I find something better.  I think a lot of Chinese / Asians from the cities I mentioned would find HKM a little disappointing vs what they have in their hometowns.

37.description: I don't usually buy a lot of chinese grocery items but I do go through phases where I cook on a wok and need things like dark soy sauce or cooking rice wine that are hard to find in the local supermarket.  Rest assured you will find them here, with tons of options and insanely low prices.  They carry all the good name brand (Chinese) versions of the various sauces you need for cooking.  Less than $2 for giant bottles of dark soy sauce, oyster sauce, etc.  Even the chicken breast, which was at least as good as what jewel carries, was really really cheap.  Something like $2-$3 a pound.  If you cab it down there you may want to call one to pick you up before you check out.  Not many in this area.

0.description: This is the best chinese grocery store in Chicago. They have a wide selection of things, even live fish!

38.description: I love Hong Kong market! They have cheap seafood, my son's favorite Japanese sodas, coconut buns, vegan food in the frozen section, and some of my British favorites, like digestives. Yumm. The staff have been really nice and super helpful to me.

51.description: My wife and I had heard about this place and we drove around trying to find it without any success. This time we tried again and we knew it was near Connie's Pizza - well, finally found it behind Connie's Pizza. We also never noticed that huge sign on the building next to Connie's.Its no H Mart, its no Ranch 99 or other big Chinese super market, but its bigger and better than the other markets in the south side Chinatown. Not sure on prices, but its nice to see so much Chinese stuff in one place. Do people even know this place exists? So much untapped potential.

27.description: There's so much space here! At least/especially compared to the cramped tiny stores near and in Chinatown square. It's so nice to be able to push a cart through the place comfortably and browse their selection! I wouldn't know exactly how well the prices compare, but for the shopping experience, I'd come here. I do believe their selections are similar. Maybe this has more, maybe it's just an illusion. There's definitely more bulk items for sale here laid out in big bins, like green and yellow beans and different types of dates, etc, something the other smaller grocery stores don't have as much luxury of space to supply. If you had to rely on public transportation to get to Chinatown, I wouldn't recommend walking from the Chinatown red line stop. It's about 10-15min one way, and that's not bad. But the sidewalks get really narrow, and at some point it reaches an area with an eerie abandoned feel. I'd drive there, especially on a gloomy day. Or maybe take a bus to nearby.

32.description: this place  is great! i came here with my parents when they were visiting (they're from  the detroit area) and they were both pretty ecstatic about both the products and the prices. it's not the biggest selection, but it had everything my mom was looking for. some of the stuff was just insanely cheap. my mom definitely stocked up.the service sucks though. i guess that's the be expected in all chinese grocery stores, so i'm not really complaining. anyway, if you're choosing from a bunch of places in this area, i think this is the one!

54.description: Best prices on Chinese produce amongst Chinatown and Arglye markets.  Huge selection of frozen Asian goods including Costco-size packages of frozen dim-sum items (ie: buns, dumplings, sticky rice "tamales," etc).  No live or fresh seafood available - all frozen.  Clean, large and easily-accessible parking.

48.description: Though there are many supermarkets in Chinatown, this is one of the few with parking. Richwell Market has parking as well, but is more out of the way since is is further North on Canal Street. Hong Kong Market has a good selection of frozen food especially dumplings. It also has a nice selection of noodles and Chinese spices and sauces. The market also sells its one of a kind pre-packaged dinner entrees like lemon pork chops, black bean marinated short ribs, and more all for the cheap price of 3 for $10. The meals are enough to feed 2 people and is easy to heat up/cook. This is a great alternative to ordering out. It is much cheaper, healthier, and convenient since it is prepared right in the comfort of your home. I would like to rate this market higher, but I have noticed that the market consistently sells expired products. The market puts these expired products on sale hoping to sell them, but legally is not allowed to. The products look extremely old and some non edible. Just avoid the sale sections or look at it to get a good legal laugh. Besides the expired items their vegetables, meats, and seafood are not as fresh as those sold in the markets that are actually in Chinatown. Because of the high demand from customers buying from markets in Chinatown those markets are constantly getting fresh produce, meats, and seafoods. Interesting Fact - At times the supermarket offers samples to the customers. Take advantage and try out the products. So far I have tried out dumplings, sea cucumber, and noodles.

44.description: Just came here once for the stuff for hot pot. I was surprised at how large the market was, with lots of selections. The prices here seems to be lower than Richwell & chinatown markets.

24.description: After reading some various yelp reviews, I decided to try this place for my Asian groceries. The place was not as big nor had as many items as I thought it would have. Granted it was clean, but not very inviting. I guess I'm just spoiled with other Asian supermarkets that I've been to. My roommate mentioned that sriracha prices were a little higher than places on argyle street. The selection of meats is very sparse as well, couldn't find the beef section.

7.description: I always go to this grocery store because it is the closest from my house AND it has a free parking lot. I love the fact that they have a great selection of many food. They even have their small BBQ and roasted station where you can get your roasted duck or bbq pork and etc. The only thing they don't have is fish that you order from the tank (live fish).This is also THE best spot to get your hotpot ingredients. The best.

49.description: Love this place.  I am from NY area and Chicago is not NY and HK market is the cloest thing you can find around here with some descent selections of chinese groceries.

40.description: Important note: this place is closed on Tuesdays. Walking back to car in disappointment now while typing to warn anyone on their way. Will try later.

53.description: I think this is the best Chinese market in Chinatown.  I believe they used to only be a wholesaler for restaurants and stores, but now they opened it up to the public last year some time.  :) They have a larger variety of goodies than Richwell does, and everything seems less expensive.  So if you're looking for some produce, frozen stuff, and Chinese snacks,  I'd suggest coming here.  :)

30.description: When I don't feel like dealing with the disorganized chaos that is Chinatown Market, I head to Hong Kong Market because they carry an even wider selection of items and more importantly SPACE than other markets out there. HK Market offers the usual items that you'll find at an Asian supermarket. There are butchers offering all cuts of meat and other parts you didn't know existed. There's fresh fruit, produce, frozen and canned items, ramen and all that good stuff. I usually come here because A) it's closer B) MORE space...did I mention there's MORE SPACE? The customer standard is pretty standard and there's a large parking lot outside the store as well. Hit this place up.

46.description: I'll keep it simple:Long beans, "live" lobsters for $11.50, squab, quail, pork spleen, soft shelled crab, sake. If this list means anything to you then HKM is worth a visit.By the way, we thought it smelled OK.

1.description: If you're seeking authentic asian groceries, Hong Kong Market is your best bet from fruit, vegetables, fresh meat, hot pot ingredients, sauces, and all kinds of snacks for your favorite niece and nephew.First off, beware of the parking lot, if you can call it that. The painted lines are marked for Fiats or the original Mini Cooper, not the suburbans and minivans that populate so much of the area. Now that you've been warned, you'll probably laugh at the size of the shopping carts. They're the size of those kids shopping carts at Jewels and Marianos, but a little taller. It's a bit funny. [Insert asian joke here.]Prices are reasonable for the wide range of items you'll find. Frozen goods like dumplings are a good buy as are the fresh produce. There's a nice variety of tea and asian drinks.The fresh cut BBQ pork, duck, etc. is hit or miss. Sometimes it's excellent, but then there are other times that the cut that you get is 80% fat, chewy, or not suitable for anything outside of fried rice which defeats the point.So it's a bit scattershot, but if you don't want to hunt all over Chinatown for that particular sauce you're looking for or some instant ramen at a good price, then head over to HKM. Just don't expect H Mart.

9.description: This is not a great place to shop if you are looking for produce. While they have a huge section of grocery and frozen foods, the produce section is extremely limited. I've had a hard time finding ginger and garlic the past couple times I've gone. GINGER. AND GARLIC.Otherwise, great spot with delicious BBQ and wide variety of meats and fishes.

26.description: I couldn't understand most of what was written on the products, but the people there were so nice and helped me (ones who understand English) and helped me get the items I needed. Plus, the guy who helped me get bean sprout let me have them for free.

25.description: I shopped here at least once a week . The price is little bit lower than other Chinese market , the main advantage this store has is free and plenty of parking .

12.description: Free parking lot? I'm listening...All the Asian snacks/cooking ingredients I've been craving? I'm putting on my shoes...Aisles that fit more than one person at a time? I'm getting in the car...Prices that beat all the other Chinatown markets? I'm on my way...Free samples? I'm so there.

21.description: If you want to have your own hot pot at home, this is the place. Basic, plentiful and they have their own parking lot. Plus, sometimes they offer samples!

17.description: First time at this market and it's a lot bigger than the other ones in Chinatown. Good selection of all the goods I'd be looking for at an asian grocery store. They also have a butcher with lots of meat and a big selection of anything you can think of. They also have roasted chicken and such. Great place to get hot pot stuff! Will definitely be coming back when I need groceries. A gem :)

10.description: Whole duck, fresh durian, and a parking lot. There's always things to discover in this larger market. If there is some obscure sauce, roast meats, frozen foods or snacks, this is a good place to go.  The parking lot was quite busy Saturday evening, so be ready to do the car tango.

5.description: Chinese hot pot deluxe meal for two?  Sounds fantastic.  But do you know what's more fantastic?  You can make it $7.50/person.  Just so you know that some Chinatown restaurants will charge you $20/person even though it's AYCE...worth it?  I don't think so.  After all, you can't beat the comfort of dining at home.  Hong Kong market can make your dream come true, especially when it comes to making a hot pot feast.  My hubby made the first trip to get the meat (pork and beef), bok choy, string beans, tofu, and mushrooms.  He got a TON of meat and everything came to $30.  We made the first "basic" hot pot and gave him some suggestions for our next feast.  We went to Hong Kong Market together today and got an assortment of milk fish balls, bean sprouts, beef tripe, fried tofu, clams, and some other essentials.  We also got the spicy soup base.  The total this time was $30 as well.  We didn't finish everything; there's enough to do this at least one (1) more time...not kidding you!  So what did I think about Hong Kong Market?  Very reasonably priced; has lots of frozen essentials for Asian cooking; credit cards are welcome.  If you don't know Chinese as a language, you may have some difficult time figuring out some items you may not be familiar with.  My hubby was the only Caucasian in the store...just in case you're curious.If you take public transportation, it's ten (10) minutes walking distance from CTA Halsted Orange line.  Once you exit, head north and stay on Archer and then turn onto Wallace until you see a big, factory-like building.  The entrance is within the parking lot.

3.description: They have rearranged the space a bit and it's better. A little more open feel to it and they even have a price scanner now (up with the times here). They did hire more Mandarin speaking cashiers. I can understand a little, but mostly I'll probably just nod.

35.description: This place is the largest in the area and the best anywhere on the South Side. Great prices and variety as well. I go every other month and stock up on the essentials. I suggest looking at the Chinese vegetables as well, they are usually fresh and very tasty. Go. You won't be sorry.

19.description: Great deals and great stuff ... Can't beat that!!! Compared to other Asian markets this place has it all at a much better price. The selection and diversity is great and everything looks so fresh. This is my market place of choice from now on!!!

28.description: This is my go to Asian grocery market. Why? Because you can actually shop here even when it is crowded, unlike the ones in Chinatown. This place is a lot bigger than the other Asian markets in Chinatown, but for all you people who are comparing it with the ones on the west coast, it obviously isn't going to be that big. If you want big, go to the burbs and hit up H Mart. I mainly come here because I live right by here and it has everything that I need.The employees here are helpful and they helped us look for sushi mayo when we asked them. We asked one guy and he wasn't sure, but he asked another guy who directed us to it. Good luck with finding any type of service with the markets in Chinatown. They have a parking lot, but it gets crowded and it could be frustrating depending on the day and time you are there. My other complain is that the lines get so long and it moves really slow. Other than that, no complains about this place.

45.description: This place is a get in get what the hell you need and get out type of place. No frills, no fuss, no problem. The selection is respectable. Is it the biggest the Asian Market that I have ever come across? The answer is no, but by no means is it the smallest. The veggies are fresh and I love there hot pot meats. They also have a decent selection of dumplings and dried items such as fungus and  fish. I also like their prepackaged meals, just take them home and stem or fry them up. I was a little shocked to find that they didn't have fresh seafood. All of the fish was frozen. This can be a good or bad thing some people go looking for fresh, but if you are a bulk shopper as I am and end of freezing some of your catch anyway this is really not an issue. The bottom line is this place as more positives than negatives. It's clean and not to cramped like some of the other places in Chinatown. I can't say enough about how nice it smelled compared to some of the other places in Chinatown. So if you can find it give it a try

33.description: I come here regularly for groceries since I live in the area. They are well-equipped and have helpful staff. This one time I had trouble finding the dried black beans and the staff who was doing a sample bar helped me find it. However, I was quite dismayed that the bag says dried black beans in English, but the Chinese said dried black olives. It really wasn't what I was looking for. Some of the downs is I noticed some expired goods a few years back. Not sure if they kept up with this. I definitely respect this place for having a parking lot and reasonable price for most goods.

43.description: This place is big. The stuff are pretty organized; from frozen buns to rice balls (oh those pearls from Kimbo are heavenly) to herbal stuff, and fresh produce. There are overhead signs that walk you from one spot to another but sometimes they are not the right signs and they seem to only make sense in "Engrish."  The produces are nicely pre-packaged and set for display. Sometimes the portions are pretty big. The pricing are usually reasonably priced or cheaper than Chinatown, so that makes up for sometimes larger portions. Meat- nice cuts of pork and chicken. There are those pre-packaged specialty meats. Their Lemongrass porkchop is to die for. They're on sale for 3 for $10. (I think it's been the same price for many years now.) They have their seafood in the little display-counter right next to there they package the meat. I think the frozen stuff (i.e. fish- Yellow Croaker, shrimp, fishballs and dumplings) are the cheapest and "freshest" of Chinatown. Every time I'm there, there is always someone filling up a freezer somewhere. Side note- If you like almond cookies, I would buy a box from HKM. They make them fresh in the back somewhere. It's 100 cookies for 5 or 6 bucks. Pretty good price for fresh almond cookies. Though when the customer fill into the store, there can be a bit of a traffic jam when people inside decide to "double park" in the middle of a busy intersection with their carts! They have a P.A. system which consist of (I think) one megaphone that has been overclocked and volume-boosted. It doesn't help when whoever uses it screams into it. I think I saw someone else comment on the smell at HKM. I think it's better than most supermarkets in Chinatown, where the stench of fish tackles you. I feel like their stench lies somewhere in their freezer(s) maybe. Outside- It's a big parking lot with about 15/20 space or more. There is a lot of truck traffic to when people drop off inventory or pick up almond cookies. Once the 15/20 spots fill up, you have to either wait around for someone to move or park on the street, which is no biggie. It's like Chinatown, your horn is useless. The horn is a toy when it comes to Chinatown and Chinese people fighting over a spot.

2.description: OOH Hong Kong Market you drop the ball on " Chinese New Years" roasted pork and bbq pork. On day where supply is demand you let the quality of your roasted pigs. The bbq pork which is usually moist and delicious but today it was not edible we had to chew and spit it out. The flavor well was no flavor really. The roaster pork belly that is usually meaty and the skin is crispy but today it was ALL FAT and no crispy. I am very disappointed. Perhaps the new owners of Hong Kong market thought it was okay to supply the demand and forget about the quality of the roasted meats. I will not order from them again during Chinese New Years. Bad really really bad!

18.description: I was a big fan of the Peking duck and this market until I realized they had charged me separately for two ducks and two chickens when I got one of each... $17.  I realized when I got home, went back, tried to explain with receipt, no resolution.  The way it went down is not an honest mistake, the way it was handled was not an honest experience.  I had been socializing this place... great food, but this was a bad deal, I'll leave them behind and send to BBB.  Be advised.

41.description: love this place so much , nice workers too!

52.description: Good bye, Chinatown MarketGood bye, Mayflower IncGood bye, RichwellHELLLOOOOOO Hong Kong Market!4 stars for the store, 1 extra star for their prepared salt baked chicken!I'm Chinese.  I eat Chinese food.  I cook Chinese food.  It took me almost 4 damn years to learn about this grocery store that is one mile from my house and now I'm PISSED that I didn't find it sooner.  Michelle E. had made mention of this place several times but because it's not in the heart of Chinatown, I always forgot to check it out.  Today, I took a smart pill and remembered!I was skeptical driving along Archer just West of Canal and I see a sign "best and biggest supermarket in Chinatown".   They weren't kidding - cuz they are!1.  Parking lot - ever since Chinatown Market lost their lease on the parking lot next to them, they saw me less and less.  It's ok though, I hate their crowded  aisle and small produce choice anyway.  HKM has their own private lot and street parking also. I imagine it's crazy busy on the weekends so I'll just try to come here on a weekday.2.  I love making my own hot pot in the winter and love gathering my friends to enjoy this yummy broth. All this time, I thought the only place in Chinatown that sells the thinly sliced hot pot style cuts was Mayflower.  And Mayflower sucked - their meat was always stacked in a very sloppy way and most often, their meat looked freezer burned.  But I thought it was my only option. NOW I KNOW - that Hong Kong Market has a small freezer section DEDICATED to thinly sliced meats FOR HOT POT.  The meats are brightly colored and neatly stacked in a styrofoam dish.  I'm begging for JUST ONE MORE COLD DAY this year so that I can have my friends over for hot pot now!3.  Richwell Market - you're so close, but I never really liked you that much.  Your produce is hit or miss but I do like your seafood section.  Perhaps I'll come and visit your aquariums when I can't find what I need at Hong Kong Market.4. Hong Kong Market - clean, no frills - Obvious focus on rodent control as seen with all the traps in their parking lot.  I think it's a good sign of hygiene.Best part about Hong Kong Market is that they have a VALUE ADDED food section - basically, you can get raw pork ribs already marinated in black bean sauce in a box that you take home to steam and it will be ready for dinner.  That's just an example. They also had salt rubbed chicken (that is true yummy Hakka cuisine), steamed fish with ginger, beef tenderloin with black beans etc.  I haven't seen this in ANY other market in the Chinatown area.No, it's NOTHING fancy like Mitsuwa or Super H, but it's definitely gone to the top of my list for Chinese groceries.  Prices are on par with all the other Chinese groceries in the area.***UPDATE***1 star upgrade!I just had the salt baked chicken (this is REAL hakka food!!) and it was SUPER DUPER delicious!  Hakka food is regional (my family is Hakka) and SO hard to find in Chicago - I never expected to find it here!  You can buy it prepared so all you have to do is pop it in the microwave for 2 mins and its ready!  HOWEVER, if you want to prepare this the correct way, use this recipe to make the dipping sauce:Scallion / Ginger dipping sauce.3 parts minced scallions1 part minced gingerput all together in a small rice bowlsprinkle with a pinch of salt and white pepperheat up 5 tablespoons of vegetable oil till hot but not smoking and pour it over the mixture (this infuses the flavors of the scallions and ginger into the oil)It's delicious! My husband loved it! I'll be buying it often!  Find it in near the butcher against the wall in the white plastic flatbox containers.

50.description: I went to this market this Sunday because I had a sudden urge to make dumplings. And after reading reviews of Asian grocers near the West Loop, I chose to bike myself over and buy some pork, napa cabbage and dumpling skins.This place is really tucked away behind Archer. I guess with a car it's easier to find, but by walking/pub trans/biking, it took me a while. But that isn't why I gave it only 3 stars.Coming from Jersey which has a decent amount of asians living among the suburban sprawl, I'm accustomed to well lit, clean, and large asian grocery stores. Hong Kong Market is quite the opposite, it was dark, smelly, pretty small since half the building is blocked for inventory storage (only blocked off by shelves and not by an actual wall). The meat department was okay, looked a little sketchy the way it was set up, but I did buy pork from them and I ate it cooked and I'm still alive. There was no seafood section, and they mostly carried a lot of frozen stuff covered with frost. The vegetables were in good shape though.As far as their canned/bottled selection, it was just mediocre. I will most likely try other Asian grocers after coming here.

4.description: This is about as good as it gets for your Chinese markets. It's not entirely too sterile, but it still has that Chinese market feel to it. It's kind of more of a warehouse than a grocery store. But, they have pretty much anything you need. Oh, free parking and not overly crowded since it's far from the square!

6.description: I really liked this place, but I just stopped by tonight and found out they are closing. Some of the refrigerators have already been removed and most items are 30% off. Very disappointing since this had become my favorite Chinese grocery store in Chinatown.

22.description: Perfect supermarket for my hot pot dinner. Man, there were so many soup bases to choose from. We got the Szechuan spicy one which made everyone sweat. But they had all the dipping sauces, meats, seafood, and veggies. I also liked how much room there was in the store. One day I'll try the fresh scallops in the shell.

15.description: I would say this is one of the better Chinese grocery markets. Place is clean, there is a private parking lot, and it has a large selection.This is a good place to go for veggies, hot pot meats, meatballs, and basically any other Chinese groceries that you need.They also have Chinese BBQ on premise. They're BBQ pork is decent, the duck is good though. Can never leave here without getting something from the BBQ station.Basically this is your one stop shop for any Chinese groceries and cooking accessories in Chicago. My parents from Michigan always makes me bring them here when they come visit.

20.description: Free parking lot? I'm listening...All the Asian snacks/cooking ingredients I've been craving? I'm putting on my shoes...Aisles that fit more than one person at a time? I'm getting in the car...Prices that beat all the other Chinatown markets? I'm on my way...Free samples? I'm so there.

36.description: Hong Kong Market is the biggest chinese market in the Chinatown area! It offers a lot of stuff. On weekends, theres many samples to try! There is a good size free parking lot but its gets full quickly.

14.description: Bought a Case of Logan Berries for $20.88 Today. Got it home and my wife washed it and a colony of Black Ants came out all over our kitchen.When we tried to return it, they accused my wife of eating the berries.I let them have it.     We bought another case before this and it had mold in it and they put up a big fight to swap it out.The workers here are very rude.I'm Very Very pissed off right now. So, I am going to leave it at this.

29.description: Prices are very reasonable and the bread just great!!Been here several times now. Service is okay. Typical Chinese, I.e. Not the American or good 'ole Southern hospitality that I'm used to in the south where they ate so eager to help -- not to say they are not helpful!! Don't get me wrong! If you're an Asian or "egg-head" or "banana", you understand how the service is in Asian culture!!Will definitely go back again!!

42.description: I usually waddle over to this bakery after gorging myself on dim sum at Happy Chef. It's right across the way, and the pastries are pretty good!This bakery offers more savory options (which is perfect for me) - sticky rice and other non-pastry items along with the standard buns.Fair prices, and yummy egg custard tarts (what I normally go there for).

23.description: The pastries here are good, but the winter melon cakes are not so great.  These are my mom's favorite pastry, and I always buy them for her before I drive home.  I bought my mom 6 of them and she ate 2 and didn't eat the rest, so I haven't gotten them for her from here since then.  It's tough with the competition of the other bakeries in Chinatown, and this is just not my preferred one.

47.description: My favorite Chinatown bakery. Delicious things are as follows :Mango whipped cream cake, orange whipped cream cake, fruit cake, fruit tarts, fried sesame balls (red bean paste preferably), black sesame paste bun, BBQ pork bun (baked is better, the steamed is just alright), almond cookies, green tea cream cake, chocolate chip cookies, sesame balls, sticky rice ball with red bean paste, sticky rice in lotus leaf, whipped cream bun, coconut cream bun, chicken bun, curry bun, egg custard tart (mmmmmmm), chocolate whipped cream cake...What I'm trying to get at is that the selection is unbeatable, the food is tasty and the prices aren't bad. If you want to eat while you're there I believe they have menu as well and there's plenty of seating in the back, even if you just want to eat your slice of cake. You may not be able to communicate everything perfectly if you don't have any grasp of Cantonese, but I've never had them get an order wrong or be anything less than friendly.Captain, you have wooed me! I shall continue to sail your delicious seas of cake and cookies and baked buns.

8.description: Yes ... Good pastries & coffee to have while you are in rainy , chilly Chi town ! Right in the center of shop/walking in Chinatown ...

31.description: Thanks to Chicago yelpers, we were here last week to pick up egg custard and wintermelon cake.It was okay.

34.description: I usually get Chiu Quon's buns, but I thought I would try another bakery and see how it compared. Captain Cafe makes really good buns and I thought the lotus moon pie was nice (an interesting flavor, not too sweet, but definitely different). It seems that Captain's buns are slightly less dense and more airy than Chiu Quon's. I'm starting to like these buns more than Chiu Quon's actually. Whenever I'm in Chinatown, I'll be sure to stop by.

16.description: I'm not a huge regular to Chinatown (a bit difficult for me to get to on public transport without planning), but my parents are big fans, so I've been there regularly over the years.  This is probably my favorite bakery in the area.  I LOVE the soft buns (get there early for the ham and cheese!) and my mother is a big fan of the winter melon cakes.  My father is also a huge fan of the mousse cakes.The prices are good - you can get a bag of stuff for under $10!  Not something common in Chicago any longer.  Additionally, the space is fairly quiet if you get there early, and I've spent several comfortable mornings reading and drinking tea while snacking on a bun.  I like the atmosphere and food.That said, bring cash!  Also, there's no public wastebasket in the cafe area, so take your trash out or hand it to the staff. (That was very confusing for me, initially and just want to pass on a tip!)

13.description: I can't get enough! I love Asian pastries because they are not TOO sweet but still have that puffy, soft, spongy texture that i ADORE. This bakery had very good pastries including:Sweet Top BunCoconut Sugar Top Bun(i love all of the Sugar Top Buns and Coconut Pastries)Egg tartSesame Seed BallThe only one I did not like was the tiny coconut puff pastry that tasted like butter and no coconut. But otherwise the buns hold up very well even after a few days and the best way to heat up the pastries is in a toaster oven because the Sugar Tops get all crisp and delicious again like they were just freshly baked!Pastries here seem to change based on the day but I can't wait to try more pastries soon!

11.description: The service here is terrible.I was here about an hour ago looking for nian gao. I came in with 2 friends and there were a few other customers ordering baked goods. My friend and I wanted to split a pan of nian gao. We spotted some containers by the wall and when we went to pay, we asked for a container. They told us we couldn't split it, and I pointed to the containers and asked if we could have one. Eventually, they handed one to me. The man said we'd need a knife to split it. I asked if they had one I could use, and he said no. I saw some plasticware behind the counter, and I asked if I could have a plastic knife. The man said he would not give me a knife, and the woman tossed a fork into my bag. At this point, all the other customers had left, so it was my 2 friends and me. We put our things down at the table and went about splitting the nian gao in half with a plastic fork. The man behind the counter kept yelling at us that we needed a knife and that we couldn't split it with the fork. However, when I asked again if he had a knife, he laughed at me, mocked us, and said no because they were closing soon. We successfully split the nian gao in half with the fork and into 2 containers. I don't expect 5-star service all the time in Chinatown, but I have never gone to a bakery that had such rude staff. I usually go to the bakeries in old Chinatown, but it's a cold day and Captain was on the way to the Red Line. I'm not sure why the man was so rude to us for no apparent reason. It's Chinese New Year, after all. Why not be kind?The nian gao itself is okay. It's very plain. What I'm really craving is a little red bean on it with a nice flaky crust and maybe some coconut. I guess I shouldn't expect so much out of this place. The bottom line is that I will not patronize Captain Cafe & Bakery again. I'll stick to old Chinatown.

39.description: This is probably hands down my favorite bakery in Chinatown.They have the most beautifully decorated slices of cakes that I seriously believe is some of the best that I have ever tasted anywhere.  Their cakes are always light and fluffy, their whipped cream amazing.You can also purchase dimsum, sticky rice, baos, and other savory treats here!My parents bought me a huge box full of Don Tots, baos, goks, etc.  I am so happy that at the moment, I am the only one in the house that adores these savory treats..I don't need to share.

37.description: Captain Cafe & Bakery was one of the contestants in my ongoing BBQ Pork Bun Off competition.  The review is entirely about their BBQ pork buns, which is the one standard by which I hold all of my Chinatown bakeries accountable.  I used 5 criteria, each with a possible 10 points, for a total possible score of 50 points.Other things to note about Captain Cafe & Bakery before the bun-off: this has become possibly my favorite bakery in the Chinatown Square section - it's one of the smallest in total, but they're very friendly to all their customers and they have a little rack near the register for other baked goods and cookies.  Another Cash Only location, but as long as you've got a couple of bucks to spare, there's always fresh product waiting for you.  I don't think I've ever hit here and found them to be sold out of anything (that I wanted).BBQ Pork Bun Off ResultsSurface: 9 out of 10Good color, good shape - and the whole thing feels so moist and soft that it's hard to imagine anything could ever be bad about this bun.  It's a reassuring kind of soft, yielding feeling.  The only thing knocking down a point is that it feels SO moist and soft that to touch it, you get the feeling that your fingers are going to be oily or wet after handling.  They aren't, strangely enough, but the slickness of the surface is a little creepy and a bit of a mindfreak.Dough: 7 out of 10There's a good bit of gluten here, and a slight bit of dryness - but neither is so much that it really detracts from the doughiness.  I can smell that sweet yeastiness of the risen dough, and my only concern is that the dryness does hit that level where crumbs can form and fall around while eating.The BBQ sauce: 10 out of 10This is just the kind of sweetness I'm looking for in a sauce complete with a good amount of volume and thickness.  It permeates the dough ever so slightly, and you can even hit good-sized pockets of just sauce in-between the chunks of meat, which means that they used enough sauce to really make it stand out while eating it, as a bonus to the meat itself.The pork: 9 out of 10There are moderate chunks in this meat, which means you actually get some chewiness of real meat in-between all of the gooey sauce and spongy dough.  It really comes together well, with no stringiness and no gristle that leads to insane amounts of chewing.  A near-perfect texture to accompany the flavors.Overall presentation: 8 out of 10These buns kept their glossy moist surface all day in their white paper bag of safety that was handed to me at the bakery.  Everything about this bun stood out as excellent except for the bits of dough between the surface and the squishy parts made soft from the BBQ sauce - that slight bit of dryness only really affects your first bite where you might not be getting a lot of sauce or meat.  The only other issue was that the bun is only maybe 50% dough, but a large pocket of air between dough and meat/sauce takes up about 15% of the bun, leaving you with only 35% of the bun filled with that glorious amalgam of sweet sauce and marvelous meat.Total Score: 43 points of 50 (86%)The complete/ongoing results of the BBQ Pork Bun Off can be found on my blog.aaronbsam.blogspot.com

0.description: I got the banana rice cake which was yummy! I've never seen a banana flavored mochi before so I was excited They have many options and service is very fast .A convenient place to grab dessert after eating in the square

38.description: So Saturday night Aaron S. and I stopped in here after having dinner at Joy Yee. For the first time ever I got something that was not a pork bun (they were out) I got a piece of cake labeled simply as "Coffee mouse cake" So you all know by know that I am a coffee freak right? Well this piece of cake had so much coffee in it, that it was ALMOST too much for me. Damn it was good!

27.description: egg tart was yummy.  pineapple bun was a little sweet.  curry beef bun wasn't that good.  I think it's the sauce flavor and the beef.  The way it's cut was weird.

32.description: Bring a limited supply of cash, because this place is too good to be true! The pastries are inexpensive and delicious, from the wife cake to the century egg buns, the coconut custard or the green tea slices. If you want savory they have it. If you want Chinese they have it. If you want Chinese-American they have that!Bring $5 and go wild, they are always a major stop on our trips to China Town :)

48.description: The pastries are yum here - service can be a little difficult if you don't speak any Chinese (especially Cantonese) but their red bean paste is delish and their cream buns are even better.

44.description: It had been years since I've been to Captain Bakery, but the light fluffy sponge-like cakes dressed with fruit and/or tasty roasted chestnuts layered into the cake has been practically a staple for every birthday celebration in my family. A couple of friends and I were in Chinatown hoping to scope some dim sum during a late Saturday morning and found some of our favorite places too crowded. We walked by Captain and noticed that they weren't too busy so we decided to stop in and check out their menu. Although the dining menu is very limited, Captain offers great deals: meals under $3. Try to find a deal like that anywhere else!I opted for the bowl of shrimp rice crepe and a hot cup of fresh-made milk tea combo. Since I'm an eater, I also ordered a ham and egg bun. All items were tasty although not the best that I've had. The price point is this place's strong point, not necessarily the food... but I would come back to give their dine-in menu another shot.

24.description: They do an incredible coconut pastry bread thingy that while the name escapes me, the wonderful texture and flavor has lingered through my head for a week now.  The banana rice cake is traditional, delicious and pretty much like anything else offered here- super cheap (I think I paid $0.85 last time).  I also love their sesame balls with the sweet bean paste inside.  Never greasy nor dry, and always a nice chew and wonderful flavor.This is my go-to spot after a huge meal either at Lao Beijing or MingHin.  It's amazing to think that after eating way too much food, Captain's always draws me in for cheap pastries and baked goods that while I buy them thinking I'll eat them hours after the meal, typically are gone within an hour of purchase.

7.description: DESSERT TIMEWe had just finished a huge dinner at our favorite nearby Chinatown restaurant, when we decided to check out a new business. We were feeling for some desert, so we stopped in here. There is a huge selection of deserts to choose from. Check out my photos. We really had a hard time deciding what to order, considering we were going to being splitting it 3 ways. We finally went with a slice of chocolate cake because it looked amazing.My 4 star review is for the staff here. They were so nice and kind to us.  They went out of there way to make us feel welcome. I could feel the customer service in the air and I love that. I should have asked them to make a few recommendations but we went on our own limb and that's our own fault. We took our cake to go even though there were plenty of places to sit inside. Then found a bench outside and sat down to dive into our slice of cake. I will say that the chocolate cake was very dry. But I can not give a low star rating to a sweet small family business because I chose the one wrong dessert. Maybe this is how chocolate cake is prepared in China? There were so many dessert items to choose from. Next time I will do a little research before going in here. In fact, I didn't even check Yelp before I walked in. I see now that many of my fellow Yelper friends have eaten here. I also now know what I should have ordered. Sometimes being spontaneous doesn't work out well but I tried.  I will say that my wife & I were one bite and done with the chocolate cake. Now our little one devoured it. We were suppose to share it but she didn't stop to offer us a second bite. Kids love chocolate deserts no matter what. I will say that the cake was incredibly dried out The icing couldn't even help because it was also not very moist.The prices were really reasonable in here. So I can see myself coming back and trying a few more items, until I find that one killer dessert that becomes my staple during my visits to Chinatown. Just some words of advice. Always remember the sense of adventure, when eating at a new place. And always be respectful of other cultures because it may not taste good to you in America but it could be amazing on the other side of the world. That is what makes Chicago so rich in food culture.  Within 10-15 minutes of downtown you can be eating authentic food from anywhere in the World. We will be back here on our next visit to Chinatown and were gonna find that killer dessert to end our meal.

40.description: I don't know what kind of crack they put into these pastries, but they are soooooooooo good, and I can't really explain why. They are not like anything I've ever tasted before. I just know that this is a must-stop-at place in Chinatown.

30.description: Here's a rarity for me - a one-star review. I was meeting up with my pal specifically to obtain for him (if samples proved good) a week's supply of baozi (or char sui bao), BBQ pork in steamed buns. My pal had happened on an online one-person survey of (what the author called) the "best" BBQ pork buns in Chicago's Chinatown. That person also happens to have reviewed the Wentworth original of Captain Café here on Yelp. That reviewer's credentials for passing judgement on this favorite bakery item are dubious and his method is full of holes, but according to him, Captain was his favorite in the area. Since my pal had other business in Chinatown Square, we wound up in this offshoot of Captain Café. First bad sign: no steamed version of BBQ pork buns at Captain, just the egg-glazed baked variety (not our favorite and made in a totally different method using different ingredients). But we were game (and it was pouring rain outside). I also ordered a custard tart and a winter melon cake ("wife" cake). Second bad sign: we told the cashier we would eat them there. She bagged up our order. After we reminded her, she gave us a tray. Third bad sign: a non-descript tea was served to us in styro cups at the cashier counter and no pot was brought to the table nor refills ever offered. Straws that broke the camel's back: the filling of the BBQ pork buns was paste-like and unlike anything we had ever been served inside a bun in any other place. Any chunks of actual pork were few and far between. This was a bun that we essentially gagged down because we had already paid for them, not for enjoyment. This was on a Tuesday. Maybe things are different at a different time or at their Wentworth original? Conclusion: don't trust one-person surveys (even my single review).The winter melon cake was equally bad and nonrepresentative of better ones we've had at other bakeries there (Chiu Quon or Wan Shi Da bakeries, both on Wentworth and where their steamed bao are excellent). It's crust layer popped off as we ate it because the entire cake (about 4-in. diameter, 1/2-in. thick) was too moist and not flaky.Still seeking a white, fluffy, steamed BBQ pork bun in Chinatown Square, we dodged water puddles and went across the mall to Saint Anna's bakery a few door up from Captain. They too featured the glazed, baked variety. Less prominent in their cases were smaller, steamed pork buns with that multi-opening look that bespeaks a less confident baker's hand and recipe for the closed-domed finest of the wonderful buns elsewhere. We decided to chalk this odyssey up as a loss and ultimately bought quality buns at Wan Shi Da.

46.description: Just reopened 3/31/07 at the new location:2161 S China Place (new Chinatown Square, right next to KS Seafood)Chicago IL 60616T: 312-791-0888meh. not as good as Golden Horse down the street. not as crazy as St. Anna's. the chinese egg custard tart's pastry bottom tastes too much like short bread, not enough like pastry. the almond cookies taste just like a larger almond cookie one'd be given at the end of a Chinese meal. there are 2 types of polo buns and 2 types of coconut buns yielding: regular polo buns (BOORING), twisted coconut buns (not bad) and... coconut polo buns (hurray, jackpot!). final plus: late hours.pricing is right on par with everyone else. service is still perfectly ok. no Chinese needed, only your index finger. perhaps their business will improve with the move tho St. Anna's is a Chinatown Square goliath.

1.description: This is by far the cleanest bakery in Chinatown!!  The workers are very nice and helpful.  This is the only bakery that makes the sweet top buns in baby size (which I love) that I've been to.  They have quite the spread of buns, cookies and cakes. They do make special occasion cakes as well.  And they have a small seating area. :)

9.description: The bakery sold things that I grew up, such as the sweet pork bun sticky rice. They also had great sweet treats like cake. The cakes were a little dry and wasn't sweet enough. The sweet pork bun was cold; it seemed like it was out for awhile. My boyfriend didn't like any of the things we bought there. We haven't been back since.

26.description: Let me preface this review by saying I don't have anything to compare this to but I do know what's a good deal and what tastes good. I've been here a couple times and each time I'm opened up to a whole new world of unique pastries, both sweet and savory, from a culture I'm really starting to embrace. :) Now that doesn't mean I liked everything. The preserved egg cake? Definitely not for me. There was a whole egg in there, like a hard boiled egg inside this pastry. Blech! I don't like hard boiled eggs at all and I think this one was fermented. However, everything else I tried there was delicious from the sesame ball filled with sweetened bean paste, to the light and elegant coconut twist (artful), to the individual heavenly little sponge cakes.The point isn't to like every single thing that is presented in the store, but rather to embrace trying these new (to me) delights. I love that I can try something new with each visit and I super love how affordable these items are. Be warned, it's cash only not that you'll need a lot of it because the prices are so low.Please bring your cash and patience with you because you are in Chinatown, and if you don't speak Chinese there is a little bit of a language barrier, and they are often kind of busy so let's hope the patience is extended to you as well. There are only a couple tables in the shop plus it gets a lot of foot traffic so it's pretty cramped and busy at times. Keep that in mind, as it is definitely not a good place for groups.I'm looking forward to my future visits, and the bags I bring home with me as well. :-) As a matter of fact, when I was sitting waiting for my train at Union Station enjoying my sesame ball filled with bean paste, a table full of girls was eyeing what was on my plate and one asked me "what is that you're eating?", so I feel like I paid it forward. Haha

25.description: This review is based on the one item I purchased at Captain. One of my favorite things to eat from a Chinese bakery is a baked BBQ pork bun. I have been eating them for years and years, and I hate to say that the Captain's version is one of the most mediocre I have ever tried (hey I am Chinese-style, so I think I can say this with a smidge of authority). I was actually killing time before a great dim sum at nearby MingHin, so I bought two BBQ pork buns to go. When I ate the first one later that day, I had an experience similar to what Weisun C described. To paraphrase the classic Wendy's commercial - "where's the pork?". The bun had a sweet paste inside that was not bad, but I did not recall my taste buds enjoying any chunks of meat at all. The next day I ate the second bun, and  the pork was still missing. I don't think I'll make a great effort to revisit Captain, but if I do I will certainly avoid the BBQ pork buns.

12.description: I am a bit impatient when it comes to food, so when I was told I had to wait an hour for my lunch (dim sum), I looked for some snacks to munch on. I stumbled to this place because of the proximity to the restaurant we waited for. CASH ONLY+ huge variety ranging from cakes (whole and slices) to cookies to ham and egg asian buns+ cheap+ fast service+ some (albeit limited) seating+ Durian pancakes: I love exotic fruits (and just weird food), and growing up I've gotten used to durian in my household.
