(This is a rough patch with my boyfriend :P) This place sells durian filled pancake, i.e., pancake with just a HINT of durian jelly/jam so you have a bit of the vanilla fruit taste without the smell. Never seen this before and was immediately in my belly. - rice crepe with shrimp we had were cold and bland- the coconut tart is too crumbly and dry. They need to work on the tart/crust which was too bland- egg tart - I absolutely love love love egg tarts. (Golden Gate bakery for the win in San Fran!) And I would still stand by my word that this tiny booth in shanghai food court sold the best egg custard tarts I've ever had in my life. But these were just beyond terrible. They were very very very eggy. A good egg custard tart would have filling that is just lightly sweetened and still soft. The eggs here are overdone and almost looked like curdles. It's like eating scrambled yolk. As noted above, the tart/crust was also bland.- cream buns are not nearly as good as places in San Francisco Chinatown. The cream was a bit over salted and dense, which that it reminded me of eating lighter butter. It does't have the light whip cream that you get in other places.Overall, I was semi-happy that i was not starving while waiting for dim sum but wish I tried another bakery down the block. The pastries were decent but not even close to some places (even Ranch 99 bakery). I would suggest trying only a few unique items here and save the standard stuff (pineapple buns, cream buns, egg tarts, etc.) for other places.Food was too meh for the camera

21.description: I am so glad we found this little gem.  After dinner we took a stroll and took some dessert home.  we bought a slice of the chocolate mousse, strawberry mousse, an Taro.  The Strawberry was amazing, the Taro root is not very sweet and a bit nutty, and the chocolate mouse was delicious.  We can't wait to try out some of the other flavors. Try the strawberry you will not be disappointed.

17.description: I threw away most or the stuff I got here.Green tea cake was wayyy too oily.The sticky rice wrapped in some leaves was so bland, it was disgusting.The yellow rice cake was again so bad I threw it away after a bite.One good thing: everything here was pretty cheap, so I didn't throw away a lot of money. I don't usually give one star reviewsBut damn I really did not like this place.

10.description: GREEN TEA MOUSSE CAKEi repeat...GREEN TEA MOUSSE CAKE!ermagerd. muy muy delicioso. so fluffy. so light.I will admit...if you like really sweet things you probably wont like this cake. I, on the other hand,  I dont like when I feel weighed down by a super crazy rich desert. I would recommend this to you if you're not really a sweets person but you're craving something on the sweeter side and you like green tea. I love this ambiance in the bakery as well. It's probably had the same interior for the last 30 years and I think thats part of the mystique of visiting a place like this in Chinatown.

5.description: Bread are good and cheap. The breads are however oily (not to my surprise). The bag they put the bread in is very oily. To get bread, you tell the lady at the counter what you want.

3.description: Cash only still!I'm hooked on these curry buns they have. I'm sure they taste better warmed up, but my guy already eats them cold in the car.

35.description: omg. I ate a custard bun in bed last night that I had picked up from here. ugh. It was DISGUSTINGLY good. So good. Definite party in my mouth. It was pillowy soft and a good custard that was not too sweet. I need to go back and pick up more of those since I had only purchased one, just in case it tasted bunk. A box full of pastries and a small container on the side of turnip cake under 7 dollars.. YAY!! They run out of my favorite fried curry buns fast though :-(

19.description: I love the regular egg tarts from here and you can definitely keep it in the fridge for at least a week and it'll still taste good. The sesame balls are excellent too. I thought it was slightly greasy but it's nothing that a napkin can't take care of. My friend loves them so I'll be sure to purchase more next time I stop by. The mango pudding was pretty good as well but the almond cookie...mm...not so much....it left a weird taste in my mouth.

28.description: LOVE Captain's! We live in Chinatown, so its a quick walk away. Every time we're in the square, we look in the window and are so tempted to get something.Tonight's fare was a slice of green tea mousse cake for me, slice of white chocolate cake for boyfriend, and lotus red bean moon cakes for both of us. The moon cakes are only 75 cents each, while the cake slices are a bit pricier at almost $3 each. But they are big slices and SOOOOOO worth it. They are not super sweet or sugary cakes, so if you have a sweet tooth, they probably are not for you. But if you have a more delicate palate, you will love them. Light, soft, and delicious.The only drawback of Captain's is that they only take cash, as their multiple signs outside insist. But with Walgreen's right down the street, go get a back of gum and cash-back. Its worth it.

45.description: If you love chestnut cake, this is the place to go.  The cake is light and fluffy, and it tickles your taste bud with just the right amount of sweetness.  I've been getting my birthday cake from here for the past 4 years now til last year when they closed down.   But to my pleasant surprise, they reopened the store in Chinatown Square near the west gate.  I was simply delighted! So, my friends and I decided to try their special combos as our energy source before biking.  For roughly $3, u get a milk tea and a very generous portion shrimp (or beef) funn roll or other delicious treats.  It was more than enough to fill me up for the biking expedition! :D Service was average.  Best if you can speak Chinese, english will also work.  But if  all else fails,  just start pointing and nodding towards what you want.  So...if u want a quick fix-me upper at a bargrain price, this is the place to try!  mmmmm

33.description: The location is convenient. The servers are friendly and helpful.  There's always a long line when I go but that gives me a chance to look at the delicious sweets behind the glass case.I feel like a kid in a candy store, wanting everything! The fruit cake slice is always a must - the cake is airy, the whipped cream is not sugary sweet just how I like it, and the fruit is fresh.  Some cake slices are only $1!A must stop, you won't be disappointed!

43.description: Not really a sweets bakery, they sell many savory delectables like buns and sticky rice. If you own a steamer or a steaming device, please try the sticky rice. You might know of it better from a dim sum adventure, but it's an amazing dish that they have for you to take home. If you don't know what I'm talking about, check out the Wikipedia page: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gl…They have 2 types of custard egg tarts including the one with a slightly burnt top ala creme brulee if you want to try that out. If you think you don't like custard, try that because the crispy top makes all the difference. They also have a light and airy sponge cake that I much prefer over more western-style sponge cakes because it isn't as sugar laden. The buns with curry beef, bbq pork, and a variety of other savory fillings are baked in sweet bread rather than steamed so they're a more portable and lasting item. Grab a dozen or so and bring them with you to lunch. At about a dollar a piece, you could afford that.

2.description: Captain is my personal favorite bakery in Chinatown (over Chiu Quon and Saint Anna), not because it's particularly spectacular but because it's better than the alternatives. I found Captain to offer more varieties, look slightly cleaner and more presentable, and provide more affable service.I particularly like the curried (chicken or beef) buns as well as the char siu (BBQ) pork bun. The meat filling in all of these buns is decidedly mysterious, and the dough is a little chewier than preferred, but all-in-all it's a great and hearty breakfast. Captain also offers the usual Chinese buns (my wife's go-to is red bean, mine is custard) as well as a medley of dimsum-esque desserts like red bean sesame balls.

18.description: The location is convenient. The servers are friendly and helpful.  There's always a long line when I go but that gives me a chance to look at the delicious sweets behind the glass case.I feel like a kid in a candy store, wanting everything! The fruit cake slice is always a must - the cake is airy, the whipped cream is not sugary sweet just how I like it, and the fruit is fresh.  Some cake slices are only $1!A must stop, you won't be disappointed!

41.description: I have to bump this place up to 5 stars for consistency and great pricing.  We hit this place during my 13 year old sister in laws visit for desert after eating at Lao Shaghai and she loved the moon cakes and her Chocolate Mousse Cake.  I think the sweet baked goods are better here than at any other China Town bakery, and the buns are always amazing - egg, bacon and cheese twist, anyone?Cheap, delicious, and even picky eaters will enjoy it.  One of my all time China Town faves.

4.description: We stopped here when visiting Chinatown on our 2nd day in Chicago.  This place has some good selection but the bakery across the plaza had better pineapple bun with coconut and red bean.  The price is very good so hey, nothing to complain.  We finished our treats for the next couple of days, so it was nice to have something for breakfast.

6.description: I have been coming here pretty often since moving to Chicago, Their curry beef buns, curry chicken buns ,and cha siu baos are so good and fresh.  I also love their curry beef pastry, ga lei ngau yuk soa, and lo po beng ( wife cake). I think this is a family owned bakery, because there is always an older man that is sitting down on the tables . Prices are pretty affordable for the size of the buns. They also have pei dan sou ( duck egg pastry), and gei dzai beng ( little chicken biscuits.  The egg tarts here are pretty good and fresh as well ( they have both regular and macau style egg tarts). I wouldn't get the American style baked goods here, because I feel like they would probably be stale since most customers only purchase the more traditional style Chinese baked goods. I also want to try the puffed rice pastry that they have! CASH ONLY

22.description: I would probably give it 3.5 stars. They had some great bakery items but nothing is remarkable about it. However, they are better (and cleaner) than some other's I've visited. BUNS: soft and fresh! You can find the typical Asian bakery items there. Their BBQ pork buns were disappointing though, mostly just Asian BBQ flavored goo rather than actual BBQ pork. Everything else was pretty good. CAKES: Their mousse cakes are gorgeous, but lacks in texture/flavor. It mostly whipped cream tasting instead of a good balance of sponge cake and mousse.SERVICE: They are pretty good with getting you in and out of there quickly. Just remember to BRING CASH! They only accept cash (no credit). There was one time however, the young lady who was grabbing the buns for me and my mom, she smushed the buns as she placed them in the paper bags. I think she was new or not a typical worker though. I had never seen her there before. The regular owner/employee stepped in upset and helped grab the rest of the buns instead. This makes me feel better they make sure they don't like their employees selling smushed buns!I still continue to go here since it seems to be one of the cleaner and (looks to be) more popular bakeries in Chinatown

15.description: Let me preface this review by saying I don't have anything to compare this to but I do know what's a good deal and what tastes good. I've been here a couple times and each time I'm opened up to a whole new world of unique pastries, both sweet and savory, from a culture I'm really starting to embrace. :) Now that doesn't mean I liked everything. The preserved egg cake? Definitely not for me. There was a whole egg in there, like a hard boiled egg inside this pastry. Blech! I don't like hard boiled eggs at all and I think this one was fermented. However, everything else I tried there was delicious from the sesame ball filled with sweetened bean paste, to the light and elegant coconut twist (artful), to the individual heavenly little sponge cakes.The point isn't to like every single thing that is presented in the store, but rather to embrace trying these new (to me) delights. I love that I can try something new with each visit and I super love how affordable these items are. Be warned, it's cash only not that you'll need a lot of it because the prices are so low.Please bring your cash and patience with you because you are in Chinatown, and if you don't speak Chinese there is a little bit of a language barrier, and they are often kind of busy so let's hope the patience is extended to you as well. There are only a couple tables in the shop plus it gets a lot of foot traffic so it's pretty cramped and busy at times. Keep that in mind, as it is definitely not a good place for groups.I'm looking forward to my future visits, and the bags I bring home with me as well. :-) As a matter of fact, when I was sitting waiting for my train at Union Station enjoying my sesame ball filled with bean paste, a table full of girls was eyeing what was on my plate and one asked me "what is that you're eating?", so I feel like I paid it forward. Haha

20.description: The Macao (Portugese-style) egg tarts are really good.  The custard is so soft and creamy.  The crust could be more firm but overall one of the best "dan tats" I've had in Chinatown.Stay away from the baked BBQ pork buns  - the bun is good enough but the filling is just a bunch of sweet brown goo with some mystery meat.   Yuck!

36.description: I got a green tea mousse slice. It tasted kinda whatevs, not great. I didn't finish it because I started having a realllllllly hard time breathing. Wheezing and congested chest and all. FYI: I'm allergic to avocado. I have a suspicion that they wrongly labeled their products because I shouldn't get an allergic reaction to green tea. -_-

14.description: I haven't been here for a long time, mostly because I can the items that I want for a much lower prices and better quantity in the other places around the neighborhood.

3.description: This place is a pretty awkward building with a bunch of little shops in it. I'd call it a mall, but it's more of a food court with a couple random stores thrown in.It's super clean (even the bathrooms) and all of the vendors seemed really friendly. Lots of different food/drink choices. There's also what appears to be a food reflexology shop. There's a large area to sit and eat your food, with lots of TVs. It never seems to be too crowded. It's a nice place to stop at and get a quick bite to eat, but if you're looking for a sit down meal, there are at least 100 other places you could go within a two block radius.

1.description: Several friends and I frequent this food court on a weekly basis. In a year, this review will go down as the last review before this place blew up and people start raving about this place and there are Zagat/Chowhound/LTH forum/Steve Dolinky's picture all over the front. For $12 you can be sure you'll get your fill of authentic Chinese food.For a no frills, authentic dining experience, be sure to visit here. Most of the items have english on them with picture, except for the dumpling place, which only has a chinese menu. There's also a foot reflexology place, and a random minimart that sells really random stuff.

2.description: This hidden gem found on the basement level of the Richland center has some of the cheapest food you will find in Chinatown let alone Chicago. The food court set up makes it convenient to mix and match small plates from different vendors. The majority of the vendors sell the typical Chinese fare consisting of rice boxes and noodles dishes, but there's also a Filipino food vendor. This review is specifically for the takoyaki at Kyu Lin. When you come down the stairs, walk straight then to the shop furthest to the right in the corner. The takoyaki comes in two sizes: 6 or 12 pieces. I recommend getting a dozen because it's cheaper and you can't just eat 6 -- they're that good (I mean, the best you're gonna find in Chinatown) For those who aren't familiar with takoyaki, "tako" means octopus and "yaki" means cooked/grilled/fried. These octopus balls are a popular Japanese snack made with a wheat flour batter and stuffed with octopus, scallions, pickled ginger and tempura bits. They are brushed with a Japanese Worcestershire sauce and mayo then covered with bonito flakes and a seaweed powder. Love at first bite -- the exterior is golden brown and crisp while the inside is creamy studded with chunks of octopus. I've tried their okonomiyaki, which is a savory Japanese pancake, but it was mehh. Skip it and use that money to buy more takoyaki!

5.description: I went . It wasnt bad or good. It just...was. That is all

6.description: I have to say I like the concept of it, but it's just not really popular. It's like a food court with a few shops. I think if they filled all the spots, it might be a bit busier, but it's always almost dead in there.They have sushi, bahn mi sandwiches, noodles and quick snacks. Food is ok, but it's quick and cheap.I like how they have cameras around the bathroom since it's hidden behind the water fountain. Hopefully more shops open and it gets more popular.

7.description: Did you know?  The Richland Center is a newly opened shopping center that holds shopping + a food court in the basement.It's actually kinda hard to tell that there's anything in this plaza.  However, if you walk in and pass the fountain to go downstairs, you'll find a number of hidden treasures.  From what I can remember, here are the restaurants:(1) Vietnamese sub/sandwich + pho noodle place(2) A Taiwanese snack place (that sells takoyaki a.k.a. octopus balls), bubble tea, and all sorts of things(3) A Chinese food/noodle place -- will be opening soon(4) A Japanese sushi place(5) A teppanyaki/hibachi place??? From what I can remember, here are the shops:(1) A souvenir shop (2) A household shopAll of the prices in this whole plaza are so cheap.  You can get a bowl of wonton noodles for $4.00 (which they sold out today at 4pm bc its so cheap, so go early), the viet sub/sandwich meal is like $3 or $4 (drink included), a whole meal (3 sides?) from the teppanyaki place for like $4 as well, 2 kids pants for $5, summer scarves for $2, and much much more from the other stands!It's a pretty new place.  The lobby/food court is set up with brand new chairs and tables.  There are 2 large LED displays to watch while you're eating.  It's still a little bit un-busy when I had visited, but definitely increasing in customers each time I go.  The word is out.  4 stars for a definite must visit.  Go and check it out for yourself!

0.description: AWESOME place in Chinatown to go when you're low on $$$! There's a variety of different food counters you can go up to...sushi, dumplings, noodles, and it's all extremely cheap (but still pretty decent, and big portion sizes!) Just make sure you bring some cash, because some of the counters don't take card (or they have limits on the card).

4.description: Been here twice in a row last week. The first time I only tried the noodle shop up front and tako yaki (octupus balls). The noodle was toothsome and broth flavorful, though I wished the brisket could be just a tad more tender. Takoyaki were spot on with big chunks of octopus.Second time I tried the szechuan hotpot from the kabobs place. Most of the items in the broth were vegetarian, so they really push people to order their kabobs. The hotpot broth was not for the faint of heart! I had to fish everything out of it halfway during my meal because I couldn't handle the heat, but if you like szechuan style spicy then this is for you. We went for the takoyaki again, as well as the japanese pancake. I'll stick with takoyaki next time. Ended with fried ice cream, which was an interesting concept but overall meh. So it looks like while there's a good collection of items, you need to know what to order. Still can't beat the price.

28.description: I love the sushi there!! my families and i order sushi tray every time we're having family parties!

1.description: They give you a lot of rolls for your money but it was far from the best sushi I ever had.

39.description: Another meh sushi place in chinatown. It's only cheap for now......with the 20% discount, but once that is over with.....seems kinda high for what you get.We tried the eel roll and spider roll. Eel roll didn't have much flavor too it. Spider roll was a bit better, but was just meh.Cool little concept if they can get more stores down there in the basement. Felt like I was in Toronto.

9.description: Ike Burro is located in the basement of the Richland Center; basically the food court of Chinatown. There is plenty of meter parking available around Chinatown. Seating downstairs in the food court is never a problem. I've been a frequent customer of Ike Burro ever since they've opened mainly because its convenient, cheap, and their sushi is average/above average. Convenience and price is key when I'm craving Sushi, I don't want to drive all the way to the North Side or pay $12 per roll somewhere Downtown. Ike Burro's menu consists of over 15 types of rolls, but based on my numerous experiences I've tried probably only 6-7 of their rolls and they are: The simpler rolls such as the California or Avocado rolls range from $3-4 per roll and consists of 6-9 pieces. The average rolls such as the salmon, and tuna rolls range from $5-6 per roll and consists of 6-12 pieces. The piece by piece rolls range from $7-$10 consists of 5-10 pieces of sushi. There are also party trays. That range from $20-$50 dollars. Customer service is always great here. The owner and his wife always greet you with a smile. And if you go back frequent enough they even remember your order. Overall experience- Cheap rolls - Average/Above average tasting- Plenty of seating.

29.description: For the price, this place is amazing - best value i have found in Chicago so far. Quality is similar or a bit better than all you can eat places - not great, but quite tasty. They don't speak much english, so just go off the numbers. I tried the spicy tuna and shrimp tempura roll - for $13.00 tax in, i was stuffed - that's 12 pieces of spicy tuna for $5.40!! plus the tempura role. I'm definitely going back to try some other rolls - this will probably be my go to sushi place from now...  i give it 4 stars - sushi is pretty good and you can't beat the price...  :)

23.description: I got the sushi combo A. It had some nigiri rolls and I'm not sure what the others were. It was not bad! The combo was still kind of expensive for a food court place ($10+tax)... otherwise I'd give it 4 stars. I did see some cheaper rolls but those were only for the "simple" rolls like spicy tuna or philadelphia roll. I'd probably come back to try the simple rolls.

5.description: I dont wanna say a lot of things about this place but here are few bads and goods. Goods: miso soup, and salmon was fresh. Bads: they dont secure take out order well. Soup that i ordered was spill all over the food and bag. Fried Calamari was mostly tiny calamari limbs which is not good. shrimp tempura was a joke. 3 shrimps and rest is onion rings (the one and only thing i hate). On their menu, it comes with sweet potato, pumpkins etc, but all i got is freaking huge onion rings!

31.description: Granted, I only had sushi in one restaurant in Chicago. However, these prices are unbeatable in all of AMERICA. I'm talking 12 piece rolls for only $5! Delicious, fresh and soft, too. Specialty rolls pretty much cost what a Cali roll would at a normal sushi restaurant. It's pretty great. They also have discounts.So, for poor travelers and plain poor people, this is kind of the best ever. Random location -- inside a food court in Chinatown, but a good escape from the Chicago weather. Would go here everyday if it were in Austin.

25.description: Yes, this small joint is as good as it gets. The owners  are the best, super friendly and super sweet. The soy sauce is very salty however the prices make up for this tiny detail. You must check it out! :D

12.description: I decided to go out of my way to try this place given the high ratings.   I was disappointed.   The proprietors appear to be nice, hard working, earnest but the food was not satisfying.  First, the place is located in a basement level food court.   Can't ask for a worse atmosphere than that.  I had a  broad selection:  miso soup $1.25, unagi ricebox $6.30, Octupus salad $4.05, Sushi party Tray B $11.70.    None of them was very satisfying. Ths fish used in the sushi seemed OK but the rice was awful and they don't seem to have the right amount of vinegar or the correct cooking of the rice to make good sushi.   It was not good.The Miso soup was nice and hot, had a good fragrance too it but it was not clear that they used the proper technique for making the miso soup as it was watered down and tasteless.  The unagi was not very tasty either.  The rice was mushy and the sauce used was not very flavorful.  The octupus parts used in the Octupus Salad were smaller than pictured, heavily vineagered and was not very tasty.   I don't think I'll be back.   I took it as takeout and it was cold by the time so that may explain my dissatisfaction.  But, the rice was not very good either in the unagi don or the sushi.

37.description: Did you know? Mention the Facebook promo, and you get 20% off!IkeBukuro sushi is one of the new restaurants that have recently opened in the Richland Center.  It is located in a plaza/shopping mall somewhat north of New Chinatown.  I was quite impressed by the quality of the food here in this little food court.  For "food court sushi" and prices for less than $10/person, its hard to beat.My boyfriend and I ordered 3 rolls to go, which all of them were quite delicious.  We had a rainbow roll, a type of rolled with cooked eel, and another spicy tuna roll(?).  My fish was absolutely fresh, cut to bring out the texture of the fishes, and the presentation was nice.  Compared to all of the neighboring places, this probably one of the best sushi places in Chinatown.  5 stars for a well deserved neighborhood favorite.  I will definitely be back again to pick up some party trays for the family.  Give it a try, but do so early, bc they close at 9pm (weekdays) and 8pm (weekends)

21.description: stopped here on a whim--was definitely blown away. The wasabi was delicious and the sushi, especially for the price, was amazing! I got twice the amount for the same price I get in Hyde Park. The owners are super SUPER nice and I am definitely coming back. I got the Unagi and Philadelphia. Am planning on trying some combos or fancier rolls next time

16.description: Is it the best sushi in Chicago?  Nope.  Is it the best combo of quality and price in Chicago?  I would say so.  Located in the food court of the basement of a shopping center in Chinatown, you would never know this place existed unless someone told you about it.  They have your standard rolls with some specialty ones as well.  They also have a standard selection of sushi pieces.  I would say the quality of the food is above average but the prices are exceptional.  For example, party tray C has 34 pieces of 6 different rolls for $22.  Party tray A has 6 pieces of sushi with 1 roll for $10.  Can't beat those prices in Chicago.  The couple that run the place are super nice and friendly too

17.description: Friendly, lovely couple runs this place.  Even with the CTA fare to get to this place and back to the Loop for sushi lunch, it is a bargain.  Especially for the quality of sushi.  Super-Walgreens can suck it.

10.description: I loved everything about this place. The sushi was really fresh and just as good! Nom nom noms definately going back.

11.description: Came here based on yelp reviews, and you guys were spot on!   Fast, good (yet basic) sushi at cheap prices. This is now our new go-to fast food.  Way tastier than other options in the area if you're looking for something to pick up quick and cheap.  We call ahead and the lady (who i think is an owner) always recognizes me and is very friendly.  We used to go here a few times a month, then I got pregnant, and 9 months later she still recognized me!  Love having businesses like this nearby!

26.description: Hands down, this is the worst sushi I have ever had in my life. I should have known better than to order raw fish from an underground food court in the nasty cesspool of filth that is Chinatown Chicago. I ate a few bites then threw it out. It smelled like it was sprayed with antiseptic cleaner. I spent the rest of that day fearing I'd get food poisoning. Luckily I did not but this place is truly disgusting.

27.description: I really hate to do this because the owners are really nice, but the sushi here was terrible. The rice was mushy and had no taste, and the spider roll and other roll that was cooked was not that great. The soy sauce was super salty. My coworker and I had to force ourselves to eat just the inside and afterwards we were just very unsatisfied. Plus it's only 10% discount now and not 20% so the price was on par with any cheap sushi grocery place. Shouldn't expect much out of a Chinese own sushi place though.

35.description: the price is pretty cheap for sushi because of that 20% off, but its only for limited time only.. i am a big sushi fan and i can tell you that these sushi isn't all that great..dont get me wrong, some of the rolls are decent.. the wasabi is the cheap ones that u buy from a bottle and it taste horrible..

8.description: I love this little hole in the wall gem. Food: Decent sushi for an unbelievable price. It will certainly satisfy your sushi craving. Decor: Well, it's in the basement of a mostly empty food court. Service: Such a cute couple who own this place. Don't forget to say hi!

0.description: Now that I live more south, this is my new cheap quality sushi spot when I'm too lazy to drive to Lawrence Fishmarket on the Northside. For the spicy salmon roll, 1 roll = 12 pieces which is unheard of! That's a good amount of sushi for the money. The Sasa roll and Disney roll are also good. Don't be fooled by their "website" this was created by the previous owner and your online order will not go through, found this out the hard way. Just give them a call, it's fast and easy. The husband and wife owners are really nice.

38.description: Affordable sushi that's pretty tasty! We ordered the salmon and spicy tuna rolls. Both yummy! I also love their gyoza (it's different from other places, since the gyoza skin is thinner) and the sauce I can dip it in! This little gem is located in Chinatown in the basement of a Realtor Building. When you walk down here, it almost looks like a Hawker Center that you see in Singapore. Except, there's a lot of vacant of spaces around their sushi stall. Will definitely come back here to get my sushi and gyoza fix!! They also give you free miso soup with purchase of sushi, which is fantastic!

20.description: I love this little hole in the wall gem. Food: Decent sushi for an unbelievable price. It will certainly satisfy your sushi craving. Decor: Well, it's in the basement of a mostly empty food court. Service: Such a cute couple who own this place. Don't forget to say hi!

19.description: You would never go here if you just walked in to this mostly empty food court but you would be missing a great Sushi place. The food was awesome and the couple that run this place is cute as hell.  You can watch the Chef as he makes your food and that is a treat also. Great place , we will be back for sure! ! !  You must go...

33.description: Had to write a review for this place and I had to put in my 5 stars here. Big food count means that there will always be seats, great ventilation, nice lighting, BYOB, cheap cheap prices, but may be hard to find since it is in a basement. It's Chinatown so it will be a quiet and friendly environment. The lady was very nice to me as well.

2.description: One of my favorite fast sushi pickup places. The man that's makes the sushi is very courteous and trys to help you pick out the best combo for the price. Quick and good quality service. The firecracker roll was a blast.

34.description: When you think of Chinatown, you might not think "sushi", but one of my new favorite sushi joints actually resides in a little hidden getaway at the edge of Chinatown Square, and even though there's no All-You-Can-Eat - at this place, I can actually get my fill for about the same price that I'd pay for an AYCE experience.(And you no longer have to mention the 20% off Facebook promotion - they've built the discount directly into their prices now!)I've been here at least 3 times now, because sometimes I get an immediate sushi craving and this is not only the closest trip for me to acquire sushi, but one of the best-priced locations as well.  I admit that when I get a slow craving that creeps up and eats away at me until I need satisfaction, I'll still make the long trip north to HoSaN, but for the ability to get not only sushi for cheap and a few doors down be able to grab some BBQ pork buns?  WORTH IT.At the far end of the Chinatown Square, near the Red Line station, you'll see a building called the Richland Center.  It looks like an apartment complex, but if you venture inside, you'll see a set of stairs with unseasonal year-round Christmas decoration leading down to a basement (and giant waterfall sculpture).  You have entered the Food Court - and way in the back, in the corner, you'll find IkeBukuro Sushi.As I mentioned, the prices (with a built-in 20% discount) are very good, and they even still feature $1.99 California Rolls.  I can usually pick out at least 4 rolls, leave paying less than the price of an AYCE sushi run, and feel very satisfied.What makes the rolls stand out to be are how fresh they are.  The rice is still a little warm.  The texture of the fish is very pleasant and you can tell it is very fresh.  The wasabi seems to have been prepared fresh as well - not scooped from a can.  I have not experienced a roll here that tasted off in any way, and that really says a lot about a sushi establishment in my book.They don't get have a webpage other than their Facebook, so it's hard to get a feel for their menu unless you actually show up and grab one of their takeout menus or look up on their big board displaying their rolls.All in all, it's worth a visit if you frequent the Chinatown area and enjoy sushi - or if you enjoy sushi enough to make a trip down to Chinatown no matter what the distance!Itadakimasu!!

32.description: Very nice lady but the sushi was just A-OK. It's definitely food court sushi.

18.description: Fast, inexpensive, fresh, and even brought out to us when ready. For the price, worth every penny. Not a wide selection, but it'll do just fine considering it's a Japanese sushi place in Chinatown. Location is very easy to miss, if you don't know it's there.

13.description: Another meh sushi place in chinatown. It's only cheap for now......with the 20% discount, but once that is over with.....seems kinda high for what you get.We tried the eel roll and spider roll. Eel roll didn't have much flavor too it. Spider roll was a bit better, but was just meh.Cool little concept if they can get more stores down there in the basement. Felt like I was in Toronto.

4.description: If I could give 0 stars, I would. My mom, sister, and I used to love coming here because it's close, good value, and the old management was very friendly and courteous. Recently we've ordered California rolls to go twice, and we were disappointed not only in really simple sushi, but also the way the new management handles customers. My mother called to tell them there was barely any avocado in our California rolls, the rice falls apart when we take out a roll because they like to stuff the rolls in a takeout box. The manager shouted at my mother to bring it down for a refund. She said it wouldn't be necessary, but she wanted to let him know, but asked how he expects to do business by shouting at his customers. The manager told her to not come back. Extremely disappointing, im not expecting 5-star service here, but it is a complete 180 from the old management, and we won't be back ever again.

24.description: I know - sushi in Chinatown?  I was skeptical at first but after meeting my cousin here I will say yes you can get good sushi in Chinatown. The owners are super friendly and the prices are solid.  the only down side is there isn't a ton of variety.  Overall I recommend this place if you are in Chinatown and looking to satisfy your sushi fix.

6.description: Oh snap! I can't believe I forgot to write a review for this place. Ever since the basement opened, I've loved stopping by and grabbing the cheap sushi rolls. Every time I'm in Chinatown, I always come here to buy food for the trip home. Fun fact: the old guy who is the chef used to be a sushi chef at Benihana. And the rolls are amazingly half the price of what you'd pay there, but the exact nice quality! (Think about it - Disney roll here = sumo roll at Benihana, Las Vegas roll is the same, etc). The cashier lady is a super sweet woman who remembers my family whenever we stop by. She'll also pack the sushi neatly to make sure nothing spills and it looks fantastic if you take it to go. The fish is fresh and the avocado is always green. My favorite roll is the Disney roll and I definitely recommend Party Tray F. I don't particularly care for the appetizers, but the tempura is really yummy.EDIT: The chef decided to retire so the owners have changed. Ikebukuro is still OPEN! :)

22.description: Recently discovered this place and it's great.  The service is excellent, super friendly, and the prices are reasonable!  $2 for a 6-piece California Roll!  Can't beat that.

15.description: I love love love IkeBukuro Sushi!Prices are unbelievably low (yes, they are located in the Richland Center basement food court, but their low prices do NOT reflect on the quality of the sushi!)I love sushi. I would eat it every day if it was FDA recommended that I eat more servings of fish per week, but alas. Just enter the new Richland Center & take the stairs down, past the waterfall & IkeBukuro is located all the way in the left-hand corner of the food court. While I wait for my sushi to be prepared, I sometimes browse the other food & specialty shops in the court.IkeBukuro & their front counter woman & sushi chef team are adorable. I always ask for my sushi with "no avocado," and they never fail to replace that avocado with thinly-sliced cucumber without my even asking. I have always carried out from IkeBukuro; never eaten in said food court. I am a fan of taking my sushi home, prepping my wasabi, soy sauce & chop sticks & enjoying a program on the tube. I have also ordered their party trays before... DEAL STEAL! Perfect for gatherings; their party trays are huge & have something for everyone. The nice people of IkeBukuro have come to recognize me when I visit & are always more than friendly. It is really nice to have a neighborhood sushi joint that is fresh, tasty & extremely low-priced.

40.description: Cheap Cheap Cheap,   Trying to survive in a the basement of a newer building in Chinatown.   I had the California Roll ($2) and Spicy Salmon HR ($2).  I watched him as he prepared the rolls.  Definitely has the knowledge and talent as he prepared the rolls.  Also, the rice is seasoned nicely, my wife said needed more.  Plenty of fish and good balance of ingredients.  Not the best sushi... but one of the cheapest for what you get. Lastly, the owners wife who takes your order is ummm very thorough (slow).....If you can find the place hope you like it.Right behind Citibank and in the basement.

7.description: The many times I came they always offer fresh sushi with amazing prices. I went to another Japanese joint in Old town where they charged me $29 for an unagi don, it cost less than half of what they charged with Ikebukuro for better unagi don!! I'll stick with this place, and the people are nice here :)

36.description: Prices are good with the 20% opening special that's still going on.  The effort is appreciated, but good sushi is not easy and requires quality, fresh ingredients.  The rice is a little too sticky while fish is comparable to packaged grocery sushi.  So I thought my experience was lacking, but I wouldn't mind coming back if had a craving and just wanted to stay in the neighborhood.

30.description: I love love love IkeBukuro Sushi!Prices are unbelievably low (yes, they are located in the Richland Center basement food court, but their low prices do NOT reflect on the quality of the sushi!)I love sushi. I would eat it every day if it was FDA recommended that I eat more servings of fish per week, but alas. Just enter the new Richland Center & take the stairs down, past the waterfall & IkeBukuro is located all the way in the left-hand corner of the food court. While I wait for my sushi to be prepared, I sometimes browse the other food & specialty shops in the court.IkeBukuro & their front counter woman & sushi chef team are adorable. I always ask for my sushi with "no avocado," and they never fail to replace that avocado with thinly-sliced cucumber without my even asking. I have always carried out from IkeBukuro; never eaten in said food court. I am a fan of taking my sushi home, prepping my wasabi, soy sauce & chop sticks & enjoying a program on the tube. I have also ordered their party trays before... DEAL STEAL! Perfect for gatherings; their party trays are huge & have something for everyone. The nice people of IkeBukuro have come to recognize me when I visit & are always more than friendly. It is really nice to have a neighborhood sushi joint that is fresh, tasty & extremely low-priced.

3.description: I have been to this place countless of times. But I think they recently changed owner or the chef again (happened about twice now). The sushi got bigger while the price stays pretty much the same. But the rice was kind of hard the last two times I went there. Since it is cheap sushi...I can let it pass. The chef is very flexible. If I see something I want the chef to substitute in the menu, he will do it without a problem. I will go back but probably not as much as I used to.

14.description: Good and cheap sushi, the lady that take your order was very nice. The place is located inside a food court on the lower level of a mall, could be hard to find. There is not too much atmosphere but the sushi worth it

58.description: Have been here three times and will continue to go back! Great tasting authentic dumplings that are handmade while you wait. They're a bit like xiaolongbao. Very flavorful and the owners are nice.Tip: It's hidden in the back of the food court, but it's worth it!

56.description: So glad we found this place, the dumplings are delicious!!  I only ever get the shrimp and lamb, they are too good to try anything else!  It appears to be BYOB down here, and you're allowed to ride bikes if they have training wheels.  Best food court ever!!

29.description: Best dumping in the Chicago if you live in Chicago you have to try it. (No longer location in the food court basement of the Richland center.)

42.description: All the hype....sorry guys the dumplings here are just mediocre, nothing more special than the ones you can buy in a frozen bag at the grocery stores.  Restaurant decor is modern and clean, but the staff is kind of clueless and awkward.  Been looking for a good dumpling place here in chicago...looks like the search continues.

23.description: Yes! I've been here when they were a vendor in the basement of the dead mall. It was great then, but the service was slow and I thought it was pricey for a mall foodcourt.Now that they opened a storefront, it's totally worth every penny! Here's why:What we ordered:Potato Salad: Cold shreds of (raw?) potato with chili oil. This is super refreshing and comes with a kick. I love the refreshing crunchiness of the potato shreds and it had a tartness to it as well. Great palette cleanser in between different dumplings.Beef & onion dumplings: Came in a steam basket. SO ridiculously juicy. Almost like a soup dumpling. The meat was super soft. The skin is thin enough where you can see the juice inside, but firm enough to hold it together without it bursting open every time you pick it up. So tasty!Shrimp, Pork & Leek dumplings: Boiled dumplings that come on a plate. Super refreshing fresh taste. The chopped up pieces of shrimps were nice and bouncy. The pork was juicy and soft. Leek provided the "soup" in the dumplings a light sweetness. Loved it.I suggest making your sauce with equal parts soy and vinegar with a dollop of chili oil (all available on the table). Service was fine. Nothing horrible and nothing spectacular. Overall, this is my favorite dumpling place in Chicago! Will return asap!

47.description: Made to order dumplings full of flavorful soup, meat (and veggie). The lamb and cilantro/coriander dumplings came out piping hot from the bamboo steamer, while the pork and shrimp ones came out on a plate - couldn't tell why they were served differently, but in general the mode of eating in the Richland food court is pretty no-frills.  For two hungry yelpers, we had the two orders of dumplings and a set of four lamb skewers, which were packed with chili-herb flavor too.  All in all, a tasty snack or meal stop at a place that might seem tucked away and hard to find - steamed dumpling-seekers will not be let down.Edit: Qing Xiang Yuan has since moved upstairs and has their own storefront on Wentworth, a stone's throw from the Richland center where they were in the underground food court.  A bit easier to find, so I hope their dumplings are as good as they were at their previous location!

8.description: best. dumplings. in. chicago!!! go, get an order of steamed lamb & coriander dumplings and change your life. sooooo good! they're probably somewhere between a regular dumpling and a soup dumpling, incredibly juicy and filled with flavor. I was tempted to order a second platter to myself! the lamb kebabs and potato salad were also great. the kebabs had a great spiced taste and the potato salad was nothing like i've had before, slightly raw straws of potato that were refreshing and crunchy. my only dislikes, we also got chicken heart and gizzard skewers - both came out cold, chewy and completely unappetizing (mind you, i've had both of these parts before deliciously prepared, so it wasn't an eating weird organs issue). the service is typical - asian place in chinatown, crap. other than these things, it's great food at a great price, and i'll be coming back asap!!

31.description: Found this place on yelp. Very best dumplings. Order the beef and celery which is their best seller! The entrance says number 103 which is kind of confusing. They are right next to the food court. 5 stars!

34.description: This place is so good the dumplings where soHot and juicy the first two times I went thereI got three plates of dumplings with my son .Be also got these meet sticks and cucumber salad. The second time I got the same thing but instead of cucumber salad we got potatoSalad and it was good to.So good!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

16.description: I got some soup dumplings to supplement the noodle soup from another restaurant in the food court. I asked the front person for her best recommendations, of which she said the lamb + coriander and pork + shrimp. They came out in a steam basket, very warm and delicious. It was a tad annoying because it was difficult to pry the dumplings off the wicker basket. If you've had soup dumplings, you know how sad it is when they prematurely burst and you lose all the delicious broth.There were about 16 dumplings per order, priced around $9 each.

13.description: Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings is located in the food court of Richland Center.  There you can find many other types of restaurants, shops, and even a barber.  The restaurant specializes in dumplings which are the only options on their menu.  Don't fret my friends, they do offer a wide array of dumplings so there are something for everyone (unless you don't like dumplings...then I have no clue why you are even considering this restaurant).The dumplings are made to order, so be a little patient.  I shared an order of 16 dumplings with my sister.  We opted for the pork, shrimp, and leek dumplings.  The dumplings were delicious: piping hot, bursting with flavor, and oozing with soup.  Be careful biting your first bite, the juices are super hot and you can get burned.If you want a quick and satisfying snack, definitely give this place a try.  The owner is extremely nice and can help you make a decision if you can't decide.  Don't forget to use the vinegar and hot oil for that added flavor.

11.description: Note: No longer located in the food court basement of the Richland Center. It is now located a few doors down on street level and have their own location.Very courteous and attentive staff. Dumplings came out very quickly and were nice and hot! We had the pork and coriander and they were excellent.

39.description: Very impressed with our first visit. We had seen the encouraging Yelp reviews when they were a hole in the wall in the basement, but never tried it.  Now that they lost the "dive" feel, we went for it and we are so happy we did.  We had lamb and leek dumplings (really good but not for those that are only into very lean meats), chicken and mushroom dumplings (also really good, and better for the lean meats crowd) and shrimp, egg, leek (good, but next time we'll try something else).  The cucumber salad is marinated with fresh ginger and it was a great side to the dumplings. Come early! We were the first ones there at 11, and it was packed by the time we left at noon. I'm not going to deduct stars for it because it did not affect me this time, but the couple that sat next to us as we were almost leaving tried to order chicken dumplings and they were sold out.  Not sure what good excuse can there be to sell out an hour after opening.

37.description: In the late hours of Thursday Dec 17, my recent visit included a piece of clear hard plastic approximately 1 inch long and 1 cm wide in the lamb and leek dumpling. The owner was very kind to remove the lamb and leek dumpling from my bill and gifted me a $10 gift card for my next visit. While everything I tried was delicious, I cannot get over almost slicing the inside of my mouth open on a piece of plasitc.

0.description: Hands down the best dumplings in Chicago. Love their food!! Oh did I mention they have awesome skewers too? The owners (couple) of the store are  awesome as well -- you can easily tell their unparalleled passion and superb devotion into their business, and more importantly their food, which is often in stark contrast with many other restaurant owners in Chinatown. They open everyday and, as a native Chinese, I could only wish I get to eat here 24/7.

38.description: This is what home tastes like.We love the lamb+dill the most.Ps I think they have moved up to ground floor or will be very soon.

51.description: this place is in the Richland Mall.  we were a bit lost because no one could help us locate where this was.  it was actually really easy.Go inside the front entrance of Richland Mall.  look to your left and you'll see some stairs.  go down those stairs.  the food place will be on your left about 3-4 places down.got the shrimp and pork dumplings.  very good.  soft and juicy.  the outside wrapping was okay.  good but I've had better.overall, I liked it!

27.description: Definitely will come back again. Their dumplings (steam ones) are so good, it was like eating xiaolongbao but better! I tried their lamb dumplings and pork dumplings and the flavor of the lamb ones stood out. I also tried their skewers too, beef and lamb and they were good too. I will try their spicy soup stew next time, since I saw many people ordered this when I was there.

32.description: Note: No longer located in the food court basement of the Richland Center. It is now located a few doors down on street level and have their own location.Very courteous and attentive staff. Dumplings came out very quickly and were nice and hot! We had the pork and coriander and they were excellent.

54.description: These are the best dumplings I've ever had.  The lamb and coriander especillay are so good. I'd recommend bringing cash, be ready for a short wait (depending on how busy it is) because they don't use pre-prepared dumplings.

48.description: Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings was so good, I went there two days in a row.  Amazing little dumplings!  You order at the counter, grab a seat and wait about 15-20 minutes for them to wrap and steam or boil them.  They ring the bell and gesture to you when they're ready.  Hold off on eating them right away, because they are piping hot, but once they cool down, you can just pop them in your mouth - there's a wonderful burst of "soup" and flavorful meat.I really enjoyed the lamb and coriander, pork and shrimp, and pork and leek.  The lamb is the most unique and flavorful, but there is strong lamb flavor so you would have to like the taste of it.  The pork and shrimp is equally good, and I would say pork and leek had less flavor compared to the other two.  I would have no problems eating a whole order (18 dumplings) by myself, but my friends thought you could share one.  We also tried the lamb skewers, which were also a winner!  These didn't have as strong of a strong lamb taste, rather more of the spices.Food is excellent, but the Richland Food Court is rather depressing.  On my last trip, a phone was snatched off a table by the entrance, so I would be very careful about watching out for your belongings.  Fortunately, this place is moving upstairs soon!

44.description: I was one of the earliest people to discover this gem in the basement of Chinatown. Now, they have moved to the ground level to what used to be the Thai place. The dumplings are the best, my favorite is beef with celery steamed. The price went up a bit because of the new location. But the environment has become so much better and can host more people. I recommend this place to anyone who want authentic northern style dumplings.

24.description: Pretty good. Delicious food, nice waiter, and hospitable managers. Really good restaurant

7.description: This place has moved from the Richland's food court to the old Sala Bua Restaurant which is only a couple shops from the Richland building. Instead of going in the Chinatown strip it is located outside the strip where you can see the train station across the street. I Absolutely love this place. My experience at the new place was even better than the old place.

49.description: Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings is located in the food court of Richland Center.  There you can find many other types of restaurants, shops, and even a barber.  The restaurant specializes in dumplings which are the only options on their menu.  Don't fret my friends, they do offer a wide array of dumplings so there are something for everyone (unless you don't like dumplings...then I have no clue why you are even considering this restaurant).The dumplings are made to order, so be a little patient.  I shared an order of 16 dumplings with my sister.  We opted for the pork, shrimp, and leek dumplings.  The dumplings were delicious: piping hot, bursting with flavor, and oozing with soup.  Be careful biting your first bite, the juices are super hot and you can get burned.If you want a quick and satisfying snack, definitely give this place a try.  The owner is extremely nice and can help you make a decision if you can't decide.  Don't forget to use the vinegar and hot oil for that added flavor.

40.description: The food is top-notch, and I have to leave a five star review because I love the lady who (I guess) owns the place. She's so sweet and she made me feel the day is brighter :D

53.description: I don't care how good the food is, if I get treated like crap, spoken down to and ignored because I speak Cantonese and not Mandarin, this is definitely not a place for me.  I was excited to give this place a try. I heard a lot about how amazing (and inexpensive) the dumplings were here so when my cousin and I decided to do an early, impromptu dinner in this basement food court, I was thrilled.  The basement food court definitely isn't much to look at..  low ceilings, empty storefronts and a funky smell; definitely not the most attractive place.  We arrived at the dumpling booth which is actually 2 booths.  One side had the dumpling menu and the other side had a big red sign with  things like chicken skin, pig stomach, intestine, etc.. and a picture of a bowl brimming with these items..  I was intrigued as I had no idea what this was so I asked the guy behind the counter what it was and in his broken English he says something that I can't understand.  So I speak to him in Cantonese and asked him what it was.  He was absolutely incensed that I spoke to him in Cantonese because he spoke Mandarin and at this point, he waves me off.  I guess I was dismissed for asking him what the item was?  or was I dismissed because I spoken Cantonese?  So, I walked away and went over to the noodle soup place and ordered what turned out to be the most fantastic bowl of beef brisket noodle (thin noodles, please) soup... I'm telling my cousin (who lives in Chinatown) about the dumpling guy and she tells me, "Oh yea, they get that way when you don't speak Mandarin"..  I told her I spoke English first..  which I guess didn't matter because I'm Chinese (American born and raised on the North Side of Chicago, not Chinatown).  I was pretty pissed off at this point because it was so rude.  My cousin tells me that no one down there is nice to anyone because they don't have to be.   I guess they're a pretty popular spot and my 2 orders of dumplings don't mean squat to them.  They would rather be rude to me because I'm not "like them"...My cousin ordered a plate of their dumplings and I had a few..  They were decent but I would never go back to that place because their attitudes were horrid..  I would sooner fly out to Seattle and eat at Din Tai Fung or Kung Fu XLB in NYC or even upstairs to Hing Kee for dumplings than to spend a dime in this place...I don't care how good your dumplings are... rude behavior is never tolerated or acceptable to me.

30.description: Damn...this place is awesome!!! Listen, if you r living or visiting Chicago, u have to go here! Most of the menu items are 8$~10$ for a really huge plate of steamed or boiled dumplings stuffed with fresh and perfectly seasoned fillings, with plenty to share! Great food, great price especially for the huge portion size, great service and pleasant atmosphere made me a great experience!

46.description: Amazing lamb dumplings and the owner is so friendly! He had my two orders ready in less than 10 mins so I don't know why people said it takes forever. Either way - super fresh and soooo worth it. YUM

1.description: I had been a huge fan of their food court location and was so psyched to hear that these guys opened up a restaurant. I really wanted to give this place 5 stars but sadly I had to knock it down to 4 due to service/wait time.I'll start with the good:We came in early in the evening and got a table with no problem. We ordered right away and the food came out pretty quickly. (There was a mix-up with our order but we managed to catch it on the ticket before the food came out and the server was sweet about it.)Now, the food was FANTASTIC! It was every bit as good as I remembered it from the food court, and it looked like quite a few new options had been added to the menu. Despite the absurdly long wait (more on that later), I still thought it was all well worth it because the dumplings were just so damn delicious. The price is a bit higher than the food court, but that's to be expected given the added overhead of a restaurant and still very much worth it. As a huge Northern Chinese food snob, I'm really excited to finally have a decent dumpling place in Chicago! Definitely my go-to dinner place in Chinatown from now on.Now the bad:About 10 minutes after getting our food, we decided we wanted a second serving of dumplings and placed the order with our server. A few minutes after this, a big rush of people came in and the restaurant was filled to capacity. We sat around waiting for 10+ minutes before the server came by and asked if we were ready for the bill. I reminded her of our second order and she-clearly having forgotten about it-rushed off to print out a second ticket. At this point, she tells us that it'll be a bit of a wait before our food comes out. Well the wait turned out to be a FULL HOUR between when we placed the second order and when the food actually came out. I assume they ran out of dumplings and had to make a whole new batch, in which case they really should've given us a better estimate of the wait time! By the time our food came out, our parking was about to expire so we scarfed down our piping hot dumplings (burning my tongue along the way), rushed to pay the bill, and ran out of there. Our server was very apologetic, which is why I'm not more mad, but boy. Lesson here is be prepared for the wait because this place is clearly not equipped to handle the increased traffic of having a sit-down location.

55.description: Tucked in the basement of the Chinatown food court near Chinatown square is a hidden gem for freshly home-made dumpling that is made to order from scrap. Orders can take up to 20minutes , but it's so fresh and good. It's so great to finally have a good place that serves good dumpling (forget Ed's dumpling), because this place puts other place to shame.  I usually order the lamb coriander which is steam, therefore its almost like a soup dumpling when you take your first bite. Other favorite would be pork/cabbage and chicken/leek. Price ranges from $6 to $8 for 18 dumplings to each order. Very generous!! Dont forget the seasoned lamb skewers that is $1.25 piece. It's very well seasoned and tender! Cash only and you can call in advance to place your order. Sometimes, I come here twice within a week, because it's comfort food!

9.description: Crave amazing dumplings? You've heard of xiao long bao (aka XLB or Shanghai soup dumplings), right? Well, these aren't soup dumplings but rather juicy dumplings. Qing Xiang Yuan delivers divine dumplings in a secret location that is literally off the map - the food court of Chinatown which I never knew existed until recently. Like many carts/merchants in Asia, Qing Xiang Yuan specializes in one thing and does it very well. These dumplings are full of juice from the fat that melts from the filling as they are cooked. They have more juice/soup inside of them than other places that were supposedly xiao long bao. One bite, you'll immediately notice that each one is freshly handmade since everything is made to order and the filling is packed with meat juices. It's like the Gushers Fruit Snack from the 90's for northern Chinese dumplings. These delicate and flavorful little pillows are heavenly. The great thing about Qing Xiang Yuan is that there is no secret menu, you don't have to order in Chinese, the food is consistent, and each order is pretty large. The real secret is the location. Just go down the alley, take a left, down the stairs, and it's the third or fourth vendor. I don't know what Qing Xiang Yuan means but my guess is that it literally translates to Heavenly Meat Juice Gushers Dumplings.

26.description: This is my favorite place in Chinatown, hand-made dumplings, very fresh! Tastes so good!

25.description: #1 Dumpling. Much Flavor.I had the lamb and cilantro dumplings, which were tasty.  I found the food court setting to be kind of depressing, and there was no cell reception down there, so I'm glad to see they have upgraded to a storefront location.

12.description: I only gave this place two stars because the dumplings were tasty BUT:-The service was terrible. There are about 15-16 tables at this restaurant and on the day we were there there were about 5 servers and yet we had to ask 3 times for water. When we asked for tea they brought it in water glasses and claimed they ran out of tea pots and mugs.-The dumplings were very expensive. Each order of about 16 small dumplings costs about $15 each, one pork and one beef. The meat was not high quality (there were bits of tough meat and gristle) and although the dumpling dough was homemade I don't think the quality met the cost.-The servers were rude. Every time we asked for something we were met with confused looks and exasperated sighs. We tried to ask for some help with the menu as well but perhaps there was a language barrier.-Various groups of people left during out time there as folks were waiting 30-40 minutes to get any food or even service. The restaurant is small there was no excuse for that.I may give them a bit of the benefit of the doubt because our visit was on the day of the Chinese New Year Parade but the restaurant should have been better prepared for the rush. I had heard great things about these dumplings but we left disappointed.

59.description: Best dumplings I've had in Chicago. No frills, just simple tasty handmade goodness. Go check this joint out.

21.description: Excellent dumplings and bbq skewers in a bright, modern space.  Try the dumplings steamed, they're juicier that way.  My favorite is the lamb with coriander.

17.description: Good reviews brought us to this dumpling joint on a Saturday night. We were seated immediately. The restaurant is fairly clean and the types of dumplings are cleverly etched into wood panels as decor. For dumplings, $8 for 16 is a bit pricey. However, all the dumplings we ordered were tasty and you could tell they were homemade. We ordered, pork and cabbage, pork and mushroom, and leek/egg/shrimp. My favorite was the leek/egg/shrimp. There was only a subtle difference between the pork/cabbage and pork/mushroom. We also ordered the beef appetizer. This was very traditional and tasty. The dipping sauce that comes with it makes the dish. Overall, I like the food, and while dumplings are generally not that expensive, these are a bit on the pricier side.

10.description: I certainly don't understand the hype.  It s just a place with boiled everything.  Everything was bland.  I'd be embarrassed to take anybody here.  But if you re on a tight budget, this is probably for you.

5.description: Great place for dumplings! Wow.Only thing they really have is dumplings. Not so Wow.We came here to try some authentic chinese food. Only had one order of dumplings and left to find another place for a meal.(Go4food)Dumplings were awesome, but that is it.

3.description: I love this place for dumplings, but that's all there is...dumplings. Dumplings to me are an appetizer or snack. You will not find a full Chinese menu here. I was hungry. 16 dumplings wasn't enough, but 32 dumplings is like eating too much of one thing. Service is decent, but the tables are too close to each other. I am not a fan of sitting so close to a table that I am part of their conversation.Portion is 16 dumplings to an order.  They are offered as steamed, boiled, or uncooked. I think that means you take it home and steam them or boil them yourself.I'd probably go back, but only if I'm in the mood for dumplings. It's kind of like Bubba Gump Shrimp of the dumpling establishments.

35.description: Tonight we returned to our fav - Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings - for amazing, juicy steamed dumplings, when we discovered they had moved upstairs to a storefront about 4 doors to the right, as you face the original door you would have entered to race to the dumpling counter in the food court downstairs.  LUCKILY, the dumplings are still absolutely delicious and come steaming hot! So "pop into your mouth" cautiously!  We like them steamed, but if you like them even juicier and don't want to "fight prying them off the bamboo surface of the steamer"  then order them boiled. They come on a beautiful red plate and are also amazingly juicy. OR try one of each style. There are 16 dumplings per order ($9+ per order) - but bite size - my hubby and I can each eat 16! And we did tonight...sharing two orders of dumplings.Then we ordered a "new item" on the menu - 8-9 lamb chops for $16.99. Great price for small tender lambchops that are baked then broiled in a delicious, spicy (cumin) and slightly hot (red pepper) rub.  They went PERFECTLY with our lamb dumplings.  You know, the combo of juicy lamb dumplings and crispy, dry broiled lamb chops is unbeatable.  I am dreaming of going back right now!We didn't stop there...we also ordered some kabobs - why not beef kabobs and beef dumplings, or pork and pork?  All the kabobs are tiny, chewy and nicely spiced. They are $1.50 a stick.We ordered 6 sticks, but you can just try a few and decide.  We love them with dumplings too!I've heard that they have delicious soups and other dishes, but we've eaten here over 7 times and never get past the dumplings!  Yum, Yum! Watch out about the tea - it's $2.50, but they have an interesting variety, so worth a spurge if you are into teas.  Otherwise, it's definitely a destination for "foodies" who love dumplings.Staff? There were 4 waitstaff. They can handle the volume, but still need a little training.  The owner/manager/chef is the same person who ran the dumpling counter in the food court.  She always has a friendly smile and loves the food as much as those who eat there. Often, she'll come out and ask how the guest like the food. It adds a nice touch to the atmophere.Atmosphere is stylishly casual.  More wood in the design, yet the green and white walls lighten up the place.Reminds be of the rustic hometown in China where these dumplings must have be first served.

19.description: Made to order dumplings full of flavorful soup, meat (and veggie). The lamb and cilantro/coriander dumplings came out piping hot from the bamboo steamer, while the pork and shrimp ones came out on a plate - couldn't tell why they were served differently, but in general the mode of eating in the Richland food court is pretty no-frills.  For two hungry yelpers, we had the two orders of dumplings and a set of four lamb skewers, which were packed with chili-herb flavor too.  All in all, a tasty snack or meal stop at a place that might seem tucked away and hard to find - steamed dumpling-seekers will not be let down.Edit: Qing Xiang Yuan has since moved upstairs and has their own storefront on Wentworth, a stone's throw from the Richland center where they were in the underground food court.  A bit easier to find, so I hope their dumplings are as good as they were at their previous location!

28.description: If you eat here, you will die from dumpling overload. The dumplings will come out very quickly and they will explode all over the inside of your mouth. After eating you will quickly go into dumpling coma and will have to take a nap. I went to here right after getting off the airplane because i read it was going to be delicious and it was. I also had the lamb chops and spicy stew. I ate the lamb chops for two days. Very inexpensive and very tasty. My stomach would give it two thumbs up if it had some hands.

45.description: Excellent lunch! I travel for a living and eat out all the time. The owners put love in their dumplings. Will return next time I'm through Chicago.

33.description: The dumpling here are awesome.  They are fresh and made to order.  Started as a small booth in the Richmond mall and now they have expanded to a dine in restaurant.  I'm looking forward to dining at their new location real soon.

43.description: They moved from the basement food court to the ground level of the same building on the side. Nice space with wait staff now and a little bit of expanded menu with a few more items in general.

2.description: This is probably the only authentic dumpling place in Chicago. They pretty much only serve dumplings....about 20 kinds. Each order was about $10 and had 16 pieces. Give it a try if you don't feel like any other cuisine in Chinatown.Don't get their cucumber salad. It's too salty.

18.description: I'm sad I found this tucked away dumpling spot so late in the game, otherwise I would have spent more hard-earned money on these fantastic dumplings. We'll just call it QXY, and it's located in the underground Richland shopping mall that's only sparsely populated at all times.First of all, the minus one star is for the absurdly long wait time it takes to get these dumplings. It's a double-edged sword, really. QXY handmakes all its dumplings to order (you can watch them being made in the stall), which is a plus-plus in my book. That means the make plus steam for an order can and ought to run you 20 minutes. That's a fine wait for these delectable pockets of tasty. Unfortunately, if there's any number of orders ahead of yours, the wait time increases three-fold. We always paired the dumpling order with a bowl of soup from neighboring Yummy Yummy Noodles. Those bad boys come out in five minutes, whereas a typical dumpling order has ranged from 30-60. All of this is a roundabout way of saying that if you want to eat these things without an absurd wait, call ahead and be prepared to speak Chinese, or come at a very off time and hope there isn't a plethora of orders ahead of yours.As for the actual dumplings themselves, they rock, as you'd expect from made-on-the-spot. Each order comes with 18 dumplings for a very reasonable price ($6 on the cheaper end, $9 on the higher). If you're coming into dumplings entry-level, try the pork and cabbage (or pork and coriander if anti-green). If you're feeling bolder, go with a lamb choice. Those can be steamed "soup dumpling" style in a traditional bamboo steamer, providing an extra oomph of juice into every bite. There are other beef, chicken, and seafood options to satisfy your fancy.There's no special sauce here, but QXY provides an array of soy sauce, vinegar, and chili oil to create your own.

41.description: They reopen in a much better place, and I think the quality of their dumplings are still the top one in Chicago. Best food need more time to prepare. I have waited for about one hour today for my dumpling, and the owner explain to me that they are make the dumping when they received the order, so they may take one hour to prepare our food with high quality when It is busy. If I have time, I could wait for that. And the environment is comfortable, we could enjoy the Chinese TV show.

52.description: Crave amazing dumplings? You've heard of xiao long bao (aka XLB or Shanghai soup dumplings), right? Well, these aren't soup dumplings but rather juicy dumplings. Qing Xiang Yuan delivers divine dumplings in a secret location that is literally off the map - the food court of Chinatown which I never knew existed until recently. Like many carts/merchants in Asia, Qing Xiang Yuan specializes in one thing and does it very well. These dumplings are full of juice from the fat that melts from the filling as they are cooked. They have more juice/soup inside of them than other places that were supposedly xiao long bao. One bite, you'll immediately notice that each one is freshly handmade since everything is made to order and the filling is packed with meat juices. It's like the Gushers Fruit Snack from the 90's for northern Chinese dumplings. These delicate and flavorful little pillows are heavenly. The great thing about Qing Xiang Yuan is that there is no secret menu, you don't have to order in Chinese, the food is consistent, and each order is pretty large. The real secret is the location. Just go down the alley, take a left, down the stairs, and it's the third or fourth vendor. I don't know what Qing Xiang Yuan means but my guess is that it literally translates to Heavenly Meat Juice Gushers Dumplings.

50.description: These dumplings were delicious!  We got three orders for three starving travelers & got stuffed silly.  We got pork & leek, pork & cabbage & by the counter gal's strong recommendation, the lamb & coriander.  Each person liked their order the best, so even though we shared, it all worked out well. FYI: The owner told me that they would be closing this storefront about the end of the month & having a grand re-opening as a restaurant upstairs on the second floor on Dec. 9, I believe.  I guess I looked like a local, so I'm doing my part & sharing this on Yelp for you all!

4.description: Yes! I've been here when they were a vendor in the basement of the dead mall. It was great then, but the service was slow and I thought it was pricey for a mall foodcourt.Now that they opened a storefront, it's totally worth every penny! Here's why:What we ordered:Potato Salad: Cold shreds of (raw?) potato with chili oil. This is super refreshing and comes with a kick. I love the refreshing crunchiness of the potato shreds and it had a tartness to it as well. Great palette cleanser in between different dumplings.Beef & onion dumplings: Came in a steam basket. SO ridiculously juicy. Almost like a soup dumpling. The meat was super soft. The skin is thin enough where you can see the juice inside, but firm enough to hold it together without it bursting open every time you pick it up. So tasty!Shrimp, Pork & Leek dumplings: Boiled dumplings that come on a plate. Super refreshing fresh taste. The chopped up pieces of shrimps were nice and bouncy. The pork was juicy and soft. Leek provided the "soup" in the dumplings a light sweetness. Loved it.I suggest making your sauce with equal parts soy and vinegar with a dollop of chili oil (all available on the table). Service was fine. Nothing horrible and nothing spectacular. Overall, this is my favorite dumpling place in Chicago! Will return asap!

6.description: Qing Xiang Yuan Dumplings was so good, I went there two days in a row.  Amazing little dumplings!  You order at the counter, grab a seat and wait about 15-20 minutes for them to wrap and steam or boil them.  They ring the bell and gesture to you when they're ready.  Hold off on eating them right away, because they are piping hot, but once they cool down, you can just pop them in your mouth - there's a wonderful burst of "soup" and flavorful meat.I really enjoyed the lamb and coriander, pork and shrimp, and pork and leek.  The lamb is the most unique and flavorful, but there is strong lamb flavor so you would have to like the taste of it.  The pork and shrimp is equally good, and I would say pork and leek had less flavor compared to the other two.  I would have no problems eating a whole order (18 dumplings) by myself, but my friends thought you could share one.  We also tried the lamb skewers, which were also a winner!  These didn't have as strong of a strong lamb taste, rather more of the spices.Food is excellent, but the Richland Food Court is rather depressing.  On my last trip, a phone was snatched off a table by the entrance, so I would be very careful about watching out for your belongings.  Fortunately, this place is moving upstairs soon!

22.description: This place has moved from the Richland's food court to the old Sala Bua Restaurant which is only a couple shops from the Richland building.
