Instead of going in the Chinatown strip it is located outside the strip where you can see the train station across the street. I Absolutely love this place. My experience at the new place was even better than the old place.

15.description: most authentic chinese homemade dumpling in chicago, all the dumplings there are hand madethey used to be in the basement and recently moved upstairs and finally have a store front, it might  be a bit chaotic now as they are short staffed, but i think they will get past this and continue to serve the awesome food they havemust try dumplings are the lamb or the seafood onesthe spicy soup is pretty good too

57.description: I got some soup dumplings to supplement the noodle soup from another restaurant in the food court. I asked the front person for her best recommendations, of which she said the lamb + coriander and pork + shrimp. They came out in a steam basket, very warm and delicious. It was a tad annoying because it was difficult to pry the dumplings off the wicker basket. If you've had soup dumplings, you know how sad it is when they prematurely burst and you lose all the delicious broth.There were about 16 dumplings per order, priced around $9 each.

20.description: Something must have been amiss the Friday night when I came to the restaurant at 8:30pm. The reviews are quite remarkable here, and even Eater had a special citing the dumplings as worth making a special visit for. The tables had dirty dishes on them, and we were initially sat at a table with dirty dishes as well. We waited nearly 10 minutes to be brought menus. I went to the front of the restaurant and had to get them myself. We ordered dumplings, which judging from the one $ rating must have been raised since the restaurant moved from the food court downstairs to this street level location. Many dumplings were nearly $14 an order, and my party ordered 3 orders at a more normal price of $8 to $9. Chinatown is full of very inexpensive restaurants with high quality food with above average portions. Thus we thought one order of dumplings per person would suffice. This was far from the truth. We waited literally 55 minutes for the food to come, as we were counting each minute since we were already eating late and very hungry. We ate the orders (which had 14 dumplings each) and we finished them in 10 minutes. Clearly you need at least 3 orders per person if you're hungry, as we waited nearly a hour for only the portion of an appetizer. The waiter apologized profusely for the long delays, but given the lack of value and the truly horrible dining experience I sadly have to give a 1*, which I do not like doing. Apparently a waiter canceled last minute, and that was the reason for such delays. If you come here hopefully the restaurant is operating at what I assume is a high level for its 4.5* average rating!

36.description: most authentic chinese homemade dumpling in chicago, all the dumplings there are hand madethey used to be in the basement and recently moved upstairs and finally have a store front, it might  be a bit chaotic now as they are short staffed, but i think they will get past this and continue to serve the awesome food they havemust try dumplings are the lamb or the seafood onesthe spicy soup is pretty good too

14.description: Damn...this place is awesome!!! Listen, if you r living or visiting Chicago, u have to go here! Most of the menu items are 8$~10$ for a really huge plate of steamed or boiled dumplings stuffed with fresh and perfectly seasoned fillings, with plenty to share! Great food, great price especially for the huge portion size, great service and pleasant atmosphere made me a great experience!

58.description: Beware of this place. The employees are extremely rude and yesterday when I picked up my food they gave me an incorrect order. I told the staff to not serve it because I had already put my hands in it to confirm whether it was shrimp fried rice like I ordered, but discovered it was chicken fried rice instead. The employee still took the entree and tried to give it to correct person who ordered it. How disgusting...they should remake the order. Unsanitary and that was done directly in front of me, so extremely scared to see what they do when customers aren't watching. The food may taste good, but do you know where it came from or how it was prepared or whether it dropped on the floor or not? If you aren't confidently answering those questions then I would suggest finding somewhere else to eat. This will be my last time eating here, which sucks bc I actually like their food.

56.description: We ordered delivery from Lao Sze Chuan tonight.  We opened the bag of food and half a dozen cockroaches ran across our counters.  Tried to throw all of the food in the trash and the dumpster before any escaped into our apartment.  We are so thoroughly disgusted!  We have eaten at the restaurant many times before, but we will never be back and we will never order from the restaurant again.

29.description: I looked forward to this place for an entire week.  I knew it would be the night that Chicago would get its first anticipated snow for the season and I wanted to share the magical hot pot meal with my friend as it would be his first experience.  So many things went wrong.  1. One of the main waitresses seemed like she was purposely ignoring us, even after speaking to her in Mandarin.  When I told her I was interested in the hot pot, she grabbed the menus from our hands and left.  The cool part about hot pot is choosing your ingredients and I was left sitting there really confused, thinking she would come back and ask.  Instead, she brought out this party snack platter of a random stuff.  Stuff that I didn't want and don't usually eat in my hot pot.  I had to ask for beef and some other meat otherwise I'd just be eating $17 worth of mushrooms and pre-packaged fish balls.  The other younger waitresses were pleasant but the main waitress was just rude.  If you hate your job that much, quit and become a basket weaver or whatever makes your cranky ass happier.2.  I am very, very, VERY disappointed in the quality.  The frozen shrimp was disgusting, fish balls were the cheapest of the variety and the sliced meat seemed to be frozen and the meat tasted old to me.  Even the "dipping sauces" were given to you in this huge container that looked like it's been passed around a bit. Garlic (not even fresh garlic), Chinese bbq sauce and the peanut sauce were the only things that came out.  What about cilantro, vinegar, green onions, or anything else? At the end of our meal, one of the employees takes it away the old containers and puts it near the registers which I am 99% it's going to be given to the next hot pot victims. I understand that certain restaurants do this, but it was quickly noticed that quality and cleanliness are not the highest priority for this place.  I guess that's why they were given a bad health inspection review.  I won't go into details, but it's bad and believe me, I wouldn't have gone if I found it before I went.3.  When we left my friend noticed their back kitchen door was open and a huge crate of our shrimp sitting on the floor unattended.4.  My friend's stomach hurt soon afterwards and I told him that it might be something else until my stomach started hurting a couple of hours later after his.  My iron stomach has been through a lot of random eating and NEVER hurts.  I've traveled to countries where refrigeration is more of a luxury and never had a stomach issue this bad.The only good thing about the experience was that the ma la (spicy) section had great flavor.

42.description: Due to being my lunch hour, I was only able to try the basics. Orange chicken, hot and sour soup, and pot stickers. I am definitely willing to come back and try various dishes while dining in next time. One question, I was actually in the mood for an egg roll, umm no egg rolls here ?! Interesting. To be continued....

23.description: Note: I've been here twice. I can't remember the first time well because I was with a big group and the food was not the center of attention, but I think I was satisfied. This post addresses the second time, when I had a terrible experience. I added an extra star to reflect an average of these two occasions. -------------------------------My family went to this restaurant some time ago and we were quite disappointed. The food was ok to mediocre, but service was extremely poor. I rarely reduce my rating for service unless it is noticeably bad, but this was one of those exceptional cases. I think that because we went during a long weekend, the customer volume was high and the waiters were over-worked. One of the guys looked like he already swore to leave the labor force forever once his shift was over. While busy season is not really an excuse for a restaurant to ignore service quality, I did cut them some slack. The first problem was our soup. We got a pickled cabbage soup, but a few minutes later, the waiter came out with a spinach soup, saying that there was no more cabbage soup and proceeded to convince us that there was not much difference between the two anyhow. Of course, you don't need to know anything about Chinese cuisine to figure out that this persuasion was doomed to fail, and we refused the soup altogether. Next we got a braised chicken dish that we never ordered. We got to keep it - I always love free food - but I had to imagine that some other group was going to become very upset...Our snow pea leaves then came and they didn't look right. Usually, they are dark green and leafy, but these were light green and consisted purely of stems that were hard to chew. If you search "snow pea leaves" on google, you'll see pictures of this beautiful, luscious dish, mmmmm. But we were not granted this pleasure. They were nearly inedible (my Chinese parents then said something about the ambiguity of the word 豆苗 (dou miao) that could have caused this discrepancy, but I barely know the language; please don't judge if you speak fluent Mandarin). The one other dish we ordered was nothing remarkable, but it was correct. I don't want to write any lies, and so will not try to name the dish. Besides that, the second floor seating area (which is more of an annex, for when the first-floor area is filled) has no foyer, so every time someone enters the restaurant, you'll be greeted with a blast of air. In the winter, beware. At least ask to sit away from the entrance if possible. It was in the low 30s and blustery when we went, so you can imagine how pleased we were to get that free air-conditioning in the wrong season.

47.description: I truly find this place delicious and I wouldn't mind to come here again. Maybe it's the crowd that makes me believe this place is something special, or the entrance door covered with Yelp, Gogobot, Chicago reviews, newspaper etc. stickers to make sure everybody knows this place has been reviewed on every platform and has been rated excellent.I would say this is a restaurant you should dine in when you visit Chicago's Chinatown. It says Szechuan but I don't think every single dish is spicy.The menu is huge and it will be difficult for you to pick a dish unless you go with the usual Panda Express' Orange Chicken lol.The dishes we ordered were great. The service was very friendly at all time. I only wish all of them speak English.Check-In for free Spring Roll

8.description: We entered on Sunday around 11 and there weren't too many people around. Meanwhile, next door, there were about 40 people standing outside and waiting to get into Ming Hin. I guess that should have been a sign.Firs, the menu is huge; maybe ten pages long. We were given water, a kettle of hot tea, and a plate of kimchi, which was a nice surprise. The kim chi had a good spice on the back and a nice flavor. We ordered six dishes and they all came out within ten minutes, so good job by the kitchen. The veggie spring rolls were fine, nothing special. At least they were crispy. And thanks to checking in on Yelp, we got an extra order for free! The Mongolian beef was the highlight of the meal. Steak, green onion, mushrooms, and onions were stir-fried in a garlic and ginger sauce. I would definitely order this again. The dry chili chicken is tremendous, but you better like some spice. It was crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside, so I was more than pleased. The shrimp fried rice was a very good standard rice dish. We also got a seafood stir fry with shrimp, scallops, and squid. Plus, we had a side of Szechuan veggies. Both dishes had that clear broth, which we really don't care for. The seafood, in particular, tasted like it was steamed or boiled instead of having that nice sear which I really enjoy when I eat Chinese food. Both those dishes were pretty disappointing. Here's the thing. The menu didn't list detailed descriptions of the items. So if you ever go here, make sure you know exactly what you're getting. In baseball terms, this would be a solid double. Good in some ways, but could have been better in other areas.

31.description: Not awesome vegetarian options, but heard good things about the dim sum. Awesome service and fast too

34.description: Came here on a Friday night around 8:00.  When my boyfriend and I arrived, there was no one at the host station by the door, so we just walked in.  This led to about ten minutes of awkward standing around, trying to get the attention of an employee and essentially being ignored, until the host appeared.  After this we were seated and ordered crab rangoon, shrimp lo mein, and of course, the dry chili chicken.  The food was good, but nothing crazy amazing.  We did appreciate the BYOB aspect of the restaurant, despite the $10 corkage fee.  If only our first impression had been a bit better!

16.description: It's been said over and over again but I will say it again ....the dry chicken chili is amazing.  I was hot to begin with when I sat down, so when I started sampling this dish, the steam literally rose from my scalp fogging up my reading glasses.  Even in the middle of a full on hot flash, I could not resist taking more and more bites of this dish.Even though the peppercorns were quite numbing, the flavors of all the ingredients still came through.  The chicken was fried perfectly, and there were no strange poultry pieces parts that you might come across at lower quality Asian restaurants.  The Ma Po Tofu was silky and spicy, and the cabbage slaw had good crunch and a good bite.  I'm going to try and recreate the chicken recipe at home tonight.  If it even comes semi close to the real thing, I will be a happy, albeit, hot little camper.

13.description: As a new resident of Chicago, and a lover of any and all things Asian related, I was SO excited that Lao Sze Chuan was the restaurant that took my Chinatown virginity. I ordered (truthfully way too much food) the Pot Stickers, LaLaLa Chicken Pot, and the hostess gave me some complimentary spicy cabbage.This was hands down the best Chinese food I have ever had in my life. And that says a LOT because I have eaten Chinese food, at one time in my life, for 7 days straight. After all these years of thinking I've experienced the best, I hadn't. Until now. When the menu says spicy, it MEANS spicy. Which almost made me want to hug the chef considering when I go to some Thai restaurants and specifically ask for my dish to be extra spicy, I don't even sweat. Not at Lao Sza Chuan. My nasal cavity was leaking 1/3 of the way in and I had to stop. I was so depressed, because I wanted to finish, but I couldn't. It was amazing. Those pot stickers...superb. Moist, savory, just the perfect appetizer. I LOVED the garlic infusion with the spicy cabbage. It was the first "taste" when I bit into a few pieces. This too was SPICY. The ONLY reason why I simply cannot give the restaurant 5 stars is because ( as most everyone else has said ) the service lacks in comparison to the great food. I had to wave down 3 different people for a straw, to take my order, a refill, the bill, a box. Had the service rivaled the food, I would have given LSC a 5 star review. But this food. Was heavenly. It tastes MUCH different than what Americans expect Chinese food to taste like. Will definitely return.

11.description: Good stuff, not the best, but great for the price. It's a bit cheap of an environment (the one in Chinatown), and kind of creepy when it's not busy, but I wasn't disappointed. Next time I might order something a but pricier on the menu just to see what they've got for the big spenders!

39.description: I love Chinese food because of that place... Just wish it is not always as crowded!!!

37.description: Craving some Chinese and ended up here tonight. Heard it was one of the better restaurants in Chinatown, so we gave it a try. It was good, but def not the best. After we sat down, we waited a while for the waitress to come over and get our orders. When she finally did, trying to get orders in was tough! She hard a really hard time understanding English, which led to just pointing to the number on the menu. (FYI if you don't speak the language and they don't speak yours, joint point to what you want) We had the spring rolls, sizzling rice soup with shrimp, Hunan chicken, tenderloin beef with broccoli, and shrimp with pea pods & cabbage. Spring rolls were ok. Sizzling rice soup didn't have much sizzle to it. Literally. And it was a thick texture- not the kind of soup I'm used to. Wasn't a fan. The shrimp with pea pods & cabbage was boring. But the Hunan chicken & the beef with broccoli were really good! Def recommend those. After a few bites of the very spicy Hunan chicken we realized that we never received waters- had to flag down our lady for those.....not sure if I'll be back here. I'll try another place next time.

0.description: Spicy Chinese food in the city!Rolled in here on a cold rainy day to warm up.The boiled beef was excellent very spicy and their ma po tofu  was also very good to have. Very small location but they do a good job with the service as well

38.description: OMG they have a sign that says Best Chinese Restaurant in The USA. LOLThat is furthest from the truth. I ordered soup, Veggie fried rice & szechaun chicken.They bought the entrée first, then the fried rice 4 mins later & the soup last.I said to my self is that right? When I received the entree it had so much oil, that it looked like a heart attack on a plate. I ordered light sauce and my waiter totally ignored it so I sent the item back. After that the waiter never came back to the table, he sat down with 5 other employees and started eating while the restaurant was full of people. I witnessed one customer get up and go to the back and get his own napkins. I only had one napkin the entire time I was eating, 1 glass of water in a dirty glass. By this time I was done I received the bill from the bus boy, so I took the left over food and gave it to the homeless people on the street in front.I have been going to China Town since I was a kid & this by far is the 2nd worst joint in China Town...... Good Luck if you choose to eat there.....

51.description: Let's run through some Chinatown reviews, shall we? First up is Lao Sze Chuan, arguably the cornerstone of Chicago's traditional Chinatown. It's also the crown jewel of the soon-to-be-defunct Tony Hu "Lao" empire that seemingly occupies every other square foot of Chinatown--Hu's intent is to sell most of his properties and refocus on the Lao Sze Chuan brand. Of course, you're not concerned about all that busy-ness, so let's get onto the food.If you like spicy food (and you probably should if you're searching for Sichuan cuisine), Lao Sze Chuan is the place for you. Your options are not exactly limited to hot and hotter, but most of the best stuff trends that way. Nevertheless, I'll present you with a nice menu to give you the non-hot optionality.The mapo tofu is a signature dish here, and it's very, very good. It's surprisingly vegetarian, though a ground pork option can be added. For those that haven't had mapo tofu, it's basically tofu in a black bean sauce. Lao's is, of course, the traditional sichuan style and heavily doused in the peppercorn chili oil that signifies the regional cuisine. Base spiciness of this dish isn't as hot as others (like the forthcoming dish) but still packs a kick for the uninitiated.If you want spicier, try the dry chili chicken. You can't mask the chilis in this dish, since they're cut and intermingled throughout tasty pieces of popcorn-fried chicken bits. Helpful hint: the chilis aren't there for eating.Looking for a a milder chicken dish? The three cups chicken ("san bei ji") is for you. Rather than using chili oil, this dish focuses on the Asian triumvirate of soy sauce, rice wine, and sesame oil. There's more of a sauce base as well to douse on your rice. Also note that the chicken is bone-in. It's a nice complement to mapo tofu, in that you can sauce your white rice with both a sweet and a spicy element.Finally for some greens, go with the deep fried green beans. Lao gives you the option of spicing it up (see the dry chili chicken section) or with the traditional, non-spicy version. It's a nice, semi-healthy break from the other, rich dishes.Contrary to what you might have heard in the news, cockroaches are not on the menu (even if they may be in the kitchen). Chalk it up to business as usual in any major city Chinatown.

27.description: This place really should get 4.5 because of their bad service. Inconsistent bad service I should add. I had ordered a beer and I got it kind of warm. The waitress stated she didn't have any more colder ones should she did what ever she could to chill that beer for me. But it wouldn't be fair to rate it 4 stars. You can't come in here expecting good service. If you're picky please don't bother because you will leave upset and end up giving this place a 1 star and hold up a table for us who just really want good food. The Three Chili Chicken is so far my favorite entree. Not really spicy for my taste but just enough u crispness to it. Enough spice to make the chicken taste so delicious. Definitely my favorite spot in China Town.

32.description: The Orange Chicken was the worst I have ever had. More like a piece of overcooked leather than a piece of meat. Service was sparse and rushed. Perhaps too many items on the menu. The food court mall where they are located is dirty and falling apart.  I'm NEVER going back there.

54.description: Delicious food and the service is even better! Linda, our friendly server, gave us complimentary herbal tea to best sooth our palette while always having a friendly smile. Seriously, for a restaurant in Chinatown, I was stunned by the level of customer service. Every person here had a smile on their face to compliment the incredible food.

48.description: Ordered this for the first time tonight since it's my "cheat night" and was extremely disappointed. Delivery was about an hour and a half and they got my order wrong. My roommate and I ordered two entrees, asking for fried rice instead of white. The entire order only came with one side of white rice (since we ordered two entrees, shouldn't we get two??). If it's not possible to substitute the white rice with fried rice I wish it would be stated online so that I'm not heartbroken after having my stomach set on fried rice only to see I received white. I also ordered potstickers and was completely turned off because they were undercooked on the inside; I had to fry them myself in a pan to cook them all the way, which defeats the whole purpose of ordering take-out. I only get one cheat day a week and I would rather waste my calories (and money-this place was kind of pricey too) on something that's worth it....I'm most likely not going to order from here again which is rather disappointing since I decided to try this place because of it's good reviews.

44.description: It's been said over and over again but I will say it again ....the dry chicken chili is amazing.  I was hot to begin with when I sat down, so when I started sampling this dish, the steam literally rose from my scalp fogging up my reading glasses.  Even in the middle of a full on hot flash, I could not resist taking more and more bites of this dish.Even though the peppercorns were quite numbing, the flavors of all the ingredients still came through.  The chicken was fried perfectly, and there were no strange poultry pieces parts that you might come across at lower quality Asian restaurants.  The Ma Po Tofu was silky and spicy, and the cabbage slaw had good crunch and a good bite.  I'm going to try and recreate the chicken recipe at home tonight.  If it even comes semi close to the real thing, I will be a happy, albeit, hot little camper.

24.description: If I could give ZERO stars I would! We walked in and the waitress took one persons order (mind you it was ten of us) and then she walked over to another table and took another parties order. It was literally the absolute worst experience that I have EVER had!!! I will never eat there again...oh and we never received water. The reviews about the horrible service are 100% credible. If you value your time and your food, do not eat here!!!!!! I repeat, DO NOT EAT HERE, MAKE ANOTHER CHOICE!!

7.description: I live on Mary st. In Bridgeport.  I usually order 5 extra prawns. Our daughter has become hooked in the sesame chicken.  Everyone has been polite when i make  pickups occasionally so this place is one i would always recommend.

49.description: This place is not accommodating to African Americans. I have witnessed rude behavior (on restaurant worker's part) on many occasions, they either make Black people wait an extra long time for the food that they've ordered and paid for or just have an attitude to tell them they aren't welcome there. I don't know about all the locations, but this one is definitely bias ..

40.description: The lunch specials are cheap and good but since I'm not Chinese and nor do i eat almost anything they eat so the only dish I liked was sesame chicken. Yea... I am very disappointed coming here but it looks like a great place for the native people and a lot of white people are here. They look like they are enjoying their dishes.

53.description: last time I went to this place， the owner was also there and welcome customers. Pretty good food，fast serving，wonderful food. I have been to this place for three times，pretty good. But keep in mind，the Lao Sze Chung in Michigan Ave is just so so，even though they owned by same person，they do have different sevice and taste！

30.description: Worst experience ever.  My companion and I agreed that service, for a lack of a better word, was comptemptuous.  We arrived after lunch while the waitstaff enjoyed a meal together in the dining room.  After we were pointed to a table, we waited 25 minutes before finally asking if we could have menus. 10 minutes later, a party of two was seated in front of us, shortly thereafter a man behind us.   Eventually, they inquired about our order, but only after first taking those of the other parties.   Our server was abrupt and clearly not all that inclined to table service.  She cut me off continuously as I placed the order.  Our food arrived haphazardly - the spring rolls were, as previously mentioned, served at room temp.  We received our chicken dish at the same time we were served our dim sum.  About 10 minutes later we were served our rice and second entree.  It was a total cluster.Boiled beef - I've had it on numerous occasions, but apparently there was some kind of beef shortage on Friday because there was little to no protein in the huge bowl of chile gravy it was served in.  I placed an order for the spicy cabbage, hoping to pay for a full size portion, not just what they comp every table.  No such luck.  Everything else we ordered was marginal at best.  First time ever I noticed that we were unwittingly being charged for rice.  Had they asked me, I would have gladly ordered and paid for rice, but we weren't afforded the opportunity.  Additional eye openers:  the men's room was, according to reports, swarming with flies.  It's right by the kitchen.  Also, the waitstaff was dutifully filling wonton wrappers from a huge vat of pink material that I've hopefully never put in my mouth.  In addition, the server that brought us our check smelled like she'd just taken a bath in a dirty ashtray.  This smell lingered and was inescapable.  Tony, you may want to take a more hands on approach managing the restaurant.  Nobody seemed to be in charge.  The place was almost empty and yet our service was shockingly poor.  The food was barely passable.  Lao is a shell of its former self.  It's really too bad.

46.description: We entered on Sunday around 11 and there weren't too many people around. Meanwhile, next door, there were about 40 people standing outside and waiting to get into Ming Hin. I guess that should have been a sign.Firs, the menu is huge; maybe ten pages long. We were given water, a kettle of hot tea, and a plate of kimchi, which was a nice surprise. The kim chi had a good spice on the back and a nice flavor. We ordered six dishes and they all came out within ten minutes, so good job by the kitchen. The veggie spring rolls were fine, nothing special. At least they were crispy. And thanks to checking in on Yelp, we got an extra order for free! The Mongolian beef was the highlight of the meal. Steak, green onion, mushrooms, and onions were stir-fried in a garlic and ginger sauce. I would definitely order this again. The dry chili chicken is tremendous, but you better like some spice. It was crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside, so I was more than pleased. The shrimp fried rice was a very good standard rice dish. We also got a seafood stir fry with shrimp, scallops, and squid. Plus, we had a side of Szechuan veggies. Both dishes had that clear broth, which we really don't care for. The seafood, in particular, tasted like it was steamed or boiled instead of having that nice sear which I really enjoy when I eat Chinese food. Both those dishes were pretty disappointing. Here's the thing. The menu didn't list detailed descriptions of the items. So if you ever go here, make sure you know exactly what you're getting. In baseball terms, this would be a solid double. Good in some ways, but could have been better in other areas.

1.description: They wouldn't redeem their Yelp check-in offer. They seemed upset that I would even suggest it. Why would you offer a check-in offer if don't want people to use it?Horrible customer service!! The food is also nothing special.

55.description: So the ma po tofu at Lao Sze Chan is supposed to be one of the 50 things to eat in Chicago before you die. Well, it was good, and I'm glad I tried it (thanks, Juli!) but not spectacular. The dry-rubbed ribs were interesting & different, with lots of what I believe was cumin, but were more like tiny dry rib tips, a little crispy like chicharones, and not worth the price. The complimentary spicy cabbage was nice, sort of like a milder kimchee, and the $2.50 spring rolls we got free with the Yelp check-in (after the server looked frightened, said she had to ask her manager about, and ran off to do so-twice, making us wait in between, but finally brought) were fine but just like Panda Express, nothing special. But they were cancelled out by the unexpected $2.00 charge for white rice, that we didn't order or expect to be charged for, but which normally comes with any large dish at a Chinese restaurant, and which had either some undercooked or overcooked grains of rice in it. This was my second time here, accidentally, and the last time was about equally ok, but with worse service that time. So next time I'll probably go to any of the other 100 Chinese places around there, maybe one with a delicious duck hanging in the window. They do have a large selection of what appeared to be authentic (and rather scary) Chinese dishes so it's probably a good place to go for that. But I've been to China and the food was pretty awful so no, thanks. You might like it though.

9.description: Don't EVER order from this shambles of a so called 'restaurant' - they have no idea how to run a business, absolutely ridiculous delivery times and disrespectful staff. There are a 1000 other Chinese restaurants you can order from, do NOT use these amateurs.

26.description: Seriously? More than one hour wait, almost an hour waiting for our food and we never even got their "spicy cabbage" side dish for starters. I swear their food better be blowing me off my feet if they're going to have such a slow service like this.

25.description: The only reason why I don't give a zero is cause I can't.1. The manager implied that we should tip more just cause we didn't reserve the seat before we walked in.2. After we were seated, we waited for more than an hour waiting for our food.3. The food tastes good, however, everything is warmed up rather than fresh-cooked. I don't understand why we need to wait for such a long time if they are not even cooking it during that time.This place is soooooo over-rated and over-priced. I am more than disappointed.

12.description: Let's run through some Chinatown reviews, shall we? First up is Lao Sze Chuan, arguably the cornerstone of Chicago's traditional Chinatown. It's also the crown jewel of the soon-to-be-defunct Tony Hu "Lao" empire that seemingly occupies every other square foot of Chinatown--Hu's intent is to sell most of his properties and refocus on the Lao Sze Chuan brand. Of course, you're not concerned about all that busy-ness, so let's get onto the food.If you like spicy food (and you probably should if you're searching for Sichuan cuisine), Lao Sze Chuan is the place for you. Your options are not exactly limited to hot and hotter, but most of the best stuff trends that way. Nevertheless, I'll present you with a nice menu to give you the non-hot optionality.The mapo tofu is a signature dish here, and it's very, very good. It's surprisingly vegetarian, though a ground pork option can be added. For those that haven't had mapo tofu, it's basically tofu in a black bean sauce. Lao's is, of course, the traditional sichuan style and heavily doused in the peppercorn chili oil that signifies the regional cuisine. Base spiciness of this dish isn't as hot as others (like the forthcoming dish) but still packs a kick for the uninitiated.If you want spicier, try the dry chili chicken. You can't mask the chilis in this dish, since they're cut and intermingled throughout tasty pieces of popcorn-fried chicken bits. Helpful hint: the chilis aren't there for eating.Looking for a a milder chicken dish? The three cups chicken ("san bei ji") is for you. Rather than using chili oil, this dish focuses on the Asian triumvirate of soy sauce, rice wine, and sesame oil. There's more of a sauce base as well to douse on your rice. Also note that the chicken is bone-in. It's a nice complement to mapo tofu, in that you can sauce your white rice with both a sweet and a spicy element.Finally for some greens, go with the deep fried green beans. Lao gives you the option of spicing it up (see the dry chili chicken section) or with the traditional, non-spicy version. It's a nice, semi-healthy break from the other, rich dishes.Contrary to what you might have heard in the news, cockroaches are not on the menu (even if they may be in the kitchen). Chalk it up to business as usual in any major city Chinatown.

59.description: Good food especially if you like real authentic spicy Chinese food! The host at the door was quite the character. His voice was as loud as his jewelry! Very kind and very entertaining gentleman. I would have given five stars if it wasn't for the service. It appeared that they may have been under staffed, because it was a while to get service and we had to flag different servers each time we needed something. At the end of our stay, it was the waitress who was so kind that I have to give her kudos for being so sweet!

21.description: Lao Sze Chuan, Yes, one of my favorite and most popular Chinese food in Chicago. visited last Friday with my family. Of course, we had an hour wait in line. the staffs are friendly, and served us nicely. we ordered dried chili chicken ( must order item), boiled beef with sze chuan sauce, crispy lemon shrimp . they were amazing. I will definitely recommended this place and will come back.

17.description: Seriously? More than one hour wait, almost an hour waiting for our food and we never even got their "spicy cabbage" side dish for starters. I swear their food better be blowing me off my feet if they're going to have such a slow service like this.

10.description: Great place to come if you want some high-quality szechuan food. I have only been here during non-peak hours (like an hour before prime dinner and lunch times), and I have found it to be quick! The food is great and the hot tea you get is also very satisfying (although I always get a cup of iced water as well..).The dan dan noodles are quite delicious and are better than many other places that I have had dan dan noodles. I think they're spicy enough to give you a bit of a sweat but not melt-your-mouth spicy. The spicy beef in hot sauce (which I have a picture of) is my absolute favorite. It has a lot of beef and some other veggies. You'll feel amazing if you eat this.The spicy beef noodle soup is also a nice dish to start the meal with. I tend to order this one on the milder side just to prime my mouth. Finally, the dry chili chicken is VERY good but VERY VERY spicy. Highly recommended, but just order with caution.If you come here you definitely will not leave disappointed!

5.description: Lao Sze Chuan is authentic Chinese as you can get. The service sucks, they don't speak very good English, they don't honor the Yelp check in freebies and they forget your orders.  If that doesn't say Chinese, I don't know what does. LSC was given a Michelin Bib Gourmand in 2012-13 and I'm not surprised that they loss it. Why? Cause they're Chinese and don't give a flying f*ck about no damn Michelin award. I'm part Chinese and I don't give a flying f*ck about awards.  I only care about direct monetary awards and instant gratification.  If it don't make dollars, it don't make sense. Anyway, we had a few items on the menu that had me sweating as if I was Jonah Hill taking a walk to the kitchen. 1) Three Cups Chicken - This was a pretty good Three Cups Chicken. The dish was served in a melt pan versus the typical pot associated with the dish.  The sauce was almost completely absorbed by the chicken.  There was still a little drip when you went to grab the juicy bits of chicken thighs.  The combination of sweetness and spiciness was really good.  It had a crispy texture to it like orange chicken.    2) Dry Chili Chicken - This was probably my favorite dish.  The taste and texture of the chicken was similar to popcorn chicken but the spices and seasoning was much better.  The crispy salty batter and the tender juicy pieces of chicken thighs with a sh*t load of dry chili that'll have you sweating like you jumped out of the shower.  It was an overall good dish to be consume when throwing caution in the wind and forgetting the consequences of tomorrow's bowel movements.3) Boiled Beef - This was my least favorite dish.  The beef tasted very bland and the soup tasted like it was water topped with chili peppers.  It wasn't a very exciting dish.  It seemed like they added the chili peppers to mask the embarrassment of the dish.  It's kind of like how people in the office always go to a different floor to drop a deuce.   Overall, it's a good authentic Chinese restaurant with your typical characteristics like bad service and MSG.  Did you know MSG is naturally produce in aged beef?  Now, you know why you get sleepy after having a large piece of steak. Also, you're not a very bright person if you expect good service from an authentic Chinese restaurant.  You have better chances of winning the lottery.  Therefore, expecting good service from an authentic Chinese restaurant is like expecting Donald Trump not to make a mockery of the election process.

3.description: I truly find this place delicious and I wouldn't mind to come here again. Maybe it's the crowd that makes me believe this place is something special, or the entrance door covered with Yelp, Gogobot, Chicago reviews, newspaper etc. stickers to make sure everybody knows this place has been reviewed on every platform and has been rated excellent.I would say this is a restaurant you should dine in when you visit Chicago's Chinatown. It says Szechuan but I don't think every single dish is spicy.The menu is huge and it will be difficult for you to pick a dish unless you go with the usual Panda Express' Orange Chicken lol.The dishes we ordered were great. The service was very friendly at all time. I only wish all of them speak English.Check-In for free Spring Roll

35.description: The food was pretty mediocre, especially the string beans had way too much salt.

19.description: We went on a non busy snow day started with the egg roll and crab rangoons. Both delish. The flavor of the egg rolls were so good. Crab Rangoons were thick and tasty. Onto Mongolian beef and eggplant in garlic sauce...it was perfect. I've eaten so much Chinese food throughout the US but by far the best I've had. Great flavors. The wait staff was very nice. I would go back again and again.

28.description: Went there for the Hunan beef and thought it was excellent.  It glad a good pepper and garlic taste.

45.description: Love this place. No wonder why their customers left positive reviews. Good food and good service. They greeting you with smiles and my shimp and lobster sauce was so delish. a 5 star with no doubt.

33.description: We have ordered aubergine in garlic sauce and that turned out to have some pork pieces in it. So that isn't a pleasant experience at all.

43.description: Pretty good Szechuan food. Got the spicy fish in broth, and Kung pao chicken. Both had a really nice kick to them, and a great amount of flavor. Located right at the edge of a Chinatown plaza and open late as well. Love love love it!

2.description: This place calls itself the "best Chinese restaurant in the USA." Not so much. Definitely not the worst, by any means, but the best? No way. Don't get me wrong; we didn't have any major issues with our food. My spicy food loving friend was happy with the spice in the boiled beef. My Mongolian tenderloin was nice and tender. My daughter was good with her orange chicken. The spring rolls were fine (used the Yelp check-in freebie). However, nothing was overly flavorful, blew us away, or was any better than what our local Chinese restaurants have to offer back home. The servers seemed overwhelmed and had a difficult time keeping up. One brought a dish out to a couple just as they gave up on it and were about to leave. Another group next to us ordered additional food and the server forgot all about it. I wouldn't tell anyone not to go, but don't expect to be amazed.

18.description: Lao Sze Chuan is by far my most favorite Chinese food I've ever had in any city. Is it greasy, unglamorous, and spicy as all hell? Yep. But its no frills authenticity is what makes it, in my opinion, so good.We got the hot chili chicken since everyone we talked to told us we HAD to get it (I don't eat meat but my fellow foodie deemed it worthy of everyone's praise), the spicy sole filet, and the spicy fried rice (the first time, which just made our meal too painful) and regular fried rice (the second time). We also got the grilled squid the second time, but it wasn't the highlight of our meal...This is the kind of food you have one night, you feel sickly full and your mouth is on fire all night, and then you crave it every day until you return. Service was quick and helpful. All around one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago!!

41.description: First time visiting Chinatown. Worst dining experience I've ever had. We waited for 20 mins+ until our table was greeted after being sat. Because of this we ordered our drinks, apps and entrees all at once. We waited for another 40 minutes until our entrees came out...before the apps (which we never received 1 of the 2 apps we ordered) furthermore we were given the wrong chicken dish but we're too hungry to say anything. Waitress never checked on us at any point during the meal either. We then waited for another 20+ mins to have our meal boxed up after eating. Meanwhile this entire time the table behind us hand great, timely service which was completely frustrating. Food was bad but didn't live up to the hype either. Long story short, go to a different restaurant! Horrible service!

52.description: Place just got shut down because they had roaches in kitchen! Never again!

50.description: We were told by someone who lives in China that this is the best Chinese food in the USA so we had to try for ourselves. We were not disappointed at all. Agreed this was an amazing place with authentic Chinese food as the flavor was outstanding. Very glad to try something other than pizza & hot dogs for our 1st time in Chicago.

4.description: I looked forward to this place for an entire week.  I knew it would be the night that Chicago would get its first anticipated snow for the season and I wanted to share the magical hot pot meal with my friend as it would be his first experience.  So many things went wrong.  1. One of the main waitresses seemed like she was purposely ignoring us, even after speaking to her in Mandarin.  When I told her I was interested in the hot pot, she grabbed the menus from our hands and left.  The cool part about hot pot is choosing your ingredients and I was left sitting there really confused, thinking she would come back and ask.  Instead, she brought out this party snack platter of a random stuff.  Stuff that I didn't want and don't usually eat in my hot pot.  I had to ask for beef and some other meat otherwise I'd just be eating $17 worth of mushrooms and pre-packaged fish balls.  The other younger waitresses were pleasant but the main waitress was just rude.  If you hate your job that much, quit and become a basket weaver or whatever makes your cranky ass happier.2.  I am very, very, VERY disappointed in the quality.  The frozen shrimp was disgusting, fish balls were the cheapest of the variety and the sliced meat seemed to be frozen and the meat tasted old to me.  Even the "dipping sauces" were given to you in this huge container that looked like it's been passed around a bit. Garlic (not even fresh garlic), Chinese bbq sauce and the peanut sauce were the only things that came out.  What about cilantro, vinegar, green onions, or anything else? At the end of our meal, one of the employees takes it away the old containers and puts it near the registers which I am 99% it's going to be given to the next hot pot victims. I understand that certain restaurants do this, but it was quickly noticed that quality and cleanliness are not the highest priority for this place.  I guess that's why they were given a bad health inspection review.  I won't go into details, but it's bad and believe me, I wouldn't have gone if I found it before I went.3.  When we left my friend noticed their back kitchen door was open and a huge crate of our shrimp sitting on the floor unattended.4.  My friend's stomach hurt soon afterwards and I told him that it might be something else until my stomach started hurting a couple of hours later after his.  My iron stomach has been through a lot of random eating and NEVER hurts.  I've traveled to countries where refrigeration is more of a luxury and never had a stomach issue this bad.The only good thing about the experience was that the ma la (spicy) section had great flavor.

6.description: Worst experience ever.  My companion and I agreed that service, for a lack of a better word, was comptemptuous.  We arrived after lunch while the waitstaff enjoyed a meal together in the dining room.  After we were pointed to a table, we waited 25 minutes before finally asking if we could have menus. 10 minutes later, a party of two was seated in front of us, shortly thereafter a man behind us.   Eventually, they inquired about our order, but only after first taking those of the other parties.   Our server was abrupt and clearly not all that inclined to table service.  She cut me off continuously as I placed the order.  Our food arrived haphazardly - the spring rolls were, as previously mentioned, served at room temp.  We received our chicken dish at the same time we were served our dim sum.  About 10 minutes later we were served our rice and second entree.  It was a total cluster.Boiled beef - I've had it on numerous occasions, but apparently there was some kind of beef shortage on Friday because there was little to no protein in the huge bowl of chile gravy it was served in.  I placed an order for the spicy cabbage, hoping to pay for a full size portion, not just what they comp every table.  No such luck.  Everything else we ordered was marginal at best.  First time ever I noticed that we were unwittingly being charged for rice.  Had they asked me, I would have gladly ordered and paid for rice, but we weren't afforded the opportunity.  Additional eye openers:  the men's room was, according to reports, swarming with flies.  It's right by the kitchen.  Also, the waitstaff was dutifully filling wonton wrappers from a huge vat of pink material that I've hopefully never put in my mouth.  In addition, the server that brought us our check smelled like she'd just taken a bath in a dirty ashtray.  This smell lingered and was inescapable.  Tony, you may want to take a more hands on approach managing the restaurant.  Nobody seemed to be in charge.  The place was almost empty and yet our service was shockingly poor.  The food was barely passable.  Lao is a shell of its former self.  It's really too bad.

22.description: this is my favorite restaurant in Chicago!!! I come here every time when I in town. That's my first plan here ever!!!

15.description: The only reason why I don't give a zero is cause I can't.1. The manager implied that we should tip more just cause we didn't reserve the seat before we walked in.2. After we were seated, we waited for more than an hour waiting for our food.3. The food tastes good, however, everything is warmed up rather than fresh-cooked. I don't understand why we need to wait for such a long time if they are not even cooking it during that time.This place is soooooo over-rated and over-priced. I am more than disappointed.

57.description: The food was great. The crispy chicken with red chilies was very spicy, coming from a person who loves spicy food. Would be 5 stars, but the service was subpar. I will be back for the hot pot, heard it's the best in the city.

20.description: Terrible - STAY HOME. Currently been waiting for almost an hour and a half at the table. Table is greasey and bathrooms are disgusting. Water at table is disgusting/funky, egg rolls are cold in the middle. Still waiting for meal. NEVER AGAIN!!!

36.description: Just sat down for 20 minutes and waited for someone to take our order while groups of people that came in after us were served their appetizers before anyone even took our order. We left .

14.description: My first visit to Chinatown may be my last.  I've had Chinese food all over the world and expected pretty good food in Chinatown, but boy was I disappointed.  There were 8 of us, so we had a lot of selections and NONE were comparable in quality to what we get outside Chinatown.  The best I can say about this place is that the food was edible and I did not get sick, beyond that, nothing.  Yech.  And  that is without mentioning the non-existent service.

58.description: It's okay..not very impressed with the food. Doesn't really taste "Hong Kong". Plus the person didn't really get my english... *sigh. Good thing i know chinese.We ordered the beef chow fun and the xo turnip cake.

56.description: Sweet station delivery review.A solid 3.5 star Chinese food. Ordered delivery. Only gripe was a little slow, took 1h20.The dumpling noodles were done very well. The sesame orange chicken was deliciously seasoned with msg, and the spicy lamb rocked! Definitely worth ordering. Chicago however does suffer from lack of good Chinese food.

29.description: I only ever come for the dirt cheap breakfast combos, so I can't comment on lunch and dinner offerings. But MY GOD! A bowl of congee, a plate of shrimp rolls/crepes, an egg tart, and a cup of warm honey lemon tea for $6.50?! You can also switch out the congee + noodle/crepes for a bowl of delicious beef brisket and rice noodle soup (also with a cup of warm beverage and egg tart) for $6. RIDIK.Service is standard at best. Most times, the waitresses act like they can't care less about your business. But to be honest, at the price of their breakfasts, I seriously wonder whether they are even making a profit from my meal. Point being, don't come here expecting great service. However, if you are looking for delicious, filling, dirt cheap food, these breakfast combos will not disappoint.

42.description: This place has fantastic chicken wings and slushies........my new go-to spot for Chinese when we take the water taxi!!

23.description: This review is for the hot pot only. This AYCE hot pot place is so much better than most of the joints in so. Cal. Started off with the half half hot pot which is basically half of a normal chickenish soup and the other half being a spicy and hot soup. Ordered all of the food we wanted to eat and boy when they brought out the dish I was blown away. Not only was it nicely presented but there was SOOO much food. The restaurant was seemingly clean, a lot cleaner than the ones im used to eating at. Overall I was very happy with this meal and have come back multiple times with different friends.Bonus is that its BYOB and they're open late. Let's just say I've come here after a hard night out and about.

47.description: I was sooooo dispointed with the food.  I went there just because I saw some good reviews from yelp.  The noodle I ordered was suck and I asked them switch to another one.

8.description: Went here to grab a rice box to go since it was the closest place. At one point I thought there most Chinese food places in Chinatown have pretty similar qualities, but Sweet Station proved me wrong. I got a minced pork over rice and it was disappointing. The gravy was watery, there was a severe lack of veggies and meat, and most of the box was rice. Maybe other stuff is better? I don't know because the rice box I had has already put this place in my do not return list.

31.description: This review is only for their hotpot, which I've had twice.AYCE hotpot that includes some side dishes such as pot stickers, and man tou (buns) with condensed milk dipping sauce for $24/person. Great selection of meats, veggies, noodles, some seafood, and other random Hotpot staples to choose from. Opens until 4am. Came here after the Beyonce/Jay-Z concert with my girlfriends on a Thursday or i should say, Friday morning at 1:30am; we stuffed ourselves silly, totally hit the spot after a long night of drinking, standing, and dancing.  Warning: maybe i was too engrossed in my food at 1:30am or just really lenient on everything since it was so late, but there wasn't any drawbacks.

34.description: Yummy and fair price!!!

16.description: I only ever come for the dirt cheap breakfast combos, so I can't comment on lunch and dinner offerings. But MY GOD! A bowl of congee, a plate of shrimp rolls/crepes, an egg tart, and a cup of warm honey lemon tea for $6.50?! You can also switch out the congee + noodle/crepes for a bowl of delicious beef brisket and rice noodle soup (also with a cup of warm beverage and egg tart) for $6. RIDIK.Service is standard at best. Most times, the waitresses act like they can't care less about your business. But to be honest, at the price of their breakfasts, I seriously wonder whether they are even making a profit from my meal. Point being, don't come here expecting great service. However, if you are looking for delicious, filling, dirt cheap food, these breakfast combos will not disappoint.

13.description: I would rate them 0 if it's possible. Their delivery service is HORRIBLE!! I waited for 2+hrs for the delivery but still didn't get it. People answered the phone is rule and unhelpful. Don't Order from Sweetstation. Period.

11.description: I love their all you can eat hot pot. The other food taste ok... I came here once for breakfast, but got stomached afterwards. Not 100% sure if it's b/c of the food though.

39.description: This is definitely one of the best value restaurant. Being new to chicago however, i got a little confused as to whether waiters get tipped because waiters in this particular restaurant aren't friendly at all.

37.description: I was pleasantly surprised by this restaurant.  I had only ordered drinks to go from here before, but finally came in for dinner. They have some good stuff on their menu. Service was prompt and courteous, and the food was pretty good too! I had the wonton noodle soup and it was delicious-even better than Chi Cafe's. The wontons were bigger and fresher, and the rice noodles were perfect. I also had a bite of the beef brisket noodle soup and that was good as well. Only negative of this place was that the TVs kept flickering, so maybe reconsider if you're trying to watch an important game. Otherwise this place is great for a quick, casual, delicious bite. Will definitely be back to try out their other dishes.

0.description: Definitely one of my go to places in Chinatown! What I love: the $2 daily sweet soups (hence the name), SUPER value-driven breakfast/brunch specials (includes drink, egg tart, and congee), and their desserts (the sweet tofu is to die for).The space is a bit small, so I recommend going in more of an off time. This is one of my favorites, not only because of the food and deals, but also because it's cleaner and a more renovated compared so neighboring restaurants. Their menu is really comprehensive - you can also do hot pot, order dim sum, bring take-home goods. Service is also above average relative to Chinatown.

38.description: Eek! Methinks not! Terrible service. I kept making eye contact with the waiter to fill my water and no water was filled. The food serving was too little for the price. They don't even have the Happy Hour anymore

51.description: I am in love with their hot pot. They have multiple hot pot soup base. Very good deserts too!

27.description: We got delivery. It took them 1 hour and 50 minutes to deliver the food. The food was decent but it was luke warm. Overall, we would not order delivery here again.

32.description: I'm sure there must be better options on the menu.  We had stir fried stuff for late night eats, and taste-wise the food was so-so.  The portions and prices were reasonable.I also thought the red bean soup dessert would've been a lot more flavorful - it was rather surprising considering the place is called Sweet Station that one of the staple dessert foods didn't seem sweet at all.  Inconsistency between batches, perhaps?

54.description: My friend brought me here when I was in Chicago and I loved their food! It has a nice open atmosphere and the wait staff was very nice. We shared a rice noodle wrap (like banh cuon if you've ever had it at a Vietnamese restaurant) and "over rice" dishes. This place is great if you have a small group of friends who want to chat and eat tasty food~

48.description: I've been here many times before I joined yelp. Their food is tasty, service is quick, and servers are attentive, sometimes. But holy crap, I got terrible service today. Firstly, I had to wait a while to get our orders taken, which is atypical. Then, I had another server come by trying to take my order again, which I find disorganized and it disappointed me. All be it they were busy, but I waited a good 25 minutes or so for congee. CONGEE. Previously, it only took 10 minutes after ordering to get congee. They also forgot the dough sticks I'd ordered, but I shrugged it off. If they didn't give it to me, it prevents me from eating more fat and oil right? It took multiple tries to get their attention to pack our leftovers; which we told 2 different servers about. And then we waited again to get the check cause I guess it was hard to assume I wanted to pay and leave when I asked for the leftovers to be packed. Then they charged us for the dough sticks that we never got. Very disorganized. Service was pretty bad. I expected something different as someone who frequented this place multiple times before. :/ It's like a diner. Crap service, but decent food.I give them 1 more star than I want because the food is tasty.They will also forget that you ordered something like a bowl of noodles, or forget to give you any water to drink.

44.description: Came with a group of 14 peeps last week; very solid.  Tried about a dozen different dishes; everything with beef was incredible and there was a radish dish that was blowout.  Prices were fair (we dropped $132, and that included the 18% service fee), service was friendly but not exactly prompt, and the space is pretty small but we came in late enough on a Thursday to not be too disruptive.  This was a bit of a surprise given the other reviews I'm seeing here but I would go back in a heartbeat.

24.description: Had to give a follow up review. What a difference a week makes in service. A week ago I enjoyed my dinner here so much I brought my husband back for a dinner date for us. Well...service was a hit and miss. When we came in, no one greeted us, staff did not acknowledge us unless we tried to trip them over. I'm fluent in cantonese and asked of the the staff members if she could get me a glass of water, well water never came. We had the hotpot, which was still excellent but if service wasn't so substandard I wouldn't have wrote an update. Really felt like we had to constantly "catch" any servers attention. I'm so used to getting good customer service, I forgot how shitty customer service felt like. Well if you're looking for it, sweet station is the place to experience it. Oh and on the way out, we observed a group by the entrance complain about how many times they had to walk up to the serving area and ask the waitress for a soup ladle. They were so angry that they were cussing. Beware, you have been warned.

7.description: I love hot pot and for the most part i really like this place for AYCE hot pot (18.95)... but man I will see past many things to get what I want.. like..- i am NEVER given my entire hot pot order. EVER. i order 10 things, i get 5. i order another 5, i get 3. give me my food, gosh darnit. - the piles of food on top of more food so you never know what you actually have - an entire waitstaff that doesn't understand any english.at least it's byob.

49.description: Breakfast - COLD egg tart, maybe this is the standard in chi-town. Sorry, I am come from California. Fried Noodles, uncooked.... No comment, won't come back again.

40.description: Had Mongolian Beef, Egg Fried Rice, Udon Noodles w/Chicken, and Chicken Wings. Liked it very much. Would recommend. Had slight language issue when we ordered, which is a very good sign.

53.description: The black stuff here is really good.If not for the one time they use bad oil that making the tofu looks black, I'll give 4 star. Still will be back tho ! Cheap, yummy and opens to super late.

30.description: Clean, decent place for a late night snack. Food is ok, but it does come out quickly. I'm a big fan of radish cakes, and this is on my top 5 list for that. Service is a bit slow. Their sweet desserts tend to sell out quickly, sadly.

46.description: Try their condensed milk mien tou!! Delicious. We had a number of dishes: 1) Deep Fried Condensed Milk Mien Tou Really good (as recommended by ABC, haha.) One of my favorite dishes growing up. It's good without the condensed milk too. For those of you who have not had this, think of a doughnut without glaze. Instead of glaze, you get condensed milk. It's so much fun dipping the mien tous (sp?)!  2) BBQ Four Things with Rice ( that is exactly what it says on the menu) They did a really good job with the meat. There was chicken, BBQ pork, and duck? I wasn't sure what the four different BBQ items were, but it was very good!3) Pea Tips with Abalone MushroomDidn't enjoy this dish. We mostly ordered to include veggies in our meal. Will not do this ever again. Haha. Just kidding. I didn't like the sauce and the Abalone Mushrooms not all that tasty. 4) Satay Beef, Golden Mushroom in Mini Wok Not as flavorful as I expected. But overall, a good dish.Admittedly, I love coming to Chinatown, but I'm always afraid that I'll get food poisoning when I walk into some restaurants. This place doesn't give the best impression when you first walk in, but the food is good enough to make me want to come back.

1.description: Sweet Station always seems to hang on to a piece of my heart through the ups and downs over the years. It started off so well providing a nice balance between value, quantity, and taste. It hit a lull a couple years ago (it turned to Groupon), but after giving it another shot, I think Sweet Station might be back.Lately, I've been having breakfast/brunch here with the family, and it has been giving us some nice service and food. The specials come with a drink of your choice (like milk tea) and a deliciously flaky egg custard tart. You'd never know it if you came in later, but Sweet Station has some excellent baos baked in house. Too bad they're sold out by mid-morning.I still prefer Chi Cafe over Sweet Station for a better ambience, but the chefs have been doing a good job in bringing this place back to its former glory. Sweet Station has been my go to for breakfast, lunch, and take-out when in the mood for Chinese. I'm glad it has stuck around!

55.description: Responding to the best Hot Pot buzz in Chinatown, my bud and I decided to dine there to see for ourselves. Okay, I'm convinced this place has the fresh varieties of meat and seafood! The electric stove top table worked great and the spicy broth was awesome. It's a BYOB and I'll be returning there for another really soon:)

9.description: Accidentally walk by this cute little place while in Chinatown. I didn't try anything else except the hot pot. Def will be coming back for the hot pot $18.95 all you can eat can't beat that. They have a large variety of items to choose from for the hot pot. Service is a little slow, but once raw items came out for the hot pot it was worth it.

26.description: The other evening I ordered a General Tso Chicken dinner. The combo seemed impressive. Large portion of chicken, and a side of fried rice and soup for only $13. At the time, the fact that there were no choices for the soup didn't seem strange to me at all. I figured, yeah these guys have a bunch of soups I am sure they will give me one of their great options. Well apparently I am not an informed consumer because they soup I received looked like month old table scraps boiled in tap water to be served and a Dickensian orphanage. At least with the General Tso's, I could at least have some confidence that what I was eating was Chicken, but with this muck I couldn't tell what animal the plentiful and various small chunks of meat came from. I am not claiming to know what canine tastes like, but the first bite of flavorless flesh I attempted to chew was so ambiguously textured that my brain was convinced that it could have been dog meat and I instantly lost my appetite. Please just send a Tupperware full of stagnant toilet water next time. The two stars are full the rest of my meal. One star for the chicken and one for the rice.

25.description: We ordered duck noodle soup n vegetarian rice wrap. The duck noodle soup was average  but the vegetarian steamed rice wrap was way too mushy. I thought I would be the responsible customer n gave feedback. I told the server that perhaps the rice wraps were steamed too long coz they tasted starchy guey n mushy. She argued with me n told me that steamed rice wrap are supposed to taste like that. Oh well. I tried. The service was good but the food not quite there. Nope,we won't be going there again.

12.description: I tried this as a change up from my regular "go to" Chinese place via GrubHub. It was a very small order and took an insane amount of time to arrive. By the time it did, it was cold and wrong. It also came delivered with no condiments or utensils. So that was a big bummer. I called about it and they did send me a new order for their mistake so I will give them that. The actual quality of food was mediocre. Definitely didn't win me over as a regular.

59.description: One star because I found a thick black piece of long hair in my hot pot meat. I told the server and she literally said "It flew in there." And walked away. I guess Chinese restaurants are the only places that you can complain about having hair in your food and they honestly don't give a shit.

21.description: Sweet Station is definitely UNDER rated. This place matches up to Chi Cafe's foods, although the menu is not as extensive. The interior design was beautiful, it was really cozy to sit in, and it just seemed really clean (although not all parts of the restaurant was clean). The service is nice and helpful and we had no problem with them. Price is cheap, quality is good, and the quantity is just right! Definitely coming back for another bite to eat!

17.description: This review is only for their hotpot, which I've had twice.AYCE hotpot that includes some side dishes such as pot stickers, and man tou (buns) with condensed milk dipping sauce for $24/person. Great selection of meats, veggies, noodles, some seafood, and other random Hotpot staples to choose from. Opens until 4am. Came here after the Beyonce/Jay-Z concert with my girlfriends on a Thursday or i should say, Friday morning at 1:30am; we stuffed ourselves silly, totally hit the spot after a long night of drinking, standing, and dancing.  Warning: maybe i was too engrossed in my food at 1:30am or just really lenient on everything since it was so late, but there wasn't any drawbacks.

10.description: Nice food and dim sum, and cheap, reasonable price, my friend love their rice rolls, I love their congee and dim sum, and they open until late night, you could do finitely try it out if you feel hungry at night

5.description: This place has grown on me for the past year, they offer the best hot milk tea and great cheap breakfast combo's in the mornings. I usually get the Early bird special with congee (rice  porridge), fried or soup noodle and a custard pie (dessert) for around $5.

3.description: If its 3am on a Wednesday in Chinatown and you're hangry, this is THE place to go. Or maybe it isn't since it was 3am on a Wednesday in Chinatown and we were one of only two tables in the joint... though who am I to judge a place based on it's Wednesday 3am crowd, of which my group makes up 50% of?We had a aight experience. Of course things got lost in translation and the service was nothing to write home about but they tried and at least 1/3 of us had an entirely edible meal, my meal was about 1/3 edible, and our 3rd's order pretty much only had rice that was stomach-able... but those donuts that Steve Dolinsky suggests are pretty darn good and the mysterious hot, creamy, white sauce actually was worth writing home about (think of a more viscous Cinnabon goo). My dining partner chose to get the super detailed, "BBQ 4 Things", on the menu... and we spent the remaining time trying to figure out what those 4 things were. One was definitely pork and we thing the other 3 were some sort of very shiny fowl with ground up bone bits in it. She ate the rice and that was about it. I got the Szechwan giant shrimp... which are only giant if you get them with the shells on (your server will ask), otherwise you get just regular sized shrimpy shrimp sparsely mixed among a million dried kung pow peppers (see pic and pray for my butthole). The whole table laughed at the thought of my impending morning and afternoon on the toilet, but it actually turned out to not be all *that* spicy, at least not for someone like me who loves spice, and I didn't suffer any unfortunate post-meal bathroom adventures either. The dish wasn't very filling because most of the peppers were really hard and broke apart like fibrous straw in your mouth, so I ate what I could but eventually gave up and just picked out everything that wasn't a hard and gritty pepper... which wasn't much.My other dining partner's soup bowl was monstrous and he seemed to love it... which was lucky for us because he then let us polish off the donuts since our meals didn't quite do our stomach's justice. Both my dining partners ordered fruit smoothies (one mango, and one lychee) and I was freezing from the torrential downpour outside so I got a Hong Kong style lemon coffee... which as it turns out, is iced. Of course. It's not a bad place... and for 3 in the morning its actually a damn fine place, but I don't know that I'd find myself here during too many regular daytime hours, though it is most affordable if you get a dish that can be eaten in full.

35.description: 3 star rating overall, I had delivery but the food came in a timely fashion and everything tasted as expected. No "WOW" moments but a safe bet to make.  Its open late too so thats a plus.Especially liked the crab rangoon. But the Stir-Fried Rice Noodle Roll with XO Sauce was quite oily so I will stay off that dish in the future. And the Orange Chicken bits were super hard & the orange-flavor was too artificial for my liking.

19.description: Easy to get lost of all the restaurants in chinatown amid the plethora of AYCE Hotpot options, but Sweet Station sure is a sweet place to go to when it comes to eating Chinese food. Came here, and heard great things about the hot pot, but also tried out their normal dishes family style. With 7 people, we ordered 6 dishes, and had MORE than enough for everyone to eat. Got the Garlic Pea Tips, Mixed vegetables(Tofu, asparagus, mushrooms) in a sort of brown sauce, hong kong ribs, Beef Chow Foon, Roast Duck, and Seafood Pan Fried Noodles. Nothing too exciting, but a good gauge of some more popular dishes. The key here is value, not culinary revotion. Fast service(water cups always full and food was out very fast), huge portions. I would probably skip the ribs next time(basically just tossed in sweet and sour sauce....too much of it), but everything else tasted as it should have and we were all satisfied.  That said, for decent food you are getting a great value. By the time we left, it was hard to even walk. And at $11/person after tax+tip, not a wallet killer either.

28.description: Their food is good once in a while. Different chefs would always switch in different shifts and that causes the lack of consistency to the food. Otherwise, everything tastes pretty good. Their Thai ice tea is always my favorite in the Chinatown area. The staff seems a little careless about the customers sometimes.. I've tried once where I've sat down for 15 minutes when it wasn't on a busy day and no one would give us a menu so we left. That was the only bad experience from this place. Overall it's OK.

45.description: There are no words to describe how good the food is!  I spent a week in Chicago and did not miss my daily stop at the sweet station.  I tried a variety of different dishes,  my favorite was the Hong Kong beef noodles,  their dim sum is pretty awesome as well.  The service is quick and the prices are decent.  If you are ever in China town,  Chicago you should definitely give it a go.

33.description: Their noodles are good. I work a late shift so the fact that they're open so late is great. Luv their pricing.

43.description: I am very impressed by this place. I went here with a large group and a friend had suggested it since he had been several times before. The place is small and quaint. Not easy to find though. We had a giant group of 14 and they were accommodating of that. The menu is GIANT. Like overwhelming, so luckily my friend just ordered for the table. I really like the radish dish. It was a weird texture but so delicious. I also enjoyed the chow mein, the flat noodles, and the other beef dishes. We had a lot of tofu, but I'm not the right person to comment on that, as tofu is not a favorite of mine. The service was a bit slow at the start but the food came out quick. I would love to go back and try some other things

2.description: I've come here during different times of the day. The most recent was for hot pot on Sunday night. One thing I need to point out is that they have hot pot delivery! You can order whatever items you want and they will deliver the stove, pot, ladles, etc! How amazing is that? Plus they pick it all up! If you order hot pot delivery 9 times, you get a free hot pot set! I've never heard of this before so I thought it was amazing. Too bad I have my own hot pot set.For our party of 5, we ordered a variety of items with the spicy and nonspicy broth. The spicy broth was definitely spicy, but it didn't have any depth. Same with the other broth. It was very one dimensional and bland. Service was spotty. Each time we ordered, they would always forget something so we would have to order it at the next round. I liked that they have crab rangoon and fried/steamed mantou as an option. I haven't seen that at other places.Overall, Sweet Station is okay. I think I prefer the seafood hot pot place on the other side of Chinatown square. They have a sauce bar and wider variety of noodles.

18.description: I'm sure there must be better options on the menu.  We had stir fried stuff for late night eats, and taste-wise the food was so-so.  The portions and prices were reasonable.I also thought the red bean soup dessert would've been a lot more flavorful - it was rather surprising considering the place is called Sweet Station that one of the staple dessert foods didn't seem sweet at all.  Inconsistency between batches, perhaps?

41.description: hot pot was ok, but the service was awful, I went today with my friend to have hot pot, there's one waiter with glasses, that was so rude to me and my friend. He place some peanut sauce, i didn't know what it was so i asked him and he gave me a weird look and ignored me well I'M ALLERGIC TO PEANUTS, this asshole didn't care after telling him lots of time i can't have that near me. Finally another waitress came and took it away. We were ignore, i had to ask for more water. This place is awful.

52.description: Love this place. It's cheap and great for breakfast time. I love the typical fried mai-tou is always amazing with condensed milk with it. Always my first choice.

50.description: Great place!! We just arrived from Reno and our host recommended this place. Delicious and affordable food, and the green passion fruit tea was to die for!

4.description: 20 minutes in, brought my plate of food out, 2 minutes later and still counting haven't brought my date's food out yet. Horrible service, mediocre food. Over priced for such bad service

6.description: This review is for the hot pot only. This AYCE hot pot place is so much better than most of the joints in so. Cal. Started off with the half half hot pot which is basically half of a normal chickenish soup and the other half being a spicy and hot soup.
