It's tasty, fresh, decently priced and fairly quick. It can get crowded on weekends fyi so jusy order your (avocado) smoothie while waiting and you'll be a happy camper. :)

20.description: wow it was a very busy place i waited about half hours to get my nuddle it still worth it food was good

36.description: If you're indecisive then this is the perfect place to go.There are hundreds and hundreds of options to choose from, many with beautiful pictures. The wait staff is constantly asking "are you ready to order yet?" While I do find them pushy sometimes, it really does help with my indecision (there's literally hundreds of items on their menu). Whats good about this is that I've yet to order anything bad. Oh and did I mention I love their smoothies, particularly the mango pineapple with black bubbles.The reason Joy Yees gets a four star instead of a five is that none of their dishes are truly amazing. They're good, adequate, and perhaps a touch expensive but nothing has ever blown me away. Joy Yees is a restaurant I go to when I have no expectations. Because, well, they're reliable and I have yet to be disappointed.

14.description: People just love the Bubble Tea and the smoothies.  There was a line out the door the other night.  I stopped in and had a seafood noodle dish.  I can't remember the name but it was just a little spicy and delicious.  Had a strawberry pineapple smoothie for dessert.  Delicious.Vincent the manager was as helpful as always.

58.description: Delicous and a great crowd pleaser!We had a group of 14 people and ordered from the family style menu...probably over 13 entrees and drinks came out to $15 per person...everyone left with a fully tummy and satisfied tastebuds!

56.description: My family and I always go here for family dinners or special occasions. It's basically our go to in Chinatown. They are very price friendly and very generous with the proportions. Some of my favorite dishes include: Beef Ho Fun, salt and pepper shrimp, pork, and octopus. Their veggies of the kon xin cai (water spinach) is really good as well. The taro duck is also delicious if you like taro. Unfortunately, the service is very inconsistent, it really depends which waitress you get..haha, but it's definitely one of the better places in Chinatown.

29.description: Excellent food. Service NOT so much.The host/ hostess pretty friendly but the waitresses not so much except when I'm w/ my Asian friends. I've been coming here for over 15 years now. Definitely, one of my favorite places in Chinatown. I love the fish fillets w/Chinese broccoli except when I found the order slip inside my food. I pointed it to the waitress and she apologetically removed it.

42.description: SMOOTHIESWe love visiting Chinatown and we make it an adventure by using the Chicago Water Taxi to arrive. It always feels like we are on vacation. One of the problems we have is that we have found our favorite places in Chinatown, so we don't really venture out and try new places. We were looking for desert, after dinner. We tried a bakery a few doors down from here and the cake was not very good. So we decided we needed a fresh watermelon drink to wash it down. We walked up to check out the menu and a lady immediately opened a window and asked what we wanted. It was great and efficient. We did not even have to walk into the restaurant. We decided to grab a fresh watermelon smoothie. The lady went behind the bar and started making our drink. We waited outside and our smoothie arrived very quickly. There is even a nice little shelf installed on the outside edge of the window. The prices were also great too. It was only $3 plus tax per smoothie. A few doors down there was another location and they were charging $4.45 plus tax per smoothie. That location was crowded. I wonder if these people knew they could save money a few doors down at this place. The watermelon smoothie was really good. In fact, I don't think I've ever had a bad watermelon smoothie anywhere. It is always refreshing and delicious. So I am happy to say we have a new stop added on to our Chinatown visits. Plus you can't beat the price of the smoothies too. Now it looks like this restaurant has a full menu. I can not comment on the food or what the experience is inside the restaurant. We only used the walk up window to grab a fresh fruit smoothie and that was a great experience.  I'm glad we now have a new stop now.

23.description: This place is deplorable.First, the service was horrible. I went when there was almost no one in the restaurant, and yet it took them 5 minutes to make me one of their fruit smoothies. I had ordered the coconut red bean tapioca, which at other restaurants, I have enjoyed. But not this restaurant! All the beans were frozen solid, and all the ice had clumped together. Essentially, I felt as if I was drinking just coconut milk. Second, the ambiance is horrible. Their tables employ makeshift pieces of wood for the spinning tray. On top of that, they use cheap plastic sheets to cover their tables for easy clean-up. How un-classy is that? Overall, the place looked somewhat tacky.The only redeeming feature of this restaurant is that some of the food isn't that bad. My group ordered a lot of dishes, and a couple of them tasted very decent, but not good enough to be in my recent memory. I do remember, however, tasting the saltiest piece of imitation crab meat I had ever had.

47.description: Many of the Chinese restaurants in Chinatown are really good but not consistently so and ditto to Lee Wing Wah. I usually go here for large gatherings of 10 or more because they have a lot of room and I can pretty much order everything, but this time we had a party of 20 and it was only so so. We had a more Americanized version of Chinese food on the menu today: Egg Rolls were okayBeef Broccoli Chow Fun had very little beef and too many noodles. Pressed Duck was too floury and greasyChinese Style Crispy Fried Chicken was good Walnut Shrimp with Mayo was good Pork Peking style was goodJapanese Style tofu with mushrooms was good Beef Short Ribs Korean Style was good but not enough to go around. Also, don't order bubble tea here, go to Joy Yee's for that.

8.description: All of their tapioca is made with fresh fruit! Finally a place that does this.  The tapioca was 5 stars all the way and probably the best tapioca I've had in Chicago!

31.description: Yummy food but service was bad AF. If you're looking to be wined and dined, go ahead and skip past this place. Cashier was rude & rushed me out speaking on how the place is closing, yet there were 3 parties still in the restaurant. Very unhappy with the rudeness but yummy fried rice!

34.description: This is our go-to place after a fierce round of golf where we order a dinner for 4 and devour it like we were lost at sea for a month. My personal favorites are the fish filet which is so tender that it melts in your mouth. The walnut shrimp is a must, but the crab is what makes our mouth water. I also like the black-bean sauce clams which are fresher and tastier than any Chinese restaurant in Chicago. I never order MSG on my food so I can only imagine how better the food can taste with the MSG.The décor is old-school and could use a makeover--especially in the bathrooms. But I admire this about Lee WIng Wah because so many new restaurants in Chicago are decked out aesthetically but can't hold a candle to the good food here.

16.description: Good Cantonese food in Chicago Chinatown.  Also, it's open a bit later.

13.description: This place is deplorable.First, the service was horrible. I went when there was almost no one in the restaurant, and yet it took them 5 minutes to make me one of their fruit smoothies. I had ordered the coconut red bean tapioca, which at other restaurants, I have enjoyed. But not this restaurant! All the beans were frozen solid, and all the ice had clumped together. Essentially, I felt as if I was drinking just coconut milk. Second, the ambiance is horrible. Their tables employ makeshift pieces of wood for the spinning tray. On top of that, they use cheap plastic sheets to cover their tables for easy clean-up. How un-classy is that? Overall, the place looked somewhat tacky.The only redeeming feature of this restaurant is that some of the food isn't that bad. My group ordered a lot of dishes, and a couple of them tasted very decent, but not good enough to be in my recent memory. I do remember, however, tasting the saltiest piece of imitation crab meat I had ever had.

11.description: We were so hungry that we didn't have a chance to review any restaurants we just walked in. We ordered Orange chicken. Let me tell you that this was the worst plate of food I ever had in my life. And you know that when your hungry you eat anything well this was an exemption. The meat was very saggy and the sauce for the chicken was plain with out taste. W ended up not eating it and order from another restaurant.

39.description: There are plenty of better places to eat in Chinatown.  This place has been consistently inconsistent.  Some dishes are okay, some are not so okay.  Sometimes I'll have a great meal here.  Sometimes I'll end up having something that just fills me up but leaves me unsatisfied.Definitely do not get the Ma Po Tofu.  Generally I don't order this when I go out, but the one here was pretty unsatisfactory.  The Chow Fun was really good though!  And the seafood I've had here has been pretty good.It's not a fancy place, but okay if you're just looking to get some decent and reasonably-priced Chinese food in Chinatown.

37.description: The exterior of the restaurant isn't fancy, the presentation of the food isn't frufru, and the older waitresses sound like they're grumpy all the time. But who cares. The food is excellent! That's all I care about. The taste and quality is exactly what I'd remembered from grade school. Two thumbs up Lee Wing Wah!

0.description: Nothing better than Chinese Christmas!! My family and I were scared that the wait would be forever on Christmas Day but Lee Wing never lets me down. The place was packed but they still seated us in less than 5 minutes. The food is delicious as usual. Family style servings ranging from typical American stomach friendly fare like sweet n sour chicken and potstickers. But they also have some yummy authentic dishes like spicy and salty smelt and lobster dishes. Open late night as well.

38.description: Pros: Cheap and tasty dishes, wonderful personnelCons: None--Been a Chicago Chinatown native for 20+ years and I find this to be my favorite authentic Chinese restaurant. The personnel are friendly and are always on the look out to refill your cup of water every second. I personally like the (1) Chinese Broccoli with Fish Fillet and (2) Deep Fried Smelts. They also have cheap smoothies.

51.description: The shrimp dishes and lobster dishes are excellent and we'll priced!  Can't wait to go back!We ordered seven dishes plus a really good curb chicken soup for five people and we had food for the next day.

27.description: My friend and I came here one gloomy Saturday afternoon for lunner/dinch. Since this was the only restaurant in Chinatown Square that wasn't completely deserted or full of non-asians, we decided to give it a try. Great first impression! The host, and probably owner, was so friendly and greeted us super nicely. We sat down and I think they served us water/tea pretty instantaneously. They gave us a few minutes to peruse the menu. We each ordered a fruit shake. My friend got a mango-watermelon with boba (it's pretty sweet that they let you mix two flavors). She seemed to really like it. I got the coconut red bean and it was the most disgusting thing ever. So artificial and the red beans were like a kidney bean-red bean hybrid instead of Azuki beans! Not to mention they were hard and not paste-y at all. Not worth the $3.50 + tax and tip at all.I almost ordered from their liquor menu but refrained. It was the same price, if not cheaper, than the regular drinks. Seriously, a cosmo for $3!?Then, the waitresses started getting impatient. First of all, they gave us less than five minutes. I don't think we were taking that long. Secondly, the restaurant was over half empty. It was 4 pm, don't know what the rush was. Thirdly, like many Chinese restaurants, their menu is an overwhelming mess of dishes. Not my fault they decided to throw every possible combination of meat and vegetables on there. Finally, no matter how long a customer is taking, it is just plain inhospitable for the server to just stand by the table and stare at us while we ordered, especially since we had already bought drinks.I got the beef with black bean sauce and my friend got the orange chicken. She seemed to like it. I'd say my dish was mediocre at best. It was really sweet and tasted like a crappy $5 dollar lunch special at your local take-out joint. Very non-authentic and greasy. Definitely not worth over $10.During the middle of our meal, half the restaurant got those special weather alerts on their phones and it started pouring. It was still pouring when we finished and they couldn't get rid of us quickly enough. Neither of us had umbrellas and half their tables were empty! So I don't see why they had to be so rude about making us leave. I paid $20 for a gross meal. They didn't even pack up our food completely so it spilled out all over our bags and we ended up just tossing everything when we got home.Don't come here, I know I won't ever again.

32.description: Like a previous Yelper mentioned, some dishes are okay and some are not. One thing I can always count on is the fruit smoothies with tapioca. They use real fruits here, not that artificial crap that gets pumped into the cup. My go-to smoothie is the watermelon one. My parents and I have tried multiple dishes, but one dish that I always order is the bok choy with garlic. One thing that's annoying about this restaurant is when it comes time to pay. The waitresses always seem to watch you like a hawk to make sure you pay and sign that check if you paid with a credit card. My dad once took his time to sign the check, and our waitress just stood right behind him and gave him the "You better sign your damn name on that check" look.There are so many restaurants in Chinatown. This is one that you would visit when you're hungry and don't really care what you eat or just want a smoothie.

54.description: Awesome food for a great price. If you can speak/read Chinese, go for the combo meals. They have a menu with set dishes for x amount of people. We spent $27 for 3 huge dishes and 2 soups (chicken soup and a sweet tapioca soup). The fried tofu is to die for (a tad salty), and the fish and veg dish is really good. Pretty much... you can't go wrong with this place.

48.description: Since the change in ownership, I can't say I love it quite as much as I used to. The food and the portion size still isn't bad, so do not be deterred from going. I just do not think it is the first place I would hit up if I want authentic Chinese food.I like to order the roast duck with taro. I can't say it was as good as the first time I had it, but it was still pretty nice. The roast duck is covered in mash taro and then fried so that it was a crisp layer on top. It is then served with a plum sauce, I believe. Delicious! You also can't go wrong with their salt and spicy squid!If you do not plan to stop in for their food, at least get their drinks. They are way cheaper than Joy Yee's and just as good. I usually get the mango one because they really load it with a ton of mangos, or I get the thai tea. The taro smoothie is really delicious too, but I was a bit wary by how much canned coconut milk they used in it.

44.description: For some good, cheap chinese food, this is one of my favorite places. Not exactly a place I would go if I was trying to impress someone as the place is a little dirty and grungy. However the service is pretty good and the food never disappointing. Maybe a tiny bit on the greasy side but nothing that I wouldn't have again.

24.description: Known for spicy -we had the lime in and Peking dumpling .. Best I have ever had !!very good service at least 5 people checking in us.

7.description: Always my favorite place to eat. Good price and the servings are huge worth every bite..all of the foods are delicious.

49.description: Big portions, low prices, & delicious. But.. The waitresses like to stare at you when it's not busy in the restaurant. Makes it super awkward to eat.

40.description: Quick service to get seated on a Thursday, 2pm. They have lunch specials for $5.50 before 3:30pm!Chicken chow mein was how I liked it, salty and noodly! Egg foo young were enormous 2 pieces! Falls apart easily than how my grandma makes it, but still good!

53.description: I don't know why I had not been here earlier. This place is so reminiscent of what hometown is like - the smell, the decor, the sound of people chatting and all. It is by far the most authentic Cantonese food AND experience in the Chicago Chinatown.You are warned that portions are huge so do not be too ambitious, and it'd be smart to come with a group so that you can try more things. On my one visit here, we tried three things and I absolutely loved two of them - casserole beef brisket with radish: just the way I remember from childhood. The radish was soaked with all the juice and flavors. Wish there were more of them in a dish.- Tung Choy with preserved beancurd: tung choi is a relative of, you guessed it, bak choy and many choy - it's hollow so it's a great vegetable to stir fry and really get the flavor in. Preserved beancurd is an acquired taste. But if you go with others who like this flavor, I'd say give it a try! If you don't like it, you know someone will finish it instead of wasting food.I did notice quite a bit of items that are fried. We tried the fried pork chop and the batter was tasty coz it was made of eggs but it was also too thick for my preference. Meat was fresh and juicy though.Next time when you go to Chinatown, before you get to this place, you will see the popular Joy Yee first. For once, do not get sucked into the smoothie wonderland/fast char chan tang (Cantonese/HK cafe) food - which I crave at times - try Lee Wing Wah. It's like several steps down the street.

30.description: I usually like to walk over to Joy Yee if I've eaten in Chinatown during the day, to get a boba tea. I used to think it was "bubble tea,"  but the 波霸 actually means round breasts, referring to the boba, the big tapioca pearls that make drinking these delicious smoothies so dangerous if you're not careful when sucking and walking. One of those explanations that make me giggle.  Anyway, Joy Yee long had this window service for their boba tea, but they're moving that shop and they have these somewhat ambiguous arrows pointing southward, which led me to another window service, and that's how I found that Lee Wing Wah has better fruit smoothies.  Durian-mango, mmm, tastes so good, smells so funny.

46.description: This place is an average Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. We came here recently for a big group dinner. Food was okay. There's nothing bad with it, and nothing spectacular either. Portions are bigger than most portions that you will find at a fancier restaurant like Cai, Minghin, Phoenix. Although it does seem to be a bit gross because we found a flying cockroach walking up the wall  behind us. It was almost the size of my thumb. We stared at it for awhile then one of the workers killed it

1.description: Pretty much the exact definition of average Cantonese food in Chinatown. You'll find all the classic Chinese favorites here at good portion sizes and cheap prices but nothing is particularly amazing or terrible. The decor is not particularly good for Chinatown Square but not ugly (reminds me of nicer looking restaurants in the early 90's). The seating isn't extremely crowded but not super comfortable like Ming Hin. Of all my trips here, I have yet to really come across a dish that I found particularly unique or that was good enough to really motivate me to write about it immediately. If anything, the ginger and onion lobster does have a nice flavor to it with a little bit of sweetness and firm lobster meat. The honey walnut shrimp is also pretty crispy and the walnut is candied very well, although the shrimp is a bit on the soft side.Very good if you're trying to host a banquet at a reasonable price and need to accomodate a large group but it won't be a particularly memorable experience.

55.description: HUGE portions, and they make a stiff cocktail for an unbeatable price!! I love coming here to sip on some $4 Mai Tai's and stuff myself. I always have leftovers, and I always eat them immediately when I get home without haste. Service is OK, atmosphere = nothing fancy or inviting, but the pro's definitely outweigh the cons..  I'll take the cheap drinks and great food over ambiance and music.

9.description: My boyfriend and I went here on a date due to a spontaneity spree that day. We waited to be seated, which was a little bit of a turn off because there were a lot of booths open. When we were seated, we searched their menu. We wanted to try something different other than "Orange Chicken." We got the salt and pepper squid and the Bird's nest (a fried noodle bowl that holds a seafood mix). We waited for the waitress to take our order and then it was another long wait for the food. The food was a let down. The fried squid wasn't that crispy and was really bland. The bird's nest wasn't good either. The sauce was a clear mucous and the shrimp and  vegetables lacked a lot of flavor. We don't like wasting food and we usually take leftovers, but this time, we chose to leave the food behind. We both knew that we were not going to be heating up that food for dinner. I think we ordered the wrong food, because the other tables were ordering some sort of crayfish dish and it was coming out sizzling hot. Maybe if I feel like giving this place another try, I'll go for the crayfish instead.

26.description: Good for drinks and spicy chinese food

25.description: My family returns regularly for their lunch special deals (smaller portions of certain dishes for affordable prices) and occasionally for dinner. Definitely order their seafood chow mein or beef chow fun at lunch. However, on our most recent visit, we ordered the family dinner meal for four that included fish fillet with vegetables, tofu and mushroom bowl, salt and pepper shrimp, and crab sauteed in ginger sauce. The crab was delicious and fresh--I even licked the sauce off the spoon. The other dishes were good though slightly underseasoned today. My sister loves the fish fillets, and I usually prefer the eggplant garlic bowl to the tofu mushroom bowl. Dinner meals always come with soup as an appetizer and a dessert. Lee Wing Wah is one of the few restaurants that serve taro tong sui, which I much prefer to the more typical red bean tong sui. Overall, Lee Wing Wah offers well-portioned and great-value Cantonese food.

12.description: Came here with a group of friends for dinner & left very satisfied. Though the decor is not as flashy as other restaurants in Chinatown, in no way does it reflect the food. Right off the bat, the owner was very welcoming & nice when we asked for recommendations as to what to eat. When the food came out, I quickly noticed how big the portions were. Some restaurants in Chinatown are stingy with how much they give you but not Lee Wing Wah. I  ordered the honey walnut shrimp & it was delicious. The waiters seemed very attentive & refills of water were not an issue at all. All in all, this restaurant is one of the most slept on restaurants in Chinatown. If you're looking for a restaurant with good food, good prices, and huge portions, Lee Wing Wah is the place to go!

59.description: It's been a while since I came in here after the restaurant shifted ownership. Rumor has it that the food is getting better. I came in here with a party of six and we ordered the dinner for 8. It's quite surprising for the price that we pay (a good $100) and we do not get a hefty crustacean! Usually a dinner for five & above would feature a seafood dish (lobster, crab, and/ or shrimp).This place is NOT WHEELCHAIR FRIENDLY for big party dinners. Huge party dinners are hosted on the second floor. If you enter the restaurant in hopes to get to the second floor, you may want to consider otherwise. There is an elevator to bring you to the second floor, yet it is a long detour to get in to the restaurant. You will need to inform the owner that you need accessible assistance (simply ask to have second floor unlocked since it is an emergency exit).Atmosphere: 3. It's pretty average and did not change much from previous ownership. If anything, it's gotten a lot quieter.Decor: 4. This place has been remodeling and trying to upkeep a lot of things. There is new decor of plastic flowers in a small vase. There is an upper level and it has been slightly more decorated as compared to before. Service: 3. Being a relatively busy place it is understandable to experience some delays. I enjoyed seeing my water being filled but not when I have to take a whiff from an armpit when I get it back... It can be worse. I guess they are working on it.Food: 3. The food is pretty average in my opinion. I did some changes they made to their menu. For the "family dinners" you can change whichever dish you want, but you have to replace it with the given items. [If you want to make your money's worth you should refrain from ordering tofu dishes. It does not taste as appetizing as compared to the other dishes.]Price: 2. It could be better. For the food given, I simply don't think it was well worth it. It was average and it was expensive...

21.description: My first ever 1* review :-( Please stay away from this place, there is absolutely no reason to eat at this horrible 'restaurant'. So many other amazing choices in Chinatown. Had 2 appetizers (both dry and had no taste), 3 entrees - all were horrible, greasy, no taste and served cold. The glasses were so dirty we did not touch our drinks, left all drink untouched. Service was rude & slow. At this point - we come to Chinatown twice a month for several years - I have probably tried at least 15 restaurants over the years. This place has not only the worse food in Chinatown, but the worse Chinese food I have ever had. That's saying something as I lived in China for several years. Please go to Lao Beijing, BBQ King or Phoenix - all serving an amazing choice of wonderful food in a nice setting, with always reliable service.

17.description: This is our go to Chinese spot! My Gf insists on always ordering Empress Chicken which is a sweet breaded chicken dish similar to Orange Chicken and Schezwan Green Beans which are mildly spicy as they're cooked with red peppers and dried shrimps. Both are good in my opinion I'd rate them 4/5. I've been to Hong Kong and eaten many authentic dishes over the years, since half of the dishes we order are catered towards Americana-Chinese food I can't say its truly authentic but some dishes are authentic in my opinion. The beer and drinks are cheaply priced and you always get a pot of tea. Tip - Leave the tea pot lid open to get it refilled. Also if you want to go with tradition always fill your guest tea cup first whenever empty!I would dine in for sure as the food is half as good take out!

10.description: Delicious comfort food.  Not fancy but never disappoints.  My family loves coming here for the Salt & Pepper Squid and also the Salt & Pepper Shrimp.  They make it just right, nice and crispy on the outside and tender on the inside.  The food never disappoints.  This is your basic Cantonese cafe.I have noticed over the years that the same staff remains, there is very little if any employee turnover.  This is both a good and a bad thing.  Good because the restaurant is efficient and everyone knows the menu.  Bad because I have noticed that the service can be very indifferent.  Over the years the service seems to have become impersonal.  The food servers seem to just not care anymore.  It's a job.  Clock in and clock out.  Hopefully someone on staff someday will discover some passion about their job.  In the meantime I will continue to come here because the food is very tasty!

5.description: Go for lunch!  There's a $6 special with a meal and an egg roll.  The food is good, the service is good.  The ambiance leaves a lot to be desired, but if you're looking for a quick and delicious Chinese lunch, this is the place to go.

3.description: My sister found out about Lee Wing Wah by asking Chinese people where they eat.  Lee Wing Wah is located @ 2147 S China Pl, Chicago, IL always has awesome food.  This has become one our family hangouts for Chinese food.  We almost always order seafood as it is always fresh (right from the tank to table) seasoned & cooked to perfection.  We always order family style that way you get to try some of everything.  The food was awesome as always.  We had out of town visitors.  My niece from Mizzou and her friend, my cousin from LA and his wife, son & girlfriend were all here.We had clams w/black bean sauce, lobster, walnut shrimp, salt & spicy squid, fried tofu, salt & spicy smelt, fish filet cooked with garlic, ginger & Chinese broccoli, shrimp with black bean garlic sauce, walnut shrimp.  I would give their food a solid 4-4.5.  Stay with the seafood you can't missOther things like the interior decor is kind of dated and the bathrooms are usually kind of disgusting (need to clean them) but I don't go there for the bathrooms I go there to eat their food.  Still it would be nice to find an updated and clean washroom to use.  The service is usually pretty good maybe because we are regulars, but that does vary depending on who your server is and the time of the day & the size of your party.  Because of the discrepancies in the service and the filthy restroom.  I am giving this restaurant 3.5 stars

35.description: Lee Wing Wah lunch specials are super inexpensive and a great deal. The regular menu is also a good deal if you're not getting seafood. The problem I have with LWW is that it's too Americanized for me.

19.description: My friend and I came here one gloomy Saturday afternoon for lunner/dinch. Since this was the only restaurant in Chinatown Square that wasn't completely deserted or full of non-asians, we decided to give it a try. Great first impression! The host, and probably owner, was so friendly and greeted us super nicely. We sat down and I think they served us water/tea pretty instantaneously. They gave us a few minutes to peruse the menu. We each ordered a fruit shake. My friend got a mango-watermelon with boba (it's pretty sweet that they let you mix two flavors). She seemed to really like it. I got the coconut red bean and it was the most disgusting thing ever. So artificial and the red beans were like a kidney bean-red bean hybrid instead of Azuki beans! Not to mention they were hard and not paste-y at all. Not worth the $3.50 + tax and tip at all.I almost ordered from their liquor menu but refrained. It was the same price, if not cheaper, than the regular drinks. Seriously, a cosmo for $3!?Then, the waitresses started getting impatient. First of all, they gave us less than five minutes. I don't think we were taking that long. Secondly, the restaurant was over half empty. It was 4 pm, don't know what the rush was. Thirdly, like many Chinese restaurants, their menu is an overwhelming mess of dishes. Not my fault they decided to throw every possible combination of meat and vegetables on there. Finally, no matter how long a customer is taking, it is just plain inhospitable for the server to just stand by the table and stare at us while we ordered, especially since we had already bought drinks.I got the beef with black bean sauce and my friend got the orange chicken. She seemed to like it. I'd say my dish was mediocre at best. It was really sweet and tasted like a crappy $5 dollar lunch special at your local take-out joint. Very non-authentic and greasy. Definitely not worth over $10.During the middle of our meal, half the restaurant got those special weather alerts on their phones and it started pouring. It was still pouring when we finished and they couldn't get rid of us quickly enough. Neither of us had umbrellas and half their tables were empty! So I don't see why they had to be so rude about making us leave. I paid $20 for a gross meal. They didn't even pack up our food completely so it spilled out all over our bags and we ended up just tossing everything when we got home.Don't come here, I know I won't ever again.

28.description: On so many levels, no.We only decided to eat here because there were a ton of Chinese people inside. You know how it goes - see a crowded Chinese restaurant filled with Chinese people, it's probably good.We walked in, the tables were lopsided. We were placed in the table next to the kitchen and already you can see so many health code violations. There was a white tub with like sludge-looking stuff right by the stove. Gross. The menu I received was sticky, but not like normal plastic Chinese restaurant menu sticky, it was gooey.Our food came out really quickly, almost too quickly. Everything was saturated in oil and salt. I ordered a dish of water spinach, and you could tell it was cooked without thought. One side of it was really salty but in the middle of the dish, it was so bland. What irritated me the MOST was when our check came out, we all put down our cards to pay. One of my friends mistakenly thought tip was included, and as  the waitress so graciously pointed out, "You gonna put tip on the table? You know tip isn't included, right?" After he apologizes and proceeds to add a tip to his card, she goes around the table, grabs the receipt and examines the amount of tip we left. Excuse me, but last I heard, tips are given based on customer satisfaction.

45.description: They have some good Chinese seafood such as crab and flounder. The seafood congee is nice too.

33.description: How have I not reviewed this place before?  Man, I've been eating here for ages now.  It seems like whenever anyone gets married or has a baby, the family is in for a banquet.  It's also a favorite for birthday celebrations.  I haven't ever had anything I hated there.  Everything is good.  The last time we were in we had a seafood basket, honey walnut shrimp and random other stuff.  All yum.  Another plus is the cocktails!  Lee Wing Wah Secret is delicious and a steal at like $4 or $5.

43.description: Big portions for a reasonable price. Their bubble tea tastes great and is much cheaper than Joy Yee a few steps down the road

2.description: We haven't been there for awhile. This time we went for lunch. It was good. In the past it was a hit or miss. We had the lunch special dishes and the Oysters. The Oysters were so good and fresh! Highly recommended if you love Steamed Oysters. We also had Fish with Bittermelons, Eggplants with Tofu hot pot, Beef Chow Foon, and Singapore Noodle. It was plenty of food for four. The only thing we did not like much was the Singapore Noodle. We also had Beef Chow Foon, Fried Sweet Rice, and another Rice dish of some sort. The bill came to about $60. Not bad for lunch for four and carryout for some more later. Recommended.

18.description: They have very bad service...I found a fat Asian hair in my food....it's heavy and dirty...I do not recommend going near this place. Also there really good at playing stupid....especially when they wrong...they act really friendly, but there shiesty .!!!!@@

41.description: Poor service. Below average food. Quality / taste has decreased over the years.

52.description: Came here with my family for dinner. Left with boxes of leftovers after we ordered a dinner for six. There was just way too much food, even with my brother there (he's fat). What was cool, though, was that we received all six of our dishes within ten minutes. That was crazy fast.The food was mostly great, but there were a few dishes that felt like a miss. Save the mapo tofu for Lao Sze Chaun down the road. This chicken dish (not sure what it was called, but it was literally just chicken. Plain. Nothing else, not even garnishes) was good, but in a very straight way, as if that's how chicken is supposed to taste. Flavorful, but ultimately uninteresting. It was really weird, and the dish remained largely untouched, so I'm planning on just using the leftovers for chicken fried rice or something.The standouts were the chow mein and fish fillets. The fish was delicious and melted in your mouth. I'd order it every time I came here. The mein was great, but not too different from similar dishes at other restaurants. It's just a generally good dish that's hard to fuck up.To sum up, Lee Wing Wah serves a ton of food, especially given how much you pay. Other than a couple of great dishes, though, the food is mostly forgettable. This place is definitely one of the best for large groups, but there are other options in Chinatown to consider first.

50.description: I spent the evening of the Chinese New Year (Year of the Snake) having dinner at Lee Wing Wah with Christopher and some very dear friends. It was a wonderful party atmosphere. Our friend Sonny ordered for all of us and we ended up with 7 entrees and soup. Our entrees included Salt and Pepper Squid and Shrimp, Sechuan String Beans, a fish and eggplant dish, sweet and sour ribs, and several other items. Everything was quite good and the potions were huge. We all took home leftovers.Perhaps the most enjoyable part for me was when the Lion Dancers came through the restaurant doing the lion dance. At the end of the dance, one of the lions climbed up on a table, devoured a whole head of lettuce and sent the shredded lettuce flying out over all the tables. It was really cool.This was a night I will never forget. Great food, great company and a true feeling of being part of all the festivities. Best part ... we had our evil spirits driven away for the next year!

4.description: This place is very special to because I've been going here since I was a little kid. It a great place, I really like the tofu dishes, Peking Pork Chops, and the Fried Chicken is always good with the crispy skin without the excessive dough. I love this place

6.description: Was good.

22.description: I've been coming here since I was a kid. I've dragged so many friends here, and they seem perplexed when they walk in, as the lighting is harsh and it smells like a fish tank. The wait staff is cold and sometimes rude, but the food is so good that I don't really care. It's become part of its strange charm. The price is right too!

15.description: GREAT FOR GROUPS:  I brought my youth group to Chinatown and just planned to find a place when there.  There were 25 of us.  I stopped in to inquire, and they already knew we were looking for a place for our group and said they'd be happy to accommodate us.  They set up the tables very comfortably.  HELPED WITH ORDERING:  I started to look for dishes to order for us all, family style, but the lady ended up offering a much better arrangement -- a complete meal for a very reasonably negotiated price.  PARTICULAR FOOD:  The food was wonderful, all the youth loved it, and what stood out were the fried fish fillets they served.  It tasted like freshly caught fish.  Just wonderful. I'd highly recommend this place in Chinatown Square, and especially for large groups.

57.description: Chinatown has definitely boomed with quite a few restaurants boasting some pretty seductive names to go along with very nice design and decor. So when you pass an old-timer looking restaurant named Lee Wing Wah, it's a little hard to predict what you're gonna get, much less get hyped or excited about the food. To tell you the truth, I always root for the underdog so I really wanted to like the food. I really did. While this place definitely offers entrees for a pretty reasonable price, the food could definitely use some tune-ups. Overall, the food was a little bland and tasteless. The fried pork chops we ordered were especially dry with very little seasoning, if any at all. The honey walnut shrimp was pretty basic as well with below average size shrimp and a little too much mayo. Honestly, the rest of the food was not very memorable. It wasn't really bad or anything just mediocre at best. Granted, Chinese dishes usually aren't as heavily seasoned or sauced as other kinds of cooking but when my entire extended family of Asian folk are displeased, then there is probably something a little off.Would I come back? Probably not. But maybe I just went on a very bad day so if you get the chance and you're looking for some new dining options, maybe give this place a shot? You can at least be assured that the prices are pretty fair.

20.description: Went to this place on Christmas eve. There a lot of people are waiting. So I talked to the lady about waiting for the table(I dont know if she is a host or owner). She said it will be 45 mins wait and she asked me how many people we have and she said she will put us on the waiting list.1 hour later, when I saw the group have same amount people and which is came in after us been sit at the table, so I start to looking for the lady I talked to. She told me is my turn yet and she run away and she never came back to me.After I waited for another 15 mins I found another girl who seems like a host, She checked the list for me, Then I found it out, the Lady that I talked to, she never put us on the list!!!!!!! I know every place is busy on the holiday, but if you made the mistake, at least come and say sorry!!

36.description: November 20This place reside in one of my best childhood memories!  I used to invite my American friend here for lunch and I still do!  I'm a big noodle fan!  Therefore, I come here myself for their authentic lunch special a lot!  It's either Seafood Wide Rice Noodle (Chow Fun) or the Beef Stew Wide Rice Noodle (Chow Fun).If it's with American groups, I usually get items similar to items similar to the American style, but with an authentic twist.  I'll get the Special Yang Chow Fried Rice, Beijing Style Sweet and Sour Pork Chops, Salt and Pepper Shrimp (sometimes I request without the shell on), Beef Wide Rice Noodle, Season Vegetable, and perhaps a Seafood Combination!  Sometimes, a soup as well!Overall, this place is extremely affordable and delicious during lunch!  If you want the set menu and do not want the headache of deciding, it's yummy as well!

14.description: Spent a few hours in Chinatown and the four of us settled on Lee Wing.Its a big place and we were seated immediately. They moved up upstairs to tables that seat 8 or 10.  There weren't many people there and service was slow but okay.The prices were reasonable and they offered the lunch specials on a sunday. I have the General Tso chicken and an eggroll for 5.95 you really can't beat that. The food was average to slightly above average for chinese but the prices were excellent.

58.description: Restaurant reviewEh I've had better. You have to pay in cash no credit card accepted. You have to be cautious with the dessert pastries as many of the chinatown bakeries do not throw away the items and save it for the next day. I wanted to order the pineapple bun bread and they only came in mini form. The selection is limited. Be ready to order quickly. Pro: noneCons: limited itemsHidden gem:  None

56.description: 10am in Chinatown on a Saturday and other than dim sum restaurants, Saint Anna's was packed. This is the place where the Chinese community go to for your quick and easy meal. The bakery has a wide variety from BBQ buns, sweet rice balls, and pastries. You can get a box full of items for cheap since most items range from $.60 cents to $1.00. Come here early otherwise, all of the good stuff are gone and what's left has probably been sitting out for a while. I recommend that you get a take home box since you can't get these items as fresh in the suburbs. There's nothing fancy about this place. To some, this might be too low key for you. For others, this is nostalgic of your childhood where you ate congee (Chinese rice porridge) with your family. The dish that stood out to me was the Portuguese Chicken which was chicken and rice dish with a mild creamy sauce with curry powder. If you are the type that is venturing to Chinatown, there are other better restaurants for dine in but I would recommend this place for getting baked goods for home.

29.description: Delicious bakery with extremely reasonable prices! Had the pork buns, chicken pie, and the black forest cake which all amounted to be around $4. The food quality was great and really reminded me of a bakery in Hong Kong or anywhere else in Asia! Its cash only I believe, so be weary of that. Highly recommend!!

42.description: I'm writing this on behalf of my (Hong Kong born and raised) mom, who said their pineapple custard bun was the best she's ever had. Silky, fluffy and crusty!! I also really like their sponge cake that comes wrapped in paper. The prices are great and so is the selection. I'm only a little sad about the savory breakfast, which had a lot of potential- the congee was really just average. Save your $$ for the baked goods!

23.description: Came here because I was craving bubble tea at 10:30 am before Joy Yee was open. I was so glad I came, they served breakfast, had nice selection of pastries, breads and cakes. Cute little place. Cash only.

47.description: I'm a huge fan of Chiu Quon in Uptown - it's the only bakery I go to when I'm there. Chinatown Square is so hard for me to navigate though, so I just find the first bakery I see and buy stuff there. After wandering into Saint Anna... I'm sad to say that I don't think all the bakeries are very similar. St. Anna's is a bit cheaper though. Many things are noticeably cheaper -  egg tarts are only 50cents! They were out of bbq buns when I got there at around 5 pm, so we picked up an assortment of sweet things. The pineapple buns are breads here, but they are really delicious - the pineapple topping to bread ratio is perfect. The egg tarts and spongecakes were made well and had great textures.This would be a solid 4 star bakery, but... Everything here has a lot more sugar than other Asian bakeries. I don't think this is necessarily a bad thing... but if I wanted an overly sweet sponge cake or egg tart, I can just buy a slice of chiffon cake or a custard from any neighborhood American bakery. If you live near here, it is a great cheap bakery with decent buns. But it's not my idea of something I want to travel out of my way to get. I still prefer Chiu Quon ( the Chinatown location is right near the entrance of the old Chinatown street).

8.description: We came here in search of mochi, sesame balls, and a fresh fruit bubble tea; we found all three (and for an insanely affordable price to boot). They only had big, thick mochi (not the smaller ones you often find filled with ice cream) and they also didn't have any with red bean filling, which was a disappointment. You must purchase the mochi in packs of three (for $3), so we did that. We also got two sesame balls and a mango smoothie with boba pearls. The mochi was good in that it was fresh. I was impressed that there was actually fresh cut fruit inside, along with a cool whip-like creamy mix. There was a strawberry version and a mango version; I preferred the mango (I prefer mango in general). The third flavor was green tea and it tasted great, albeit a bit sugary and nothing really like green tea. The sesame balls had red bean paste, which was great! However, the exterior part was very thick. I had to take two big bites before I even reached the yummy red bean interior. We were especially grateful for the red bean interior because we had just eaten sesame balls for dim sum at Phoenix and the filling was lotus seed--not what we were expecting. Finally, the mango bubble tea. It was basically perfection with very fresh mango, perfectly smooth and blended. My only slight complaint was that they provided SO MANY tapioca pearls. Like, I would say 30% of the drink was tapioca. I do love the pearls, but I don't like to slurp up four every time through the straw. I was left wanting more of the amazing smoothie! Next time, I'm going to ask for "light on the pearls." This may be my favorite mango bubble tea in Chinatown! I look forward to coming back to sample more, especially some of the buns and hopefully (!) some red bean mochi, too.

31.description: I highly recommend the coconut buns and the Napoleon layer mini-cakes! This was a pleasant surprise on Christmas Day and I'll be coming back for more!

34.description: Their pineapple buns are great since they combine the outside of the traditional pineapple bun with the sweet coconut filling of other buns. I love both, so it's amazing!Very helpful staff, and a large assortment of chinese bakery goods. Egg tarts are not the flaky type though, but still nice.Quite affordable overall!

16.description: Having just had dinner at Chi Cafe next door, friends and I were pretty stuffed so unfortunately couldn't really eat anything. This review is basically based only on a single dessert: the green tea mousse cake. It was just as you'd expect and want from an Asian style cake - light, fluffy, and not overly sweet. The ladies were not as warm as your own grandmother, but nice enough (definitely way nicer than what you'd find in an Asian bakery in NYC for instance). They weren't pushy and were easily accommodating in giving us napkins and forks to eat. Price is cheap and what you'd expect in a proper Chinatown as well.

13.description: I really wanted BBQ pork Bao, which they didn't have but I had their cream-filled buns...unfortunately I was disappointed that the bread was dry. The cream was yummy and plenty in the middle. It reminded me of those Mexican cream-filled breads. So I'm not judging the store but more that it wasn't my type of treat.GO GET the egg tart, which was oval shaped, flaky warm crust that had a perfect egg tart center. Yum! It fell apart in my hands and just a perfectly piece of paradise!

11.description: Nice little bakery to pick up your favorite Asian pastries/cakes. Prices are reasonable and the women working there are friendly. They have a wide variety of sweet and savory buns and pastries. You can buy a bunch of pastries and still spend less than $10. They also sell boba, fresh fruit smoothie/drinks, and a selected amount of regular sit down food. I would definitely come back if I am ever in Chinatown and stock up on yummy pastries!My favorite is the egg tarts! =D

39.description: I can't go by this bakery without going in. I've never eaten a meal here, but I am obsessed with their drinks. I usually get either the Hong Kong style milk tea (hot and cold are both delicious) or the Yin Yang (coffee mixed with milk tea). I'm convinced this place has the best HK style milk tea in town!

37.description: This place has the best egg tarts ever. However, they usually run out by the time I get there since it seems that I'm not the only one who enjoys them. It doesn't help that or the ladies working there are good at convincing me to buy more than I planned since "there's only a few left" or "it's only a dollar or two more." Regardless, I'm never disappointed with my decision. :D

0.description: Small place but great good. This bakery has some of the best bake goods in Chinatown Squre. They fresh and tasty. We go there sometime for breakfast noodle soup with spam and pickle cannage and milk tea. They also have great egg tards! You should give this place if you're looking for a hidden gem.

38.description: The pastries here are even more pricey than Captain Cafe, but maybe everything is just highly priced at Chinatown Square. Their egg tart is not only uniquely shaped, but the crust was also hard (not that I hate it.) As for the fruit tart, there is jam and whipped cream underneath the fruits and the fruit tart  was not too sweet and tasted just right, but the strawberry left a sour aftertaste in my mouth. I only came here once (because of the prices and quantity), so I can't really provide much of an update but the lady who helped me that time was extremely polite.

51.description: I always get the bbq pork bun and the sweet rice roll...DELISH!!

27.description: Yummy,  yummy in my tummy!  This is the place to go for Chinese baked buns and other sweets. Not exactly hip and the bathroom is a little scary but the food more than makes up for those things.

32.description: My go to spot for pastries when I am in the new Chinatown strip. They serve rice plates, noodle dishes and smoothie drinks as well-- they're decent too!This place has also been my go to spot for birthday cakes too. (Be careful: They misspelled something on the cake TWICE before!)

54.description: Just had one piece of cake, but it was Delicious !!   I got the Orange cake and it was moist, flavorful, with a nice light cream frosting. Many people in front of me got boxes and boxes of pastries, so that is a good sign.A solid pasty shop in the area.

48.description: The bbq pork buns are perfectly proportioned, with bbq pork distributed throughout the bun and not just in one corner. This is much harder than it sounds to make, so you can imagine how impressed I was when I got a bite of bbq pork with every bite of the bun. Amaze balls.The egg tarts are excellent here. And oddly shapped...

44.description: We went to this bakery mainly to pick up baked pork buns for my uncle, then decided to eat lunch there. Nothing impressive. Usual dirty restrooms and staff who speak with abruptness. Hopefully the buns are good.

24.description: When my friend and I walked it we were made welcome!  It feels like a large dining room in someone's home. It was packed full of locals and that's how we knew it would be good. The ladies that serve you all huddle around and talk while you are eating.  They seemed surprised we could use chop sticks and that my friend spoke some Mandarin.  I had some sort of house style noodle dish with beef or pork.  It is also perfectly located for shopping within Chinatown.  I plan to go back when I visit Chicago next month.

7.description: I'm 25 years old, and I've been going here with my mom since I was a little girl. Perhaps it's more of a nostalgic place for me, but I don't go anywhere else for my Chinese baked goods. My favorite are the egg tarts and pineapple buns, and they're all under $1! Can't go wrong! The ladies are sweet and the buns even sweeter :) I believe it's cash only (maybe this only applies to under $10), so I always make sure to bring cash!

49.description: I love this place. The workers are nicer here compare to other bakeries. I like to get their egg tarts, ice HK milk tea, hot dog bun and coconut bun for breakfast sometimes. They are usually under $1.

40.description: Update: tried the food at St. Anna's for the first time and I must say... not bad. I wouldn't have ordered anything if it wasn't b/c my dad recommended it to me. A baked rice. The Portuguese chicken. Dark meat chicken, potatoes, rice, with a curry sauce that doesn't taste like curry, a few pieces of carrots... pretty good.

53.description: Pros: Good food, decent personnelCons: Expensive--In all of Chinatown, this place is one of the best places for its Egg Tart. Other than that, I do not think they have anything else special.The dollar sign rating in the description is incorrect. This place should be 2 out of 4 in terms of price. Everything on the menu is at least $1-2 more than any other bakery in Chinatown. However, since it does make slightly better food than other restaurant and bakeries, I guess it is worth the price.

30.description: My friend and I popped into Saint Anna Bakery & Cafe after enjoying an enormous Christmas Day lunch in a nearby Chinatown Square restaurant.  We were looking for a Chinese bakery, and we noted that though there were loads of restaurants in the Square, there seemed to be very few bakeries.  Saint Anna has a display of baked goods, and also food and drinks and fancy cakes as depicted on the menu at the front window.  The window is a bit dated, as you can barely make out the Saint Anna name on the glass.  There is a decent amount of seating here, but we were only interested in the baked goods to go.  Everything we ordered was good, and reasonably priced.  The BBQ Pork buns are tasty and have a generous amount of meat filling.  There are bite-sized egg custard tarts and coconut macaroon tarts that are perfect for quick snacking, or passing along to friends to enjoy.  I joked that my friend would arrive home with an empty bag, as she devoured her purchases of a custard bun and pound cake while driving back.

46.description: I love coming in here for a quick grab of pastries. I do not enjoy, though, they put my decorated cake in a paper bag even though I said I'm taking it to go. Sorry, I'm picky with looks and taste. Of course, the taste doesn't get affected, but if you intend for a far and bumpy travel you should definitely aim for ordering more than 4 pieces of cakes so you can get a box for it.Their buns are awesome and definitely filled well.

1.description: I usually stop in here after getting dim sum. I love how large of a selection they have. They have both large coconut tarts and small coconut tarts, along with different sizes of other things too. I always admire the cakes, but I'm usually too full to buy any.This bakery is very reasonably priced. The workers there are super nice, which is a huge contrast to most places in Chinatown. Business seems like it's always good.I docked a star because of the inconsistency in quality of the filled mochi. Sometimes, it's super good. One time, I only had it for one day, but the mango filling was already bad. When I got it the other day, the rice cake was hard and bottom was mushy. Clearly, it had been sitting out for more than a day. This place is cash only, so don't forget your money!

55.description: Costs a bit more, lines are a bit longer, but the best overall quality.  Egg custard tart, warm from the oven--yum!   Chicken pie--popping portable flavor!  Strangest Napoleon I've ever tasted, but it was good.

9.description: Delicious cakes. I had the Taro cake which was made with bits of fresh, sweetened taro sandwiched between whipped cream and a soft, moist, spongy cake. In addition to cakes they have bubble tea, various flaky and fried pastries, and some meat pies. Cash only so come prepared.

26.description: Yum!  Stopped in after having dim sum next door. Most of the items I bought were 90 cents a piece. What a bargain. The coconut custard baked bun was delicious.

25.description: You need cash for this place, but boy, you need to try their pork bbq bun, they are great for snack time and even for lunch or dinner! the sauce is great which is already inside the bun! Best chinese buns I've tasted.Their ham and egg buns are great for breakfast.Only downside besides the cash only policy, is the language barrier, we came with a group one time and we were ordering a lot... the girl from my group was telling the lady behind the counter that we needed 2 dozens, separate each dozen in a box. the lady kept saying "two thousand?" "two thousand?" and boy they were there for more than a few minutes to clear that up. imagine if we came home with two thousand and how much cash we had to go to the ATM for? hahahahaDespite that we come back for more!

12.description: LOVE this place! It's the only bakery in Chinatown that I go to. Their cakes are tasty, and everything is so cheap! I would also recommend the pork and chive buns, which are amazing. Convenient location too! Make sure you have cash though, they don't take card.

59.description: The cheapest, tastiest pastries in all the land. We had a veritable feast of chestnut cake, pineapple custard bun, banana walnut cake, and chicken pot pie. Flavors were light and airy like most Asian pastries. Service was both rapid fire and friendly. Don't forget to bring cash. They don't take credit cards. Our whole bill came to less than $10.  So, cash was not a problem.

21.description: The buns and bakery are fresh and tasty. But my absolute favorite item from their restaurant is the Hong Kong milk tea (warm). Not sure if that is the same taste as the ones in HK, but it's delicious! Whenever I am in Chinatown, I will be sure to get a cup.

17.description: After twenty years, I am still in love with this place. Love the cake! Freshly made everyday, very little sugar in the cream. Milk tea is the best, strong tea! An eye opener.

10.description: My friend and I popped into Saint Anna Bakery & Cafe after enjoying an enormous Christmas Day lunch in a nearby Chinatown Square restaurant.  We were looking for a Chinese bakery, and we noted that though there were loads of restaurants in the Square, there seemed to be very few bakeries.  Saint Anna has a display of baked goods, and also food and drinks and fancy cakes as depicted on the menu at the front window.  The window is a bit dated, as you can barely make out the Saint Anna name on the glass.  There is a decent amount of seating here, but we were only interested in the baked goods to go.  Everything we ordered was good, and reasonably priced.  The BBQ Pork buns are tasty and have a generous amount of meat filling.  There are bite-sized egg custard tarts and coconut macaroon tarts that are perfect for quick snacking, or passing along to friends to enjoy.  I joked that my friend would arrive home with an empty bag, as she devoured her purchases of a custard bun and pound cake while driving back.

5.description: I stopped by Saint Anna Bakery when visiting Chicago during the 4th of July holiday weekend. It's a small bakery in Chinatown with a broad selection of Asian and Western desserts from egg tarts to chocolate mousse cakes to mochi. All the baked goods here looked absolutely beautiful.I got the green tea mousse cake for $2.45. The shop wrapped it in a small cardboard box game me a napkin and fork, so it was a perfect to-go snack. The cake itself had a very moist and light sponge cake base with a green tea cream mousse top. I'm not a huge fan of most cakes, but man was the sponge cake base on this one was soooo good. The mousse top was just okay. It was lightly sweet, tasted of green tea, and had some red beans interspersed throughout. I liked the texture of the mousse, but it could have used a bit of vanilla flavor and a tad bit more sugar. The cake came topped with a dark chocolate decoration, which had a good taste and made for a pretty final touch. Overall a very good (and pretty) cake for the price!Next time I would definitely try some of the other cakes and pies!

3.description: I went to this bakery right before closing time and I honestly wish I could have been able to enjoy it earlier in the day. The customer service was a little off, as I could tell they were ready to leave and kind of wanted us out of the store, but nonetheless everything was tasty! Even in the 12 degree weather, I opted for the Mango Smoothie with "bubbles" and it was delicious and made fresh on the spot. The egg pastry and sesame bun were extremely yummy and cool new things for me to try while visiting China Town. Hoping to come back on my next trip to Chicago to try more!

35.description: Every time we make a trip up from the far Western suburbs (Iowa City, IA), we stop in and grab enough treats to keep us busy for a few days.The egg tarts, sesame balls and bbq pork buns are among our favorites and at under $1, they make stocking up easy and affordable. As anyone familiar with this area of town confirm, cash is king as they don't take "insert credit card here". Luckily a weeks worth of goodies will run you about $12 so you're good even when the funds is low. Standard Chinatown customer service where you're not convinced they care that you're around, but they're happy to help you and bag up whatever you fancy for the day.Worth it every time we come into town and definitely worth a look if you're around.

19.description: Rude staff! Never coming back here again. I am writing this review outside the restaurant after my boyfriend and I were told to leave while in the middle of eating because "other customers need the table." ThE place is tiny with only maybe 10 tables, and what I find more odd is that we were the only table asked to leave. What kind of service is that???

28.description: This was and still is my childhood to go place.  I've always loved their egg tarts because their egg tarts are different from the rest of the egg tarts in the Chinatown or Chicago area. Their breakfast and lunch menu are always delicious. We normally order their birthday cakes because they're so yummy and gorgeous. The cakes are always light and not too sweet so perfect for you if you're having a sweet tooth for desserts!

45.description: Seriously wondering how I've never been to this place until now. Amazing and very affordable selection of pastries and buns, they even have little containers of pan fried noodles! My only complaints: the line can kinda get hectic and people kept cutting in front of me and they only take cash, but other than that it was love at first bite!

33.description: Great pastries for super cheap, Cash only!

43.description: We tried this Shanghai-French-influenced bakery, and were profoundly disappointed. The establishment is dirty; the desserts are stale, and packaged; the air is muggy. The baked pork buns were recommended, and after the first try, I can safely say there'll be no need to try, again.The egg tarts were also recommended, and far from appetizing. Surely, I am not a fan of the warm, undetectable custard taste. The red bean sesame buns are your safest best here, and cheaper than the costs from neighboring establishments.

2.description: When it comes to HK bakery items,  I come to St Anna. It is worth the 3hrs drive. That's how good it is. Everything here is authentically HK. The staff speaks in Cantonese with Cantonese's hospitality. Weekday parking is plentiful. I parked in the back of the complex. $1 an HR. The sesame balls were fresh out of the oven when I got here. They were delicious. Dinner it was late lunch for me,  I ordered a plate of dry fried beef noodles,  and their version is very good with a hint of ginger. I would also recommend the Wonton noodles. If you want bakery items I recommend these curry beef turnovers, chicken pie,  sponge cake,  egg tart,  and winter melon biscuits.

18.description: I came here to pick up some buns, they don't have as large of a selection as Captain bakery. The ladies working here are pretty friendly, and I ended up purchasing dan tat ( egg tart), ga lai sou( curry beef pastry), cha siu bao, and a wu dip sou( butterfly cookie). The egg tarts here do not have the flaky crust on the outside, and instead of the lard crust.  I prefer the flaky crust, they only have the regular dan tat here and do not have the flan style one. The curry beef pastry here was a bit smaller than at Captain's, and I don't think I would purchase it again. Buns are around $1 - $2 each, the butterfly cookie was only 40 cents but it was the smaller than the palm of my hand.The cha siu bao was pretty typical, the bun was fresh, and none of the items that I purchased seemed like they were sitting there for too long. I will probably come back to try the rest of their pastries!

41.description: I came here to pick up some buns, they don't have as large of a selection as Captain bakery. The ladies working here are pretty friendly, and I ended up purchasing dan tat ( egg tart), ga lai sou( curry beef pastry), cha siu bao, and a wu dip sou( butterfly cookie). The egg tarts here do not have the flaky crust on the outside, and instead of the lard crust.  I prefer the flaky crust, they only have the regular dan tat here and do not have the flan style one. The curry beef pastry here was a bit smaller than at Captain's, and I don't think I would purchase it again. Buns are around $1 - $2 each, the butterfly cookie was only 40 cents but it was the smaller than the palm of my hand.The cha siu bao was pretty typical, the bun was fresh, and none of the items that I purchased seemed like they were sitting there for too long. I will probably come back to try the rest of their pastries!

52.description: Really inexpensive.  Unlike others, we had good service.  Cash only.

50.description: The milk tea was great! Reminds me when I was little had it in Honghong. Egg tart was not quite what I expected, but crunchy  and still yummy! The sesame balls are the best I have ever had! Not too big but thin and crunchy with good amount of red bean paste inside, couldn't stop eating them!

4.description: Came in a little late before it was about to close...egg tarts were unfortunately sold out so I didn't get a chance to try. Had many different cakes and fruit tarts. Really liked the taro cake and the green tea cake! Fruit tarts were delicious as well! Napoleon and Black Forest turned to be just alright for me! Probably won't recommend those two. Would definitely love to go back and try their egg tarts some other time since it's what they are known for!

6.description: This place certainly has a very friendly and patient service. I'm one of those, who take forever to decide, but that wasn't a problem for the people to wait until I made a decision what to order.I came here to get some pastries for breakfast. It's delicious and cheap. Seeing all these pictures of cakes and drinks I'm convinced without even having tried it, that those are pretty delicious as well.It's located downstairs in this plaza and it's about 5 min walk from the CTA metro station.

22.description: We came here in search of mochi, sesame balls, and a fresh fruit bubble tea; we found all three (and for an insanely affordable price to boot). They only had big, thick mochi (not the smaller ones you often find filled with ice cream) and they also didn't have any with red bean filling, which was a disappointment. You must purchase the mochi in packs of three (for $3), so we did that. We also got two sesame balls and a mango smoothie with boba pearls. The mochi was good in that it was fresh. I was impressed that there was actually fresh cut fruit inside, along with a cool whip-like creamy mix. There was a strawberry version and a mango version; I preferred the mango (I prefer mango in general). The third flavor was green tea and it tasted great, albeit a bit sugary and nothing really like green tea. The sesame balls had red bean paste, which was great! However, the exterior part was very thick. I had to take two big bites before I even reached the yummy red bean interior. We were especially grateful for the red bean interior because we had just eaten sesame balls for dim sum at Phoenix and the filling was lotus seed--not what we were expecting. Finally, the mango bubble tea. It was basically perfection with very fresh mango, perfectly smooth and blended. My only slight complaint was that they provided SO MANY tapioca pearls. Like, I would say 30% of the drink was tapioca. I do love the pearls, but I don't like to slurp up four every time through the straw. I was left wanting more of the amazing smoothie! Next time, I'm going to ask for "light on the pearls." This may be my favorite mango bubble tea in Chinatown! I look forward to coming back to sample more, especially some of the buns and hopefully (!) some red bean mochi, too.

15.description: My go to spot for pastries when I am in the new Chinatown strip. They serve rice plates, noodle dishes and smoothie drinks as well-- they're decent too!This place has also been my go to spot for birthday cakes too. (Be careful: They misspelled something on the cake TWICE before!)

57.description: Solid, inexpensive, conventional Chinese style buns and pastries. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I happen to be in the area, I'll pick up a few things. When I went, the lady behind the counter understood and spoke English which was great. I have never tried dining in so cannot comment with regards to the prepared food.

20.description: Nice little bakery to pick up your favorite Asian pastries/cakes. Prices are reasonable and the women working there are friendly. They have a wide variety of sweet and savory buns and pastries. You can buy a bunch of pastries and still spend less than $10. They also sell boba, fresh fruit smoothie/drinks, and a selected amount of regular sit down food. I would definitely come back if I am ever in Chinatown and stock up on yummy pastries!My favorite is the egg tarts! =D

36.description: This is my to go place for curry chicken with fried rice. Oh my gosh, cannot believe how amazing it is. The cakes are okay, but they are famous for their special egg tarts. Must try! They're special oval that will not crust off easily like other egg tarts.

14.description: My quest for a Chinese breakfast took me to Chinatown & then after skipping the other highly rated "chi town cafe", I made a stop at this bakery.It was definitely a busy place for 8:30am on a weekend.They offer a ton of stuff but if u a veggie options are limited to sweet Danish or boring breads. Whatever I took (coz I don't care to remember now), maybe some sort of Danish pastry was not great. All the other stuff looked glazed but wonder if they were any good. Nevertheless, I might go to this place again if I end up in Chinatown to try more of their breakfast items and just sit there and watch Asian people sip their coffee. The place does have a good feel to it.

3.description: Went there on a Saturday night and it was completely DEAD inside My group of friends reserved a karaoke room for a couple hours and we had fun in there by ourselves but the main lounge room outside had maybe 4 people just sitting at the bar...which is pretty sad considering the place is really well designed and looks very stylish. Maybe management just needs to hire better promoters and get the word out because I think it could have a lot of potentialThe private karaoke room itself was very clean which is a huge plus because most karaoke rooms I've been to have been really gross and questionable lol..They have a good selection of music and the screen actually plays the music videos of the songs and not just random shots of landscapesIt's a nice place with potential but I probably won't be back any time soon unless it becomes more populated because it was kinda weird how dead it was

1.description: On a Friday.. I wasn't disappointed!! It waste of money & time. The customer service is bad and with an attitude. The staff had a major attitude. It appears that I was being a inconvenience to them. The return time of service is long and forever.  By the time you get the food you're not hungry anymore. Poor selections of food. Everything that I asked on the menu they ran out. However? They have great drinks.  As stated before, on a Friday I was surprised that they ran of food, pineapple juice and etc very quickly.  Prices for karaoke bar is too high!! $250 for group of 4 ppl.

2.description: It could be more.Negotiate the price for the karaoke rooms because even on a weekend night, it's pretty dang dead to near empty. The crowd is mainly Asians in their mid 20s. Watch out if you don't spend a certain dollar amount for one of their rooms, they will charge you an additional fee.

9.description: Love this place, the newest KTV in Chi-town, nice huge lounge with good amount of private rooms.

10.description: This place was decent. I didn't understand charging everyone $20 for a place that isn't really worth it. You can see the whole venue just from standing in one spot. The Bathroom was ridiculously small. The worst part of the night was the DJ. There were so many other songs he could've played. It was an alright night.

4.description: I don't usually leave comments on yelp but this place is horrible. I've been to this place for 3-4 times already. Pro about this place is nice and clean; however it's always dead during the weekend. On a Saturday night, couple of my friend decided to grab couple drinks. We reserved a table and open 2 bottle of Hennessy and 2 dozen of miller light (the server never bring us the second dozen) When we were about to pay our bill, the total was $600+!!! That ridiculous. Other karaoke bar in Chinatown is far more populated and cheaper comparing to this bar.I will never come to this place ever again.

6.description: I visited 15/20 lounge four times since its soft opening. Why? You asked. It's because I can discover some new and fun everytime I go there. They only offer a small menu for now and all the items are great. I can't wait until they have their full menu. Tried their happy hour menu, I loved it. Will definitelt recommand this place to my friends.

11.description: This place is huge and a great spot to hang with friends! There is an open lounge area and many private karaoke rooms. The drinks are great, they music selection is vast and the whole place is well maintained. A must go if you want to sing the night away!

5.description: OK. .. so I'm here 4 a comedy/poetry event.  The space is nice and large,  open feel with removable furniture along the interior.   But there are a few problems that I see which will probably lead to it not staying around for too long. 1st: Which most will feel is the most important.  The service needs work.   Its about 80-100 ppl here with a total of 4 servers/ food bar staff.One girl who is actually a server,  another girl that was orginally a bartender now she's serving/bartending. One guy that's a bartender (I guess).  He's hasn't moved from behind the bar so I guess he is. And another guy who doesn't have a firm position. .lol he's doing it all running food, taking orders, making drinks,  telling other ppl what to do. Not as organized as one would think.2nd: Timing... timing need to be seriously checked in this place.  I waited about 5-10mins to get a drink.  Now that wouldn't be bad if the bar was full but I was at the bar with 3ppl...3ppl.  Not 30ppl! And without a simple look my way, head nod notice, nothing saying ok I see you. Not to mention that ppl are pretty much walking to the server station to place orders and get someone's attention.  WTH.. is that?..poor customer service3rd: Possibly getting your food order correct or in a timely manner. Now while writing this the girl that's the actual server approached me asking if I order chkn wings. ... now as good as they looked I would have told her yeah! But I don't take what's not mine...lolvs.4th/& a possible 5th: This one might just be me but they need to turn on a little heat in this place because it's colder in here than outside tonight. .. but then again this might just be me...lolLastly but 4 you to decide is the drink prices.  I personally think they could have been more reasonable but I'm not management.  So that's what I think about 15/20 lounge. So Spend well and spend wise

7.description: Big place with no people in it.... I came last saturday night, it was completely empty. And the waiters were doing bad services as well. The decoration is OK, but I dont think im gonna come back again.

8.description: Went here for an after a banquet, Place is huge. Didn't get to see the Karaoke rooms, but the main lounge area is nice. Can feel a bit empty because of the space though, but all in all had a good time.

0.description: Been to all the karaoke within the area. This one is by far the cleanest and well kept. The music selection is up to date. And theres a decide variety of drinks on the menu.  Definitely coming back here again
