58.description: If you don't mind Guangzhou-train-station-type shoving, this place is great. Fresh wonton noodles, hard-to-find seafood, Thai rice, even frozen duck tongues -- it's all here. The only complaint of course, is that someone's armpit will probably be up your nostrils in the vegetable section. If you're a stickler for personal space don't think of visiting -- the violation of physics, i.e. 'where you are I can be also' prevails. The rest of us just grit our teeth and sally forth to buy yard-long beans at non-Whole Foods prices.

56.description: This is the sort of market I grew up knowing all too well like in Flushing, NY (AKA the 2nd Chinatown of NYC). They carried my childhood brand of frozen green-onion pancakes (AKA Scallion Pizza Pie according to the package). My roommate has tendency to ask me to make them every Sunday morning from scratch, and hopefully these will buy me a few weeks off. I think this frozen pack of those delectable pancakes taste better than most restaurants because they cook up chewy, crispy, and flavorful.The selection of produce is small, but hardcore Chinese (if I could be allowed to describe it that way) from 3 sizes of bok choy and all for $2.00/pound or lychees. They also have a wide selection of teas from China from gunpowder green tea to jasmine in ounce tins for $2.99 (about the size of a peanut butter jar).Also from my childhood are the single-serving juice boxes of Vitasoy. It's juice sweetened with cane sugar rather than corn syrup. I've always liked this style of juice better than something like Welsh's or Juicy Juice as a kid. The only thing missing is elbow room.

29.description: This place is small, but the store has most of the stuff most people needs, and the price is cheap.However, it still leaves a lot to be desired. A lot of the 'fresh' noodles are not as fresh as I'd like (check the date/inspect for freshness), the tofu/bean curd products are limited - they do not have fried tofu skin pouches, and the selection of vegetarian sauces are more limited than I'd like. Also, the variety and the freshness of the produce isn't as good as I like. I grew up in NYC, so perhaps I'm spoiled, but I have to say that I have been disappointed in most of the Asian markets here. So by Chicago standards, it gets 3 stars. (For the record, I prefer to go to H-mart in Niles for produce if I happen to head out that way- it's much fresher as there's much quicker turnaround. However, H-mart is Korean and doesn't have many Chinese sauces and tofu products, so for those you still need a Chinese market).

42.description: much smaller than i expected. from previous reviews i knew the aisles were a bit tight but i didn't think the store was made up of about 4 aisles. definitely have cheap prices. i left with 2 bags of stuff for only $15.they are a bit limited in their selection of products but its good enough to hold you over. super close to the red line which is very convenient.

23.description: Small. Dirty. Pales in comparison to H-Mart and 99 Ranch Market. Small selection of everything. But still the best way to get groceries in Chinatown :(

47.description: Chinatown market keeps cheap prices in a crowded grocery store.  As the name suggests, you can find all sorts of asian products that jewel doesn't stock, but that's not why its a four star establishment.  You see, I gained a general understanding of the death of animals in order to make me delicious food from the Rosario's Butcher sign at 87th and Pulaski.  This sign shows a flourescent pig with a smile on its face jump into a meat grinder which then spells 'rosario's'.  Its old and animated the way they used to do so its actually four pigs, but at night you can see the neon pig throw himself into the meat grinder.  I stared at it for years, before, at 10, it made sense to me.   But  I digress.  You should take your children here to watch the butcher counter.  I've never seen someone handle blades and goo and various eels with such professionalism.  As a city dweller, I feel so far removed from the process of my food!   It certainly doesn't make me hungry, but it gives  a moment of pause as to how hard it is to make animals taste so good.  Wait, maybe your kids don't need that.  Ok, just get some asian candies and gelatin.

8.description: Chinatown Market is a typical Chinese grocery store. I was able to easily find the items I sought as well as be pleasantly distracted by other wares. I found Chinatown Market to feel authentically foreign but readily accessible by someone who is not Chinese (or Asian).I was delightfully bemused by many items - even familiar ones - because of the Chinese writing on them. For example, I eagerly bought some almond tea but discovered it was different from what I expected when I got home. I'm sure my confusion was a result of not being able to read the details of the label. I had a similar experience with the bao. I couldn't properly comprehend the flavors and ended up not buying any at all.The prices of items were less than related items in a non-Chinese grocery store. For example, a bag of about a dozen bao was about $5.99 at Chinatown Market and a box of six is $8.99 at Jewel. I came away with a bag of frozen steam bread, almond tea, and red bean ice cream for about $15.The isles are close together but not impassable with other shoppers present. Business was bustling but I was still able to move about as I wished without any hindrance.Chinatown Market has live seafood; however, I wouldn't feel comfortable buying and consuming any of it. The tanks were very small and the fish seemed sickly and close to death.The customer service at the check out registers was efficient. I don't recall any smiles or niceties. Furthermore, nobody offered assistance as I wandered around the store. I didn't notice any employees helping other customers either.I like Chinatown Market better than Joong Boo Market. I found Chinatown Market to be smaller and more manageable to my needs; however, Joong Boo Market had a much larger inventory.

31.description: We stopped by here on Saturday afternoon, the place was kind of busy, free parking helped a lot, we found almost everything we had on our shopping list, great selection is offered here, things don't look like they have been sitting on the shelf, prices are very reasonable. Great store!

34.description: I went here yesterday as Chinatown is alot closer to me than my normal Asian grocery stores in Arlington, Uptown, or Joong Boo Market and all I needed were a few fresh goods.The place was slammed and since it is small and cramped to begin with this made it rather difficult to get around.  This store is not my favorite because of this and it is small so selection is not the best.  That being said I got exactly what I wanted.  Tofu, long chives, bitter melon, sprouts, shiitake, inoki, & shimeji mushrooms.  Asian mushrooms are hard to find outside of Asian markets and when you do find them they are way overpriced.  Whole Foods carries inoki for about $3.50 per bag compared to here where they are .59 cents.  Moral of the story is when I need to do a major trip I will still go elsewhere but when I just need some fresh goods for the week this is definitely worth the trip.

16.description: Crowded. Tiny. But this is the place I am here every week because:Fresh vegetables compare to other Chinese grocery stores. Private parking. Not bad customer service. Good price.

13.description: !!!RATS!!!***RUN AS FAR AS YOU CAN, UNESS YOU CANNOT GET THE SAME INGREDIENT SOMEWHERE ELSE*****Let me start off by disclaiming that I am second generation Vietnamese from Ca, now residing in the south loop.  I use to frequent this market twice a week.  I have seen it all in Asia, and in California, as far as Asian markets go this one takes the cake for dirtiest market I've ever seen.  ILike all Chinese operated establishments if you don't speak chinese you are treated like dirt. The fish mongers will bypass you standing, patiently waiting and speak to gal who speaks Chinese.  You will stand there and wait until the last person is done until they start yelling at you in unintelligible chinese knowing you don't speak the language.  After having my bag of bleeding ribs tossed at me like a beggar, I headed towards the front to pay.  The cashier without a care, threw my onions and scallions into the same bag as my bleeding meat.  I think I threw up in my mouth.  Wow.  i"m a person who loves her food, this place clearly couldn't care less if they contaminate your food.  For the unforgettable final act, I realized I'd forgotten bean sprouts and headed to the back to grab a bag before leaving.  As there were no more bean sprouts in the front, i walked to the back where they were sorting veggies to see if there were any left.  I stopped dead in my tracks when I saw what I came to realize was a huge rat nibbling on what ever derby there was on the floor.    The people sorting the veggies did not notice me.  I stood there in awe and disgusted beyond comprehension.  I understand that lots of markets have rats, but to come out in the day time is something I've never seen before.  Plus the fact that the people working there seemed completely unfazed by the rodent is truly disturbing.

11.description: It's really dirty, small, and smells like sewage.  They try to cram as much as possible into the limited space, leaving virtually no room for people to pass one another in an aisle.  I only go here because it's so convenient being in Chinatown, and I like to stock up on my Asian coffees and beverages.  Otherwise, I'd avoid at all costs.  Go to H Mart or Mitsuwa in the burbs if you really want to go all out with Asian ingredients, but for a hard-to-find Asian ingredient or two, this place does the trick.

39.description: PROS AND CONS...They have free parking: Pro.The aisles are so narrow and crowded that there's no way I'm making it out in a fire: Con.Produce selection is so-so: Con.The ladies in the back will give you fresher stuff if you ask: Pro.Again, they have free parking: Pro.

37.description: i'm not going to argue with a place that has like, three dozen different kinds of tofu to choose from as well as a candy aisle with so many items of interest that they'd send my lady into diabetic shock if she ever ate them all (and she's not even diabetic - but this candy aisle, THIS is where things like that start people!). Veggies? Meh. This place isn't my first choice for those. But that tofu selection though? Good grief.

0.description: UNIQUEEveryone loves Chinese food but how many of us try and tackle it home. This store is a perfect place to start this adventure. I recently dragged my family in here to check it out. Hopefully I haven't traumatized my little one who seemed to be clutching her poor nose the whole time. She has to understand that Dad traveled the World and finding a place like this in Chicago is an adventure he can't pass up plus it's educational. I am going to jump right to the fish section which I thought my little one would enjoy. They have live fish in tanks which is what they have in the grocery stores and restaurants in China. I was always impressed with how you could truly order a fish from the tank for your meal. What was really unique here was the live bucket of eels. It was sitting right on the floor and you could literally put your hand in there and grab one. My little one wasn't petting any of the eels. Ha!One of the areas of the store that I really liked was all of the noodles available. We do experiment at home with our cooking but I want real Asian noodles at home. This place is going to really change our dishes and probably take them up a few notches. I can hardly wait to start stocking up on the many varieties of noodles. The store was an adventure. I could have spent an hour in here checking all of the items but I'm not sure the girls could handle it. I was just happy they lasted as long as they did. As a young child, my parents took me on a train trip in Italy and the smells I experienced on that train made me the adventurer I am today. Everything doesn't have to smell like roses and that is what makes the adventure more exciting. I really enjoyed this place and can not wait to come back shopping here. The store is small and people will be rushing by you because they actually know what they are looking for. I am glad to have experienced this place and can not wait to come back.

38.description: Not my favorite market in Chinatown, by any means. They do though however have some of the cheapest prices on some of my favorite snacks. What I don't like about it is, that the isles are really really tiny and not easy to navigate, if one person has a cart in the isle forget trying to squeeze by. The place also is very run down and not as clean as one would hope a market to be, and their is a very very strong ginsing smell here. That smell is all over Chinatown but it's especially strong in this little market for some reason. This place also has a creepy factor, every person who works here is wearing latex gloves  and sometimes face masks. It's really off putting, for some reason. What keeps me coming back here even with all these negative factors? The snack isle. You won't find cheaper Poky prices in this main area of Chinatown. Same for the chocolates, gummi's, and the odd Japanese kit Kat. (In fact this tiny little store is the ONLY place that I know of that the kit Kat's can be found) Also don't forget to grab some tasty rumane soda while you are here, they also have the best pries on that too!

51.description: Not having a car, this is the most convenient place for all my Chinese food needs. Despite it's small size, it has the basic snacks, instant noodles, drinks and sauces that I need. It also has some good fresh produce from more commonly eaten chinese vegetables, to meats and seafood. Whenever I'm dying for a whole steamed fish, I'll get it here for always under $5. Sometimes fresh, sometimes frozen depending how I'm feeling. I also get everything here when I'm having hot pot. The food is dependable and also at affordable prices. I prefer the extra aisle space here compared to Mayflower in the plaza, but if you have a car, I would definitely visit the larger markets right off of the main part of Chinatown. Still props for giving me all my yummy goodies that I crave.To get/try:Nissan Instant Noodles (Pork Bone flavor)Shrimp ChipsVita drinks (iced tea, soy milk)Aloe Vera DrinkFish/vegetables/meats anything you need that you can't find at a regular supermarket.

27.description: My favorite place to get groceries in Chinatown! It's conveniently located just off the "L" stop and usually has a solid selection, though not amount, of produce at great prices. (And the produce is always fresh and in good shape.) The aisles are narrow so it always feels crowded, but what gives, more authentic Chinese shopping experience, right?

32.description: I got a nightmare experience with this place today, When we first came in, the first feeling of this market is extremely dirty and dark, the same as most of the Chinese style market. Smelling bad, mixed with the smell of mold and smoke and nasty food, even could not breath. When we finally got through the crowd and tried to check out, the rude cantonese cashier switched my credit card but said the machine was broken and brought us to the nearby counter. She shouted at me: " Bring all you stuffs back here, I need to screen them again. " She pointed to me and gave feeling that all was my fault in front of all other customers. It really raise my temper and I decided to cancel this transaction because i did not sign anything.  But when I got back and I suddenly found on my bank statement that they just steal the money from my card. What a freak. I called the bank straight away to stop this payment and raise dispute. I will never go to this Chinese market anymore, they are a group of thieves and lier. And I suppose most of the workers are just arrived from the border and they need some clean up. Maybe someday I will call 911 to verify their status.

54.description: Only decent place in the city I know of to get good live blue crab.  I wish the cashiers didn't look at me like I stole something every time I buy something tho.Cheap prices!

48.description: A word of warning to anyone with a waistline larger than 32": the aisles are tiny and don't even THINK about bringing a cart into this place-especially on the weekends. This is a great place for produce, pork bellies, crabs, and yellow croacker, etc. Did I mention the awesome selection of Asian candies and snacks? Gummies, candies, seaweed chips, fish chips, red bean jellies galore. The parking is awful and if you do find a parking spot on the street, treasure that spot and dump the groceries asap so you can also eat sometime in between grocery shopping trips.  It's relatively close to the Cermak el so if you're not lucky enough to have a car, hop the Red Line instead. In any case, it'll be worth the trip since it's fresher, cheaper, and more exotic produce and game.

44.description: As a native Southern Californian, this market is certainly nothing to write home about.  Limited brand selection, reallllly realllly small and crowded, and often smells super funky.  Often, veggies (specifically, eggplant) aren't really nice and fresh.  That said, it really has almost everything that you might want (perhaps not in the brand you want, but at least something is there), everything is pretty cheap, there's hot-pot meat available, and the pork loin (great for almost any Chinese dish) is MUCH cheaper than at Jewel or other supermarkets, and it's at a convenient location (Cermak/Chinatown stop on the Red Line).  I'd be sad to see it close, but I wouldn't be sad to see it closed and replaced by something more awesome (like Super H Mart in Naperville!).  And I'd be happy to see their big free parking lot back, too.   Parking's a nightmare in Chinatown!

24.description: OK honestly this pales in comparison to the wonderous Asian markets of California.. but you adapt. They have maybe a dozen fresh veggies, bagged by those Asian ladies in the corner. You can get a week's worth of greens for 2 people for about $10. I haven't yet ventured into trying the meat yet, but it looks like it's all pork. I've also picked up some random Chinese snackage (grass jelly, tapioca pearls...), but the place is tiny so not a whole lot of selection. Best part is that they take CREDIT CARD! And it's across the street from the L.

7.description: The preggo wifey was craving moon cakes because of the mid autumn festival so I booked a zip car and drove down there. We chose Chinatown over heading to uptown as we figured Chinatown would definitely have moon cakes whereas lil Vietnam may not have it. The grocery store is ok. It smells of fish right when you walk in but don't all Asian grocery stores. This is an ok grocery store if you are in Chinatown and need to grab a few things, but even then it doesn't cover enough to be considered a true grocery store. It does the best with what it has but beyond that it is a pass.

49.description: Lots of cheap produce and weird fake meats. Some stuff I tried was really good and some was gross like the fake chicken I bought. But it's all really cheap. Lots of interesting imports.  And I love the cans of Chinese red bull.

40.description: This is my usual go-to spot for Asian grocery items. They have a pretty good selection and pretty good prices. The produce, frozen goods, teas and sauces are great. They have live seafood available and will freshly cut either fish or meat for you. I try to avoid this place on the weekends because there are more people packed in here than usual and it's a little cramped as is. Besides that, they carry lots of imports and have great prices.

53.description: One of the better supermarkets in Chinatown in terms of selection and price.Just one block away from the Cermak/Chinatown Red Line stop and a mile or two away from the Loop, Chinatown Market offers a wide selection of Chinese goods from live seafood to cookies to frozen dinners. Their beverage selection is pretty decent.However, I agree with the other yelpers in saying that this place is too small for its clientele - it gets really busy on the weekends. There is barely enough space to walk in the aisles when it is crammed with people and shopping carts and flattened boxes - so be prepared to squeeze and shout your way through the insanity of it all. The lines will actually extend all the way into the aisles as well - there are only three registers open and you can spend upwards of ten minutes in line cursing those in front of you. The checkout people are pretty calm and efficient, however. This place is also pretty notable for being one of the few grocery stores that will take credit cards.If you're looking for some Chinese groceries, Chinatown Market should be on your list. But be prepared to bring riot gear on the weekends.

30.description: It's a conveniently located market if you visit chinatown for a food run. Perhaps I'm just spoiled by the Ranch 99 type of chinese supermarkets, but this place is it's so tiny and the isles are so narrow that it's a headache getting around while inside. This especially becomes a problem on the weekends when the place is flooded with people and shopping carts. That being said, though, this place pretty much has everything you would need for an authentic chinese meal. Their butcher counter has a good variety of unusual cuts usually not found in American supermarkets such as pork belly and such. They also have a very good selection of fresh/live seafood including things like razor clams, live eels, and live fish that they will clean up on the spot for you. So overall this place has the goods, I just wish they had more space to put it all but with that said I would return here for my shopping needs in the future.

46.description: Chinatown Market is pretty decent.  They're not spectacular, but they're acceptable.  They're clean enough - doesn't usually smell much - and they have a good selection.  They'd be well-served to split the entrance and exit doors to improve traffic flow.  But, truth be told, this is the Chinese market I use the most because the balance of cleanliness, selection and convenience (it's the closest one to the Red Line stop) is the best.  I recommend it, even at 3 stars.Note: Recently (as of Feb 9th, 2009) their former parking lot adjacent to it has been unavailable.  Not sure why, and it doesn't affect me at all but if you're a driver keep that in mind.

1.description: Daddy J. and Rosa J. were on the look out for rice wine (michiu cooking wine) because Mama J. needed it for making Ginseng chicken soup.  Mama J. wanted the Taiwan-made, preferably the one that was made by "Taiwan Tobacco & Liquor Corporation."  Was this piece of information specific enough for you know-it-all Yelpers?  My captain: we have successfully located the michiu cooking wine.  In addition, it was the brand that Mama J. was looking for.  Ok, I guess our mission could be considered accomplished.That 750-ml bottle cost $4.90 (including tax).  That was much more expensive than the compatible size you would find on the other side of the globe.  Well, our Democratic government certainly thought we Chinese like to consume hard liquor on our spare times.  The truth is: no thanks.  That sucker is normally used for getting rid of the funny smell poultry or seafood renders.  Thus, after this thorough explanation, would you reduce the import tax?  I personally thought this place was crowded and unsanitary-looking.  The aisles were extremely narrow.  Just like many other markets and eateries in Chinatown, having personal spaces is prohibited.I still recommend the Hong Kong Market on Wallace (south on Archer; near CTA Halsted Orange Line station).  However, the Chinatown Market is one (1) south to the CTA Cermak/Chinatown Red Line station, if you're looking for convenience rather than shopping with a peace of mind.

55.description: I bought this "diet" tea I nick named "Poo Poo" tea from here. It worked. I lost 5 pounds!!I like the live creatures they have in buckets. It's great if you know what you're looking for - in my case TEA. Poo poo tea!

9.description: Went there today to buy some clams.  The market is very stink in general.  So when I brought the clams I didn't know they were already dead.  After I brought it home, it stink badly, and the claim was obviously mostly dead.  I went back and ask for refund.  The old man in charge of the seafood section say there is no refund on seafood.  I told him I will report to consumer service if I don't get my refund, he say "GO DO IT".  Bad attitude!!!!  I just paid for it, how could there be no refund.  Luckily I was able to exchange my credit for something else from the cashier.  I will not recommend people buying seafood from them.

26.description: This place is the epitome of what a stereotypical Chinese grocery store is like.  It is so crowded.  You will be often moving from place to place to get out of someone's way or to try and get something.  They definitely try to pack in as many things as possible on the shelves and floors.  I am surprised that they have a meat/poultry and seafood section available here because the place is pretty small.  My request to others that are just here to hang out with friends and not really to shop and buy anything is to wait outside because we need the space!  The lines wrap down to the aisle so it makes it hard for people that are shopping down the aisle to look since people are also waiting  there to check out.  I can definitely get the essential items here, but there might not be as many brand options to choose from.  The prices are comparable.  The staff is pretty quick on the registers, but they have to be to get people out of the lines faster.

25.description: Hm. Prices are more or less the same as any other market. Nothing really stands out here except the free parking lot. The space is small and when you add shopping carts it can get frustrating when navigating around the store. Some people are just super oblivious and block up the whole aisle (which is already narrow) so you just have to push past them.

12.description: If you don't mind shopping in a rush-hour subway like atmosphere, then you'll do well here. Although I'm glad I don't have to travel all the way to Argyle to get the basics, the size of this store gives me anxiety. I suggest coming during the week as opposed to the weekend.

59.description: Small grocery store, but it has a good selection of products. The prices are decent and who can complain about 69c tofu! The veggies are always fresh and I always get what I need here. Only drawback is that is it always crowded since it's so small.

21.description: They definitely have some awesome stuff here. I like their selection of drinks since they are don't carry the typical stuff that other stores have. The aisles here are pretty small so it's aggravating to deal with patrons shopping while you're clambering to get out. It's nice to know they have a decent dumplings selection along with buns and meats.

17.description: One word comes to mind when I think of this place - CLAUSTROPHOBIA. This place is disgustingly tiny and I always feel like I'm in the way. You can't get up and down the aisle without stepping on someone or hitting a person with your cart. Also, it's dirty and kinda smells.Chinatown Market, compared to many of the other Asian grocery stores in the area (HK market, Richwell market, etc) is super tiny. The variety is also on the limited side and not all of the produce is fresh. On top of that service is kinda blah, not surprising considering it's Chinatown, but ehh..still come here time to time for Asian ingredients though...On the positive side, there is a private parking lot...

10.description: This place is dinky. Like "wow you guys really tried to make the most of your space" dinky. But it gets the job done and it also happens to be the only spot I have found so far since moving here a few weeks ago. The prices are fair and the produce that I have gotten here is not too bad. I am still trying to find the Chicago equivalent to Ranch 99 but until I do I'll be coming here.

5.description: Nat as nice as I had imagined it, more industrial than commercial but you can definitely find a lot of  options for lunch and dinner.

3.description: I wanted to make mapo tofu at home, so I thought, where else to get authentic szechuan ingredients? Chinatown Market! Seems like a foolproof plan, right? Wrong. Because unfortunately I am not Chinese and cannot read what the labels say. The nuisance I am, I tried asking various checkout clerks for help but they just shook their head saying they don't speak english! Fine. I'm the foreigner here. So I asked, like, six fellow shoppers. Most of them had different names for the items on my list and didn't know what I wanted. The guys who work in the aisles brushed me off as soon as I spoke english. By the way, the aisles can probably fit one skinny person because that's how crammed they are. And a bunch of english labels on the products aren't proper translations, which can be frustrating for non-speakers.Ultimately I got all the things I needed after 1.5 hours of searching, thanks to a lovely Chinese lady and her newborn son who took pity on me.Pros: - CHEAP! I got a bunch of spices, some douchi, two containers of doubanjiang, two containers of tofu, some vegetables, and (just in case) instant mapo tofu sauce. All that came to $16.- Authentic. The smell says all- You enter, and completely forget the store is 15 minutes from downtown Chicago, an American metropolis.Cons:- Service is nonexistent even when requested- Language barrier- I wouldn't say it's dirty, but I definitely could not call it clean.

35.description: They finally have the parking lot open for this market! Free parking!! But I wouldnt park here if you dont intend on shopping here. They might tow your car otherwise.The grocery store has a lot of items for sale, some ON sale, some not. But the prices here are pretty cheap without a sale.  The aisles are extremely narrow so expect to be standing really closely to your neighbor, especially when it gets busy.  They have fresh veggies (wrapped in bags for cleanliness and ease of purchase), seafood, and meat (butcher available). I was able to charge less than $10 worth of food with my AMEX. Yay! I guess they dont have a credit card minimum?

19.description: Save yourself some trouble and go to HK Market where you can actually walk around without feeling overwhelmed. This market is located right across from Chinatown Square and conveniently located right by the CTA Red Line, which is probably the only good thing about it. This place always seemed packed with people and like everyone else say, their aisles are so narrow that you don't even have room to walk or shop peacefully. Chances are you can find most of what you are looking for in here, but this place is small compared to other markets around.

28.description: This is more of a local review, as we were only here because the person we were staying with needed to go grocery shopping.  She wanted to get some water and rice.  This way she could get us to carry it back.  It's a small asian market, but has the basics, and very close to her place of residence.

45.description: Decent little market. We usually come here for our meats, veggies and other items when we do hot pot at home. Sometimes they have good deals on the asian drinks.Aisles are small and tight. Can get crowded at times. Heard they sold their parking lot or rented it out. Which I think is dumb. Can park across at the parking lot, but a little inconvenience.

33.description: Imagine squeeze as much as possible groceries in a small space, and you got it. It is crazy here when people are shopping, because of the lack of walking space. I really did not find anything that I was looking for, nor wanted at this market.

43.description: For whatever odd reason, every time I come here, the fish monger is always slaughtering a turtle.  My friend Trisha was with me and she had just purchased a itty bitty turtle from a gift shop down the street and now she was watching one get murdered!I have NO idea how to cook turtle, but I wish I did.  It must be nice and fresh here because there are always people buying.I was impressed to see that they had live razor clams today.  That is a nice find! However, I couldn't remember if my husband likes them or not. If he does, I will return.  The other fish selection is ok, probably about the same as Richwell.Produce section kinda lacks.  Hong Kong Market is much bigger and better selection.  Excellent selection of sauce and SURPRISINGLY today, I actually had one of their staff ASKING ME IF I NEEDED HELP - in English!I've been grocery shopping all my life at Asian groceries stores and I've never been assisted proactively!!!  (Young Chinese guy with glasses with a Cantopop singer haircut).

2.description: I like that they have their own parking lot, albeit a very small one. Aside from fresh seafood, they have asian beauty products! They have My Scheming masks $13, My Beauty Diary masks $13, tsubaki? Conditioner and other items! The produce quality can vary but if it's good enough for my parents, it's good enough for me!

18.description: I don't have other bad things to add besides what everybody else has mentioned - tiny, tiny, tiny, did I say tiny?BUT, this is the only place that I have found the yogurt flavor of the hi-chew candy. Yes, I am that obsessed with this flavor of this candy.Also awesome selection of sauces, noodles (not just ramen, non-fried too), Asian snacks and drinks. I also find their shiitake mushrooms the most fragrant and fresh.The private parking lot is sweet.

41.description: Coming from a pretty amazing Chinatown in Houston stocked with large Asian supermarkets, this was quite the change.  However, being in the city, it's not too bad.So the cons: - The veggies aren't exactly the freshest (but what do you expect in the city?)- There aren't too many brands to choose from (you have your standards, Lee Kum Kee, etc etc)- It gets crowded really easily (the aisles are tight.  As in, no room for anything more than a cart)But the pros:- It's CHEAP, which, in my opinion, is always a plus.- It's super close to the El.  This saves me a lot of trouble not having a car.  Just take the red line to Cermak-Chinatown, walk 5 minutes, and you're there.- Although it doesn't have everything, you can always find things that are in season.Overall, this isn't the absolute best shopping experience, but it gets the job done; and I don't have to waste money buying the same thing at Whole Foods.

52.description: I went on a Saturday and I didn't find it to be ridiculously crowded at all. I don't see why I haven't been here before. They have an amazing selection of stuff. Things are cheap too. For $21 I left with two bags full of stuff. What's amazing about that, is that I didn't just buy candy. I bought everything from dumplings, to a case of green tea.  The fact  that it's close to the train is an added bonus. I honestly love this place and wish I lived nearby because I'd go almost every day.

50.description: I usually go here to shop for my groceries because it's conveniently located by the Cermak El stop. I tried the smaller markets, but I think the produce here is marginally better (not by that much, though). The selection is adequate too. Prices are reasonable, but nothing compares to 99 Ranch Market or TS Emporium in SoCal.Chinatown Market is good for the basics, though, and I usually don't have to go elsewhere for my grocery needs. Make sure you look at the expiration dates on all your stuff - I have on occasion gotten items that were questionable in quality...Extra star because they carry my favorite brand of frozen dumplings (Wei Chuan). $10 for 3 bags, not bad! They have yummy mochi ice cream too! Also, they're typically open later than the smaller markets, which is a definite plus.

4.description: The Chinatown market is the most rubbish I see the attitude of the service is very poor A lot of packing everything is out of date And the door covered with 50 consumer to send 3 hour parking is false We on the same day in consumption of 200 across the may flower is better In a word This shop open They don't lack I

6.description: The great thing about this place is that I can get my fresh fish from here (Yes, using your Chinese language will be useful here.. if you don't know Chinese, a lot of pointing, nodding and body language will be necessary or you can find someone who can translate for you). I usually go to HK market for everything but Hk market doesn't sell live fish. They also have a free parking lot. Most places in Chinatown is street parking but this place has a parking lot so it's more convenient than others.

22.description: One word comes to mind when I think of this place - CLAUSTROPHOBIA. This place is disgustingly tiny and I always feel like I'm in the way. You can't get up and down the aisle without stepping on someone or hitting a person with your cart. Also, it's dirty and kinda smells.Chinatown Market, compared to many of the other Asian grocery stores in the area (HK market, Richwell market, etc) is super tiny. The variety is also on the limited side and not all of the produce is fresh. On top of that service is kinda blah, not surprising considering it's Chinatown, but ehh..still come here time to time for Asian ingredients though...On the positive side, there is a private parking lot...

15.description: If you're familiar with H-Mart or 99 Ranch, this place definitely cannot compare.  It's small, cramped, and seemingly always crammed with people.That said, there is a surprisingly good selection of fruit, produce, meats, seafood, and various Asian condiments.  I saw both rambutan and durian in the fruit section.  Prices are cheap and there's a private parking lot.  Not a bad place to stop for the staples.

57.description: The store gets crazy busy on weekends and the aisles are small....if you're a little chubby you'll be getting in the way of a lot of people.There are some good deals and great selection.  Fresh vegetables and seafood.  Tons of snacks and hong kong specialties.Don't try to park there and go across the street to pick up some bubble tea from Joy Yee's.  I did it once and the parking guy yelled at me for five minutes.My favorite chinese grocery store in Chicago for sure and I live 2 Redline stops from the Argyle stores.

20.description: If you're familiar with H-Mart or 99 Ranch, this place definitely cannot compare.  It's small, cramped, and seemingly always crammed with people.That said, there is a surprisingly good selection of fruit, produce, meats, seafood, and various Asian condiments.  I saw both rambutan and durian in the fruit section.  Prices are cheap and there's a private parking lot.  Not a bad place to stop for the staples.

36.description: If you are ever in the area, it is fun to come here for some great produce or meat.  The Fish is great as well!  Lobster, crab, ect......One of the few places in Chicago you can still get live crab and lobster....They butcher the fish right in front of you!!  Nobody speaks any english, so be patient in explaining what you are looking for.

14.description: My friend says she thinks the little saigon (with touches of chinese & thai eats) on argyle feels more alive than the actual chinatown.  I don't have enough experience with either to say, but it's something to consider.  The boba tea we got nearby was overly watery,  alas.    At this market I bought two tasty snacks which I love, honey sesame walnuts and ginger candy.  Excellent.

58.description: asian candies to make yer head spin. i got the dried lemon ginger and the candy cigarettes.

56.description: Aji Ichiban along with Saint's Alps are super awesome Hong Kong imports. Aji Ichiban is basically an Asian snacks buffet galore, with plenty of candy, savory snacks such as dried squid as well as other sweets such as preserved prunes and mango. You can mix and match everything and the prices are based on how much you put in your bag. If you've never eaten these things before, I would highly suggest you try them (there are free samples for almost everything except the packages candy). You will be pleasantly surprised despite the alien appearance, and you'll definitely be hooked forever. I really hope that as the Asian population in Chicago grows, more and more restaurant and store imports from all around Asia will make it to Chicago. It'll be so much more colorful and fun.

29.description: Everything here can be found at 1/4 the price anywhere else. This must be a tourist trap.I have not been so price abused since I went to Navy Pier, but  that is a location kind of rip off and I expect it. $17/pound for rice cracker mix  and hard candy is just too much.

42.description: Wow, I love the candy here!  So yummy!  We stopped here while we were bumming around Chinatown, and I decided to get my kids some candy.  First of all, there were 4 people working in this tiny store, and at least 2 of them were closely following us at all times.  I'm not sure what it is about me that makes me look like a thief, but I'm pretty sure that the mother was telling her 3 child employees to make sure I didn't give myself a five finger discount.  That was unsettling, to say the least.  I got a few tiny bags full of candy, and some other random packages, and somehow managed to spend $60!!!  Wow!  I was a bit shocked, but only a bit.  Hopefully the taste will make the $$ spent worth it.  So far, I have developed a grape gummy addiction, so I'm sure I will be back here to get my fix.

23.description: Munchie's paradise, indeed. While I'm sure there are other places to procure Asian candies at a better cost, Aji Ichiban serves as one-stop shop for me. If only I could curb my "kid in a candy store" enthusiasm and simmer down now. There's stuff that's familiar and unfamiliar. I grab handfuls of both.  The end result at the register can be shocking. I don't care. I love it.

47.description: Try before you buy: words to live by. Ichiban has samplings of tons of stuff sitting out for you to try and I highly recommend doing so.What sounds good or looks appealing may be the exact opposite, as was the case with multiple items. Interesting to see the various Chinese sweet and savory treats and not just the usual candy aisle offerings. The pocky was a bit more expensive than most other places but I did see a fancy pocky with nuts!Ps. the gummy candies are great! and I personally think the apple ones have a hint of whiskey (no one agrees with me).

8.description: Aji Ichiban is a cute little candy store in Chinatown.  We passed so many similar looking stores in this little "mall" that it took awhile before we found Aji Ichiban, the one we were looking for.There are some familiar treats like rice candy and Pocky, as well as the unfamiliar like dried spicy crabs.  Many of the bulk candies and salty snacks had sample bowls in front of them.  We tried some dried rose plums (or something like that), which were the best dried fruit I've ever eaten!  But for $10.99 for a teeny bag, I passed.I did pick up a few small items for myself including rice candy, but also some gummies in interesting flavors like Lychee and Muscat.  The flavors are subtle, so if those are unfamiliar to you, I suggest you give them a try!  I also threw in some random green tea hard candies and a candy wrapped in white with a Hello Kitty face on it.  The hard candies and gummies are pretty cheap, I only spent about $4 here.Some bins of candy are only labeled in Chinese.  That's okay.  I'm in Chinatown, after all.  But some bins of candy aren't labeled AT ALL.  I wasn't going to take my chances, and there were SO many unlabeled goods that I didn't bother asking.They also sell some American snacks like Skittles and Oreos, but they're way overpriced.  Stick to the unfamiliar stuff.  You didn't come to Chinatown for a bag of freakin' Skittles, did you?  I definitely don't need to be coddled in a candy store, but the ladies working here weren't friendly at all.  They weren't rude either.  Just don't expect anyone to take you by the hand and explain what a Muscat gummy is, and you'll be fine.

31.description: I was so excited to come here because I love asian candies! I really loved that they have sample out and open for you to try out before you buy. Although I got like 4 or 6 differnt candies it came out to be like 10 bucks! That is kind of pricey for some candies, I would suggest coming in here with at least 20 bucks willing to spend on a few candies. But some of the snacks are like 10 - 11 bucks the bag, although it's a pretty big bag.

34.description: You can trust this review. I'm huge on candy. I have a candy drawer in my room. Even one at my parent's house when I lived there. I tried giving up candy for Lent once during college. That just wasn't realistic cuz I ended up giving in to my sweet tooth a couple days in while trying to write a 20 page paper in 48 hours with footnotes required along with the paper. I couldn't be strong for Jesus. *weeps* Damn you candy. So I know my candy and this shop is alright for a couple pieces. I said a couple. This place sells asian snacks and that includes candy, dried fruit, dried fish, squid and shrimp, packaged cookies and cracker mixes. You can just fill up your bag with as much as you want. The downside is that it's a total rip off. You can find everything here for way cheaper elsewhere. They even sold snack size skittles for 50 cents apiece and other american candy for more than what you'd usually pay for. You can get the calbee shrimp chips elsewhere for atleast a dollar cheaper. I only come here once in awhile if I want a piece or two of a certain candy to snack on. I loove the asian gummies- it's a lot tastier than american gummy candy. My favorite would be the pineapple and the lychee gummies. Nearly 8 dollars for a pound? Huh? Fuck that shit.. I can get a bag of it for 2 dollars at the most elsewhere.They're really nice here and there's samples out. It just turns me off that tourists or those new to asian snacks attack these samples like they haven't eaten in days. I like how they tape up your bag neatly so your candies don't fall out. It's best to pay with cash but if you must- it's a ten dollar minimum if you want to pay with a card. If you know someone who deserves to be robbed of their money- send them here. Like that annoying co-worker with the annoying voice? Or the lazy one that takes long lunch breaks and doesn't do any real work spending their entire morning planning on where to lunch at and takes credit for your ideas during presentations? What a bitch. Yes, send those two.dead to me

16.description: I love candy and I also enjoy trying new things so this place was perfect! They have many different kinds of candy, some I was familiar with and others that were  new to me. What I like the most is that they offer samples of almost everything so that you can try before you buy! My Favorite is the candy that looks like rocks but its actually really yummy chocolate :-)P.S-  This place is EXPENSIVE but what candy store isn't?

13.description: The place is wonderful. A good variety of dried fruits and vegetables. Drinks and candy and also dried seafood. I am a fan of the dried rose plum and the dried vegetable chips. The place is very clean and well kept, but they are price gauging like crazy. I will be back, because I am pregnant and need those rose plums and vegetable chips, but please be warned the prices along with tax is through the roof. Will be back on special occasions only.

11.description: Look, I'm not going to pretend I know everything about what was happening in this jolly-looking little Asian snack shop, and the scowling, superannuated Chinese lady behind the counter was no help.  All I know is that they have vast, colorful buckets of candy in mystery flavors (well, I guess they're not so mysterious if you can read Chinese), and it's fun to buy a bunch and take them home and guess what they're going to taste like.  Or, in the case of durian, smell like.  Bonus for lazy Japanophiles:  decent assortment of bizarre Kit Kat and Pringles flavors.

39.description: Aji Ichiban, what happened? I know it's been a while since I've visited you, but you've really let yourself go. For one thing, most of the helpful tags are now gone and just replaced with stickers that tell price per half pound. And most of these items per *half pound* cost in the range of $9 to $10. This is for things that now you can usually find packaged at Super H Mart or Mitsuwa. The unusualness of their stock seems to have slipped. The two girls working there on the occasion I was in were not helping patrons, just chatting amongst themselves behind the counter. Considering the fact that there are signs everywhere saying things like, "Use the scoop! If you use your hand, you will have to buy entire bin!", they might have wanted to watch people a little more closely (there were a number of patrons in the place while we were there), but I guess it's management who's concerned about hands in the dried fish bin, not the 16-year-old clerks, ultimately. Overall, Aji Ichiban, I'm disillusioned. The thrill is gone. I'll stick with the Asian grocery stores from now on for my sugary goodness.

37.description: Two words: incredibly over-priced.  We bought shredded squid for $15 - if I had known it was $15 (this wasn't clearly labelled) I would not have bought it.  We then went across the street and saw bags of shredded squid at a local Chinese supermarket for $2.  I was tempted to buy the $2 bag and go back to throw it in their face.

0.description: Exotic Asian bulk foods. This would be five stars except the prices are high, per pound.You can find everything from fried crabs to preserved fruits. They also put samples of many of the items out for you to try before buying.This chain of stores is also open in various Asian countries and the selection is similar there as here.

38.description: What a nifty candy store. I really like the fact that there are samples of the bulk items for customers to try. One of my favorites is the spicy Thai peanuts: sweet at first, then a real spicy kick! I picked up some Pocky for my little sister (she really likes it) and some gummy rings (which were some of the best I've ever had). Aji Ichiban is a little pricey, but it has a really great variety. The staff was friendly and helped me, but you've got to take the initiative and ask, as they don't hover over you like the salespeople we're used to. I look forward to my next trip! It's fun 'cause there's always something new to try.

51.description: I have no idea what half the candy is in here, but how can you resist getting a bag and taste testing? Most of the things you can kind of guess what they are - a wide variety of gummy candies have pictures of the fruit they taste like on the packaging. Adorable cartoon characters and bright colors festoon the packaging. You immediately feel happier upon entering the store!The staff was not particularly helpful and they chatted amongst themselves, but that was fine by me because I just wanted to stare in amazement in some of the products.Definitely worth a visit even if you only leave with an 85 cent gummy hot dog.

27.description: This place had all sorts of candies, a bunch of dried foods, and chips. You can buy the items in bulk by weight. They also have samples of lots of the items that I think they make. For example, the dried squid has the store name on the bags. They had a spicy version and it was salty and perfect for snacking. :)

32.description: Nice little candy shop in Chinatown.  I like how they have samples out so you can "try before you buy".... especially since I can barely read/translate some of the packaging.  It's not just candy I saw in there, but snacks as well... things like dried squid, wasabi peas, and dried fruit can be found here as well.Definitely unique feel to the store and the staff are really nice about letting you wander through.  I'm always a fan whenever you can surprise yourself and find something new to try.

54.description: Took the 13 year old sister in law here and, needless to say, she LOVED it.  I don't think I've ever seen such a happy and sugared up kid in my life.  Hopefully, her parents don't find out that we let her eat about 5 lbs of mysterious Chinese candy while she was here.

48.description: So many fun, funky dried sweets and fish jerky options. Truth is, I always mean to buy some of the candies... but my little plastic basket fills with the dried stuff first. I could go broke here. The girls aren't overly helpful, but it isn't as if I need any help. It could very well be my busy vibe keeping them at a distance.

44.description: This place is pretty good and decently priced, but be careful you check the prices that are listed.

24.description: Great selection of Asian goodies including bulk candies, dried vegetables, dried fruit, and dried fish snacks. Want some cuttlefish or squid chips? This is a good place to go. Also lots of snack items including spicy peas and nut mixes with wasabi and such. My sister and I used to love to stock up on their candied ginger. It's the stuff dreams are made of (well, if you dream of ginger). Random stuff like miniature Japanese-market Kit-Kats show up here, too. As others have noted, the prices are a bit high, and you can definitely comparison-shop for some of the stuff here and get it cheaper elsewhere. But there's no other bulk candy/snack store that's solely devoted to all this pan-Asian goodness, so there's that. If you look like you don't know what you're doing with the scale, one of the staff members will swoop down to help you. Don't be alarmed. They just don't want you breaking their stuff. :)

7.description: This place is expensive. Like the Bergdorf Goodman of candy stores. But they got some cool snacks and candy that you can't find everywhere. I bought a ton of black Chuckles. I've never seen Chuckles packaged individually before and black licorice are the best so I had to stock up. I also bought some lychee gummies. Other than that, I didn't buy much. I did, however, try a few samples of some random candy that were all good.The people working the registers were very friendly and efficient. I want to also say that they do take debit/credit cards, which can sometimes be iffy in a small place like this. They were pretty busy but were still able to get us in and out quickly.Side note, I was sad they didn't have the Green Tea Oreos that someone posted a picture of. I actually wanted to try those.

49.description: Another chain that was all over Hong Kong that I never frequented until I moved here. This place is an Asian fat kids DREAM! Not only do they have all these packaged snacks from Asia (how many different ways can you coat a pretzel stick? Chocolate, nuts, fruity flavors, pizza... the list in endless) but then you also have the bulk candy. The sour gummy candies are a must try! The sour strawberry "tape" is amazing! As are the sour lychee and sour mango gummies. To top it all off, they have a bunch of treats from my teenage years - preserved plums, dried orange peel, dried cuttlefish, squid strips, Chinese-style jerky... mmm! I always walk out of here with over 50 dollars worth of stuff. The staff are pretty helpful and will tell you what certain items are (I don't think all of the bulk items in the boxes are named). Bonus points for having samples! Domo arigato Aji Ichiban!

40.description: I appreciate the wide variety of candies they carry here from Asia, but it is just too expensive. I actually went in and just bought 3 pieces and it was 75 cents. Seriously? When I saw the same candy in big bags and the May Flower Supermarket next door? However, I do like the fact that I can just buy 1 piece to try, instead of being stuck with a whole bag.

53.description: This is a really neat candy shop that carries just about any kind of Asian snacks/sweets that you may be looking for. They have a huge selection that changes every so often and have samples out for most of the dried fruit/seafood and some of the candy. They don't look at you weird for tasting everything you see either. They have few really awesome things that you can't find anywhere else. "White Rabbit" milk candy is really really good, so is the soda candy. Not many other places in the city carry it either so I don' t mind the sorta high prices. The jelly candies are also pretty tasty, Not my fave though. I also really like the "Preserved Plum" most people I know have a different opinion of it but I have odd taste buds. Check it out, Even worth a special trip to China Town just to visit here.

30.description: I love their dried vegetables. Crispier than potato chips, flavorful, and not greasy at all. I can eat a ton without feeling guilty. Their dried fish, fried squid and shrimp were also quite nice. The staff were always attentive and helpful when I visited this store.I would like to give it 5 stars, if their stuff was less pricey.

46.description: No, I"m not Chinese...but I'll eat their candy!  I love their soda candy that fizz in your mouth with a little grape flavor!  Coming in here makes me feel like a little kid again!  If you want help, you're definitely gonna have to ask for it...don't forget...you'r e in Chinatown...a place not known for great customer service.  But don't let that get in the way of your sugar hight!  *There is a $10 min. purchase to use your credit card, so be sure to bring some cash.

1.description: Was planning a Chinese New Year party in the office earlier this month. Happened to be in Chicago, so decided to come here to buy some snacks for my party. A good variety of snacks and candies, but pretty expensive. If you want to find snacks that you couldn't find elsewhere, then this place is great. But for some of the more common snacks, like Kit Kat matcha (green tea), then you're better off going to your Asian grocery stores where you can get them half of the price they had here.

55.description: Who doesn't love going to a candy shop?  You walk in and there are bins of candy everywhere, the majority of it is Asian candy.  Adults turn into kids in this store, curiously looking at all the different varieties of colorfully wrapped treats.I love Pocky, and they have several flavors of it here.  I had to smile when I saw the strawberry Hello Kitty pocky.  They also have dried fruit, such as pineapple and mango; dried fish snacks (I like the sweet and spicy squid); and even Chupa Chup lollipops and Pop Rocks.  Not really into sweets?  They have savory items here, as well, such as crunchy wasabi peas.I like to stop by this shop after a meal in Chinatown.  There's nothing like going home with a bag of goodies and sweets!

9.description: This candy/snack shop merges the best of both worlds for lovers of American candy and Asian candy. The fruit candy next to the display window caught my eye when I was walking around the Chinatown plaza, and I'm so happy I took a chance with this place. Even though Aji Ichiban is located in Chinatown, it definitely caters to a non-Asian population as well. Everything in the store is labeled with both Chinese and English names, making it super easy to decipher what you're dumping into your candy bag (which, by the way, goes for $11.50 per pound. A bit pricey, but I have yet to find an economy candy shop that sells candy at face value). Their store consists of Asian candy, a slight variety of old-school American candy, gummies, and a HUGE variety of dried fruit. Snacks that I have not munched on since middle school were sold here, and guess what, you get to sample before you buy! Even though I was never a big fan of the dried plums that Asians just seem to be extremely fond of, it was interesting getting to sample the 3+ varieties of dried plums they sold at Aji Ichiban. They also had dried strawberries, dried cherries, dried kiwi, you name it; most likely, if you're craving it, they have it. In addition to dried fruit, they also have dried anchovies, dried olives, and dried mushrooms (which I ended up purchasing). Since I wasn't from around there, I don't think I will be revisiting anytime soon, but if I find myself in Chi-town's Chi(na)town, I definitely would try to make a stop here! I am giving this place 4 stars because I'm impressed with their selection and sample offers. Honestly, you would not believe how many times I've bought a pound of food only to realize I did not like it because there was not an option to sample before purchasing. Service is friendly, although the workers do converse loudly across the store in Cantonese instead of greeting people. With my purchase, one of the nice guys working the register gave me a free pack of Coke-flavored pop rocks. If he had not offered it to me, I would have had no idea what it was especially since it was covered with Japanese words throughout. Feel free to ask what things are, you never know what you'll end up finding!

26.description: My boyfriend and I stop in here every time we're in Chinatown... so basically, we load up on candy every other week, lol.Not only does this place have the best selection of bulk Asian candies around, they carry dried fruit, dried fish, and some dried herbs as well.  I LOVE that they carry my favorite Kasugai gummies in bulk!  I like to keep (interesting) individually wrapped candies around for my clients or hand them to friends, and every flavor that I know of is represented at Aji Ichiban for price/oz similar to what I'd find at H-Mart in Niles.  For things like the dried fruits/veggies, you're probably better off going elsewhere for a better price. Convenient carry baskets located right at the front door, because you know you're going to buy WAY more than you intended!This visit's haul of individually-wrapped goodies:Ume-flavored hard candy- salty/sour and a tiny bit sweet?  my mouth is confused.Double Green Tea hard candy- very strong tea flavor, not too sweet.Coffee hard candy- meh.  not exciting.Hello Kitty Strawberry Marshmallow- mouthgasms!mini pancake sandwiches with red bean paste filling- meh.yuzu gummies- I was hoping they'd be bigger, more yuzu-ey than the Kasugai ones. :(

25.description: I realllllllly like the candies from this place but it is unGodly expensive. Buy at your own risks. Also, shop around. Some of the candies here sold individually can be bought from the nearby Asian stores for much cheaper. ;)

12.description: This is a really cute candy store that has a ton of different flavors that you can go through. I had one that was so sour I could not even hold it in my mouth. I had a lot of fun here and I will come back to buy some more and test out different kinds of candy. It is not our average candy price store though!

59.description: nice service and clean and stocked with hard to find Asian candies, this place gets a high candy store rating from me.  they also have a nice selection of tea in back.  part of the store sells crystal jewelry too -the selection is small but pretty.

21.description: It's a fun place to check out all the goodies and Asian snacks. It's very pricy though! My son 11 & daughter 8 had fun browsing the store. We even found Green Tea flavored KitKat! That was the high of the day! A Sweet Fun place!

17.description: All the little candies!Rows  and bins of colorful sweets. Pay by the pound; some pay per piece.Jellies, Rice Candy, Gum and more. Melon, Strawberry, Muscat, Lychee and others.Some pricey, some cheap. Fill up your basket. Savor the flavors. Wasabi Kit Kat? Gotta have it. Another stop on our Chinatown jaunts.

10.description: A super fun place to go - all the wacky Asian stuff.  Many you can sample!  The best tropical fruit gummy candies!  More kinds of Pocky than you shake your Pocky at!  The only downside is that it's expensive, but for one-stop shopping, and a fun experience, it's worth it.

5.description: Cute little candy store in Chinatown. They also have died fruits and vegetables. It's a little pricey,  but they have a huge variety not readily found just anywhere. It can be tight in there with a crowd. They charge for extra candy sacks.

3.description: This Japanese candy store is unique for Chinatown and Chicago in general.   Only Mitsuwa Market in Arlington Heights (25 miles away) has as big a selection of Japanese hard candies and other exotic confections.   As an added bonus, you can also purchase dried fruit, some of which you can't find anywhere else.But this experience comes with a price, and that price is high.   Your shopping basket with only a few items will end up costing you far more cash at the register than you might expect.   Unless there is something particular you are craving, best to satisfy your sweet tooth elsewhere.

35.description: I love their selection! I love going in and just looking at what they have to offer. My most recent grab was fruity daifuku. So delicious! Can't wait to go back.Some of their individually wrapped candy does seem a bit over priced at $11.00 per lb., but when you think about it, most of it is really light weight so you actually do get a lot for what you're paying.

19.description: Munchie's paradise, indeed. While I'm sure there are other places to procure Asian candies at a better cost, Aji Ichiban serves as one-stop shop for me. If only I could curb my "kid in a candy store" enthusiasm and simmer down now. There's stuff that's familiar and unfamiliar. I grab handfuls of both.  The end result at the register can be shocking. I don't care. I love it.

28.description: My parents went here for my Christmas Gifts. I asked for candies like Hello panda, pocky and Hi-chew. They said that everything was kind of expensive. If your going to go here take at least $25

45.description: Like my pastries, being Chinese, I need my asian snacks and candy just as much as I need my non asian kinds.  Yes, I am a lover not a hater!Aside from all kinds of Japanese and Chinese soft and hard candies, I also LOVE dried and preserved fruits.  I grew up eating preserved plums...let me warn you...they can get VERY sour...but they are ooooooh sooooo delicious!  They also sell watermelon seeds (yes, just like sunflower seeds) and dried squid (which sounds gross...but is AWESOME!).For first timers...no this is not your regular candy shop...and it doesn't smell like one either.Oh, and everything is sold by either the piece or weight.  I believe there is a minimum for credit card purchases as well...

33.description: Somehow I always end up spending $15 whenever I come here. Seems like a lot to spend for some candy, but the green tea candy is delicious and I haven't found it anywhere else. Besides, it's nice to have a bargaining tool to use when I want to get my daughter to eat dinner at Lao Sze Chuan.

43.description: Weird and wacky - and I can't resist the candy that looks like real food like eggs, french fries and hamburgers. The staff is nice enough if you ask for help. I think they carry more Korean and Japanese stuff. If you have never been, Aji Ichiban is worth a tourist visit.

2.description: If you're in the mood for some asian candy, this is your stop. Munchies Paradise, or "Aji Ichiban" is chocked full of candies, dried fruits, and savory crackers and snacks. They often have the same candies, but in different flavors, which is nice. They also have little dishes with samples of everything so you can try stuff before you buy a larger amount. Personally, I think the prices here are a little high. The goods range from ~$8.50-$16.50 per pound which is pretty steep. However, if you're craving a piece or two of white rabbit or a pack of hi chews, head on over!

18.description: It was a nice little candy store with a wide variety of Asian sweets.  They even provide free samples of things such as the dried squid and stuff, so that you can see if you like it before you get it.  Very nice little store and staff was kind.

41.description: YAY! A candy store in Chinatown, AMAZING!After the Dim Sum Feeding Frenzy, we walked around the plaza to go to the park and found ourselves in the middle of a candy store! For $7.50-$11.00/lb for candy, we could help ourselves to our heart's content! Mini Reese Peanut Butter Cups, M&M's, Gummy Bears were all for the taking! Free samples, deliciousness and snacky snacks were well organized in big bins and there were cute little basket to carry around. After making my rounds, I felt like I was trick or treating with a true cornucopia of Corn Nuts, Calbee Shrimp Chips, six packs of fusen gum, 2 mini M&M bags, Skittles, golden chocolate coins, and even some Mentos! Aji Ichiban is not without its knocks, all in all I spent $20 at the candy store! Now I am eating my Corn Nuts and am taken aback by how stale they are. Looking at the date stamp it says 12/06/09. DOH :((

52.description: This is a good candy store but I feel the prices of the candy are better in other Chinatown shops that sell candy. I love the variety of the candy though. It's not somewhere I would go frequently but somewhere I would go to just try or when just craving for candy and don't want to go somewhere else. Maybe it's my opinion but great selection just kind of pricey compared to other stores.

50.description: i wish we still had one in hawaiithis one was alright.  they didn't have a huge variety of candies like they do in hong kong but it was all g.  i found my favorite candy of all time so i'm happy.  be careful not to go too crazy because it will add up.  it was a nostalgic moment to be back to this store.

4.description: This is a really cute asian candy store in Chinatown. My mom loves coming here to get some dried snacks that we cannot typically find outside major metropolitan Chinatowns. I'll refrain from using the english translations of candies she and I like since it would probably disturb any reader. They have a lot of dried fruit, dried asian candies, dried seafood snacks, nuts, chinese gummies, and then there is also things that are more common like Pocky, green tea flavored chocolates, hamburger gummies, lollipops, and much more. A majority of things are kept in bins that you can fill up a little bag with to keep items fresh, but a lot of the candies in bins are non-perishable anyways (not that you would be getting a lot of these items anyways that would last you longer than a week or two to eat).There are also lots of mini snack samplers so if you are not familiar/ want to try an odd sample there are plenty to go around- you can even ask the people working there to make a sample for you! Personally, I would not buy any common candy (like Pocky or green tea kitkats) there since the items there are not the cheapest, and you can easily find those items at any asian supermarket. If you don't care about the prices and not frequently going to asian supermarkets, I say go ahead and try anything that might interest you!

6.description: I used to go to the aji ichiban in Chinatown, ny and 10yr old me went bonkers. Now I'm an adult with money so I went bezerk. All my favorites were there: fizzy soda candy, Japanese jellys, salted fruits!!!! The samples look a bit stale, but they're freeeee. The only gripe is the price. Be choosey about what you buy, some of them may not be worth it since they could probably be found in Asian supermarkets.

22.description: All the little candies!Rows  and bins of colorful sweets. Pay by the pound; some pay per piece.Jellies, Rice Candy, Gum and more. Melon, Strawberry, Muscat, Lychee and others.Some pricey, some cheap. Fill up your basket. Savor the flavors. Wasabi Kit Kat? Gotta have it. Another stop on our Chinatown jaunts.

15.description: All my fave Asian candies growing up! I like that you can buy everything by the pound, so if you don't want a whole bag of candies, you can mix and match and just get a few. The only bummer was it felt a little pricy and it was a $10 card minimum. Also, it was a little confusing how you're supposed to go about buying the candies (use separate bags for each...?). I ended up putting all the different candies in one bag and they separated them out by price for me later. I felt kind of bad, like I had messed up and annoyed them, but I didn't want to use a different bag for like 4 candies each. Anyway, overall a cute place and I will definitely be back!

57.description: Yes, there is candy. Yes, there are fruity snacks. But the true prize here is the vast variety of candied dried fish....mmmmm....dried fish. Try the glazed sesame dried fish...you'll buy a whole sackful and be munching for days.

20.description: They have White Rabbit candy! I thought I would never see them again. I have not had them since I was 9. So you can imagine how excited I was when I saw them here. They have Kopiko (coffee candy) which is nice to have around. I grew up with dried squid, candied fish and dried plums. So all these were familiar, although there were others that I did not recognized and their samples were helpful. They do need to do a better job at labeling their goods because some were labelled to describe what they were and many others were not. They are a bit pricey but I didn't mind because my mouth went back to memory lane. Oh so yummy. One tip.. get those dried plum to help you digest all the food you ate from one of many Chinese restaurants in the shopping strip. They work.

36.description: My son loves coming to this store to check out their candy.  It is a bit pricey, but they offer many varieties that you can't find elsewhere.  I was a little shocked when he only chose one piece.As for me.  I grew up on dried cuttlefish, dried plums, dried kumquats, lemon peel and fresh fruit jerky.  I am the one that gets us into trouble here.  I am happily chewing on cuttle fish as I write this.

14.description: This store did have a good variety of Asian candies but I didn't like the one I picked. I got the egg candy that was soaked in soy sauce. I thought it was something different, but oh was it different. When you opened up the small package, it smelled formaldehyde. I ate a tiny bit of the egg in my mouth, it tasted like salty plastic. I couldn't finish the rest. I think the place was a bit overpriced too. I've been to Asian markets that sell some of their candies for a cheaper price.

3.description: Came here once looking for a plum wine. The lady was nice and we walked around a bit and everything is nicely shelved and clean.Prices are fair....even though I found my plum wine a few dollars cheaper at Super H, but this location is more convenient.

1.description: This place did indeed rock my world. It was sooo sleek, clean and modern! As a tall, waifish Mary Poppins lookin' white b*tch standing out like a sore thumb in Chinatown, I didn't come expecting exceptional customer service. Touché. But I finally found another place in the city with a profound sake selection. Joong Boo was my boo before but has been replaced. Sorry Boo, you know I still love you!As for Chinese liquor, I'm at a loss but definitely intrigued. And now I know where to go!

2.description: This is the classiest, cleanest, best stocked Chinese liquor store in the city.  It's set up like a duty-free liquor store in a major airport international terminal, only with the taxes and a little less aisle space.  If you're already going to eat in Chinatown, stop by here if you're going to a BYOB place (and so many of the restaurants are BYOB).  This is also a good place to come if you're looking for a nice present for people who like Chinese liquor, people from China, or drinkers who like to try something different.  A few other reviewers have incorrectly described the place as having a wide selection of "Asian liquor" but I didn't find that to be the case, they have an excellent selection of Chinese alcohol, a smaller but good selection of other Far East Asian drinks like Japanese sake, plum wine, and Korean soju, and a limited but generally higher class selection of whiskey and other liquors from other places. I don't think it's worth going out of your way for liquors other than the Chinese selection, as parking is always challenging in Chinatown.  It is worth a visit if you're celebrating anything with Chinese people and/or Chinese food, because drinks are very basic requirements for Chinese celebrations, and billions of people have found that Chinese liquor goes well with Chinese food. For dinner, there's lots of affordable baiju choices, I've found through a little experimentation that none of the very cheapest choices are palatable, so as a rule of thumb, start one or two rungs above the basement priced brands. Sometimes baiju and huangiu, the two most common of the Chinese liquors, are translated as "rice wine," which I find misleading as they really don't taste like grape wine, they're stronger than most wines, though they are made from rice (usually).  I think there are regional differences in the grain, Southern Chinese baiju are made from rice, but Northern Chinese baiju may be made from sorghum, barley, or wheat.  The Chinese were the first civilization to develop modern agricultural techniques for all these grains.  I don't believe the grain makes the bigger difference in the taste variation for baiju, I think it's like vodka, the choice of water makes the difference, but I could be wrong on that, it may be caused by the different choices of yeast starters and I don't want to know about that.      I do know that baiju varies quite a bit in taste, and the fragrance patterns are:1)  Sauce bouquet (jiàng xing) - Has a strong ammonia smell and is commonly served with appetizers and pickled food.  Maotai () is typical of this category.2)  Heavy bouquet (nóng xing) - Sweet and mellow.  I think this is the kind that the chefs use, just a couple of drops, on fish or fish and vegetable dishes, just at the end of cooking, the improve the fishy smell.  Or, it could be that this is the choice of alcoholic cooks who cover up their drinking on the job, as a couple of Chinese cooks have told me that baiju is never used in cooking.3)  Light bouquet (qng xing) - A bit drier with less aroma.4)  Rice bouquet (m xing) - A subtle rice aroma.5)  Honey bouquet (fng xing) - Lightly sweet and aromatic.  I know this is the kind I don't like.6)  Layered fragrance - A combination of "sauce," "heavy," and "light" fragrances.The translation is crude, it's an example of the Sapir-Whorf thesis, some things just don't translate, but once you try the 6 different taste types, you'll know these differences and maybe you can correct or improve the English adjectives.  At any rate, this is the only liquor store in the metropolitan area that allows this wide a selection.  On the higher end are some absolutely beautiful bottles, so artistic and unusual, they would make memorable gifts, even if the recipients don't usually drink baiju, you can tell them it may be healthy for them (dubious Chinese medical research suggests that drinking yaojiu improved the blood circulation of elderly rats).  I find baiju to be very deceptive in terms of how quickly one can become impaired. Especially when you're eating dinner in Chinatown, I would recommend designating a driver who doesn't get any, or using public transportation.Gam Bei!  (I think that's Han for Kanpai)

9.description: A friend and I were walking around Chinatown Square after dinner a few nights ago and came across this place.
