I had never seen it before, so we decided to walk in (sure enough, after asking, we found out they had only been opened for about a month).The first thing that struck me as I entered the store is how elegant and clean it is for a liquor store in that area. Very, very nice. After a few minutes of just walking around, looking and chatting, the floor salesman came over to talk to us. Before walking into the shop, I hadn't planned on buying anything, but after he talked with us a bit we ended up buying a cheap bottle of sake. I can't stress enough how polite the salesman was and there was no pressure to buy. He was wearing a suit jacket and a tie with the knot down low. He gave off a professional yet very casual vibe. One of the few salesman I walked away from thinking "I wouldn't mind talking to him a bit more..."I'm sure I'll be back again sometime. They had a lot of interesting liquor in there that I didn't get a chance to check out yet.

10.description: We were going to Spring World for dinner and it's BYO. Spring World and China Place Liquor City are right next to each other, so couldn't be more convenient. Great selection of sake. We got a 12 pack of Tsing Tao and a 3-pack of sakes.

4.description: Their Asian liquor selection will rock your world. All the representative sorts of Chinese liquor are here. They carry some interesting Japanese and Korean brands as well. A good starting point is something relatively mild, such as sake or plum wine. Stronger kinds like Chinese spirits are acquired tastes and certainly not for everybody.There are a bunch of BYOB restaurants in Chinatown, so it would be a good idea to check out this place before your meal.

6.description: This is a great liquor store in the Chinatown Mall. Love the selection and the unique flavors of sake they have including Coconut Lemongrass, Asian Pear and Lychee. Beautiful interior and prices are very reasonable. I'm taking a star away because I don't like how the staff follow you and watch your every move.

12.description: Went to Chinatown for dinner one night and stumbled into this place walking around afterward. It was a pretty inviting place. Classy and clean.Spent a few minutes looking at the sake, and one of the salesmen the store walked up to us to see if we needed anything. We asked for some advice and he gave us some pretty good advice. He was a nice guy and had a lot of interesting things to say.I will definitely be going back here. They've got some stuff I've never tried before and it was all at a pretty reasonable price.

5.description: I like the store's variety of alcohol and would have spent more time shopping, however the lady standing in my peripheral watching me made me feel like I needed to make my NYE purchases and go. She didn't speak to me, she didn't return my smile, she just stared. When I picked up something to read the box and re tuned it to its space, she walked up to straighten it an returned to her area of staring! I say all of this to request that you address your customer service skills, as such great reviews suggest that you treat people much better than that.

13.description: Decent selection of wines and a nice array of sake and soju, but beware- no one here speaks a word of English.

11.description: After reading the article on China Place Liquor City in the Reader a few weeks ago (chicagoreader.com/chicag…) I decided I had to check this place out.I hang out with a lot of, let's say, functioning alcoholics. Ones that love nothing more than trying new sauce. With Christmas coming up, it seems that the stars aligned.I walked into Liquor City and was immediately greeted by Mr. Jia. He smiled, eagerly waiting to be asked a question. I knew right off the bat that I needed some lychee wine for myself, and when I nabbed it he chuckled, noting that a lot of American customers like it. When I mentioned I'd read the article he grinned modestly, and then helped me select a baijiu for a friend. He talked a little about a few, nothing overpowering or super salesy. I let him know what I was looking to spend, and there was zero pressure.The prices we more than reasonable (seriously, ten bucks for the bottle of lychee wine, which made last night a marvelous one) and I can't wait to go back and try more. Though they don't have a mailing list, he did mention they were looking at hosting some in-store events on Chinese drinking and business customs, as well as tastings. When I expressed interest, he promptly gave me a business card and his email address.Seriously, amazing service and great product. What more could you ask for in a store. I hope this place is around for a long time.

8.description: This will be a short review because it was a real quick stop.I'm a little conflicted about 3 or 4 stars but I'm going to err on the side of praise.  Not everyone here speaks English so if you call the store and ask any question like "What time do you close?" then be ready for them to 'smile' over the phone and then hang up on you because they don't know what you're saying.The selection here is pretty good though.  I walked in, they saw I wasn't Asian, recommended a '98 Merlot.  I then specifically asked for Lychee wine from reading another review which ended up tasting very good.The prices seem a bit much but not over the top.  Service is polite and courteous, establishment is clean and organized.  I'd come back again but it would definitely be advisable to have enough time to look around or know what you want ahead of time.

0.description: Wonderful variety the people are do warm snd helpful!! Excellent place! They new the wines, they were  able to come up with about 5 bottles for us and we loved them all! Thank you so much.

7.description: Some things I've learned from my first visit to this very clean, very pretty, decently stocked store...1. If you want any other kind of Chinese beer than Tsingtao and you don't live in L.A., you're FUCKED! The closest distributor is in Canada. This sucks, as I had been hoping to find Lanjian (Blue Sword, some good good beer from Chengdu, Sichuan Province) here (Tsingtao is not very good beer at all, but it's pretty good with Sichuanese food all the same; I wish they sold some of the great Taiwan beer I've heard about and the killer beer I had in Japan--maybe someday).2. There are more types of baijiu and soju here than I'd ever thought existed.3. Most of them are out of my price range (or at least were today.4. Many beautiful, giggly Chinese-American girls pop in here looking for sake and other good stuff, so the eye-candy points are pretty huge.5. Shao-hsing wine from Taiwan is pretty tasty and affordable.6. They don't carry (or at least don't yet carry) the sake from my fiance's home prefecture (this is a negative, not a positive--the stuff's the best I've ever had).7. I really, really hope they carry it soon.I'll be back.

58.description: Wonton to live and die for.  At 1am on Sunday the wonton here are wonderful and soothing.

56.description: Best place for wonton noodle soup.  This place has everything that Wonton Gourmet has at a lower price.  They are fast, the noodles are perfect and broth has flavor! I get mine with duck and a side of beef stew.  I don't mind the dated look and sticky tables.  They look clean, how can they still be sticky?

29.description: Good if you want quick cheap Chinese food.  I've been coming here dive I was a teenager, for the same shrimp won ton soup. They make their own noodles however.

42.description: Cheap, but nothing special. Can get a better chinese meal in my lame town in Michigan. Had the chinese vegetables in oyster sauce and my son had the sweet and sour chicken. Veggies were drowning in the sauce and the chicken pieces were so big we had to cut them to get them in his mouth. Not terrible but kind of expected something more authentic.

23.description: Seven treasures is great. It's opened til late at night. Me and my friends usually go out during the night so we look for restaurants that are opened late at night. This place is opened until about 2am. When I come here, I usually get the 554. I don't know what it's called how it's written in the menu. It was 554 before the they changed the menu, but if you tell them 554, they will know exactly what you want. It's basically pork with rice and soysauce and fried eggs on the top. It sounds really simple but its good. I'm not that big of pot stickers in general, but their potstickers are okay. I like the crab rangoon there. They have other good food on the menu like noodles in soup or other kinds of fried rice. I heard not to get the taro bubble tea there because they use real taro. The taro that most people drink and enjoy drinking is the powdered kind. But if you like real taro, I guess give it ago. But my all time favorite bubble tea is the milk tea with tappiocca.

47.description: Ahh yes. The 504. Which consists of Chinese fried rice with bbq pork and a fried egg. Chinese fast food.Open til 1am this place is a good late night stop. No frills...just good food at cheap prices.  I love the avocado milkshakes.

8.description: My first experience was fairly good. They are well known for their BBQ pork, and I can see why so many people have such rave reviews about it. However, my second experience was immensely frustrating. We were there on a weekday so it was not very crowded. I asked for a whole duck, which is $17.00 w/o tax. The lady who cut up the duck for me proceeded to go through all of her ducks in the window, and find the smallest one to give to me. What a joke! I could literally see her taking down the ducks and measuring out their sizes. The duck she gave me had next to no meat. Normally a duck fills the entire styrofoam container standardly used at most Chinese BBQ places. Not the case here! At most 3/4 of the container was full. To make matters worst, the skin on the duck was not crispy and parts of it did not taste as fresh as it should.I am so disgusted with this place. Maybe if you speak Chinese or are older they will not pull this stunt on you. As for me, my verdict is that I am NEVER COMING BACK HERE AGAIN.

31.description: 554. That is the reason I come and I leave happy. Usually I get pretty decent service, but tonight was different. There was this younger gentleman working who was to say the very least very curt and rude. Totally unexpected. I even politely told the server that my order was missing my usual extra egg. Not only does he not apologize he goes and accuses me of lying. Seriously, one shouldn't be in the restaurant  business with such poor customer service skills. The guy never even came back to offer water or see how we were doing! In summary the guy was a dick

34.description: This was a pretty good place. Service was nice and it was also a BBQ joint. The food was decently priced and I liked how quickly it came out. Food was a little on the over greasy and waiters did seem to mill about without tasks. Overall good but nothing's spectacular

16.description: I picked my oldest son up from work and as a treat he offered a quick dinner meal. If you are looking for classy, or a neat-find, or just a nice place to be treated nicely - this is not "it". I'm sure in it's day this may have been a happenin' place, but not today. It had the feel of being dank and dark. The place was empty less a college group of about 5-7 young people. For whatever reason we sat right next to them. They left shortly after our arrival so it wasn't so bad for too long, (they were a bit loud). The food seemed like basic Chinese food prepared by someone's mom - but without the love. This was probably due to the service - I felt as if we were interrupting something, (it wasn't closing time). The tables were somewhat cleaned, the glasses had that frosted look about them from being washed too many times by a machine. It was chilly, so I kept my coat on. I just wanted to feel at home and didn't : -/ Perhaps this is place for the neighborhood crowd - they may order on the way home from work, run in  and run out and eat at home. They don't get colored by the atmosphere or lack thereof and lack of smiling faces.

13.description: I used to come here waaaay back in the day (2007 and prior with car forum friends).  I ordered Spiced Salt + Pepper Prawns, Duck with Mixed Veggies, Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce, and Milk Tea with boba.The nice guy who took my order asked if I wanted the prawns de-headed and de-shelled; I told him I was fine with them as-is (I'm white, but not THAT white [to the dismay of my family who is a bit horrified at some of the things I'll eat]).  Like another reviewer said, once they're fried and crispy, you can eat the whole thing - head, shell, tail.. no biggie.  The portion size was generous, they were deliciously hot and seasoned well, and I ate about half of the to-go container on the way home!  The Duck and Veggies were just OK.  I do love duck and miss it, but the good duck meat to unsavory pieces (liver? some type of innards..) ratio was really off.  The veggies were good  (love the big mushrooms!) but obviously sitting in sauce a while so they were quite mushy.  The Chinese Broccoli was just OK - a bit watery, so the sauce was diluted, and there were fewer leafy pieces than stems.  The portion size was good.  So, um, YAY for fiber!In all, it was an OK option, but the prawns were definitely the star!  I'll be back for them.

11.description: I've only heard of the 554 dish more recently, but now I realize how popular it is!  It's even on urbandictionary!After a late night and craving Chinese food, I tried out the 554.  It was amazing.  So amazing that I got another order because I thought it would make the most amazing breakfast.  I have to admit, it's so much better after a night of drinking than the morning after, but still...it's pretty legit.  If you're a self-proclaimed foodie in Chicago, you should definitely give it a try!

39.description: I've only eaten in here once, and it was fine.  But when I'm in Chicago I always go for carry out.  I go to the counter and get roast duck, pork, and cuttlefish to go.  Very good, very cheap.  I make a huge mess in my car because I can't wait until I get home to eat it.

37.description: If you're looking for a place to eat and not looking to spend a lot of money, this is definitely the spot to go. You can get full off of a simple rice plate which is approximately five dollars or wonton noodles which is also roughly five dollars. What I'm trying to say is that it's super affordable. It has a lot of variety here too! The food comes out extremely quick as well. My all-time favorites are the fish filet w Chinese broccoli, wonton noodles with beef stew, and the infamous 5-5-4 (BBQ pork w egg over rice).The thing that I dislike about this location is the not-so up-to-date interior. It looks unsanitary and that is sometimes reflected in the utensils' uncleanliness. Make sure to check that your plates and utensils are free of stains. Overall, I would recommend this place because it's good food with good prices!

0.description: Great place to come with a big group of people since they have lots of tables.  The service is quick and the food is delicious.  They give you hot tea when you are seated.  There are tons of options on the menu which makes it hard to choose sometimes.  The chow fun and salt and pepper pork or squid are some of my favorites.  The noodle soups are also good.The street parking is not free until 9P and they do ticket heavily!

38.description: This place definitely gets you full for just $5. All time favorite for myself and popular amongst my friends is the 554, or BBQ pork with fried egg over rice. I've also had the noodle soup with BBQ pork and braised noodles with BBQ pork. The smoothies are delicious as well. The service is great. I swear they're always at your table whenever you need help. The food also comes out very fast. Basically fast food.

51.description: I was craving Chinese food and Seven Treasures hit the spot. The won ton noodle soup tasted fresh and was hearty on a mildly chilly day. At a little under $5, this was definitely a good deal and especially because it was tasty and comforting.The roast duck was also good though very pricey (around $5) for a small portion of meat.No credit cards accepted for transactions less than $10.

27.description: We decided to go to this restaurant for take out due to fellow yelpers reviews. We ordered the 554 that everyone raved about and took it home. Now don't hate me people but it wasn't spectacular how everyone says. Don't get me wrong, it was good but I guess based on its reviews I thought this we going to be glorious, but it was just good. What really stood out in our visit was the customer service. A+! The woman at the register was friendly and very helpful. The staff was accommodating (we had our toddler who is somewhat of a handful) and everyone had a smile on their face. Based in that experience we came back to dine in. My hubby had the orange chicken which was delicious, my daughter had the combination fried rice. I'll be quite honest it was a little too greasy and salty for my taste but she seemed to enjoy it. I had the beef with white rice and shared that with my little guy. He loved it! He is a picky eater and he ate like he had never been fed before. The dine in experience was just as good as our take out. At some point my water was empty and I didn't see a waiter but as I reached  over to steal my kid's water the waiter swooped in and refilled all of our glasses.I have every intention of coming back sans children hopefully with another couple and try their dinner for 4. Did I mention they're open late?

32.description: This place is where you wanna go for some super late night eats that you will probably regret the next day but is so worth it while you're eating it. Even better if you're probably intoxicated and anticipate a lovely hang over the next morning.I didn't know that Chicago-ans like to get their Chinese food fix for late night booze food. In California, it's either Mexican food or pho. But this place hit the spot with some shrimp fried rice, wonton noodle soup, and a plate of garlic chinese broccoli. Can't believe how cheap the dishes are! Can't wait for my next late night shenanigans in the city so that we can indulge in some of the affordable late night eats.

54.description: I've only had takeout from here but it was so good I'm inclined to go back and eat in again very soon. Courtesy of the mom who brought home Fresh Shrimp Won Ton soup. It was the best I've ever tasted. Found out through the grapevine that the owner of this family restaurant also have a another place, Wonton Gourmet, that's manage by one of their children. I've had Won Ton takeout from that place too and its quality is just as good. Honestly, I was indifferent toward Won Ton Soup until these places set the benchmark in quality and taste. Now I'm a fan! Mm... So good!!

48.description: Noodle with Beijing styleh

44.description: Every time I eat at this place, I get thirsty afterwards. I think it's from the MSG, that's added to the food

24.description: OK--Sorry guys for the description--but you are my FAVORITE Chinatown dive.   7 treasures has the BEST won-ton noodle soup (for those not familiar--the soup that is a meal, and the small portion you get with fried rice).  The shrimp Wontons are great--NO BETTER in our Chinatown and I seldom encounter equals in other US or international Chinatowns (I've never been to Hong Kong or the mainland).  Go here for Noodles & Soup and some nice barbecue on the side (Pork, Soy sauce chicken, duck).  A great 7 treasures meal:Won Ton Soup--extra noodle1/2 soy sauce chicken1 lb Char siu (BBQ Pork)1/4 duck or duck over rice plateSnow pea pods & Chinese broccoli stir fried in Garlic Sauce2 Bottles of wine (no corking fee)Great , fun, hearty food!My favorite Chinatown Dive--No one can beat it for its specialties!!

7.description: This place is where you wanna go for some super late night eats that you will probably regret the next day but is so worth it while you're eating it. Even better if you're probably intoxicated and anticipate a lovely hang over the next morning.I didn't know that Chicago-ans like to get their Chinese food fix for late night booze food. In California, it's either Mexican food or pho. But this place hit the spot with some shrimp fried rice, wonton noodle soup, and a plate of garlic chinese broccoli. Can't believe how cheap the dishes are! Can't wait for my next late night shenanigans in the city so that we can indulge in some of the affordable late night eats.

49.description: Cheap, but the food sucks. Other than the wonton noodles, everything else was below average. Got sick from eating a chicken dish there, so did my girlfriend.

40.description: I used to come here waaaay back in the day (2007 and prior with car forum friends).  I ordered Spiced Salt + Pepper Prawns, Duck with Mixed Veggies, Chinese Broccoli with Oyster Sauce, and Milk Tea with boba.The nice guy who took my order asked if I wanted the prawns de-headed and de-shelled; I told him I was fine with them as-is (I'm white, but not THAT white [to the dismay of my family who is a bit horrified at some of the things I'll eat]).  Like another reviewer said, once they're fried and crispy, you can eat the whole thing - head, shell, tail.. no biggie.  The portion size was generous, they were deliciously hot and seasoned well, and I ate about half of the to-go container on the way home!  The Duck and Veggies were just OK.  I do love duck and miss it, but the good duck meat to unsavory pieces (liver? some type of innards..) ratio was really off.  The veggies were good  (love the big mushrooms!) but obviously sitting in sauce a while so they were quite mushy.  The Chinese Broccoli was just OK - a bit watery, so the sauce was diluted, and there were fewer leafy pieces than stems.  The portion size was good.  So, um, YAY for fiber!In all, it was an OK option, but the prawns were definitely the star!  I'll be back for them.

53.description: It's all about the food here.  The less they spend on decor, the better the food is gonna be, right? I've never been disappointed here.

30.description: We went on a late night. We ordered the food with no msg. Not sure if that threw the taste off or not. We had noodle soup, shrimp egg foo young, chicken fried rice. The service by June was great. Thank you.

46.description: I HATE TO SAY IT, BECAUSE I USE TO LIKE THIS PLACE, BUT IT IS PATHETIC NOW. Yes they have cheap prices, but you get what you pay for. They have been in business for YEARS, and yet all the money people have poured into this place to make the owners filthy rich, they have not put any of it back into the restaurant for the customers.The place is filthy filthy dirty filthy. They should spend a few dollars to at least get the bathroom sanitized. The kitchen I can assure you looks the same as the bathrooms. And people eat the food coming out of there. I became so ill from the food that I must warn everyone else coming there. BEWARE. Health department is on its way.But what really irks me is that the millions they've sold they can't even give away a few extra hot sauces or vinegar for their won ton soups without giving you the evil eye as if you're robbing them. I have been coming here when they were still small and located on Cermak Road, before they moved out for Good World Noodles. Too bad Good World lost their lease because they were actually better.Oh well, I guess until another late night place comes along that is cheap, people will still gamble with stomach flu and food poisoning at this restaurant. REPEAT, BEWARE.Oh, if you do gamble, ask that the waiters not put their thumbs in your noodle soup bowls while carrying them out to you. I'd bet those thumbs been places you don't want to taste.

1.description: ***Restaurant is closed for unsanitary conditions***Good inexpensive food. The food is prepared quickly but service is terrible. The decor is very old and dirty. Poor management! I tried going there for lunch today but it was closed.

55.description: The only reason you would want to come to this place is for the nostalgia of when you were a teenager and this was the one place open after a night of clubbing or illegal racing or hanging out with friends doing absolutely nothing.  Otherwise, stay away.  This is a perfect example of a restaurant that never evolved with modern times.  It's old and filthy.  Mold and mildew decorates the ceiling while the floor has a tough layer of dirt to prevent more dirt.  Cups are cloudy.  Tablewares way past their life expectancy.  It's one of the restaurants where you dont want to rest your elbows on the table, not because your mom told you so but because you dont want to dirty your clothes.The food is cheap, full of MSG, and about as clean as the floor I mentioned earlier.  The good news is that if you are constipated, the food will give you a good reason to find a bathroom later.  If you grew up eating here, your immune system has developed the necessary defense to continue eating here.  If this is your first visit, don't even drink the water provided.  If you MUST eat here, pick from their selection of BBQ items.  At least those are remotely fresh.  DO NOT get their beef items.  Like many old chinatown crap restaurants, they use tons of baking soda to "soften" the beef.  If you like ingesting insane amount of baking soda, then go for it.I really wish the owner will completely rehab this place, fire entire staff, and give us a restaurant the current generation can remember down the line.  Sadly, they are probably flushing their money down the Horseshoe drain.

9.description: Whole BBQ duck for $17! I love the cuttlefish and preserved vegetables.  Perfectly sour. The Papaya smoothie with tapioca pearls is a wonderful transition from such a heavy meal, and if it weren't for the complimentary green tea I'd be out before my meal was halfway done due to the overwhelmingly tired feeling I get from this great stuff. Sitting in my car now without the will to drive home. I need to pass out for about thirty minutes just to muster enough strength to drive back to the north Chicago burbs. That's right, I drove thirty miles just for this meal.

26.description: This Chinese restuarant should have 4. Stars.Had what they call "554" very popular among Chicagoans (Rice with fried eggs and sausages).Menu has really affordable food no wonder this spot is very popular  among college students in the city.iLike it.

25.description: This is the best place for congee,chowfun with beef & chinese brockerry,also the best dumplings with oyster sauce.

12.description: Everytime we come here they are consistent. Excellent food, good service...testament to their restaurant is most customers are from there ethnic background. Enjoyed my food

59.description: Used to come here all the time growing p and now whenever I visit I have to stop in. I agree with all the users who talk about the Wonton Soup, and I really like the flavor of their BBQ pork fried rice. Bubble teas are excellent, and being open so late is a plus. It is true that the bathrooms are a little sketch, but I also think it is unfair to compare them to the kitchen. In all the years of eating here, I have never gotten sick. I also love the sweet sauce you get to go with the rangoons. YUM!

21.description: Order the 554 - BBQ pork with egg over rice. I also like the wonton with noodles. I always go here for quick and cheap chinese food.If you are a college student this is the place to go.PS THEY HAVE THE BEST HOT SAUCE IN CHINATOWN

17.description: Order the 554 - BBQ pork with egg over rice. I also like the wonton with noodles. I always go here for quick and cheap chinese food.If you are a college student this is the place to go.PS THEY HAVE THE BEST HOT SAUCE IN CHINATOWN

10.description: I've been coming here for over 25 years..  Same good food at a reasonable price!!   They changed the décor once in 25 years so obviously the investment must be in the food cuz it ain't in the décor!!

5.description: I so love this place their beef stew wonton noodles are the best. I drive 45 mins just to satisfy my cravings.

3.description: Food was delicious! I ordered the Braised Noodles with Roasted Duck and my boyfriend got the Congee. The fruit drinks with milk are also great. We were not sure what to expect and were not disappointed with this restaurant. Would definitely recommend as a place to try when in Chicago Chinatown

35.description: Weakest Chinese spot ..... Soup had no flavor, "general chicken" was basically sweet n sour chicken that is sub-par to Panda Express..... BBQ pork had a weird after taste, and a good cleaning crew is needed to mop the floors. Super bummed I wasted a meal while in Chicago at this spot.

19.description: I wish I could give 0 stars. I had food poisoning from the food here and I know it's from them because that was the only thing I ate. my mom was very worried and called them to speak to the manager and they didn't even say sorry, and said its not their fault. The ladies in the back don't even wear gloves.. very unhygienic!

28.description: Seven Treasures never fails me when its super late and I'm hungry. My usual order of won ton mein is always ready within the next 5-10 minutes after I call. Quick, efficient, and convenient.

45.description: Tonight's experience in Chinatown was unique, and I feel like I just had so much off one menu that I had to write this review. I don't usually wander out of Chinatown Square unless I'm with my mom - which is probably the worst thing ever, but that's because I only go to places that are recommended to me - so I was hesitant to stop into Seven Treasures. My mother's friend, who was with us for the visit, talked up this place and shared so many great details about this place that when we walked into this dingy little hole in the wall, I didn't immediately turn back around and out the door.Seven Treasures has certainly seen better days; the moderately sized restaurant is composed of one large grey dining room and brought me back to my school cafeteria days. The table we were seated at was very wobbly, and even the gentle movement of an elbow could be felt from across the wide table. The rest of the furniture in the restaurant seemed equally outdated and worn. My mother's friend told us stories of the days Seven Treasures would keep tanks full of fish and lobsters for customers to pick. Those days sounded nice, and I wish I could have seen the restaurant in its hey-day. My mother's friend, clearly a veteran customer of 7T, ordered a large portion of the menu for our group, which definitely made this visit to Chinatown worth the travel through the snowy weather. The egg rolls were crunchy and fat, and just spilling with goodness. I don't think I've ever had egg drop soup that fulfilling (yes, it was fulfilling). It was warm and seasoned so well. Sometimes, egg drop soup lacks any memorable flavor, but this soup was everything you could ever want and more. Among other things, the beef and Chinese broccoli was phenomenal. The beef was tender and savory, and the broccoli retained it's crunch and signature flavor unique to this variation of the vegetable.  The shrimp in the shrimp chow mein were so plump and juicy. Tip: The Cantonese fried shrimp are cooked in such a way that you can eat the whole thing, shell and all. The fried outer shell of the crab creates a crunch to the already almost soft shell crab-like texture of the shrimp meat. Tip: the food, as expected from a little hole in the wall, was fairly greasy. If you're feeling like you've hit your fat wall, but just can't stop, get a Coke. That carbonation will help move the grease trapped inside you and gear you up for the rest of your meal. Tl;dr - Dingy restaurant, great food. Spend more time in Old Chinatown and find these gems that don't get as much attention as the more modern places in Chinatown Square.

33.description: This place gets a one star bump up because it is open very late, for that post bar plate of braised noodles with duck and won ton dumplings (the best in Chicago I think). I have eaten many meals here, and about half of them were under $10 (plate of noodles and a meat will set you back 6 to 8 bucks with a tip and tea.I have also had full dinners. That gets the three. They are good but not great, and some were a little disappointing, especial when I took a friend there for seafood and they were not impressed. However the food here is better than any of the neighborhood Chinese take out places I know In Chi outside of Chinatown.

43.description: I picked my oldest son up from work and as a treat he offered a quick dinner meal. If you are looking for classy, or a neat-find, or just a nice place to be treated nicely - this is not "it". I'm sure in it's day this may have been a happenin' place, but not today. It had the feel of being dank and dark. The place was empty less a college group of about 5-7 young people. For whatever reason we sat right next to them. They left shortly after our arrival so it wasn't so bad for too long, (they were a bit loud). The food seemed like basic Chinese food prepared by someone's mom - but without the love. This was probably due to the service - I felt as if we were interrupting something, (it wasn't closing time). The tables were somewhat cleaned, the glasses had that frosted look about them from being washed too many times by a machine. It was chilly, so I kept my coat on. I just wanted to feel at home and didn't : -/ Perhaps this is place for the neighborhood crowd - they may order on the way home from work, run in  and run out and eat at home. They don't get colored by the atmosphere or lack thereof and lack of smiling faces.

2.description: These people charge based on table. We only had 4 people in our party and was seated at a table for 6. This caused them to charge gratuity. The food was neither good nor bad. Would not recommend it to anyone.

18.description: If there's one thing about Seven Treasures worthy of praise, it's the noodles in soup which get 5/5.  This staple is what has kept this restaurant alive, in my opinion, because it has fallen out of favor over the years.  Part of the reason is that the young trendy/yuppie/foodie types flock to Chinatown Square nowadays, and generally there are a lot of options on Wentworth.Every time I go, I get noodles in soup with wonton and duck/bbq pork/beef tripe.  Whichever meat I choose to supplement the wonton and noodles depends on my mood.  To this day, I still go back to the noodles in soup because NO OTHER PLACE DOES IT LIKE THEM, PERIOD.  The noodles are made in-house and have a bit of springiness to them while maintaining a sort of substantial/hearty texture in a way noodles from other places do not.  Usually springy noodles are weak and unsubstantial.  Here's an illustration:  I eat the noodles so fast I get heartburn almost every time.  This is not a bad thing.  The noodles are very "substantial" as I said before and I just can't help myself because they're so delicious.I absolutely love noodles in soup.  One of my favorite things to eat.  In particular, I prefer Cantonese noodles in soup.  Japanese stuff and Vietnamese pho just don't cut it.  The Japanese and Vietnamese stuff is a bit wimpy and not hearty enough, in my opinion.  I've had Cantonese-style noodles in soup in restaurants in LA, SF, NYC, Toronto, Hong Kong, and no place I've ever been to has noodles like Seven Treasures.  So credit should be given where credit is due.That being said, the service is abysmal and most everything else they serve is only decent, nothing special.  But sometimes a restaurant needs only one or two things to stay alive and it's obvious Seven Treasures has its noodles in soup.

41.description: Really no more than an average Chinese restaurant in an area with a lot of competition.  I got their pork belly and it wasn't very good.  There's about a dozen more interesting alternatives within walking distance.  It is a little bit dirty on the inside, too.

52.description: How is it possible for anyone who has eaten here to give this place more than 1 star? Came here for the shrimp wonton and the BBQ pork fried egg over rice that everyone seems to recommend. Both were incredibly subpar. Don't waste your time or your money. The shrimp wonton soup at Hing Kee is much better, and you can find better BBQ pork at most of the places in New Chinatown, including BBQ King House or even MingHin.

50.description: Came here at like 1:00AM. Food was pretty good and you get a lot for a super cheap price! I'd go back.

4.description: This place was great! My husband and I had a sudden late night craving for some authentic Chinese eats, and with the help of my fellow yelpers we stumbled upon this gem. We went with the BBQ pork fried egg over rice dish and it was stellar the fried egg was fried to perfection and the pork was tender and flavorful. We also had a couple egg rolls which were pretty standard but still tasty nonetheless, followed by the sweet and sour shrimp. The shrimp was a little heavy on the batter but still a good portion and sauce was on point. The green tea that comes complimentary with your meal was a nice surprise and great as far as green tea goes. The best part about this place has to be the prices we had an appetizer two entrees and also a Chinese fried bread stick that I almost forgot about which is surprising because it was so freaking good! In total our bill was only $22, amazing!

6.description: If you're looking for authentic Chinese, this is your place! Located in the heart of china town, you are sure to love it. It was packed with locals, which is always a good sign. Try the chicken chow mein. Their egg rolls and spring rolls are delicious. They serve gracious portions, and the prices are very reasonable. They offer a large selection of foods, so there's something for everyone. Don't miss out on this gem!I gave it 4 stars because there was a live fly in the sugar shaker. This would probably turn a lot of people off, but we ate there anyways.

22.description: Won ton noodle soup vs. RamenWon ton noodle soup wins!If I crave noodle soup, this is my #1 destination. Won ton noodles with barbecue pork, duck, and Chinese broccoli with a touch of  aged garlic spicy oil. I'm guessing the spicy condiment provided upon request must have previous essence blended in with new to give its distinctive flavor and deep color. Hands down in my book, it triumphs as the best bowl of noodles over Santouka's tonkotsu ramen with pork cheek. Santouka's pork cheek is tender but Seven Treasure's barbecue pork is satisfying and more is offered. String's ramen is in Chinatown. I ate there but had to make a pitstop at Seven Treasures for true goodness.Best to order extra noodles and extra won ton. The won ton has a shrimp filling that melds with the hot soup.  Best eaten on the spot to enjoy the "al dente" noodle texture. No soggy noodles here. Left overs are still tasty with a can of Asahi dry. Never thought to try with Chinese beer. Carry out, the noodles are separated from the broth. The broth has moderate salinity with a spice blend that can't be replicated in Chicagoland. I've searched by word of mouth and none have prevailed. A signature umami flavor. There are versions of this bowl in the suburbs but Seven Treasures is still my go to spot for decades.

15.description: Best tasting won ton noodle around. I tried the dumpling with Chinese mushrooms and shrimp, it was a good taste but the flavor was distracting to the broth and regular shrimp wonton that I was craving. Added gailan  ( Chinese broccoli) to my soup and it cooked to the large stem was very easy to eat- tender with crunch! Service was good, soup is always out quick and price was reasonable. Not the newest remodeled place but a great hole in the wall.

57.description: Some of the best soup in Chinatown.  Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce is delicious.  Fresh fruit smoothies are great.

20.description: Most i know who come down to Chinatown go to the over popularized college kid spots such joy yees and three happiness, and anyone who come to 7 treasures always gets the bbq pork and egg over rice. But the won ton noodle soup is amazing. I cannot go to Chinatown without getting soup from here. I bring my girlfriend here and where else can you go and spend like $12 and get super full and satisfied. Downside is that it is a drive, but we'll worth it for me.

36.description: Looking for late night Chinese food in a strange part of Chinatown? Come here. I think people were smoking cigarettes in here the last time I went. I used to come here and the food was OK (probably because shitfaced) at best. Now, damn the food. The food is gone. There aren't enough Old English 800 40oz's on earth to make the food taste good. Let's talk about the atmosphere.Chicken bones all over the floor. I feel like this isn't some ancient Chinese secret to guaranteeing happy customers or some foolish shit like that. Nope. People were eating chicken wings (?) and throwing the bones all over the goddamned floor. Maybe I'm missing something but this doesn't add anything to the experience. The workers here definitely talk about you behind closed doors and they definitely know what a drunk loser you are. Don't use the bathroom here unless you want to shit on someone else's shit. I would say don't come here but it's worth the gamble.P.S. almost everything thing on the menu comes out soupy. EAT UP

14.description: Food 4: consistent w dumplings n noodles, not really a fan of their brothService: 4 quick n efficient takeoutCleanliness: 3

58.description: Top 5 Chinese places in Chicago! The Moon Palace Chicken is the best! Great soups, and really good pot stickers. Typing this review, I think I may visit.....

56.description: Worse service, they put friends ahead of you in line to be seated. Yell at you. Provide poor service and rude.Before I say anything, I have been coming to your restaurant for 10 years. I love your food and was never swayed to change restaurant inspite of my friends and their opinions.We arrived around 7 pm. We were sitted for a table for four. We had 5 adults, one 2 year old and one 3 months. We told the host that we will need a bigger table. The host then said she will move us to a bigger table. We waited for 15 mins, no one came back to sit us. So , we went to the front desk again to find out what happened. They said that they gave away the other table to another party and promised us the next free table. She pointed at the table that was finishing up their meal. We said we will wait . While I was standing infront of her , she got a phone call for a reservation for 6 people at 8pm. At that point I did not realized that she had promised them the same table she promised me. We waited for our promised table for another 30 mins. By then both children have been restless and hungry. Once again i approached the front desk to inquiry about the table and this time they said its for a reservation. The host looked at my direction and proceeded to sit the incomplete party ( there were only 2 guest out of 6 that was in the restaurant) to the table she promised to my family. We waited for almost an hour with two kids for a table that the host never intended to give us. If she has told us we would have left earlier to find a different place so we could put our kids to bed on time. She was rude about it and did not offer any solution. My group was really unhappy and left.  Sad to say my long dedication to your restaurant had to come to an end after last night experience .

29.description: This is a nice restaurant in the heart of china town. The drinks and food are great. I have been here several times and they accept reservations from open table. They aren't too crowded when I have been and the servers seem attentive. They have this old candy bowel in the front where you check in that throws me off. The decor is basic and the washrooms are clean. They have a 2.00 parking lot where they will validate for.

42.description: I came here by myself for lunch on a Tuesday. The place was more empty than I expected it to be. It was also rather dark in the room. Anyway, I was seated quickly by one of the two waitresses that were present at the time. They were really nice. She didn't ask me what I wanted to drink though. She just gave me tea even though I didn't ask for it.On to the food. I ordered from their lunch specials. I chose the Mongolian beef for $6.75. It came with a soup (I chose the egg-drop soup) and a bowl of white rice. For the amount of food, I thought it was a pretty good deal. The price ended up around $7 with the tax which was relatively cheap considering how full I felt.The food wasn't bad. The egg-drop soup was your standard egg-drop soup. Nothing special but it wasn't bad. The Mongolian Beef was pretty good. I wish there was more beef though. Either way, it was yummy. Best part was how quickly it came out. I ordered and within 3 minutes my food was already on my table. It might be because there were only 8 other customers there at the time, but it was speedy nonetheless.The service was good. The food was good. The prices were even better.. and that's coming from a broke college student.

23.description: By far the best Chinese restaurant in Chinatown ,egg rolls ,edamame,spring rolls ,crab Rangoon ,shrimp wanton soup,shrimp fried rice,Mongolian beef tried them all and they are all awesome just like their food so it's their service friendly and efficient

47.description: I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE FISH & GREEN BEANS. I am not writing in caps to be obnoxious, I am writing in caps to emphasize how amazingly awesome it was. Service was quick and friendly and great atmosphere. Very impressive all around regarding quality, service, and pricing. Great place to eat with BK after some SC2. 5 Stars!!! Would recommend and will be back!

8.description: This restaurant is conveniently located near the main parking lot so its easy to get to. The restaurant does validate parking good for 3 hours. Make sure you get the validation to save some money. The dining room isn't huge with approximately 15-20 tables. The decor is modern and clean which isn't always the case with Chinatown restaurants. The servers were nice but when the restaurant is packed, they get overwhelmed and can't seem to keep up.  Overall the service was decent, not great. As for the food, appetizers were good. We had hot and sour soup, xiao long bao, and shanghai spring rolls. There are two menus.  One in English with your typical entrees and a Chinese menu. We ordered a few entrees from the English menu which included salt and pepper pork chops & fish fillet with peapod sprouts.  Both were good.  Overall ok service and ok food.

31.description: Nothing to write about. Orange chicken was ok. It was bland and not served with broccoli. I will not return.

34.description: Absolutely the best dumplings since I visited Hong Kong!  The flour consistency is delectable and we're lucky to have the food here in Chi town.  Try the pepper sauce on the chicken or pork over a bed of greens.  Heavenly!However, the servers are inconsistent.  Just be patient & your dinner's flavor will make up for the service

16.description: Only came here for soup dumplings while visiting. Not as good as others ive had, not enough broth and dumpling doesnt stay together well. A lot of pork inside which was fine, for some reason i had a slight sour taste.. Not sure if thats the way they made it. Overall i give this an OK.

13.description: I love this restaurant... In fact I'll be taking my fiance' there tonight for our 1 year anniversary... Shhhhhhh ... its a secret.. LOL

11.description: Did dinner on New Years Eve here; crowded and had to wait for our table even with a reservation.  Food was very good; I had the moo shu chicken and had enough to take home for lunch the following day.  Hubby had Gen Tso's chicken and enjoyed it; just disappointed he didn't get a bit more in his serving.  Having validated parking so close is a bonus.

39.description: I love this restaurant. Their hot and sour soup is so tasty. Their jajangmyeon noodles are the best that I have had in Chinatown. The service is fast, the prices are decent, the food is delicious. I have been here multiple times and have ordered carry out from here also. Will definitely be going back.

37.description: Moon Palace has great food.  I have noticed on several occasions that you receive a chilly response on the phone and in person if carrying out.  If you don't leave a tip when ordering and picking up, you'll probably get a scowl and attitude, which is odd considering you're not dining in.  Otherwise, again, the food is great and the dining in experience is great.

0.description: Great place with good service The firecracker chicken is an explosive burst of flavor in your mouth. Pure yum !

38.description: Hands down the best Chinese food I've had in Chicago. Their egg rolls and shrimp fried rice are perfect and the chicken with hot garlic sauce is fantastic.  I also really love the crab rangoons. Service has always been good, I will gladly go out of my way to eat here.

51.description: This place was mentioned in a Chicago magazine and was a Michelin recommended restaurant, and so the bf and his parents and I visited to see what the fuss was about. They are very friendly here, but one thing I did notice was that no matter how much Chinese I spoke they would always respond to me in English, which made me somewhat uncomfortable. Am I not speaking Chinese well enough for you to converse with me in it? Do I look funny? Anyway, the food itself was pretty good. The dumplings I have to say were probably the best part of the meal. We got potstickers and the steamed variety and the filling inside was just plain tasty. The skin was thick, which I usually do not like, but this time it gave it a good texture and chew. The potstickers were better than the steamed, but then of course they're fried, oil makes everything better.And they followed that line of reasoning to the end. We also ordered the sauteed peasprouts, the chicken nest, and the shredded pork with onion. Everything was greasy to the nines - way greasier than I'm used to. Thankfully we had some tea to cut through the fat, but it was pretty greasy overall. The pea sprouts were "old" and was not the tender variety, which just means that it requires more chewing and is kind of more like chewing on grass. But the flavor was good. The pork with onion was very tasty, authentic, but it was SUPER oily. And the chicken nest had some great flavor; although it was greasy it tasted slightly healthier than the pork since it was just a leaner type of meat.They finish the meal by giving you fortune cookies and almond cookies. The prices are decent but more expensive than I would like to pay for at a place like this. Next time I will be trying some spicy dishes!

27.description: Noodle dishes and egg rolls were good.  I would love to try additional things to see how consistent they are with their dishes.

32.description: 4 stars for their pot stickers, but everything else we have had is too oily, the Szechwan chicken and Mongolian Beef, were huge disappointments.

54.description: I experienced what could have been an average to good Chinese restaurant with nice atmosphere, moderately high prices on dinner items, and pretty good service.  However, I encountered THREE very BAD food QUALITY issues the day I went!Moon Palace does NOT at ALL live up to the 2 Star Rating Chicago Magazine gave it.  If you're curious about checking it out because of that, and expecting that level or excellence, you may wish to save your self a trip that perhaps shall disappoint you.I did not see many Chinese people in there, and I guess there may be a reason for that.The service is not refined per se, but it is very friendly, shows great effort, and is just very diligent and timely.  Drinks are always refilled quickly and dirty empty plates disappear like lightening. Most dishes were nice and soups and appetizers were at a reasonable price point.  Dinners were definitely higher priced than most Chinatown restaurants. They just were not better.The clams in black bean sauce tasted very far from fresh, and they were a huge disappointment.  The clams were also overloaded with what appeared to be too much ground pork in the sauce.   The Hunan fish recipe was delicious but even under the mask of what was a nice recipe, the fish quality did not seem good enough, and I occasionally detected an older fishy taste when eating the dish... maybe there was also quite a bit of MSG / Sodium to hide the not so fresh fish taste I detected at times?You also need to watch out for the Pot Stickers.  They were served a little too soft and thick, with too much grease, oil, or fat oozing out to the plate, and that is not what I hoped for.  If that is what I wanted, I would order xiao long bao or soup dumplings.  Also, the meat in the pot stickers were not prepared carefully enough, as I tasted hard strange objects while I chewed them (that scares me about the meat quality inside).  That was really gross...If I lived close, I would perhaps go and try some other lunch specials, but it is hard to justify a special trip to the area just for that restaurant.    On the weekend, lunch for 2 can quickly set you back for $60 with tip, without any drinks.  It was Ok in some ways, but simply not that good to justify the trip.

48.description: Went back whole visiting Chicago, hadn't eaten here in, oh, 15 years maybe, and while the room was different- maybe a different location even? the fried noodles with black mushrooms was the same. Ok, not the Best thing to eat ever, but in all these years I do sometimes crave the perfect way they fry them crispy and kinda burnt on some ends and soft in the center of the nest. Plus the soy salty mushrooms. We always went there for the Chinese New Year parade and with out of town guests. Maybe it's nostalgia, but I would still go again.

44.description: I took my fam here because I heard good things and I was glad I did. Started w the steamed dumplings which were good. They're were five of us so we got a good selection of things. Lo mein pork, Shanghi noodles, Mu shu beef and stir fried eggplant. All were good w the Mu shu tasting the best. Service was sharp and the restaurant clean. I can't wait to come back.

24.description: This place is overrated Chinese restaurant, or maybe I should say this place is a good American-chinese food, but definitely not for Chinese Chinese food.

7.description: Review JUST for the Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings).  Out of the three restaurants we tried over the weekend in Chicago Chinatown (husband is always on a quest), this was by far the best.  GIANT portions of tasty pork made up for the minimal soup inside the rather doughy dumpling.  Good flavoring.  Wait staff was friendly and attentive.  Restaurant was packed at a rather odd time considering it was late afternoon, but it was a holiday weekend.  Other dishes looked equally appetizing.  They validate cheap parking, but we were able to find free street parking two blocks away.

49.description: My favorite Chinese restaurant I've ever been to.  The pot stickers are amazing, and its all served on a big plate that you scoop onto your own plate, so its shared with everyone at your table. It can be crowded inside if its busy, it is sort of small.

40.description: I dont know if maybe I am just being overly critical of this place because I was sent there under the impression that it was going to "ruin" chinese food for me at any other restaurant for forever because it is so darn good, but I dont understand all the hype. The food wasn't awful, but its very americanized. I should have expected this because the tables are set standard with forks, but even so it was a bit disappointing. I only tasted the egg drop soup, the sweet and sour soup, moo shu pork, and fried rice. The soups were almost syrupy, the moo shu pork was served with mexican tortillas and the fried rice was nothing special. None of it tasted terrible, but just nothing special. The service was nothing special either. If I ever go back to this place maybe Ill try to orange chicken, because it sounds like many people enjoyed that. Regardless, there are probably better, more authentic chinese restaurants to try in chinatown.

53.description: The best Chinese food I've ever had.  Period.

30.description: Ordered a few common Shanghai noodle dishes and they used the same thick noodles for all of them. Not really strong flavor for any of the dishes and I didn't really like the noodles that much. The dumplings were not good. Too large, too much meat, not juicy enough and skin is too thick. Though this place is pretty clean and had a good ambience, I'd find a better and tastier Shanghai restaurant to go to.

46.description: We used to come here with some regularity up until about 5 years ago, so I was happy enough to try again.Nicer decor than most but our meal was so full of salt and MSG that I cannot imagine going back.   We had fried rice, kung pao chicken, a beef dish and one other forgotten item.   I swear I could feel individual crystals crunching in my mouth!These days it feels like Chinese restaurants in traditional Chinatown are mainly the domain of aging overweight tourists.  I've had much better luck at, say, Joy Yee in the mall.----------------------------Edit:(Daniel from Moon Palace responded with a friendly note)I wish I had said something about the salt at the meal -- I'm typically too shy for that (and we were there with another couple).  Daniel's is exemplary of one thing I didn't mention -- the staff was friendly and responsive.

1.description: Moon palace isn't bad but I've had better in Chinatown, doubtful I'll be coming back.I tried the Xiao long bao which to me was just a meet ball dumpling. It was ok but I'm not huge on dumplings just wanted to try it because it was recommended. For dinner I got the orange chicken and also tried the sweet and sour chicken and general tso chicken.  The orange and tso tasted very similar.  The sweet and sour was my favorite dish out of the three I got to try.

55.description: They have some of the freshest chinese food I've ever had! I love everything I've tasted so far, but amongst some of my faves are the sesame chicken, sizziling rice soup and shrimp toast. A bit pricey, but worth it I think. I'll definitely be back and always recommend Moon Palace whenever I'm near Chinatown with friends.

9.description: great spot to grab some lunch with your coworkers or friends.  had sweet and sour chicken, ran goons, bao, and chow mein.  sweet n sour came out crispy on the outside and juicy chicken in the in.  also had chow mein for the first time.  I heard it's supposed to be really crunchy, but it was yummy nonetheless. the restaurant wasn't busy at all and the service was alright.  easily accessible by red line or car.  you can get your parking ticket validated for a discounted price if you ask the server.

26.description: We came here looking for Xiao Long Bao! This restaurant is very Americanized Chinese food, so if you know that coming in, then you'll be alright. We didn't know that, and as a result were a little disappointed. Customer service is very good here, however.But their Xiao Long Bao was a disappointment--no soup inside the dumplings (most of them were torn/popped, but even the ones that were not popped had no soup); the meat itself was tough and dry. I probably won't return here.

25.description: First time I came here I was blown away by the food and the service. Every time since then the quality of the food and the service keeps going down. Really wish the service wasn't so bad now. The waitresses always seem rushed and barely check if you need anything. Will give it a try again in a couple months.

12.description: OVERPRICED, OVERPRICED,  OVERPRICED. SO I WENT here tonight and got an order of beef fried rice for $9.50 when i could've went across the street to 3 happiness and got the same container with double the tender beef and taste for $6.50.  I also ordered chicken and chinese broccoli which was extremely bland and small. Guess how much that ish was, $12. Talk about wtf. Im pissed and angry at this highway robbery i experienced tonight. I will be sticking to my norm, the lovely 3happiness across the street. Btw, you should too

59.description: I love this place. Every time we have family visiting and someone suggests a trip to Chinatown, we eat here. The service is always super friendly and attentive. The beef lo mein and wonton soup are delightful. The fried rice and egg rolls so tasty. We always have leftovers and everyone leaves satisfied. Two thumbs up.

21.description: So this place came recommended from a friend. Sadly, it's not quite what it's cracked up to be. Ordered the pot stickers and Kung Pao chicken. Everything came out quickly, which was great, but the pot stickers came out so hot that I couldn't actually eat them until the entree showed up.Once they cooled, they were good -- not fabulous, but certainly above average. However, the entree was not okay at all. The chicken was clearly fresh and so were the veggies, but the sauce was bitter and medicinal-tasting. It was certainly spicy enough for me but it had this very obvious bitter/burnt flavor in the sauce to it that was very, very off-putting. In short? A+ for fresh ingredients, B for solid potstickers, but an F for awful sauce and a disappointing entree overall. Net result? C+.

17.description: Yan du xian here is much much better than Lao Shanghai, the broth is just thick enough to be tasty and not too heavy.

10.description: My friends and I went here for a late dinner this weekend. It wasn't too crowded so we were seated right away. Our eyes were also far bigger than our stomachs, so we ordered nearly the whole menu. We got dumplings, Peking Duck, peppered beef, salt and pepper pork, okra, and chicken fried rice. Enough to feed a small village. All were delicious, and the portions were huge. The food came out quickly, and the service was friendly and helpful.

5.description: The best Chinese food in the city. A comprehensive menu that ranges from familiar American-ized favorites to traditional dim sum. Parking is horrible. They take reservations and will deliver via Grubhub. Have never had a bad meal, dining in or out.

3.description: We went on a Saturday night so it was busy. We got seated right-a-way. Waitress brought us water and then disappeared for awhile. The food was GREAT especially the hot and sour soup. Beef with garlic sauce, chicken and mixed veggies and Kung Pao chicken and shrimp were fantastic. Nearby parking was nice and they validated the parking stub to make it even cheaper. Only bad thing was the service. We did not see our waitress too often and when I asked for the check and if she could validate my parking she got very impaitent and said " yeah,yeah,yeah". It was a Saturday and they were busy and understaffed so I guess I should cut her some slack, I will definitely be back!!

35.description: I took a lengthy break from Moon Palace but decided to give it another chance yesterday.  I'm glad that it did because it reminded me that the food is really tasty.  The pot stickers are among the best in the city, and both the Mongolian beef and pepper steak were very good.  I still take issue with the meat-to-vegetable ratio in the entrees but overall, this was a very good meal.

19.description: Despite the recent additions to Chinatown, Moon Palace remains the only place that satisfies my cravings for Shanghainese. The place is run by an elderly Shanghai woman and her son. The wait staff is fluent in Mandarin, Shanghainese, and English. No worries on any language barriers! My usual order consists of hot and sour soup, xiao long bao, potstickers, stir-fried Shanghai chow mein, and stir-fried Shanghai rice cakes. All of them are my favorites and I would usually pair them with soy sauce and red vinegar. The xiao long bao are slightly larger than the usual so it's a bit more filling but I love how they are gushing with hot soup. The rice cakes are usually served with shreds of pork and stir-fried to a soft texture. You do not have to chew on it for ages!

28.description: Moon Palace...what happened?  Once a favorite and highly recommended, things have changed with the food.  Didn't even want the leftovers.  Please go back to how things used to be.  Nice wait staff.

45.description: I've never had orange chicken quite like this. Its crispy without heavy breading. Flavorful with just enough sauce. You can actually tell by the taste and texture that it's actual chicken. Take that McD's cardboard all white meat!The service is meh but the real gem is the FOOD!

33.description: Really rude waiters but the food was good. I had dumplings, noodles, fried rice, orange chicken and they were tasty. Only forks on tables, no chopsticks no knives

43.description: Get the dumplings, scallion pancakes, beef or chicken "sukiyaki" and a spicy fried rice. You are good to go. Great food and great service.

2.description: My beloved shanghainese food! It's really hard to find them these days; even harder to find good ones! Only got the xiaolongbao; not the best I had but still really good. Give them a try if you come here.

18.description: I'm surprised that I haven't reviewed this restaurant after two holiday parties here over the years. It's your average Chinese restaurant with a small bar in back and about 10 tables or so. I've attended holiday parties here. Let's just say that they don't skimp on portions for their parties. The meal started with crab rangoon, bao, and hot and sour soup. That was just the appetizers. Then, came what felt like the whole side of a menu of other dishes ranging from Kung Pao Shrimp & Chicken, Sliced Beef Shanghai Style, Orange Chicken, Hot Plate Black Pepper Beef, Shredded Pork with String Beans, Shrimp with Asparagus, Salt & Pepper SquidFried Rice Combination. It was a crazy amount of food. I ate about half of the choices hoping to keep within my points range for the meal. The dinner ended with almond cookies and fortune cookies. For a holiday party, you get a huge bang for your buck here with lots of food. The decor is basic, modern, and not outdated or anything. Overall, it's a solid choice for parties.

41.description: I've been coming here for a long time when I have the crave for the hot and sour soup.  Robust flavor of sour, heat from the chili, and heartiness of fresh ingredients. The green onion pancake is crispy and not too oily...the texture is just right. I also enjoyed the hot and sour fried fish...that dish was the 1st to get completely gobbled up. Perfectly fried, with excellent sweet and sour sauce on top.  The service is friendly and helpful which is hard to find in most chinatown restaurants. Give those items a try, you won't regret it!

52.description: Wanted to try a new Chinese place in Chinatown.  I generally hit up the handful of places in my rotation, but the lady had a friend in town and we decided to try something new.  I found Double Li on Yelp and we were on our way.  Unfortunately, it looks like Double Li closed (or potentially relocated).  We tried Moon Palace instead, and we were very pleased.The restaurant has better décor than most places in Chinatown (nice but not a necessity), and it can be a nicer place to take people you want to impress.  I don't expect much in terms of service at Chinese restaurants, but I'd say the service was above average (they spoke English).  Most importantly, the food was solid.  Started with Chive Dumplings followed by Beef Nest, Salt & Pepper Shrimp (no shell), and Baby Bak Choy and Mushroom Variety Dish.  We got both almond and fortune cookies at the end of the meal.The dumplings were similar to what Mom makes and everything else had solid flavor and was fresh.  I wish it was a bit spicier, but I'm sure that's something I can request for next time when I bring the extended family and order more authentic dishes.  The best part was that 1-hour later I wasn't thirsty = No/little MSG!  That means a whole lot to me.  Moon Palace has definitely made its way into the restaurant rotation in Chinatown.

50.description: Okay first off I have to say that the food was good, it was me and my boyfriends first time there, I'm picky about food and they had a great variety of dishes. People must try the cold jellyfish, delish....however...Service lacked. We were seated and it took 10 minutes for our waitress to come back and take our order for drinks but not before she took the order of someone who came in right after us!? After we got our appetizers and my boyfriend got his drink it took at least another 20 minutes for another waitress to even notice us and I told her I had yet to get my drink. By then the people that came in after us had already gotten their food and were happily eating away. At that point I was sorely disappointed with the service, as much as the food was good I will not go back. The service was very cold and unfriendly...not impressed

4.description: We came here for only one reason the soup dumplings.  Since soup dumplings are scorching hot and a little difficult for a 4 year old to eat we ordered him some Shanghai style BBQ pork, he loved it.  I tasted a little and the sauce had good flavor with a little bit of sweetness.  These soup dumpling are little meatier than, I am used to, however, the pork inside was excellent.  Where they fall short for me was the lack of broth.  There was only a little bit of broth in each dumpling and some of the broth was leaking from some of the dumplings.  What broth you did get did taste good, they just need to do a better job keeping the broth inside the dumpling.  A big knock off on this place, for the little Buddha beer they charge $6.95 absolutely ridiculous.

6.description: Their soup dumplings are decent compared to most places in Chinatown but nonetheless, Americanized overpriced Chinese food.

22.description: Well, we could not be more disappointed at how quickly this place has gone downhill.  We've gone here for years and introduced many people too it.  Unfortunately, after our bland dining experience there today, we will be looking for a new regular restaurant in Chinatown.  We had lunch there and I ordered the shrimp with lobster sauce, something I've eaten there before and remembered fondly.  When it arrived, it didn't even look like the same dish I had had before and the taste was simply average.  I could get the same dish at any Chinese restaurant in any part of the city; no point in treking down to Chinatown for the dish.  My partner had 2 of his favorite dishes there:  hot and sour soup and mu shu pork.  After eating the first spoonful, he looked at me and said, "Something's going on in this kitchen."  I asked him how it was and he said, "How can you screw up hot and sour soup?".  When he started on the Mu Shu, he looked at me and said it tastes different.  And, after talking, we both agreed that the dishes lacked whatever seasoning and/or spice that used to be in them that made them so great before.  My partner said he knew something was going on the first time we came there and they no longer gave you chopsticks.  Then they changed the menu.  The last time we were there for lunch, you got the regular menu and the lunch special card.  Today, all we got was the lunch special card.  And, I drank my glass of water and finished it in the middle of my meal and it took me sloshing my ice around loudly to get any of the other servers to look up from their cell phones to give me more water (Oh, and we were the ONLY people in the restaurant at that time).  Whether there's a new chef or new owners, whatever the case may be, this restaurant's quality and uniqueness has plummeted.  I've wanted to get my partner to try Lao Se Chuan after eating there once a few years ago with work colleagues.  He always insisted on Moon Palace.  Now, we're going there next time.  Sorry, Moon Palace, you made changes that are causing 2 customers who have been coming there for over 15 years to STOP coming there.  Might want to re-think your new approach.

15.description: We visit Chinatown every few months and subsist on local neighborhood Chinese restaurants at other times. When we visited Moon Palace on a recent Monday for lunch (granted, it was a slow day) a friend suggested this place, and I wondered why,because it gets very mixed reviews. Having now sampled the egg rolls, the hot and sour soup, a fried chicken dish, the Peking duck and the dumplings, I conclude this restaurant is underrated. The egg roll was the very BEST I've ever eaten, and was a far cry from the ubiquitous frozen/quick-fried variety. The hot and sour soup was the equal of the best I've had. The Peking Duck was superb, and reasonably priced to boot. Everything else was top notch, and Moon Palace has become my new fav in C-town. I'll visit again when the kitchen is busier and update this.

57.description: I love this place!  To m, best Chinese food in Chicago.  I'm a big Kung Pao chicken fan, and they make the best--by far.  Not just hot, but you can detect the levels of flavor in the heat.  That's the difference.    Everything else has intricacy of favor as well.  The service is attentive and helpful.

20.description: This restaurant is conveniently located near the main parking lot so its easy to get to. The restaurant does validate parking good for 3 hours. Make sure you get the validation to save some money. The dining room isn't huge with approximately 15-20 tables. The decor is modern and clean which isn't always the case with Chinatown restaurants. The servers were nice but when the restaurant is packed, they get overwhelmed and can't seem to keep up.  Overall the service was decent, not great. As for the food, appetizers were good. We had hot and sour soup, xiao long bao, and shanghai spring rolls. There are two menus.  One in English with your typical entrees and a Chinese menu. We ordered a few entrees from the English menu which included salt and pepper pork chops & fish fillet with peapod sprouts.  Both were good.  Overall ok service and ok food.

36.description: I'm surprised that I haven't reviewed this restaurant after two holiday parties here over the years. It's your average Chinese restaurant with a small bar in back and about 10 tables or so. I've attended holiday parties here. Let's just say that they don't skimp on portions for their parties. The meal started with crab rangoon, bao, and hot and sour soup. That was just the appetizers. Then, came what felt like the whole side of a menu of other dishes ranging from Kung Pao Shrimp & Chicken, Sliced Beef Shanghai Style, Orange Chicken, Hot Plate Black Pepper Beef, Shredded Pork with String Beans, Shrimp with Asparagus, Salt & Pepper SquidFried Rice Combination. It was a crazy amount of food. I ate about half of the choices hoping to keep within my points range for the meal. The dinner ended with almond cookies and fortune cookies. For a holiday party, you get a huge bang for your buck here with lots of food. The decor is basic, modern, and not outdated or anything. Overall, it's a solid choice for parties.

14.description: So this place came recommended from a friend. Sadly, it's not quite what it's cracked up to be. Ordered the pot stickers and Kung Pao chicken. Everything came out quickly, which was great, but the pot stickers came out so hot that I couldn't actually eat them until the entree showed up.Once they cooled, they were good -- not fabulous, but certainly above average. However, the entree was not okay at all. The chicken was clearly fresh and so were the veggies, but the sauce was bitter and medicinal-tasting. It was certainly spicy enough for me but it had this very obvious bitter/burnt flavor in the sauce to it that was very, very off-putting. In short? A+ for fresh ingredients, B for solid potstickers, but an F for awful sauce and a disappointing entree overall. Net result? C+.

3.description: The dresses here are really pretty but kind of pricey in my opinion. Though if I were looking for one for a special occasion then the price wouldn't seem so bad. Staff isn't outgoing or anything like that but helpful when needed. Definitely worth a stop in when visiting china town.

1.description: Cheongsam dresses? Oh hellz yeah, Dragon Lady! Ninja gear and teeny, overwhelmingly cute satin pajamas for babies. Love the satin slippers with dragonflies scattered over them - a must have!

2.description: I've bought my daughter two Chinese dresses here so far. This is the only place with this much quality variety in traditional Chinese women's dresses. Staff is very helpful. Besides the dresses, there is not much else to this store that is distinguishing.

0.description: I came here for the first time just three weeks ago (a dear friend was visiting from out of town). She got a beautiful silk dress for her daughter, I walked away with a gorgeous black silk robe. Came back tonight; I've got two weddings in the next two months, and I've got nothing to wear. I got two GORGEOUS silk tops, very strong contenders!!

4.description: Cool authentic Chinese clothing store, where you can get some pretty sweet satin dragon robes and such.

3.description: Got an amazing haircut. Tina took a long time getting every detail exactly perfect. She was polite and fun to chat with. I didn't have enough time this time to get color, but will definitely be back for haircuts and color. Better service than river north and the price is better. Loved it!

1.description: I've been curious about No 1 Salon since they opened, but noticed a lot of reviews from new users so I was a bit apprehensive.  After my haircut, I noticed that they had a sign for 20% off for leaving comments on Yelp, and that solved the mystery.  For the record, I'm just wanted to share my experience and didn't get the discount, and don't believe it's good business to offer incentives for reviews.  However, I gladly took advantage of the new customer offer.  When I called to ask if they could take me as a walk-in, there was a little of a language barrier, so I switched over to Cantonese to see if it would be easier but she spoke Mandarin so English worked better, just had to speak more slowly.  It was the early afternoon on a weekday, and there was only one other person when I arrived - several stylists hanging out at the waiting area.  Tina greeted me and assured me that I would have someone that I could communicate with.  I was sent to be washed, where I got a very relaxing scalp massage.  Hugo was my hairstylist.  He was friendly and really took his time working on my hair.  I had asked a trimmed down version of the same haircut with fresh long layers with moderate thinning out, and he did a good job.  The bangs weren't what I preferred, but he recommended not to cut them too short or they would be unruly.  Eventually, I decided to trim them myself after all.  I would recommend bringing a photo as an aid, just in case the hairstylist doesn't see your vision.  Good experience, although I'm not sure if it won me over from the other competitors in Chinatown Square just yet.

2.description: I got my haircut there over the weekend from Tina and I'm still trying to figure out what to do about it.  It's terrible.  My hair is short, so an uneven, chunky hair cut is extremely obvious.  Do I go back and complain? Do I ask for a refund? Do I let someone try to fix my hair? It's already short, I can't afford for it to be any shorter if they try to hack at it again and it turns out even more uneven.
