As we saw people at nearby tables who had ordered after us get their xiao long bao first, we realized they had probably forgotten our order. When we asked our waiter what happened to our order, he just said "let me go check" and didn't come back until 20 minutes later, which meant they probably had to place a new order. At that point, we had pretty much finished our meal already. Food: nothing impressive, and looked better than it tasted. Here's what we had:- Shanghai fried rice cake: yummy and chewy with good flavor. Probably my favorite dish out of the ones we ordered but I like fried rice cake a lot lol.- Short ribs with mushroom and onion: decent, slightly greasy- Shui zhu yu (spicy fish fillet): I have a low spice tolerance and even I didn't think this was spicy at all, except maybe towards the end. Also lacked salt. I was disappointed because Lao Szechuan has such a good version of this.- Tofu, egg, and veggie soup: okay, nothing to write home about. - Xiao long bao: disappointing after reading all the positive reviews, but maybe it didn't taste as good after we were already full. It had an odd stale kind of flavor to it; perhaps they are frozen like some reviewers suggest. Overall disappointing experience here, but maybe we didn't order the right dishes. Would recommend Lao Beijing instead!

12.description: One of the star in china town. This place is very authentic chinese food. Service is nice. Staff is very friendly and knows the menu. I order the shanghai dumpling, seafood in xo sauce, oyster stir fry with house special sauce. The duck with roast tea then deep fry is a MUST TRY. I have never had such a delicious duck dish like this.

59.description: ROACHES!! There was a roach in my plate. It had been cooked and sauced... Not what I ordered, will never go back.

21.description: Most restaurants in the Chicago Chinatown serve up Cantonese cuisine, so it was a nice change of pace to eat northern-style Chinese food. I found the food to be fairly average and the servings to be rather small compared to other places.Ordered:-Xiao long bao (soup dumplings)-Kung pao chicken-Sliced pork in wine sauceThe place is definitely worth trying if you are interested in northern cuisine.

17.description: Lao Shanghai - why have I not discovered your wonders sooner? We've ordered food for delivery from you before and the food was always solid but the delivery time was less than stellar?The real magic happens when you eat in-house at the restaurant. It's affordable and the service is the best I've had at any Chicago Chinatown establishment. You re-filled the waters of our party of 8, you patiently took our orders and answered questions about the menu, you checked up on us when we needed something. Food was outstanding - this coming from a girl who's parents owned two Chinese restaurants in NYC. This place is the real deal in terms of Shanghai cooking so if you're used to Panda Express, you're in for a real treat. I highly recommend:-Stir fried Chinese broccoli with garlic-Tony's gourmet eggplant-Fish fillet in spicy szechuan sauceAnd when they say your table will be ready in 10 minutes - they really mean 10 minutes! Not the generic fake 10 minutes that other places will tell you.

10.description: Oh no! Just called them to see if they use chicken broth in their veggie dishes. They said they do, and that it's all cooked together. It couldn't be separated. Boo! What a shame. Not vegan-friendly. This was my favorite place in Chinatown too.

5.description: Went here because I had a groupon. The place was pretty empty, so I guess I knew my answer about this place. I ordered the soup dumplings which were good. I also ordered the steamed buns with red bean filling which was good also. The appetizers were probably the best dishes that came to the table. For entrees we ordered the cumin spare ribs which were under the chef specialties. This dish wasn't really good at all. Too many peppers, salty and the meat was chewy. We also ordered the clams in black bean sauce. This is usually one of my favorite dishes but not tonight. The best entree was the flat noodles pan fried with beef. I've had better but it was the best entree dish we had. If I were going to Chinatown, this wouldn't be on my radar to go to, sorry!

3.description: I went to this restaurant because online it is listed as having the "best soup dumplings in Chicago." I was not impressed with the soup dumplings at all, they were not soupy and were actually very dry. They did not seem fresh and they looked liked they were frozen. I should have anticipated this when we were the only people in the restaurant.

35.description: The service was absolutely horrible. We were the only people in the restaurant and they messed our order up twice and forgot to put in our pot sticker order. The chicken was dry, and the waiter would disappear for long periods of time. The only thing they didn't mess up was the glasses of water.

19.description: Shanghainese food. I crave it ALL the time. Sure it's not the best, but it's authentic enough for me whenever I miss it. My parents are both from Shanghai and this is a stop whenever they come to visit. The service here is good but the place is a little small and fills up pretty quickly.

28.description: Lao Shanghai - why have I not discovered your wonders sooner? We've ordered food for delivery from you before and the food was always solid but the delivery time was less than stellar?The real magic happens when you eat in-house at the restaurant. It's affordable and the service is the best I've had at any Chicago Chinatown establishment. You re-filled the waters of our party of 8, you patiently took our orders and answered questions about the menu, you checked up on us when we needed something. Food was outstanding - this coming from a girl who's parents owned two Chinese restaurants in NYC. This place is the real deal in terms of Shanghai cooking so if you're used to Panda Express, you're in for a real treat. I highly recommend:-Stir fried Chinese broccoli with garlic-Tony's gourmet eggplant-Fish fillet in spicy szechuan sauceAnd when they say your table will be ready in 10 minutes - they really mean 10 minutes! Not the generic fake 10 minutes that other places will tell you.

45.description: Steamed buns were perfect.  Filled with a red bean paste im eating them as I type, and I believe I have found an addiction.  (Crap)! Lol I will be back very very soon.  This place is very reasonably priced as well!!!

33.description: Not very good for Chinese people. I don't like the food. Even the recommended dishes are not delicious.

43.description: I still stand by my 3 star review for this place. I went again yesterday and got a number of different dishes this time. Thanks to someone in our group who speaks Chinese! Woohoo!!!~She was saying that the xiao long bao (soup dumplings) were probably store bought, frozen ones. Sigh. Where can I find some legit, good ones in Chicago????She did order this dish that was like duck egg sauced crab legs. The crab shell had a lot of the crab eggs that looked like it would be perfect mixed with some rice and hot sauce. At least, that's how I like to eat it hahaha. Nothing else that stood out to me, but check out the photos once I upload them I guess.

2.description: I went here last year with a group of friends and I LOVED it. Food was great and I actually tired Jellyfish and i was good too. They gie you free tea wen you enter in. Yup I am definitely gong back there.Did I mentioned that the waiters were friendly too.

18.description: If I could give zero stars, I would.Tonight, Saturday, I took a friend to dinner at Lao Shanghai expecting to use my Groupon. It takes about 1 hour to get there on the red line train. They had a sign on the door that said they do not accept "coupons". We sat and I told the waiter that we had a groupon and he said they don't accept groupons on Saturdays. I asked to speak to the manager who came over and re-iterated the same. I showed him my Groupon which has no stipulation excluding Saturdays, or any days for that matter. He refused to accept the Groupon, so we left. I won't eat there ever again.

41.description: It's just American Chinese food. If you are a Chinese I do not recommend you to go there. They just mix the pork with the sauce which looks like catchup and obviously the sauce is full of red pigment. We spend $50 for two.  I feel totally not worthy. The service of the waiter is good so I give one more star.

52.description: Incredible! When we moved to Chicago we were afraid we'd left delicious Chinese food back in greater Los Angeles, where, as some of you know, has suburb after suburb of countless authentic Chinese restaurants of all types and regional styles. We remember eating at generic Americanized places in Chicago's Chinatown back in the 90s and were dubious this time 'round. To our surprise, Hing Kee (a few doors down from Lao Shanghai) was amazing. Tonight we gave Lao Shanghai a try and were blown AWAY! Everything was excellent - the soup dumplings were perfect with delicious broth and thin dumpling skin. The dry bean curd and greens appetizer had that rich sesame flavor. Bitter melon with black bean sauce didn't hold back - real bitter melon - as it should be. Pork with mustard greens and soybeans was tender, finely chopped, saturated with broth. That alone would've been a one-dish meal. Wow. And, the lamb. Oh, the lamb... We went for the cumin and red chili lamb, which we could smell across the room, as it was being brought to the table! Damn, that was good - roasted cumin flavor throughout with those big slivers of garlic, huge wedges of onion, whole red chilis and sliced jalapeños. BIG and bold, and it hit the spot.Great service. Free tea and rice! The room was spotless and tastefully designed with those beautiful globe lights, framed black and white photographs, and stamped tin bar. We appreciated the attention to detail. Really stands out from the flashy, plastic interiors and trendy offerings of some places on the same strip.Lao Shanghai is our new favorite restaurant, city-wide, hands-down. We'll be back next week!

50.description: They have good food, but they lie! Never count on getting your delivery close to their estimate - double the estimate and count on eating food prepared some time ago.

4.description: Got to check out Chicago's version of Chinatown while we're here. Lao Shanghai is located within Chinatown Square, away from the bustling city, tucked close to the 'burbs, and filled with shops, restaurants, and clinics. Complimentary oolong tea upon seating. We stuffed our faces with ong choy (water spinach, rau muong, or ipomoea aquatica), fried pot stickers, shu mai, and two orders of xiao long bao (soup dumplings). Our soup dumpling virgin enjoyed her first time eating xiao long bao. :D All the dishes were delicious; a great addition to our Chicago food adventure. Staff and service was great. The establishment was quaint and intimate. The restaurant offers free wifi with their password on the register.

6.description: Average food + bad service gives this place 3 stars in my book, which is a shame because I quite like Lao Beijing (hot pot!) and Lao Szechuan. If it hadn't been for our Groupon ($26 for $50), I might have given it 2 stars... Service: getting seated and giving our orders was fine, but we thought something was strange when they started bringing out our entrees first before the xiao long bao and soup we had ordered. As we saw people at nearby tables who had ordered after us get their xiao long bao first, we realized they had probably forgotten our order. When we asked our waiter what happened to our order, he just said "let me go check" and didn't come back until 20 minutes later, which meant they probably had to place a new order. At that point, we had pretty much finished our meal already. Food: nothing impressive, and looked better than it tasted. Here's what we had:- Shanghai fried rice cake: yummy and chewy with good flavor. Probably my favorite dish out of the ones we ordered but I like fried rice cake a lot lol.- Short ribs with mushroom and onion: decent, slightly greasy- Shui zhu yu (spicy fish fillet): I have a low spice tolerance and even I didn't think this was spicy at all, except maybe towards the end. Also lacked salt. I was disappointed because Lao Szechuan has such a good version of this.- Tofu, egg, and veggie soup: okay, nothing to write home about. - Xiao long bao: disappointing after reading all the positive reviews, but maybe it didn't taste as good after we were already full. It had an odd stale kind of flavor to it; perhaps they are frozen like some reviewers suggest. Overall disappointing experience here, but maybe we didn't order the right dishes. Would recommend Lao Beijing instead!

22.description: Everything  was delicious  especially  crispy  duck! Fast service. Nice waiter,  free hot tea, and has grupon! Good  deal!

15.description: Just had lunch to laoShanghai, feel is good, the taste of food is still more suitable for me, the steamed stuffed bun, snacks, cold cuts, are my favorite.

57.description: Once again this place is amazing! They have a new program called "perka" which is an app you can download- where you can accumulate points for eating. 1 dollar = 1 point. Once you hit 75pts you get 5.00 off!It is very simple to use and really adds up if you eat here a lot- family style!The service is incredible and my favorite food is still the xiao long bao (XLB)- soup dumplings. They take a little bit more time to steam so always ask for it first (before appetizers) so it is ready when you are ready eat.Recently I came here with a couple of my  (non Asian) law professors after working at the legal clinic and they really enjoyed it. I highly recommend the Szechuan green beans- they are crunchy and crsip!I also love the Shanghai noodles- the sauce is not too salty but just buttery yet with Asian flavor. (my description is probably way off but it is yummy!) The wait on the weekends sucks though so makes sure to go in and put your name down before you walk through New Chinatown!

20.description: This place is horrible. I ordered rice cake as lunch. It's totally messed up! The rice cake is not chewy. The vegetables were not fresh at all. Definitely not going back again!!

36.description: Every bite was a small slice of heaven - especially the walnut shrimp. Yummy yummy.  And the best service I've ever had.

14.description: This establishment sticks out amongst the dozens of restaurants in Chinatown. I had the empress chicken one fine afternoon and now I'm back for the same dish. While I can't say that it made me feel like an empress, it sure is delicious. They have little gold and black tea cup looking things mounted to the wall to give the place a "modern" flare. Dining here is quick, quiet and deeeeelicious

3.description: I've only been here for the half off buns after 5pm or so. Get here early because they go quick. Even the dim sum items and others are part of it. Though not the best, pretty good deal though!

1.description: We ordered a mango smoothie, shrimp dim sum, and a ham & egg bun. We received a pineapple smoothie--okay, small mistake. But it was mainly ice, with little in the way of fruit. A waste of money.  We didn't even bother to have the incorrect order corrected. The shrimp dim sum was passable, as was the bao.  There are many better bakeries and fruit smoothies in Chinatown.

2.description: I am a sucker for pies and this place has a variety of flavors: apple, blueberry, cherry, and peach pie. One of each flavor only cost me a total of 4 dollars and I must say: so glad I walked all the way there that day (pies are not too sweet or flakey.)

5.description: Golden Apple Cafe is average compared to the many bakeries in Chinatown. The buns are yummy, but the lunch dishes aren't that great. I tried the rice noodles and fried noodles, which was overflowing  with tasteless sauce and oil.The prices are cheap, however. (65 cents for a pineapple top bun!) I love to come here after 5:00 pm to get discounted buns: buy one get one free (Although the prices mysteriously changes from 65 cents to 90 cents). I would rate this cafe with four stars, but the service was terrible. The cashier tried to rip me off because she didn't know that I knew about the buy one get one free offer. When asked her about it, she just said "Yeah", changed the price, and continued watching the Chinese drama on TV.

0.description: This bakery is definitely at the top of my list in Chinatown. Fresh food and great prices make it hard to pass up.  If you're bringing more than 5 people, the afternoon seems like a better time than the morning.My favorites include:Shrimp won ton soup  (Hong Kong style)Ham & Egg bunBBQ Pork pastryApple pie pastryButterfly cookies (order of 4)You can always get a cup of milk tea for under a dollar.  Pick out a sandwich, a pastry and tea for $3.00 and you should leave contented.In addition to the baked goods, you can also find a full range of decent restaurant fare that is always fun to share with your table mates.

4.description: I just found out about this place a few weeks ago - never even knew there was a bakery there. Prices on the pastries and desserts are pretty good - you can get three steamed white buns with pork and vegetable or BBQ pork for two dollars. I've also had their cheescakes and tiramisu and it's pretty yummy too, although some may find it a tad too sweet. Entrees are decent for the price. Service is great, and the staff is fluent in English.If you do go, I recommend trying out their chicken sandwich. Pretty good and it's only 1 dollar!

28.description: i think 2 stars may be a bit generous.  just moved here to chicago from Boston.  After having been pampered for years by my Japanese stylist in Boston, i have forgotten what a bad hair cut is like.  Urban Roots reminded me.  Just like many of my peeps out there, i always thoguht taht if i want a decent cut, i need to find an Asian place.  So i went.  And left looking like every Chinatown teenager gangsta, with over-gelled spikey hair.  I felt like i was back in high school.  Perhaps i should take it as a compliment that the stylist thought i was younger than i am .  Anyway, i am still in search of a decent place to cut  this asian guy's hair.  Suggestions please.

1.description: Being of Asian decent, I thought my best bet for finding a hair stylist would be to go to an Asian one...  What a huge miscalculation! I came here because the place looks classy, but the staff struggles with the English language. I asked for a particular type of perm to make the hair on my sides lay back. The stylist struggled to grasp what I clearly explained to him. He hands me a book of mens hairstyles. I find one I like and show it to him. The end result looks absolutely nothing like the one depicted in the photo, even though he told me he can produce said hairstyle. I reluctantly agreed to pay $70 even though I walked out of that salon looking exactly the same as I did before. In other words, I flushed $70 down a toilet.I don't remember my stylist's name, but he's the guy with the hipster glasses. This salon has really left a bad taste in my mouth. The overall atmosphere gives the sense of being rushed in and out with no consideration for customer satisfaction. After numerous lousy experiences with hair stylists, I've come to the conclusion that they're akin to car salesmen. They're only in it to syphon money out of the consumer. There is neither artistry nor work ethic involved.If I could rate this sewer with Zero Stars, I would.

9.description: Behind all the cute little anime shops and the fancy new fusion restaurants that are popping up left and right, the backdrop of Chinatown serves as the battleground for an underground war of hair salons that all originated at this nice little salon. Over the years, different disgruntled hairstylists have broken off from Urban Roots to start their own salons right down the street; what's somewhat amusing is the sense of tension you get from all this "hair salon" drama. Granted, it really isn't thaaat deep but Urban Roots Salon used to be the top dog, the Queen Bee if you will and now, from her own hive, ambitious worker drones have colonized new hives to challenge her throne (i guess drones wouldn't be able to but for the sake of the metaphor, whaatever). Even my extended family has been torn apart (at least in the hair arena); some of my family has switched to other salons while others have remained loyal to Urban Roots. As for myself, I've been getting my hair cut here for about 6-7 years and I can honestly say that I've never come away disappointed. My wallet maybe. But me, never.I've always had my hair cut by Ray so I can't comment on the skills of other stylists but I highly recommend asking for Ray if you make an appointment. He's very nice and is very good at remembering how you got your hair cut during your last appointment; definitely saves on the trouble of bringing in a picture or something. What makes this place great is how easy everything seems to flow. You walk in and within 5 minutes, they'll take you back and wash your hair with shampoo and conditioner. After a quick towel dry, you'll have your hair cut and once your finished, they'll wash your hair again with shampoo and dry/style it for you, if you wish. And what's more important is that they are very good about being on time. Rarely will they be behind schedule and make you wait and what's more is if you know you will be late or might be in Chinatown a bit early, they will gladly switch up your appointment time if they have the room. One thing you can try to do is schedule during the weekdays or earlier on the weekends. This isn't as much of a problem now since many other salons have slowly sapped away customers but when the schedule gets packed, most of the hair stylists will start to rush on your haircut just so they don't fall behind. While that's obviously annoying, you can save yourself the irritation and at the same time, you'll get more well paced service.The only point of contention I can think of is the price. While the haircuts are good, the cost is definitely on the high end and adding a tip for your stylist will raise the total quite steeply. However, if you're not too worried about the pricing, I would definitely recommend this place. It's a solid salon and will definitely treat you with great service and a good haircut.

29.description: I went here six years ago and stopped because it was getting a bit too expensive for me in high school, and for awhile I wasn't sure if I should come back since I mostly had my hair done at Hair Cuttery and a hair salon in Indiana. I was more on the budget hair cuts since I don't really need anything special done to my hair other than long layers and a trim. I went back for my first time after 6 years with the fear that an Asian person was going to cut my hair. I have always been scared since most of my friends who had their hair done by an Asian turns out to be pretty bad..it had that "Asian" look with split ends, etc. It just doesnt look healthy. Sorry if I am offending anyone but I'm sure some of you understand what I mean.  Anyway getting to the point, my hair cut turned out alright. No split ends, no Asian wave, etc.  It has been about 4 months and my hair grew the way how I wanted it to be. The price for a haircut is not expensive since I am now working. The negative side here is that most of the workers there dont speak good English. The customer service was good, though. Overall, this isn't a bad place to go to. The setting is pretty hip..they are very cultured in HK pop.

23.description: Walked in on Sunday at 6p.m.  The wash was thorough and they got to me quickly.  No wait.  Got a decent trim-Eric is a very nice guy and stylist.I will definitely go back for future cuts.  He recommended products to style my hair but also told me that I don't have to use their brand. I appreciate that.

5.description: 2 of my Asian coworkers go to this place religiously, so I had to try it. More than a year later, I still travel close to an hour from Evanston to see Eric to get my hair cut. My sister also started going to Eric regularly. So I know 4 picky women who swear by him... he can do girls styles too!  One observation is that the style varies each time we visit. We don't mind too much, as it always looks cool. Somehow he knows exactly what to do with our hair!Not sure why people complain about the prices, as many salons charge 60-100 for a wash, cut and style.... seems very reasonable to me. I am long overdue for a cut and can't wait to swing by here, and get some dim sum while I'm at it. In a nutshell, great asian haircuts!!!

31.description: I used to have a rule that I would ONLY go to an Asian stylist because they know how to cut  Asian hair better.  Afterall, the texture of our hair is different.After my first and only experience at Urban Roots, I will not be going back.  I called to schedule a weekend appointment and no one answered. so I left a voice mail. Two days later, I got a call and booked at 9am on Saturday morning.I was the first one there and was ready to get my hair "did".  I needed a cut and highlight pretty badly as my roots were growing out of control. It was the start of summer and I really wanted to lighten up with blondish highlights as I do every year.  I think it was Andy that cut my hair; he give me the booklet of little hair samples to choose the color I wanted.  He made some suggestions and we settled on a blond-brunette color as the highlight that he would mix himself.After the color was done, we did the cut.  I couldn't tell what the cut would be like as my hair was still wet.  The end results came up when he blow dried my hair.  It was RED.  ALL OF IT.  I mean, the highlights were so overwhelming that it made my entire head look BRIGHT red.  I wasn't happy with it at all.  My hair cut was sooooo "FOBBY"!  Like a Japanese school girl!When I got home, my boyfriend asked, "what did you do to your hair???" and he is NOT normally rude!After that experience, I've opted out of coming here again.  I got to Exsalonce now. Pricier by about $50 and many more miles for me to travel to - but at least they get it right.

25.description: I started going to Ray at Urban Roots about 6 years ago.  He's always so flexible and can fit me in anytime.  It's a bit of a drive for me, but it's worth it.  I love the way Ray cuts.  The style always looks "grow-in" instead of blunt and obvious that you just got a haircut. I love that the salon washes your hair before a cut & after it's cut.  Plus, they're thorough when washing.  It's refreshing.

12.description: Walked in on Sunday at 6p.m.  The wash was thorough and they got to me quickly.  No wait.  Got a decent trim-Eric is a very nice guy and stylist.I will definitely go back for future cuts.  He recommended products to style my hair but also told me that I don't have to use their brand. I appreciate that.

21.description: I like this place, it's trendy, affordable and entertaining.I've been going there for the past 2 years and I regularly get my haircut with Norris. Weekdays are better, there are less customers so you'll get more attention.I strongly recommend this place if you're looking for stylists who are familiar with asian hair.Make sure you know what haircut you want or bring a photo if you don't want to be disappointed.

16.description: I forgot to get cash before I came so had to go to the credit union around the corner before my appointment.  (*Has to be $65 and up in order to use your credit card here.)Came to see Ricky again today.  He did a great job.  Was in and out of there in an hour.  I love how all the Asian places wash your hair after the cut and before the blow-dry to make sure all the loose hair is out and so they can do one more final check before letting you go. Cost me $35 + tip.  Can't beat that.

17.description: I like this place, it's trendy, affordable and entertaining.I've been going there for the past 2 years and I regularly get my haircut with Norris. Weekdays are better, there are less customers so you'll get more attention.I strongly recommend this place if you're looking for stylists who are familiar with asian hair.Make sure you know what haircut you want or bring a photo if you don't want to be disappointed.

10.description: Came here for my last 3 speedy haircuts and have always been satisfied. I can't believe I was travelling all over the north side chasing the dream haircut and it was in Chinatown the whole time! I usually go with Andy and he always cuts my hair perfectly. He's like a genius with my hair, (I'm half asian) where as other salons can't seem to do a simple long layered look.Brought a friend here who's hair is the opposite mine and she was also very pleased. I will forever be a customer here.

11.description: Been going here for a few years now.  It was very convenient  while living in the city taking the red line down.  I now live an hr away and still drive down for hair cuts and a good meal (tons of good places to eat).  Eric does a pretty good job with my thick Asian hair.  He takes his time and does exactly what you want done to your hair.  I've had other places who cut to much off making my hair stick up in the back or charge me $60 for a barley noticeable trim.  Urban roots will run you $26 plus tip which includes a precut shampoo and conditioner and wash and style after the cut...can't beat it.

26.description: After years of having horrible hair cuts, I found Urban Roots on advice from a friend.  I love going here because Andy finally gets it right everytime.  I love that they wash my hair before and after the cut.  I've been going there for years and now my family and girlfriend all go to him.  I was worried about posting because I don't want him to get any more busy, then he might not have time for me :)

27.description: This is one of the best haircuts I have ever gotten!  They wash your hair before AND after they cut your hair!  I usually end up with a hair-covered neck and have to jump in the shower when I get home, but this was not the case.  The only reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5 is because you can't use a credit card unless you spend $65+.  Ask for Billy.

0.description: I've typically been a big fan of going to the Aveda School in Lincoln Park (cuz it's cheap and gets the job done) but this place might have converted me! I've always had problems finding new ways to do my hair just because I have very thin hair and not a lot of it. Also, it's stick straight and doesn't have much texture. This is pretty opposite of a lot of American hair. I came to this place with my dad on a daddy and me adventure day in Chinatown and we decided to get hair cuts together in hopes that they would be more knowledgeable about Asian hair and they were! It was pretty packed on a Saturday afternoon but the wait was less than 20/30 minutes with about 5 people ahead of us in line. The shampoo-ist was a little sloppy with the wash as water rolled a bit down my back but he was speedy and efficient in getting my hair prepped for cutting. I had "B" as a stylist - one of the few women there - and loved my experience with her. I told her about what length I wanted and what my normal routine was and told her to have at it with something that she thought would look good. She gave me a cut that was flattering and more inventive than the ladies at the Aveda School has ever given me...and she was quick BUT GOOD and was very attentive to detail. Total time of haircutting was about 40 minutes and that includes blowdrying and some styling. For a $31 haircut, I'm sold. My dad's was $27.Will definitely come again for good fast service and knowledgeable people when it comes to Asian hair!!

20.description: been going to urban roots for at least 10 yearshaircuts, highlights, perms... i had it all there, always great service (my stylist is Ray) and always great resultsdefinitely a fan!

19.description: Ray does a great job on my hair every time I go.  He cuts Asian hair really well which is not easy to do - mine is super straight.  They have alot of attentive staff, fun gossip magazines, and as the name implies, a cool urban feel to it.  There's always fun pop videos on the flat screens, too!  I can't wait to try out the karaoke place they opened up too!

33.description: I've been getting my hair cut by the same person for the last 10-12 years and I can honestly say this place is great for guys and girls.  It's kept cleaner and the facilities are definitely more modern than a lot of other asian run hair cutteries around.  You get to enjoy various asian pop/club music while you get your do on.  They recently added some LCD TV's throughout the entire place so you get music videos as well.Go there and ask for Eric (spikey, mohawk, crew cut... you name it) if you're a guy and Andy if you're a girl.  They're cool guys and really give you the attention you deserve for your hard earned money.

2.description: may not come back

32.description: Agree with all the other posters - these guys take the time to cut hair right.  Pricey (mens cuts are 26+) but you definitely get what you paid for.  Good mix of female and male clientele

18.description: It's a decent looking salon, I've had a cut there once and my brother had a few.  I must say it really  depends on who you get for your cut.  My brother once had this guy cutting his short hair for two hours.  Totally worth it if you asked me since it was a pretty awesome cut.But personally I can't tell who's who since they look kind of the same.  But don't get the guy that doesn't look like the other since my brother HATED his cut, it was a 20 min waste of time.  And it cost the same amount as the two hours long session.I do think that they do better with guys cut than girls, since I've seen many females getting cuts there and they all look alike...almost like they didn't even cut it.  So the one time I did get mine cut there from long to short hair, you'll notice the difference, but I don't see any style.  So don't think I'd recommend any female friends there.Oh and remember you ask about the price before you get your cut.  And bring cash, there's a high minimum on the credit card usage.

13.description: After trying various places, and being disappointed, I've settled on Urban Roots for my haircuts.As someone who gets his hair cut about once every two months, it is very important that my hair gets cut properly.  Otherwise, it gets bad after about two weeks.  I have learned the hard way that Asian hair is different enough that I need to go to an Asian salon.  Other places that cater towards a more Caucasian clientele don't utilize tools, like thinning shears, which are necessary for Asian haircuts.They provide a pre and post cut hair wash, and are very quick and efficient.  However, it does get busy so you want to make reservations.  This place is on the pricey side ($27 for men's cut), but they do a proper job, allowing me to go 2 months without a trim.  Ricky cuts my hair and he does a great job.

4.description: They're now known as PRIVATE 1 Hair Salon . Renovated the whole place but most of the stylists are still here.

24.description: Having checked out a few of the Salons in Chinatown,  I would say average skill and technique, a bit on the high side for a mens cut for the ability.However, they do play a nifty assortment of HK pop videos which is entertaining

6.description: It was my first time to have my hairdo at Urban Roots and it was for a wedding! Ray was very patient and innovative. My hairdo took approximately 30 minutes and he engaged me in friendly conversation. There were no hair-straightening or curling involved, but lots and lots of hairspray as well as BOBBY PINS! He wrapped my hair in the back and twirled it into a bun. He also created a wavy section to the left and here's where the creativity came into place. Ray asked if I had any accessories and I said no. He felt that was too boring so he proceeded to adding some 20 silver bobby pins... At the end, I felt like I had a spaceship landed on my head except it was lopsided. I would not have minded if I was attending a fashion show but this is for a wedding. Not quite the place to make a loud statement... Of course, I sneakily removed all of them the moment I left the salon. Luckily my hairdo was still intact afterwards. PHEW! As for the prices, it's approximately $65-85 for bridesmaids. It really depends on how complex you want it. I would try to keep it as simple as possible especially if this is a wedding held in the summer. Note: My bangs didn't hold together as I had hoped. It fell apart and divided into three parts mid-day. A bit of a bummer for me.

22.description: I forgot to get cash before I came so had to go to the credit union around the corner before my appointment.  (*Has to be $65 and up in order to use your credit card here.)Came to see Ricky again today.  He did a great job.  Was in and out of there in an hour.  I love how all the Asian places wash your hair after the cut and before the blow-dry to make sure all the loose hair is out and so they can do one more final check before letting you go. Cost me $35 + tip.  Can't beat that.

15.description: I've been to Asian salons in NorCal and Philly but the rude service here really took me aback.  The cut was mediocre and really didn't warrant the bad service.  My haircut is really simple (short bob, few layers) and I told the stylist so in both English and Cantonese.  Mid-haircut, the stylist stepped away twice without saying a thing - once to help another stylist blow dry another girl's hair and another time to help with something in the back.  Each time he got back, he was a bit flustered and wasn't sure where he had left things so proceeded to take more off the hair he had already cut, leaving the hair too layered and a little uneven.  When I got home, my roommate asked me what I had done to my hair and why in the world was there a tail in the back.  -_-I'd say it's a your mileage may vary situation.  Didn't request a specific stylist so probably got a trainee.  It was pretty clear that there were VIP stylists and customers and non-VIPs so maybe you just have to be in the know.   Could be a decent place if you're looking for the Asian music video style and don't mind the service but I'll be sticking to Aveda from now on.

7.description: Unfortunately, my favorite stylist, Ricky, has left the place, so I'll be updating the review as follows:If you're looking for an Asian hairdresser, particularly for trendy, FOB-ier hairstyles, Urban Roots is a very good place. Customer service of the place is very good and never once have I left the place itching. They're a bit pricier than what I was used to in San Francisco ($15-$20 in most salons) at around $30 for a wash and cut. They're also conveniently located at the Chinatown plaza, so it's very accessible by the CTA red line.The quality of your haircut is very dependent on who you get. To summarize from other reviewers, if you're a girl, stick with Andy and if you're a guy, go with Eric or Ray. I recently went with Andy and was very pleased with the results of my cut. He was very attentive and very fast and gave me a hairdo that was super easy to manage and super flattering all at once. He is also very nice and one of the co-owners of the shop. I also took one of my exes (a white guy) to Urban Roots a couple years back and Eric did his cut. I found Eric to be very focused and attentive, and my ex told me it was the best haircut he had in his life.One thing to keep in mind is that the place becomes very packed on the weekends, so if you want a weekend cut, book ahead! Also, keep in mind that for anything $65 or under, you'd need cash and if you want to leave a tip, you'll need to do it by cash also.Note: I still stand by my previous review, especially regarding the difficulty in finding a good hairdresser who can handle Asian hair. However, for those who prefer less FOB looks, I highly recommend Kelly Cardenas in the Wicker Park neighborhood. If you're living in the city of Milwaukee, I'd suggest trying The Establishment. Although both places are pricier than Urban Roots, I think they can handle Asian hair reasonably well, despite not being Asian run.

8.description: I have got three haircuts at Urban Roots in total, overall I'm fine with the quality of the haircut, no major screwup and nothing extraordinary. The customer service was fine. However, I dislike being charged with 20% tip automatically without even asking, I thought that was up to me.

30.description: Andy makes my wife's hair look good and that makes her happy, which makes me happy.  There are lots of stylists at this salon, and most look like they're trying to imitate Andy: he wears boots, they wear boots, he wears a bracelet, they wear a bracelet, and so on.  But, you can tell which one is Andy from the moment you enter - the maestro looks comfortable in his coolness.  His clients like his personality, and in my brief interactions with him he's been very pleasant.  As an onlooker, I admire his craft and skill.  He's my wife's favorite stylist, and worth a long trip for his services.

3.description: I've been there couple of times. Last November I went there for hair cut, AL was my hairdresser. He said to me that my hair needed to be straightened which I did. It cost over 400 dollars but overall he did a good job. I went to cut my hair again a couple days ago, he said to me that my hair needed to be straightened. I was so surprised about his recommendation. I told him, " didn't you remember you were the one who straightened my hair last November?" He smiled and said, " different customers everyday that he forgot."  Haha, all he wants it's to make big $$$. Make story short, he didn't ask my permission, and he cut my bangs very very short to an unacceptable level. When I saw it, it was too late. I complained to him.  Then he cut my bangs even shorter. A bad hair cut is going to cause me embarrassed for a full month till it grow long again.Shame on him.

14.description: I've gone to Urban Roots quite a few times because: a) I have a friend who swears by this skinny metro guy there with highlights andb) my mom won't let me go to white people for haircuts. On the whole, I've been pretty satisfied. No, I didn't feel like Anne Hathaway in Princess Diaries when they turned the chair around, but then again no one has traced my royal lineage yet. I do like how they give you two hairwashes -- one in the beginning, and one in the end. Also, the guys there are just on the verge of being sexually questionable so I trust their judgement. However, I'm sad to say that I won't be coming back. Each time after getting an "Urban" haircut, I always notice that I have a bunch of split ends that grow back. I've switched salons since, and haven't noticed the problem again.. which leads me to think that they use blunt shears. (Just don't tell my mom.)

58.description: Really good korean food in chinatown. I tried the japchae, bulgogi, chicken wings, and dolsot bibimbap. Everything was reasonably priced and satisfying. This will be my new go-to korean restaurant since Cho Sun Ok is too far. Next time I'll definitely try the Kalbi and Soontofu Chigae!

56.description: I had dolsot bibimbap and it was delicious. My friend had the regular bibimbap. The meal was great, and the servers are polite and to the point. The side dishes were kind of cold but it's okay since it wasn't really the main focus. Would definitely order other dishes next time. Wasn't crowded, had the regular amount of customers.

29.description: Dine in is better than take-out/delivery.  A bit costly for the quality/amount

42.description: Don't know what the previous reviewers got served, but we certainly didn't get any of it!  First time there with 2 other couples and no one enjoyed the meal.  We started with the kimchi and seafood pancakes.  Both were spongy and tasteless.  Then we had the stir fried kimchi, pork belly w/ tofu.  The pork belly was almost nonexistent and the only distinctive seasoning was from the kimchi.  The bulgogi had a weird, unappealing, mushy texture to it.  We suspect it was from being left in the marinade for too long.  The dolsot bibimbop was flat and the egg was overcooked.  Service was horrible and the wooden benches you are forced to sit on are incredibly uncomfortable.  The waitress was clueless when we asked her for recommendations.  My doctor who is Korean once told me that you can tell how good a Korean restaurant is by how good the ban chan are.  Guess what ....

23.description: Well, officially the worst Korean food i have ever had. And I promise I have had my great share of good Korean food in many places including Seoul, San Francisco, Chicago, Shanghai, Tokyo, Korean friends' homes, some real dives, etc. name it. Never so wtf.So sorry to say this because i really liked the servers and thought were nice, good, hard working people. I am sure kitchen staff are same good way too.Unfortunately the end result (i.e. the food) got to be as bad as it gets.Clean restaurant. Sorry and best wishes.

47.description: It's a really neat place in Chinatown. We ordered soontofu and bulgogi. Both dishes tasted delicious! The waiter also gave us 2 servings of the side dishes. Best! Will definitely go back there.

8.description: Solid Korean restaurant, I'm unsure of why it is only rated 3.5*. Definitely the best Korean place in Chinatown and over much of the south side. The price is great and the atmosphere is super authentic. Also the service is great!

31.description: This place is so cheap and gives huge amount of food. I love the chicken bulgogi(?). Went there three times in two weeks. And then tried other restaurants but I guess it's about time I go there again. I miss their food already!

34.description: Yum! This place is great. Nice place in Chinatown to get a quick Korean meal fix. I had the Haemool Soontofu Chigae, all the spices were there and it was amazing. It was a seafood tofu soup that came with rice on the side. It tasted amazing and big enough to share for two. I couldn't even finish it because I was so full. For appetizer we had the seafood pancakes and it was tasty but too much onions in the dish. I wished we said no onions like I did for my soup. I will most definitely be coming back for more Chigae.

16.description: This place is pretty good, although it's run by Chinese and has a Chinese flare to it. There weren't too many veggie options for me, so I got the ramen, which isn't truly veggie either. I would go back to try the kimchi pancakes.

13.description: Never been to this place before. I've been craving Korean food awhile.I ordered Soontofu and dumpling filled for take out tonight.Soontofu was ok, although I wouldn't say it's the best...but the most problem food is the dumpling. I thought Korean style dumpling is Pan-Fried. Not deep-fried. I got the deep fried dumpling tonight.. Which for me was also ok, but they seem to fry the dumpling too much at a time. So I can't even eat those dumpling. It tasted really old and flat.. And very hard to bite!

11.description: Sadly it seems like things have gone to the way side. They serve their own beers now seems like the main focus. The Bim Bop has been lack luster the last few times the rice wasn't near being crisp or crunchy. The sides that are supposed to accompany the meal didn't come until the last minute. This place started off awesome now it's kinda mediocre they have the time and place to right this. It's not far off, service could be better too with refilling tea and water.      They can easily regain 4 stars if they put a little more effort into it.

39.description: This place is just ok and yet I've been here 4 times. The banchan is pretty tasty and it's great that they keep bringing them out (the fish cakes and the seaweed are 10/10)! Whenever I come I usually get the naengmyeon (cold noodles) which is a little lacking in coldness and flavor. They have a good selection of alcohol and other drinks. The Korean grape juice is really yummy with the little grape pieces in it. Overall, I'm probably going to keep returning because it's the closest Korean to me and better than other places.

37.description: I recommend trying this place if you are in the mood for Korean. Food is good and reasonably priced. I love the chicken wings!

0.description: I came here for dinner with two friends Friday night for the first time. We were seated immediately when we walked through the door at a little past 7:30. All three of us ordered the dolsot bibimbop. I got mine with beef, and it came out in a HUGE stone pot. The veggies, rice, and meat were all tasty and fresh. My only complaint was that my sunny side egg was way undercooked. All of the egg white surrounding the yolk was still raw. I don't have a problem with raw/ runny egg yolk, but I draw the line at raw egg whites! Should have been cooked better...The banchan here are delicious (I daresay they're even better than the bibimbop!). Service here is fantastic. Getting the check took a solid 10-15 minutes (waited a little too long), but besides that, our waiter was great. For those of you who don't want to make the trek all the way to the northside for authentic korean food, Ahjoomah's is probably your best bet! And you'll HANDS DOWN get better service than the places up north!

38.description: Never been to this place before. I've been craving Korean food awhile.I ordered Soontofu and dumpling filled for take out tonight.Soontofu was ok, although I wouldn't say it's the best...but the most problem food is the dumpling. I thought Korean style dumpling is Pan-Fried. Not deep-fried. I got the deep fried dumpling tonight.. Which for me was also ok, but they seem to fry the dumpling too much at a time. So I can't even eat those dumpling. It tasted really old and flat.. And very hard to bite!

51.description: The food is okay here, and a bit more expensive than the surrounding restaurants in Chinatown. The food was not so memorable. I had the ramyun soondubu and seafood pancake. They were okay. The interior is very clean and nice though. The service is very good and they are very attentive. But this is the only Korean restaurant thus far in Chinatown...so if I want my Korean food fix and I don't want to drive for more than 5 minutes, then I will order from here.

27.description: Absolutely coming back again today for Ssamgae Tang and Boodae Jun Gol. If you haven't gotten ready for winter, come for hot entrées! The only thing I might concern this time...the rice inside the chicken has not been fully cooked. Some parts were still freezing...

32.description: Sorry but it's bad. Just bad.We ordered the bulgogi and some kind of noodles with black bean paste. The bulgogi came out like meat has been steaming or has been frozen and thawed many times - it was sickening! The noodles literally was udon smothered in pureed black bean paste. Very disappointing.

54.description: I like this place, I don't have to travel up north for decent Korean food. They don't have much side dishes which I love about Korean places but I'll live....lol people under rated this place so I'm glad I came and checked it out myself. 4th time here and I'll come back if I'm craving for a nearby Korean place!

48.description: I had a really good experience here! Ahjoomahs Apron is cozy and clean. The side dishes were delicious, and there was a wide variety. The kimchi pajeon was sadly a little burnt. Our waitress was nice about it and offered to get us another serving of it. Nonetheless, it was a little disappointing. Besides the kimchi pajeon, the food was delicious. I especially liked the dwenjangjjigae. I will come back just for that.

44.description: Loving the food there!Got the bibimbap (stone) and we got the seafood pancakes! Very delicious. The server was very nice also!Atmosphere is wonderful and also, it's byob so who doesn't love that? The closest thing to Korean food at Chinatown! Especially if you're a commuter

24.description: I just rode bike here last Sunday afternoon about 3pm. There is not a lot people here, the noodle with soup is bad and the pancake is worse for a meal. But the fried chicken is good, this is the Korean fried chicken but not American way. I come from Asian this is good for me, the taste is more like the chicken is cook by a chief but not a waiter in the fast food restaurant like KFC or Popeyes.

7.description: Well, officially the worst Korean food i have ever had. And I promise I have had my great share of good Korean food in many places including Seoul, San Francisco, Chicago, Shanghai, Tokyo, Korean friends' homes, some real dives, etc. name it. Never so wtf.So sorry to say this because i really liked the servers and thought were nice, good, hard working people. I am sure kitchen staff are same good way too.Unfortunately the end result (i.e. the food) got to be as bad as it gets.Clean restaurant. Sorry and best wishes.

49.description: We went there around 1AM on Saturday.It was just so-so.Had Dduk Bbok Ki and Port+Kimchi combo i think.

40.description: I came to visit Chicago with a friend and after a few days, we craved a hearty Korean meal. I thought the decor was really nice and modern... Staff was okay, but not really all that friendly. I didn't expect much because our appetizer, kim mal e looked a bit unappetizing.. but it tasted okay. We ordered budae jungol which was surprisingly good. Maybe I'm too used to the good Korean food in NYC so I didn't find anything special about this place. It's great for late night since it's open until 2AM. If you're not familiar with the Korean scene in Chicago, I think this place will be just fine.

53.description: My bf and I came here last night at 12am cause we saw that they were open till 2am. We ordered the soon tofu but substituted the seafood for beef and omg it was good. We also ordered bulgogi which was delicious as well. Loved the staff here they were amazing. Definitely a great place to eat and drink.

30.description: This place is probably the easiest place to get real korean food in Chicago but is it the best? meh. I have tried various dishes here and it seems like a very easy restaurant to run. You can tell they use a lot of grocery store mixes and is not too special. However, it has a nice location right by the train and the food is good when you've got a craving

46.description: MUST TRY the spicy pork bulgogi!The chapche was sweet and delicious and maybe the best i have ever had. LOVE THIS PLACE

1.description: I come to this restaurant whenever I feel like getting some nice and hot Korean military pot. I didn't expect much because from what I remembered most authentic Korean restaurants are located somewhere up north of the city, but to my surprise, the Korean military pot they served here was very good! Their service was very good, too. The servers come many times to our table to offer water and make sure they provided everything we needed. They were always very friendly to our requests. The only reason I gave this restaurant a four-star review is bc of the inconsistency of taste among their other dishes. I've tried so many dishes, and most of them are so tasty that I wanted to come back more. But there have been some dishes I ordered that made me feel like they weren't authentic. My fix? I stick with my favorite military pot!

55.description: My mom and I traveled near Chicago, Illinois due to my brother having his Navy Recruit in Great Lakes. Since we live in koreatown, Los Angeles and were korean, Korean food was genuinely an easy access for us all the time. I yelped Korean food nearby and came across this place in Chinatown of Chicago. The interior of this restaurant was clean and almost had a comforting vibe. My mom got the seafood soon-tofu and I had ordered the kimchi jjigae. The food took a while longer than I had expected but I took it for to go to eat at the hotel we were staying. The workers were really kind and attentive.Each of their soup is so flavorful and soothing- I might say. You could automatically tell it's completely home-made and they really took their time with the broth. I wish this place was in Los Angeles!

9.description: I ordered delivery and it took one hour and 30min. When I called them they told me that the food is already out and seems like the delivery company they are using is late, but when I got the food it was still warm. I seems like they were trying to blame it on delivery guy for letting the food out late. Also, kimchi pancake was burned.

26.description: Bad. I came here with a friend and she warned me about coming here.  But I had a strong craving for korean and did not want to drive to Skokie. We did not like the food at all. I ordered the seafood pancake and the seafood soup. Both were very disappointing because there were very limited seafood. The pancake was burnt on the bottom and had no taste at all. The soup was so bad, I had two sips and asked for the check. All i heard that night was a bunch of I told you so. Next time, I'll do the drive to Skokie.

25.description: A nice hidden gem in chinatown, ahjoomah's apron continues to serve delicious Korean food. During this visit we got the Dolsot bimbimbap and a ramen that was "less spicy". I'd like to tell you that the kalbi meat was good, but I didn't have any, my partner ate all of it before I could get some. I'm assuming it was that delicious. The bimbimbap base was standard Korean, served in a sizzling cast iron bowl, lots of it. The ramen was still quite spicy. However when you poured the miso soup (came with the bimbimbap) it reduced the spiciness and added some extra flavor, turning the dish into one more tasty imo. Very surprised that the tables were filled on a Thursday night and they only had one server to start, although more showed up during the typical dinner rush hours. Service still good and quick.

12.description: When I'm craving Korean food, Ahjoomah's Apron does the trick. I was wary at first due to the reviews but, honestly, this satisfies my Korean craving.I've tried the DDUK BOKKI (Korean rice cake, fish cake, boiled egg, and vegetables stir-fried in sweet and tangy sauce) and thought it wasn't spicy enough, the sauce was too watery, and there wasn't enough rice cake.I've also tried the JJUKUMI BOKUM (stir fried webfoot octopus with vegetables in sweet and spicy sauce) and thought the sauce was way too sweet but just the right amount of spicy. It came with three banchans (side dishes) and rice.Overall, this isn't mom's cooking or the best Korean food but, in a pinch, it'll satisfy that craving. Until I find another Korean restaurant that does delivery, I'll keep coming back.

59.description: I go out of my way to go to this Korean restaurant in China(!?)town. The ambiance is simple but quiet and calm, the menu is fairly diverse, the food is fresh, delicious and prepared quickly, and so are the sides. I've found the prices to be reasonable given the amount of food provided. They have my all-time favorite Korean dish, dolseot bibimbap, for under $10. I have had an excellent experience here every time I've gone, with no complaints. I'm so glad this restaurant is here!

21.description: This place is pretty good, although it's run by Chinese and has a Chinese flare to it. There weren't too many veggie options for me, so I got the ramen, which isn't truly veggie either. I would go back to try the kimchi pancakes.

17.description: Best Korean food I have tasted in Chicago for a long time. I loved their bibimbap lunch and the service was excellent on a busy Friday noon- the two girls refilled my banchan (with huge portions! :) ) and also brought the egg on top back to the kitchen to recook. For the price, I was extremely stuffed- the only caveat was that the food was a bit oily.

10.description: A nice hidden gem in chinatown, ahjoomah's apron continues to serve delicious Korean food. During this visit we got the Dolsot bimbimbap and a ramen that was "less spicy". I'd like to tell you that the kalbi meat was good, but I didn't have any, my partner ate all of it before I could get some. I'm assuming it was that delicious. The bimbimbap base was standard Korean, served in a sizzling cast iron bowl, lots of it. The ramen was still quite spicy. However when you poured the miso soup (came with the bimbimbap) it reduced the spiciness and added some extra flavor, turning the dish into one more tasty imo. Very surprised that the tables were filled on a Thursday night and they only had one server to start, although more showed up during the typical dinner rush hours. Service still good and quick.

5.description: Man this place was Amazing. Went for the first time & i Will deff be going back for sure. My Food was EVERYTHING!! Ordered Bibimbap & my sis got Jjajangmyeon. Our Meals as well as their side dishes were both good. Service was good & place was Nice & Clean(Thats a Bonus)..love the korean style seating, the wooden benches. Im telling you the Food is Delicious & Prices are good for the amount of food they Serve(ANOTHER BONUS) Will be going back VERY SOON. *who's ever reading this* heyy maybe Ill see you there!!

3.description: While this is one of the only Korean restaurants in Chinatown I would recommend this spot. It could be on the pricier side but I would rather get my Korean fix here and pay a higher price than travel far north of in Chicago. I love this place especially when it is cold out and I want my stew fix!

35.description: The food is great, very traditional Korean cuisine.  They offer various dishes of appetizer for free.  The food amount and quality are both excellent.  The service is also very good.  We didn't finish eating at their closing hour but they waited for us patiently.I give it a four stars only because I want to try out more dishes on their menu.

19.description: Sorry but it's bad. Just bad.We ordered the bulgogi and some kind of noodles with black bean paste. The bulgogi came out like meat has been steaming or has been frozen and thawed many times - it was sickening! The noodles literally was udon smothered in pureed black bean paste. Very disappointing.

28.description: I was craving for some kalbi and i found this place on yelp. This is not a typical korwan bbq place.  The kalbi was done on a skillet and precooked for you in the kitchen.  So, if you want hot charcoal grilled kalbi then this is not the place.

45.description: One of my fav korean restraunts in chicago.. so happy they opened one in China town... I've been here many times.. each time trying something new... yayyayayayayayay!!  Everyone should try it.... BON APPETITE

33.description: Unfortunately, this restaurant really does Korean food a disservice. I love that they offer such a variety of korean food - but every time I go I am disappointed because nothing tastes good. It may taste fine to one who does not know much about Korean food or what it should taste like, but for example, the rice cake soup - was so salty and lacking in flavor. I also ordered the seafood scallion pancake - tasted like dough. the sujunggwa (cinnamon/ginger tea) was probably the nastiest thing i have ever tasted - it was super sour (meaning, it was probably too old) and it is one of my favorite dessert drinks. it's too bad.. Chicago just needs a good Korean restaurant..

43.description: The service we had wasn't the best. The time we came wasn't a whole lot of people. It took a while before we got to order our food and it took a little while which I did expect. During the last order of kalbi it took quite a while to get to the table. And it was very burnt. Then we told them and they took it back and this time returned it a little faster but by then we were just ready to take it to go since we were long finished with the meal. The main guy we had took a while in general so we had to ask the other waiters as well. It took a while to refill drinks too. I think the other waiter was better than ours in general and was faster to deal with things...maybe he was the subae to that the other person. The food wasn't the worst and wasn't the best either. The seafood pancake didn't taste like anything. The fish was slightly on the oily side. The kalbi was softer than the previous kalbi I had, the taste was a lot lighter also...I think Choga's Kalbi was the best, though on the pricey side. And it was a little less also at this place. I'm only giving my opinion from a place I can compare too but in general, the food isn't amazing or special. The design wasn't that good either inside. If you wanted something to eat that isnt so special but with okay food and prices then come here. I'm sure the service isn't that bad either but the waiter we had might not be feeling it or that our party was 8+ that his tip was assured.

2.description: It was decent. Jajangmyun was not bad.Little pricey.

18.description: We went with a big group of people. This place isn't idea for larger groups because the size of the restaurant is small. We all ordered some appetizers and entrees. The service was slow and we had to keep reminding the server for water refills. After around 30-45 minutes most people got served. I waited and entire hour and asked the server multiple times to check on my order. He insisted it was on its way. An hour later someone else came out to say the order was not in the system and they had to renter it. The food would take another 15 minutes. Because it was late in the afternoon I ended up taking my meal to go. Bottom line: food is decent, ambience is decent but service is terrible. Definitely not a quick spot for lunch so make sure you provide ample time for your meal if you choose to go here.

41.description: To start off, this place has a great ambiance! The restaurant was very clean and had pictures of Korean food hanging on the wall. I also liked the fact how they had bench styled seating instead of individual chairs. On top of the nice atmosphere, the food was great! It really felt like a homemade meal cooked by my mom! It was very authentic and they provided a nice variety of side dishes (banchans). If you enjoy spicy foods, I would strongly suggest the kimchi stew (jjigae). Overall, it was a great spot for lunch and I'll definitely be coming back!

52.description: Good service. Nice people. First time at a Korean restaurant so really no comparison. Jajangmyun was had a very strong flavor. Husband finished it. Bulgogi was flavorful and satisfying! Bibimbap was also good, sauce was ok. Got a big portion. Took some to go. Loved the space! Prices were decent. Would recommend to try.

50.description: Went to Ahjoomah's Apron on Monday with my friends and it was empty. We were the only customers there for a while. The waiter was nice. Kept coming back and checking up on us, asking if we needed anything. How sweet. The food was good too. I forgot the names to them because they're all Korean names written in English, but the food was delicious and the atmosphere was calming. The menu is kind of small though, as in not a lot of dishes to choose from, but overall I'm satisfied with everything.

4.description: It's my 2nd time at the restaurant and sadly, it was pretty disappointing, not as I remember from my first time here in the summer. My sister and I got to the place at around 5.15ish, there were about 3 or 4 tables so it wasn't very busy. We got seated quickly and ordered an appetizer, Tokbokki, and a noodle dish, Japchae, to share. It took the waitress a long time to bring out our little side dishes, which is a part of Korean restaurant that I really enjoy, so I was already a little annoyed (I was also starving!). Food wise, it was so sweet, to a point where we had to order a side of rice because we couldn't handle the sweetness. Don't get me wrong, both dishes were really flavorful, the rice cake was hot & spicy, but it was towards the sweeter side. A bonus is the portion is quite generous and shareable. My sister & I got really full and still left with a tiny bit of leftover. Service, though, was the worst. There were only 2 waitors, so I understand that dinner flow could pick up fast, but our waitress didn't once come back to check on us after bringing out our food. We had to get the other waitor's attention to order rice & more water. As we were ready to get the bill, we tried to make eye contact with her but she literally walked pass us so many times and didn't bother to stop by at all. It was unprofessional and very displeasing. I'm willing to give it another try, solely because I love Korean food too much, hopefully with better service and well seasoned dishes.

6.description: it is enough to have this only Korean restaurant in Chicago ! Perfect! !so great and really Korean

22.description: Love the food here, large portions!. My wife and I fell in love with there amazing soups. They have a soup with spam, bacon, sliced hotdogs, and kimchee that hits the spot on a cold Chicago day. If you get a chance order there dumplings also.

15.description: To start off, this place has a great ambiance! The restaurant was very clean and had pictures of Korean food hanging on the wall. I also liked the fact how they had bench styled seating instead of individual chairs. On top of the nice atmosphere, the food was great! It really felt like a homemade meal cooked by my mom! It was very authentic and they provided a nice variety of side dishes (banchans). If you enjoy spicy foods, I would strongly suggest the kimchi stew (jjigae). Overall, it was a great spot for lunch and I'll definitely be coming back!

57.description: I like the food here and usually get the bi bim bop. It hits the spot and the location is easy access compared to going all the way up north for legit Korean food. The staff is friendly as well, which always makes the visit great. However, I've heard that prices have increased, which were already pretty high compared to nearby restaurants. I think they should consider that given the Chinatown market.

20.description: best hangover soup! This place has really good soups

36.description: Really liked the ambiance of this restaurant. It reminded me of the little hole in the wall restaurants I've visited in Korea. Food was mediocre at best. The rice cake skewers were okay - the sauce was a little watery but sweet and sour and tangy. I think the same sauce was used to make the pork belly & kimchi with tofu because it had an overpowering sweet and sour flavor that did not mix well with the ingredients. There were huge chunks of carrots in the kalbi tang which I found interesting because I've never had kalbi tang with carrots in it.I can't say that this would be the place to go if you want authentic Korean food. Both taste and presentation seemed a bit experimental. But then again, I'm from California where you can find amazing Korean food at every corner.I would have given 2 stars for the food but the servers definitely made up for the disappointment. They were attentive, friendly and made the meal time a pleasant experience.

14.description: I get so full here. The Kimchi pancake could last for two meals, by is better when fresh off the pan. My partner got the pork bone soup and I got kimbap which was freshly made and sesame-oiled. Also recommend the vegetable mandu dumplings as appetizer. Everything was crazy fresh and spicy. Meal comes with about 6 free appetizers.The spicy squid and pork stirfry is chock full of vegetables and a fine balance of sweet, spicy and salty.So by and large all the dishes are solid except the ja jyang mein (black bean sauce noodles)... Even as a fermented bean dish it had a meatsauce-spaghetti taste and texture my partner and I didn't expect and it was a surprisingly mediocre letdown. Just avoid that dish.

28.description: To all owners of chinese restaurants who actually serve good shit:"Seriously, I get it. Most white people who come to your restaurant are turned off by intestines, spicy food, and anything that they've never tried at Panda Express. They want their crispy egg rolls, their reliable Happy Family, two fortune cookies at the end of their meal, and a big fat Buddha smiling at them. But not all of us are like this, so please, PLEASE stop it with the incredulous looks when I order pork belly dishes, and PLEASE stop dumbing-down the seasonings on my food. Sincerely yours, Scott."Maybe I should start wearing a Yelp headband when I go out to eat. I dunno. But seriously, the shit is getting old. I came here hoping for some tasty, authentic Szechuan food, and I was extremely underwhelmed.In all fairness, I give this place 2.5 stars, but I'm rounding down because of my disappointment factor. I've recently begun to learn about Szechuan cuisine, and the magic of those little tongue-numbing seed husks. I came here hoping for the goods. What they gave me were strange looks, the most boring hot-and-sour soup I've ever had, and some mediocre-at-best foods. I got the twice-cooked pork, sliced pork intestine appetizer, and a bowl of hot and sour soup. The hot and sour soup was generic. I understand that you can pretty much put ANYTHING in this soup- that there's no 'authentic' ingredient... but the soup itself was extremely underwhelming. No vinegar bite. No peppery snap. Nothing at all. I brought it home, ground up some peppercorns, dropped in a bit of black vinegar and some sliced ham steak, and BOOYAKA... much better.The sliced pig intestine appetizer was fine, except that it had absolutely NO spice to it, whatsoever. The taste of the meat and the infused oil was fine, but I'm sorry... I can't in good conscience say much more positive about it without the fieriness and tongue-tingling goodness that I've experienced elsewhere. Just didn't taste right. The twice-cooked pork was fine... a little on the salty side because of the fermented black beans (which I absolutely don't mind), but no spice to balance out the saltiness. This place made me sad. I really wanted to love it, and I was really hoping for a lot.I will say, though, that their menu is extensive, and is written in English. I've noticed that a lot of reviews said that they didn't have an English menu. Well... they do.

1.description: Yum! I've never had a disappointing meal here. Most recently, my friends and I came here for our pre-Chinese New Year's dinner, and it was delicious. We ordered a lot of food, where do I even start?One of my favorite things to order here, though, is the saliva (kou shui) chicken (ji). That sounds gross, doesn't it? That's the literal translation; a better translation is probably mouth-watering chicken. It's a cold appetizer with chicken chunks drowning in peanuts and chili oil. The fish hot pot is also a must-order here, as other Yelpers have mentioned. Unfortunately, I do think it's a bit pricey here. Cheng-du Impression in Lincoln Park (of all places, I know!) offers the same dish at a much more affordable price; I just wish they would finish with their renovations and re-open soon.I also really loved pickled mustard green and fish soup (suan cai yu). My mom made this when I was a kid, and the flavors really brought me back. I loved the sourness of the pickled mustard, coupled with slices of white fish and garnished with red peppers, green onions, and topped with some oil. I'm going to have to try to replicate this recipe at home now.The married couple's lung slices (fu qi fei pian) is delicious here as well. I know the names are strange, but trust me on this one. There's probably no lungs in this dish. It's thinly sliced beef tongue and tripe (as far as I can tell) marinated with chili oil. I mentioned a lot of chili oil in this review. There's lots of chili oil in Sichuan cuisine, so it's not for those who cannot handle spices.Can't stand spices? You can always order the Sichuan green beans or pea tip sprouts. The latter is a good dish to order for vegetarians, as there's no meat in it. But you can find these two dishes almost anywhere else in Chinatown.It's hard for me to name off all the dishes I enjoyed here because there's a lot. For our most recent trip here with 9 people and possibly 9-10 dishes altogether, our price was about $15 per person, including tip. It's definitely one of my favorite places for Sichuan Chinese food in Chicago.

9.description: If I had to choose between Lao Szechuan and Ma Gong La Po, I would definitely opt for the latter. (BUT, I'm giving both of them a 3-star review.) The Lao chains are meant for the tourist masses. All of the Lao menus are the same but placed under different restaurants. Tactful but distasteful. MGLP is a little more distinctive. MGLP has a few oddities. Whip out your magnifying glass and you still wouldn't be able to find a single spot with their store hours. Believe me, I've tried. Ask the waitress for a recommendation and she would find it offensive. She replied, "EVERYTHING on the menu is good." Calm down, I just wanted a second opinion. Ask for the check and she would stand by you as you write in the tip and total. It was Monday night at 9:30pm and there were three small tables dining in. We ordered the cumin roasted lamb with peppers, barbecued mushrooms with cumin, and a mini pot with shrimp, scallops, crab meat, and tofu. The lamb and mini pot were nicely done. The flavors were hitting the right spots. The mushrooms were among a long list of barbecue and skewer items. It was beyond normal. The mushrooms' natural flavors did not fuse with the cumin. We should've ordered the barbecue beef and chicken wing skewers instead.

29.description: My husband and I came here for dinner around 8 pm on Friday. It was busy, but we were seated right away. We ordered the fish that everyone else orders that seems to be the thing to get here. We also ordered the spicy lamb in chili oil. We also got an order of the shredded pancake. That shredded pancake was AMAZING! everything was delicious and the food was tasty. The portions were huge. We definitely ordered too much food. They also have a bakery case in the front so next time I will have to try a pastry. I also liked that they gave us a cup of their complimentary grass jelly drink. Yum! However, their menu is in Chinese with only a few items written in English, so if you can't speak Chinese and don't have any Chinese speaking friends, it might be tricky. Luckily we speak Chinese. Our waitress was very friendly though and gave us good suggestions. We will be back. I want to try their dumplings and the green bean pancakes. Based on the shredded pancake, they rock at making dough!

23.description: We ordered the fish dish which the waitress highly recommended. We asked for a small fish cause we were only 2 people. But we were told the small fish have been sold out and the smallest one they have is 4 lbs. Fine, we took the 4 lbs fish and also ordered 4 veggies on the side. The taste is just so so, not as good as I expected. But the most important thing is, I don't think the fish is 4 lbs. I cook fish at least once a week at home. I know how big a 4 lbs should be. The one we had here is definitely smaller than a 4 lbs fish I bought from any supermarket. The other thing which annoys me a lot is the girl who's selling the ice tea. I told her at least 3 times I don't like ice tea at all, but she didn't want to give up. She was so aggressive and kept talking talking talking for a few minutes. It's like a bunch of flies around my ears. I wish I had earpiece! At the end, she got pissed off cause I still didn't want to order the ice tea. What a terrible experience!!!I will never ever go back there again!

5.description: The best Sichuan food I have in Chicago. The waitresses are very nice and the food is super super good.
