31.description: It's been a while since I have experienced something truly different in Chinatown. Ma Gong La Po provides an authentic northern style Chinese meal that is outside of the standard Canto fare found all over the rest of Chinatown. Most of the restaurants in Chinatown I feel are "sold-out", appealing to the tourist masses *ahem Lao Bejing/Szechuan/Shanghai/YouJu* (Gross). They over-emphasize on quantity over quality. Which is why I really enjoyed both my visits to this new establishment. This place opened not that long ago. I've been here twice within a month, and the food has been excellent both times. I came here with a few friends each time and we ordered more than we can handle. Item's I have tried1. Lamb and vegetables cooked in hot oil - This in my opinion is hands-down the best thing. Silky smooth lamb cooked in their home made hot spices. The kicker are the vegetables found underneathe which has absorbed all the flavor of the spices. There is lettuce, bean sprouts, onions, celery - the combination is perfect and flawlessly tasty!2. Fu-qi-fei-pian - Beef and beef parts marinated in hot spices topped with cilantro. How can you complain? Its delicious and tastes better than Ed's and Spring World. 3. Vegetable/Melon cooked in garlic sauce - It is cooked very lightly and sauteed with garlic. Not overwhelmingly salty and goes perfectly with the lamb and fish. Just as a vegetable dish should be, it doesn't over power from the meats. Just healthily cooked veggies. 4. xiao long bao - Average5. Whole fish cooked in hot oil - This is the restaurants trademark. If you come on a busy night, 9/10 tables will have ordered this. The fish is cooked in their home made spices and you can throw in veggies, noodles, etc. The whole time you are eating the fish is sitting on top of a portable stove so it is steaming the whole time. Fish doesn't taste fishy at all as well. The last time I went it was quite cool outside, but it was pretty warm inside. Add that to eating some scolding spicy food and I was drenched in sweat while eating since they did not have the AC on. However, no complaints because I feel like it really adds to the experience. If I was dining at a authentic restaurant in China, it would be the same. I really enjoyed this place and there really hasnt been anything new in Chinatown for a long time so this is a must-try!One side note though, their menu is only in Chinese. lol

25.description: Only here you will have a traditional cooking of Chinese "Shui Zhu Yu". The pepper mixed with boiling fish taste heaven:-)

12.description: 服务很一般，环境很一般，就是菜还可以。进去之后等人带或者自己找地方坐都行，反正也没人带你。就一个男的态度还好一点，会服务你，其他的一个推一个。等人点喝的都快半小时了，渴死人。点个喝的还没说完人就走了，莫名其妙的，然后就继续等吧，连菜牌都不拿给你就来点菜了，感觉特别搞笑。我很少发脾气，这次真的很恶心！很失望！

21.description: Authentic MaLaTang (which is Beijing street food, meat, fish, vegitables cooked in a spicy broth). They also have terrific grilled lamb on a stick, just a snack for a buck each. The fresh fish and grilled vegetables are out of this wold good...but for spice lovers only.

16.description: I think the food is very tasty and hot pot is the best in Chicago. It is definitely the priceless and yummy Chinese food in the old town.

17.description: The hot pot is tasty and the price is reasonable!! The service is also nice~I would like to go there and try something different next time.

10.description: I was pleasantly surprised by how much I like the food here given the upsurge in the number of Sichuan restaurants in the city.  The menu is poorly translated and fairly nondescript, but all the dishes we ordered were solid.   The beef with dried bamboo had a strong licorice flavor - my guess from star anise - and plenty of spice.  It's definitely an acquired taste and for some the flavor profile may be too strong.  The cabbage salad (labeled "cauliflower" on the menu) was fresh and spicy.  Finally, the tofu smothered in a light pork gravy was a nice complement to the spices from the other dishes.  The place is a bit of a dive, but the food is definitely worth coming for.

11.description: Wow.  This place is legit. I'm pretty picky with my Chinese food (from living there for 5 years) and Ma Gong La Po did not disappoint.I came with my friend who comes often so I let her do the ordering.  We got the fish hot pot which is by far the most popular dish here.  It is sort of a cross between huo guo and shui zhu yu.   You pick your fish which comes whole in some nice oily broth and then add a bunch of sides to dump in.  The fish was good and the sides were about average... what I can say about a plate of spinach?We also got some kou shui ji which was fantastic.  Oh and make sure you try the hand pulled scallion pancake... it is perfect for dipping.  We washed everything down with some sour plum juice. What a night.

26.description: very typical Szechuan food. I really like it. I guess it might be the most typical Szechuan dishes in Chinatown (according to my limited experience). And the cooking style is very Chinese. I know several restaurants make Szechuan dishes by some Hot Pot sauce or other special sauce, instead of using chili and peppers. The taste of food in this place is not like that which is cooked by special sauces.However, here is the thing I *really* do not like. The woman there (not sure she is the owner or a waitress) strongly recommended the Szechuan style grill fish and the boiled spicy fish. She said those are the things I should not miss. After I refused to order them for at least 3 times, she took back her smile and became indifferent and cold. (Btw, the fish is a little expensive. It's 8-10 dollars per pound, and at that time I visited the smallest one is 3.3 pounds.)Another thing is that their air conditioner does not work well (actually I doubt the AC was on at that time). It is very hot inside and the waiters were using a fan.

27.description: Yum, but it is not an easy meal to eat.  I would compare it to hot pot but a lot more flavor.  Basically order the fish with veggies on the side and you get to throw in the veggies any time.  The flavor is mala sechwan (Sp ?) and will give the same flavor to what ever veggies are in season. We got spinach, bok choy and the ones who hates veggies ate it with gusto.  The fish itself was fried before going into the sauce and at a good texture,  there was also alot of interaction between the eaters to make it a fun meal.  I would stay away from their specialty ice teas, althought not bad,  too overpriced.  One of the more interesting dinners I've had in Chinatown as of late.  Can't wait for a cold winters day to go back.

0.description: A good place if you are not afraid of spicy food. This is a better place to go if you want to have decent Sichuan food. It can be a little expensive, but the food tastes very good.

20.description: If I had to choose between Lao Szechuan and Ma Gong La Po, I would definitely opt for the latter. (BUT, I'm giving both of them a 3-star review.) The Lao chains are meant for the tourist masses. All of the Lao menus are the same but placed under different restaurants. Tactful but distasteful. MGLP is a little more distinctive. MGLP has a few oddities. Whip out your magnifying glass and you still wouldn't be able to find a single spot with their store hours. Believe me, I've tried. Ask the waitress for a recommendation and she would find it offensive. She replied, "EVERYTHING on the menu is good." Calm down, I just wanted a second opinion. Ask for the check and she would stand by you as you write in the tip and total. It was Monday night at 9:30pm and there were three small tables dining in. We ordered the cumin roasted lamb with peppers, barbecued mushrooms with cumin, and a mini pot with shrimp, scallops, crab meat, and tofu. The lamb and mini pot were nicely done. The flavors were hitting the right spots. The mushrooms were among a long list of barbecue and skewer items. It was beyond normal. The mushrooms' natural flavors did not fuse with the cumin. We should've ordered the barbecue beef and chicken wing skewers instead.

Most white people who come to your restaurant are turned off by intestines, spicy food, and anything that they've never tried at Panda Express. They want their crispy egg rolls, their reliable Happy Family, two fortune cookies at the end of their meal, and a big fat Buddha smiling at them. Sincerely yours, Scott."Maybe I should start wearing a Yelp headband when I go out to eat. I dunno. But seriously, the shit is getting old. I came here hoping for some tasty, authentic Szechuan food, and I was extremely underwhelmed.In all fairness, I give this place 2.5 stars, but I'm rounding down because of my disappointment factor. I've recently begun to learn about Szechuan cuisine, and the magic of those little tongue-numbing seed husks. I came here hoping for the goods. What they gave me were strange looks, the most boring hot-and-sour soup I've ever had, and some mediocre-at-best foods. I got the twice-cooked pork, sliced pork intestine appetizer, and a bowl of hot and sour soup. The hot and sour soup was generic. I understand that you can pretty much put ANYTHING in this soup- that there's no 'authentic' ingredient... but the soup itself was extremely underwhelming. No vinegar bite. No peppery snap. Nothing at all. I brought it home, ground up some peppercorns, dropped in a bit of black vinegar and some sliced ham steak, and BOOYAKA... much better.The sliced pig intestine appetizer was fine, except that it had absolutely NO spice to it, whatsoever. The taste of the meat and the infused oil was fine, but I'm sorry... I can't in good conscience say much more positive about it without the fieriness and tongue-tingling goodness that I've experienced elsewhere. Just didn't taste right. The twice-cooked pork was fine... a little on the salty side because of the fermented black beans (which I absolutely don't mind), but no spice to balance out the saltiness. This place made me sad. I really wanted to love it, and I was really hoping for a lot.I will say, though, that their menu is extensive, and is written in English. I've noticed that a lot of reviews said that they didn't have an English menu. Well... they do.

2.description: This is a Szechuan restaurant, meaning you can expect the majority of dishes to be spicy. We were definitely eating up a sweat! Usually, restaurants try to skimp on the meat in la zhi ji (diced chicken with hot peppers). At this establishment, the chicken to hot pepper ratio was much better. That was probably one of my favorite dishes of the night, along with the bear paw tofu. Even the lamb skewers were amazing, and I hate lamb! The decor was reminiscent of the traditional Chinese (in America) restaurants I grew up frequenting with my family and family friends - there was something comforting about that. When my friend first mentioned this hole in the wall in old china town, I was skeptical. We ordered about 7 dishes for our group of 5, and each dish managed to impress. I've gotta say, it's been a while since I've had stand out Chinese food, and being Taiwanese, I've eaten plenty of Chinese food in my day. Ma Gong La Po is now one of my favorites in Chinatown which says a lot.

32.description: Recently opened. Their menu doesnt even have English. Chinese only. They give you a discount if you pay cash and speak Chinese essentially. Food is good but you have to enjoy very spicy and oily food. The restaurant's new and packed with guests. It's right next to Triple Crown. They lack staff so service in getting more water or tea is incredibly slow. Prices end up being higher than the average Chinatown restaurant, but worth a try since it looks like business is pretty good so far.

18.description: I really like the food. It is authentic Chinese style and it did remind me of my hometown. The food is definitely worth the price and I liked every single dish they served.

13.description: First, I all for Chinatown! I just hate the Tony Hu franchise taking over everything. So good thing there's this little place. Honestly, it doesn't seem very clean, but dang... It's delicious. Boiling fish!!!

4.description: Food is just ok. Service of one waitress is very rude!!! We ordered more than we need. So we ask very politely whether it is ok to cancel a couple of dishes, to prevent waste. We are ok if the waitress say sorry it is already in process, or even simply we cannot cancel it. She said: what is the matter with you, if you cannot finish, take it home! very loudly in front of other customers......

24.description: new favorite sichuan restaurant in chicago. finally, something that's authentically spicy.

6.description: My new favorite hot pot place! The atmosphere reminds me of Chengdu.  The smell of spicy food in the air, nice space that isn't too big and just the right amount of cleanliness. Service could be better but that's a given for all Chinese joints.

22.description: If you want authentic Sichuan cuisine, this is the place. If you want Americanized Chinese food, you'll have better luck else where. I've been here several times, and unlike most Chinatown restaurants from what I've observed the clientele is almost exclusively Chinese nationals.All of the Chicago Sichuan restaurants I've tried so far, Ma Gong La Po's Shui Zhu Yu (Sichuan boiled fish) is by far not only the best but also the most authentic.

15.description: Poor quality together with poor environment. The fried fish was not what it supposed to be. Not recommended

7.description: Went in here upon learning that Lao Ma La had closed.  It's a solid Szechuan hot pot place, and the people were extremely friendly.  We got the all-you-can-eat and were definitely satisfied.  Didn't try the bakery items this time, but there was a constant procession of people in and out of the door just to buy them so I'm guessing they're pretty good also.

8.description: Be careful ordering the Ma la fish dishes.  They charge by the pound, but they actually serve much less poundage of fish than u pay for.  We ordered 2.5 lbs of tialipa, but when it came out, instead of 1 big 2.5 lb fish, they served 3 small fishes, with each fish only being a head plus ONE side of the fish body, with the other side of the fish body missing.  Rip off!

30.description: Very authentic spicy Chinese food where menu is in almost all Chinese.  I got some dishes recommended to me by a friend and the waitress.  I had a spicy lamb stir fry dish with spices and peppers, it was good.  Also had a shredded pancaked which was very flaky and crispy.  The whole fish in oil with vegetables, noodles, and tofu wasn't as impressive as I hoped it would be.  The sauce was very spicy and numbing.  The fish had lots of small bones, so watch out!Glad I tried this place out, but it might be too authentic for me.  As others have mentioned, it is also pricier here than I would expect of a restaurant in Chinatown.

3.description: Abandon lao szechuan!Yushiang eggplant and boiled spicy fish are done the RIGHT WAY here. The eggplant was slightly crispy and not mushy on the inside, though it could be just a bit spicier.Everything got to the table in 10 minutes.Saw other customers ordering spicy hotpot and roasted items too. The fried green beans were extremely fragrant.

14.description: yum! I don't usually go for such spicy foods, but this was a pleasant surprise. We ordered the tilapia, which came in a huge tray of soup so you can add other stuff in, like a hotpot. One thing to remember is eat this quickly, otherwise the fish will melt into the soup, and everything will be too spicy. Also had a variety of kebobs, thousand year egg & tofu, and some cold spicy chicken dish (forgot the name, sorry!). Everything had complex, in-your-face flavors, so if you like your food strong & flavorful, you'll love this place. The place looked a bit rundown, but don't let that stop you. Better go with a friend that reads Chinese because the kebob menu is Chinese-only.

58.description: Service is ok. Food is pretty good. I had the beef spicy noodle. Not the best I have had so far but it is ok

56.description: I found this place to only be okay. I came here with a friend yesterday, and we loved the atmosphere.I ordered the beef brisket. The sauce was only okay, but the fat on the meat was ridiculous. Their quality of meat is poor.It also took 20 minutes for our server to get us our check after we finished eating. Service is definitely not that great.

29.description: beef noodle soup is overpowered by excessive bean paste (dou4 ban4 jiang4).stir fried beef stripe with ginger and scallion was full of soy sauce gravyfish stomach with garlic chive flower is tasty, attributed to dry shrimp and tint salty fish chunks.service is so so, as waiters cared more about speed and table turnarounds than serving the patrons.

42.description: Solid food for a fair price - if you steer away from the classic Americanized dishes like "orange chicken," there are some pretty authentic things on the menu.

23.description: Chose this place for our breakfast. We got a table within 5 minutes. Ordered some basic Chinese foods and soups. Food came out pretty fast but they were a bit salty. I loved their fried buns.. Definitely come back here.

47.description: perfect drunk food. the spot is open till 4am, say wha?!?! also the food is priced fairly low! the line can get line because space is limited and its the place to go because the service is quick.

8.description: Good behaviorAlways the same good tasteDeliciousGood for kids Sometime they are so full of peopleSome time the food take long time to prepareThey can improve WC.

31.description: Good food and really great prices.Love the intestines.No complaints.

34.description: Pretty decent Chinese food. Didn't have a chance to explore the menu as we popped in for a quick bite before a drive back to IA and we were pleasantly astounded by the stir-fry beef rice noodle! Authentic and comparable to those found on the streets of Hong Kong! Will definitely be back to have a go at the rest of the menu!

16.description: Dropped by for late sunday night dinner. Ive been here multiple times now and their quality and taste is consistent. If you are confused and overwhelmed seeing a lot of chinese restuarants around, and dont know which place to choose, this is worth a shot/ safe and good bet. This time, we ordered two dishes: fried rice noodles with veggies and tofu (for my friend of course) , and I ordered orange chicken. I liked my dish and my friend LOVED the customized veggie noodles with tofu (substituted for beef). So yes, this is a vegeterian friendly place which is nice. Clean and artistically modern ambience, well dressed staff wearing cute waist coats with ChiTown logo. Had a nice time.

13.description: Another reviewer said cheaper than Joy Yee and good. I say 1/2 the Joy Yee price and 2/3 the quality...great noodle breakfast menu

11.description: It's been a while since I've been here. They are newly renovated which is weird since it wasn't that old anyways and they wait until everything is run down before renovating in Chinatown!The food is solid.  In the latest trip, I had wonton noodle soup, side of Chinese broccoli and an order of fish filet with onions and ginger.  The wontons and soup is a little light on flavor. Noodles are snappy. Broth could use some more depth.  This is the only critique I would have of the place.The broccoli was good. Not over cooked like many places and sparing in the oyster sauce.The fish filet was the best nice dark rich sauce and freshly cooked fish at the right firmness.Before they used have Macau style pork belly but I guess they don't carry that anymore.This place is clean and fairly neat. Very modern and follows the form of newer HK cafes.  Refreshing for a Chinatown restaurant.  They are related to Minghin next door which is also an outstanding restaurant.Most people like this place either because they're not Chinese and it's one of the few clean places - or they like the late hours. I think the food is pretty good too. And it's affordable with many entrees priced less than $10!

39.description: Can't go wrong with this spot! It's open super late and definitely hits the spot after a long night out! Servers are tentative and the food comes out so fast that it's almost like they read your mind and cook the food to be ready 5 minutes after you order! Crab Rangoon here is awesome! Can't got wrong with Pan fried egg noodles with beef! Love the thousand island shrimp!

37.description: Growing up in Southeast Asia somewhat gives me the ability to say I have high expectations when it comes to Asian food and flavor. This place is by far the best place I can go to and it never  disappoints me. The service is good, the ambiance is somewhat family friendly but who cares about all that when you are getting amazing food with an affordable price! Can't beat that! Strongly suggest their Japanese tofu with salt and pepper, and sizzling beef in pepper sauce. Eat your heart out here!

0.description: Late night?  Wrecked from drinking all night?  Come through to CHI CAFE, open til 5 or 6am.  Many of times this place has made my night complete.  Come in here, sit next to every drunk asian person in Chicago, order Salt & Pepper Pork, and an Almond milk tea (I don't think it's actually milk tea, but they give me the same thing every time and its delicious).I've never been here sober, so I can't speak to how good it is normally.

38.description: Incredibly rude staff- came here with some friends for dessert, and to split a bottle of sake (BYOB is great, don't get me wrong). Had 3 different people ask for all of our ID's, slammed silver ware, basically threw glasses of water at us- just awful. Food wasn't spectacular either. Grass Jelly wasn't fresh and Japanese Tofu was WAY over salted, as in completely inedible. Just awful, and have no desire to return- especially disappointing since Chi Cafe has been recommended by many friends that grew up in Chinatown.

51.description: My current goal is to try more of the restaurants in Chinatown: I come down here all the time, but always end up going to the same places. My friend suggested Chi Cafe, and we were not disappointed! The food was great for the money: it was about $15/person and we ordered 2 dishes, 1 appetizer, milk tea, and congee (to go). Definitely will be back!

27.description: Food always good, we always have to end up here if we can't think of anything to eat. Servers are very nice and food comes out quickly. It's a small place and sometime you will sit next to random people but if you're cool with that. You'll be fine. Give this place a try if you're in the area!

32.description: The big pluses for this place are:1. Open until real late into the night to satisfy any late night cravings.2. Large selection (maybe too large?).3. Cool vibe, they're always doing a pretty good job for their decor.If we're out at night, Chi Cafe is definitely one of our go-to places to grab a bite and kick it with friends.

54.description: Should be called MK-Cafe. Twas aite. Dinner menu = meh. Breakfast/lunch looks good. Mayhaps a do-over in the future.Would be 5-stars just for the drinks menu, authentic HK drinks and well done.But trust, the dinner was meh.

48.description: Shared three dishes with two friends. We got the smoked duck, Chinese broccoli and a beef dish. I really liked the smoked duck. Uniquely prepared and delicious. Also, the portions were really large for it being an appetizer. The other dishes were good as well. It's a cute restaurant, nicely decorated and clean. There was a short wait for Sunday lunch. Great value and good service. I would definitely visit again.

44.description: I expected this place to be three stars but I guess it's easy to impress tourist and first timers (as I was at first). After visiting this place several occasions I think I have grounds to create a review. I am not a fan of the staff but whatever ...it's Chinatown. Not expecting the Ritz. They have an extensive menu so you're bound to find something you like. Some of their dishes can be greasy so beware.

24.description: This restaurant is located in new China Town square.  They remodeled a year ago and the place looks great.We usually come for the fried man-tou buns, baby clams with black bean sauce, noodle dishes, fish in sweet sake sauce, and the long list of drinks.The wait staff is always speedy and we've learned that you gotta wave at them haha.  As for the kitchen staff, they are awesome in the kitchen but need to step it up and wear hair-nets because we've found hair in our orders (yucky).  This restaurant is great for cheap but delicious eat!

7.description: This restaurant is located in new China Town square.  They remodeled a year ago and the place looks great.We usually come for the fried man-tou buns, baby clams with black bean sauce, noodle dishes, fish in sweet sake sauce, and the long list of drinks.The wait staff is always speedy and we've learned that you gotta wave at them haha.  As for the kitchen staff, they are awesome in the kitchen but need to step it up and wear hair-nets because we've found hair in our orders (yucky).  This restaurant is great for cheap but delicious eat!

49.description: Many choices, clean and comfortable environment.Hong Kong style milk tea is very authentic. And they open till 4am.

40.description: easily one of the best Chinese food places I've ever eaten at. my sister and I go there almost every single Saturday night. i order beef satakay along with tomato beef on rice every single time & there wasn't a time I was satisfied. the food is always steaming hot and the service is phenomenal. they don't continuously bug you & the food is out within 10-15 minutes. would totally recommend.

53.description: Open late af. So much damn fun going onto this place and just ordering random great food. Hell, just have them start bringing you food till your satisfied. You'll leave haply as clam.

30.description: I'm pretty disappointed in this place. I'm giving it two stars because yes, it was cheap, the food was good, and the waiter was nice, but it was pretty disgusting. I went last night with five friends and one of them had a hair in their food, another had a hair in their water, and I had so many floaties in my water I kind of felt like throwing up. I had already drank half the glass before noticing! It looked like there was old food in my cup or something. We did all try each other's dishes and if you STILL want to go there after what you read above, we all agreed that the best dishes were the orange chicken and the chicken corn and rice (not sure if that's the name). Good luck eating here, I won't be risking it again.

46.description: It's been a while since I've been here. They are newly renovated which is weird since it wasn't that old anyways and they wait until everything is run down before renovating in Chinatown!The food is solid.  In the latest trip, I had wonton noodle soup, side of Chinese broccoli and an order of fish filet with onions and ginger.  The wontons and soup is a little light on flavor. Noodles are snappy. Broth could use some more depth.  This is the only critique I would have of the place.The broccoli was good. Not over cooked like many places and sparing in the oyster sauce.The fish filet was the best nice dark rich sauce and freshly cooked fish at the right firmness.Before they used have Macau style pork belly but I guess they don't carry that anymore.This place is clean and fairly neat. Very modern and follows the form of newer HK cafes.  Refreshing for a Chinatown restaurant.  They are related to Minghin next door which is also an outstanding restaurant.Most people like this place either because they're not Chinese and it's one of the few clean places - or they like the late hours. I think the food is pretty good too. And it's affordable with many entrees priced less than $10!

1.description: No, will not be back.Maybe I just had all the wrong food here but the flavor and taste is sub par for a restaurant that is situation in the heart of chinatown. Ordered the wonton noodle soup, the wontons were TERRIBLE, premade, the noodle had this really weird taste to it. The 2 pieces of iceberg lettuce in the soup was super unappetizing.Pan fried noodle in soy sauce, good but small portion and FILLED with onions and scallion. I understand that it was just a bit over $4 but come on. Everything here price wise is pretty cheap, you can get smoothie for $2.75 and milk tea for less than $2. Ambiance is pretty clean and nice but those stool chairs are not very comfortable because you cannot lean back. Also the biggest pet peeve I had was the drawers of chopsticks and spoon that people are raving about, my waiter pulled out my chopstick from the drawer and he held the ends where I would pick up the food with his bare hands. That is very sanitary, if it weren't a restaurant in Chinatown I'd totally be bewildered and asked for a new pair. This restaurant is tucked away inside an alley so you can't see it easily if you are on the main street. Less than mediocre food, will not be back.

55.description: For Friday and Saturday, late night, after hours, quick meals, Chi Cafe, hands down, beats any 24-hour diner or greasy spoon you may feel the need to visit. Easily located in Chinatown, with ample pre-dawn parking, you can't go wrong with your money well-spent for food that is delicious and wide in selection. The  atmosphere ranges from youth to old-timers. This place can't be ignored nor forgotten. A perfect spot to share food and good times with friends and family alike, the service is considerate and fast. The decor is hip yet functional. The restrooms are clean. The menu selection is perfect, not too little, not overwhelming, not ordinary, nor bizarre. The best little culinary delight for your palette in the neighborhood. Go and find yourself pleasantly surprised and well-fed. Enjoy!

9.description: Cheap prices and generous portions. Could be a bit more adventurous with flavor. The bubble tea is pretty good. And they're open late. Service was great. Very courteous staff.

26.description: I have eaten at this location three times. The first two times were fine. I usually order the chicken over rice with Portuguese sauce. It really taste good. This last time approximately a week ago, my boyfriend and I ordered the honey garlic wings, the chicken over rice and the pork tenderloin something. Everything tasted really good but hours later I was violently ill and vomiting the rest of the night. I gave the restaurant 3 stars because it could have just me catching a bug because my boyfriend was fine after eating. The food taste great and always hot..just be careful i guess.

25.description: I have been trying to find a new Chinese place so of course headed to yelp and this place had really good reviews.  Unfortunately my experience was not like others.I got the orange chicken, Egg Roll, and Wonton soup.  First of the Orange chicken was the only decent tasting thing, but it was not Orange Chicken.  I don't know if they made the wrong item but it was more of a teriyaki glaze.  It was still good, but not what I ordered. I thought the egg roll was veggie, but it was pork.  That's fine, but it tasted terrible.  Just mushed up pork the consistency of re-fried beans.  Lastly the wonton soup.  I love the to go container it came in - wontons on top and soup on the bottom.  But, as soon as I opened it there was a god awful smell.  I tasted it and something was definitely wrong with the  broth.  I couldn't stomach to try the wontons.I threw everything out minus the not Orange Chicken and could only eat about half of that before tossing the rest.  I did love the fortune cookie though.I wanted to love the food, but was left disappointed.  My search for a good Chinese restaurant continues.

12.description: I used to LOVE chi cafe. But they've really gone down in service and quality since their renovation. It looks much more spacious and gorgeous to sit in. Open concept seating. They are quick... but maybe now, it's to a fault. I brought a friend, who hasn't had much authentic Chinese fare, so we needed a little longer time before ordering. Servers are antsy to get your order. Once they've got your order, all they want to do is drop off your food, and don't want to come back for more.  It's actually become quite insincere.Food is still good, but I'd say stick with staples. I still say salt and pepper anything will win here. I do love the almond drink, whether it's served hot or cold.  The soup base has become bland. A lot of items have become more slacking.Crab rangoon. yes. but weirdly, some weren't filled completely. i had an air pocket of empty space in two  of the 4. but delicious. maybe a fluke.Shrimp wonton noodle soup. Wontons yes. Soup base no. bland, salty, boring. Theegg  noodles are meh and become redundant.Shrimp dumpling appetizer. yes.Salt and pepper anything. a favorite. pork chops are good, but the seafood combo is everything. you can get shrimp with or without the shell.I wanted a veggie option and ordered some mushrooms with chinese okra. i love okra, but this was all sour like bittermelon!! the server never came back. at the end of the meal,(since he was AWOL for 30 minutes),  he asked if everything was okay. I was apologetic, but explained I couldn't touch more than a bite. He said, "oh, okay." Didn't take it off our bill, didn't offer a replacement. WHY ASK, IF YOU REALLY DON"T CARE. so we took it out of his tip.AND! There was a HAIR ON OUR PLATE of salt n pepper porkchop. It's in the bottom right of the picture.  We tried forgiving it, since it was on the edge and didn't touch any of the food. But the garbage service put a bad taste in our mouth.  I loved this place and raved about it for years. But now, I'd say think twice.

59.description: Really solid noodle soups. Good portions, super cheap and satisfying. Didn't care for the pepper beef all that much only because I feel like they overused the cornstarch/ slurry, making the sauce too thick for my liking. Really easy parking because it's located in a plaza; food comes out really fast. I prefer a tad more veggies in my soup as well, but I'm nitpicking. Broths taste better than more expensive noodle houses.  Definitely hits the spot in the cold Chi fall weather.

21.description: Weird meat.  Next door at a huge line so we thought we would try it.  Don't recommend.

17.description: Chi Cafe was a good and inexpensive dinner in Chinatown. We brought a bottle of wine and the waiter promptly brought us plastic cups for it. We started with the salt and pepper squid and it was great. I ordered Singapore noodle, which is usually served with thin vermicelli noodles, but here the noodle were large and wide and I don't think it was as good that way. Also ordered a dish with shrimp, chicken, and eggplant, which was pretty good.My friend also insisted on ordering beef intestines. The waiter cautioned against it, but my friend wanted to try it. After bringing the intestines to the table the waiter watched my friend try it and hate it, which I thought was hilarious.

10.description: Eat here. Get the Salt and Pepper Tofu (Japanese Style). Skip the egg rolls.Get the sizzling beef and hot and sour soup.They're open until 4AM.The service could be better but it wasn't horrible. The guy's bathroom, I've heard, wasn't bad. The girl's, however... meh. I'm gonna give them the benefit of the doubt and assume it was that way because there were no girls working during the late hours of the night we were there. But still... that should be better. Way better.

5.description: I ate lunch here today and it reminded that despite eating here about once a month, I haven't reviewed it!Atmosphere: Sit down restaurant Asian diner with a very modern interior. Think bright white, sharp lines, booths.Service: The food comes out lightning fast!Food: Extensive Chinese offering. For the most part, I've liked everything I've tried. And yes, I've been here a few times at 3 am in the morning and I guarantee you this is the best food you're going get at that hour!Price: Most everything is under $10.Overall: There's nothing to not like about this place. It's fast, cheap, and pretty good tasting. And I believe it's open until 4 am most every day! Ohhh... and it delivers! :D

3.description: My UIC students constantly remind me of their love for Chi Cafe. They describe it as a cheaper, more authentic Joy Yee with a bit more emphasis on Chinese cuisine and not the whole array of Asia.I haven't dined in yet, but I've ordered from them twice. Both times, it was super hard to get them on the landline since I am sure they are constantly busy. Each time, I ordered two of my favorite Cantonese style dishes, and so far, it's been above average, but still misses the mark on some parts. Allow me to explain:* Salt & Pepper Squid - I love me some calamari, and Chi Cafe does it well. For $9, you get a generous amount that resembles what I expect to get from a Chinese restaurant, Well done, and definitely ask for more pepper because it's not enough!* Beef Brisket w/ Egg Noodle Soup - The soup was bland as hell surprisingly, but the egg noodles and beef brisket itself was great! This one barely made it pass average, but with the low price tag, I could hardly complain.* Squid In Thousand Island Sauce - Looks like tteok bukki if anything, but was surprisingly delicious! They prepared this well with the sauce not completely overpowering the dish, and you still had good amounts of squid to eat. Garnished with two pieces of bok choy* Salt & Pepper Pork Chops - Okay... this is one of my favorite Cantonese dishes that is not hard to execute. Chi Cafe unfortunately disappointed me with these. Flavors were not there, pork chops were chewy as hell. I was upset by these! Definitely pass.So overall, better than average, but still really depends on the actual dish. However, the low prices here pulls it forward and I appreciate that Chi Cafe does not try to make you pay for more than you should. Til the next take out opportunity!

35.description: We usually get dinner delivered from this place and they do an amazing job of delivering on time even at 3 am. We have never had to wait for more than 30 mins. The food is always fresh and they do a great job of following special instructions. I have tried quite a few items on their chicken beef and Fish menu most recently had the kung pao shrimp.

19.description: Wow. Just awful.  Wow.  Salt and pepper Chicken Wings the size of a hummingbird ' s wings,  had a sweet taste without salt or pepper. Special fried rice was basically white rice with peas and carrots and a couple of slivers of chicken and pork. And very many at that. Just awful. Oh. the delivery was fast so there's that. I hate giving bad reviews but Will never order again.

28.description: My UIC students constantly remind me of their love for Chi Cafe. They describe it as a cheaper, more authentic Joy Yee with a bit more emphasis on Chinese cuisine and not the whole array of Asia.I haven't dined in yet, but I've ordered from them twice. Both times, it was super hard to get them on the landline since I am sure they are constantly busy. Each time, I ordered two of my favorite Cantonese style dishes, and so far, it's been above average, but still misses the mark on some parts. Allow me to explain:* Salt & Pepper Squid - I love me some calamari, and Chi Cafe does it well. For $9, you get a generous amount that resembles what I expect to get from a Chinese restaurant, Well done, and definitely ask for more pepper because it's not enough!* Beef Brisket w/ Egg Noodle Soup - The soup was bland as hell surprisingly, but the egg noodles and beef brisket itself was great! This one barely made it pass average, but with the low price tag, I could hardly complain.* Squid In Thousand Island Sauce - Looks like tteok bukki if anything, but was surprisingly delicious! They prepared this well with the sauce not completely overpowering the dish, and you still had good amounts of squid to eat. Garnished with two pieces of bok choy* Salt & Pepper Pork Chops - Okay... this is one of my favorite Cantonese dishes that is not hard to execute. Chi Cafe unfortunately disappointed me with these. Flavors were not there, pork chops were chewy as hell. I was upset by these! Definitely pass.So overall, better than average, but still really depends on the actual dish. However, the low prices here pulls it forward and I appreciate that Chi Cafe does not try to make you pay for more than you should. Til the next take out opportunity!

45.description: My favorite in Chinatown, which doesn't come lightly. Great food, great price, open as late as you could possible want Chinese food. Def go for the sweet saki fish, you will not regret!!

33.description: LOVE this place! It's my number one Chinatown restaurant if I'm looking for a quick bowl of noodle soup or some yummy Asian comfort food. This place has a big menu. Lots of Hong Kong cafe style dishes. Everything is YUM. AND it's open late night!Ambience is nice. They recently updated the interior. Service is prompt and casual. Early afternoon specials are very reasonably priced. For just a few bucks you can get congee, noodle soup, or noodle dish plus your choice of hot beverage.Definitely recommend family style. You can order a bunch and sample everything! Some favorites:-SATAY BEEF RICE NOODLE SOUP!! (or your choice of noodle). SO good here. Have yet to find another restaurant that makes the satay beef so flavorful and delicious! (Trust me I've tried.)-sizzling beef with black pepper sauce-yung chow fried rice-deep fried man tou (deep fried dough with a delicious sweet dipping sauce)-crab rangoon-lean pork with preserved egg congee

43.description: WAS. A fan of this place and a regular. But today I ordered take out from them the same thing I always get except they sent fish and this weird sauce that tasted like there was alcohol in it. Oh and this time (only time ever) there is no receipt in my bag. Officially feel pissed off and ripped off and the food tasted like shit. WASNT WHAT I ORDERED.  Never ordering from there again. Sucks because I always used to leave a good tip. Last time I ever do that.

2.description: Very fast service!!!! Excellent because I was starvingVegetarians: several options considering its Chinese food. I got the veggie stir fry which was very good! Crunchy noodles that are softened with the gravy served with the veggies.They also have several veggie dishes but since they're pricey I would split them with friends. It doesn't make sense to order a veggie dish to eat as a side dish to whatever else you're eating because of the prices.

18.description: I have frequented this place many times with my wife whenever we are in the Chinatown area and we usually order the Sizzling Beef bathed in sweet sake sauce. The place is usually bustling at all times during business hours. Lots of tea variety and many food choices that is usually not available within your typical Chinese takeout restaurant. Service is prompt and wait times for your order are usually within 15 minutes or less. Menu prices are reasonable and not quite as expensive as Joy Yee.

41.description: This place is amazing. Chinese food is good dependent on the region. Don't get a rice dish if they specialize in noodles or don't get get dumplings if they are good at rice dishes. This place had awesome noodle dishes for an extremely affordable price. Get the noodles and rice cakes. Also, the service is great. I see some reviews that said the service was bad but all the people are white. Just know this is a Chinese restraint run by Chinese people in china town. It's not fair to expect the same type of service you would get run by a white person. You are dealing with different cultures so keep that in mind

52.description: Really yummy chinese food in Chicago, their congee hits the spot for a late bite after you've been dancing for a few hours.Get there quick because it fills up fast.

50.description: Real Chinese! Everything was genuinely scrumptious.. The menu itself is so grand you'd know this place understands variety of taste buds! The hours are amazing and so is the food. What we loved from all we ordered were sizzling pork chops, wonton soup and noodles! And the mango tapioca was out of the world!!

4.description: The big pluses for this place are:1. Open until real late into the night to satisfy any late night cravings.2. Large selection (maybe too large?).3. Cool vibe, they're always doing a pretty good job for their decor.If we're out at night, Chi Cafe is definitely one of our go-to places to grab a bite and kick it with friends.

6.description: I've recently become a regular here and I've come to realize how bad their service is. I wouldn't recommend any of their soups as their broth is an acquired taste. They are fast for the most part once you order but they can drag hardcore to tend to you initially and when you ask for your check. Not to mention they are not the friendliest and you can tell they seriously hate their lives working here. The crab Rangoon is what has me coming back :)

22.description: I've recently become a regular here and I've come to realize how bad their service is. I wouldn't recommend any of their soups as their broth is an acquired taste. They are fast for the most part once you order but they can drag hardcore to tend to you initially and when you ask for your check. Not to mention they are not the friendliest and you can tell they seriously hate their lives working here. The crab Rangoon is what has me coming back :)

15.description: Since this was the only Chinese restaurant I had while in Chicago, I can't really determine whether it is 5-star worthy for Chicago (although it would definitely be "as good as it gets" if it were located back in Richmond, VA). I was exploring Chinatown with a friend and we decided to have lunch here. The restaurant is moderately-sized, and looks like it was recently renovated (much sleeker than I expect most Chinese restaurants to be). Service was decent, and most waiters had better English than I am accustomed to as well. The menu was EXTENSIVE, which got me so excited. I wish I could come back more often. Everything is pretty reasonably priced as well. We settled on a stir-fried intestine dish, clams in a hotpot Chaozhou-style, rice noodle rolls with beef, and deep fried smelts.We had no wait to get seated, and food came out quickly as well. Open late. Would definitely return if I am ever back in Chicago chinatown! I wish we had this caliber/variety of Chinese in Richmond. =\

57.description: Me & my friends' late night go to! I never order anything except for the salt & pepper squid and sizzling beef w/ sweet saki sauce~The only problem with the beef is that it's kind if a strange texture (I saw it mentioned in another earlier review *chewy/rubbery texture*) and the onion to beef ratio haha. We're always like did we order onions with beef or beef with onions? I don't really like seafood and definitely had no desire to eat squid at that, but this is the only kind I'll eat.There was only one bad experience I had with the squid where it was super overcooked and I couldn't even bite through it because it was so hard, but it's been perfect the last two times I've been there~

20.description: 4.5 Nicely renovated, opens late, delivers late, inexpensive, and decent food. I have no complaints!

36.description: Seriously love this place!  Their salt and pepper tofu with jalapeños, garlic, and scallions is so good!  There are two options, though, and I've had both.  One is cubed firm tofu and the other is round and soft.  I prefer the soft tofu, mainly because I can mash it up and get a little with each bite I mixed with side of steamed veggies. I used to live in the south loop and always ordered delivery.  It was always crazy fast and crazy good!!!  Whenever I am in the area I stop for carry out.  Thanks chi cafe!

14.description: 4.5 Nicely renovated, opens late, delivers late, inexpensive, and decent food. I have no complaints!

3.description: This is a great place for buying herbs for making Chinese herbal tea. The woman who runs this store also does consultation - but unlike other herbal practitioners in this area - you can buy the herbs without being a patient. I go here regularly for an herbal tea I make using Reishi, Goji, Scizandra Berry, Licorice root, Asparagus root, etc. She seems to be well organized, is pleasant and speaks English well. Also her business is CASH ONLY.

1.description: This is a hidden gem in a couple ways. First, another Yelper mentioned that this store is unlisted in phone books -- true -- and there's no website. It also looks like absolutely nothing from the outside, just some cramped little store. That's sooooo not true, though! They manage to fit seemingly every Chinese medicinal herb ever made into this shop. I asked for yan hu suo, and the woman behind the counter knew exactly where it was. Of course they had it, they have everything, and I was able to choose between multiple selections -- they had roots, powder, and tablets.  The East wall of the store is full of dried roots, plants, and all kinds of medicinal teas, stacked floor to ceiling. This is where most of the natural remedies seemed to be. The front counter has more "modern" pre-packaged tablets, pills, and capsules in small colorful boxes. The woman who works there is so kind and helpful. She has a very pleasant personality and was happy to talk about the medicine I was buying, what it was good for, and how much to prepare for particular ailments. Since I was trying this herb for the first time, she cut open a pre-packaged bag for me and repacked a smaller amount so I could try it out. It was totally unnecessary, but that's just what this place is like. Recommended if you want to pick up some TCM supplies in Chinatown.

2.description: A great place to buy traditional Chinese medicine. I used to come here when I was in the University of Chicago nearly 20 years ago, back when the shop owner's little daughter stayed in the shop with mom in the shop after school. I have been ordering medicine from them periodically since I left Chicago so many years later. The service is excellent, the price is good. Highly recommended!

0.description: I took my grandmother to two other stores, but only Bark Lee Tong had what she needed.  Also, my grandmother can be very high maintenance, but the herbalist remained very nice and helpful.FYI, this is not a fancy-looking store, but that's Chinatown.  Some of the best places, be it restaurants or herbal shops, focus on high product quality rather than aesthetics/BS.

4.description: Talk about off the grid. As far as phone directories go, this place doesn't exist. Yet there they are. Selling ginseng, tea and herbs. Probably you can find magic cures for ailments here, and then it'll be gone when you try to go back.

58.description: posters missed a key point: untranslated/off-the-menus items that are posted on the walls. Currently it's featuring some "mountain mushroom" stir fried with a variety of meats. There is also a pickled mustard with pork intestine over rice and some other varieties of beef/fish (which i can't seem to recall right now :( :( )Also of note, under chow mein/chow fun/vermicelli, the noodle of choice can be substituted literally into anything, much like any of the plats over rice items, ie, Rice Vermicelli Singapore Style can be made with Chow Fun, etc. Between Mei Wei Zhi Jia and Wing Chan, a lonely Chinaman can dine for days at $5/nite.

56.description: This place is definitely a hole-in-the-wall restaurant, but it is my favorite in Chinatown.  The inside dining section is kinda small, with about 8-10 tables that look a little greasy still from the previous customers.  I am completely unoriginal and I always order the same things:Silky egg with either shrimp or beefBeef with bitter melonFish fillet with vegetablesYou get a huge plate of food served over rice for about $5 (or noodles for a little more money).  The meals can be split easily between 2 people.  Or if you are a big eater, you will definitely be pleased with the size of the meal.  I cannot emphasize enough how much I love this place.  This place has the ultimate "soul food" of Chinese food.  It would also be great as late-night/drunk food, but sadly, this place closes at 8pm.Also, cash only.

29.description: Oh Gourmet...what would I do without you and your deliciously cheap rice boxes?I'm so glad my friends introduced to me this place! I've recommended it to so many people looking for cheap eats. The restaurant itself is more of a take out place, but there are a few chairs and tables inside if you'd like to dine in, but it's kind of dirty and the ground is sometimes sticky. I usually prefer to order take out.On to the food...Gourmet is known for their ridiculously cheap rice boxes. They also sell xiao long bao, BBQ meats, etc. For just about $5, you are able to get a large box of food that usually lasts me two meals. They have all different types of rice boxes from chicken to pork to beef, but I usually get the minced beef with a fried egg on top - so good! They also have some of the best fried chicken wings I've had in Chinatown! These wings have to be battered in crack - that's how good they are! I've also tried the xiao long bao here, but the skins are too thick and there is rarely any soup inside, so avoid them at all costs. The douhua (tofu dessert) here is really good and super fresh - they make it fresh daily, and it's only a dollar something for a large container. Make sure you get here early for this because they sell out pretty fast.Because it's located in the old part of Chinatown, parking can be a bit tricky, but there is street parking - just watch out for all those people who think they're invincible that walk out in the middle of the streets or behind your car as you're parking!  Overall, it's a great joint to grab a quick lunch at rock-bottom prices.

42.description: If you're looking for fast, cheap, yummy Chinese take-out, this is the spot! I have fond childhood memories of my mother bringing me here while we waited for our laundry to finish.However, I do not recommend dining in unless you just want a quick and dirty bite. The tables are not very clean...it's kinda like McDonald's. People don't wipe up after themselves. I recommend Tomato & Beef over rice if you're a tomato lover like me. You get a big take-out box FILLED with the goodness, and it's only $5! Lasts me 2 meals. I also recommend the Tofu Dessert =) It's simple but sweet, and refreshing. Just be sure to mix the syrup from the bottom in with the rest of the tofu or it won't be sweet till the very bottom. Best way to experience Gourmet is to call half an hour ahead, order (their English has gotten better!), then swing by and pick it up.

23.description: Pros: Cheap and tasty foodCons: Not so clean dine-in area--This place is known for its tasty and ridiculously cheap food. In all of Chinatown, this place makes the best Deep Fried Salt and Pepper Shrimp. I personally like the Onion Oil Chicken, Deep Fried Shrimp, Deep Fried Smelts, and Deep Fried Fish Filet.

47.description: Wow, just wow. I give this place 5 star because of their incomparable fried chicken wings . Chinese fried chicken wings is chicken wings but Gourmet foods' chicken wings are exceptional!Cheap, fast, and convenient. By far the best chinese take-out in the city of Chicago! 5 STARS!

8.description: If you are looking for the best bang for your buck, not many places beat gourmet foods. For $5, they give you Chipotle "bowl" quantity (maybe more) amount of food. I got the salt and pepper chicken, and like the reviews said below, if you order anything salt and pepper (pork, chicken, etc., etc.) you cannot go wrong. It was my first time getting salt and pepper chicken, following the suggestions below, and I am an instant fan. This is a true hole-in-the-wall in chinatown, so expect limited English from the staff. But the food is worth a try. *Tips: Cash only

31.description: $5.25 Lunch box will fuel you through the day! Enjoy

34.description: Make no mistake this place is small, the floor is sticky, they reluctantly speak English, their water is kept in a big Gatorade cooler they occasionally fill with ice , and they don't take too kindly to questions--but hot damn is the food good. Their portions are huge, served hot and quickly in a container they have to staple closed due to overflow of deliciousness. Beyond their giant serving sizes their prices are low. 5 bucks in cash will get you a meal and all the Gatorade-cooler water you can drink. They only take cash handed to them over their dead animal display, but nothing beats their eats!

16.description: Disclaimer: my review is based on take out that was eaten about 30 min after we ordered it. The beau and I ordered some rice boxes to go since we were leaving Chicago and going on the road. I ordered the baked fried rice (seafood with vegetables and tomato sauce) and he ordered a pork and rice dish. It's a pretty good price for the amount of food - I was able to split mine up into 3 different meals and it cost $6.50 total.The tomato sauce ended up being pretty ketchup-y and sweet, making it delicious at first but hard to finish. The fried rice also wasn't too special - the seafood that was inside was shrimp. We also got some BBQ pork to go, and that was pretty good, but not the best we've had. Overall, good price but average food based on our one-tiem experience...

13.description: My family usually goes here to buy carry - out dinner. But we are going much less now. The food isn't good anymore. The food is gross some of the time. Sometimes, the food from another dish is messed up into the wrong dish.

11.description: In Cantonese, this place is pronounced "May may jee gah."Gourmet is authentic, delicious and beloved by Chinatown locals.Some favorite orders where you can't go wrong:1) Minced Beef with Green Peas Over Rice (comes with a pan-fried egg)       -Variation A: ask to add jalapenos.       -Variation B: ask for the ketchup version2) Deep fried chicken wings ($1/each)3) Fish Fillet with Chinese Broccoli Over Rice4) Salt & Pepper Pork Chops Over Rice5) Basically anything labelled "salt & pepper"... (chicken, squid, shrimp etc.) GET IT!The place is small and unassuming from the outside... and yes, the exterior looks very dated.  The service is a little brusque.  They may seem a little rude but they're not singling you out so don't take it personally.  In fact, it mimics old-school Hong Kong and it's a hole-in-the-wall place... the cheeky, cut-to-the-chase service is kind of (pleasantly) expected.  What they lack in decor/pleasantries they make up for in their delicious food and speedy service.I love this place BECAUSE their food alone has carried them so far.  My family and I have been coming here for years.  There's a lot of competition right along Wentworth and their location is kind of tucked behind Chinatown's main road.  Regardless... if you come to Chinatown and want good, authentic food, hustle on over to Gourmet. It's about $5 per rice box.Skip dining in.  Most people get take-out and you will see rice boxes stacked/bundled and lined up across the back table behind the counter.  Costumers will pop in, pay and hurry off in the matter of seconds.You come to Gourmet because you like the food.  You don't need to shovel out $$$ for it to be authentic and satisfying.  $5 and you're covered for the day, and will have leftovers for tomorrow (maybe).  That's what I love about Chinatown.

39.description: My rating is strictly for the soy "pudding".  I stop by here every time I'm in Chinatown.  It's the best in Chicago and made fresh constantly throughout the day.  For $1.50 each, it's the best dessert you can have in Chinatown without worrying about the calories.  Pick some up before your meal because Gourmet Food closes early.  8:00 p.m., I believe.I

37.description: Friday 11/04/2011. 7:00pmCame here after reading Janet's review.You order and pay for the food at the front counter.They do NOT accept CREDIT CARDS, bring your cash.I ordered the BBQ combo over rice and won ton soup with noodle.The roast pork was good but the Soya Chicken was just ok, however; I would never order the Won Ton soup with noodle again. The Won Ton was okay but the noodle was way too starchy for me.Warning: the dining area is dirty, the tables are sticky and it is just dirty. If you are thinking of trying their food, get it to go. Pro: the prices are very affordable, you will find many items under $5.00 , great place for struggling college student or those of us still looking for work. Your money will go a long way here.Portions: they give you enough, you will be full.I will visit again if I am in the area and short of cash.

0.description: Hidden gem from the main strip of Chinatown-Wentworth Ave, most people who live here go here for their traditional rice boxes. I heard about this place and had to see for myself. They have a vast amount of dishes to choose from, I stuck with what I know and have eaten before. I proceed to the counter and of course, waited for my turn to be served. I ordered a beef and rice with extra gravy, she took my money (avg dish here is $5 - $8) and told me it will take 10 minutes. If you eat here on premise, you get a cup of hot soup. If you take out, you get nothing but the dish you ordered. Nothing fancy here, just exactly what you order. Plenty of metered parking in front.

38.description: Hmmm.....thought I reviewed this place before. Anyways, they can be hit or miss with the food sometimes. Sometimes it's bland tasting.Still a great spot for cheap eats!

51.description: I grew up eating this place when the parents were too tired to cook and wanted some rice boxes and it never disappointed.  This is THE place in Chinatown for delicious rice boxes.  Its not as great as it used to be since the owners changed and the food tastes slightly different and slightly smaller portions (hence not a 5 star) but its still one of the best.  My favorites are the minced green onion and ginger chicken (OMG - just the sauce is to die for - ask for extra sauce and its worth the extra dollar they may charge), minced beef with peas (not as delicious as it was before) and pickled veggies with beef (this place has the REAL pickled veggies that actually tastes sour).  Pretty much all their rice boxes are good - they also have good fried rice noodles and chicken wings.  And its super cheap with big portions - you can share a rice box with someone else.. so you end up paying less than 3 bucks... or just "splurge" and eat the whole thing yourself.

27.description: I always order the same thing, beef and chinese broccoli chow mein. It is my all time favorite, My gf's favorite is their salt and peppered pork chop. We always order the same thing but there are plenty of other options. For this price, you can't beat it. It is about $5- $6 per dish and it will fill you up, This is one of those hole in the wall places that look shady but its really good. This restaurant has been around ever since I can remember and I grew up getting carry out from here.

32.description: I am 28, and I have been eating at Gourmet Food since I was 5 years old.  This hole-in-the-wall is an institution in Chicago's Chinatown.  The food is cheap.  You can get a rice box for around $5.  It mainly serves local residents, but tourists are also sometimes found ordering food here.  I presume these are the more adventurous tourists who are curious and eager to learn about local culture because almost all of the items on the menu are authentic Chinese dishes.  Non-Chinese speakers may have a little bit of difficulty communicating with the cashiers, but they know enough basic English to figure out your order.  Although I have been eating here all my life, I have to say things have not been the same since the original owner sold the restaurant around 10 years ago.  Management has changed here a few times over the last decade, and the current owners are not operating the restaurant in a way that is consistent with its legacy.  The cashiers are not very friendly and the food is not as good as it once was.  Nonetheless, it is still a restaurant worth visiting for its history and once great, but now just mediocre, authentic Chinese rice boxes for a very affordable price.  For all that, your $5 will not go to waste.

54.description: When my friend Jess, who is from Hong Kong, was living in Chicago, she named this as the most authentic Chinese restaurant in the city. Which may not be what you're looking for. It is a hole in the wall with an odd name and all the ambience of a bus station, but the food is affordable and, if you go with someone who speaks Cantonese and knows what to order, you'll get hit with some very unfamiliar and intriguing flavors and textures. For less than twenty dollars we got a ridiculous amount of food; it looked like we were going to feed eight people. When Jess visits, we plan to go again, and this time I'll try to remember or note what we ordered. I remember a nice sweet and tangy pork dish, some smoked and chopped chicken (chopped up with the bones still in, very strange presentation if you're unfamiliar), and for desert there was a custardy bean soup. I couldn't get with that, but the rest of it was delicious, satisfying and an adventure for Western palates that are used to General Tso's and potstickers.And what a great name! It's not misleading so much as random; it has virtually nothing you would associate with the actual restaurant experience. I am in favor of randomness like this. It keeps you on your toes.

48.description: Gourmet is a place that was introduced to me by my girlfriend, who is of chinese descent.  I am a big fan of authentic chinese food. Although, sometimes I do have a craving for orange chicken.  As Joe Koy says "Orange chicken is delcious."  Anyways, Gourmet is a the typical hole in the wall greasy-spoon place that you either love or hate.  In this case, I love it.  You can get a huge styra-foam plate full of noodles (or rice) topped with a nice heaping pile of seafood or any other meat and vegetable combination on their menu.  All for under $5!  The food comes out piping hot and is spot on with all the flavors of authentic chinese home cooking.  This is one of those places that has a special place in peoples' heart because it invokes that highly reserved phrase, "this is how my mom makes it."

44.description: Excellent authentic Chinese food! I would highly recommend their black bean sauce and green pepper chow fun (flat noodle). That dish, along with others are really tasty. Plus, on weekends they have fun rolls (a dim sum dish) of every kind! We order out here several times a week. Gourmet Food (aka in Chinese May May Zi Ga) has become THE place to go for great tasting, cheap priced food!

24.description: I am giving it 3 stars because it took them 30 minutes to make my Fried Rice Noodles w/ Beef. Total was $6.05 and it was pretty good. I really like their WonTon Noodles because their WonTon taste different than other cafes. It has a very special taste to it. I would skip the congee because they give you very very little meat and preserved egg. It's super dice small.They have other good food and price is decent.

7.description: Terrible attitude and dirty circumstance. Feeling tired and in health for whole day after had breakfast there!!

49.description: This is still our current (and long time) favorite place for Chinatown carry-out.  Great value and taste at about $5 per dish.  A couple of our favorites are Singaporean noodles, spicy salt and pepper pork, and fish fillet with veggies.

40.description: I've been to Chinatown so many times but had never come to this restaurant. This may be my new go-to place for cheap chinese food!! They seemed to sell a lot of different foods that most other Chinese restaurants in the area dont sell.  First, they sell roasted duck. DELICIOUS! And it was not overly fatty (as most roasted ducks can be).  We also got the roasted chicken (I didnt try it but my friend did and loves it).  We also got the garlic eggplant which was awesome (I love eggplant).  For dessert we had the soft tofu (slight sweet and served warm).  All this food for about $23! Not too shabby. I'm definitely coming back to try their other dishes! Prices looked to be about $5.

53.description: Though the restaurant may have a contradicting restaurant name (Gourmet? I think not!), the food here is delicious. It is one of the best places to get a cheap, filling, and delicious rice box that is devoid of the usual oil drenched foods. The foods are light, but quite delicious. My favorite is the bittermelon and beef rice box and the eggplant and chicken rice box. The rice box prices range from $3.75 to $4.50 and are huge portions for the price. Also the orders are placed and cooked very quickly even though the place may be crowded with customers. This restaurant deserves 5 stars for the food (taste, quality, price), but much lower for the environment. To sum up the environment it looks like an old diner-esque atmosphere with the floors, water dispenser and everything else of questionable sanitary quality (although the table tops seem to be quite clean). In other words I would recommend take out!   Their Funn Roll is one of the best in Chinatown. Funn Roll is basically like a rice noodle crepe with various ingredients inside like beef and shrimp served with soy sauce. Their Funn Rolls are only offered on the weekends.Interesting Note - When the weather gets cold sticky rice hits the spot. Gourmet Food makes sticky rice year round, but on days when the weather is extremely hot they do not make this oh so yummy treat. When the weather gets warmer nothing is better than soy bean pudding. Soy bean pudding is like tofu, but much softer and silkier and served with a side of sugar syrup to be poured over.

30.description: I work near Chinatown and I get my lunch there frequently.This place is so-so, and the price is reasonable.I would have given it a 3 stars, but a dead bug in my congee kill it for meI would avoid this place completely, but my co-workers choose this place and we order lunch in a group. They don't seen to mind, and I'm to lazy to go pick up lunch.So, I say avoid the congee.

46.description: This will be the first review of Gourmet Food in 2010.  So don't let the older reviews scare you.  My family has been getting food from here for about a year now, and it has rarely disappointed.We used to get food from here when I was a kid, but mysteriously stopped.  The earlier reviews might have pinpointed the issue.  Changing owners and chefs gives restaurant rating scales an inaccurate view of quality, especially in Chinatown.Everything is good and fresh.  And it's currently one of the best in Chinatown for carryout.  I swear they lace their eggplant with crack.

1.description: Okay. Once you walk into this place, you might want to discredit me as a yelper. BUT, you need to understand this place. They're not trying to win you over with fancy decorations or modern design like places like Sweet Station attempt to. I've been coming here since I was 5 and I seriously think the Chinese character cutouts they hang on the wall are the same ones I saw as a kid. What makes up for the lack of show, is the food. Rice boxes to-go are the name of the game. $5 for delicious and nostalgic Chinese food is unbeatable. The food is really, really good. I'm guessing I've eaten more than a billion Chinese meals in my life, and this is the place to go to keep me wanting for more. Personal favorites are salt and pepper shrimp and ginger and scallion chicken. Make sure to get some of their hot sauce to go, too. I'm putting my reputation on the line for this one.

55.description: Wow Gourmet has let me down big time, I heard that they changed owners hip and MAN, the food changed with changing the ownership.We ordered the usually fish over rice with some vegetables, mapo tofu and some chow mein noodles. The Fish was frozen, the tofu spelled spoiled. It was incredibly a let down for me and my family. It was $20 down the drain. VERY SAD!

9.description: Ordered "pork with eggplant" and had a really hard time finding any pork.. The stuff in "xiaolongbao" are questionable, hope it's  diarrhea free..Not sure if I will come back

26.description: I think the only reason why this place gets high ratings is because everyone reviews it based on fond childhood memories.  It was a dump when I was 5 years old, after  23 years later and several changes of ownership, still a dump.  Only now it's frequented by local drunks and mice.  And if you notice a smell before walking in, it's because 23rd street also happens to be an alley.

25.description: I've been eating from this place for as long as I can remember. It has been recently remodeled so the interior looks a lot nicer and modern. But it's still a very basic and no frills restaurant that serves everything you could ever want in Chinese food. They added a BBQ section, so now you can order duck, roasted pork, etc. It's cheap, authentic and oh so good. Plus, the serve my favorite, sweet tofu and red beans and coconut.

12.description: Always fast, efficient, and delicious at a very affordable price. They have a massive menu and you can even try asking for stuff not written on the menu or like add/substitute ingredients of an item. There were times that they did forget the substitution and still collected for it, so try to confirm before you leave the restaurant with your food.I wish they had later hours and take credit cards, though. They can use a little modernization, but why fix something that works, right? It's a pretty well oiled machine as is, and is a chinatown staple with lots of homey, comfort food flavors.

59.description: Pretty much grew up on this place since it is perfect for starving student budget.  Most rice boxes can feed 2 people for lunch and comes with soup for about $5.  The place is not much to look at but good for take home meal any day. Recommendations:Spicy Salt and Pepper Pork ChopsSingapore NoodlesTomato Beef on RiceCurry Beef BrisketChicken Wings (appetizer)Jar Jar (dessert)Grass Jelly (summer dessert)Soy Milk Jelly (dessert) - made fresh daily

21.description: In Cantonese, this place is pronounced "May may jee gah."Gourmet is authentic, delicious and beloved by Chinatown locals.Some favorite orders where you can't go wrong:1) Minced Beef with Green Peas Over Rice (comes with a pan-fried egg)       -Variation A: ask to add jalapenos.       -Variation B: ask for the ketchup version2) Deep fried chicken wings ($1/each)3) Fish Fillet with Chinese Broccoli Over Rice4) Salt & Pepper Pork Chops Over Rice5) Basically anything labelled "salt & pepper"... (chicken, squid, shrimp etc.) GET IT!The place is small and unassuming from the outside... and yes, the exterior looks very dated.  The service is a little brusque.  They may seem a little rude but they're not singling you out so don't take it personally.  In fact, it mimics old-school Hong Kong and it's a hole-in-the-wall place... the cheeky, cut-to-the-chase service is kind of (pleasantly) expected.  What they lack in decor/pleasantries they make up for in their delicious food and speedy service.I love this place BECAUSE their food alone has carried them so far.  My family and I have been coming here for years.  There's a lot of competition right along Wentworth and their location is kind of tucked behind Chinatown's main road.  Regardless... if you come to Chinatown and want good, authentic food, hustle on over to Gourmet. It's about $5 per rice box.Skip dining in.  Most people get take-out and you will see rice boxes stacked/bundled and lined up across the back table behind the counter.  Costumers will pop in, pay and hurry off in the matter of seconds.You come to Gourmet because you like the food.  You don't need to shovel out $$$ for it to be authentic and satisfying.  $5 and you're covered for the day, and will have leftovers for tomorrow (maybe).  That's what I love about Chinatown.

17.description: I've been eating from this place for as long as I can remember. It has been recently remodeled so the interior looks a lot nicer and modern. But it's still a very basic and no frills restaurant that serves everything you could ever want in Chinese food. They added a BBQ section, so now you can order duck, roasted pork, etc. It's cheap, authentic and oh so good. Plus, the serve my favorite, sweet tofu and red beans and coconut.

10.description: My husband was in the mood for congee so we figured we'd try this place out. Keep in mind this place is cash only and kind of divey. We couldn't find a spot, so I got out and placed an order for carryout. It was around 11 on Sunday and there was a short line, but it was moving quickly. Most customers appear to do carryout since the seating area is pretty small. Luckily I speak decent Chinese, but they seemed to speak some English so even if you don't speak Chinese, you should be fine. I ordered a large beef congee, 1 peanut mochi, 1 mantou (steamed bread roll), half of a roasted duck, 1 cold soymilk, 1 fan tuan (salty rice roll) and the price came out to about 17 bucks. Pretty cheap. Everything tasted fine. I wasn't blown away by anything, but it was cheap and fast.

5.description: I come here for the Soybean Pudding...aka Taho. It's cheap and oh so delish!

3.description: Normally this would get a 3-star review for the food alone, however because of the big variety, fast speed, and incredible prices this gets bumped up to 4 (this is cheaper than fast food and as such shouldn't be compared to restaurants twice its price per dish).The restaurant itself is fairly small and busy -- but run very efficiently where they move a line as quickly as somewhere like KFC. The menu offers many types of Chinese cuisine including Cantonese, Szechuan, Mandarin, Shanghai, Hong Kong, etc. Everything is offered from dim sum to baked race to Chinese barbeque to buns to noodle soups to Taiwanese Breakfast to curry. The food itself isn't spectacular but is of higher quality than expected for this price (especially the rice). Think of it like a food-court-plus. The flavor combinations you'd expect out of food court restaurants but in bigger portions and generally prepared decently. Nothing here that will win any culinary awards though.I'd consider returning to this place if I'm in the area although there's other well-priced options like Chi Cafe that do offer a nicer decor and better ingredients for only a few more dollars. But if you need to feed a large group on a budget, this is definitely your place to go.

35.description: My friends were visiting from Minnesota and we decided to check out Chinatown for some fun browsing and nosh.  I had been to Sweet Station before and really enjoyed it, but decided to try something new.  Upon yelp recommendation we headed over to Gourmet Food.  Gourmet?  More like Gour-nay.We ordered excitedly and sat to wait for our lunch.  The crab rangoon came out first.  Typical to rangoon, they were crispy, cheese-filled, faux-crab laden pockets of joy.  Then my egg and bitter melon dish over rice.  I wanted to try something I never had before, and the dish did not disappoint.  It was like a giant scramble of egg and what seemed like an especially tart green pepper.  Two bites in (and waiting on my friends' entrees) the aural assault began.Hack.Hack hack.Hack hack hack hack hack hack.  Sneeze.
