It was a triple lucky day as it was the day of the dragon, in the month of the dragon, in the year of the dragon. I was shopping for my birthday party and I happen to have been born in a dragon year, so she and I both celebrated with a lot of well wishing and she gave me a discount on my Buddhas as well as several Chinese paper lanterns. I also picked out several larger Buddhas for myself, so needless to say, I left one happy camper!!!The shop itself is small, claustrophobic and jam packed with merchandise, which is exactly what I was looking for. After a great lunch at Moon Palace, this is exactly what I needed to complete my Chinatown afternoon.All I can say is that my Buddhas have brought me good luck ever since I got them. Coincidence? Perhaps ...... hmmmmmm.

4.description: This is a cute little store!  It has cute little knick knacks to a good selection of chinese dresses and shirts.  What I really loved about this place are the employees!  My friend tried on quite a few shirts and was looking for a specific type of shirt.  Bless their little hearts...they helped us and searched hard for what she was looking for!  Unfortunatly nothing worked out but I recommend this store for sure based of customer service and the great stuff they have in there!

1.description: I came here with a large family party on Saturday night. The restaurant was completely empty at 830PM. We ordered the family party menu and each of the dishes were pretty good compared to the family party menu we had for lunch from Mayflower. Highlights? The yellow chicken at my table was delicious, but it was undercooked at the other table. Good variety of dishes. Lowlights? Eel in a clay pot was disappointing. I don't know what kind of rice they used, but it was hard and a bit dry. I like eel, but I wasn't a fan of the flavor either. It was pretty cold in the restaurant. We brought the space heater to the table, but I could barely feel anything.Overall, I enjoyed my meal. There isn't much in terms of decor or ambiance, but eh. The quality is better than some other restaurants. Plus since it's on a side street, you'll likely have the place to yourself!

9.description: On a side street off bustling Wentworth, I never would have come across this place had I not been looking for a place to get Lap Cheong (Chinese sausage) clay pot and through some brief Internet research, this place came recommended. The dish was not actually on the menu (well the English side at least) but they were more than happy to make it for us. The service was friendly and attentive. Great hot and sour soup, fried potstickers, Szechuan string beans, and the main course of Lap Cheong clay pot (chopped up flavorful sausage, rice, mushrooms and green onions) made for a delicious dish big enough for 4 to share. The flavor was subtle and delicate, but truly tasty. The prices were also very affordable. Take a break from your go-to Chinatown spot and go-to dishes and give this place and its unique offerings a shot. I promise you won't be disappointed.

12.description: Restaurant reviewWhere in Chicago can you find a expansive authentic cantonese menu? Kam Fung is the place to visit during your next trip to Chinatown. Hidden away on a side street of Chinatown is one of the most versatile Chinese restaurants in Chicago. The menu is expansive including your typical asian-american dishes (fried rice, chop suey, chow mein, walnut shrimp), but the true gem is in the detailed menu that is in english and partially in only chinese. Included are some picture of excellent food items that I would not know how to order (I had a friend that could read chinese) which included twin stir-fried lobster, organic free range chicken (you have not had chicken until you try this dish), striped pangasius maws stirfry, and fresh steamed fish just to name a few. They are open late nights and also have clay pot rice which is one of the few places in IL which have this dish. If you want to take a walk on the wild side and try authentic Cantonese/Asian cusine you should venture here for a try!Pro: extensive menu, variety of meat/fresh seafood/chicken dishes, large portionsCons: part of the menu is only in Chinese and you might need them to translate or have a friend that can read chineseHidden gem: the clay pot rice is cheap and enormous, only place where you can find this dish. Also BYOB which saves you a ton of money!

21.description: Hellooooo Kam Fung! On a recent trip to Chinatown with some friends, my BF & I wound up at their favorite restaurant for a late dinner. Walking in to Kam Fung is an unimpressive event, it looks like every other little restaurant you've ever seen around the country that doesn't care about their decor. Paper flags on all the linoleum walls with specials (I think) printed in Chinese with random prices, minor decor, all items picked up at the local stores, and huge lazy susans in the middle of each table.Don't let that deter you, once you get your first dish from the kitchen, you'll swear you're sitting in heaven.We lucked out and hit the place at a great time. We walked in at about 9:30 on a Sat. night, and easily had our choice of any seat in the place. That quickly changed, as Kam Fung serves a late night menu (until 2am) where everything is $3.99. By the time we left we were the only non-Chinese people in the place and there were people waiting for our table.We started with soups - wonton, which had a flavorful, fragrant broth and multiple (!) wontons; and a hot & sour, which was loaded with pork, chicken, mushrooms, and tons of other things in a thick, brown soup. I'll be getting the wonton again next time I go back, which will be soon. On to the egg rolls - served hot & crispy without any stray oil & grease. By this time I'm bouncing around with anticipation like a little school girl waiting for the main dishes. I mean like silly giddy.  We ordered 4 dishes, which was WAY too much food. But that's ok, because it was soooo good that all the leftovers (2 more meals worth!) got devoured.We had the: Shrimp & vegetable chow fun - served in a casserole dish, the noodles were delightfully slightly crunchy while being the perfect noodle consistency at the same time. The sauce was light, the vegetables plentiful & crunchy, and the shrimp was wonderful.Seafood w/XO sauce - For those of you who don't know what XO sauce is (that was me until I tried this dish), here's wiki's answer: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XO…. Kam Fung doesn't joke around when it comes to seafood. This dish was piled high with shrimp, scallops, octopus, and other fish that escapes me right now. Yum. I'm now a huge fan of XO sauce.Shredded Pork in Ya Shung sauce - I'm not a big pork eater so I only had a bite to taste this, but it tasted remotely like barbeque. It was as good as something you don't really like can be. :)  The 2 guys at the table who love pork raved about the dish; flavor, texture, and anything else they can think of. It was an overflowing plate of food and they put a nice dent in it.Shrimp in lobster sauce - You all know this dish. An old standard that Kam Fung does well. They do theirs with a yummy thick brown sauce with tons of giant shrimp. Certainly not disappointing.I haven't had good, real, Chinese food since moving here from NY, and my BF, who is from Alabama, has had great NY Chinese, but nothing as authentic as this. Kam Fung is the real deal, and restored my faith in Chinese food and opened his eyes to an entirely new world. I can't wait to go back, and I'm sure it'll be soon.Everyone left stuffed and elated, and brought home over half their dish. But we all clutched them tightly on our way homes, for fear of forgetting our delishiousness in the cab.Go and try this place. I can't stress it enough. Judging by their late night crowd they're not hurting for business, but you'll certainly be thrilled you went.

16.description: Honestly, these people who are giving two stars, are you even ordering the right dishes? who orders orange chicken at an authentic chinese restaurant? try a chinese american place.Anyway, Kam Fung isn't 5 stars but it's a solid 4. Their food is good, especially the Fish Chow Fun. I'd definitely want to go back just for that next time I'm in Chicago.

17.description: Really bad Chinese/Cantonese food! We came here for a family dinner with lots of people, hence we ordered lots of dishes. Honestly, all the dishes were salty & oily.

10.description: On hindsight, we probably should have heeded the negative review given here by a Yelper friend. Although we did not encounter the same problems as in that review, all was not rosy at our group's meal either. Kam Fung was a last minute choice switch in our group's quest for Cantonese fare. Their menu met that criteria and the ingredients used would please the many who savor the cuisine of south China. We were seated at a round table with a round glass "lazy susan" in the center of the white vinyl "table cloth." Although the rotating glass disc was large, the number and size of all our dishes eventually overwhelmed it.We chose one of the pre-selected "family" package meals that was intended for a group of 8. This would give us an excellent introduction to the cooking at Kam Fung while also providing a variety of meat, fowl, seafood, and vegetables. As with many such Cantonese meals, our table began it by sharing a tureen of flavorful soup, based on a pork broth, containing pieces of Chinese broccoli. It was a good beginning. A helpful touch at Kam Fung for large groups are the electric rice steamers that they station next to your table, so you can refill your own bowls of white rice as you feel the need to.Our main dishes were a mixed bag. The whole lobster was one any kitchen couldn't mess up, presented in cut pieces with the shell still attached. The vegetable stir fry featured slices of lotus root, wood ear, and black mushrooms, but nothing much memorable about that. There was the two-bite filets of white fish gently deep-fried in a whisper-light golden coating of flour (?), presented on a plate of complimentary vegetables. Cantonese cuisine doesn't use the spicy, hot flavors of the northern cuisines. But sweet and sour is something that highlights its dishes. Ours was a rather odd one; pieces of cut-up pork chops (instead of ribs) battered and coated in a gloppy red sweet/sour BBQ sauce. One ate it for the well-cooked meat, but the sauce was a disaster! We also enjoyed the large shrimps (oxymoron) in a stir fry with unmemorable vegetables and a too-thick sauce.Being that we were dining just ahead of the lunar new year, the prospect of sharing a whole roasted chicken was a traditional touch of good luck. Unfortunately, the platter of sliced pieces (including the head, of course) must have just come out of the refrigerator - cooked, but cold! I can't recall ever getting chicken served this cold in a Chinese restaurant or even direct from the Chinese BBQ shop. The standard dipping sauce for chicken of salt and oil with chopped chives was a hit though.Everyone thinks that fortune cookies are the Chinese "dessert." It's not! Maybe that's because the sweet treats that end a Cantonese meal aren't all that spectacular. Our meal ended with each getting a small bowl of traditional, cold, sweet, red bean soup. THEN, the fortune cookies. All in all, not a terrible meal. And the service was good and attentive. But with so many choices in Chinatown and around the city, it's unlikely our group will return here.

5.description: The 煲仔饭 is the one must order items here, small place but sometime they keep it as very taishangese local style. Food are authentic and good. I will go Back

11.description: This is currently my favorite Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown. It's open late, the service is solid, and the food is just a bit (or often more than a bit) fresher than its competitors. If you don't speak English, some servers are more helpful than others, since there's a fairly extensive Chinese-only menu with great options that just aren't listed otherwise. The eel with ginger and green onions, for example, which is a bit pricey but amazingly flavorful if you like eel.And, as for the English menu, I have not had better clams in black bean sauce in any restaurant around here. The sauce is light but intense, with enough fermented black beans to complement the clams but not overwhelm their natural sweetness. This is a must-try dish here, in my opinion. As always, I'd love to go back with a group of friends and really dive into the menu. It's well worth a visit.

3.description: My favourite restaurant in old Chinatown! Really traditional Taishan food!!

0.description: We wanted to try a place off the beaten path in Chinatown and luckily I happened to peer down some random alley and spot this place.  I'm glad I did because it turned out quite well.Food:  Most of the items were stellar.  None in our party spoke a Chinese dialect, so we were kind of relegated to the English menu.  True, I guess we could have asked what some of the Chinese dishes were, but there were so many that it  would been a burden to have the waiter walk us through everything.  Egg drop soup was excellent, and the pot stickers were also amazing as well.  They served them with a "red vinegar," something I've never seen before.  However, it was really good, and I could easily see my self prefer the vingar to garlic sesame soy sauce occasionally.  We had mongolian beef which was well done, and the waiter was nice enough to let us have the Szechuan string beans with some pork in it.  However, it also came with tiny, dried shrimp, and I don't eat seafood generally (yeah, a crime I know...).  Other than that, the dish was really quite good. So we politely asked to have that dish redone and the waiter graciously agreed.  The replacement came back about 5 minutes later sans shrimp, though the green beans were noticeably undercooked and the seasoning was toned way down.  I have a feeling that they probably thought, "ok, let's just put out something that can't possibly offend these guilo." Anyway, that was the only flaw.Service: Very nice and accommodating.  No complaints.I'll definitely come back.  This place is one of the best Chinese restaurants I've been to in the city.

20.description: we went with a group of people to chinatown for dinner.  the restaurant we had in mind had had a fire and was closed.  we wandered around and had our name down at a place on the main drag (wentworth).  I was crowded with regular folks and we were to wait 30 mins.  one of the group went exploring and found Kam Fung.  It was not as tastefully decorated as the first place, but in a way I liked it better.  The service was friendly and prompt.  The food was delicious, ample and devoured.   I do not remember any particular dish as we had many.  We were the only non-asians in the place.They do not sell alcohol, so BYOX (this is a plus in my mind as it saves $$$)

19.description: Authentic quality Chinese food. My grandmother had a mother's day celebration here and the food was delicious! The most memorable dish was a taro with pork and mixed vegetables. One of my favorite vegetables in the world is taro and Kam Fung cooked it just right. Although it was on the salty side, it had the flavors of the taro cooked with the other vegetables was just so tasteful! Then my family came here one summer night. We ordered the taro dish again asking them to add less salt. Another dish was a Chinese sausage clay pot dish. They steam the rice and the Chinese sausage in a clay pot. All the flavors and aroma of the Chinese sausage gets soaked up by the rice so the rice is just as flavorful as the Chinese sausage. Once you open the cover of the clay pot the smell of the dish is irresistible. You just gotta dig in! This place is the place for authentic flavorful Chinese food. Just make sure you drink a lot of water while eating and afterward. You are surely gonna need it after eating all the tasty salty Chinese food. Interesting Note - This is one of the few places in Chinatown that has clay pot dishes. My parents always say how they really enjoyed eating the clay pot dishes in China. When they came to Kam Fung, they couldn't stop eating it especially my mom. She said that it was just as good as the ones in China, but definitely with less oils.

2.description: The prices for lunch is reasonable but the food is extremely salty. The quality isn't there like it used to be.

18.description: Hellooooo Kam Fung! On a recent trip to Chinatown with some friends, my BF & I wound up at their favorite restaurant for a late dinner. Walking in to Kam Fung is an unimpressive event, it looks like every other little restaurant you've ever seen around the country that doesn't care about their decor. Paper flags on all the linoleum walls with specials (I think) printed in Chinese with random prices, minor decor, all items picked up at the local stores, and huge lazy susans in the middle of each table.Don't let that deter you, once you get your first dish from the kitchen, you'll swear you're sitting in heaven.We lucked out and hit the place at a great time. We walked in at about 9:30 on a Sat. night, and easily had our choice of any seat in the place. That quickly changed, as Kam Fung serves a late night menu (until 2am) where everything is $3.99. By the time we left we were the only non-Chinese people in the place and there were people waiting for our table.We started with soups - wonton, which had a flavorful, fragrant broth and multiple (!) wontons; and a hot & sour, which was loaded with pork, chicken, mushrooms, and tons of other things in a thick, brown soup. I'll be getting the wonton again next time I go back, which will be soon. On to the egg rolls - served hot & crispy without any stray oil & grease. By this time I'm bouncing around with anticipation like a little school girl waiting for the main dishes. I mean like silly giddy.  We ordered 4 dishes, which was WAY too much food. But that's ok, because it was soooo good that all the leftovers (2 more meals worth!) got devoured.We had the: Shrimp & vegetable chow fun - served in a casserole dish, the noodles were delightfully slightly crunchy while being the perfect noodle consistency at the same time. The sauce was light, the vegetables plentiful & crunchy, and the shrimp was wonderful.Seafood w/XO sauce - For those of you who don't know what XO sauce is (that was me until I tried this dish), here's wiki's answer: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XO…. Kam Fung doesn't joke around when it comes to seafood. This dish was piled high with shrimp, scallops, octopus, and other fish that escapes me right now. Yum. I'm now a huge fan of XO sauce.Shredded Pork in Ya Shung sauce - I'm not a big pork eater so I only had a bite to taste this, but it tasted remotely like barbeque. It was as good as something you don't really like can be. :)  The 2 guys at the table who love pork raved about the dish; flavor, texture, and anything else they can think of. It was an overflowing plate of food and they put a nice dent in it.Shrimp in lobster sauce - You all know this dish. An old standard that Kam Fung does well. They do theirs with a yummy thick brown sauce with tons of giant shrimp. Certainly not disappointing.I haven't had good, real, Chinese food since moving here from NY, and my BF, who is from Alabama, has had great NY Chinese, but nothing as authentic as this. Kam Fung is the real deal, and restored my faith in Chinese food and opened his eyes to an entirely new world. I can't wait to go back, and I'm sure it'll be soon.Everyone left stuffed and elated, and brought home over half their dish. But we all clutched them tightly on our way homes, for fear of forgetting our delishiousness in the cab.Go and try this place. I can't stress it enough. Judging by their late night crowd they're not hurting for business, but you'll certainly be thrilled you went.

13.description: A great low priced restaurant with great food. My not have the biggest dining area but the people who works there are extremely friendly.

4.description: This place has been around forever and this was my first time stepping foot in the door. Our relatives came to visit from NY and they have close ties to this place, so we had dinner here with the family. From the outside, this place looks small and unattractive. This place is definitely hidden and if you aren't local, you won't know this place existed. The inside, however, is more welcoming and it wasn't bad at all. My relatives ordered all the food and I didn't look at the menu, so my review won't be that specific. My favorite dish they had was the tea leaf shrimp (direct English translation). It was recommended by the chef(owner). This was better than the Salt and Pepper Shrimp. Another dish that is extremely good was the Steamed Scallop Shell with Vermicelli in Garlic Sauce. This place pretty much serve really traditional Chinese food and they have certain entrees that I have never had at other restaurants. All the other dishes we had were just average.This is a place that I would only come if my family is with me because it is that traditional. All the good stuff I do not know how to order.

6.description: This is a hole in a wall place with the bare minimal decor.  Here you will find cheap and decent Chinese food.  Very authentic dishes, and big portions.  I always leave stuffed, so don't say I didn't warn you.

15.description: Came here with family and friends. Wasn't too impressed with the food. A few of us thought the food was a bit salty.We had some kind of fish soup ( I think), squab, crab, walnut shrimp, salted fish eggplants, black pepper beef, 2 kinds of clay pot rice (one is with chinese sausage with some other things and one with eel), greens, mixed greens and I can't remember the rest.The squab was good. Walnut shrimp didn't have much mayo which was good, but tasted different than other places, the 1st clay pot rice was ok, the eel was tough in the other clay pot, mixed greens was pretty good (crunchy). Overall, nothing too impressive. Dessert was red bean/tapioca soup.My sister ordered Orange Chicken for her husband for take-out and it was basically like Mandarin Pork Chop sauce with chicken and spicy.

7.description: This place is located in an unassuming side-street right across from the original Triple Crown restauarant. The place is rather small; it could maybe fit about 100-120 people max. We ordered the beef stipe, but it was rather chewy and not fresh at all. The plate portions were not that great and we left there hungry.BATHROOM REVIEW  If there's only one rule I follow when I go to Chinatown, or any restaurant, its that you always use the bathrooms AFTER you eat because what you find in the bathroom might make you lose your appetite. In this case, I should have NEVER used the bathroom, even after the meal.... yeah, it was that bad. The bathroom was a one-staller and came straight out of a horror flick. Flickering dim light, rust and mildew everywhere. I did the trick of kicking the toilet seat up and peeing -- now i'm wondering if I should burn my shoes. I couldn't wait to get out of there. SIT or SQUAT??? Do I really need to answer that question? I'm shuddering just writing this. please make this bathroom memory go away!

8.description: This is a toi shan style cantonese restaurant.  it reminds me of my grandmother's dishes. Im a fan of their rice clay pot with cured meats! So tasty!  I will be back!

14.description: This restaurant has good food and it not that pricey. I do recommended this restaurant. The place is small but it can accommodate large groups.  We were a family of 11 adults and two toddlers and had no issues with customer service.

3.description: Came here one night for some Filipino food. I was surprised they didn't have tenola so I settled for the fried fish over a bed of rice. It took a while for the food to come out so you know it was cooked right when I ordered. The fish was very flavorful. They kept the skin on the fish giving it a nice crisp texture but there was not enough meat on the fish. I thought my dish was a bit on the pricy side but it still satisfied my craving!

1.description: Bahay Kubo is a Filipino restaurant located in Richland Center's food court.  It's a small little shop that offers an array of Filipino food.  I was excited when I learned a Filipino restaurant opened up less than 5 minutes away from me.  I met my friend there for lunch and we shared:Lumpia Shanghai: Filipino style eggrolls with pork and vegetables.  These eggrolls were deep fried to the point it was burnt.  It made the eggroll too hard and the meat dry out.   Longaniza Platter: three sausages (almost like a chorizo, but it leans more on the sweet, salty, and sour side), mango salsa, garlic rice, and a sunnyside up egg.  The rice was cold and did not have enough garlic flavor to it, the longaniza was really greasy and too sweet for my liking, and the mango salsa had no type of flavor to it.  The only thing they didn't screw up on was the egg.   Halo-Halo:  a mix of sweet jello, beans, and fruits covered with crushed ice and evaporated milk and then topped off with ube ice cream and corn flakes.  This dessert was way too sweet for my liking.  There was no balance at all; it felt like I was eating a mouthful of sugar.This was a huge disappointment.  It may be the only Filipino restaurant in a couple of miles from me, but I would travel the extra 20-25 minutes for good Filipino food.  I wouldn't recommend anyone to go to this place, but I might still come to this location if I was really craving Filipino food and didn't want to travel far.

2.description: Disgusting all salt and grease, no flavor "special" of the day. Guy said it's a steak special, I asked what kind of steak, he says beef. No duh. But is it tbone, skirt, NY strip, tenderloin, rib eye, or what? Seems like he couldn't help l, but I'll give it a shot since the picture made it look like skirt steak. 10 minutes later, I got 4 pieces of the thin cut short ribs cooked "medium"on a less then sizzling iron plate with a perfectly shaped mound of very dark fried rice topped with a sunny side up on the side. The rice and egg was extremely bland, and the rice was overly greasy. Then it made sense after I took a chewy bite of the rib. It was very, very salty. So that's pretty much the flavor of the special, salt and grease. Felt like I'd would've died from high pressure and a heart attack if I ate that dish.

5.description: I was a Peace Corps volunteer in the rural Philippines... So I've had the gambit of Filipino cuisine. The lumpia here was alright, but the adobo and the pancit bihon rocked my world! This is my new Filipino food dig, close to home! I'm gonna try their halo halo tonight! Gustung-gusto ko ito!

0.description: I was super craving for tocilog (tocino, egg and garlic rice) so I yelped it and found this place. It is in the lower level food court  of  Richfield building, it looks exactly like the food courts in Chinatown, Phils. The tocilog was exactly what i wanted! The pancit guisado was delicious. The lumpiang shanghai was undercooked, but I can fix that. Overall, I am happy that there is a Filipino place near my area. Great for takeout! Griselle, the manager said you can order delivery in GrubHub! We will definitely be back to try their lechon kawali and sisig!

4.description: Ok so I ordered longsilog at this place.the rice was so nasty,the egg was burned.never going back to this place ever again.Not sure why people giving positive feedback to them.there must be something wrong with your taste buds or u might be related to the owner lol peace Don't wanna write this but I want the people know so...it's not worth it peeps

1.description: Will never shop at this store again!! My 3 year old little girl got a frozen coin purse and a frozen stamp that she was so happy to get. She got her own bag for her stuff. 5 minutes later she realized her stuff was no longer in her bag because the bag was torn and her stuff had fallen out. I happened to see a lady picking her purse up in the street and just caught her before she put it her bag, but as for the stamp it was broken in the street and my daughter was heart broken. We went back to the store to get a new stamp and explain that the bag that was given to her was torn on the side and her stuff had fallen out. The lady was EXTREMELY rude and said we had to pay the 75 cents for the new stamp and that it wasn't their fault. I said are you kidding me??? AND her reply was U kidding me..and continued to be nasty. The 75 cents was not a big deal, it was the point and because of that I will be sure to never shop at this store again!!! I almost returned the other items we bought as well but since it was already given to my kids I did not. HORRIBLE customer service...

0.description: This was our last stop after visiting all the other tchotchke shops in China Town.  It has the best selection of items and at reasonable prices.  Everything is organized and neatly displayed, well lit and decent sized aisles.  Will definitely go back

1.description: Yet another bakery, this one is a little more modern, neat and clean.

0.description: Actually, we had this bakery do our wedding cake. It was very reasonable, a 3 layered cake to feed 100 people for $100? I honestly don't remember the price, but it was quite good. One layer was vanilla cake with mango filling, chocolate cake with chocolate filling, and vanilla cake with strawberry filling. The owner even hand delivered it to the wedding and assembled it. She gave me the cake topper for free, but I returned it after I found a cockroach (yes it was gross) in the box.

1.description: Al, Manny, and the whole staff are very professional. Very accommodating. Al & Manny are great barbers. I travel across town & pass several shops just to have my son and my hair cut at Groom.

0.description: The Barber Manny is A1.. Always on point and takes his time.. The Groom Shop does not feel like a factory assembly line, with a get them in and get them out attitude. They take pride in treating every customer as a VIP..

1.description: This is a no frills store - much like other Asian grocers. They had what I was looking for and luckily my friend knew exactly where to find it because the smell of an Asian grocery store is definitely not like the smell of a Whole Foods.

9.description: Mayflower Foods offers a wide selection of Asian foods that I am unable to find in traditional supermarkets at reasonable prices. Some of my favorite finds include a wide selection of bok choy (at least 5 types), huge bags of dehydrated mushrooms including shiitakes and many other types (great flavor and no spoilage), a fresh and widely varied seafood counter, medicinal herbs, kitchen housewares, and oils/spices/sauces. It is a great resource for home chefs who enjoy preparing Asian foods whether from scratch or using premade preprocessed items.

23.description: The store is cheap and an adventure if you're not already steeped in the staples of Chinese-American cuisine.  I'm lucky to live in Chinatown to have a store like Mayflower around.  It's fun to dig into the frozen fish and meat section, pull out random products, bring them home and try to come up with something edible.  Most of the time I'm not disappointed!  The produce is cheap, though they could stand for more selection, and the variety of stocks, daishon, meat and fish products, noodle products, and any other bizarre accoutrements you could imagine is impressive for a such a small space.And it is such a small space.  A bit hard to walk around but that's part of it's charm.  Well, no, it's a pain in the ass, but the prices are worth it.

5.description: Never shop this food store!!!! Its product clearly past the expiration date, and the owner didn't even give a shit when I brought this up. the food store refused to replace or refund. I made a complaint to the FDA accordingly. I hope the store realize that they are doing business in the U.S., and there are business ethics and regulations that they should follow.

25.description: Four words: Ten types of Pocky.*shivers and faints from foodgasms*

12.description: I only brought a few small bag of gummy candies here, but overall I just go here with my mom for groceies. Anyway, my mom and her friend were picking out chicken feet so I moved aside and stood in front of this aisle with dried fish. I got bored and decided to look at freezer items. There were nothing much to look at, so I went back and waited at dried fish aisle. I was still waiting, so I decided to look at the survelliance screen and all of the sudden the screen footage was just focus on me and all the other screen was gone. I got even more creeped out when the cursor started pointing at me whenever I moved. I moved to another aisle to see what would happen and the screen finally changed back with all of the other screens. It got even more weird when this man guy with sunglasses came up to me and said ''open your plastic bag.'' Then he just walked away casually without apologizing, unbelievable and I didn't even touch anything! I only found out who he was because I took a guess and asked my mom, plus also saw his picture when my mom was paying (we came inside the store on the other side.) By the way, some of their items are highly priced!

21.description: I agree with Eric M.There is NOTHING special about this grocery store.  Their meat section where the hot pot stuff is - is freezer burnt.  Their fish section is slimy.Their produce non-spectacular.  Hong Kong Market or even Richwell is better than this.

16.description: I really wish Mayflower will clean up their store because i do like the live seafood they have. But the other day i was in there buying live shrimp (which i absolutely love the ones they sell there), the stench in the back room almost took me out completelyi just don't understand why Chicago chinatown grocery stores and bad smell and unclean environment have to be synonyms. I visited chinese grocery stores in west coast and new york city and a lot of their chinese grocery stores are clean and invitingTo be honest, i am more than willing to pay more if they can keep the place clean and smell free

17.description: The Mayflower Food is kind of dirty, but it serves its purpose.  I would have given it another star if the employee were more friendly. 1.  I had called to ask for their operating hours.  Perhaps due to their lack of knowledge or just plain rude, I was hung up on once.  It wasn't until the third call that they finally gave me an answer.2.  Those of you who wants to use your credit cards to pay for your purchases, make sure to spend at least a minimum of $20.00.  The lady who rang up my tab was rude and border line A$$.   3.  if Chicago wasn't so limited on Chinese Markets, I would avoid this place all together.

10.description: Minimum 20$ for credit card, which is illegal, but they of course want you to spend more money.  Lady at the cashier was rude and gave us an attitude. Heard many bad things about this place and dreaded coming here.

11.description: An alternative to Chinatown Market, roughly same prices I think, maybe a little higher? But for some reason I definitely prefer Chinatown Market, is it cleaner or brighter, simply more convenient?

26.description: This is another Chinese grocery store that's pretty big, very well organized, and despite being fishy-stinky, clean. It has buckets of dried roots, mushrooms and every sea creature known to man, including squid.

22.description: I'm not sure why people are rating this so high.  This is probably the worst of the Chicago Chinese markets.  It's small, cramped, dirty (filthy might be a better term) and the selection is ok, but hardly great.It always smells from the seafood/meats section, and sometimes it smells so bad it's near wretch-inducing.  I've been in enough small fish markets (I grew up on the West Coast, and I come from a family of fishermen) to know that that smell IS avoidable through proper cleaning processes.I also found a dead baby mouse crushed between jars of chili oil.  It's possible, I suppose, that the mouse came all the way from the factory in China, but it still begs the question of how the jars could have been shelved with a dead mouse between them.  I took a photo, so if you don't believe me send me a message on here and I'll email you the photo.With all the other, better, Chinese markets (Chinatown Market is just across Archer and while not the best is still better than this one), there's really no reason to shop at this place until they literally clean up their act.

0.description: I come in occasionally for groceries as a kid and I come in for the drinks as an adult. They have half the collection of drinks for the herbal line I like. It's sold at a relatively good deal for $1 a bottle. With tax, I can walk out with two bottles at $2.06.This place isn't as packed as it used to be. I'm not sure why.

20.description: Surprise surprise, one could surmise the fishy smell originates from the large amount of fish being processed in the back room of the store. Vegans such as myself have no business really going back there anyway and honestly, it's fairly easy to ignore! The selection of noodles in tandem with the produce (64 cents for a 5er of garlic bulbs and a buck oh nine for a pound of baby bok choy) are quite exhaustive and certainly beat out many of the other grocers within the neighborhood. Also, Sriracha (you know, the hot nectar of Jesus) - yeah that's three bucks here. Grab that at any chain grocer and you'll be paying nearly twice as much. In terms of sheer selection of goods both fresh and packaged, this is easily within the top three of best grocers in Chinatown. Mayflower + Chinatown Market + Fat Lee's = all of your grocer needs for what you're no doubt coming to this neighborhood to find.

19.description: I agree with Eric M.There is NOTHING special about this grocery store.  Their meat section where the hot pot stuff is - is freezer burnt.  Their fish section is slimy.Their produce non-spectacular.  Hong Kong Market or even Richwell is better than this.

2.description: It smells really bad. Yeah, I know all tiny cramped stores like this are going to stink, but this place's stench is far out. Way worse than Chinatown Market across the street. Anyway, we were looking for two items, which they don't carry because apparently, as the hipster guarding the door explained, lemongrass and lemon leaves are "specialty items." Really? Ya think? Do people generally go to Chinatown to find Creamettes and Velveeta?

18.description: If you ever been to Chinatown square and want to bring some fresh Chinese food back home to cook, this is a place worth to take a look.Yes, it can be a little dirty, crowded and smelly. But most of the time, their price is right. They have the lowest price on bag of Rice ( not anymore ) , fresh pork and shrimp on Chinatown square area. one more thing, Chinatown square parking can get really nasty, you get $50 fine ticket if you missed 5 mins meter, then you can switch to 24th Canal Street Hong Kong market.

13.description: This is my grocery store of convenience since I am more so in new Chinatown when eating at restaurants and picking up items for my mom.  There is a pungent welcome upon entering the store, the dried medicinal and fish items are right there to the left as you walk through to get to the other aisles.  It impresses me that so many items can be packed into this store.  They have seafood and meat and another small side area that you can walk into, and of course they have their herbal part of the store a little beyond the checkout area.  The prices are pretty comparable and there are a few things that are cheaper and a few things that are pricier depending on what you are looking for.  I agree that the staff here are no nonsense type of people that seem to not smile much.  Understandably, if I had to work next to the scent of that dried fish everyday I wouldn't be very happy either.

4.description: Store Review:Cramped stores, small aisles. This is merely a functioning store for groceries. I dread bringing the stroller in because the aisles are barely enough for people to walk through. If you know what you are getting than it is not bad. There is a good selection of asian food (noodles, snacks, fresh vegetables) but alas during peak times very hard to shop. Also don't expect to use your credit card in chinatown, a 20 dollar minimum even than I don't bother. Pros- cheap asian grocery, fresh vegetables and fishCons- super cramped aisles, very few english speaking employeesHidden deals- None

24.description: This store has some of my favorite items like mochi ice cream and frozen gyoza at really good prices as well as my favorite apple flavored pop.  They have a huge frozen fish selection as well as live lobsters that look like they'd like to come home with me and dive into my giant lobster pot.  I like to freak people out by showing them the live frogs.  If only I knew how to cook them....   Gotta love the Pocky and giant boxes of Hello Panda.  A+ on the service.  Once they let me use my credit card even though my purchase was less than their credit card minimum.

6.description: They sell snacks that passed expiration dates. And when we told them, they responded with very bad attitudes. Like they don't care at all if the food is expired.

15.description: I usually come here to just get some snacks or a quick grocery look around. The place is small and cramped. The fish/meat department can use some updating or cleaning.

7.description: I am not really adding anything by writing this review. It's more of a co-sign on almost all the other reviews that have already been written. So here's confirmation--it smells like homemade death in here, some have said from the fish market in back, but I also suspect the large jars of dried whatever-that-stuff-is in the front.Yes, there is a $20 minimum for credit cards.Sure, the staff could use a little customer service training.But they have Shin Ramyun ad kim chee--even though neither of these items are Chinese--for when I am too lazy to drive all the way to Joong Boo Market.

8.description: Customer service here is non-existent. They haven't been rude to me but neither have they been polite to me either. I get in here just to get what I want and get out of there. The aisles are extremely narrow and every time an employee is stocking up the shelves, you have to squeeze past. I only come here out of convenience when i'm in Chinatown for dinner. Otherwise, Richwell is a better place to shop for Chinese groceries. I totally dislike their $20 minimum for credit card purchases.

3.description: Checked out this place and the Chinatown market, this place seems to have the lower price. Also, we asked for ice to keep our perishable goods fresh on our way home, they gladly gave it to us. Store is  a bit cramp, has 2 different entrances.

14.description: SO PISSED OFF at the moment. Really??DO the ladies there think they can cheat you if  you are a younger they can cheat you? I went with a group of friends yesterday and we bought a lot of stuff. I mean we c ome from the suburbs...I got 3 bottles of Lee Kum KEe soy sauce. Silly me not looking at the receipt after they ring me up because Im just too trustworthy.Or maybe I think that people would do their job right. I looked at my receipt now and it says 4.....They rang me up an extra bottle. Im not going to go all the way to Chinatown for a refund its not worth the gas obviously but....seriously.... My family and I always support this store whenever we come to Chinatown-- looks like I need to make a switch. They cover their butts with a simple no refund and no exchanges on their receipt...so basically no one can ever do anything. On top of that they let you use your credit card with a 20 dollar m inimum. Im pretty sure its against the law to have a minimum now a days....

58.description: The pho here is the best hangover cure I've ever had.

56.description: This place is run by Vietnamese people so their menu is only in English & Viet. It was my first time here and I ordered the House Special Pho, I believe it's #14. It's pretty good, but it had very few meats in there. There's not a lot of Pho to choose from. Phos are from $8 and up. Maybe I will return to try out their Vermicelli.

29.description: I like this place. The waiters are typically unfriendly but the food is consistently great. I've tried multiple dishes here but my default is #012 the sliced beef pho. The broth is refreshing and really hits the spot. Esp when your throat is sore or you're feeling stuffy, this broth will clear all that up. I frequently order the Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk, which is also good. Spring rolls and the Vietnamese pancakes are also good as well. I came here once like 10 minutes before closing time, and thought they would definitely turn us away (but i wanted to try anyway bc I was craving pho). Surprisingly they welcomed us in and served us with the same service as usual.Some may say the best pho is in Viet town in argyle. and yea maybe that's true. but if you don't live near argyle (like me) and want quality pho, this is the place I turn to. They get 4 stars for the consistency of food quality :)

42.description: This restaurant has some really kicking egg rolls and crab Rangoon. The special pho is decent sized and more than enough to make you full and satisfied! You won't be disappointed! This is my alternative to Tank up north.

23.description: This place gets props for being a Pho place in Chinatown to help out with the severe imbalance that is Argyle.  The pho here doesn't stand out at all.  If you asked me to describe how it may be different from other places I can't really tell you.  I've been here multiple times and I still don't know.  It's warm.  It's decent.  It's really convenient to get to.Mainly because this place is so close to where I'm living right now I'll be coming here more often and try their other dishes like bun buo nuong and bo luc lac as well as the softshell crab that they keep touting.

47.description: AWFUL SERVICE, food was decent. They need new servers.

8.description: I always like coming to cafe hoang for pho in Chinatown because they're cheap and usually really good. But last time I went ( after they remodeled ) I had the smallest spring rolls with one tiny shrimp in each roll. The best part was my spring roll smelled like dirty socks/dirty table cloth. When I asked the server about the smell, she told me it was normal for spring rolls to smell like that. Uhm I have tried many spring rolls in my life and none of them smelled like socks. It was such a disappointment. But the pho was good.

31.description: Cranky waiter. Average food. The vegetarian pho is a little bit below average. Deep fried fish is surprisingly delicious. One "banh xeo" costs as much as an entre, too expensive and too little.

34.description: Hands down best Bun Bo Hue! Rice dish was small. Pho was okay. But damn Bun Bo Hue was sooo good.

16.description: The bun bo hue here is delicious!  We have come here several times specifically for this soup, and it has always been good except for the last time when the broth seemed watered-down and oily.  I'm hoping that this was just a one -time issue and that it gets back to the norm, because where else in all of Chicago will I be able to find a bun bo hue broth this good?  We have also had the pho here but to be honest their specialty is the bun bo hue and so I stick to it.

13.description: This is my go-to place for lunch when I am in the city, a quick Red Line ride from the loop (and only a single fare if you return in less than two hours).Certainly start with the spring rolls.  Have the spicy lemon rare beef salad.  That's plenty for one person.  With others, add another dish.  Today we had the lemon grass chicken stir fry.It's reasonable just to order several things off the appetizer menu.  In addition to the spring rolls and the beef salad, try the Vietnamese pancake (surprise, not what you're expecting).On a cold wintry day, the pho of course.The owners are delightful people who take a genuine interest in their customers.

11.description: My friend and I have been here before and had really good experiences, so when a sudden pho craving overcame us while we were walking around Chinatown, we decided to go here.We ordered the Spring Rolls after reading good reviews on them, the Bun Bo Hue (because of the reviews again) and the Seafood and Pork with rice noodles. The Spring Rolls were underwhelming after reading that they were big and fresh. They were small in comparison to the ones served at Tank Noodles and Le's Pho on Argyle for the price and the ones we were served were not fresh at all. As my friend was about to take a bite, she caught a whiff that was not appetizing at all. It smelled like a wet table cloth. We let the lady at the counter know and she tried to pass it off as the smell of the noodles inside. She was not apologetic at all and said that she didn't smell anything wrong with it so we just cancelled the item.The Bun Bo Hue was quite good and decent with the amount of meat. The soup base wasn't as spicy and had as much depth of flavor as the one at Le's Pho. The Seafood and Pork with rice noodles was okay as well. There was a lot of noodles but just a few pieces of seafood and pork. The lady server was very quick to give us the check after seeing that we were finished. This is the place to go if you really want to get your pho craving satisfied otherwise, I would just go elsewhere.

39.description: I always visit this place when im in chicago. i prefer the one in China town. The food is great and the staffs are friendly. My favorite is Bun Bo hue!!

37.description: Went there with a friend on her invite. She gave a precaution to stay away from the pho there, so stay away from it I did. When I looked at a menu I was delighted that they also made Thai iced teas so I ordered one right away. It wasn't potable - my cup was mainly half-and-half. I normally don't make a big fuss of things and just eat or drink what was given to me, but my friend insisted that I get the waiter to exchange my drink. When I got around to flagging the waiter and telling him what my problem was, his reply was: "It's supposed to be like that." and walked away. I ordered a Panang Curry and my fried ordered one of the rice dishes. She was content with her dish, nothing really to rave about. My Penang curry was decent although it didn't taste like Penang curry. My dish had ingredients that I had never associated with Thai cuisine let alone curry such as green peas and celery. I admit though that was partially my fault due to my oversight of not looking at their ingredients in the menu and for ordering a Thai dish in a Vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown. Because of the mediocre (bordering on bizarre) food, I would have given it a three, but the lazy service was definitely off-putting.

0.description: So I badly wanted to try the Bun-Bo-Hue that everyone talks about, and I was also enticed by an episode of Anthony Bourdain where he traveled to Vietnam and went ape shit over this dish, he made me want it so damn badly because of how he described what goes into this dish.  We also ordered the Crab Rangoon and the Vietnamese Pancake for appetizers.  The appetizers were damn good, I especially loved that pancake.  Now for the main course, the soup was pretty damn good but not as good as a nice bowl of Pho  at Pho777 up north.  I did not fall madly in love with this dish at all and this is the only place I know of in the city that carries this dish, so I have no comparison.  All I know is I would rather have Pho any day compared to this.  The service was not the best, we had to keep asking for napkins for the messy soup and they kept bringing like 5 of them.  They were also slow at getting to our table even though it was slow as hell in there.  I will not be coming back, but the food was not bad.

38.description: #19 Bun Rieu is the bomb! Seafood tomato base rice noodle soup with tofu and shrimp. Love it! Their Bun Bo Hieu is also pretty tasty and comparable to the Cafe Hoang in Argyle. What I don't like about this place is that the service is terrible...I actually think our waiter snapped at us and said "just give me a min" when we asked for tea the second time. Also they charge you an extra 35 cents for every 4 oz of extra sauce. Talk about nickel and dime the customers...

51.description: Phonomenal!!!!!! Cheap, delicious, courteous staff. Have been back 4-5 times already. Headed there today in the cold to warm up and can't wait!

27.description: Food is great. I came here alone since it's got one $ sign. There's a 15$ minimum for credit cards...so keep that in mind. It's a lot of food to order just to meet that.

32.description: Most of the food is really good, and the prices are really good! My favorite is the vermicelli noodle with chicken. I didn't like their Thai options very much so I stick to the Vietnamese options.

54.description: OK.  So the food deserves 4 stars.  But the service we received at our last visit was so bad that I don't think we'll be going back there for a while.We've been pretty loyal customers of Cafe Hoang for the past 2 years...even though it seems like they're always closed when we decide to go there.  To be honest, there aren't that many Vietnamese restaurants south of the Loop, so Cafe Hoang kinda became our go-to place for pho.  I really enjoyed their spicy pho option (can't remember what it's called).Last week, my wife and I decided to go there for dinner and brought our 6 month old daughter.  We found a table by the entrance and had to wait a LONG TIME for anyone to acknowledge that we were there.  No eye contact, no greeting, no menus, no nothing...even though the restaurant was relatively empty.  Our server was an Asian dude with a shaved head and he was probably having a bad day.  We finally got the attention of our server, placed our order and received our food in a reasonable amount of time.  The food (as usual) was pretty good.  When it was time to pack up and leave (our baby was getting fussy), we couldn't get this guy's attention again.  When I finally spoke up to ask for the check, the dude gave me the sign to wait (one finger salute - not the middle one) without even looking up.  This really got under my skin.  We eventually got the check, paid with a card, and the entire time the guy wouldn't make eye contact or say anything.  No thanks, no warmth, no invitation to come back.  So we won't.Cafe Hoang needs to get new servers.

48.description: The food here was okay but the service is certainly lacking.  Vietnamese restaurants are not known for their service but the server we had was just very rude!  Everything we asked for seem like such an inconvenience.  We ordered a bunch of foods and asked for more salted fish sauce since the foods were kinda of bland.  He brought me out the diluted fish sauce and when i again asked him for more of the raw fish sauce, he told me I already had some on the table (it wasn't enough for all our dishes!) and did not bring out more!  If they didn't want to bring condiments to paying customers then they should have condiments on the table.  They had nothing on the table, not even siracha sauce or hoisin sauce.  There are certainly better Vietnamese places to eat in Chicago and I will not make the mistake of coming back here again.

44.description: Pros: Convenient place for authentic pho, friendly personnelCons: Not the best pho--Just a place for average and authentic pho if you do not want to make the 20-25 minute drive to argyle, which is where all the best pho is at. Still the best pho in Chinatown in my opinion.

24.description: I went  to cafe haong for lunch .I had fog legs ,fried whole red snapper ,spring roll with shrimp and pork and pho meat ball .everything  was delicious . The service was also

7.description: Fan of Cafe Hoang's Arygle location. Not sure if I will be a regular at the Chinatown location. I made the mistake of not ordering Pho but I don't like to eat Pho unless it's winter or I have the flu. Order the springs rolls and beef pad Thai. The spring rolls were ok. I laughed at the stingy portion size- one shrimp cut in half and a tiny slice of pork. The Pad Thai was utterly disgusting. The rice noodles had barely any tamarind sauce, carrots, or onions. The noodles tasted like mush. So why three stars? My dad loved his Pho & the Thai iced coffee hit the spot. In sum, only order the pho. UPDATE- must come for the Pho. Will be a regular during the cold winter.

49.description: The spicy chicken salad (#9) is very tasty.  Chicken pho (#15) is great too.

40.description: I like this place. Close to home for pho.  The food taste good,  authentic. The service is nice.  I like their fried pork meatball vermecelli with fish sauce. And the crab rangoon is good too. I will definitely go back and recommend.

53.description: Great pho, service and price!

30.description: Very good Vietnamese food. I come here to carry out all the time. The dining room seems to be always too cold. They did me right one time when I forgot my credit card and they let me take the food rather than force me to go back home and bring back my credit card saving me a trip. I came back next week bought more food and paid back my outstanding bill.

46.description: Not the best place for pho. It was okay... The noodle shop not so far from there had a better broth. When you walk in there is a distinct smell to the place. Service was okay, food was okay. Thai iced tea could be just a tad sweeter. When I got my pho they gave me a fork and a spoon. I've been using chop sticks for quite some time now. When I asked for chopsticks the guy kinda seemed confused, but he gave them to me anyway. Dunno if I'll be back.

1.description: Best Bun Bo Hue I've ever had in the States!! The taste is really authentic, tho it's a bit sweet for me. They even have pig blood (don't sweat guys it's firm). The bowl is super big too. I really wanted to but couldn't finish em all. Also I highly recommend Vietnamese style salad with lotus roots (Goi Ngo Sen) and other salad dishes as well. Very tasty and Vnese xxIm gonna miss this place badly when I'm back in NY

55.description: We were there 7/3/13; Everything started with the waiter may be he had a bad day don't know? The spring rolls looked old and the chicken tasted kind of funny!! "I don't think it was chicken" We ask for the red sauce and the bottle was stick on the outside eek! Pho was ok not the best like areas in reviews, but the the fried roll shrimp was the only good thing there! Also my 2 year old got SICK from those spring roll and I got the runs thanks Cafe Hoang. I think menu is to big to keep all  food fresh!

9.description: I crave their Pho once a week, it is incredible. Service is great, food is reasonable price.

26.description: My favorite Vietamese spot in Chinatown. This quaint family run business is a must try. For Chinatown to have multiple Chinese places this spot is the only one I go to for home cooked Vietamese food. My usual is the beef pho and shrimp rolls. Everything is served hot and ready!! If you love authentic pho it's a must try!! Eat on!

25.description: the food is ok, but theres this younger dude waiter/clerk there who just stares at you with this blank retarded face when you order or say anything to him. outside of that, it's fine

12.description: It's really hard to make it over to Argyle for pho every time. That's why I am so happy to have Cafe Hoang in Chinatown. I would stick to their pho and salads. Their beef pho is spot on. The broth is light and beefy. The noodles are usually nice and chewy but other times a bit too soft. The beed they serve in the pho is also good. Not too fatty but still flavorful with the right texture. It's no frills because they give you just sprouts, lime, and basil. But it's all you really need when the pho itself is good.I always get the spicy pork and shrimp salad. It is so fresh! A real nice texture and flavor to get your appetite going. Also, you feel good about eating salad before eating all those carbs and fats in pho.

59.description: This is my go to Pho spot.   You can never go wrong ordering the Pho here.  I always go with the #12 and an order of fresh Spring rolls. Prices are very reasonable.   Parking can be a challenge during the weekends.

21.description: My to go fix whenever I need pho! Fast, easy, and great quality noodles! Fills me up very fast and they give you good decent amount of meat.

17.description: This place gets props for being a Pho place in Chinatown to help out with the severe imbalance that is Argyle.  The pho here doesn't stand out at all.  If you asked me to describe how it may be different from other places I can't really tell you.  I've been here multiple times and I still don't know.  It's warm.  It's decent.  It's really convenient to get to.Mainly because this place is so close to where I'm living right now I'll be coming here more often and try their other dishes like bun buo nuong and bo luc lac as well as the softshell crab that they keep touting.

10.description: It's the only Vietnamese place within a reasonable driving distance. Their Vietnamese food is great. The restaurant are Northern Vietnamese, so dishes like Bun Bo Hue are more their specialty. Southern Vietnamese dishes like Bun Rieu are not as good. I always get their spring rolls because their big, fresh, and healthy as my appetizer. Cafe Hoang also offer Thai food. I've tried their Pad Thai and I didn't like it that much. I'm sticking with only the Vietnamese food. This is very popular too, but it seems like people are always coming in and out. So don't worry; you should have a table available when you arrive. There is a $10 minimum to use credit card, but order Bun Bo Hue and a drink, and you'll go over $10 just fine.

5.description: Bad service ! Bad attitude ! We had two bad experiences there that we could never go back. We traveled to Chicago for a conference. Due to pregnancy, I was dehydrated so I came in to order some drink to go: The lady responded to us that they only sell drink there, they cannot make it togo. They only made coffee togo. That made no sense to me.The next day before we left, my husband came to the shop. He sat down there for 15 minutes and no one greeted him. A waitress finally came to hand him a menu. He ordered a HOT coffee for now, and food in a little bit. The waitress then replied him with attitude that " We don't sell HOT Coffee, they only sell ICE coffee." That is ridiculous, they should know that ice coffee was first made by hot water  first then put ice after. In fact, it is about 28*F outside, we needed something warm..By doing this, they are trying to push customer away with bad experience and bad services. We will not go back here again !

3.description: Best Vietnamese cuisines ever!!! I highly recommend Bun Bo Hue, Pho noodle, and rare beef salads! So authentic!

35.description: Out of ALL the PHO places in Chinatown (Not the Arygle Chinatown), I vote here. Service is not great here at all but as far as pho, this is the best in Chinatown (I mean, I'm in Chinatown. My standards as far as customer service lowers instantly. It's all about the food!). I love the Bun Bo Hue and Bun Rieu. Plus, this place is run by Vietnamese people. Since I live very close to Chinatown I go here for my pho. If I were in Argyle, maybe I'll give elsewhere a shot but in Chinatown, here....definitely.I've tried other places that serve pho: The Noodles, Hing Kee (rather have their fresh homemade hand pulled noodles) and Joy Yees (rather have their 1001 other food items on their menu)...and none of them were as good as here.

19.description: I love Chinatown!  I love that you can go into just about any restaurant in Chinatown and get an amazing meal for not a lot of money.  Cafe Hoang was delicious, inexpensive, and fun.My 9 year old son picked this place out because he liked the pictures of the food in the window :)  We walked in, and got seated immediately.  Our waitress couldn't speak a lick of English, but she was so sweet and nice it didn't really matter.  I learned that you just point to the menu to tell her what we wanted.  My son thought this was so cool, it was like being in a foreign country.We ended up getting an order of egg rolls, Pad See Ew with Chicken, chicken satay skewers, and some steamed rice.  The food was just delicious.  The pad see ew was fresh, and definitely one of the best I've ever tried.  The satay skewers were perfectly cooked and had a delicious seasoning on them.  Egg rolls were perfect- not too greasy, yet packed with delicious fillings and fried perfectly.  I've never had a bad meal in Chinatown, and today's was no exception.  I saw these guys have BYOB, so feel free to bring your own if you want.  The menu is in Thai, Vietnamese, and English, so ordering is a breeze.  Ambience is average, but the quality of the dishes makes up for anything it might be lacking.  Overall I'd highly recommend if you want some Vietnamese or Thai while in Chinatown.

28.description: We came here hung over and in search of some good food before hitting the road.  The egg rolls were oily, their cafe sua da was on point, and their bun bo hue needed some color--although most of the flavors were there.  I love places that put all the good fixings in their bun (i.e. cha, blood, meats, pork feet, etc).  My friend got the pho and i tired the broth, it is definitely on a sweet side, but was still ok.  The husband got the pork chop with rice and it came with eggs and a side of chinese sausage.  All in all, food was ok, service was great.. if you're close by and want a fix, this place will totally do it.

45.description: New owners... The price has remained the same however the quality and quantity isn't the same. The crab rangoon is awesome. For the 6.95 price of my pho with beef, it was a rip off. Not gonna come back. The waitstaff is not friendly or attentive.

33.description: My favorite Vietnamese place in Chicago. The pho tai, the lemongrass chicken, the grilled beef, the frog legs--all exquisite. The dishes are so inexpensive and the service so good I find myself never getting enough.

43.description: expensive, small portions, subpar service, and empty on a weekend... gg

2.description: Step 1) You have a pho craving and you need something to hit the spot, but you are far too lazy to drive to argyle.Step 2) you yelp some place in the west loop/chinatown and you find cafe hoangStep 3) you make it there. it looks like your typical dingy basic pho place. you realize that places like these sometimes really come through and give you a solid meal.  you notice tacky christmas lights (the large bulbs), but you chill on that. you are hungry.Step 4) you sit down at a table. an asian woman approaches the table in a no nonsense manner. she asks you what you want to order--only she doesn't say anything, she just looks at you. She continues to look at you.  You order the pho dac biet.  She walks away having not vocalized anything.Step 5)  You eat the pho and notice that the broth flavor is basic 6/10.  Noodles are okay and sometimes break on their own when you lift them up 6/10.  the pho extras are what you would expect 8/10.  The price 8.95 is makes you feel you probably won't come back again unless you are hung over 5/10

18.description: We had a table of about 12 and we were hungry! The staff was super friendly and accommodating. Their chicken pho is the best! Hard to find a good Vietnamese pho spot in china town. I would definitely go back when I visit Chicago.

41.description: It's hit or miss here, so you gotta know the right things to order. I didn't like their spring rolls, because there really isn't much substance. The roll was predominantly vermicelli, with thin layers of veggies and shrimp. So texture-wise it was pretty limp. But the Ground Crabmeat, Tomatoes Rice Noodle Soup (#019) was sooo delish and full of flavor! The broth was seafoody, spicy and a little sour. I assume most people go for their pho, but this is definitely worth a try - seeing as the pho got mixed reviews from our group.

52.description: Great pho!!!

50.description: When we don't feel like driving all the way to Argyle for Vietnamese food we come here. My husband was craving Pho so we stopped by here on Saturday. We started with the spicy rare beef salad with lemon. This is our favorite thing ever! It is such a delicious combination of flavors with the basil, peanuts, spice, onions, and lemon. We cannot get enough of this. We also were craving something fatty so we got the crab rangoons and they were an awesome guilty pleasure. My husband got the house special pho and I got #22 which was chicken and eggrolls on top of noodles mixed with veggies and basil. Very tasty and we had plenty leftovers to take home. Oh and I got the Mung bean drink. I love mung beans and this had nice little chunks of jelly, shaved ice, and condensed milk/coconut milk. Loved it! We will be back!

4.description: Delicious spring rolls; ours were huge! I've seen some other reviews that were bashing on them a little, but ours were larger than the pictures on here. The peanut sauce with them was delicious. Also a big fan of the Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk.The big star of the night was the stir-fried pan noodle dish with seafood and veggies. The noodles were perfect: wide, crispy and crunchy at the edges, but tender and soft in the middle. I seriously crave these noodles. Tons of seafood (shrimp, imitation crab, squid, mussels, fish cake) and good veggies as well. Some places skimp on the protein and get veggie-heavy, but this dish was well-balanced.I'd gladly visit again!

6.description: I wasn't expecting much already, but was not even good. Their Pho is okay I guess. I didn't like it, but my friends said theirs was okay. My boyfriend ordered a crab rangoon, which was really greasy for me. I would not go back. I'm sorry to keep it short, but I have nothing good to say about this place.

22.description: I love Chinatown!  I love that you can go into just about any restaurant in Chinatown and get an amazing meal for not a lot of money.  Cafe Hoang was delicious, inexpensive, and fun.My 9 year old son picked this place out because he liked the pictures of the food in the window :)  We walked in, and got seated immediately.  Our waitress couldn't speak a lick of English, but she was so sweet and nice it didn't really matter.  I learned that you just point to the menu to tell her what we wanted.  My son thought this was so cool, it was like being in a foreign country.We ended up getting an order of egg rolls, Pad See Ew with Chicken, chicken satay skewers, and some steamed rice.  The food was just delicious.  The pad see ew was fresh, and definitely one of the best I've ever tried.  The satay skewers were perfectly cooked and had a delicious seasoning on them.  Egg rolls were perfect- not too greasy, yet packed with delicious fillings and fried perfectly.  I've never had a bad meal in Chinatown, and today's was no exception.  I saw these guys have BYOB, so feel free to bring your own if you want.  The menu is in Thai, Vietnamese, and English, so ordering is a breeze.  Ambience is average, but the quality of the dishes makes up for anything it might be lacking.  Overall I'd highly recommend if you want some Vietnamese or Thai while in Chinatown.

15.description: If your looking for a quick pho fix without having to drive all the way to argyle, this is the place to be. The broth is good, trimmings are fresh, and staff is friendly. They also have very good spring rolls and the peanut sauce is on point.

57.description: Best Pho in town!

20.description: my favorite is the hue style spicy noodle soup. their noodle soups are authentic cooked by the viets and taste pretty good for the price. however, their service is lacking and take-outs aren't the best.

36.description: Good food. BUT, be prepared to possibly get bad service. Although we got decent service, my carpool guy told me service can be really bad at times--since he goes there often.However, no complaints here about service.FOODThe crab Rangoon lives up to it's name. It is very flavorful, flaky,and filled with all sorts of yum. I also  ordered the #14 house special noodle soup, described on their menu as: Slice Rare Beef, medium cooked, beef meatball, tripe, and tendon.  As a person that tries to eat less meat these days, it was very hard to feel guilty. After adding a little sriracha, I definitely did not want to share with my companion. It was the perfect meal to a rainy Friday evening.My companion ordered the shrimp pad thai, which was average, I suppose. I definitely have had better pad Thai (I've also had far worse).I will return to try out other menu items and may update this review. Meanwhile, I'm daydreaming about that delicious noodle soup.

14.description: My favorite Vietamese spot in Chinatown. This quaint family run business is a must try. For Chinatown to have multiple Chinese places this spot is the only one I go to for home cooked Vietamese food. My usual is the beef pho and shrimp rolls. Everything is served hot and ready!! If you love authentic pho it's a must try!! Eat on!

58.description: Like many others, we've been going there for BBQ Pork and other animals, since the other place's too greasy (the BBQ pork).  But if you over-look the 'age' of the place and their staff the food is okay.  The price is decent and you get what you pay for.  Just stop looking around and ignore the occasional fighting between the old ladies, you'll be fine.  They're just talking in outdoor voice.  Besides you don't need pretty decoration to go with yummy BBQ Porks.

56.description: This place isn't for everyone.  If you want fancy Chinese food then look else where.  But if you are looking for simply Chinese style BBQ food  and don't mind the "hole in the wall" style then this place is great.  The price is reasonable and the portion is usually big (not always consistent).  My favorite is BBQ duck and soy sauce chicken.

29.description: Had it for lunch. Good service, funny conversation between some old customers and the owner. I had the combo of roasted duck leg, soya chicken and BBQ pork.  The BBQ pork was really good that I had to order another lb to bring back! Roasted duck was good too. Soya chicken is a little bit plain, lots of food. If you eat there, come with soup! The rice quality is so so. But great Value! Will definitely come back!

42.description: I came here for a quick lunch with a friend. The waitress was really shy she just brought menus and scurried to some room in the back. I ordered the 'bbq duck with rice' and waited for about 20 minutes. Again the waitress said nothing and just wrote it down. When the food finally came I was shocked, the rice was hard it was probably from the day before. Some parts of the rice were mushy and cold others were hot. The duck was nasty too, some parts of it were cold and hot. I didn't say anything and just stopped eating. My friend had ordered a dumpling soup and claimed it was good. So we finished and paid. We assumed the tip was included in the bill but it wasn't. After we had left, the shy waitress chased us and asked for a tip. I thought it was weird. She said her boss didn't pay her and she would just keep the tips as payments.I felt really uneasy about the whole experience good thing I did not get sick from the food. Never going back there again.

23.description: Yes there are tons of Chinatown restaurants offer better atmosphere, but the food deserve 5 stars. They have the true Cantonese home made cuisine, I'm native Cantonese so I def know it. Among all the Cantonese restaurants, Minghin is best for fine dining, Cai is great for dim sum, but only Great Wall makes me feel homesick. Highly recommend white cut chicken白切鸡, soy sauce chicken豉油鸡 & roast duck烧鸭, whose tastes are equivalent as top restaurants in Canton, China. Cha sui叉烧 is not that excellent, but still one of the best in Chicago. Roasted pork belly烧腩肉 is only average.

47.description: The first time I wanted to go to the Great Wall I walked out because it was packed.  The second time I attempted to give it a try I ignored the crowd and sat down at one of the empty tables.  This restaurant doesn't just taste like home cooked Chinese it *IS* home cooked Chinese and it appears that all the locals in the area agree as most pick up their take-out orders in giant droves.  Their barbeque is *AMAZING* and their egg rolls are *ENORMOUS*.  The food is prices very reasonable and you get huge portions.  I agree with Lina W. that the waitresses don't speak much  English but I think it creates this other world that literally makes a person feel like they are visiting a random restaurant in China and isn't that the point of Chinatown?  As most restaurants in Chinatown the Great Wall will validate your parking if you park in the lot off of Cermak and sit down for a spell. I can assure you that you won't be disappointed.

8.description: Okay bbq at an okay price. My friend and I split a pork and duck bbq combo. The pork was a bit too fatty and chewy for my taste and the meat overall was kind of oily. But, it wasn't terrible.I'm sure there's better Chinese bbq in Chinatown though. I suppose try this place if you've got no other alternatives.

31.description: They speak a little English. I wanted to order a "Noodle Soup" but I accidentally got a "Noodle soup without soup" and it was fantastic! (the soup came in a separate bowl.) It's not on menu, but the other Chinese customers were having the same thing. So it must be a popular dish for them. Noodle was thin yellow egg noodle, dumplings and Chinese broccoli were on it. Hope I can order the same thing next time.

34.description: After eating at several other restaurants in Chinatown, this has become the go to place for great food, great portions and a great price.  The duck is among the best, with crispy skin and very meaty,  when the dishes come out, we always comment on how much food comes for the price.  The wonton noodles soups are very good and we share it with dinner.  The singapore noodles and chow mein dishes are excellent.  We have never had a disappointing dish here and this is about the cheapest place in all of Chinatown and one of the best imho.  It is small and seems fairly empty most of the time, but don't let that discourage you from visiting this hole in the wall.  This was Chinatown, before the newcomers came and bought up the old places and renovated them!

16.description: I came and I was going to dine in but the place so very warm / hot; no air condition, so I decided buy whole Duck & 1.5 lb. of BBQ Pork for TO GO, when I got home tasted the Duck & the BBQ Pork theirs no taste at all; the BBQ Pork was so hard and dry.  I was watching the butcher cut the Duck into half she shop the small half portion and the grab another whole duck and split it and shop the small portion and combine it with suppose to one whole duck that I paid for. I just waste my $35.00 garbage food.I will not buy in this Restaurant again.

13.description: We were here last week.We had the 3 items BBQ wonton egg noodle.The 3 items we had were white cut chicken, soy sauce chicken androast pork.I also added half a roast duck.We also had the seafood chow noodle.Everything still relatively cheap.

11.description: nasty place with nasty attitude. The price keeps rising but the qulity of the food and service keeps dropping. whatever, this isn't the only bbq place in town. Don't have time to deal with irrational owner.
