20.description: I left this restaurant feeling queasy and like I never wanted to have Chinese food again in my life. Even though I knew what items I got, I still felt like each item was a "cafeteria special" aka random leftover meats. The service was bad and none of the waiters could even explain what the different items they were rolling around were. I'm all for stepping out of my culinary comfort zone but I definitely won't be coming here again.

36.description: What can I say, it's the end of an era. Phoenix used to be the best Chinese food IN TOWN. Not just Chinatown but all of the Chicagoland Area. They had a wonderful staff to match their exquisite food. They were packed ALL the time. But I guess all good things have to come to an end.. The Remodel was the beginning of that end. It went from an out-of-date, large but slightly cliché, 90s Chinese restaurant (just from appearance) to a lush, modern and shiny new establishment. Unfortunately, that's not where the change stopped... At the beginning of the sumer, ownership switched hands and let me say it was NOT for the better. My family has been coming here regularly for two decades and I think today may have been our last. First, the entire staff that had been working there for the whole time we had been coming was replaced with a younger staff. Sure their English is better but they also stopped trying. Little things like walking around your table as they refill your water, not a huge deal, but when my 81 year old grandma is reaching a glass across a table to a 20 year old guy it starts to look ridiculous. The lack of liquor license is certainly not helping either...I don't know how to put this best but the most heartbreaking part is the degradation of the food. It's still relatively tasty but bland compared to how outstanding it used to be. It's sad because Phoenix really did crash and burn but unlike the name suggests, it did not rise again from its ashes.

14.description: Abysmal service. Food was hit or miss.My wife and I arrived for dim sum on a Sunday at about 1:30 pm and was told it would be about 30 minutes for a table. No problem. We knew this place was popular and were totally expecting a wait (it ended up being closer to 40 minutes, but I'm not complaining). Phoenix Restaurant apparently no longer does the traditional Dim Sum experience of bringing carts around to the tables and allowing diners to select items; rather, the diner selects items on a menu and then the food is brought out, making it far more similar to a typical tapas restaurant than anything else. Not totally what I was expecting, but not a deal-breaker.After we were seated, it became clear that the restaurant operates under some degree of chaos. We were never sure who we were supposed to provide our order to and ended up with a few flummoxed servers (I think?) who took our order. Then another (that we had to flag down) for water and soy sauce. A few of our items came out. The spring rolls were good, if a bit greasy. The steamed pork buns were nice. The pan-fried chive patties were delicious. I would like to comment on the other things we ordered, but they never showed up. Except for some gelatinous-looking (and feeling, and tasting) shrimp and cilantro dumplings a full FIFTY minutes after ordering.Frustrated, we left, taking our order sheet to the cashier and paying for the items we actually received. They didn't charge us for the items we ordered and didn't receive, which was nice, but there was nothing in the form of an apology. At least comp us our tea (your cost on a pot of tea is what...four cents?). Then, the cashier told us we could leave a tip at our table. A TIP? For what????We definitely had dim SOME, but I'm going someplace else next time. What a joke.

29.description: I can't stop coming here for a midnight snack these couple of days. Their platters are usually good (a bit oily but will change if you ask them when ordering for less oil/ salt). The dishes really hit the spot for me. The salt and pepper squid is crispy and adequately salty with the garlic and jalepeno peppers. I loved it!The veggie dish (tong vegetable with garlic) was overcharged (we were charged the regular menu price for a midnight snack dish size)... Rice is charged $0.50 per bowl. It was still great. The second time we came we ordered the black mushroom with soft tofu ("japanese tofu"). It was a delicious experience as well. The mushrooms were sweet and soft. The tofu was pretty crispy with a soft texture after biting through the shell. I loved the taste that was preserved. All due to the good wok heat. :)I totally recommend this place. The service was a bit horrible (due to a huge party at the ungodly hour that we went... midnight). We were there for more than an hour because of waiting for the dishes. It was fine. I still enjoyed my food. They're good for pick up as well. Ordered here several times. We just need to call in to order about half an hour prior to pick up.

42.description: Going to TC is where I get my Chinese food fix. This is not an egg foo yung or shrimp fried rice type of joint, but a  good authentic Chinese seafood place. I brought my caucasian coworker and his wife to TC, but I ordered all the food. They hated squid, but I stll ordered the salt/ pepper squid anyway, his wife and him ate the whole order before the end of the night. Some other dishes I always order are the black bean clams, honey/ walnut shrimp, steamed oysters, Chinese style fried chicken, but the plain steamed chicken with the ginger scallion sauce is also very good. You can't go worng with the thick rice noodles with beef either. They have live lobsters, crabs, and fish in tanks that you can pick out for dinner at the old TC, but I have not been to the new one yet. They might still have that half price special after 10 pm?

23.description: articles.chicagotribune.…Everyone should read this before comparing the two...food for thought.

47.description: Decent food, albeit salty and oily. But it's Chinatown, that's par for the course. I liked the honey walnut shrimp and the beef ho fun. They gave us soup and this soupy dessert on the house. Wasn't crazy about either but it was free so I can't complain. After dinner I had to walk around for a bit because I felt disgusting. Oh Chinatown, how I love to hate you.

8.description: Went with my girlfriend Toey and her cousin Sitthichai, his wife recommended this place, what a huge mistake. No Dim Sum, the whole reason we came to Chinatown is to get some Dim Sum, very disappointed too start out with. Our orders took for ever. One dish at a time. We ordered 3 main entrees and appetizer. By the time we got our 3rd dish we were stuffed. Continuing on the quality of the food, it was greasy and did not taste fresh. First I order the dumplings for appetizer, was ok. The the shrimp almonds...too much mayo. The next entree beef short ribs, beef tasted rubbery next fish tasted so greasy and finally got the last took forever the leafy green, that was only best part of the meal. Next time I come to Chinatown. I will never come here, also the price was a rip off, paid almost $70.00 for lunch, remember it was lunch not dinner...argggg. I'm Still searching for my Dim Sum.

31.description: I can not support a place that serves shark fin soup, when I tried to ask them if there were actually shark fins in the soup (illegal) they pretended not to understand what I was asking. Totally irresponsible. I understand it is a traditional dish but it is now 2012 and we know better, it is not sustainable.On another note, a bathroom in a train station would be more clean that Triple Crowns. Gross.

34.description: TRIPLE CROWN!! I grew up on this food!! Ever since I was little: birthday? Triple Crown! Wedding? Furama! But thing is, you just never tire of the food even though you can find the same dishes everywhere in Chinatown. And I've most defiantly strayed from Triple Crown, but I just end up going back even though the waiters (an integral part of Triple Crown) have left and the place has switched owners, remodeled, and all that jazz because the food is good and it's great for large parties. The atmosphere is just right, you know? The food is great, not good, not bad; I don't know what it is, but we just keep on coming back! After the huge name fiasco, I'm very disappointed that the Triple Crown dim sum got to keep the name because it was/is an integral part of the restaurant.

16.description: I can't stop coming here for a midnight snack these couple of days. Their platters are usually good (a bit oily but will change if you ask them when ordering for less oil/ salt). The dishes really hit the spot for me. The salt and pepper squid is crispy and adequately salty with the garlic and jalepeno peppers. I loved it!The veggie dish (tong vegetable with garlic) was overcharged (we were charged the regular menu price for a midnight snack dish size)... Rice is charged $0.50 per bowl. It was still great. The second time we came we ordered the black mushroom with soft tofu ("japanese tofu"). It was a delicious experience as well. The mushrooms were sweet and soft. The tofu was pretty crispy with a soft texture after biting through the shell. I loved the taste that was preserved. All due to the good wok heat. :)I totally recommend this place. The service was a bit horrible (due to a huge party at the ungodly hour that we went... midnight). We were there for more than an hour because of waiting for the dishes. It was fine. I still enjoyed my food. They're good for pick up as well. Ordered here several times. We just need to call in to order about half an hour prior to pick up.

13.description: FYI this is the original triple crown only by location, it's different owners.Quality wise, it's not bad.  I would say the service could use some help, they have a decent amount of staff for the place but it was so dead no one wanted to do anything. We were there on a Sunday night and we were 1 of 5 tables, and 1 of the other tables were actually family of the owners or something from the way they talked to them.These are authentic cantonese style dishesSalt and Pepper Squid and baby squid - not bad. nice texture and flavor, the baby squid was nasty though, rehydrated dehydrated stuff.Fish Fillet w/ Broccoli - Real smooth solid fish with the right amount of give and perfectly cooked broccoli with a nice snap to it.Salt and Pepper Beef Short Ribs - this was ok, not a huge amount of flavor but the beef was tenderBeef Stew Casserole w/ Eggplant - wasn't bad but hte eggplant was mushywalnut shrimp - made with salad dressing not mayo, it wasn't great, but hte walnuts were really crispy which was greatsalt and pepper shrimp w/ shell - remember eat the shell! ignore the tail.  it was very good, nice and crispy and good enough salt and pepper flava (jalapeno peppers)

11.description: I was very disappointed in my first order from Triple Crown. I only ordered from here because my usual Chinese take-out wasn't taking GrubHub orders. I ordered two things: the walnut shrimp --- there's basically three ingredients: shrimp, walnut, and mayo (sometimes honey)... but I have NO idea why this thing was flavored with Orange/Lemon. It just was not palatable with the shrimp and mayo. It's like they were too lazy to clean out the orange chicken pan when they cooked this shrimp dish. Blechhh.The next item I typically like to order was the salt and pepper pork chop. Usually these are actual pork chops. But I feel like the pieces I got where the "leftovers" if you know what I mean. No generous portions. All breading. AND to top off my disinterest in finishing my meal, it was sprinkled all over with MSG. Thanks for trying to ruin my organs. Oh, and those 2 items... $30. Too expensive for less than great quality food.

39.description: Note: This review is for the late night menu only (10pm - 2am) This is my favorite restaurant in the city and my go-to spot late night. I love the hundred flavor trinity -- hundred flavor chicken, hundred flavor beef, and hundred flavor shrimp. Pair that with a vegetable dish and I'm a happy camper. After 10pm, the late night menu starts, and the prices are much more reasonable. Dishes are $6 instead of $10 (ballpark estimates) for smaller servings, so its great if you like trying different things. The food at the original tastes better to me than the new one that's on Wentworth Ave. The other difference is that the new triple crown serves alcohol while at the original you get to bring your own. If you like Cantonese style Chinese food, this is a great place to go after a night of partying. Get a group of friends together and order maybe 2 dishes per person and share everything!

37.description: My family always come here for family dinners because the prices are cheap and the portions are big. We normally take up 2 tables when we're here so this is the place to go if you have a budget and a big family to treat.  The food to me is very oily and greasy. When it's busy the service is VERY slow. Sometimes it'll take 30 minutes for ONE dish to come out after we ordered. Then right after, a whole bunch of dishes come out at once creating clutter on the lazy Susan/table. I personally would prefer dishes to come out at a decent interval ensuring the customers have enjoyed  each dish that comes out, but the trend is: wait 30 minutes after you order the food, first dish comes out then every dish comes out at once. So if  you like to clutter your table and lazy Susan at once this is your place.The service here is good, people are nice. Owner is very nice.

0.description: Favorite authentic Chinese restaurant! Our usual dishes are salt and pepper silky tofu, eggplant casserole, lemon chicken and satay beef.

38.description: The last time we stopped by here we were turned away because of remodeling.  Now, they are back in business! I had never been here before, but it was a family gathering that brought me here.  The food here was good and even the elderly relatives loved it. We had the fish soup, jelly fish, sweet and sour pork, crispy chicken,  scallops, calamari and veggies, steamed fish, abalone, salt and pepper shrimp, and a bunch of other stuff I can't remember! I just know the food was good and was not filled with MSG (because one of my relatives is allergic).  An extra bonus was that the bathrooms were clean and heated!! Big portions and great taste!

51.description: This is not the original Triple Crown! This is the original location, but not the restaurant! The original moved to Wentworth.

27.description: We are very discerning about Chinese food and spent a good half hour debating where to eat in china town tonight. We both felt good about this place and we weren't disappointed. Hundred flavored shrimp (peeled), clams in black bean sauce and Szechuan green beans were really wonderful.  Ask for the chili oil, it's great.

32.description: Good affordable option for large-portion family-style Chinese food in Chicago Chinatown.

54.description: OMG!!! Thank you so much for re-opening!!!! I used to come here almost twice a week and was having withdrawls from not coming here!!!!! The food is to die for and I could eat it everyday!  The new TC was not cutting it.  I prefer the ambiance and staff here over the "classy" TC anyday!!! Come late night for great food and great deals! Also, it's BYOB!!!!

48.description: this place deserves NEGATIVE stars. I've eaten at this "original" triple crown for years. That is, until only recently. I've since gone over to the other Triple Crown on Wentworth. This restaurant has the worst service. Led by the female maitre d'. She always used to bring us to the table just underneath a large TV, where it's quite noisy, or brings us to the table closest to the bathroom (and the restaurant isn't even that busy). She refused to take us to the good tables, so we ask us if we can sit somewhere else. She hands us the menus and tells us to go ourselves. What kind of service is this?Next, after sitting at our tables for a while, the servers would take about 10 minutes to come over and take our order. Still, no tea or water at our table. We had to ask for it.Food comes - portions are fairly generous, but it's too salty, too oily, and MSG. We always ask that our food be prepared without the salt, oil, and MSG, since we are allergic. They didn't care. They just added ladle upon ladle of the crap unto our food. We ask for our bill about 10 minutes after getting our food since it's really not edible. They give it to us, and we pay with credit card (chinese restaurants prefer you pay in cash instead of c.c. cause they can hide their earnings "under the table" without reporting it to the IRS- as I've been told by friends who have worked in the industry). we paid, then started to make our way out of the restaurant. The maitre d' stops us, and tells us" don't ever come back to my restaurant. you're not welcome here". and she starts using the hand motions to wave us out of the place.What the fuck. I don't ever deserve to be treated with such rudeness and outright discrimination. The maitre d' is right on only one point - I won't ever be going back to "YOUR Restaurant". You don't even own the place bitch. I've discovered the Triple Crown on Wentworth, although quite pricey, to be MUCH better in service and quality.

44.description: When I use to live in SF, the first place I would go when I am visiting my friends and family in Chicago is Triple Crown. No one I know can make salt and pepper anything the way they make it here. The Salt & Pepper Smelt, is the best!! But I love the Japanese Tofu and my BF and his family love the Squid. Yes, it is a whole in the wall and yes they open another location but this is where i have been going since college for the cheap late night menu. Which will also include the beef and broccoli Chow fun, extra crispy noodle, the string bean and pork, and if there is three of us then the black bean and clams.  I also ask for their vinegar and use to dip the smelt and chow fun to add some sour to it.

24.description: Very authentic Chinese food. The service is usually pretty good when there aren't a lot of people. I absolutely love their food!

7.description: THE Original Triple Crown Restaurant, not to be confused with the Triple Crown Restaurant.  Personally, I would have gone with Quadruple Crown, step it up a notch, but that's neither here nor there.  This place is SERIOUS about family style in terms of the portion.  The BEEF CHOW FUN I ordered could have probably fed a small country.  It was a mountain of tender beef, Chinese broccoli, carrots and sauce over nicely cooked wide flat rice noodles.  All for $10!  Salt & Pepper Pork $9 - Very large portion of pork served with a side of rice.  Always a favorite.Salt & Pepper Squid $10 - Again, big portion and very tasty.  Who knew salt and pepper can be so delicious?  These guys!  They pretty much offer S&P everything - pork chop, squid, crab, soft shell crab, blue crab, shrimp, fish fillet, smelt fish, duck's low jaw (whaaat?), and duck tongue (double whaaat?).The waitress was fast and friendly.  She brought us hot tea right away and glasses of cold water.  We were a medium size group but she didn't mind giving each of us separate checks.  I was surprised that this place was hopping at 11:30P on a weeknight!This place is open late (until 2AM everyday) and offers a special late night menu between 10:00P and 2:00A with about half the portion and half the price (w/o rice).

49.description: The last time I came here we had a birthday party with at least 35 people and the restaurant accomodated us very well. They had 2-3 servers working on our tables and being the first table the servers reach my table ended up getting the food first. Score! BYOB! You can never go wrong with that! My family and friends enjoy drinking so of course they took advantage of it and brought heineken and bottles of Hennesy (sp?). I'm surprise the restaurant workers did not complain to us as to how LOUD we were. You probably could of heard us down the block! The food was really good this time. I believe we started off with shark fin soup (I never had it before so i have no comparison), but I thought it was flavorful. The crab was nicely cooked in the ginger and onion, yumm so tasty. Our beef chow fun was extra crispy *drools* (it's always the best when it's extra crispy!). I can't remember the rest, but I remember stuffing my face and feeling so full that I was about to burst!I'm sure I'll be back.

40.description: good Restaurant to go to at night with a group of people! out of all the restaurants in chinatown i have been to, i think this place makes the best salt and pepper shrimp and walnut shrimp ... the flavor is on point and overall its a great place to eat at.

53.description: First off, I want to give this place NO stars.  But, my Singapore Rice Noodles was tasty.This was by far the worst restaurant experience I have ever witnessed!  I have worked in the restaurant biz for 15 years now and I have been in the weeds many a time.  This restaurant couldn't find its way out the weeds with a team of machetes and a GPS.  We went there on Chinese New Year, expecting to be busy and have a wait.  That wasn't really the issue.  The issue was waiting  20 minutes for the complimentary tea.  Watching all of the tables around us warming themselves on their tea but us sipping on our water, knowing early that there was no way we going to get refills on our water.  When we placed the order, 3 soups, mongolian beef and a very delicious and authentic sounding salty fish and pork belly dish.  The server informed me that its a 20 minute wait for the pork belly dish.  Alright I said, I'll take the Singapore Rice Noodles.  Off she runs to the next table.  30 minutes later we get the mongolian beef dish.  No soup for us!  10 minutes later we manage to wave down somebody, anybody and inform them that we hadn't received the soups or the other entree.  Much confusion on their part, server comes over and looks bewildered and lost.  We explain skip the soup and just bring out the other entree.  10 minutes later, 2 of the 3 soups arrive.  Ok great, where is the other one?  5 minutes later the other soup shows.  15 minutes after that my entree finally shows.  The server warns me about a 20 minute wait for a dish and I wait an hour for a standard Chinese dish?  I decide there is no way I am waiting for a server to bring a bill, so I venture up to pay and am very rudely ignored by a manager.  Matter of fact she tells me to wait so she can speak to somebody that just walked up in front of me!  Then promptly ignores me again.  I tell her that I don't really have to pay I can just walk out at this point!  I tell her that I am crazy to even be standing here right now!  Suddenly a bill appears, soups on there that I told to be cancelled!  As I left I told all 15 people waiting to be seated to run while they can!

30.description: We ordered our food at 7:20, deliver time quoted as 8:18. OK, I can deal with that. The time comes and goes. I call the restaurant. I am told the driver is right around the corner. 15 minutes later I call back to the restaurant, I am told the driver is in my lobby. I call my doorman, who tells me no one is there. He arrives 5 minutes later. (just getting started)The food....first of all it's called de-veining!!!!! Every single shrimp looked like it just pushed back from a hearty thanksgiving meal. YUCK.  The fried rice smelled like it was prepared in a sealed room with 20 chain smoking cooks. Of course all the food was cold.On a bright spot the Crab Rangoon was tolerable, and might even be good had it been even luke warm.  I don't know what former glory this place might have had to warrant some of these rave reviews, but it could not possible be this place.  As my good friend always says "what in the wide, wide world of sports is going on here?!?!?"

46.description: I have been going to this "original" Triple Crown for years and am the biggest fan of the late night menu.  It's the best deal and awesome food!  It's also one of the cleanest CT restaurants IMHO.The BYOB policy makes it extra awesome, but I haven't advantage of that yet.  Stand out items are salt and pepper pork chop, shrimp with scrambled egg and sauteed ong choy (sp?) with garlic and olive oil.  Heavenly.There is a language barrier so, when in doubt, just point to the item you want.

1.description: It's everything I ever dreamed. I almost (almost) organized our whole short trip to Chicago around eating dim sum. After reading the other reviews, I settled on Triple Crown (largely based on the fact that it was a few hundred yards closer to the CTA station than the other place). Lots of people were huddled outside the front door and I was afraid we would be in for a long wait. However we walked up the stairs and were seated IMMEDIATELY. Next thing we knew we had tea (which to my unrefined tastebuds just tastes like warm water..but still!) on our table and the dim sum menu. Oh, sweet heavens. Ordered: pan fried dumplings. taro cake. bbq pork buns. custard roll. custard buns. lotus buns. rice in lotus leaf. The BEST: Pan fried pork dumplings. OH. MY. GOSH. is all I can say. we ordered an extra order and stuffed ourselves and then saved the remaining for breakfast. bbq pork buns. What is IN this deliciousness?? Sticky rice: good portion and yummy. The least: Custard roll. Simple and sweet but tastes like a fancy twinky. Of course, it wasn't bad. just takes up room in your tummy that should be saved for the stuff listed above. They did forget a couple things we ordered (which was fine...there was no room left in our bellies) but did not charge it. That plus the fact that I've only got minimal dim-sum experience means I'm giving it 4 stars. but I really, REALLY want to give it five. This place is AMAZING!

9.description: Wow, I was disappointed with this place.  Perhaps I should have ordered some of their other, more authentic dishes but my roommate and I decided to give them a try getting sesame chicken and orange chicken, which were highlighted on their grubhub page. My roommate disliked it so much, she decided to write/joke about "nasty chinese food" on social media.The meat had way too much breading and not enough actual meat, both of us noted that in both orders and my roommate said she noticed a slight burned taste. Yikes.Each order was ordered with rice and yet our bag only came with one box of rice, so we ended up splitting the rice and I didn't call the driver back because I decided to just cook white rice if needed. The sauce was like goop, thickened. The flavor wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as well made sauce.I've had way better Chinese food for less or the same price, so I was not impressed and would be unlikely to order again without a recommendation for a specific food item from someone I trust.Positive points- The broccoli in my sesame chicken was well cooked, not too soft or hard. The portion sizes are huge, so if the food was tasting really good, it would have been awesome. The driver was nice and came within the estimated time. For delivery, the prices are reasonable though the quality doesn't quite match.All in all, we were pretty disappointed and after some bites, I started feeling a bit nauseated. I tried to add some ingredients and spice it up to make it taste better, which helped, but not enough. Perhaps these type of Americanized dishes are not their strong suit.

26.description: We love this place, come here as much as we can. The food is a bit oily but they can fix it if you ask them. The food is also very nicely priced. Just had a party of 7 come here and were filled with just $67 worth of food. (2 salt & pepper squids, Chinese broccoli and beef, Chinese broccoli and chicken, Shrimp in lobster sauce, Mongolian beef)The best dish for us has to be Salk & Pepper Squid. Amazing!

25.description: THE Original Triple Crown Restaurant, not to be confused with the Triple Crown Restaurant.  Personally, I would have gone with Quadruple Crown, step it up a notch, but that's neither here nor there.  This place is SERIOUS about family style in terms of the portion.  The BEEF CHOW FUN I ordered could have probably fed a small country.  It was a mountain of tender beef, Chinese broccoli, carrots and sauce over nicely cooked wide flat rice noodles.  All for $10!  Salt & Pepper Pork $9 - Very large portion of pork served with a side of rice.  Always a favorite.Salt & Pepper Squid $10 - Again, big portion and very tasty.  Who knew salt and pepper can be so delicious?  These guys!  They pretty much offer S&P everything - pork chop, squid, crab, soft shell crab, blue crab, shrimp, fish fillet, smelt fish, duck's low jaw (whaaat?), and duck tongue (double whaaat?).The waitress was fast and friendly.  She brought us hot tea right away and glasses of cold water.  We were a medium size group but she didn't mind giving each of us separate checks.  I was surprised that this place was hopping at 11:30P on a weeknight!This place is open late (until 2AM everyday) and offers a special late night menu between 10:00P and 2:00A with about half the portion and half the price (w/o rice).

12.description: Always favorite spot to go grab Chinese food for birthdays and midnight snacking. It's super delicious.

21.description: Food-wise, this place is good and the portions are fair. However, this review is only based off the few common/safe entrees i usually order from this place: - shrimp fried rice- walnut shrimp- salt and pepper fish- salt and pepper squid- short-ribs

17.description: My friends come here all the time. It's like their favorite spot in the city! So they are a huge group of college boys. If you come here during a school break or weekend, and see a huge group of Asian boys being all loud and silly, it's probably them. Now, I will tag along every once in a while. They are very group friendly, like 10+ people friendly. And they close at 2am, so if you are looking for a big dinner with a big group of friends this will be your kind of place. Now as for the food, it's quite decent for its price and portion. Personal favorite: Salt and pepper silk tofu Peatips Salt and Pepper short ribs Walnut shrimpI am going to be honest. This is not my to-go place. The interior design haven't changed for a decade+ and it looks worn down. This is like one of theose old school Chinese restaurants on tv. However, the food is pretty good and they welcome huge groups!!

10.description: We came here late at night after our plans fell though. The order- hot and sour soup, general tso chicken, Orange beef and orange chicken and salt and pepper squid.I made my friends crawl under their chairs because I ordered the chicken fried rice... Ok I know this is Americanized Chinese food but I like it so? The waiter was polite and was even quick to put forks on the table (lol after I order fried rice) little did he know we can all eat with chopsticks!!The food came out hot and fast and was all very good!! It was really late so we ate a bit and packed up the rest. It was good!

5.description: Awesome authentic Chinese food. It might be hidden on a smaller street with a shadier location because it doesn't have a flashy sign or amazing interior modern decor. I don't really need any of that as long as you have good food.I was with a group of 4 and ordered 5 dishes.1) Tong choy with bean paste2) Steamed oysters with black bean sauce3) Clams with XO sauce4) Intestines with preserved vegetables5) Salt and pepper short ribs It was a lot of food for all of us, and we ended up having a lot of leftovers. The only dish I wasn't the hugest fan of was the intestines with preserved vegetables because the intestines weren't the texture I like the way intestines should be I guess. The preserved vegetables were good though. I think this place is quite authentic, and I would come back.There may be other Triple Crowns in Chinatown now, but this was the very first one. Must say something if it's still doing so well in an area with so many other Chinese restaurants. I'd definitely go back to try other dishes, especially authentic Cantonese ones.

3.description: Went there today to celebrate mom's bday and Xmas. Got the 10 course dinner for $179 (twin lobster dish included). Plenty of food. Very decent service. Nice owner too! Good food even though it was packed today. This is our usual spot for gatherings!

35.description: Came again with family and pretty good. I'll say more like 3.5 stars. Great prices and they give a lot. Service was pretty attentive.Clams in Black Bean Sauce - These were meaty and not mostly just shells. Black Pepper Beef - Pretty good flavor.Walnut Shrimp - Pretty good, just wished it had a little less mayo.Vegetables (Dow Mui) - Fresh and crunchy....I like it a little softer though.Chicken Dish - This was fresh and I like the sauce that came with it. Eggplant, Tofu and Green Pepper Stuffed with Shrimp - This was ok, I thought it had a bit of a burnt taste too it from that sizzling platter. I only ate the eggplant one, but my mom and sister didn't seem to care for the tofu.If you have a big group, this is a good choice as most tables sit 6-7 people.

19.description: I had the Lemon Chicken delivered.  It tasted like someone took lemon meringue pie filling and poured it all over some chicken.  Everything else on the menu might be delicious.  No fortune cookies.

28.description: First of all, if you don't know what "real" Chinese food is, then you won't like this place. Second of all, if you like "Americanized" Chinese food, then you should go to the Triple Crown restaurant on the main Chinatown street. For those who like free stuff, they give you free soup and dessert. It's missing a star because all they play on their TVs are 1980s Chinese shows...please play some new stuff =o)

45.description: Dear Triple Crown:Close down again, and I swear that good, innocent people will die.My family and I have been faithful patrons for years and when it closed down...well we were lost for a little bit.  But I am ever so grateful that it has  re-opened-Triple Crown Banquets didn't quite cut it. The food is to die for in all its tasty, greasy, Chinese goodness (Clams w/black bean sauce, the calamari, and the beef chow fun-extra crispy DO IT!!!).  800% of the menu is phenomenal.   TC is not a place to bring a date and woo him/her with its ambience.  There's nothing classy about it-but damnit this place is amazing. And it's BYOB and that makes it even more amazing.TC, I am headed your way in about an hour...Can't wait to be in you. Mmmm.

33.description: I'm always leery about eating in Chinatown but was forced to come here for a party. Needless to say, food was not good, overly greasy and maybe just too too authentic for my American tastes. Still hungy---Panda Expess here we come!

43.description: I'm always dragged here by drunk friends, but walk out loving it.  The breaded/salty squid is super good, and so is basically everything else I get.  All of your normal standbys are very good, and the service is efficient and good.  I'm always here late at night, so I can't comment on how the service is during normal business hours... usually we are just one of 3-8 tables occupied.I didn't realize that the OG was really the New-G-Old building.  Maybe I can convince everyone to go to the new one next time.

2.description: I haven't been here in YEARS. We used to come every year around Christmas for a family dinner/birthday celebration. Due to health issues and other things, that tradition stopped. We came here for dinner on Wednesday night and ordered the family style dinner for two tables. Some highlights? Salt and pepper beef short ribs, salt and pepper shrimp, green beans and orange chicken. Some not so good dishes? Clams in black bean sauce, Chinese style lobster and the steamed fish.Although the interior could be vastly improved, my traditional parents and aunt approved of the meal.

18.description: Good spot for cheap food in huge quantities but it's in Chinatown so that's every restaurant. Nothing stands out about this place at all. A bit dirty. mediocre service. Ok food.The other triple crown is by far better but is a bit more expensive

41.description: Found out about this place from some riding friends last year and I have not gone anywhere else in chinatown since, everything here is amazing, especially the mongolian beef, and anything salt and pepper!  I have literally driven down to triplecrown from the burbs late night  just to pick up food, and with their cheaper late night menu(10pm-2am) it is easy to overspend since you want to try everything! Cant wait to come back.

52.description: You can steal the name.  You can steal the crew, but you can't steal the caring service and the customer attention.  But you can steal the goodwill of 15 years and a great reputation.  Well, at least you can try...  and FAIL.Go to the NEW TripleCrownChicago.com on Wentworth and eat well and be happy.  It is opened until 2AM and the service is  G R E A T !!!  I go there every night.  Ask for the "On The Wild Side" Menu if you love good, spicy, tasty, fresh, non-oily healthy food.  Come to my table and say "Hello."  And you can Google me at "Chi Kung Gary"

50.description: Wow...4 days off in a row kid free! Hes at Grandmas! What to do that's oh so fitting when you have no curfew and are well rested. We found just the thing. Late night drinks at a few local bars and of course topped off with 1am Chinese cuisine. We feel 20 again! We haven't been out this late in so long. No better time to go than for their half price menu. Yeah portion are a bit smaller, but taste even better past midnight and you just can't beat the price. 2 bowls of rice Clams in bean sauce Fish fillets with Chinese broccoli Salt & pepper pork chops Blue crab-Hong Kong style. Which is crispy and served dry. If you want sauce try Thai style. 32 + tip! Are you serious??!!! And we have so much left over. Containers to go please!! leftover Chinese food is just as good as day 1.

4.description: Serendipitous find, just me and the Chief of Staff, looking for Dim Sum and we found it.  The staple when you're doing Dim Sum isn't rice, it's congee, and it's good here.  Add a variety of fried, steamed, buns, seafood, greens, variety is key and like many better Dim Sum places you get pictures here to help you out.  It was all good but we especially liked this lotus root bun, fried turnip cake, pork and shrimp dumpling, there were a couple of selections we couldn't get a translation for.  Their website has some tantalizing PICs but isn't fully functional. Open late but they don't always have the full Dim Sum menu, and that's their forte so call ahead.

6.description: Been coming here and still the best family style dinner in chinatown.  Love the tofu, smelts, steamed fish.

22.description: FYI this is the original triple crown only by location, it's different owners.Quality wise, it's not bad.  I would say the service could use some help, they have a decent amount of staff for the place but it was so dead no one wanted to do anything. We were there on a Sunday night and we were 1 of 5 tables, and 1 of the other tables were actually family of the owners or something from the way they talked to them.These are authentic cantonese style dishesSalt and Pepper Squid and baby squid - not bad. nice texture and flavor, the baby squid was nasty though, rehydrated dehydrated stuff.Fish Fillet w/ Broccoli - Real smooth solid fish with the right amount of give and perfectly cooked broccoli with a nice snap to it.Salt and Pepper Beef Short Ribs - this was ok, not a huge amount of flavor but the beef was tenderBeef Stew Casserole w/ Eggplant - wasn't bad but hte eggplant was mushywalnut shrimp - made with salad dressing not mayo, it wasn't great, but hte walnuts were really crispy which was greatsalt and pepper shrimp w/ shell - remember eat the shell! ignore the tail.  it was very good, nice and crispy and good enough salt and pepper flava (jalapeno peppers)

15.description: Came again with family and pretty good. I'll say more like 3.5 stars. Great prices and they give a lot. Service was pretty attentive.Clams in Black Bean Sauce - These were meaty and not mostly just shells. Black Pepper Beef - Pretty good flavor.Walnut Shrimp - Pretty good, just wished it had a little less mayo.Vegetables (Dow Mui) - Fresh and crunchy....I like it a little softer though.Chicken Dish - This was fresh and I like the sauce that came with it. Eggplant, Tofu and Green Pepper Stuffed with Shrimp - This was ok, I thought it had a bit of a burnt taste too it from that sizzling platter. I only ate the eggplant one, but my mom and sister didn't seem to care for the tofu.If you have a big group, this is a good choice as most tables sit 6-7 people.

20.description: Easily the most rancid Chinese food I've had since living in Chicago. Everything was covered in some sort of gelatinous ooze. I was drunk and it still didn't taste good. This place reminded me of one of those Chinese restaurants located out in the sticks...the one that gets in the local weekly newspaper after its owner gets caught serving rats and seagulls.

36.description: Come here due to late night hours, BYOB & I love spicy food so I always gettheir Hundred Flavor with Chicken (or is it thousand chicken?). In any case, it's in the menu, red font, can't miss it. Other than that, I don't really dine here often.

14.description: One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. Standard order is * salt & pepper squid* salt & pepper pork chop* salt & pepper smeltYou can't go wrong with any of those. Also I thought the good tasted better with no msg, maybe its just me.

58.description: I have been hoping around looking for places to eat ramen. The most important thing for me when it comes to ramen is the noodle. The noodles will make or break the ramen. Strings make their own noodles and it is cooked perfectly everytime. Some places that I go to the noodles break in your bowl and it is extremely soft. The noodles here have the perfect amount of crunch and is just cooked enough where it's not too hard. The broth is also one of the best in the city and there is no place that will cook a pork belly better than strings. The pork belly is not tough and it melts in your mouth. No one else's pork belly even come close. My least favorite ramen is the spicy house noodle, the one where you can pick your level of spiciness. I tried it a couple of time and find that it just lacks the depth of flavor like the rest. Overall the food is great, the only reason why I gave it a 4 star is because the service is not great. If they can improve their service and I don't have to sit there and wait and wait for someone to come to me and I have to make an effort just to get their attention, I will change it to a 5 star. Considering how small this place is, I expected the service to be better.

56.description: We came in a on a busy Friday night and even though the hostess says the wait was 35 minutes we only had to wait 20 minutes.  The ramen were great, not too salty or porky, just right.  We also ordered the wasabi string bean appetizer which was pretty good.  Overall, a good place to eat on a chilly Chicago evening.  Convenient location in Chinatown.   I have had better ramen before but this is pretty a solid choice as well.

29.description: Great ramen place. Rice bowls are also tastes. Cool and intimate atmosphere. BYOB which is always a plus. If your in china town it is a great option.

42.description: I don't know why people like this place, but it's not the best in chicago. Their soup base isn't good enough and their noodles are hard. I wouldn't highly recommend this place.

23.description: Recently saw a story stating they were one of the top 10 ramen places in Chicagoland. Since many places are in the burbs or Northside, I got excited about a ramen place so close to Bridgeport. Got the to Tonkotsu ramen.  Wanted the largest bowl they had on the menu, but they were out of a couple of ingredients. Instead got the "supreme" which was one step down. Ambiance - 3 out of 5 - could of done without the dubstepIngredients - 5 out of 5 - absolutely delicious and traditionally authentic to what you'd get in JapanPortion - 2 out of 5 - if I'm paying $18 for a bowl of ramen, I better be full at the end and I wasn'tSo take it all with a grain of salt. Ramen is expensive everywhere in Chicago, and I've yet to find a place where I feel the proportion to the cost were equal. I was spoiled living in Japan, and then moving back to Michigan where I could go to Matsu Chan in Canton.

47.description: My fiancé is vegetarian, ok, and I asked her to try the tonkotsu broth and she fell in love with it. She hates soups, and she hates the flavor of meat, but this broth won her heart. Try it out. You never know.

8.description: Pretty darn busy!  Pretty darn good ramen on a cold windy Chicago day!  Get ready to wait about 15-20 mins.  Found this small ramen shop thanks to fellow Yelpers.   I had the tonkotsu special (duck and chasu) and it was done just right.  Very generous with the chasu (huge piece) and the duck was med rare which was perfect.  Noodles lacked a bit of springiness like Ippudo (NYC) but I guess all ramen are different.  Soup was not very salty (which I prefer) and very rich and creamy which is what I expect in a tonkotsu.  Only gripe is that the soup was not piping hot for me (I prefer mine piping hot till the end).  Service was prompt and friendly.  They have a Hell Ramen contest if you can eat it in 20 mins then you get a $50 gift card and your bowl is free.  Not worth killing my gut for (imo).Enjoy!

31.description: Sorry do not waste your time at this restaurant. The look from outside is very deceiving. But inside is a night mare. The music in the room was too long and never herd such a horrible list on pandora. It gave me a headache. Then I got a stomachache too after eating their shitty food. I was served by a hippie who barley knew what he was stalking about so I decided go with a recommendation; which was this disgusting bowl of Pork stew. It was half cooked. Worst experience in my life. This is should be in Halsted not in China town. I take my business to Chi Cafe all day.

34.description: I got the hell ramen, and it was easily the hottest food I've ever eaten. I love hot food, I mean I eat el yucateca habanero sauce on everything as ketchup and this was unreal hot. I didn't even finish my ramen it was so hot. Not their fault, my fault. Great service, cool people we met, and good experience

16.description: Another ramen shop that I can cross off my list. I got a Tonkatsu Ramen. Smooth, creamy broth floating with sesame seeds that accompanies with earwood mushrooms, bamboo shoots, a slice of seaweed and pork belly (you can also opt to do pork loin for a leaner option). Noodles were fine, they are firm, but lacks the springiness I enjoy in ramen. Adding a egg comes as a side. It seems to be cooked in soy served with green scallions. Prepare for it to be a little cold and the egg yolk slightly gelly, just the way I like it. Overall 3.5 - a solid bowl of noodles, but not something I crave.I'm pushing it to a four because I thought the service was really good and I really liked their zen environment. World music fills the space and wipes out the normal chatter of a restaurant. Plants and lanterns fill the vertical area. Green tea is also served and yelp check in gives you 2 sticks of oden - more food! Unagi sauce with hot mustard - mix it or be prepared to get your sinuses cleared out immediately. I love that sauce!

13.description: This place has great ramen! I tried the tonkatsu ramen and it was amazing (but a bit overpriced). I was also surprised at how clean and well kept the restaurant was. Although the food and ambiance was great, the service could've been better. My table was barely checked up on and our waiter was not friendly. Overall, I would definitely come here again! I hope that they widen up the variety of ramen on the menu the next time I'm here!

11.description: Me and my boyfriend ate here and it was real yummy! My boyfriend got the ramen and I got the beef rice bowl. The food looked good, smelled good, and tasted good. Our waiter was a real cool dude he had blonde hair I should of asked for his name but he was real nice, helpful, and funny! He made our first time here one to remember. It's also BYOD our waiter was so nice we left him our last beer. Good job strings!

39.description: Strings is a pretty reliable place for ramen. I got the hell ramen level 2 my first time and it was really good! Pretty spicy but definitely manageable, especially because they give you a whole pitcher of water. This time I got level 3 and died a little. They aren't kidding and don't be fooled by 3 only being halfway to 5, it is VERY spicy. The noodles were maybe okay but the tiniest drop of the broth was death. I tried to cool the spice with the milk tea they have but it did not work at all. I ended up getting through the bowl but I think I would've enjoyed just getting a classic bowl of ramen a lot more. Moral of the story, definitely do know your own spice tolerance and take their warnings. Overall I still think it's a good ramen place though, usually pretty popular but they call you when it's your turn so it's not too bad. Not good for big groups either.

37.description: Came here for dinner last night. We've eaten at Strings twice before and I remember it being yummy. My fiancé and I ordered a Tonkatsu ramen with an egg. We were both disappointed this time. Their broth did not taste the same and their noodles were not good. Really disappointing. The only redeeming quality was that the egg was done perfectly. Will be scratching this place off our list of go to ramen spots.

0.description: Hell Ramen. That is the name of my Ramen. IMO its the best Ramen in the city. Every ingredient is best in class. i added a soft boiled egg to my soup, and it was a soothing, refreshing addition. The Hell Ramen some Stock with crispy pork rinds on tip. They are crack. loaded with.The service can be hit or miss. Or maybe the employees just don't give a shit because it was Sunday. not worth docking them a star for. This restaurant is the reason for our last 2 visit  Chinatown.It's also a great date spt. BYOB. Get wasted and ease the hangover all at the same time.

38.description: Good ramen, but a little on the pricy side. They prepare tasty renditions of Japanese street food, just above street food prices. Love the chilled out ambient trip hop music they play and they have that tasty milk tea that goes with ramen so well.

51.description: This place is always busy and is totally with the wait. It's sooooooo good. I love the Odon shoyu ramen. It is fantastic. I'll be back soon. Lol....

27.description: I'm not a ramen expert, but I've had some good stuff in New York, and this was among the best ramen I've had! I went pretty classic and ordered the Tonkatsu with pork belly and egg, which came in a pretty hearty portion that I enjoyed to the last drop. The broth was outstanding - it had such deep flavors and was so earthy, with almost a nutty taste. The soft-boiled egg (shoyu tamago) was also incredible - our server said they marinate them in mirin and something like star anise. And I really liked the square-cut noodles, which tasted really substantial and homemade.Service was attentive and efficient. The space is pretty cozy. Overall, a really fantastic place to stop off the red line for something warm and delicious during the winter months!

32.description: Love it! This was my first time eating at what I consider an authentic Ramen restaurant. Besides the instant rubbish I usually eat it is nothing compared to the food here. I ordered the Kamo Yakisoba, which was beautifully prepared. There was an abundant amount of duck, onion, and noodles. I had three sunny-side up eggs with three pepperoni sitting on top of the eggs of my dish. The eggs were wonderful seasoned. The meal was pretty fulling and I had leftovers. My order was placed over grubhub.com. I was told that it will take an hour for delivery, however it only took thirty minutes.

54.description: I always only order the pork belly tonkatsu, which is my favorite and a good portion for the price.

48.description: This is some sub par ramen. Ordered the Hell 2 and the broth hardly had any consistency. It's like drinking water with chili. If you want some good ramen go to Furious Spoon in Wicker Park.

44.description: The tonkatsu ramen was really good, the broth excellent. The noodles surprised me- they were more firm than I was prepared. I was expecting more decor from my bowl like Naruto or egg but didn't realize I could order them as like extra. Overall the food was good though.free My boyfriend had the level 2 hell bowl which was quite spicy for me but he loved it. The environment and the food was very good and I will go back for more.

24.description: I've made a couple trips here now and as they say 3rd time is a charm. For those of you not family with Strings it's one of the best Ramen shops in Chicago. Not only do you get an excellent bowl of Ramen you get top notch service(any and all servers will take care of you) you get educated(referring to their Ramen 101) This trip I tried their "Chicago style Hell Ramen" yep you guessed it this is not for the light hearted. Level 2 Kokujou (Chinese tian Jing red chili, szecchuan chili bean says and Thai Chili, shoyu broth based with asari, ground pork , crispy pork skin and hot pepper and chili straight from hell) honestly one of the best bowls of Ramen I've ever had. Super heat but a nice savory finish and very flavorful. Not a oily broth but just right I added bamboo and an egg. You will not be disappointed if you are a fan of quality Ramen and spice from hell! Merry freaking Christmas Chicago I'll be back !

7.description: Tasty but a bit expensive.  The duck and pork belly were cooked to perfection.  Broth was tasty and flavorful. Chili sauce and soft boiled egg are extra. Soft boiled egg could have been boiled a little softer. The noodles weren't the texture I expected but pleasant nonetheless. I do wish there were more noodles though.  Portion size is comfortably full for one. My meal was $20. Service was attentive.  He got busy with a rush though.  So it took a few extra minutes to pay.

49.description: Ramen is my weakness although I am nowhere near an expert and just started experimenting with the dish about a year ago.  I do like their ramen here but I've had better in the city. I would give the ramen a B-, I've had the tankatsu, the spicy miso, the kura buta (sp?) and just the pork.  I've also tried the hell ramen was pretty good but I think I could have gone up a level.  But I do understand why they wouldn't want someone burning their face off.  All quite good but I don't particularly like the noodles they make, the broth tends to be a little over salty, and the flavor just doesn't wow me like some other ramen bowls.The service is really what needs to be improved- long wait times, no greetings at the door (sometimes I almost feel downright awkward just standing there waiting), slow service at times, one waitress didn't seem to know all that much about ramen once.  So there is room for improvement on the service side.The environment is very cool and I love the decor.  It's a small place and you may have to wait but a lot of ramen joints are like this.  It's part of the charm in my opinion.I don't like that they charge extra for the eggs.

40.description: Just the type of food to hit the spot for a cold night. Got the Kuro Buta Tonkatsu Ramen and the wood ear salad. Should've ordered more noodles on the ramen. Since I heard they make their ramen in house, I had to try this spot. It didn't disappoint. The noodles had a good texture and tasted a tiny more floury than normal. The broth was very flavourful and drool-worthy. The wood ear salad was okay. It was definitely spicier than I imagined.

53.description: Another ramen shop that I can cross off my list. I got a Tonkatsu Ramen. Smooth, creamy broth floating with sesame seeds that accompanies with earwood mushrooms, bamboo shoots, a slice of seaweed and pork belly (you can also opt to do pork loin for a leaner option). Noodles were fine, they are firm, but lacks the springiness I enjoy in ramen. Adding a egg comes as a side. It seems to be cooked in soy served with green scallions. Prepare for it to be a little cold and the egg yolk slightly gelly, just the way I like it. Overall 3.5 - a solid bowl of noodles, but not something I crave.I'm pushing it to a four because I thought the service was really good and I really liked their zen environment. World music fills the space and wipes out the normal chatter of a restaurant. Plants and lanterns fill the vertical area. Green tea is also served and yelp check in gives you 2 sticks of oden - more food! Unagi sauce with hot mustard - mix it or be prepared to get your sinuses cleared out immediately. I love that sauce!

30.description: First time that I eat restaurant ramen and I loved it, and I was so full at the end but happy. I recommend this place 100%. The only thing is that you get out with your hair and clothes with that smell of food

46.description: You know the Marichan ramen noodles soups? Delete it from memory ASAP! After slurping my way through a bowl of seafood ramen here, I'm thoroughly convinced I was eating imitation crap during high school and university. The Seafood and Kuro Buta has crabmeat, scallops and shrimp mixed with corn, scallion, bean sprouts,curshed garlic, three types of miso etc in an organic chicken and turkey bone broth. Yea....try to get all that yumminess in a pre-packaged cup from the corner store. 5 star dance party in my mouth!!

1.description: Loved this joint. Greeted by a hipster-looking fella as I entered the place. Sat down and checked out the menu and a good variety of ramen dishes. Decided on the Tonkotsu Ramen, Kura Buta with an egg on the side and it was fabulous.The service was great, fast and efficient. I didn't go during the busy hours, so I didn't experience any delays in service. Wonderful!

55.description: Service was fast and fairly friendly. I had the Shoyu ramen with mushrooms and seaweed. The sesame added some nice flavor, but I found the broth to be very oily.

9.description: Literally my first time experiencing Ramen noodles so not able to compare or know what to expect, but the meal and service at Strings Ramen Shop was nice! It is a quaint little shop with very small bar side type tables. The waitress was kind enough to explain the menu and different kinds of ramen soup to order. My husband doesn't like seafood too much so he ordered the Turkey Shio Ramen and I went with the decadent richer broth with Duck and Pork, Tonkotsu Ramen. I really liked the richness of the broth and the fullness of all the flavors. It was not over salty as described by other reviews. The only complaint I have is the cost of such an entree? $15.95 for a couple of pieces of meat. I must be paying for the broth! The ramen noodle is something I have not experienced before and it was cooked al dente but at least it wasn't like the instant ramen noodles you can buy at the store. Yes, I would come back but will try the Hell's ramen for spiciness as that was lacking in the Tonkotsu.

26.description: A nice change of pace place from the all the surrounding Chinese restaurants.  this nice gem offers the quality of comfort food that is equivalent to nice bowl of chicken noodle soup on a cold day when fighting the flu.  I order the Tonkatsu Ramen as i am not able to eat the seafood base ramen due to my fish allergy (Menu helped educate me with the ingredient list for each item, very helpful).  The warm broth, rich in flavor, allowed me to feel comfortable and warm during a cold fall day.  the pork was tender and soft with a little fattiness for flavor.   noodles was on point but it must be eaten fairly quickly as you can tell that the noodles can lose its texture after a long period of time.in terms of wait staff, they were educated and helpful.  With some fine tuning and better teamwork, that place will run efficient in no time.

25.description: Well deserving of the "Best Ramen" in Chicago by Thrillist.  Super helpful staff and knowledgable about the entire menu. Level two has the perfect heat, I'm scared of Level 5!!

12.description: Portion sizes are small compared to the price. I got the pork belly with mine and I only got one small piece...I felt ripped off. For almost $15-20 you would think they'd give multiple pieces...not one small one. Even ordering extra noodles at the end...I still felt hungry. You're better off going elsewhere for a better value with the same if not better quality.

59.description: The ramen was good. I loved the broth, it was very flavorful. I had the hells ramen level 2. It was spicy but not too much. Next time I'll try level 4. My wife had the fish and soy sauce broth ramen. We both though the ramen noodles were great and the broth flavorful. The only complaint we had was that the broth was oily. I understand the add the oil but I just thought it was too much. We also had the wood salad which I really liked. It was very refreshing. The miso string beans were very good also. I would definitely go back to try the other styles of ramen broth.

21.description: Kuro bato ramen was amazing!!!  first time here and my friend and I walked here after the Bears game let out and so happy we discovered this gem!  The broth was delicious and the toppings were wonderful.  I have never had anything like it.  I ordered the fried pork to go on top and was not a fan, but I think it's just my taste.  I wish that the menus were easier to understand for people that have never been to a ramen shop, as we had to ask a neighbor customer and we still were pretty unsure of what we were ordering and the place definitely needed some air conditioning, but otherwise was pretty amazing!!!

17.description: My wife and I heard good things about this place but I am reminded time and time again, when the Asian American reviewers on Yelp give Asian restaurants anything less than 4 stars, STAY AWAY. Strings wasn't terrible but as my Yelp review states "Meh. I've experience better." The noodles reminded me of thick spaghetti noodles. If that's the style you enjoy, you'll LOVE Strings but as others have shared, there are other ramen places in the city that "up" their ramen game. I ordered the Tonkotsu and my wife ordered the Miso. The soups were fine. The portion was smaller than expected. Glad I tried it but I won't be visiting again.

10.description: Another cold-feeling day in Chicago, so warm ramen sounded like the right thing.  This trip we got the Tonkatsu, a solid staple, but also branched out and tried the Kamo Yakisoba.  The tonkatsu was creamy and savory, and just a bit slightly salty, delicious none the less. The Yakisoba has no broth, and the ingredients are stir fried and topped with an egg sunny-side up.  It was a nice surprise at how much flavor the dish had.  Also a tad on the salty side, it had a nice portion of duck breast (the kamo), with a few mushrooms and scallions, overall a bit skewed towards meat and noodles.  It came with a side of dashi broth, which I think had more flavor than some of the full ramens on the menu, very good and I finished it in quick fashion.

5.description: I'm not a ramen expert, but I've had some good stuff in New York, and this was among the best ramen I've had! I went pretty classic and ordered the Tonkatsu with pork belly and egg, which came in a pretty hearty portion that I enjoyed to the last drop. The broth was outstanding - it had such deep flavors and was so earthy, with almost a nutty taste. The soft-boiled egg (shoyu tamago) was also incredible - our server said they marinate them in mirin and something like star anise. And I really liked the square-cut noodles, which tasted really substantial and homemade.Service was attentive and efficient. The space is pretty cozy. Overall, a really fantastic place to stop off the red line for something warm and delicious during the winter months!

3.description: After a long day at the Auto Show, stopped in on a Sunday at 4pm. Parking wasn't the greatest but found the place. We walked in and it was packed. We got seated at a corner booth since it was only two of us. After that, there was a long waiting list. It took the waiter a while to attend to us. I ordered the Hell Ramen level one and my friend, the Shio Ramen. It was our first time at a Ramen restaurant. We were curious about the drinks so we ordered the Royal Milk Tea and Grape Japanese Cider, btw it's byob. The food didn't take long. The negatives are its super small so get there pretty early and the waiters are so busy, so don't be surprised if they don't attend to you a lot. everything negative was worth it. So delicious and it's definitely something to try once. The experience and the flavors. Amazing! We will be going again.

35.description: String's lamen is definitely not traditional Japanese lamen. As a lamen lover, Strings food just a mimic of lamen but not the lamen flavor you taste in japan. However, they still serve taste and good food. It's just not the lamen I expect. By the way, if you check in in Facebook or other social media, string still treat you a free dish.

19.description: I think I've tried every thing on the menu from the ramen to rice bowls! My personal favorite ramen from here would have to be the shoyu ramen. The shoyu ramen is very light, the broth is still clear and delicious! As you go down the menu the broth becoming more rich and butter like? I couldn't really enjoy the tonkatsu ramen. I felt like the broth was too thick and butter like feeling down my throat. Overall this place is nice. Service is okay they are busy most of the time when I dine there. Downside, they don't let you order for takeout for ramen! :( But you can order rice bowls for to go as well as the yakisoba.

28.description: Another cold-feeling day in Chicago, so warm ramen sounded like the right thing.  This trip we got the Tonkatsu, a solid staple, but also branched out and tried the Kamo Yakisoba.  The tonkatsu was creamy and savory, and just a bit slightly salty, delicious none the less. The Yakisoba has no broth, and the ingredients are stir fried and topped with an egg sunny-side up.  It was a nice surprise at how much flavor the dish had.  Also a tad on the salty side, it had a nice portion of duck breast (the kamo), with a few mushrooms and scallions, overall a bit skewed towards meat and noodles.  It came with a side of dashi broth, which I think had more flavor than some of the full ramens on the menu, very good and I finished it in quick fashion.

45.description: As authentic as it gets! My first time in an authentic Chinese town and certainly wouldn't be my last. I had Shio ramen  and Sasa dango for desert. Service good and portions large. Nice music when you eat but be sure to be careful with your step when exiting.

33.description: Pretty darn busy!  Pretty darn good ramen on a cold windy Chicago day!  Get ready to wait about 15-20 mins.  Found this small ramen shop thanks to fellow Yelpers.   I had the tonkotsu special (duck and chasu) and it was done just right.  Very generous with the chasu (huge piece) and the duck was med rare which was perfect.  Noodles lacked a bit of springiness like Ippudo (NYC) but I guess all ramen are different.  Soup was not very salty (which I prefer) and very rich and creamy which is what I expect in a tonkotsu.  Only gripe is that the soup was not piping hot for me (I prefer mine piping hot till the end).  Service was prompt and friendly.  They have a Hell Ramen contest if you can eat it in 20 mins then you get a $50 gift card and your bowl is free.  Not worth killing my gut for (imo).Enjoy!

43.description: Holy scneikeees! I'm not sure why you wouldn't like this place, well it does not seem to be the most vegetarian friendly place ( I could be wrong, looked all over the menu and didn't see options but perhaps you just have to ask).  The ramen here is damn good. I ordered off the "ramen from hell" section, level 2 out of 5. I can eat some pretty spicy stuff, I could handle level 2 but I wonder about 3, I dunno, will have to try. Strings is kind of a modern atmosphere, super quick order delivery to your table, nice and hot, spicy as hell if you want it that way. I've been told that if you order level 5, they give you a mini fire extinguisher for your table as people have been known to have their eyebrows burst into flames.

2.description: We went there at about 7pm on a Friday night and it was packed. They don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait. (highly worth it though)Pros: -amazing broth (they actually had a REALLY good vegan broth option, which is hard to find!)-inexpensive..about $45 for 2 people-BYOB!-received free edamame for #hashtagging on twitter-"Hell broth" is a must try-extremely friendly service, attentiveCons:This isn't really a con, but since the place was 100% packed when we got there, instead of having to wait for a table, they sat us in the far back area which was secluded from the main dining area where there are just 2 tables. I felt like we were sitting in the carry-out area...hard to describe. Still, it was nice that we got seated so quickly, and the service was great despite not being in the main area.Definitely check this place out! I am a fan!

18.description: When Strings first opened, I heard many negative things about the food through word of mouth so I was very hesitant to come here. However, it seems like String has improved over time. I came here with a group of friends on a Saturday night and there was a line forming outside the restaurant. The wait was probably 30-45 minutes. The tables are a bit cramped and some of the people waiting to be seated kept bumping into us since we were sitting by the entrance. I ordered my go to ramen (tonkotsu), which came with pork belly. I was slightly disappointed that the soft boiled egg was not included and was an extra charge. The pork belly was on point but I wish the broth was creamier. Overall, I would come back but probably on a weekday when it is less crowded.

41.description: It was my first time trying Strings Ramen and I'm hooked! Delicious ramen, friendly and informative staff, and delicious ramen (yup, I'm writing it twice). I will definitely be back!

52.description: Soup base is just MSG soup, nothing special.  The restaurant doesn't participate in the Chinatown parking so you get no validation from the parking, pay the full $10 which is insane!!!

50.description: Love love love love the miso! My husband loves the tonkotsu. You must try the ramen it won't disappoint.

4.description: This was my first real Ramen experience (packets from the Jewel don't count), and it was a good one. We were seated immediately on Friday afternoon (post lunch rush time). It's a small place with minimalist decor, cute and inviting, with a definite hipster vibe. There's a little patio section for alfresco if weather is agreeable. Staff was very knowledgeable and helpful when info about menu was requested. Water refills! They make their own noodles, which are cooked al dente, very good. I had tonkotsu with kamo and Kura buta. That's the pork bone broth, which was rich, salty (but not too salty), tasty and satisfying. It included several slices of duck breast and a slice of pork loin, sliced scallions, seaweed sheet (yum!) and veggies. Hubby had Miso broth, seafood and Kura buta. That included a scallop, some nice shrimp, some veggies, and a big ol' hunk of pork belly. Portions were generous.  We split a mango guava gelato flute and left feeling surprisingly full. Street parking with pay to park box.

6.description: Recently saw a story stating they were one of the top 10 ramen places in Chicagoland. Since many places are in the burbs or Northside, I got excited about a ramen place so close to Bridgeport. Got the to Tonkotsu ramen.  Wanted the largest bowl they had on the menu, but they were out of a couple of ingredients. Instead got the "supreme" which was one step down. Ambiance - 3 out of 5 - could of done without the dubstepIngredients - 5 out of 5 - absolutely delicious and traditionally authentic to what you'd get in JapanPortion - 2 out of 5 - if I'm paying $18 for a bowl of ramen, I better be full at the end and I wasn'tSo take it all with a grain of salt. Ramen is expensive everywhere in Chicago, and I've yet to find a place where I feel the proportion to the cost were equal. I was spoiled living in Japan, and then moving back to Michigan where I could go to Matsu Chan in Canton.

22.description: Good with good music. First restaurant I went to in a long time that played good music and not the Katie Perry and 1 direction fallout boy

15.description: Chinatown is one of my favorite spots in Chicago! During my last visit, I came to this ramen spot for dinner. There was a line outside the door, but we were able to get seated immediately. Their veggie ramen is delicious!

57.description: The pork belly they provide is 99% fat.  It is completely unacceptable..I ordered extra pork belly and the first massive slab was probably 30% actual meat and 70% fat, and the second slab was 100% fat.  This is unlike any ramen I have ever had in my life.  There were literally pools/globs of fat inside my broth and it made me sick to even look at it; it made the remnants of my ramen unedible.  No quality control whatsoever here.

20.description: Portion sizes are small compared to the price. I got the pork belly with mine and I only got one small piece...I felt ripped off. For almost $15-20 you would think they'd give multiple pieces...not one small one. Even ordering extra noodles at the end...I still felt hungry. You're better off going elsewhere for a better value with the same if not better quality.

36.description: Ramen is decent. Tonkotsu prefered. I've tried other ramen here but they were kind of bland.  Service is not great. ラーメンなのに高い。インスタントの方が美味い。

14.description: One bite here and you know why they are consistently ranked the best ramen spot in the city.  You choose from four different broths and they make their noodles in house.  I tried the Tonkotsu ramen which is the pork bone stock with duck and pork tenderloin.  The broth was delightful and even more so once I added a little bit of heat to it.  My only regret was that I wasn't hungrier when I was there.

58.description: I went today to get highlights in my hair for the first time. I've never colored my hair, so I was slightly anxious about the results, but Norris did such an incredible job. Upon examining the picture I wanted my hair to resemble and double-checking to make sure I was okay with the color with a separate swatch, he thoroughly and carefully proceeded to color my hair. He was such a lovely individual and my hair looks so, so good now that I'll be sure to come back for all my hair needs from here on out :) You're amazing, Norris! I hope you and your staff have a great day!

56.description: I went to the salon for the first time for my haircut and color...I had read lot of reviews about them so g ad high expectations also and I must say they lived up to my expectations,especially Norris..I let him decide my haircut and color and he did a very good job..I feel great and yes "I feel light". I would recommend it to everyone. Good job Norris...Hope to see u soon

29.description: This is a VERY VERY VERY overdue review. And I know the salon is in Chinatown, which isn't your Lincoln Park or River North Salon, but hear me out.I've been going to Norris since I was 19 (I'm almost 27 now) and when he was at a previous salon a couple of doors down from HeadQuarter. I followed him to his new salon because he knows what I want and he does EXACTLY what I want. I'm a very impulsive person when it comes to my hair (which, I know, is annoying for hairstylists) but Norris always lets me come in either that day or whenever his earliest time slot is. I've done everything from haircut, color, ombre, and balayage. Every time I stray away to another salon to check out other people, I ALWAYS come back, frustrated, because someone else ruined my hair. And Norris ALWAYS fixes it. And he's never made me feel bad about it.

42.description: Very disappointed with my haircut. I travel here for work and decided to try the Chinatown hair salon here in Chicago. The price is $27 for hair above shoulder length. They do try to give you a shampoo beforehand. It was actually unnecessary as The stylist Samson spent too much time blow drying it out before cutting my hair. His technique is not very good. He tried to multitask by serving other customers. The cut itself took longer than 20 min but the result is NOT good. It has no shape or layer as I had expected. I look pretty much like an idiot. I think I need to go back to my usual salon in Bay Area to get it fixed. :(  my husband thinks I look like I just got hair cut from supercut. Anyway maybe others may have better luck with the owner cutting. But don't risk it.

23.description: I came here for a cut and a perm, but ended up getting highlights and a cut instead. Everyone was very nice and hospitable, offering water and magazines whenever I needed. Norris was very friendly. I know he wasn't paying attention to our conversation when we first started because I told him the same stuff at the end of the appointment, but I'm okay with that. I would rather have him focus on my hair than that I've never gotten my hair dyed before. The salon could be a bit cleaner in terms of the walls and wash station. Overall, I would come back. The balayage and cut cost a little over $100, which was great. Too bad they don't validate parking passes.

47.description: I've heard so much about this place and decided to give it a try. When I got there the place seemed to be busy, which was always a good sign. I asked the guy at front desk if there was any wait, he said no and walked me straight to the hair wash area and just told me to sit on one of the hair wash seats. After waiting for about 10 minutes he came back and asked if I could just stand somewhere in the corner because someone else needed to wash. I asked if I could just grab a seat instead of standing around, he proceeded to move me to a hair cut seat, but after several awkward minutes someone else came over and asked if I could move to another seat. When it was finally my turn to get my hair wash, the guy probably spent less than 10 seconds shampooing my hair.Overall the hair cut was decent. But the service was sloppy. I have definitely had better experience at a hair salon before.

8.description: I came here for a cut and a perm, but ended up getting highlights and a cut instead. Everyone was very nice and hospitable, offering water and magazines whenever I needed. Norris was very friendly. I know he wasn't paying attention to our conversation when we first started because I told him the same stuff at the end of the appointment, but I'm okay with that. I would rather have him focus on my hair than that I've never gotten my hair dyed before. The salon could be a bit cleaner in terms of the walls and wash station. Overall, I would come back. The balayage and cut cost a little over $100, which was great. Too bad they don't validate parking passes.
