If I craved Canto dinner food, then yes.. however, nothing was super unique about the resturant- no unique dishes, just the same traditional foods. However.. I was happy when I left the restaurant. If you have no idea what good Canto food tastes like, then I highly recommend this restaurant. If you're Canto and know your food.. then this food is average.

30.description: Steamed juicy buns are great.  Need to order these as soon as you sit down since they take about 15 minutes to prepare.  Eat them hot and with a soup spoon so you don't miss out on the juice.  Chicken and corn soup is excellent.  The walnut shrimp and szechuan eggplant are also great.   Definitely a place to try in Chinatown.

46.description: I have been fortunate to go to House of Fortune several times with my friend's family for special events like Chinese New Years.  It is always a lot of fun and they have their own separate banquet room for larger parties.  I would suggest ordering the peking duck here and going with a large crowd helps as you can try more dishes.

1.description: I use to come here for the past 20years but since they changed management over the years it has gone down hill! It makes me sad because I had great memories. The owner treated me horribly. I had placed order online it says if I order 35 or more I get free fried rice but because I couldn't find e-noodle had to call I asked him about free fried rice and he started yelling that online is not right and can't honor that. It was so bad! But I'm not at a loss he is...mind you my order was 140.00 just lost a long time customer over fried rice! Oh and this is not the first time he has been rude ... He has been for long time but finally got the nerve to try new restaurant! Ps I would have given a no star if I could !!

55.description: "Meh" indeed.I walked to the House of Fortune from my nearby hotel and got some stuff to go.  Wonton soup, crab rangoons and Singapore noodles.Soup: ok.  Nothing fantastic, but completely edible.  Huge portion for the cost.Rangoons: Like the soup, ok.  Not the normal basket shaped wonton wrapper, more crab in the filling than normal.Singapore noodles: bleh.  Not bad, just not good.  Really scant on the pork and shrimp, not enough flavor in the rest of it.

9.description: My friend and I decided to check this place out during the Chinatown summer fest earlier this summer. Because it was both of our first times in the neighborhood, we pretty much blindly chose a place without any real expectations. Thankfully, house of fortune ended up being great! We ordered crab Rangoon to start, an excellent choice. Very full of crab and cream cheese, which I always enjoy! For the main dishes, we went with a Szechwan chicken and a shrimp lo mein. While the noodles were not the same as lo mein dishes I've tried in the past, we were pleasantly surprised by how much we liked them!The service wasn't the best, but I'd attribute that to the fact that they were likely 5x busier than an average day due to the festival. I always love me some goooood Chinese food :)

26.description: First of all, walking into a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown with no Chinese people dining here and only 3 tables the entire night, should have been my first warning. After trying the food, I can see why.... This place is only one step away from Sweet and Sour Chicken balls and agg rolls.!  What a disappointment after reading some of the reviews.  Even more upsetting was that this was a recommendation of the Hyatt Regency McCormick Place.  We ate less than half the food we ordered. There has gotta be somewhere better, no?

25.description: Delicious! Generous lunch portions, served until 3pm, for $5.50#win :)

12.description: Have visited House Of Fortune many times.  The food along with the service is great.  Wonderful place to go to when in Chinatown or after a White Sox game.

59.description: Came here for a 10-course lunch banquet. Having been to a number of Chinese banquet meal in the SF Bay Area, this one did not impress too much. Was there an insane amount of food as custom with these banquets? Yes. Was the food ok? Yes. Was it memorable and great Chinese food? No. However, it was a medium-sized restaurant right in the middle of Chinatown and was a decent place to have a cozy banquet without feeling overwhelmed by the size of the place. Parking in Chinatown really sucks, esp on Sundays, if you are looking for street parking. Best bet is that 2-floor parking lot a block or so down... you got to pay but it saves 30 min of driving around for parking. Bottom line: Average. But hey, since I didn't have to pay, I'm not going to look a gift horse in the mouth...

21.description: Our go to Chinese restaurant for delivery!  Good food &  large portions! The juicy buns and lemon chicken are delicious!

17.description: First time there... we go there before the rush so YAY us :)Old school decor.. doesn't look like much has changed in ages.. table clothes, but casual.Pleasant host and server that were eager to get water tea and whatever else we ordered.Started with eggrolls.. basic and good, but nothing specialSweet N Sour chicken was a tad too sweet for my taste, but crunchy and full of fresh bell peppers so YAYMongolian beef was average.. sauce needed a little extra punch, but I added that myself. Meat was tasty and lots of onions.I saw someone eating soup and that looked awesome.. so I may be back for thatThey also offer no MSG on request and that is always a good thing

10.description: This is the only place my family goes to in Chinatown. The food is exceptional. The owner is always there with a friendly greeting. Rock salt shrimp without the shell is outatanding. We usually order two! Also the governors chicken is outstanding. Definitely best Chinese food I've had

5.description: I ordered sweet and sour pork from hotel via grubhub and it arrived very quickly. However the pork was so overcooked, dark , and unrecognizable that I could not eat it. I could not even get a fork in it. Very sad. I ordered a hot and sour soup as well and when I opened the lid there wad a pungent smell. I could not eat that either. Im glad i ordered 8 fortune cookies as that became my dinner.

3.description: Great Chinese restaurant. We didn't try to many from the menu, but Peking duck was absolutely perfect. It was our best experience. Thank you for your service!

35.description: Hands down- our favorite Chinese Restaurant in Chicago's Chinatown. Great service, amazing menu, clean, and the best Chinese food around. My husband and I joke that in another life, we must have been some sort of Asian. We chose to live in the South Loop to be close to Chinatown as we typically eat some sort of Asian food twice a week. After trying almost all Chinese locations in Chinatown we came across House of Fortune by accident. We went to their not so friendly neighbor Evergreen and left prior to them even putting water on our table. All we wanted was a 1/2 of a peaking duck and soup. Evergreen, although they have a 1/2 duck on their menu, stated that we had to order a whole--- we were only two people, way to much food. House of Fortune to the rescue. We always order: 1/2 peaking duck, sizzling rice soup (amazing- best in Chinatown). Sometimes we tack on some governors chicken and ox tail but no matter what we order- its great clean yummy food and never disappoints. The staff will remember you and will greet you with a smile at the door. When it gets cold and you aren't feeling the best- we always crave House of Fortune, our comfort food.

19.description: Delicious! Generous lunch portions, served until 3pm, for $5.50#win :)

28.description: I've had my fair share of Chinese food, and I must say that House of Fortune is lacking something. Not sure what the fuss is about this place, but I have definitely experienced better in and out of Chinatown.Food was sub-par. My family and I ordered a number of dishes. Nothing really stood out. You can find better quality next door or down the block.

45.description: What a pleasant surprise! We parked at cermak and wentworth and walked a few blocks south to this gem and it was worth it.  We started out with sizzling rice soup...it had lots of chicken, scallops and shrimp and was delicious.  We also had kung pao chicken and shrimp with vegetables.  We requested no msg and I asked for some spicyness in the shrimp and it was made perfectly.  So glad we stopped here!  I will come back again for sure.

33.description: My family and I have been coming here for more than 15 years. It is our favorite Cantonese restaurant in Chicago. The food is great! My mom usually orders all the dishes for us, like a good Chinese mommy would do.  Crystal shrimp, crispy chicken, hot and sour soup, beef chow fun and Chinese vegetables are our usuals in addition to a few more!Enjoy!

43.description: One of the family's favorite places to eat.  Our standard Christmas dinner spot.  Lemon chicken...chicken moist, super crispy...batter is light and sauce has a nice fragrant lemon aroma.  I have a fixation on the beef in beijing sauce...a sweet pungent sauce with lots of sliced and gently sauteed onions.  Can't get enough!  Damn good cold outta the fridge.

2.description: Blend food. Never had Peking Duck so uh...forgot their spices i reckon.Attentive service. Nice enough people. Kind of them to roll the duck. Else I would have given it one star.Certainly not worth a repeat.

18.description: Best Lo me in noodles I've ever tried. Everything was delicious. They were very nice with the kids and gave them easy-to-use chopsticks

41.description: Truly excellent Chinese food!  I used to live in New York and miss Chinatown-style food - it was always better, just a little more pronounced on the flavors than most neighborhood take-outs.  Chicago's Chinatown isn't especially exciting, but since we were there I went on Yelp and found House of Fortune, and I was absolutely satisfied.  Like New York's Chinatown restaurants, the flavors were bold, the menu a little more exotic.  The review I read recommended Sizzling Rice Soup, so I tried it since it sounded different.  It really was, but it was delicious.  Very much about a fun presentation, which crispy rice dumped into the soup at the table so you can hear the "sizzle," and pieces of carrot cut into animal shapes - no joke!  I was with my Dad and we also shared Kung Pao Chicken and Sesame Chicken.  Figured I'd stay in familiar territory with Dad along.  The Kung Pao was awesome, and definitely spicier than your neighborhood take-out.  It had a light, fresh taste and I couldn't stop eating it.  The Sesame Chicken pleased my mild-palated Dad a bit more, and I really enjoyed that too.  It was crispy, very sweet, and tangy.  The only drawback was that I probably ate more in one sitting than ever before in my life and I was uncomfortable for a few hours afterwards, lol, but you can't hold it against the restaurant for making delicious food!Prices weren't rock-bottom, but I was satisfied with them for a nice Chinatown eatery.  For the quality and quantity of food, it was a bargain really.  The decor was typical Chinese - plain white table cloths, no frills black chairs.  My Dad, who adores the kitchy dragons and lanterns of more touristy Chinese restaurants thought it a bit dull, but I appreciated that it was spacious, well-it, and clean.  The walls were decorated with tasteful and elegant framed caligraphy.

52.description: This place is little more than acceptable.  Is there any really good Chinese food restaurant that delivers to the Near North Side?On the day that I tried the grub from this place, the star of the show here was the hot and sour soup.  It was quite good.Chicago's Chinese food scene continues to disappoint.  One day, I'll find its hidden gems.  I know that they're out there.

50.description: I hardly go the restaurant itself as there are better cantonese restaurants in chinatown, i do however, order from there for delivery because its the only restaurant i know that delivers peking duck (plus soup), black bean steamed oysters and stir fried clams from Chinatown. The food is decent and the delivery is quick, perfect when i feel lazy and don't want to trek all the way to Chinatown.

4.description: It's so awesome place! I ordered a peking duck yesterday cause I read a lot of different reviews, wanted to taste it too. The duck was unbelievable delicious and cooked so fast! It was my very good experience in Chicago, I enjoyed it.

6.description: Good Tasty Food. Rarely gets the orders correct on take out orders.Ok, ok I am one of those who ask for modifications to my order, for example Mongolian Beef NOT SPICY, however 8 out of 10 times, they make it spicy.  Not sure what "NOT SPICY" means to their cook.  I will no longer place carry out orders because of the frustrations of the kitchen rarely getting my order correct.

22.description: Went back a second time and the food was just as good. This is now our "go to" place in Chinatown. The menu is extensive, and the lunch specials are a bargain. Next time we'll try the Dim Sum menu. You try it too!

15.description: Love HOF! I've been dining there for years now. The staff is attentive, the prices are reasonable and the food is great. Fan favorites: beef with Beijing sauce and the Mongolian combo. PS, the drinks are cheap, too.

57.description: Now that I've gone for a normal meal - it's still 4 stars!Dinner for four at House of Fortune was almost as good as the private banquet for the Chinese New Year I attended on my first visit here.  Cutting back from 14 courses and specially made dishes does have an impact, but it was still a great meal.The restaurant is clean and inviting, with well spaced tables, clean white table clothes, and cloth napkins.  This is not a paper-napkin three-floor eight-page menu Chinese restaurant.  It's a classy place.  They have plenty of menu choices, but is a smaller restaurant with a realistic menu.  And if you don't see what you want, they'll make it special for you.House of Fortune does not have a website, so you're stuck looking at what we had to eat to see what they offer:- Sauteed shrimp with mushrooms and bamboo.- General Tso chicken (yes, I know it's a Chinese dish only in America - it's still good.  It's not on the menu, but they'll fix it if you ask).- Orange beef.- Green beans with small pieces of shredded pork.- Noodles with vegetables.Not a traditional Chinese meal, but appropriate for our group.  Everything was great.  Lightly cooked vegetables, huge shrimp, excellent beef and chicken.  Service started slow, but once we ordered everything kept flowing.  A bottle of wine, lots of tea, all the above food (half of which came home with us), and dessert cookies for four for $96, tax and tip included.On a Wednesday night House of Fortune was about half full, with both Asians and Westerners.  My feeling is they have a loyal regular clientele.  It's not where I'd bring a dozen kids after a ballgame.  But it's excellent for a relaxed better-than-most Chinese meal with friends in a real dining room.

20.description: Definitely go here! Best Cantonese and Mandarin food you will have!!!! In my book, I give it a 100 stars!

36.description: I went to House of Fortune with my siblings to celebrate a birthday. It was lunchtime on a weekday, just part of our little tour of Chinatown. We were the only diners there. A few people came in to pick up carry-out orders, but basically it was us, the staff, and a clicking rotating fan. Strange.We ordered anyway. The food came out hot and it was good. I had hoped that more of my soft wide noodles (with vegetables & tofu) would come with the crispy, caramelization on the outside but they didn't. I liked the little shapes they made out of the veggies though. My brother asked for black bean sauce along with his fish dish, which turned out to have better taste than mine. My sister had chicken & vegetables stirfry dish, which she didn't think was very memorable. They both enjoyed the egg soup that came with their orders. We all enjoyed the complimentary hot tea (likely jasmine). Service was very nice and attentive, but again, we were the only ones there. All in all it was okay. I'm entertaining the idea of going back, maybe on a weekend, to try more Cantonese cuisine.

14.description: It was my first time in Chicago and instead of trying a deep dish pizza we opted for some Asian food and it was a good decision.My friend and I split an order of the Peking duck and I am still thinking about how delicious it was, even 4 days later! The service was awesome, they were all very friendly and helpful. We got complimentary soup at the beginning and also a small bowl of dessert at the end of the meal. Both were super good. Would definitely come back if I ever visit Chicago again!

3.description: This place has a lot of knick-knacks for gifts and general amusement. For 75 cents, I bought a chopstick training holder thing that connects chopsticks. I am uncoordinated when using chopsticks and am curious (and a tad bit excited - dorky, I know) to see how this thing works. It was that or buying a Hello Kitty set of already-connected chopsticks for kids. Which one would you choose? I also bought a hard eyeglass/sunglass case for $4.99, a bit more than the one I bought (and later lost) in L.A. Whatever. I needed a new one.

1.description: Fun little souvenir shop with a wide range of 装饰品诀窍(Zhuāngshì pn) which I think means knick knacks or decorations.  They sell calligraphy pens but I wasn't able to write this, though I tried for a full 5 minutes.  The staff is helpful, and patient. There's quite a bit of stuff crammed into a small space, and it ranges from the very cheap (and looks very cheap) the to the inexpensive (and doesn't look cheap) souvenirs to nice decorations.  It's too tight with too many fragile items to bring in younger children (unless they are very well behaved) but there are lots of toys to give to children as gifts.  Not surprisingly it's all made in China, including the Japanese sake serving sets which are quite a bit cheaper than you would find elsewhere.  It's really fun to shop here, and you can't leave Chinatown with out some sort of souvenir, right?

2.description: Shopping in Chinatown is always an adventure. At least that's the way I look at it when I get to poke into every little shop looking for nothing but invariably finding something that calls to me. Chinatown Bazaar is no exception. This store stocks more clothing and purses than most on this stretch of Wentworth. Know that the sizes are SMALL. My friend who weighs about 100 pounds soaking wet was a large . . . .hmm . . .doubt I'll be shopping for clothes here anytime soon! I did pick up a little purse that will be perfect for a fancy night out for a steal, though! They also have these interesting cloth posters with Bruce Lee and cartoon characters on them (have no idea what I would do with something like that but they drew quite a crowd!) The other thing I liked were some of the accessories but I wasn't willing to search through all the junky jewelry to find something of value. My more patient friend actually found a necklace that I now covet but since I live here (and she doesn't) I can go digging for treasure anytime. The store is small and packed from floor to ceiling with stuff. If you've got patience and an eye for "treasures" you'll probably walk out with something you love. As for me? Check out my new purse the next time you see me. You might see my "treasure" of the day.

5.description: If you need a souvenir from Chinatown this is the place. They also are a video rental store. Need a Chinese language newspaper? You can get them here too.

0.description: Very nice store with a ton of interesting gifts.  I've experienced from some gift shops (across the street) a language barrier when I am looking for a specific item.  Staff is very helpful and A+ in my book.   If you spend over $10 they give you a free gift (a colorful paper lantern) a nice touch.

4.description: People at this store are very friendly and try to help you find what you're looking for. They have a huge selection when it comes to clothing, shoes, jewelry, lanterns, charms, tea, etc.... and everything they carry is considerably higher quality than most other stores on the strip. If you walk in and think that some of their prices are a bit higher than other places, just compare what they are selling to that of their competitors and you'll understand why. Whenever I need a a nice gift, I just run in to Chinatown Bazaar because they stand true to their name, "BAZAAR." They always have new merchandise coming in and I don't have to go to a bunch of other shops just to find what I am looking for. If you're in town, you def wanna check it out! Hope this is helpful! *-*

3.description: I swear the staff can be a bit rude. I know my family is a regular and I guess I don't make a big deal of my presence but the lady there today plucked my straw. She was asking all sorts of question saying who I was and the hullabaloo.I just want to order some BBQ pork... not have my life publicized or have people gawk.By the way, the food was a hit to the kids. We purchased this for a potluck and the kids couldn't resist opening the container to get a head-start. Or BBQ pork was always a hit since it's glazed with honey sauce.

1.description: Small, simple shop that does pretty much one thing here but does it fairly well. The Chinese BBQ here has a slightly better texture and milder flavors than most restaurants in Chinatown, probably relying more on using slightly more fat cuts of meat than others in Chinatown. With that said, the food isn't amazing (no one really stands out here as being exceptional, not even BBQ King) but it'll be good for any family dinners, gatherings, or traditional ceremonies that require Chinese BBQ.

2.description: Finally made it here and can't wait to try everything else on the menu! Duck was perfectly roasted with beautiful color.

9.description: Bf and I come here for the roast pork. It's the best we've ever had, hands down. It's tender and the skin is super crispy. The only downside is since it's so freaking good, it sells out really fast. When it's Chinese New Year's, my grandma and stepdad go extra early to get huge chunks of the succulent meat. Yeah, it's that good.

10.description: thank god for decent roasted duck in chinatown!!!

4.description: Although I dislike to see it or hear some one say that this "is the BEST____ "  fill in the blank. I'd have to say that this is in the top 3 places for Chinese  BBQ.  This place is part take out/ part grocery store  they have all kinds of household goods and cooking ware.  It is our families favorite place to take out duck, chicken roast pork and BBQ pork for over 35 years.  The appearance is a little dumpy but they create authentic Chinese styled BBQ. Freshest around. But my only complaint is choices become very limited when they are out. of duck pork or chicken. So shop early.

6.description: Worse service ever!! The cashier lady which happens to be the owner is rude!! I would never go back even everything is free!!  Their food is not good compare to other bbq place in chinatown. The reason I went there was because it's close by but now I would rather walk a few extra blocks to buy from other BBQ place!

12.description: This is by far the best BBQ house for roast duck in Chicago Chinatown.  There, I said it.  Its cash only store front (no seating and the staff mostly speaks variations of Chinese), but the fresh out of the roaster duck is just perfect.  The meat is juicy and tender, a gentle layer of fat, and crispy brown skin fills your mouth with its decadence.  I am by no means a connoiseur but this place gets it right.  Just make sure you eat it while its warm! Run home after you pick up the duck!!!!

5.description: Best roast duck and duck wings in the city! Sells out fast so gotta go early in the morning to buy them before they sell out! I like their duck because the skin is crispy and meat is moist.

13.description: Although this place lacks seating of any kind and is therefore only good for takeout like many Chinatown BBQ places, it's still great. I've been a long-time Sun Wah fan since I live on the north side, but it's much more expensive and frankly, Tai Ho Yee's BBQ is just as good. This is for sure one of our go-to places for Chinese BBQ

11.description: I very much love the roast duck they have there. I can't speak much for anything else because all I eat is the duck they have. Its really good, not dry and salty like  most places. The sauce they have is sweet and thin, not paces that you get with chucks of black bean. Sometimes I can't help myself and end up eating half a duck before its time for dinner. Sigh... I need self control

8.description: Can't be too bad when I ate the whole damn duck in one sitting.  I'd place this one half a star below BBQ King, but hey, they should get six stars!  I'll try the soy sauce chicken next time.  The best duck I've ever had was in SF Chinatown and sat on the curb eating the whole thing...nobody cares, it's San Francisco.  That and a weird little Hmong place in Centerline Michigan.

0.description: I went to China Town in Chicago and Yelped Chinese BBQ. The results showed a ton of results so I decided to walk around and walk to the end of China Town to pick this place.  Here are my thoughts:What I ordered: 1/2 Salted Chicken & 4 pounds roast pork.Pros:-they chop it in front of you.-they are cooked fresh daily.-the roast pork was SUPER crispy on the skin + moist in the meat.-the salted chicken had a good texture, wasn't too chewy.Tips:-they are on the corner of S Wentworth / 24th pl [located at the edge of China Town]Conclusion: If I want to get my Chinese BBQ fix in Chicago, I'll go to a place that specializes in Hong Kong BBQ such as Tai Ho Yee Food Co.

7.description: The BBQ duck is my favorite! I've tried all the BBQ duck in different BBQ store in chinatown, and this store is the best so far.  Provided that I'm from HK, I really know what is good and what is not. They have roasted pork ribs also, but they sold out very quick in the morning. BBQ pork is just alright, so I'll just stick with BBQ duck and roast pork ribs.

3.description: I liked this place a lot better than Giftland. I found an awesome purse (for $17), some stationery/giftwrap products aside from Hello Kitty/SanX, and a Chicago shot glass in the old school style that I collect ("Greetings from..."). All reasonably priced. Would definitely return when in Chinatown for their variety of gifty goodness!

1.description: Cheaper than Giftland, smaller but way more cuter and interesting. Even in a small location they have a wide range of hello kitty stuff which I love! The purses/bags were a little on the pricey side. I'd recommend this over Giftland.

2.description: Don't come here (nor to Giftland) for anime stuff unless you've got a hankering for knockoff merchandise for anime from 10 years ago (primarily Gundam S and first gen Pokemon with some Naruto mixed in). They have other cute stuff though. If you're used to the price of Chinese knockoffs in China it'll all look super expensive, but for Chicago it's reasonable I guess. If you want snacks on the other hand, don't buy them here -- go to the market near the red line station where they're practically half the price.

0.description: I think this is the newest gift shop in  Chinatown and it is located right in the square it is very easy to find if you get lost easy or are a tourist or are only hitting the square to grab a bite to eat but then get the urge to walk off your meal a little bit. They are a pretty much a smaller version of Giftland. They have a small but decent collection of anime posters and items. They have a great assortment of Hello Kitty stuff, which is what fills up most of this small spot. Nice location and a fun little stop in Chinatown.

4.description: This place is like Giftland Jr. specifically for the Chinatown Market Square area.  Like if you are sick of "Chinatown Proper" by Wentworth and wanted to cruise the square but still wanted a shop full of random cutesy crap like will likely break the minute you get home, but Giftland is all the way out by the Red Line - this is the place to go.They're also authorized to sell Sanrio stuff, so all of the Hello Kitty (and friends - you can't forget all of her friends - and her "nemesis", too) merch is available here.And my anime posters, though there's not as wide a variety as at Giftland.It's a little more than half the size of those Chinatown Proper gift stores, but it's the same range of toys and trinkets and of course a random Chinese dress section.I'm not sure if Chinatown recognizes that there's really only two main flavors of customers who hit the shops in Chinatown:1) Chinese people who aren't fully assimilated to the American culture and need a haven to purchase their authentic Chinese items, which would likely not include cheap and poorly-crafted versions of the authentic items they need.2) Slack-jawed tourists who likely see the Chinese culture visible in Chinatown as a novelty and something to gawk at and take a picture of, but not likely purchase.  It's fun for them to take the interesting-looking Chinese-style dress off the rack and hold it up and laugh at how crazy it seems to them, but it's not like they're going to buy it and wear it because it's not their culture.I'm sure there's a third group that is everyone NOT in those two groups, but another trip into Chinatown proves time and time again that there's mainly those two elements - and I don't see how some of these stores can stay open.Oh me?  I'm in the slack-jawed tourist group.  Well, technically I'm in the "foodie" group because I hit the bakeries and restaurants and try to avoid the trinket venues as much as possible - but another possible location where I could get a Death Note/Bleach/Chobits/Naruto poster was something I couldn't pass up.  Again, I wasn't impressed with the selection, but I have a feeling as they're open longer, they'll realize that we slack-jawed tourist crowd like to purchase culture we can understand.And I understand anime posters and wall scrolls and keychains.  So I'll be back.(The only reason why they didn't get a 5th star was because they were I guess eating lunch at the counter or something and half the store smelled like awfulness.  And they didn't carry the "Chinatown" T-shirt in a large enough size, which would have been the perfect souvenir for a visiting relative who we took we us.  I mean a T-shirt with the Chinese characters for "Chinatown" and big "Chinatown" written underneath is the PERFECT slack-jawed tourist item and it should be in the window and in sizes not only large enough for adults, but for 4XL-sized adults like me and a large percentage of today's grazing tourist population.)

58.description: Great dim sum. Nice decor. Better service than most Chinese restaurants. Has a parking lot attached to the property. Solid food options. Will be back!

56.description: We brought a large crew here for dim sum, which was delicious and one of the better places in the city with a wide variety to choose from.  The service ranged from non-existent and a bit rude to very friendly depending on who stopped by the table (or who we managed to flag-down).  Overall, the food is worth the trip, but be flexible with the service.

29.description: I wish there was a 3.5 stars rating.  Went in to surprisingly empty place so also had attentive staff (given there was a lot of them!).  The decor was not too special except the awesome fish tanks... yes my little fishes, you will wind up in my stomach.Was a bit disappointing to not be there for dim sum but went because reviews were good.  The crawfish were great but not as good as New Orleans.  The other dishes (beef,  soup, fish of what kinda I cannot remember) were good  but not notable enough for me to say its worthy of dreaming about it.Overall OK but I'll probably explore somewhere else next time.

42.description: First time at Dolo and I can honestly say that it has now become my top dim sum place in Chicago. Everything we ordered was fresh and very tasty. I will be returning.

23.description: Food is not expensive at all! The Resturant is really nice inside but the Resturant isn't clean. I sent back dirt dishes and when my food arrived I was discouraged to eat when I found short hair in my food. The people was nice of course but I was displeased. I wouldn't go back.

47.description: Restaurant close to the center of Chinatown with it's own (tiny) private parking lot??  Count me in!I came here around 8:30 PM on a Saturday night, and while it was pretty loud (we were yelling across the booth) and busy when we got there, by the time we left it had quieted quite a bit.After looking at the other Yelp reviews (which actually happened to line up with what our table was thinking about getting anyway), we ordered the Szechuan Style Seafood Eggplant Casserole, the Sweet & Sour chicken, and the French Sauteed Diced Beef Filet Noodle.  They came out later to tell us that they had run out of the noodles for the dish (Whaaaaat??? It was only 9 and they close at 1PM).  We ended up getting one of their other noodle dishes.  All of the food was really good, flavorful & cooked well.  Although the prices seem slightly more expensive, they're actually pretty reasonable considering the portion you're getting.Definitely would come back here, if anything, to try the Dolo Seafood Combo which, it seemed like, every other table had ordered.The decor was clean and modern, from our booth we were able to peek into a private room which looked pretty fancy.

8.description: Been back nearly a dozen times.Dolo is consistent with great food quality.Will be back again soon.Typically love their dim sum.If you call in advance, they have a couple of private rooms if you have a large party.Free parking lot fills up quickly, but typically haven't had any issues with free street parking close by.

31.description: We waited 1h15 minutes for dim sum but they can't deliver a single dish.The person who answered my phone stated the wait is approx 10 - 15 minutes. Got there, suddenly the wait became 45 minutes, but whatever. After we were seated we waited another 30 minutes. When we asked what's going on the waitress finally inform us that the kitchen is over capacity and they haven't even begin processing our orders.DON'T OVER PROMISE WHEN YOU CAN'T DELIVER.

34.description: This is the best Dim Sum, I have had in Chicago. The restaurant is modern and nicer than most in Chinatown. The service is just ok, like most places in Chinatown. The food is fantastic and reasonable. We had all kinds of dumplings, spring roll, Shu Mai and the famous Beef Tenderloin Chow Fun. Everything was scrumptious!!  There are no carts, so everything comes out hot and fresh. They have a parking lot, but it is so tiny. You won't be able to park there, don't try. I look forward to going back to Dolo.

16.description: Very good food a lots of choices and very quality free parking in china town and very accommodating people they cater dim sum for me even its only up to 4pm I'm so impressed

13.description: Thank you my yelp friends Danny W. and Jaci Y. for the excellent recommendation.This place is pretty awesome. I called ahead and made a reservation so me and my hungry friends wouldn't have to wait to be seated.Once we were seated we did have a bit of trouble flagging down someone to ask a question about the menu. Then we set about the important task of ordering. So we were all like we don't want chicken feet but everything else is a go. So there was this one interesting looking item on the dim sum menu that was listed as Shrimp dumplings but looked an awful lot like Chicken feet. So uhm... the really smart ppl that we are cwe decided to order that and see what it is. We also picked a bunch of other stuff. Then it was time to flag down someone again. Again this took a bit of time to get their attention. But we finally got the order in. The bar manager was walking around talking to folks so our server called him over to our table to see if he can make me a bloody Mary.( yeah, I was been difficult trying to order something that was not listed on the menu). He came over and started chatting with us. His name is Jason. He didn't have stuff for a bloody Mary but recommended me a great cider. Jason's recommendations were spot on for all of us, he probably saw that we were alcoholic, well I'd say just my friends ;) and invited us over to the bar after the meal to try some mezcal.Anyway then the food showed up. The first thing they bring over is chicken feet.  We were like yeah dumb move to order something that looked like chicken feet although it did have it listed as something else. So moral of the story folks always go with the picture if it looks like chicken feet chances are it probably is. Since we ended up ordering chicken feet we decided to be adventurous and dig in. Have to say the sauce was pretty good although I probably wouldn't order it again just because it's not my thing.I can't remember all the stuff we ordered but the baby octopus in curry sauce was delicious. We ordered a few types of dumplings. Everything was so....good and we were stuffed.So once we were done we headed over to the bar and hung out there for a bit. Jason was nice enough to give us complimentary mezcal shots and another excellent cider for me.He mentioned that he's planning to do some wine tastings so we asked him to keep us posted so we can make another trip to this place.

11.description: A friend was telling me about an article she read (awhile back) which listed Dolo as one of Chicago's best up and coming.  (I forget the actual magazine but the owners will talk about it as well.) So, I got a group together and out we went to Chinatown to check out their finest in eats.Via Yelp/Open table on the smartphone app, I had trouble trying to get a reservation so I called the restaurant and setup it up pretty easily.  At the restaurant it was a little after 7 pm on a lazy Sunday evening and the place was maybe 25% busy.The restaurant is snazzy looking in comparison to many of the other more ethnic restaurants of Chinatown.  It's modern chic, perfect for a date or to impress a group.  And surprisingly, not expensive at all.  Since I created the event and had already checked out their food porn (Food photos per Yelp & Instagram), my group allowed me to place the bulk of the orders.  a few of the items were:Peking style pork chopsSzechuan style Eggplant with shrimp (spicy)French style filet mignonLobster special x2 in different flavors. (Requires finger use, difficult otherwise. No tools avail?)Beef tenderloin chow funLamb chops x2 in different marinades (The meat was easy to cut through for sharing.)Appetizers:Something with Woodear mushrooms (I love mushrooms and Woodear is great for you, but most of the table was not impressed with it.)Fried Shrimp dumplings.Beyond this a couple more plates were ordered. Due to their bartender being sick that evening, the bar area was closed because they hadn't anyone to tend! So our bill was for food only.  And because of that, the breakdown was about $20 per person(x5)! Awesome pricing and all of us left full.Since their bar was closed and I had a bartender buddy in the group, we sent him over to have a conversation with the owner.  Maybe he could tend their bar and make us drinks which we would then pay for? Surprisingly, they were cool about it and the owner requested a mixed drink as well.  After some conversation with him and his trying to sway us into ordering more of their specialty dishes, he decided to "comp" us on our drinks. Score! Initially we declined but he wouldn't take no. He thanked us for coming in and tried a second time to get us to order more. (At that point, we'd already ordered more dishes than necessary) (I would guess that having 3 attractive women in our group helped with the complimentary drinks, even otherwise, it was a nice gesture.) Regarding service; serving and time it took for plates to hit the table was not long. But to have a conversation and understanding with their waiters took a bit of patience. Also because many different waiters came around to the table, we weren't sure whom was or if there was a main waiter for our table.  There were a few instances of misunderstanding and an inability to find out whether they offered desserts or not. That evening there was probably only one waiter on hand that spoke English semi-fluent, unless one of the owners were on the floor at the time.

39.description: Nice modern space, with a slideshow of their own food going, and of course the ubiquitous TV. We had: salt and pepper shrimp - very big and fresh shrimps; sautéed peapod greens with garlic - fantastic, best we've ever had; and steamed whole sea bass - just fine, but priced to kill at $38. Cocktails! Some even designer-y. Some scratched off the menu - why? Who knows. Had to wait too long for them but the bartending waiter guy said he was new so, OK. Once the food is served you will have to wave your arms and yell to get any further attention. The total - $120 for two (incl. 3 drinks); now you are prepared.

37.description: We came in moments after opening on a chilly, rainy Saturday morning, wanting to try something different than Ming Hin, our usual source for Chicago dim sum.  The prospect of free parking in an off-street lot appealed, and we easily found a spot near the door - very handy, as the rain was pelting down.Restaurant was still chilly, but the dim sum was fresh and steamy warm.  We had our usual (steamed pork buns, siu-mai, har gow, all really nice), and tried a few other things (slippery noodles, and Shanghai soup dumplings, not so wonderful).Restaurant was quite chilly, but warmed up a bit once people started wandering in.Restroom surfaces were sticky.  Wondered if the cleaning crew had had a chance to go through after Friday nigh.We'll go back to Ming Hin next time and maybe try Dolo again in a few months.

0.description: This is a discovery, I lived in Beijing, China, for 3 years and know how Chinese good food tastes and Dolo is all about delicious Chinese food. The restaurant is casual, but has some touch of Chinese class in the private rooms, where you can host a private party of ten.  We came at a very busy time during a Sunday in Chinese New Year, the restaurant was crowded and very loud, we had to wait quite a while, that's my main complain, but once  we sat at our table, ordered the food, which they served us fast, and started tasting the food we couldn't decide which dish we liked the most. There's a wide selection of  dim sum, we chose the pork vegetable bun, the seared pork bun, the Shanghai soup dumpling  and was all exquisite. The black pepper beef udon noodle was top also. We ordered the duck Beijing style and also it was very tasty with the crispy skin up and came with buns and toppings. We ordered a few other dishes and all was excellent taste. They have a variety of Chinese beers, my favorite was the lucky Buddha beer. I really recommend this restaurant, it has the Chinese flavor I was missing so much from when I lived in Beijing.

38.description: I seem to write reviews when I am extremely excited about a place, or severely disappointed.  In this case, I am very happy to offer this place 5 stars. I am a Chinatown food junkie. This place is perhaps my favorite dim sum place in the whole city. Always fresh, and just perfectly done. Never been disappointed with the food quality. The tenderloin peppered chow fun noodles as previously reviewed by many is special here.  It is a must try. A full stocked bar with all the good stuff awaits as well.Service is sketchy if you don't speak Chinese,  so beware of that.  However, they'll find someone who understands if you flag them down. There's a few free parking spaces in this place as well. I almost don't want to tell you about this place because soon it's going to be overly popular!

51.description: Most of their best menu items you see on yelp are gone. There are no oyster rolls with bacon & foie gras, no pork belly, and no beef short ribs. French beef is probably my only favorite entree left on the menu.

27.description: great dim sum with a small parking lot.Recommend Seafood congee, crispy crepes. Decent egg tart too.

32.description: Good place for dim sum.   Recommend pan fried vegetable and pork bun, pan fried stuffed eggplant.

54.description: We came here with some friends on Saturday night and everyone thoroughly enjoyed the food. We were told that the bartender would not be there (it was a Saturday night), so we could only order wine or beer and could not order cocktails. When we tried to order Tsingtao, we were informed that they were out. They were also out of another wine we wanted. The drinks situation was disappointing, so come here for the food and plan to go somewhere else for drinks afterwards. While we were placing our order, we were informed that if we spent 100, we would get a free lobster prepared in the style of our choice. We choose a salt and pepper lobster.Salt and pepper enoki mushrooms- okeggplant seafood casserole-very goodstring beans dry stir fried-very goodtea smoked chicken- goodpeking duck (2 preparations- traditional as well as minced in lettuce cups)-very goodwalnut shrimp- the shrimp were large and fresh, but I have had better walnut shrimpsalt and pepper lobster-very goodThe food was solid and everyone had plenty to eat. It was also pretty reasonable for our party of four. We even had leftovers to take home.

48.description: Best dim sum I've had in Chicago and probably the best dim sum I've had in my life! Everything is made fresh to order. My family and I ordered almost everything on the menu and were super pleased. The shumai was one of my favorites and the fried turnip cakes were SO GOOD. You can't go wrong with anything. It's 20% off in the afternoon, I believe between 2-4! The food is not only amazing, but the restaurant is modern and clean compared to the old, dumpy places in Chinatown. They even have private rooms for large groups. I haven't tried this place for food other than dim sum, but 100 stars for dim sum!!

44.description: The only thing great about Dolo is the parking, which is less then 10 spots. I went in for a light lunch and the prices are reasonably cheap for the volume of food you get. I did not opt for dim sum but wanted to try their lunch specials. I placed my order for a spicy beef with rice dish and forgot to order a beer so I went up to the bar to get a beer. the bartender asked me what beer I wanted and I spit out a few simple light beers and she told me "No we don;t have that" after three generic ones I asked her what she had and she just gave me the menu, after all that she only had two beers - sigh - terrible. After 10 minutes finding the only beer they have in stock I asked the waitress which was busy talking to other staff members if my dish was here yet. She went to the back and my dish was here. I have to say, for the money - you can't beat the taste - enjoyed every bite. You can't go wrong here other than the beer selection, give Dolo a try!

24.description: This just became my no 1 Chinese restaurant in Chicago.  Food was delicious and service was great.  I just missed the dim sum from 2-4 but I will be going back.  If you're one of those people that eat with their eyes, this is a great restaurant to try.

7.description: I wish there was a 3.5 stars rating.  Went in to surprisingly empty place so also had attentive staff (given there was a lot of them!).  The decor was not too special except the awesome fish tanks... yes my little fishes, you will wind up in my stomach.Was a bit disappointing to not be there for dim sum but went because reviews were good.  The crawfish were great but not as good as New Orleans.  The other dishes (beef,  soup, fish of what kinda I cannot remember) were good  but not notable enough for me to say its worthy of dreaming about it.Overall OK but I'll probably explore somewhere else next time.

49.description: First off this place did not have 3/4 of what we originally wanted so we should have taken that as a sign and left immediately.  I ended up ordering pretty standard fare of spicy chicken.....which made me ill that night.  It looks like a good place but if our experience is any indication (my girl got sick too....) then avoid this place like the plague.

40.description: Went for a late lunch to try the dim sum. It was delicious. The dishes are well seasoned and surprisingly good. It's a bit pricey but there is a 20% discount between 2-4 from M-F. It's a newer place but secret gem. I'm sure it's packed on the weekends.

53.description: I came here with a friend and we ordered the Dolo Seafood Special-- the one that comes with 5 pounds of seafood goodness. It was spicy and delicious-- we left FULL. The service was also pretty good. I would recommend their seafood!

30.description: Great cantonese dishes and decent service. It kicks the axxhole of the nearby szechuan restaurants.

46.description: Totally awesome. Amazing food. We got the Mango Beef, some noodle dishes and a huge seafood casserole with crab legs, mussels, shrimp, crayfish, potatoes, sausage and corn on the cob. 4 of us worked on it for over an hour and couldn't finish it!We had 2 kids, 1.5 and 5 years old, with us, absolutely no problem! We requested some corn cobs with no spice on them, they gladly gave us a dish of them for the baby.Free parking is a big plus!I will be back, I wish I could eat here every night!!

1.description: i've been making my way around chinatown and so glad to find this place! came here for dinner with friends and everything was fresh and portion sizes were generous.food rundown:spicy jellyfish - if you're into that slimy cartilage thing (just trying to be real), this is really good! dolo seafood combo - a giant platter of boiled seafood including crawfish, crab legs, shrimp and clams. it had a cajun flavor profile (minus all the butter), incredibly hearty and satisfying. eggplant casserole - chinese style eggplant is by far my favorite preparation of the vegetable, and it did not disappoint here. the sauce was rich and flavorful fried flat noodle with beef - the best i've had in the city, super crispy and perfectly saltycan't wait to come back and try their dim sum!

55.description: Sunday lunch dim sum was really popular. No hostess so people wrote their own names on a piece of paper at the bar.Reasonably priced menu and got 10% off for checking in on yelp. Score!100% Asian clientele and my mom got to speak Cantonese to the wait staff.Delicious food!

9.description: It's not often that I'll rave about a dim sum experience, but this place is truly phenomenal.  I've had my fair share of dim sum in Boston and New York, and they are all excellent, but Dolo brought dim sum to a whole new level and went above and beyond.  The restaurant itself is classier than most.  It's not your rundown, hectic, Chinatown-stereotypical restaurant.  It's rather elegant.  The tables, chairs, and booths have a classy edge to them, which I know is funny to say!  There is also a bar in the restaurant, so I'm sure this place is hopping at night too.My friends and I shared the spare ribs, chicken feet, beef dish (?) -- see pics, shumai, shrimp dumplings (ha-gao), shrimp crepe (ha-cherng), and many other things!  The quality of the dim sum here is top notch.  The shumai were my favorite.  They were so FILLED and ginormous!  We paid under $40 for three very happy and satisfied stomaches, which in my book, is a pretty good deal.  Asians do tapas the best! If you check in on Yelp, you get a 10% discount.  Alternatively, you can also you get the 10% discount if you pay cash instead of credit card.  Their happy hour is on weekdays from 2-4pm, where you get 20% off your bill!  If I lived in Chicago, I would frequent this restaurant pretty regularly!

26.description: Very good food and good service. The couch like settings are very nice. I have been there twice and their food are awesome. The $5 red wine lamb is a must order. The beef and mango are absolutely delicious. They currently have a 10% off for checking in. Very nice restaurant, will return!

25.description: This is the worst place I have even been customer service-wise. My friend and I sat there for 15 minutes without being served. Literally sitting in the booth. We confronted them about it and they blamed it on not speaking English. Bull. Why are you even open in Chicago if you can't speak enough English to serve customers?

12.description: This place is indeed a gem!! My friend (who grew up in China town) took me here! Ambience is wonderful. We had a great time catching up! It is also very clean and not overly noisy! Dim sum was fantastic!! I loved everything that we ordered, except that the durian dessert was an okay. I especially loved the egg tart and shui Mai-but honestly though, everything was absolutely delicious! Now I am thinking about it...I drool...Their price is super fair and affordable too! Please make your trip to try this place! It's totally worth it! There is no doubt that I am going back whenever I am in town! It already became one of my favorite dim sum spots in the U.S! It is definitely comparable to many of the dim sum places in HK that I've tried!

59.description: Mannnn, fuck this place! They double charged my card and when I called the manager about it he gave me the run around for over a week. I finally had to call my bank to get it settled. Go here if you like small portions and over priced food.The food was meh, save your money and eat in the square or else you're just paying for decoration and the parking convenience(if you can find a spot). NoGo to Dolo!

21.description: For some reason I was thinking I already wrote a review for here, but I guess I haven't yet. First of all, this restaurant has a parking lot, in Chinatown! That's rare and comes in handy. I like going to this place for dim sum or dinner. They specialize in seafood, and I love seafood. Their food is fresh and tasteful. I love their lobster and shrimp. Very good size, market price. They also have very good dim sum as well, egg tart is good and congee is yummy so well. I wish they had fried dough with the congee but it's okay. To keep it short, I do love this place! seafood is the way to go, unless you want dim sum. Written by an ESL before she sleeps, forgive typos

17.description: More like a 3.5, but I like to round up. It was one of my friends' birthday, so we made a reservation for a party of 12. When we arrived, I was surprised to find out that they reserved a room for our party. The room was pretty small for 12 people, but we still managed. We had trouble communicated with some of the workers since they do not speak English, but it was fine since the workers were really nice. I prefer that over rude staffs any day. We ordered a few appetizers to start off our dinner. The assorted house appetizers were ok, but the fried spare ribs were so good. The Mai Thai was pretty strong, two of my friends did not finish their drinks. We also ordered the seafood combo. Honestly, I had better, but it was decent. Way better than most places in Chicago. The Beef Tenderloin Chow Fun was whatever, I expected it to be better since people kept talking about it. The fried rice and the Crab meat fish stomach soup were basic. Overall, friendly staffs and ok/decent food. Would I recommend this place to a friend? I am not sure about that. However, would I come back to this place again? Yeah.

10.description: Restaurant close to the center of Chinatown with it's own (tiny) private parking lot??  Count me in!I came here around 8:30 PM on a Saturday night, and while it was pretty loud (we were yelling across the booth) and busy when we got there, by the time we left it had quieted quite a bit.After looking at the other Yelp reviews (which actually happened to line up with what our table was thinking about getting anyway), we ordered the Szechuan Style Seafood Eggplant Casserole, the Sweet & Sour chicken, and the French Sauteed Diced Beef Filet Noodle.  They came out later to tell us that they had run out of the noodles for the dish (Whaaaaat??? It was only 9 and they close at 1PM).  We ended up getting one of their other noodle dishes.  All of the food was really good, flavorful & cooked well.  Although the prices seem slightly more expensive, they're actually pretty reasonable considering the portion you're getting.Definitely would come back here, if anything, to try the Dolo Seafood Combo which, it seemed like, every other table had ordered.The decor was clean and modern, from our booth we were able to peek into a private room which looked pretty fancy.

5.description: this place has good environment which is a plus for restaurants in chinatown.we came here for dim sum, and they have a lot of items that are not found in Cai or Minghin. we really loved the durian pancake, it is not smelly but they had the real durian fruit in there, very nicely made, and surprisingly refreshing.we also ordered a bitter melon sesame cake, it is quite good, the cake does not really have a bitter taste, and the sesame is not overwhemingly sweetwe came here once for dinner, the portion is a bit small and food are on the oily sideoverall, i would recommend people to come here, the owner of the restaurant is very nice, he would come around and make sure everyone enjoyed their meal

3.description: We just had a pretty solid pre-Chinese New Year dinner! It was quite empty at 10pm on a Friday, but I assume all reasonable people already had eaten. :) We ordered:Salt & Pepper Prawn - 3.5 / bordering on 4Pretty standard size and taste wise. Quantity was pretty generous in my opinion.XO Cuttlefish - 3.5I really enjoyed the flavor! My +1 thought the whole dish was overcooked. The cuttlefish was a bit rubbery, but I've never had it any other way/texture, so couldn't speak to that opinion. I wasn't crazy about the lemongrass... yes, "aromatics" and all, but there was a sh!t ton if the stuff! Honestly.Sweet and Sour Pork - 3.5 / bordering on 4Not fatty nor overcooked and, when piping hot, the coating was crisp and thin. Good flavor and not too saucy. "French" Filet Sautéed Beef Tenderloin w/Noodle - 2.5Supposedly this is really popular, but we weren't big fans. The beef was tender but was more chewy than I prefer, and was plopped on top of a circular blob of noodles. The noodles were way crisp around the edges and very soft underneath the beef. I love carbs, but totally skipped the noodles. He wasn't a fan.  Service was friendly: not obtrusive, our questions were answered, and another server (owner?) chimed in when we were undecided about noodle dishes.  We asked about the Peking-Style Pork Chop (photo posted by Kaman T.) AND Tea Roasted Chicken... we didn't see either on the menu and our server said they didn't have those dishes. Hmph. They did offer some off-menu (but soon-to-be-added) items that included a tofu and woodland mushroom dish.Decor was more modern, but the tables have lots of unsightly water stains (and they've only been around a short time?). They have what looked to be a full bar and a TV well into the dining room (kind of clashed with the dining room ambiance, IMO, but I guess if you have a boring date, you can zone out and watch the game). From what I saw, it was clean.I totally forgot to use the Check-In deal, gurrr. That just gives an excuse to come again and try the tofu or dim sum.

35.description: It's not often that I'll rave about a dim sum experience, but this place is truly phenomenal.  I've had my fair share of dim sum in Boston and New York, and they are all excellent, but Dolo brought dim sum to a whole new level and went above and beyond.  The restaurant itself is classier than most.  It's not your rundown, hectic, Chinatown-stereotypical restaurant.  It's rather elegant.  The tables, chairs, and booths have a classy edge to them, which I know is funny to say!  There is also a bar in the restaurant, so I'm sure this place is hopping at night too.My friends and I shared the spare ribs, chicken feet, beef dish (?) -- see pics, shumai, shrimp dumplings (ha-gao), shrimp crepe (ha-cherng), and many other things!  The quality of the dim sum here is top notch.  The shumai were my favorite.  They were so FILLED and ginormous!  We paid under $40 for three very happy and satisfied stomaches, which in my book, is a pretty good deal.  Asians do tapas the best! If you check in on Yelp, you get a 10% discount.  Alternatively, you can also you get the 10% discount if you pay cash instead of credit card.  Their happy hour is on weekdays from 2-4pm, where you get 20% off your bill!  If I lived in Chicago, I would frequent this restaurant pretty regularly!

19.description: Dolo is on the low low. Hard to find if you're not familiar with Chinatown, but definitely worth it when you do. Their dim sim is really delicious and absolutely dirt cheap. I was lucky enough to go with some seasoned pros so they just ordered a bunch of stuff that was super tasty and totaled about 11 bucks a person including gratuity. Best part is the abundance of private rooms available by reservation. There's a couple and if you're trying to do dim sum Sunday these can be hard to find in Chinatown. Dolo doesn't just accommodate, but they do it with a big screen TV in tact so you can watch football while you're stuffing your face full of shui mai.For a cheap Sunday snack this is one of the better bets in this area. Just be sure not to drive cause parking can be a nightmare.

28.description: Brought Whitebread inlaws there for Thanksgiving. I was already screwing up their holiday by not letting them have the same meal they have had for 40 years complete with the same stories. Flat out by the end of it.. everyone was literally fighting for the right to somehow figure out how to lick the plate and not seem rude. The salt and pepper enoki mushrooms app was flat out as addictive as crap. I am an eastcoaster and lobster in the midwest just ain't the same thing as fresh maine lobster. Dolo's lobster isn't the same.. it's fucking transcendent. They turn something simple and beautiful and turn it into something that I would flat out sell blood to get more of. Thank god it's only $15. Go now. RIGHT NOW. GO WITHOUT PANTS. PS. He said he wasn't working there anymore in a week but in case he is.. Jason the waiter was PRICELESS. DOLO don't let him go:)

45.description: Dolo is on the low low. Hard to find if you're not familiar with Chinatown, but definitely worth it when you do. Their dim sim is really delicious and absolutely dirt cheap. I was lucky enough to go with some seasoned pros so they just ordered a bunch of stuff that was super tasty and totaled about 11 bucks a person including gratuity. Best part is the abundance of private rooms available by reservation. There's a couple and if you're trying to do dim sum Sunday these can be hard to find in Chinatown. Dolo doesn't just accommodate, but they do it with a big screen TV in tact so you can watch football while you're stuffing your face full of shui mai.For a cheap Sunday snack this is one of the better bets in this area. Just be sure not to drive cause parking can be a nightmare.

33.description: Only went there once, great food. I am surprised that they have private rooms like back in China. But parking is limited...

43.description: Better than expected dimsum. Seriously, all of the food was good-- especially the turnip cakes in XO sauce.   SO GOOD!  The bill also came out to $36 for 3 people, which is great for dimsum. We will definitely come back!

2.description: As much as I want to give this place more stars I didn't enjoy eating here..For one thing,No one speaks English! Just because I'm Asian doesn't mean I speak Chinese. They never gave us dipping sauce for our dim sum.They don't have hot mustard I don't think I'll be eating here again.

18.description: Sunday lunch dim sum was really popular. No hostess so people wrote their own names on a piece of paper at the bar.Reasonably priced menu and got 10% off for checking in on yelp. Score!100% Asian clientele and my mom got to speak Cantonese to the wait staff.Delicious food!

41.description: Real live stream of solo dim sum experience of Dolo. Came in for lunch at 1pm after finishing up at the conference. Chicago does this thing where you tick it off a colored pamphlet....kinda wasteful if you ask me. Anyways I went with the shrimp dumplings, ginger tripe, beef rice crepe, soup dumplings, and pork n shrimp siumai. They supplied me with my own pot of hot tea, free of charge. The latter being important cause some places are sneaky and charge like $4 for that.Holy wow this dim sum was good. Tripe was so soft and the ginger was equisite. The shrimp dumpling and rice crepe were average. Soup dumplings were meh, probably wouldn't get again. The winner of the show was the steamed pork dumpling which was GINORMOUS. 2 giant shrimp inside with the pork, and when you break it apart a little broth comes out. This was honestly so delicious, I wish I had just gotten 5 of those. And I wouldn't even regret it.Weekdays they do 20% off between 2-4. I arrived a little before that but was honestly too hungry to wait. Instead, checking in gets you 10% off. Next time in Chicago, will definitely come.

52.description: Ok, a little disappointed at first when we were denied crawfish on a Sat night. They were out!!  Next shipment Monday. That's not a good sign. Then, the next disappointment was no foie gras thing that I saw in the pics!!  What?????  But, in the end, it was a fantastic meal. 4 adults, 4 pre-teen kids, all ate for $133. Not bad considering we had two lobsters, a pound of crab legs, walnut shrimp, and a whole host of other stuff I can't even remember. I do recall the fried enoki mushrooms having a tremendous effect on even the pickiest eaters in the bunch. I loved that you can pick what style you want your seafood cooked in. There were a ton of options: Dolo style, taiwanese, singapore, etc. It was awesome. I heard this place was compared to Angry Crab. I was pleasantly surprised by this place. The service was friendly and efficient. We had a private room with a TV no less! And this place has a small parking lot. I highly highly recommend this place.  I will definitely come back here again.

50.description: Very delicious! Good service, good food, clean and cosy, comfortable seating and atmosphere, have private parking. Best stream egg York lava bun.

4.description: I was craving dim sum and decided to go here to celebrate my birthday. I know most dim sum places are super busy on Sunday so luckily I was able to make a reservation for my large party. We were seated in a separate room with another large party. It was a very accommodating and intimate setting. I ordered an assortment of dishes for all of us to share: soup dumplings, siopao, shrimp dumplings, sesame balls, shrimp egg rolls, beef, bbq pork and shrimp crepes, spare ribs in black bean sauce, pan fried noodles, fried rice and mango pudding. Everything was delicious! I've had my share of mediocre dim sum and this restaurant stands out for good authentic dim sum. The service wasn't great - many of the servers did not speak English so it was a bit frustrating, but the great food made up for it. I also checked-in on Yelp and got 10% off! I also read that happy hour is 20% off during the week between 2-4 pm. I absolutely want to come back and try their other dishes! Come here for amazing dim sum!

6.description: Real live stream of solo dim sum experience of Dolo. Came in for lunch at 1pm after finishing up at the conference. Chicago does this thing where you tick it off a colored pamphlet....kinda wasteful if you ask me. Anyways I went with the shrimp dumplings, ginger tripe, beef rice crepe, soup dumplings, and pork n shrimp siumai. They supplied me with my own pot of hot tea, free of charge. The latter being important cause some places are sneaky and charge like $4 for that.Holy wow this dim sum was good. Tripe was so soft and the ginger was equisite. The shrimp dumpling and rice crepe were average. Soup dumplings were meh, probably wouldn't get again. The winner of the show was the steamed pork dumpling which was GINORMOUS. 2 giant shrimp inside with the pork, and when you break it apart a little broth comes out. This was honestly so delicious, I wish I had just gotten 5 of those. And I wouldn't even regret it.Weekdays they do 20% off between 2-4. I arrived a little before that but was honestly too hungry to wait. Instead, checking in gets you 10% off. Next time in Chicago, will definitely come.

22.description: A friend was telling me about an article she read (awhile back) which listed Dolo as one of Chicago's best up and coming.  (I forget the actual magazine but the owners will talk about it as well.) So, I got a group together and out we went to Chinatown to check out their finest in eats.Via Yelp/Open table on the smartphone app, I had trouble trying to get a reservation so I called the restaurant and setup it up pretty easily.  At the restaurant it was a little after 7 pm on a lazy Sunday evening and the place was maybe 25% busy.The restaurant is snazzy looking in comparison to many of the other more ethnic restaurants of Chinatown.  It's modern chic, perfect for a date or to impress a group.  And surprisingly, not expensive at all.  Since I created the event and had already checked out their food porn (Food photos per Yelp & Instagram), my group allowed me to place the bulk of the orders.  a few of the items were:Peking style pork chopsSzechuan style Eggplant with shrimp (spicy)French style filet mignonLobster special x2 in different flavors. (Requires finger use, difficult otherwise. No tools avail?)Beef tenderloin chow funLamb chops x2 in different marinades (The meat was easy to cut through for sharing.)Appetizers:Something with Woodear mushrooms (I love mushrooms and Woodear is great for you, but most of the table was not impressed with it.)Fried Shrimp dumplings.Beyond this a couple more plates were ordered. Due to their bartender being sick that evening, the bar area was closed because they hadn't anyone to tend! So our bill was for food only.  And because of that, the breakdown was about $20 per person(x5)! Awesome pricing and all of us left full.Since their bar was closed and I had a bartender buddy in the group, we sent him over to have a conversation with the owner.  Maybe he could tend their bar and make us drinks which we would then pay for? Surprisingly, they were cool about it and the owner requested a mixed drink as well.  After some conversation with him and his trying to sway us into ordering more of their specialty dishes, he decided to "comp" us on our drinks. Score! Initially we declined but he wouldn't take no. He thanked us for coming in and tried a second time to get us to order more. (At that point, we'd already ordered more dishes than necessary) (I would guess that having 3 attractive women in our group helped with the complimentary drinks, even otherwise, it was a nice gesture.) Regarding service; serving and time it took for plates to hit the table was not long. But to have a conversation and understanding with their waiters took a bit of patience. Also because many different waiters came around to the table, we weren't sure whom was or if there was a main waiter for our table.  There were a few instances of misunderstanding and an inability to find out whether they offered desserts or not. That evening there was probably only one waiter on hand that spoke English semi-fluent, unless one of the owners were on the floor at the time.

15.description: For some reason I was thinking I already wrote a review for here, but I guess I haven't yet. First of all, this restaurant has a parking lot, in Chinatown! That's rare and comes in handy. I like going to this place for dim sum or dinner. They specialize in seafood, and I love seafood. Their food is fresh and tasteful. I love their lobster and shrimp. Very good size, market price. They also have very good dim sum as well, egg tart is good and congee is yummy so well. I wish they had fried dough with the congee but it's okay. To keep it short, I do love this place! seafood is the way to go, unless you want dim sum. Written by an ESL before she sleeps, forgive typos

57.description: Drove past and said let try it. Very tasty. Had governors chicken. Very delicious. Nice lil spice. Will def b coming backSpring rolls were out of this world.

20.description: My new go to Dim Sum place in Chicago.We were there on Christmas Day, dim sum were fresh and tasty. Everything we ordered, we have nothing to complaint about as they were all great!Shui Mai & Beef Tendon - a must!Be sure to make reservation though - enjoy!

36.description: wonderful atmosphere accompanied by delicious dishes that are one of a kind that will have you craving for the rest of the week. i love it.

14.description: The food was delicious. The atmosphere is extremely cute and the service was spectacular. Absolutely loved the Beef with Mango and the lamb chop was to die for. Really enjoyed it.

58.description: Spacious interior with nice decorations, low noise level, and decent service. Dim Sum is really the specialty here (my guess is this is why they got the Michelin recommendation -- not quite a star but still quite difficult to get). A smaller menu than what you'll find at Cai or Ming Hin, but every item is prepared consistently well although served at a slower pace. One complaint I do have about the menu is the lack of pictures for dim sum and not following the  standard naming convention of dishes in Chinatown (meaning it's more difficult to order some of your favorite items if you can't read Chinese). Even with some flaws, the superb quality of the food at a very reasonable price level easily gives this restaurant 5 stars.Some of my favorite dishes:Chaozhou style dumpling - Excellent combination of peanuts, ground pork, chives, and mushroom. Great combination of textures and flavors in a thicker skin.Mango pancake: Delicious fresh mango in a slightly sweet pancake Shui Mai: Cannot be missed, this is probably the best you'll find in Chicago. Full of flavor, juice, and a very bouncy texture.Fried dough: Very nice crispy exterior with a delicious pork meat filling inside. Sticky rice is chewy and fantastic.Lao's style shrimp dumpling: Nice big pieces of shrimp with a great texture and very clean flavor.Fried dough crepe: This an every other crepe they have has very nice thin bouncy skins filled with quality ingredients. This one stood out since it's uncommon for many restaurants to be able to keep the fried dough super crispy while being steamed by the crepe.Shanghai steamed stuffed bun: Better known as Xaio Long Bao, for me this wasn' the most amazing version I've had (could've used more juice and broth could've had more flavor) but it's a solid version.Mixed meat and peanut congee: Creamy congee and the mixed meat in here is delicious. Light but very enjoyable.Coconut red bean pudding: Superb combination. The coconut really brings out the flavor of the red bean. This really has no bitterness or starchy feel and is almost like eating a very nice ice cream (with a silky almost tofu like texture).BBQ pork bun: Fluffy bun with a very addictive BBQ pork filling that is just sweet enough to satisify your sweet tooth but just salty enough to bring out the flavor of the pork. The sauce in this is fantastic.Even if you aren't into dim sum, the dinner options are quite good here too. A bit lighter and more skillfully prepared dishes like tony three chili fish fillet, crispy rainbow fish flower, three kingdom steamed egg, and pork belly with pea leaves are good items to try.

56.description: the server was nice to us , but the food was not good at all . The sizzling plate was cold , the pork chop was cold and the waitress took it back to the kitchen to microwave it. Overall , it's not a good Chinese food place

29.description: It's an authentic Chinese restaurant. And the service here is really nice.

42.description: We went there on Sunday, 8/24/14 around 2pm. It was empty being that it was in the middle of the afternoon, but right when we walked inside the decor looked pleasant and the servers seated us right away. Looking at the menu, I was glad there was pictures! We ordered Spicy Fish Fillet (not spicy, but more on the sweet side. It was still good, but don't expect it to be spicy), green beans (it was better than the regular ones that are served at the buffet), crispy shrimp & fried corn (shrimp was butterfly cut and nothing out the ordinary. It was salty. The corn was fried which was weird, but different to try.) General Tso Chicken (it was spicy and flavorful.) Beef hot pot (it was also flavorful. I should have requested to add more mushrooms since I love mushrooms.) And  then a side of chicken feet from the dim sum menu ($3.99 for just one order).Food was flavorful (anything compared to the Chinese buffets that you usually get is always better.) Service was EXCELLENT. Our server was extremely helpful and gave us suggestions on what food would suit us. He was patient and attentive. Also rare to see in a Chinese restaurant. Being that the restaurant was empty, all the servers helped us with getting us drinks and whatever we needed.I would go there again!

23.description: Xiao Long Bao was not on their menu.  Maybe it's on their secret menu but still do not understand the purpose of maintaining one.  However, their XLB was alright.  Not quite exactly like Din Tai Fung but close enough.  I felt it was too pricey...4 pieces for $8.  At least there were soup juices inside those XLBs but had to ask for black vinegar and never got my julienned gingers. I plan on coming back to Chinatown to try other restaurants that has XLBs for cheaper.    I'm sure some of them are from frozen bag.  I'll just have to find out for myself after all on which place serve freshly made baos and which are frozen.  This is the whole point of food exploration which makes it a fun activity.

47.description: A buddy and I got here just after midnight. Service was SLOOOOOOW and there were only 4 customers including us. We order General Tso chicken. Waitress recommends sweet and sour soup and we accept her suggestion. After about 15 minutes, soup comes and it is extremely bland - neither sweet nor sour. Would not recommend it. About 15 to 20 minutes later General Tso Chicken comes out. It looks good and tastes good too. However, the meat was maybe a bit tough. Waitress or bar back may have sensed our displeasure with the wait and appetizer. We were presented with free pudding at the end of our meal. The pudding was good. Overall, the server and bar back were very pleasant, albeit a bit pushy regarding ordering a drink and appetizer. I would visit again, but in hopes that service was just a little faster and the recommended appetizer is actually good.

8.description: I've been here three times, twice in the main dining room and once in a private room.  The private room was definitely nicer and more personable.  The main room has some larger tables for mid-size groups, but it can get busy and there will be significant background noise.The food has been average, some good some bad, reasonable price for Chinatown.  But honestly if I'm going all the way to Chinatown I want to eat something really delicious and with so many other options, I'd rather go elsewhere.
