A big plus is that Lao You Ju takes reservations and can accommodate large parties, and the tables have always been ready when my party arrived.The egg custard yolk bun was great, bbq pork bao was pretty good, soup dumplings were flavorful but fell apart easily.  Boiled fish and cumin lamb were both average.  Skip the Shanghai spring rolls and green bean jelly.

31.description: The fact that this is a Tony Hu restaurant doesn't mean anything other than his name and photo pops up.  Your food will vary based on the cook that shift.  Dinner is hit-or-miss (2.5 stars), but dim sum is great (3.5 stars).Dim sum: The menu is small, but has all your favorites, and what they have, they do well.  The rice crepes were the most impressive since the key is getting them translucent thin, and Lao You Ju's got it right.  Both the beef and shrimp were delicious!  The shrimp and pork dumplings were generously sized and juicy.  Chicken feet was yummy and had substantial skin to chew on.  They have xiao long bao!!!Skip the congee and bean curd rolls unless you're going for plain food as they really doesn't have much flavor.  I would also pass on the short ribs, which are very fatty with no meat. For dessert, the coconut red bean jello was nice.Dinner: The eggplant, string beans, and fish fillet had one thing in common - glistening in grease.  Chili oil is expected in Szechuan cuisine, but I thought the veggies would be somewhat healthy.  My finicky stomach is prone to indigestion, and I was folded over in pain halfway into the meal. Dinner may be a gamble, but I like to throw it in the mix dim sum!  No wait and $2 validated lot parking is a plus.

34.description: After our first visit here for dinner, I wasn't expecting to ever return.  Everything was doused in oil and the pool of oil settling at the bottom of the plates was troubling.After spotting some pictures of the dim sum on yelp, my girlfriend pushed to give this place another try, and I'm pretty glad we did.  There was no trouble getting seated for six on a saturday.  The xiao long bao was piping hot and was served in little individual metal dishes, possibly to keep them from losing all their soup if they burst?  Almost all of the other food items that we ordered (rice noodle-wrapped shrimp, siu mai, ha gao, turnip cakes) were pretty good, with the exception of the water chestnut cakes.  So...come here for dim sum - it's a pretty good alternative to Cai, Ming Hin, Phoenix, etc. etc.

16.description: I came here just to try the durian pancake..but...Had to wait 30 min for my order and they brought out only 2 out of 4. Waited another 45 minutes while trying to get the waiters attentions to check on my order even to get the soy sauce. Then after 45 minutes the manager comes and tells me the waiter forgot to put the order in.Horrible. By then all my expectation and craving for the durian pancake is gone as I was sipping on the bland weak Chinese tea while waiting for a waiter to stop at my table.Terrible service!

13.description: This place went downhill over the years. Food used to have good presentation and taste good but now it looks crappy and taste nasty. I would choose a different restaurant and stay away if possible.

11.description: I've only ever been to this place for dim sum so I am only speaking for the breakfast. I've been here with the family about 5 times. Every time, I have left full and satisfied with the food. They have all the traditional foods: the shrimp and pork dumplings, the shrimp in rice roll, the bbq buns, etc. Food comes out relatively quick and fresh; super yummy!The thing I really love about this place is the service. They are so nice here. There's never a long wait and they always reassure us that it'll be our turn soon. They update you on the wait time and smile often. During the dining experience, they constantly ask for ways to improve our experience such as asking if we want anything else, if the food is good, etc. I really appreciate the way they treat their customers. All in all, I would highly recommend this place. Nice people and awesome food!

39.description: It covers a large range of Chinese food, including Sichuan food and Cantonese food. Recommend the fish and Sanbei Chicken.

37.description: This place has private room with Karaoke. If you spend more than $150 the Karaoke is free. Food is just OK though. The spicy food on the menu is not spicy at all.

0.description: This restaurant now goes under the name of Ding Sheng.  It serves Szechuan cuisine with an extensive menu of dishes I never heard of. Lots of fish and seafood dishes along with Diced Rabbit with Red Chili Sauce, Tea Smoked Duck and Baked Eggplant with Salted Egg Yolk. First off the negatives. The egg rolls were slightly overcooked; it was hard to cut them open to eat. I would have returned them but it took so long to get served we were too hungry to wait. The service was slow and disorganized. However the food made up for it. The Braised Eggplant with Chef's Special Sauce was flavored with a wonderful rich sauce that had a hint of garlic. The Shredded Pork with Peking Sauce had narrow strips of tender meat with thin strips of green onions on top that added a nice crunch. It was delicious. We ordered Pancake with Beef Inside but we never got it. As I said, the service was disorganized. They were crowded and the manager wound up taking our order. He apologized for the delay and said we had come at a busy time. I would give this restaurant three and a half stars. The food was great and the portions were very generous. The two of us spent $17.00 including tax and tip for two entrees and an appetizer. We will definitely come back and see if the service improves.

38.description: My new favorite place to go for soup dumplings (xiao long bao)!!! I've been on the search, and I can finally say that this place will fulfill any of my soup dumpling cravings LOL.I'll have to try this place for dim sum, but we came for dinner and ended up ordering random entrees and a couple "dim sum" dishes that were available to order. The prices are reasonable, and each dish is legit. So for those of you who, like me, were looking for a good soup dumpling place, then this is it!!!~I always order the green beans, you really can't go wrong with this dish LOL. Sorry for being so boring and always ordering the same thing at every Chinese restaurant. But come on. It's green beans. SO delicious and crunchy and flavorful! hahahaha.

51.description: Went for lunch on a Saturday afternoon. Clean and a little nicer than the sister restaurants. Service was good, seemed to have a front/back waiter system.   We had pork belly and pea leaves, the duck that also comes with duck fried rice, special spicy fried shrimp, tofu and mushrooms, and edamame. Everything was great except for the overcooked edamame.  Nice size portions. We love this chain of restaurants! Would eat here again!

27.description: I heard great things about this place and was excited to try it with my boyfriend and everything was pretty good until my boyfriend looked over and saw roaches crawling along the wall by the kitchen, ruined my whole appetite, will definitely never be going back.

32.description: I went there for Sichuan cuisine and its definitely a wrong decision. Taste like the Sichuan dishes altered for Canton people (which can be easily spot in Hong Kong, sign) Not spicy, used too much soy sauces.

54.description: Dear Tony, you've got a mess on your hands.My previous experience was atrocious enough that I didn't return for 3.5 years but this morning while I was feening for dim sum, I decided to give LYJ one more try.  I've read decent reviews about the new dim sum menu and it was the only place that I could get a table at without a 30-60 minute wait.  I'm giving 2 stars for the food, it was good.  That's all the credit you'll get.The service was so infuriating that I can't help but just laugh at how ridiculous it was.  Let me start by saying I could literally care less about service at a Chinese restaurant, if you have good food and can get it to me within a reasonable amount of time, you've done a great job - that's to say, my standards are low.As soon as you walk through the doors of LYJ, you're greeted by chaos.  The place is only 2/3 full, plenty of empty tables, but the staff is running around like chickens with their heads cut off. I have no idea who the host is, everyone is doing everything, there is no rhyme or reason to the flow of the restaurant. You've got to take a Xanax before dining here.There weren't any issues with ordering our food, we get pretty much everything in a decent amount of time...but then we play the waiting game. I get my congee and I'm waiting on the fried dough to eat it with.  Never get it, or my bf's noodle dish.  I asked a server about the two missing items, turns out they completely forgot about the fried dough. Fine whatever, I'm pretty full anyways, I'll just eat my congee without it.  Then 10 minutes later, we're done eating, still no noodle. I ask for the check thinking that maybe they just never put it in since the guy who took the noodle order was a totally different person than who took the rest of the order (again, crazy chaos).  Well...they still charged me for the missing noodle. I tell another different server about it, she tells me the noodles are ready and waiting in the kitchen (what?? so why did you never bring it out??).  She asked if I wanted to cancel the order and I said yes, we're done eating and all packed up.  So she goes to give me a new check, and directly behind her is another women who drops the noodle off at our table.  Ok....so maybe they're sorry about all the mistakes and just giving us the noodles? Nope, the last server comes back again and gives me the original check, telling me to pay for the noodles.  I'm not paying for something you forgot about, I told you to cancel and then you decide to bring out to me.  We get into an argument, she scolds me for messing up.  According to her, I should've never allowed the other server to even put the noodle down on our table.  But we were so confused by all the different people telling us different things, I had no idea what was going on.  After she finishes yelling at me for my "mistakes" she whisks our noodle away and angrily takes my credit card to pay for the meal.  Ugh....mess mess mess mess.  There's no way I'm going back. EVER.If I ever crave dim sum again, I will get my lazy ass out of bed earlier to wait in line at either Ming Hin or Cai.

48.description: Came in here very hungry after a day out at the Lincoln park and the beach. Left very disappointed. Didn't realize I have not been here for that long since my last visit. The decor was changed. No more lounge or chic feeling any more. The atmosphere is more close to Lao sichuan now but unfortunate the dish is not in par with Lao Sichuan.We ordered the spicy fish fillet, Shanghai tofu curd, Beef kabob with cumin, green beans, beef noodle soup, and xiao long bao. The decent one is Shanghai tofu curd. Still had the texture flavor as expected. The spicy fish fillet was the beginning of the lousy dishes for the night. It is NOT spicy at all. Fish fillet had too much bread and not fresh nor tender enough. It is getting close to a cantonese dish in a bad way. Beef Kabob had the right flavor but the meat was not fresh enough. Beef noodle soup was fine which tasted more like a wonton soup base. Kids liked the noodle so I won't complain. Xiao Long bao was no where near Hing Kee or Cai. I suppressed my urge to ask the chili sauce which might save the dish a bit. The whole thing was more like a Cantonese place trying to sell lousy Sichuan food. In short, the decor, food and services were deterioratin  from last visit. Not recommended any more.

44.description: good noodle

24.description: I've been here three times, twice in the main dining room and once in a private room.  The private room was definitely nicer and more personable.  The main room has some larger tables for mid-size groups, but it can get busy and there will be significant background noise.The food has been average, some good some bad, reasonable price for Chinatown.  But honestly if I'm going all the way to Chinatown I want to eat something really delicious and with so many other options, I'd rather go elsewhere. A big plus is that Lao You Ju takes reservations and can accommodate large parties, and the tables have always been ready when my party arrived.The egg custard yolk bun was great, bbq pork bao was pretty good, soup dumplings were flavorful but fell apart easily.  Boiled fish and cumin lamb were both average.  Skip the Shanghai spring rolls and green bean jelly.

7.description: I love having Dim Sum at this place, but the dinner dishes we had today weren't very satisfying. We ordered several things today. The way the dishes were presented gave me a high expectation; however, the expectation wasn't met... We ordered the Crispy Rainbow Fish (if I remembered the name correctly), which tastes like deep fried shell with tons of sweet sour sauce. The Salt and Pepper Pork Chop was good! The Frog Leg was a little over cooked. The Chinese Broccoli looked not as green/fresh as in the picture. The Three Cup Chicken has a strong flavor as always. The fact that it was brought to our table after 2 mins we ordered it made me believed that they simply reheated it... The service was good and everyone was friendly. I would definitely go back for Dim Sum, but doesn't recommend for dinner.

49.description: I shall start this review by saying that if you go to Chinatown without someone from China, chances are very strong you'll get food that has the flavouring of China Buffet. I went with a former colleague who is from mainland China and the food that we got was very reminiscent of the Chinese cooking my first room mate's parents cooked when they visited. Authentic!We opted for the dim sum menu options, which meant we had food galore. I've posted photos, so I'll let the captions speak for the pictures that I captured. But the flavours I couldn't capture in digital prints. Everything was spicy or had a kick without salt. And truth be told, I didn't get the usual MSG bite either.The service was outstanding, although the servers spoke to my former colleague in Chinese. What little bit I did understand was not a slight to me and they were very much aware of my presence. Lao You Ju is one of the restaurants in Chinatown that brings in more Americans than the restaurants that seem "off the main street." Would I return? Yes, but with a friend who is Chinese so that I'm not served food that tastes like it has been delivered from China Buffet.

40.description: Come before 11:30am for fantastic Dim Sum!!! This place feels like you are in a restaurant in China with fancy decor and modern atmosphere. The food is fresh and tasty full of flavor with every dish! If you want dim sum with no wait then come before 11:30am to get seated right away! After you order your dim sum, they will make it fresh for you, so you might wait a little. It tastes better than the cart dim sum, since the food is not pre made waiting in the cart until you get it. Good service when you ask as usual in a chinese restaurant. The prices for dim sum are about the same as the others but taste better and it is freshly made when you order. They don't charge for tea here unlike other dim sum restaurants. The chairs are comfy and they have several private rooms that fit about fifteen people to one table. Two TVs in the room entertain you while you eat! Great place for dim sum and dinner! I'll be back to try the other entrees!

53.description: Great menu, but my food took forever. The waiter even made a joke that they had to go to the farm to get it.  Great veggie dish, try the pea shoots.

30.description: really great. planned a surprise party for a friend in one of their private karaoke rooms, good food, tons of asahi, and overall not that expensive for 15 people. really sweet waitresses and good service.

46.description: A made to order type of dim sum, not the one where they push a cart around. All the food we ordered was cooked to perfection and seasoned well. The taste was on point. The place is decorated well, and the staff friendly and focused. The price is good too,  cheaper than Chicago pho! For desert we had the papaya crispy pastry, bomb!

1.description: Recently got a name change?  I did noticed that the Chinese name changed, didn't catch what the new name is now. Have been going to LYJ for their dim sum for a little more than a year and I have to say their quality of dim sum was not what it used to be. However, that being said, I believe they still have one of the best dim sum in town.   Their Shu Mai is definitely one of the best in town and they do not cheap out on the seafood they incorporated in to the different dishes. Everything is just a little more flavorful than other places in the area (maybe extra MSG added?). Anyways, still my go to place and will continue to go there until I find another place to top it.

55.description: What I love about Lao You Ju is that they have Karaoke rooms! The restaurant environment is very nice and very nice service. The food is great too!  If you have a huge party, they offer party package meals.

9.description: This place has dim sum, and I'm not sure how long that has been the case.  Anyway, it is quite good, and I would not hesitate to return.  Seating is comfortable, so that is advantageous over at least one of their competitors that I can think of.  Pricing and dim sum variety is also comparable to the competition.

26.description: Just stopped by today with a friend for some dim sum and it was wonderful. Their sui mai and egg custard yolk bun are the best. This place is so fancy in the interior which makes me feels so comfortable as I'm enjoying eating dim sum. Their employees serve with great service and I will definitely come back another time.

25.description: OK so apparently according to some of the reviewers on here, this place used to be legit but shit hit the fan and it went downhill.Well, let me enlighten you, they are right!I've always just stuck to MingHin for dim sum but I needed a break from that place and try another so my friend suggested this one.I dont understand the service here. There is this head honcho guy who runs around and yells at his staff and the rest of the staff is usually running around clueless. They also don't have the space organized so it's one server per a few tables, nope, lets just have all 5 servers serve all tables. And the servers are stupidly clueless! Last time I went to eat here, one server at one point took away all the sauces that we had on the table while we were still eating. Um hello? We need those, bring those back!  And then 5 minutes later, another server came by and started clearing out our tables WHILE we were eating. The server was motioning toward my friends plate as of my friend needs to put down her choptsticks. My friend literally had to tell her to walk away. it was weird as hell! And then to top it off, they charged both our cards multiple times. The food here is good but honestly, i don't need that kind of shitty service. I'm going back to MingHin.

12.description: Just ok. The congee was bland.  We needed to add a lot of soy sauce and pepper. I felt the choices were lacking. They didn't have the fried taro puffs filled with minced pork. There were a lot of staples I felt were missing.  They did have a few things that were new like the mango Rangoon for lack of a better name. Basically a noodle roll filled with whipped cream and mango bits. Just ok. The custard buns were good. Overall, doesn't really compare to the old standard Phoenix.

59.description: The food was mediocre. But what really pisses me off is the terrible terrible service. I honestly have never seen such a frantic and disorganized restaurant. I kid you not, every single waiter in that restaurant had served and stopped by at our table at least once. We were never assigned one person, which would have been much more clearer and convenient for everybody. The restaurant is run by this middle age man that flies around the restaurant yelling and running and stopping at every table. He does a terrible job managing the clueless younger asian boys that have absolutely no idea what they're doing. The casualties: First of all, our food took a total of 40 minutes for all of it to arrive at our table. Mind you, it's DIM SUM that shit should be FAST. You have to flag a waiter down to help you and nag them to get your food. Not once did a waiter come and ask us if everything was alright. What really pissed me off was that these girls sitting next to us ordered 15 minutes after we did and got their food immediately. The phone ringing is so loud you can hear it in the entire restaurant. Like it's on speakers or something. This older man that is clearly the manager runs around the restaurant, is frantic, and never stops to breathe. I saw him THROWING towels used to wipe tables to the waiters.My mom asked we could order more food. The guy literally replied with "I don't know."I asked for water. He served me hot water in a glass clearly meant for cold water?! So I got up myself, located a glass, and poured my own glass of water. And I got up again to refill also. Service sucks.We ordered another thing and it didn't come until 20 minutes later. AND IT WASN'T WHAT WE ORDERED. HE BROUGHT THE WRONG THING. Not all speak chinese which is fine but a little problematic for a dim sum restaurant. Some just could not even understand what we wanted if said in english AND chinese. I literally saw a waiter standing there with his hands up like, "what am I doing?" CONCLUSION:The service was so bad it makes ME even feel bad. The manager does an absolutely terrible job managing because he doesn't even manage. What they need to do is calm down, regroup, and also retrain these boys. These boys were wandering around like lost puppies. They need to organize. Get assigned tables, learn how to pour glasses, how to time things right. Some waiters were better than others but honestly, it all fell to pieces because of the lack of structure. Not ever coming back.

21.description: Open very late, reasonable prices, and a menu that is more than the typical Chinese restaurant offerings. Service is decent. Not particularly good ambiance.

17.description: First of all I don't like to give out review unless this is really pissed me off，but this experience that totally changed the impression about"Lao" restaurant .Services : no doubt , good services ,but sloooooooow. I still can understand since I came at late night and there is only one server  with couple tables, that is totally fine , I actually appreciate that she is being really nice. Food: so we got there at 10:24pm and the restaurant close at 12am, we tried to order couple spicy food but all the food are soldout, we found out that is because the chef wis off who is able to cook spicy food is off already , then why they are open until 12am?? Ok that is fine, we order couple dishes non spicy where they are able to provide , but it came out with replacement of the veg, even missing lotus and the veg is raw on the four season dish, plus NO TASTE in the cold noodle , this all gets me up set, terrible food. Cleanness: so we already pissed off on the food and we tried to get over it , and it suddenly , a small COCKROACH show up on the table !!! It was speechless and I was so regrad that didn't take a pic of it . Summary: a terrible experiences

10.description: After our first visit here for dinner, I wasn't expecting to ever return.  Everything was doused in oil and the pool of oil settling at the bottom of the plates was troubling.After spotting some pictures of the dim sum on yelp, my girlfriend pushed to give this place another try, and I'm pretty glad we did.  There was no trouble getting seated for six on a saturday.  The xiao long bao was piping hot and was served in little individual metal dishes, possibly to keep them from losing all their soup if they burst?  Almost all of the other food items that we ordered (rice noodle-wrapped shrimp, siu mai, ha gao, turnip cakes) were pretty good, with the exception of the water chestnut cakes.  So...come here for dim sum - it's a pretty good alternative to Cai, Ming Hin, Phoenix, etc. etc.

5.description: I waited to write this review so I can compare with Cai. Some Observations:- it's not a bustling, crazy busy place as other places for dim sum. - the décor is a bit inconsistent. they have swanky seating in some parts and regular round tables the middle of the dining area. it is supposed to be a karaoke placeGood:-Service was attentive and friendly. Generally, the food was rather flavorful: -the black bean spare ribs were very garlicky but ooohhh sooo tasty. Hard to say this being a big fan of Minghin, I actually liked this version more. -Shu mai was soo awesome. -Lotus leaf sticky rice was freshly steamed and tasty. -black pepper beef was very good too. this was on par or better than Minghin. -the steamed soup buns were okay. They actually gave us soup spoons without being asked as it should be. When we ordered this in Cai, the staff was confused. bad or eh:- not too much was bad. The wait to get our food took a bit long when it wasn't even full yet and we were hungry.My favorite is still MingHin for being consistent in flavor and freshness. I would look forward to coming to Lao You Ju since some items are made with more flavor and it's semi fresh. Cai was a sore let down in comparison as it lacked freshness and flavor.

3.description: We wanted to try another Tony Hu restaurant and came for dinner on Friday night, there was one other table occupied at 6:25pm. I asked the hostess twice if it was indeed Hu'S restaurant 2times before we settled down and sipped our tea. We ordered onion pancakes,  Singapore noodles, walnut shrimp and cumin lamb. Disappointed to say the food was subpar compared to Lao Shezwan and I didn't personally like anything on the menu.  Long who served us was excellent with customer service,  all the food was brought to the table within n 10 minutes of ordering. When I complained about the lamb he generously took off the bill.

35.description: This place has dim sum, and I'm not sure how long that has been the case.  Anyway, it is quite good, and I would not hesitate to return.  Seating is comfortable, so that is advantageous over at least one of their competitors that I can think of.  Pricing and dim sum variety is also comparable to the competition.

19.description: Went for dim sum, the dim sums were very bland. The beef stew was spoiled. Looks like they use the same filling for Sui Mai and lotus cake.

28.description: I found there is a fly in milktea. oh my god, I will never go there again!!! So disgusting!!! When I say there is a fly in milktea, the waiter just quickly pick it up and change it! no apologize! I am so disappointed with this restaurant!

45.description: This is one of my 2 fave dim sum haunts since Happy Chef closed years ago. The decor is nice and like Phoenix, there're private party rooms, which is nice. There's usu. no need to wait for a table on weekends, and the food is unique; they have a papa roll desert that is only served here that I quite like, even thought I hate papaya. The service is pretty good... nothing special.

33.description: I've only ever been to this place for dim sum so I am only speaking for the breakfast. I've been here with the family about 5 times. Every time, I have left full and satisfied with the food. They have all the traditional foods: the shrimp and pork dumplings, the shrimp in rice roll, the bbq buns, etc. Food comes out relatively quick and fresh; super yummy!The thing I really love about this place is the service. They are so nice here. There's never a long wait and they always reassure us that it'll be our turn soon. They update you on the wait time and smile often. During the dining experience, they constantly ask for ways to improve our experience such as asking if we want anything else, if the food is good, etc. I really appreciate the way they treat their customers. All in all, I would highly recommend this place. Nice people and awesome food!

43.description: Fast friendly service. Fresh and good selection. Very upscale decor for a family friendly place. Like the idea of selecting what you want right on the menu for dim sum! Tea and water was flowing. Not too expensive would come back again.

2.description: This is a great dim sum place to bring a group of people to. You can get a ton of food for incredible prices. (Gorged myself in a group of 8 people for less than $15- tax and tip included.)Our party included a gentleman who grew up in Taiwan, so he knew what to order and put in the order for us.  I will attempt to describe the dishes, but have no idea what the actual names of the dishes are.Egg custard ball- sweetened egg yolk surrounded by a steamed bun. So tasty to end the meal on.Dumplings- chive, shumai- this place has excellent steamed dumplings. I highly recommend the shrimp and prk dumplings (shumai?)BBQ pork bao- pork bbq surrounded by a rice flower bun.  Very light, and soaks up chili oil beautifully.bbq pork pastry thing- bbq pork surrounded by a sweetened puff pastry.  My favorite dish- this was sweet, but with that spicy, salty pork filling.Apologies for the lack of names, but they have a picture menu that you can order off of.  Definitely worth a trip for a new culinary adventure. Speedy service, and not as busy as the other dim sum places in Chinatown.

18.description: Spacious interior with nice decorations, low noise level, and decent service. Dim Sum is really the specialty here (my guess is this is why they got the Michelin recommendation -- not quite a star but still quite difficult to get). A smaller menu than what you'll find at Cai or Ming Hin, but every item is prepared consistently well although served at a slower pace. One complaint I do have about the menu is the lack of pictures for dim sum and not following the  standard naming convention of dishes in Chinatown (meaning it's more difficult to order some of your favorite items if you can't read Chinese). Even with some flaws, the superb quality of the food at a very reasonable price level easily gives this restaurant 5 stars.Some of my favorite dishes:Chaozhou style dumpling - Excellent combination of peanuts, ground pork, chives, and mushroom. Great combination of textures and flavors in a thicker skin.Mango pancake: Delicious fresh mango in a slightly sweet pancake Shui Mai: Cannot be missed, this is probably the best you'll find in Chicago. Full of flavor, juice, and a very bouncy texture.Fried dough: Very nice crispy exterior with a delicious pork meat filling inside. Sticky rice is chewy and fantastic.Lao's style shrimp dumpling: Nice big pieces of shrimp with a great texture and very clean flavor.Fried dough crepe: This an every other crepe they have has very nice thin bouncy skins filled with quality ingredients. This one stood out since it's uncommon for many restaurants to be able to keep the fried dough super crispy while being steamed by the crepe.Shanghai steamed stuffed bun: Better known as Xaio Long Bao, for me this wasn' the most amazing version I've had (could've used more juice and broth could've had more flavor) but it's a solid version.Mixed meat and peanut congee: Creamy congee and the mixed meat in here is delicious. Light but very enjoyable.Coconut red bean pudding: Superb combination. The coconut really brings out the flavor of the red bean. This really has no bitterness or starchy feel and is almost like eating a very nice ice cream (with a silky almost tofu like texture).BBQ pork bun: Fluffy bun with a very addictive BBQ pork filling that is just sweet enough to satisify your sweet tooth but just salty enough to bring out the flavor of the pork. The sauce in this is fantastic.Even if you aren't into dim sum, the dinner options are quite good here too. A bit lighter and more skillfully prepared dishes like tony three chili fish fillet, crispy rainbow fish flower, three kingdom steamed egg, and pork belly with pea leaves are good items to try.

41.description: I bought 3 discounted coupons from Restaurants.com. I gave my mom one to use with her friends which she used in Sept. They had 6 dishes of Dim Sum which less than $30. She did not know that she had to have $30 or more to redeem the coupon. They took it anyway but did not say anything. Needless to say, my mom did not get any discount.I did not see my mom till this past weekend since we live so far from Chinatown. Yesterday we went there again. Regardless of her bad experience with the coupon, food was good! We had 9 dishes which just made the $30 guideline. The waitress did not know how to redeem the coupon so she passed it to someone else. I think that was the reason why no one said anything to my mom when she used it. There was not enough communications between the workers and the customers in that situation. Oh, by the way, they want cash when you use the coupon but it did not say on it.

52.description: tl;dr: no wait peak hour dim sum, possible uncooked food.I normally come here for dim sum during peak hours because there's usually no wait. And I've eaten here 5+ times without issue. However, this time was a nightmare!I ordered 6 dim sum items, the shrimp dumplings and xiao long bao came first. My first bite into the shrimp dumpling felt mushy, so I took a closer look and realized the shrimp was not cooked! Not even close! It's pigment was still gray! The manager apologized and said he will bring another one out.At this point, my gf was furious because she had already eaten one of the shrimp dumplings. I had to reassure her that ingesting a bit of raw shrimp isn't going to kill her and it would be okay. However, as soon as I realize the pork in the xiao long bao was also uncooked/undercooked, that was the end of it.When I showed the manager again, he said he'll brim another one out and that the bill will be on the house (it better be), but my gf was not willing to eat anything there anymore. The manager's explanation was that the chef who is normally in charge wasn't in yet and the person operating the steamer doesn't know the timings. That's ridiculous! How can they serve food like this?!I wish I took photos of the uncooked shrimp and pork, but just forgot in the heat of the moment.

50.description: I'm confused about the mixed reviews, maybe people went on bad days when inexperienced servers/cooks were working. I had a wonderful experience with having dim sum here. The dishes are well made and taste delicious! Also, everything on the dim sum menu is under $4 (unless you go XL for portion size), and for $60, it fed a table of seven with extras leftover.It is very clean and has a trendy interior much like many newer restaurants in Chinatown. The waiters were very quick to refill water, bring out food, and remove empty plates. When we arrived, I noticed there were a lot of empty reserved tables, and towards the end of the meal, those tables were filled. The waiters were a bit rushed, but they managed to hold down the fort and not keep us waiting.Now for the food review: awesome! Perhaps by being part of a Chinese family, we can communicate well with the waiters and get the best dish recommendations, so I was very happy with the selections. Each dish was served piping hot from the kitchen and I savored every bite. It's also nice that they let you select which flavor of complimentary tea you get (jasmine, chrysanthemum, and a few others).Baked Pork Bun: Awesome, awesome, awesome! I highly recommend people get this. There are two types of pork bun: one is baked (golden brown colored) and the other is steamed (white-colored). While both are yummy, I prefer the baked buns. The baked pork buns came hot and had the perfect taste of freshly baked sweet bread and savory barbecue pork. It was heaven biting into it and getting to taste the succulent pork and fluffy bread.Lao's Beef Bun: I've never tried this before, but a waitress said it was really good, so we ordered it. Every bite was so worth it. It was sweet, juicy beef in steamed bread and reminded me of the steamed pork bun, but even yummier. Preserved Egg and Pork Congee: To diners who are scared of adding the sides provided with the congee. Try a bit! It adds a lot of different texture and flavor to the congee, which by itself is good to eat but since congee is just rice porridge, it's meant to be bland and flavored by the eater's choice of added ingredients. It was piping hot and smelled heavenly (just like how the cute Chinese grannies make it!) and while had a hint of saltiness along with sweetness.Cantonese Sponge Cake: Not the prettiest looking dish, but it tastes very good! This is a nice dessert for adults because unlike mango pudding, it has a light hint of sweetness that isn't overpowering and a fluffy texture that gives a melt in your mouth feeling as you eat it. It's also a generous serving of cake that can be shared among diners.Mango Pudding: I always order mango pudding as an end to my dim sum meal, so I had an idea of what to expect: a lump of generic mango gelatin with a covering of evaporated milk. To my surprise, it came out in four cute shapes and a generous cover of evaporated milk. To top it off, I bit into it and found they had put actual pieces of mango in the pudding! I appreciate the attention to detail put into what is usually an underrated dessert. Oddly, it also felt like I was eating a tasty, solid mango lassi.I hope I can come back soon for dim sum! Hopefully, they get more consistent staff and I can get a good repeat experience.Additional notes; they take reservations and are open until 2 am.

4.description: The fact that this is a Tony Hu restaurant doesn't mean anything other than his name and photo pops up.  Your food will vary based on the cook that shift.  Dinner is hit-or-miss (2.5 stars), but dim sum is great (3.5 stars).Dim sum: The menu is small, but has all your favorites, and what they have, they do well.  The rice crepes were the most impressive since the key is getting them translucent thin, and Lao You Ju's got it right.  Both the beef and shrimp were delicious!  The shrimp and pork dumplings were generously sized and juicy.  Chicken feet was yummy and had substantial skin to chew on.  They have xiao long bao!!!Skip the congee and bean curd rolls unless you're going for plain food as they really doesn't have much flavor.  I would also pass on the short ribs, which are very fatty with no meat. For dessert, the coconut red bean jello was nice.Dinner: The eggplant, string beans, and fish fillet had one thing in common - glistening in grease.  Chili oil is expected in Szechuan cuisine, but I thought the veggies would be somewhat healthy.  My finicky stomach is prone to indigestion, and I was folded over in pain halfway into the meal. Dinner may be a gamble, but I like to throw it in the mix dim sum!  No wait and $2 validated lot parking is a plus.

6.description: My new favorite place to go for soup dumplings (xiao long bao)!!! I've been on the search, and I can finally say that this place will fulfill any of my soup dumpling cravings LOL.I'll have to try this place for dim sum, but we came for dinner and ended up ordering random entrees and a couple "dim sum" dishes that were available to order. The prices are reasonable, and each dish is legit. So for those of you who, like me, were looking for a good soup dumpling place, then this is it!!!~I always order the green beans, you really can't go wrong with this dish LOL. Sorry for being so boring and always ordering the same thing at every Chinese restaurant. But come on. It's green beans. SO delicious and crunchy and flavorful! hahahaha.

22.description: I came back here for another try. One of my friends really like this place and it's been awhile since I've been back so thinking things may have changed. And yes it did. We ordered a lot of dim sum and they were all yummy. It's very standard Chinatown dim sum, but there were few plates that differ than other Chinatown restaurants.

15.description: I shall start this review by saying that if you go to Chinatown without someone from China, chances are very strong you'll get food that has the flavouring of China Buffet. I went with a former colleague who is from mainland China and the food that we got was very reminiscent of the Chinese cooking my first room mate's parents cooked when they visited. Authentic!We opted for the dim sum menu options, which meant we had food galore. I've posted photos, so I'll let the captions speak for the pictures that I captured. But the flavours I couldn't capture in digital prints. Everything was spicy or had a kick without salt. And truth be told, I didn't get the usual MSG bite either.The service was outstanding, although the servers spoke to my former colleague in Chinese. What little bit I did understand was not a slight to me and they were very much aware of my presence. Lao You Ju is one of the restaurants in Chinatown that brings in more Americans than the restaurants that seem "off the main street." Would I return? Yes, but with a friend who is Chinese so that I'm not served food that tastes like it has been delivered from China Buffet.

57.description: This place is at the top of my list. I really like the salt and pepper pork chops, the Chinese broccoli, and the BBQ steam buns. There is another place in Chinatown by the same owner ( Tony Yu) and it's also wonderful!!!

20.description: First of all I don't like to give out review unless this is really pissed me off，but this experience that totally changed the impression about"Lao" restaurant .Services : no doubt , good services ,but sloooooooow. I still can understand since I came at late night and there is only one server  with couple tables, that is totally fine , I actually appreciate that she is being really nice. Food: so we got there at 10:24pm and the restaurant close at 12am, we tried to order couple spicy food but all the food are soldout, we found out that is because the chef wis off who is able to cook spicy food is off already , then why they are open until 12am?? Ok that is fine, we order couple dishes non spicy where they are able to provide , but it came out with replacement of the veg, even missing lotus and the veg is raw on the four season dish, plus NO TASTE in the cold noodle , this all gets me up set, terrible food. Cleanness: so we already pissed off on the food and we tried to get over it , and it suddenly , a small COCKROACH show up on the table !!! It was speechless and I was so regrad that didn't take a pic of it . Summary: a terrible experiences

36.description: Service was slow, waited over an hour for six dim sum items. We were seated at the bar and the tables after us were given food before us. If we had known that choosing the bar seats would relegate us to the lack of food and service, we would have stayed in queue for a table. We asked at least three times why the tables which seated after us were getting food and we were told that they would rush our food. After over an hr, we closed out check and told them to cancel the rest of our food, over 8 more dishes.

14.description: So delicious, the schumai (sp) is amazing and the restaurant is very clean and pretty to look at.  They're also really good with separate checks if its even so that's a plus :)

1.description: Plastic Chinese swords, mini ninja statues, Bruce Lee flags, plastic Gundam action figures, and Hello Kitty errthang - this store screams all things stereotypically Asian. Not to mention, there's a pungent plastic smell that fills the room emitted by Dalin's uncountable number of colorful toys and trinkets. And by colorful, it's as if a rainbow grenade exploded inside. It reminds me of this: bit.ly/1hilqyW.Three folks staff Dalin, and one of them is a tiny woman. She'll at first kindly welcome you, then proceed to sneakily follow you to ensure that you aren't snapping photos, stealing, or breaking anything. (And you'll be reminded of these things by the small signs taped around the store.) Everything is ridiculously cheap, but I'm sure for good reason.Not really into this kind of stuff, but if you're into all things stereotypically Asian, this might be the store of your dreams...

2.description: I went here to buy some red envelopes (lucky money) for the Chinese New Year. This is the first gift store we ran into, so we just went there. I've been in here before and its collection of stuffed Hello Kitty's is awesome. Also, they have the best little trinkets. The kind you would use to decorate your desk or a window sill. They didn't have a lot of variety, but I wasn't looking for anything special. Surprisingly, the store didn't have a lot of things related to the Chinese New Year. However, the new year only comes once year, so I understand.

0.description: Really?  No one has reviewed this place?  Has no one been to this beacon of wonderful shopping in Chinatown?!  If not, you are MISSING. OUT.I've been obsessed with Asia since... going to Asia, but somehow have never made it to China town in the xx years I have lived in Chicago.  What's great about this shop is that, unlike most of the other tchotchke shops lining the road, this one is less on the knick-knacks and more on the fun furniture and artwork.  Prices were slightly cheaper here for the same quality and the associate was super friendly (instead of pushy or non-communicative, as I find in most of these types of shops I visit, in America and in Asia).  I was pressed for time, but wanted to buy so many things.  Cool artwork, fun statues, a sweet looking bar, and some colorful wine covers that looked like little samurai jackets.  BALLER!  In the end, I DID walk out with two of these really cool colorful wooden pieces that look like dual-sided tuning forks that you put on top of a wine bottle and you can hang wine glasses from them (pictures to come later).  For $1.99 a piece, it was a deal I could not pass up!Is this store alone worth a trip to Chinatown for?  No.  However, Chinatown itself is a place worth going out of your way for, so while you are there, be sure to stop in and pick yourself up some homegoods fun!

1.description: This place is a joke! I called and they said they have no lobster for $8.95 per pound. False advertising! And explain to me how their price of shrimp per pound is double the cost of their so-called lobster.

2.description: Live lobster $8.95/lb? You've got to be kidding me!   While in Chinatown today we stopped in here and walked out with two lobsters...for $28.  Crazy!!  (For the record of why this is obscenely inexpensive, lobsters at Dirk's are $20/lb. currently)  ...They also had live dungeness crab for $6ish a pound, and a number of other live and dead fish.The lobster was very good if you must know...  They also had various produce and specialty food items..Cash only... ( Chicago Food Market not Chgo )

0.description: Every Valentine's Day I make live lobster and cook for my wife. We had been going to a place in Little Vietnam for the last 3 years, but since we moved to Pilsen decided to try out a place in China town. This place had only 2 reviews, but was so close we didn't lose anything by driving the 10 minutes.Pros:Extremely healthy, active lobsters.Large selection of lobsters (over 20 when we went)Unbeatable pricesThe less than 2lb ones are $9.99 a lb and the 2+ lbers were $10.99 a lb.The owner let us pick our lobsters and understood this was a fun experience for us. We didn't feel rushed at all.Cons:Parking is hard to come by and only pay to park on WentworthCash only

3.description: My family comes here for eastern medicine. It is our preferred spot as Dr. Young, I presume is his name, that treats the sick and ailing. This is where I take my family to see the doctor when they come into town, and where I buy any type of non-western medicine. Dr. Young performs acupuncture and does cupping as well. His office is basically in the open and I sit and listen to the little Chinese that I can understand. There is a little makeshift room where acupuncture and cupping is done. He speaks Cantonese with my parents, but I do hear other people coming in and speaking Mandarin as well. He is very patient, and seems pretty knowledgeable as he asks them questions about their health and pain. My dad said he felt much better after the acupuncture was done to his leg since he wasn't the same after bowling. My sister has come here for bloating stomach issues, and my mom has come for an ailment as well. The medicine from here has also traveled to family friends in Minnesota who seem to agree that it has made them feel better as well. I do not get sick often (knock on wood) so I haven't been able to use the doctor's practice for my own advantage. I would certainly give him a shot since he seems to have cured my family and friends. I have been able to call and get refill orders easily enough. There are plenty of teas and pills for all kinds of things here even if you don't like the herbal medicine the doctor prescribes.

1.description: My family, friends and I have been coming to Dr. Young for many years. He has treated many ailments with accupuncture and cupping and optional natural herbal teas and natural herbal medicines. I've come to him for back pain, migraines, and even my PCOS (Poly Cystic Ovarian Syndrome) and hormone issues. I HiGHLY recommend him and drive an hour to see him at least 2-3 times a year if needed. You won't be disappointed and get better results than other accupuncturists/doctors.

2.description: I was referred by one of my clients. His mother and him had gotten acupuncture at this place. You would never find this place through advertising of any sort. Just word of mouth. True Eastern medicine. The guy is excellent. I found this out myself. Migraine head aches went away from a single visit. From getting them weekly to going away 95% for 4 months. I returned today and I highly recommend him. You have to go early. He gets booked. I suggest calling to find out how busy it is & then show.

5.description: I had both cupping and acupuncture for a shoulder injury. I left feeling better and the price -unlike western medicine- was affordable.

0.description: I've been going with Kent for a few years now.  He has helped my entire family with all sort of issues such as high blood pressure, running injuries, sprained ligaments, headaches, to some more serious issues.  I fully trust in his methods and I have not seen the results with any other acupuncturist as I have with him.  Keep your little card he gives you and bring it with to your next session.  It's a hit or miss with the wait time but it's worth it.  I've had the acupuncture, cupping and have also taken the supplements he has suggested.

4.description: I have had acupuncture by Kent multiple times and it's always fantastic and spot-on for what is needed to make me feel better. He is also the best around for herbal supplements and teas.

28.description: omg. TOTAL HOLE IN THE WALL. like totally... (wow! i sound like a valley girl)given that, chinese people are super rude in the restaurant industry, this place is like no other. first of all, i would love to give this place at least, AT LEAST, a 2.5 but i just can't BECAUSE the prices are outrageous!their lunch specials are extremely cheap! no more than $4. all of the dishes! i swear! and i swear, they have over 100 dishes. i ordered kung pao beef style noodle and it was sooo salty, total soy saucey... ew.i waited approximately 20mins and asked if my order was ready any time soon, and both times, this lady, snapped at me, and said, "wait, wait for your order. you sit over there. i tell you when ready."sheesh!HAPPY cafe, my ass. should be more or less, CRANKY cafe.

1.description: When I returned, I was disappointed that the beef fun roll was only served during breakfast hours.  However, I got two servings of my shiitake mushroom and chicken congee.

9.description: I had a simple dinner roll (plain bun) and some tea. I enjoyed both and was pretty enticed by the amazing prices on their menu. I'd like to return to try some real food but based on the service and my small order I'm already a fan =)

29.description: This used to be my default for Chinese breakfast. Why? Where else can you get a meal for 2-3 bucks nowadays? My ex used to say that Chinese restaurants in Chinatown are dumb in that they cut their own profit by lowering prices to compete with other similar places. I personally prefer it that way. I like their Hong Kong style breakfast, which can include macaroni with Spam, Congee, chicken wings, egg with rice....really cheap stuff, but helps if youre on a budget. I can imagine place smells better after the smoke ban has been in place. I have fond memories of coming here with my ex....ahhh...the romance of a $5 breakfast for 2...

23.description: Insanely cheap, authentic lunch specials with your choice of rice, rubbery rice noodles, or thin pan fried noodles.  Yum!One of these is enough to fill up two normal people.  Can't beat that.

5.description: If you like Lawrence Fish Market, you'll love HC. Like LFM, you don't go there for the decor or the aviance, you go there because you get the bang for the buck. I went there the other day for rice noodle and beef, and I left full. There are a full menu full of dishes or rice boxes to order around $5.00 -$5.50 and surprising with flavor. This place has a steady stream of frugal customers.This place also has dim sum with a bakery inside,one stop shop.

31.description: My recommendation is to come with someone who can read chinese and their better items aren't found on the English menu.  All different types of food here - I prefer their desserts though.

25.description: It's a weekend night and my family does not feel like cooking, who do we call up for take out? Happy Cafe! This is our go to place for cheap, tasty Chinese food. Their foods are delicious and there is a wide variety to choose from. The size of the portions vary. One time we were surprised at how much food they gave us. We even had enough leftovers for dinner tomorrow. The next time we ordered (expecting the same big portion orders) we opened the take out box and saw that it was practically half of what we received the last time. Perhaps it is the different cooks making the orders, but if Happy Cafe would be more reliable on its order portions (hopefully on the larger side) that would be better. Happy Cafe also has seating if you want to dine in. They recently got new chairs, so dining in is more comfortable. Although they do try to make the dining experience as pleasant as possible, they can only do so much. Happy Cafe is a small casual restaurant. The tables and flooring looks like it can use some revamping. If you are dining in try out their sizzling hot plate dishes. For example they have short ribs with onions and sweet sauce cooked on a sizzling hot plate. The aroma and crackling noise of this dish is sure to attract the attention of other customers sitting nearby.Interesting Note - Make sure to try out their red bean drink. They have one of the cheapest red bean drinks and it's also very tasty.

12.description: Might have been the traveling blues or maybe the fried rice wasn't that great, but whatever it was, I found myself crying at the Happy Cafe. This was definitely no Happy Meal (har har). Juan got soy sauce in his pork fried rice and he was happy. Perhaps that was the secret? Without soy sauce, the pork fried rice tasted pretty bland. Fresh, but lacking flavor. So sad.. so sad.... ::sniff::

21.description: Cheap is good right?  I mean come on its $5 for a rice box!  It's chinese food IN chinatown!  Score right?!WRONG!  Not when the quality and quantity fails.  I was so disappointed with this place.  I've gone three times and have yet to be satisfied by the food or the quantity.  The final straw with my parents were when we got 4 rice boxes and each one lacked taste (not even MSG can save this one), and there was either very little meat or else the meat was just all fat.  Now I got no problem with fat but if it ain't coupled with meat then there is something drastically wrong, even bacon has meat!  Worse of all, I got sick from the food.  I've never felt so sick after eating so little.I'm sorry but please avoid this place and do yourself a favor and eat at gourmet foods which is right around the corner of this place.  You can check my review for the good stuff!

16.description: eh.. this place is not what it used to be.. i used to go there few times a week back when i was a kid and it was greattt ... then i went back there for the first time after many years and the quality just went down hill big time... i gave it two stars because the food is cheap and the service is decent.. but there is alot of other Chinese restaurant. around the area with cheap prices and better quality food..

17.description: Cheap is good right?  I mean come on its $5 for a rice box!  It's chinese food IN chinatown!  Score right?!WRONG!  Not when the quality and quantity fails.  I was so disappointed with this place.  I've gone three times and have yet to be satisfied by the food or the quantity.  The final straw with my parents were when we got 4 rice boxes and each one lacked taste (not even MSG can save this one), and there was either very little meat or else the meat was just all fat.  Now I got no problem with fat but if it ain't coupled with meat then there is something drastically wrong, even bacon has meat!  Worse of all, I got sick from the food.  I've never felt so sick after eating so little.I'm sorry but please avoid this place and do yourself a favor and eat at gourmet foods which is right around the corner of this place.  You can check my review for the good stuff!

10.description: I love this place! It is a small cafe that I come to eat ever since it opened (when I was in high school). Food is very cheap compared to most restaurants in Chinatown and they are delicious! It is so affordable that I'm so sure elementary school kids can come here and order food to get full! I no longer live in the city but anytime when I do come to the city to visit I definitely try to eat at Happy Cafe to relive the memories and eat my old time favorites. You get the bang for your buck here!

11.description: Honestly, this place can do well if service was better. If you're not a regular it'll be difficult to get food here. I mean, their walls are filled with a few pictures and menu while they try to incorporate English on there now-a-days. I used to eat here a lot when I was a kid (right when they open) and then it ceased due to the service. Since I was in the area for work and was making my way through town, I decided to drop a phone call in twenty minutes ahead of time. I went in to pick up the food (just a macaroni and chicken wings meal). They told me to wait (probably counting money to a delivery guy. She went back into the kitchen and I had to wait some more. Then she told me the food isn't ready yet. I was in a hurry and I made that point clear to them so I just said cancel the order and departed. One thing learned is never have ANY hopes walking in here for their service. I didn't bother buying any "quick" foods since I wanted something cooked and hot. =[

26.description: This place sucks! I have to wait more than 30 mins for my stupid order and I just ordered some fried rice! and i started complaining and they totally forgot about my order and just started cooking it after ii was done complaining. and when i received, there was a fly in it! totally disgusting! UGHHHHHHHHHHH.

27.description: FOOD:     Your average Chinatown Chinese food.  A bit too greasy, and somewhat over-MSGed, but there is a wide variety and several menus to choose from.  They have a school menu (equivalent to kids' sizes), a combo menu (entree over rice or noodles), and a full dinner entree menu.  AMAZING bang for your buck.  For $5 (off of the entrees over rice menu), you get a HUGE portion.SERVICE:    It's a small restaurant, so you can pretty much motion and get service instantaneously when it's not very buy.  The staff speak minimal English, so it's better to just point than to try to say your dishes aloud.AMBIANCE:     A bit of a run-down, dilapidated cafe feel.  There is a TV if you're eating alone.  Mostly filled with junior high/high school kids.TRY:     Five-wing chicken dinner; crispy pork over chow fun (wide rice noodles)BOTTOM LINE:     Not a particularly classy place, but good bang for your buck.

0.description: I WOULD eat here again, but......................This is a small, nine small tables restaurant. I came here by myself, and I am not Asian, to eat in. The food was good and the price was right, but the service, maybe it could be a little better.I walk up to the counter and grab one of those throw-a-way menus. As I'm looking at it, I'm asked what I want. I say I need some more time, and the woman stands there staring at me. So I say Mongolian Beef just to get out of a somewhat awkward situation. I sit down at the table nearest the counter. Eventually, she brings my food out.The two servers passed by me over and over and over and over to check on the Asian family at the table near me, never stopping at my table once. I still left a five dollar tip on a nine dollar bill, and would eat here again.

20.description: $1.50 for a bowl of congee and bun of your choice before 11am or hot and fresh soy milk-nuff said!

19.description: First time i went there, i have no clue what to order until this kid told me to order a kid meal A. That only cost me 2:75 and i got like 3 item with that cost.

33.description: This place is great for take out too. All kinds of fried rice, bakery items, cold drinks. I dont recommend eating in because you will smell like a greasy ashtray.

2.description: I love Happy Cafe! Why? because of fast service and they are ready to service you at 8:00 a.m. . We like their macaroni noodle soups with ham. I love their rixe box entrees. Super adorable to get breakfast, lunch and dinner.

32.description: not a date place, but go here if you want some good, cheap chinese food, canto-style.  portions are big enough, and they've got a pretty good menu selection.  if you're feeling adventurous, try their 'shwang pay nigh' dessert'; it's not on their english menu but it's one of my favorites and they're the only place that makes it.

18.description: A very economic way to full fill your lunch or even dinner. Chicken Wings are a plus and it was also posted by the Chicago Tribune recently. Plenty choices from their menu for the "lunch boxes". The only draw back is the kitchen and their front counter don't seem to look too nice and clean. I personally have no problem eating there and will go again for sure.

13.description: This is the place to go in the afternoon for a quick lunch & dessert. I used to LOVE their peas with beef, until it changed & became salty. I also noticed that their rice boxes tend to have mostly rice, and less what you ordered (i.e. meat or vegetables). I know you are trying to cut cost, but 1 pound of rice in a rice box? Seriously?Their take outs comes with soup and they make a good tofu flower dessert (imagine super soft tofu floating in sugar water, yes i know it doesn't sound yummy, but I grew up with it), and homemade soil milk too. Their baked goods are ok, but very reasonably priced.

4.description: I've been eating here since I was a kid and it's still delicious. Since I've moved out of chinatown, their food is what I missed most. Whenever I was sick, my mom would go here to get me their pork with preserved egg congee, and on a regular I would eat their pork and pickled radish vermicelli noodles.When my brother and I were younger their "kids meals" were what we always got. Either the one with the soda, fries, and a chicken wing, or the one with the ham macaroni, fries, and a chicken wing. We became regulars there and my mother had a tab to pay for whenever we went. Yeah, it's always packed with elementary school kids, but what do you expect? It's cheap, and right down the street from Haines. Kids not only get their fast food, but they can also hang out and then go back to the school or go to the library next door to do homework.

24.description: Might have been the traveling blues or maybe the fried rice wasn't that great, but whatever it was, I found myself crying at the Happy Cafe. This was definitely no Happy Meal (har har). Juan got soy sauce in his pork fried rice and he was happy. Perhaps that was the secret? Without soy sauce, the pork fried rice tasted pretty bland. Fresh, but lacking flavor. So sad.. so sad.... ::sniff::

6.description: I came here with my friend for lunch and it's definitely a hole-in-the-wall kinda restaurant, but the prices are super affordable and portions are large compared to other restaurants in Chinatown. I went with the wonton noodle soup with beef brisket, which was delicious. I'm a big eater, but the portions were so large that I had to take my leftovers home. This is a great place to come when you're low on the dough and feeling like a starving animal.Parking can be scarce in this part of Chinatown, but there is street parking. Happy Cafe is super close to grocery stores, pharmacies and banks, so you can run a buncha errands while getting a cheap bite to eat!

22.description: So this is seriously one of the hole in the wall chinese places in chinatown.  Why the 4 stars? because the food is good and STILL cheap.  they have excellent iced hong kong style milk tea - what all the other places should taste like. i've heard they have good lemon ice tea here too but i ALWAYS just get my HK milk tea.  they have good noodles  and rice dishes here. my fav is the beef brisket funn noodles (its more of a brunch item but they will make it anytime).  the basic macaroni with ham in chicken broth is also really good (even though it sounds really plain).   you can seriously get an entree + drink for 5 bucks here.

15.description: Insanely cheap, authentic lunch specials with your choice of rice, rubbery rice noodles, or thin pan fried noodles.  Yum!One of these is enough to fill up two normal people.  Can't beat that.

7.description: I remember coming here years ago for their macaroni. My mom said to come here since it was cheap and you get a lot of food. Yes, the tables do seem a bit dirty. They seem to have a lot of deal options and I see why so many school kids come here after school for a cheap meal.Fish Fillet Noodle - My mom got this and I didn't try it. My sister said it was ok, but the noodles were a bit too chewy. She said like eating a rubberband...lol!BBQ Pork Chow Funn - This didn't look that good, but it was actually quite good. The noodles had this nice crispiness to it.Kids Meal A - This came with the macaroni and ham, fries and one chicken wing. Fries were ok, my sister said the chicken wing was crispy, but not much flavor. I tried a spoon of the macaroni and ham and remember it being better.Beef and Tomato Egg Rice - I ordered the beef and rice and it was weird when she asked did I want it sweet or salty....huh? I said sweet and she suggest to add an egg and that was a good choice. It was good, but tasted a bit too much like ginger to me.My sister and I got the iced milk tea and it was ok. Tea was pretty flavorful, but the drinks here are pre-made.Overall, not a bad place to come for cheap eats.

8.description: Yes it's a true hole-in-the-wall type restaurant with only 1 of the over-40 ladies who can speak some English, but the mostly-Northern Chinese Cuisine is so delicious, and you can feed 8 people for under $50!! We have not ever been disappointed in anything we've tried in the 10 years we've been going to Happy!

30.description: Two words: Excellent chicken wings! (oh wait, that's three, oops....) Funny story about Happy Cafe: a few years back, I was seated in here, with my back to the door, eating and watching television. I heard a two-way radio squawk behind me, and upon turning around, noticed 5 police officers sitting at the next table, quietly eating their dinner and watching 'NYPD Blue'. I don't know what the point or moral of that story was, just figured I had to tell it...

3.description: This place is my go to for Chinese food on the cheap but good on taste. It's your typical, small Chinatown restaurant that's better for to go orders but it's not that bad to sit down and eat. I just wouldn't sit here and eat here with my in laws.Try the salty spicy fish and any of their noodle soup dishes. So many noodles!!!

14.description: This is one of my go to places becasue I'm a dirt poor grad student.  I've been coming here for the past 5 years primarily because the price of the food is so inexpensive.  It is unreasonable to expect gourmet.  However given the price, it is certainly worth it.  Probably the best bang for you buck anywhere in chinatown.  Usually I order food for carry out, but it's perfectly fine to dine in too.  It would be place just to chat with friends over food whom are not picky eaters.    Going there gives me nostalgic feelings of what HK was like way way back.  Their prices have gone up (like everywhere else), but still remains one the most inexpensive restaurants in Chinatown.Suggestion bring cash.  I dont' remember if they take credit cards.  They probably don't just like almost everywhere else in Chinatown.

12.description: Made a reservation weeks in advance for a big group and on arrival was told that they didn't have room for us.... Never coming back

7.description: Came here with a group of ~18 people on a Saturday night and booked a medium sized room. Even though we reserved a room in advance, we still had to wait in the lobby where the music was WAY too loud. If you spend a minimum of $350 on drinks and food, the room fee is waived. The room itself was decent, however can anyone explain why it smelled like B.O? The bathrooms were also super disgusting--there was vomit in the sink.

3.description: SO. COOL! I really enjoy this place. On a Wednesday evening me and my friends had the entire club to ourselves (except for one group that were at the very back in their own private room). I can only imagine what this place is like on the weekend when it is packed. I love these sofas! Super luxe and comfy! They have all of the major hits from like 2010 and back. It is SO hard to navigate the karaoke machine though because it is all in Chinese. But the owner/bartender was very kind to show me how to work it. We spent a good hour and a half at K Pop pretending to be superstars. I like that you can choose instrumental tracks or just sing along with the original stars! The music videos play while the song goes! I also really enjoy how they have obviously hits from China Korea and Japan not just the USA. Id return! OH! After carding us, the bartender gave me and my four friends one round of shots for free!

1.description: Whenever my friends and I go out in Chinatown for karaoke, we don't settle for any of the private rooms. We make work and end up taking over the open lounge outside. Passerbyers and children alike, you've been warned.Pop KTV is a quintessential Chinese-Hong Kong karaoke lounge (I mean, just look at the name. KTV!) that gets the job done. The bar area in front was empty on a Saturday night, so we stretched out, owned the dance floor, and started plugging in our own songs to the bar karaoke machine.The song selection was very minimal, and all the functions were (naturally) written in Simplified Chinese. If you can't read it, it never hurts to ask the service how to use the machine. (Un)fortunately, all of the songs we added to the queue weren't entirely instrumental versions. The two mic stands in the front were also very short, so it'd be difficult to move about and dance if you're singing. But you can still drop it low.Overall, song selection is not up to date, but has most hits you'd find from the past three decades.Drinks here were basic for any karaoke bar. I definitely suggest pre-gaming a but before coming, and if you're okay with the open lounge in front, take advantage! You'll end up singing and dancing without the need to pay more for a private space.

2.description: As a group of three, we arrived there at 2pm after having lunch in Chinatown. It was quite confusing as there was nobody in the karaoke lounge, and I had to call their service line to make sure that the place was open. However, the place is pretty decent in general - mostly up-to-date (6 months old) songs, good mic, and the weekday discount was a plus.

9.description: I came here with ~20 people for my birthday, and I had a blast. It was exactly what I wanted - I've been to KTVs in China when I travel for work, and this place is very similar to the ones in China.  I reserved the room about a week in advance (and even then the rooms were starting to fill up). There are different sized rooms (small, medium, large, VIP) and there are no room rates, just a minimum amount you have to spend. We had a large room for 20 people, and it was $400 from 11 PM - 3 AM (this is the time slot they have available. Earlier one is from ~6:30 to 10PM).For the music system, there is a touch screen computer in the corner and luckily one of our friends is Chinese and could help us, because the buttons are in Chinese. But we learned the right buttons to hit and search artists/songs and then it was no problem.The English music selection is great for pop hits. There were some classics that my friends were looking for and they weren't available.Beer is ~$5 and cocktails are ~$10. Beware of the mixed drinks, it seemed like they were over the board - either barely any alcohol or a lot of alcohol.Another thing is our room was really hot - we had to have the door cracked for a bit to get some fresh air. Overall, fantastic place if you have a great group of friends to drink and sing with.

10.description: There are a handful of karaoke bars in Chinatown - PopKtv is my new favorite. It's brand new, clean, and definitely a fun place to be on a Saturday night. The karaoke machines are top of the line, with a huge selection of English as well as international songs. We got down to some  Eminem, Mariah Carey, and grooved to Brit Brit... There's something for everyone!If you're looking to go on a weekend, you may want to make a reservation as the private rooms fill up quickly.

13.description: I give this place NO STAR!! It seem to me that this karaoke bar only seem to know how to cater to Chinese people. If you're not Chinese I highly suggest you not to go here. The bartenders are extremely rude, and if it was up to me I wouldn't of left and them one dollar tip, but of course gratuity was ready included in our bill. I don't recommend this place for anybody!!!

16.description: Pretty fun place, friendly staff. Downgrade a star for lack of music selection. They had a lot of older and more obscure songs, nothing recent.

17.description: I went to PopKTV on Lunar New Year Weekend with my friends. We reserved 1 month in advance for a medium room. When we got there, we had to wait half hour for  our room to be ready. The manager was rude about it when we mentioned that we have been waiting for half an hour. They still charged us the full price of 4 hours. During the night, I went to the bathroom and it was disgusting, someone had puked all over the bathroom and no one cleaned. I almost puked just from being in the room. Overall, I do not think I will go there again.

15.description: WOW! So much fun.  Get the private karaoke room and prepare to have some fun.  They have an extensive list of songs to chose from, and nothing beats flashing lights and tone deaf singing.  The bar selection is limited, so don't go for the drinks.  Can't wait to get a crew to head back.

0.description: I would love this place 4 or 5 stars based on venue and ambiance. They have a communal room where you can sing and dance. They have a full bar. They also have private karaoke rooms which rent by the hour.The main complaint is the sound quality in the communal area. Often times the background music is very low volume and they cannot remove the vocals to do true karaoke singing. Besides that, it's a fun place to go after dinner with friends for karaoke and drinks. The staff are very nice and they speak English. The selection of English songs is sufficient enough for a Chinese karaoke bar.I'd still go back to have a good time with friends after a dinner in Chinatown.

5.description: Would have had a nice time if it wasn't for all the smoke throughout the venue. This venue allows smoking in the private karaoke rooms, but you can still smell it in the halls and throughout the private rooms, even if yours is smoke free. I had to leave the party I was invited to after 45 minutes because I couldn't take the smell. I'm also pregnant, so it didn't feel like a safe environment to be breathing the air. This is a big deal because Chicago is supposed to be smoke free. Not something I should have to worry about when going out. I mentioned something to the bouncers, and they didn't seem overly concerned with my concerns.

11.description: Not really catered for English speaking people.  Very limited American songs.  Very nice place for Chinese speaking people.   Ambiance is very nice.   Pretty empty on a Saturday night.

8.description: My friends and I organized a last minute karaoke meet up last night (Friday) for 9pm. We tried to book a room six hours in advance but all of the rooms were already reserved. Here's a quick breakdown of their rooms and capacity:  Small room - 12 peopleMedium room - 20 people Large room - 25 peopleVIP room - 35 peopleWe were a party of 11 and we had to sing in the lobby from from 9:30pm till midnight until a medium-size room became available. There is a minimum charge of $15 per person in the lobby. Either order up to $15 worth of drinks per person or just pay the $15, which is a very standard price charge for Chinatown. The lobby was very spacious with black leather couches and flashing neon, disco lights. People were courteous in taking turns to sing and servers were very helpful.A room finally opened up at 12am and we immediately switched over. It is $48 per hour but the rate increases after 2am. There is no minimum charge other than the room rate. You are not obligated to order any food and drinks. We tried the lamb skewers, beef skewers, grilled squid, lychee juice, mango juice, and a variety of beer. The lamb and beef skewers tasted good, but the texture was very ground-meat-like and the cumin smell was a bit unusual. I was glad we only ordered a few to try. The lychee juice and mango juice can be ordered in pitchers at $12 each. Each pitcher was 50% ice but they were good with the lychee juice being sweeter. With the two-hour stay, drinks, and food, we each paid approximately $25. The room is also very spacious and can easily fit 20 people with plenty more space to go around. Furthermore, they only have two unisex bathrooms towards the back. They are also very spacious but there is always a line! They weren't too busy last night but imagine if the place was packed. You would never make it through the line before your bladder explodes! The bathrooms are obviously very new but not a bit clean. Towels were rolled out of their dispensers and left laying on the floor in a wet puddle and the garbage cans were spilling over. I hope the Richland Center has more bathrooms elsewhere in the building...    In conclusion, our group had a pleasant time. We stayed from 9:30pm to 2am and more people were arriving as we were leaving.
