What gets me is the time they start serving Dimsum food. Why 9pm? Why not all the time? All in all, we'd be back here.

34.description: Our go to place for oxtail and singapore noodles.

16.description: I've been living in the Chicago area for 4+ years and I tried dim sum at Phoenix when I first arrived. I was so unsatisfied that I lost all interest in trying dim sum .. for THREE YEARS.  And man, I love dim sum. I decided to give dim sum here a second try and went to Ming Hin.  It was pretty good!  They had most of the things I liked. However the service was TERRIBLE.  It would be 5-10 minutes between receiving dishes so instead of having lots of different entrees on the table... it was like some pseudo 10 course meal at a nice restaurant where they serve you one item at a time.. except for dim sum!!  Also, they didn't have any sauces or condiments on the table and you really have to be aggressive in asking for them to be brought to your table.  Overall.. it was okay and I would come back if friends were craving dim sum.  I still don't think it matches up to my expectations to the point where I'd ever crave it and try to rally people up to go with me.

13.description: I'm giving Min Hin 4 stars despite the less than satisfactory service.  However, I'm sucking up part of the blame because I went with a party of 6 on the busiest night of the year, Xmas Day.  My group of assorted non-Christians made up of Muslims, Jews, (and folks with assorted other afflictions like shellfish allergy & celiac disease ) hook up frequently for dinner on  Xmas Eve or Xmas Day.  Only restaurants open are Chinese, OK?  Jewish people have been doing it for years.  It's traditional to go to a movie, and do Chinese.  Our table was ready on time, and the waiter did forewarn  us that the kitchen was really busy .  Suffice it to say, the kitchen was totally"in the weeds".  Dishes for our table came out one by one over a period of about fifty minutes.  It was painful, because with all the various dietary allergies and restrictions, we were unable to share!  (Our problem, not Ming Hin's)   I managed to taste each of the dishes, and they were really delicious.   Plates of dim sum being carried by the servers looked awesome.  I'll be back on a "normal" night of the year

11.description: Late. Night. Dim. Sum. - Whaaat! I wish everyone would do this. Everyone should do this. I would definitely help these businesses stay in business. Flew into Chicago super late on a very cold and very blustery night. Once we got situated in our place at 1AM, I was about to take a hot shower and call it a night. But wait... there's dim sum open? Let's Go! We walk through the doors and the place is so nice and warm, I forget how cold it is outside. We thaw out with hot tea and drool over the menu. I notice they don't have a very big dim sum menu but it will do.We started with the crispy pork belly. O.M.G. - crispy is no lie. The skin was super crunchy and the meat awesomely fatty and to make it even worse for your health, they give you sugar to dip it in. Mmmmm. Must try this. We then ordered the shrimp har gow dumpling, sticky rice in lotus leaf, egg bun, spare ribs, chicken & dried scallop bun and the tofu skin filled with meat and veggies. Everything was great. At first, they didn't give us any chili and I LOVE the chili sauce so I asked if they had any. They were holding out! There chili sauce was delish! It had a lot of different spices and tiny dried shrimp and tasted different than the normal red kind you get at Chinese restaurants but was amazing. Not as spicy though. So the moral of the story is - if they don't give you any - ask! We went back for lunch one day and the place was packed but the wait was still short. They have a really good system down and all the staff seem to work together. I would say that this place has one of the friendliest services of the Chinese restaurants I have been to. The menu is more extensive than the late night menu (yay). We ordered the pork belly again. Obvy. BUT, they forgot to bring it to us. We were disappointed but also a tiny bit relieved b/c we realized we ordered too much. So, we didn't ask for it. We got the taro cakes which I liked but are a bit dry. The egg custard tart which were really good but super sweet. The shrimp noodle crepe was good and had big shrimp in it. The spare ribs with noodle roll ball were disappointing. The spare ribs were not tender like how they are in the black bean sauce. They looked the same but were super tough and chewy. Did not like. This place is a bit on the expensive side but the place is nice inside and the service is pretty good (besides forgetting our pork belly). Enjoy!

39.description: First of all, they're open until 2am. Nothing makes me happier than knowing that I have dim sum options late at night. For someone who moved from SLC to Chicago, this is pretty exciting. Second, their service is great and super fast. And third, the food was really good - - no complaints about any of the dishes we ordered. You mark off what you want on a menu, rather than wait for a cart to come around. I liked this because every dish we ordered came out piping hot.. fresh from the kitchen straight to our table. I highly recommend the deep fried pork dumpling and pork bun.

37.description: If they are busy and table limited, prepare to wait a little bit longer then usual if you are ASIAN!!! I know it sounds odd because they are Chinese restaurant but that is their mentality. They will sit White and non- Asian first regardless of what number they give you or table size. They think that white people will give them more tips and come back again while on the other hand, Asian tend to tip less and will come back regardless how restaurant treats them. Well my advice if you wanna come here as Asian, put some make up on and pretend to be non-Asian!

0.description: Monday night officially ends the 2 week Chinese New Year celebratory period. The Lantern Festival, (aka Sweet Dumpling Festival - Yuan Xiao Jie) is Monday so the restaurant was insanely packed. Must have been close to 40 people waiting to get in.  Despite the vortex of insanity downstairs, we had reserved the giant table Banquet Room upstairs for the night which shielded us from the most of the madness outside.The table and spinning top is huge. I kept saying to myself that despite what must have been pure craziness in the kitchen tonight, the food was quite food and hot. We had a wide variety of typical banquet style dishes including, lobster, shrimp, scallops, noodles, dumplings, pork, beef, veggies, bird's nest, etc. Quite authentic. Great job and service given the crazy night for the restaurant.

38.description: You would expect better food quality just because the place looks nice and everything is pricer than other dim sum places. Came here for dim sum once and they were just ok, some dim sum dishes were kinda bland or flavor was kinda off.The other day, we ordered out for dinner. Some dishes we got were walnut shrimp, 椒盐虾，椒盐猪排,  京都骨, etc. The shrimp from the walnut shrimp dish were kinda soggy and the taste was kinda off. The 椒盐虾，椒盐猪排 were not crunchy/crispy. 椒盐猪排 were tasteless. The pork from 京都骨 was ok , but you could taste the strong canned pineapple, which was overly sweet. Overall, the food quality is not worth with how much you need to pay for.

51.description: I'm giving Min Hin 4 stars despite the less than satisfactory service.  However, I'm sucking up part of the blame because I went with a party of 6 on the busiest night of the year, Xmas Day.  My group of assorted non-Christians made up of Muslims, Jews, (and folks with assorted other afflictions like shellfish allergy & celiac disease ) hook up frequently for dinner on  Xmas Eve or Xmas Day.  Only restaurants open are Chinese, OK?  Jewish people have been doing it for years.  It's traditional to go to a movie, and do Chinese.  Our table was ready on time, and the waiter did forewarn  us that the kitchen was really busy .  Suffice it to say, the kitchen was totally"in the weeds".  Dishes for our table came out one by one over a period of about fifty minutes.  It was painful, because with all the various dietary allergies and restrictions, we were unable to share!  (Our problem, not Ming Hin's)   I managed to taste each of the dishes, and they were really delicious.   Plates of dim sum being carried by the servers looked awesome.  I'll be back on a "normal" night of the year

27.description: Great for Dim Sum in Chinatown!

32.description: Compared to Cali dim sum, this place is pretty darn cheap. You don't get the whole experience where the ladies are pushing around dim sum carts, but that's not a huge deal for me. One great thing I like about this place is that their menu is very easy to read. They have pictures for each dish and a piece of paper for you to place your order. Dim sum was good, tastes just how you would expect it to taste. I suggest ordering the dim sum staples such as ha gow, shu mai, and pork belly (this one was actually my favorite, it had the perfect amount of crunchiness at the top). Their plate of chow fun is only $5.95! Some dishes that didn't impress me was their ha cheung (there wasn't enough soy sauce) and their dried bean curd skin (I'm not sure how to spell it in Chinese...). Also, they don't cut their dishes in half so if you're sharing with a large group, don't forget to ask for a pair of scissors! Other callouts:This place looks packed, but the restaurant is fairly decent size. We went during peak hours for lunch and only waited 15 minutes (for a party of 2). They say dim sum is served 24 hours, but they stop serving dim sum between the hours of 4 to 9). Overall, this place has pretty good dim sum. Only reason why it's 4 stars instead of 5 is because it doesn't have any mind blowing dishes that makes me want to come back next time I'm in Chicago.

54.description: I was hugely disappointed with my visit in terms of food tastes...I came in wanted dim sum but unfortunately they didn't serve it until 9pm. Decided to give regular dishes a shot since we were too starving. Ordered creamy king crab meat with corn soup 蟹肉栗米羹, chicken corn soup 雞茸栗米羹, fish fillet and tofu with XO sauce casserole XO醬班腩豆腐煲, Macau style roasted pork belly 澳門燒腩仔, BBQ pork rib 蜜汁燒排骨, and stir-fried chow mein noodle with beef 乾炒牛肉麵. Both soup tasted not like 羹湯 but regular corn soup that you could get anywhere/make on your own easily and, though different orders, tasted exactly the same...casserole was decent, tofu and fish were both fine. Pork belly was the best part of the meal. BBQ pork rib wasn't bad but didn't stand out. Chow mein noodle was really plain, wouldn't recommend. I think I might still go back and give their dim sum a shot, but overall -I don't think I'll be coming here for regular dishes... Aside from the food, interior is nicely decorated and the place is clean. I also saw that they have private rooms, which looks pretty nice for groups!

48.description: Love their shrimp dumplings, honey bbq ribs, chives dumpling.  Not a big fan of their stick rice and the squid has too much batter.  Top 3 dim sum in Chicago - tad expensive - expect to drop about 20 bucks per person - and don't forget the delicious chili oil.

44.description: 1000 plus reviews must say something I struggle to add something new that has not already been said. Awesome dim sum!  This place packs in hundreds of diners on any given day. With volume like this, you are assured of freshness. If aren't Chinese, or don't have a Chinese friend to come with you, study the dim sum menu online before you come.  Best pot stickers and shu Mai I have ever tasted.  Go there!

24.description: Have been here multiple times on weekends with friends over the past few years for dim sum, and so far haven't been disappointed yet! Their selection of dumplings are amazing, and they also have my favorites of chicken feet and beef tripe. The fact that they are open until 2 AM makes it great also with the karaoke crowd. While they have a few carts going around, you'll mostly be ordering from the menu, which personally for myself takes away some of the charm of dim sum. Maybe not as good as some of the dim sum places I've had in west coast Canada (Richmond in Vancouver comes to mind), but hey, for a place in the midwest, I can't complain :)

7.description: Is it late at night and all you think about is dim sum? Fear not my friends, MingHin is here for you. Located in Chinatown square, with plentiful dedicated parking (paybox). I enjoy coming here and very family friendly. I enjoy mixing my hoisen and hot sauce for an all purpose dipping sauce for my dim sum dumplings. They serve smaller type dishes as a part of their dim sum. my favorite is the crispy pork belly, Rolled noodles in XO Sauce and chinese broccoli.   Starting at 9PM, they are slinging you all the tiny dishes, Shumai, shrimp and Chive dumpling, you name it! They all taste very delicious. I like being adventurous and try them all, dont be scared. Pricing is decent for some quality late night eats. the servers are very friendly. I suggest you order a lot and enjoy picking up various type of dim sum over some good conversation.

49.description: Addicted to their dim sum. Tip: go there before 11 am or after 2 pm. Otherwise be prepared to deal with a long wait.

40.description: One of my favorite Cantonese style Chinese restaurant in Chicago. Seafood and dim sum are good choices. Recommend the clam cooked with spicy and wine.

53.description: Tried this place upon the recommendation of some Chinese friends my husband and I made. This time we ordered egg rolls (They have chicken, veggie or shrimp) and the crab rangoon. We loved both! The egg rolls weren't as big as at other places, but who needs torpedo sized egg rolls anyway? These were hot and crisp, with a great crunchy texture. The crab rangoon were equally delicious. Since they are one of our favorite Chinese appetizers, we were pleased! We weren't too hungry so we ordered a large combination fried rice to share. The hostess had explained that theirs was a combination of beef, chicken, and shrimp. (No pork). My husband is very particular about his Chinese because if you've read my previous reviews, he moved here not too long ago and hadn't been very impressed with the Chinese places in our area. As far as fried rice goes, he likes it freshly fried, not steamed rice sitting in a vat that they call fried rice. This fried rice was fresh, moist, and flavorful! I only subtracted one star because there was hardly any beef or shrimp. The shrimp were plentiful and a nice size, but this was supposed to be combination fried rice!We noticed that the dining rooms were all packed and people were waiting to be seated, so business must be good. We were also encouraged that this place is in the heart of Chinatown, giving it a true authentic feel. I love dim sums and they have it, so we definitely plan to come back and try more things.

30.description: Breakfast, lunch and dinner.  Has consistent food and the best service in Chinatown.  Everything is pretty good but my favorite is the fish filet and eggplant casserole.  Clean and nice decor.  Busy during the weekend dim sum and dinner.  Can't wait to try their new location.

46.description: Dim sum! Such fun for Sunday brunch, great atmosphere, delicious bbq pork buns. Even though they couldn't find our reservations (made online), they seated us right away when there were dozens of other people waiting. Fast service, amazing food, and so fun to walk around Chinatown afterward and shop. A great day!

1.description: After arriving in Chicago, the BF wanted to eat asian...so we went to MingHin to get some late night dimsum/chinese food. Walking in there was a few people waiting and it did seem pretty packed for 9:30PM, but then again...it was a Friday night. I can tell you the hostess wasn't the nicest person but then again...this is chinatown? Took a bit of time to get seated, but once we were seated our server and the busboy were pretty attentive. Our server asked us for our drink order, I ordered a tea and he ordered a Sapporo. We looked over the dimsum menu that had the typical dimsum such as shuimai and shrimp dumplings, etc and we also ordered a LARGE chicken congee & stir fried udon noodle. The dimsum items were okay, I'd say they were a bit "over-steamed". The Chicken congee had almost no flavor...which was also a bust. My favorite dish of the night would have to be probably the stir fried udon noodles...which weren't even that amazing. All in all the meal was decent but there is better food elsewhere...maybe my standards are too high? I might go again but will definitely choose different dishes...

55.description: Beef Chow mein was phenomenal!!Fried rice  flavorless Busboy was fast and friendly which was the total opposite of the waitress almond cookies with check were pretty darn good overall not the best but to feed 2 for under $30 I suggest order only the chow mein and an appetizer save your money on the fried rice. Tip the busboys and remind your waitress to at least make an appearance and ask if everyone is happy The End

9.description: Compared to Cali dim sum, this place is pretty darn cheap. You don't get the whole experience where the ladies are pushing around dim sum carts, but that's not a huge deal for me. One great thing I like about this place is that their menu is very easy to read. They have pictures for each dish and a piece of paper for you to place your order. Dim sum was good, tastes just how you would expect it to taste. I suggest ordering the dim sum staples such as ha gow, shu mai, and pork belly (this one was actually my favorite, it had the perfect amount of crunchiness at the top). Their plate of chow fun is only $5.95! Some dishes that didn't impress me was their ha cheung (there wasn't enough soy sauce) and their dried bean curd skin (I'm not sure how to spell it in Chinese...). Also, they don't cut their dishes in half so if you're sharing with a large group, don't forget to ask for a pair of scissors! Other callouts:This place looks packed, but the restaurant is fairly decent size. We went during peak hours for lunch and only waited 15 minutes (for a party of 2). They say dim sum is served 24 hours, but they stop serving dim sum between the hours of 4 to 9). Overall, this place has pretty good dim sum. Only reason why it's 4 stars instead of 5 is because it doesn't have any mind blowing dishes that makes me want to come back next time I'm in Chicago.

26.description: The dim sum was great. We also had duck and fried rice. The duck was not good. Everything else was great. The restaurant is clean and stylish. The waitstaff was attentive. Overall nice. I'd go back, I just won't order the duck again.

25.description: Decor is nice and clean and well lit. Had a large (1.5 dish) Fatty beef + pork stomach. The dish looked like it was piled high. However, there were so many vegetables (logs of chinese broccoli) underneath that. This is false advertising, as neither the dish nor the picture mentioned anything about getting vegetables. Terrible.Did I pay for vegetables? I can cook those at home!

12.description: MingHin is hands down the best dim sum place in Chicago's Chinatown! It highlights the best part of your traditional dim sum joint- fresh, piping hot dishes! You order straight off their menu instead of waiting for carts full of food being wheeled around. I like this because you never have FOMO- all of the dish options are already right in front of you. No need for waiting around to see what goodies are in the next cart!MingHin gets very busy during weekend brunch hours. For larger parties you will definitely have to wait a while in line during peak hours, but for smaller parties (read: parties of 2), it's usually a quicker wait. I've gone during weekdays and it's almost never been a problem to get immediate seating. Great selection, good service, and delicious dim sum. I personally really enjoy their short ribs with honey, shu mai, and plain crepes (the fried dough inside, you tiao, brings me straight back to a traditional chinese breakfast. only thing missing is dou jiang!) best. Definitely a go-to in Chinatown!

59.description: Just okay.  Too much dough on the buns for my taste.  Tea was flavorful.  I find that Chinese food in Chicago is somewhat unsatisfying compared to coastal cities in the US.  A couple of dumplings that we had were good.  But the meal wasn't earth shattering or memorable in anyway.

21.description: This place is definitely the best Chinese I've had in Chicago. Just be sure to make a reservation! We made one for Saturday brunch and it was lucky we did so, the place is so popular you could be queuing a while if not!Excellent!

17.description: I've been here twice for dinner, once late enough for the dim sum menu. Aside from the BBQ pork buns, I actually prefer just to order appetizers and rice/noodles from the main menu, but the pork buns are worth going at dim sum hours for alone. These are the fluffiest BBQ pork buns I've ever had! The dough is melt in your mouth soft, piping hot, and stuffed with sweet, tender pork, really REALLY good! The restaurant is decorated nicely, clean, and has lots of seating; I haven't had a wait either time I've gone, once on a Saturday night. The menu is huge and has lots of colorful pictures. The food is fresh and comes out quickly. They also have a full bar, and a specialty cocktail list. Both times I've gone, someone has come over to ask about my drink and see if I had any feedback. The first time I had a drink called the Almond Joy, which had pineapple, Malibu rum, and grenadine. It was tasty, but the feedback I offered was that it was missing chocolate if you were naming it after a candy bar, and I'd like to see some Godiva liqueur and not grenadine to line it up with the name expectation. I forget the name of the drink I had on the second visit, but it was pretty strong, which the staff could tell by my nursing of it throughout the meal. Overall, the food is very good, the staff are friendly and fast, and the prices are pretty reasonable for the quality. This is our go-to dim sum spot now!

10.description: Amazing dim sum food! Amazing service! My favorite dim sum place here in Chicago!!! No complaint about this place!Tip: Happy hour is from 2:30-4 pm 20 % offThis is a very huge restaurant. They have two stories. So if you want to bring a large group, call them first. And the environment/setting is nice and clean, I would bring my family and friends (from Cali) here.

5.description: I've had more delicious and cheaper food elsewhere; however, my companion has some hold-up about cleanliness, blah blah blah, and wanted a cleaner, more contemporary setting.Sigh... still a 3 for me. In order from best to worst:Curry Cuttlefish dim sum:Delicious like always!Pork in Stone Pot:Authentic and something neither of us had had. The server warned us that it's a fatty dish. The larger pieces of pork in the middle were and we hardly touched the stuff. There were a lot of smaller and shredded saucy stuff that totally made up for it, though, and that was delicious! I'm really not a big fan of pork, but this was sooo good!Beef with thin Pan-Fried Noodle:Alright, but bland. The big fresh veggies were the best part.Salt and Pepper Squid:The flavor was alright, but I much prefer the flavor and texture of Prawn. Not Ming Hin's fault: I blame this on my +1 who suggested I try something different. Seafood Fried Rice:Very bland and very oily. There was good distribution of seafood, which was cooked well, but overall disappointing. I'm not big on salt, but soy sauce was necessary when reheating.2- Meat Platter: Pork Belly and Duck:The duck was delicious. Not a huge fan of the Pork Belly. I've had it before and know it's supposed to be deliciously fatty, but this was a teeeeny bit of pork between two giant layers of fat and with a slight crust.  Tried dissecting it for my leftovers and the minescule bit of pork wasn't worth the effort.Pea Tips with Preserved Egg:The veggies themselves were good, but there was very little preserved egg. There was, however, a sh!t ton of what turned out to be tenderized bamboo, (?!) which is apparently a new addition. I'm not one to ever be turned off by texture, but this was absolutely gross.Shrimp and Chive Potsticker dim sum:Meh, they were OK. The wrappers were slimy and my +1 commented that they looked old.Pre-tip total = $86.Service was good: the server guy brought us chili oil and gave us a little to-go container of the brown sauce they put on the table. Oh, and lots and lots of take-out containers and two giant bags.It's an A-OK joint...  next time, though, I'm steering us elsewhere.

3.description: Absolutely great Chinese food.  One of the best places to eat in Chinatown!!The food was great.  Went here with a few friends and was not disappointed.  We each ordered an item, then ate family style.  There was plenty of food served and the prices were very reasonable for the price.  Good quality and freshness.  A little salty, but to be expected for a Chinese restaurant in the US.  The service was standard of a Chinese restaurant l, not great, but there when you need it and always refilling our water glasses.  Only one small "downside" we wish we had known earlier.  When went for dinner at about 7 on a Friday night and tried to order some dim sum and we're told it didn't start until 9pm.  I don't know if it is only sold at certain times or if it is only this time, but since they are known for their dim sum, wish we would have known so as not to get so excited.  Otherwise a great experience.

35.description: Very fast service but not very attentive so prepared to order and ask your questions when you finally get the attention or a server. I tried the steamed buns, pan fried dumplings, wonton soup, shrimp steamed dumplings and a beef noodle dish. The dumplings and buns were amazing. The shrimp ones were incredible. The wonton soup was just ok. Very bland broth but the wontons had good flavor. The noodle beef dish was interesting. Didn't have very much flavor and was very oily. In the end, for two people and all 5 things, the total bill was only $22! Unbelievable. We left so full and satisfied. Will definitely come back and try new things!

19.description: I've come to the conclusion that there is a price to pay for decently good dim sum in Chicagoland, and MingHin is one place that actually delivers.While prices here are much higher than what I am used to ($4 for a small? really??), I can't deny that the quality here trumps a lot of other establishments. The quality of the siu mai and the har gow tops all the other joints nearby, and these are the staples that every dim sum place is typically judged upon.Rather than having traditional carts, you order off a picture menu so visual eaters can pick and choose freely. Try everything! The noodle crepes here were very good (with large pieces of shrimp), and the taro cake is a must-eat as well.The funny thing about MingHin is how un-Chinese it feels. The service here is actually pretty good, and all of them speak to you in pretty good English. The workers here don't seem to all speak Cantonese, which is surprising to me. I even had trouble communicating with the workers unless I used Mandarin. On top of that, they didn't cut some of the items that are usually served in smaller portions. When I asked for them to use scissors to cut the noodle crepe or meat balls, the server thought I wanted cutlery, lol. A small detail in what was overall a great experience.Overall, MingHin is likely one of the better places in Chicago. It's not the best, but if you're willing to pay a higher premium for dim sum, you'll find this place delectable and satisfying.Get there early on weekends to avoid the chaotic lines!

28.description: Perhaps the best dim sum menu around. Good service during busy time. The food is always wonderful here, a must stop on any trip into the big city.

45.description: MingHin is probably the most upscale looking and well maintained restaurant in Chinatown.  Missing are the typical kitschy and cheap plastic decorations, plastic table cloths, sticky table tops and clutter.  Our family has gone there for Dim Sum about 4 to 5 times a years since they opened about nine years ago and were always satisfied with the quality of their food. I would rate their Dim Sum as better than most, but not quite as good as The Phoenix. Service is adequate.

33.description: Ming hin is my go to place for dim sum. The atmosphere is really nice for China town. The food here also is quite good. They have a dim sum menu as well as a regular menu. I like how it has a lot of pictures. One thing that's semi unique at minghin is that many of their regular menu items feature 1 and 1.5 portions. Imo this is just their way of justifying definitely higher than average prices for slight more food. I will say however the food quality is quite good. My go to dish-i'm not certain if it's on their menu. But it's their shrimp with golden sauce. Basically salted egg yolk crust over a lightly fried shrimp. I know I know, the name is kinda off putting. But trust me, Holy cow its sooooo good! My second favorite dish from minghin is their egg yolk pastry thing from their dim sum menu. If I were 18 again I'd eat 5 of these!!! Sooo creamy and the salty and savory combination is sooo good. I ordered some to go and popped them in the microwave for 20 seconds the day after and it was still sooooo good!If you live in chicago or in town visiting minghin is definitely worth a check out!

43.description: MingHin is hands down the best dim sum place in Chicago's Chinatown! It highlights the best part of your traditional dim sum joint- fresh, piping hot dishes! You order straight off their menu instead of waiting for carts full of food being wheeled around. I like this because you never have FOMO- all of the dish options are already right in front of you. No need for waiting around to see what goodies are in the next cart!MingHin gets very busy during weekend brunch hours. For larger parties you will definitely have to wait a while in line during peak hours, but for smaller parties (read: parties of 2), it's usually a quicker wait. I've gone during weekdays and it's almost never been a problem to get immediate seating. Great selection, good service, and delicious dim sum. I personally really enjoy their short ribs with honey, shu mai, and plain crepes (the fried dough inside, you tiao, brings me straight back to a traditional chinese breakfast. only thing missing is dou jiang!) best. Definitely a go-to in Chinatown!

2.description: Come to MingHin if you want some solid, authentic, affordable, and nicely-portioned Cantonese-style Chinese food. The servers here are helpful when it comes to dietary restrictions and the entire place feels clean.I came here with a party of 6 and ended up paying about $13/person tips and tax included.We ordered:Peking Duck (4.5/5):I would totally recommend this dish! They do duck really well for a cantonese restaurant and they provide all the essentials for an enjoyable Peking Duck dish.These are all solid food to order. They make it well and authentic (all dishes are 4/5). Pineapple fried rice, Stirred fried beef noodle, Cha Siu, Stirred friend lamb (juicy!) and garlic Chinese broccoli.This is a place I would bring my parents (both spent 30 years living in Canton) if they ever come visit me in Chicago. It's such a gem and a surprise to find food so authentic in Chicago.

18.description: I come from Canton where dim sum originated from. I would say dim sum here is pretty authentic and good! Rice Crepe, Egg yolk Bun, Shumai and Chicken feet are my must to have. Give it a try and you will like it:)

41.description: This place is relatively new, which might explain some of the kinda clueless waitstaff. Otherwise, props to this mammoth restaurant for defying the typical cramped dim sum scene. The tables are spaced out generously and the vibe is nice. Call ahead for a reservation. The dim sum was very good. I would go for the turnip cake, shu mai, vegetable or meat filled crepe noodles, and maybe a bowl of congee. And daisy tea!

52.description: I've been living in the Chicago area for 4+ years and I tried dim sum at Phoenix when I first arrived. I was so unsatisfied that I lost all interest in trying dim sum .. for THREE YEARS.  And man, I love dim sum. I decided to give dim sum here a second try and went to Ming Hin.  It was pretty good!  They had most of the things I liked. However the service was TERRIBLE.  It would be 5-10 minutes between receiving dishes so instead of having lots of different entrees on the table... it was like some pseudo 10 course meal at a nice restaurant where they serve you one item at a time.. except for dim sum!!  Also, they didn't have any sauces or condiments on the table and you really have to be aggressive in asking for them to be brought to your table.  Overall.. it was okay and I would come back if friends were craving dim sum.  I still don't think it matches up to my expectations to the point where I'd ever crave it and try to rally people up to go with me.

50.description: Recently I attended Ming Hin Cuisine for lunch with a friend. Although he swears it is one of his favorite restaurants, I found the Dim Sum dish at Ming Hin merely "OK". It was somewhat bland compared to other restaurants I've tried. I ate the egg rolls as well, which were slightly better, although a bit towards the greasy side. The service, while not terrible, was a bit lacking as well. I feel as if this restaurant could improve a bit on the decor and service, add in a bit of flavor and achieve a 4 star rating from most eaters. It's also a bit more expensive than I would expect for food of this calibur. All in all, an acceptable option if you're in the area.

4.description: Tried this place upon the recommendation of some Chinese friends my husband and I made. This time we ordered egg rolls (They have chicken, veggie or shrimp) and the crab rangoon. We loved both! The egg rolls weren't as big as at other places, but who needs torpedo sized egg rolls anyway? These were hot and crisp, with a great crunchy texture. The crab rangoon were equally delicious. Since they are one of our favorite Chinese appetizers, we were pleased! We weren't too hungry so we ordered a large combination fried rice to share. The hostess had explained that theirs was a combination of beef, chicken, and shrimp. (No pork). My husband is very particular about his Chinese because if you've read my previous reviews, he moved here not too long ago and hadn't been very impressed with the Chinese places in our area. As far as fried rice goes, he likes it freshly fried, not steamed rice sitting in a vat that they call fried rice. This fried rice was fresh, moist, and flavorful! I only subtracted one star because there was hardly any beef or shrimp. The shrimp were plentiful and a nice size, but this was supposed to be combination fried rice!We noticed that the dining rooms were all packed and people were waiting to be seated, so business must be good. We were also encouraged that this place is in the heart of Chinatown, giving it a true authentic feel. I love dim sums and they have it, so we definitely plan to come back and try more things.

6.description: Just so you know if you are dining in China Town or any Chinese restaurant in the city, do not expect spectacular service lol.Since we got that straighten out, I would like to say that the food here is bomb.comI highly recommend the Macau Style Crispy Pork Belly, Pork Fried Rice, Pork Steamed Bun, and Pork Pot Sticker - you can probably just order anything with pork on the menu and it will be delicious lol :)

22.description: The last time I was there, it was a Thursday evening around 8pm.  The restaurant was relatively empty (maybe our table and 3 more tables tops).  Our waiter kept trying to rush us out, and was VERY intent on getting our menus from us immediately.  We wanted to sip some tea and order an appetizer before deciding on entrees (and we were contemplating Dim Sum which began at 9pm).  The waiter must have asked for our menus 5 times in 15 minutes after we ordered an appetizer.  We explained we would be ordering more food, and he kept coming up to us every 2 minutes to ask us for our menus.  It was so weird.  By having the menus, we were planning on ordering more food which we made very clear.  I finally said to him jokingly "you seem really intent on getting these menus from us, do you want us to leave, or do you think we're going to abscond with them?  What is the deal?"  (He was also trying to clear our plates as we were literally still eating off them).  He told us that the owner docks the server's pay if menus are left at the table!  CRAZY!  Although the food was good as always, the service experience left a lot to be desired.  We felt like we were being hounded throughout the dinning experience, and that the waiters were hovering over us so much that they were practically dining with us!I've been here several times, including for Dim Sum.  Overall, the food is delicious.  The prices are reasonable (actually rather cheap for Chicago).  I'm hoping that the most recent experience with the service is an isolated one!

15.description: Dim Sum at night?! I didn't know it was possible until I came to MingHin! Came with a group of 4 and we definitely ordered enough for all of us.Turnip cakes: pretty good, a little bland for my tastesPork shu mai: basicShrimp and chive dumplings: only comes with 3, wouldn't recommendShrimp har gow dumplings: basic, but a necessity! Fried pork dumplings: get it! Tastes great!Sticky rice in lotus leaf: one of my go-to dishes! Never disappoints no matter the restaurant.Everything was great. Was a bit sad that they did't really have many dessert options available - Where are the egg tarts?!Prices here are a bit higher than your normal dimsum restaurant, but $10 per person is definitely not a bad price.Would go back here for late night dim sum!

57.description: Love how the dim sum is available for extended hours. I love the roast duck and the pork belly. It's served warm and hits the spot. Your order from a menu vs. them walking around with carts of food. The menu has pictures of the item so it's pretty easy to pick out your favorites. I think it's a little pricier than some other places for dim sum, but not that much of a difference.

20.description: Dim sum pickings are pretty slim in Indianapolis, and I live way outside the city, so I haven't been in years. Finding myself with a free afternoon in Chicago, I made my way into Chinatown and decided this was my restaurant of choice.Rather than the cart approach, you get a menu to mark your selections on. I like this approach; it takes some of the randomness out of the equation, and means that if you're far from the kitchen the good stuff doesn't disappear before it gets to you.I almost squealed out loud to find out they have snow mountain buns, an item we had in LA but haven't seen since. They're sweet and crunchy on the outside, are made of tender dough, and ar filled with this killer sweet-salty-eggy filling. Sooooooo good.The har gau and siu mai seemed pretty standard, but the fried veggie/pork buns were flavorful and different, and the shrimp crepes had just enough sauce. The tea was complimentary, and the service was quick and friendly. I'll definitely come back again.

36.description: We had dinner here last night. While the food was very good, I have to give them only one star due to the treatment I received.  After we finished our meal I went to the restroom (!which in itself was not up to cleaniness),  while exiting the restroom I slipped and my feet came out from under me. I hit the floor hard! Fortunately I was not hurt (though every part of my body aches today). The staff helped me up and said we need a cover here. What upset me is the manager looked at me and claimed it was my fault I fell. Instead of being concerned that I was ok he attempted to shift the blame for their slippery floor to me. He said I was walking too fast. He is very lucky that I am just bruised from this, another person might of sued. Sorry for my rant but the rudeness just upset me so much. We had planned on returning to try their dimsum but myfamily will not be returning to this restaurant

14.description: On a good day I would give Minghin a 4 on a bad day it's seriously a near 1 star. Their seating is great... no one can argue with but the service here can be extremely bad. If you come to Chinatown in large groups you will never get your food at the same time and never get good good service.I wanted to love Minghin and I did the first maybe two times I came here but then I realized all the serious flaws.

58.description: Recently dined in once a few months ago and thought it was ok, so decided to give another shot with takeout last night. FAIL!Out of the three entrees and one soup we ordered, only the veggie entree came in ok. Everything else was not good. The hot and sour soup texture was like water and there was way too little ingredients in the soup/water - felt like you were just drinking water. The Chinese broccoli with chicken was butchered - over chopped and over cooked. The pork in Peking sauce is a cornerstone of Cantonese cuisine, yet Golden Bull's version totally massacred it - treated the dish like it was Sweet & Sour Pork. DISGUSTING.Needless to say, not going back. They were busy, but I really don't know why...

56.description: Appetizers were a waste of money! Shrimp balls had something resembling shrimp but no actual shrimp inside. It was gross! I ordered mongolian beef and it had no flavor! Some of the beef was still red and undercooked. It was so gross!! Worst restaurant in Chinatown.

29.description: We are take out delivery Saturday , because all restaurant will be book and we working trade show in McCormick and we just want to eat . It was a great decision . The food is really good , we got chicken  with veg cashew nuts and eggplant  casserole . It was great and we are picky !, great food , fast , easyI would recommend this place for sure

42.description: Given the good reviews and single dollar sign on Yelp, we decided to get dinner here after surveying the plethora of options in Chinatown. From the outside, it looked questionable - but the food was delicious. We had:Sweet and sour pork ribs - very flavorful, but don't get if you're a lazy eater and don't want to navigate the bonesLong beans and pork - super yummySalt and pepper shrimp - good, but it's just shrimp and no veggiesBeef and wide noodles - yum because it wasn't as oily as othersAll in all, big bang for your buck!

23.description: We wanted to bring our less than adventurous food eating teens to Chinatown for the first time. I read the top rated reviews and Golden Bull stood out for a few reasons: the traditional complementary hot tea and pork broth soup, the old style Chinatown exterior but modern interior, and of course, the food ratings.My wife and I are not "foodies" but we certainly appreciate variety and uniqueness. Definitely were not going to go to Chinatown and have Beef and Broccoli or Kung Pao Chicken...and wanted the kids to have an eating experience.Ordered five dishes and amazingly, one came out first (salt and pepper soft-shell crab) and then the other four came out.The crab was the best I've ever had...crunchy and spicy. Even my wife who does not eat seafood tried it and said it was good. The kids of course loved it but might have been a bit hot for them with the jalapeno garnish.Then the Mandarin Pork Chops, French Steaks, Boneless Chicken with Black Mushroom casserole, and Farmer's Chicken arrived.The Farmer's Chicken is a cold dish....the meat of the chicken is shredded and left on top of the carcass. The seasoning was incredible...we noted vinegar and cilantro in the mix. My favorite.Mandarin Pork Chops were meaty in a sweet sour sauce. A bit tricky to pick up with chopsticks so you better be pretty good with them!French Steaks were cubes of steak with a honey sauce. My wife's favorite.The Chicken casserole was served in a pot with a medley of Chinese vegetables and was the kids' favorite.There were so many other dishes I would have liked to try but just can't eat that much food!I'd consider food for four and leftovers for $60 plus tip to be a bargain!We did find some free on street parking in the traditional area of the neighborhood and walked two blocks.About the only negative I can think of is no dessert menu...but we walked the area and found some bakeries that were open late afternoon and picked up a few treats.

47.description: Very good food, very friendly staff. On Saturday night it is full. Local residents, a birthday party with three generations, suburbanites and Chicago cops. Solid Cantonese food. Reasonable prices.

8.description: One of the better family style restaurants in Chinatown. Their sweet and sour pork chops are crispy and meaty. The crispy rice casserole with mushroom, chicken and Chinese sausage was my favorite! The sauce was so tasty and the rice extra crispy! Beef with Chinese broccoli was also on point. Will be back!

31.description: Actually came to this place after we discovered that MyPlace did not have their special advertised $22 twin lobster. The Golden Bull Restaurant is a tiny, reasonably decorated place. The menu is quite expansive and does have a little but of everything. An appealing factor is that they have set menus for x-number of people, which is more than enough to share. A few qualms I have about the place is that there is only street/meter parking out. You can find additional parking in the lot by where the train tracks are. You have to ask for ice water. It's assumed you will have hot tea with your meal. Service of preparing the food is also slow, even though I know it is fresh and made to order, I would like some speediness to my food. If you are a traditionalist and are looking for the stone pot sticky rice, place that order as soon as you walk in because it takes 40 minutes to prep/cook this dish of deliciousness. If you want the hand shredded chicken, also place that order in the minute you walk in because they literally hand shred half a chicken for that dish and it will take 30 minutes to prep and season the dish. We had ordered the dinner for 3, which came with 3 beef & barley soups to start, we decided with the beef with Chinese broccoli, stir fry lobster, and instead of the sweet and sour pork, we went with the spiced salt and pepper pork. Beef & barley soup: clear beef broth, barley beans, carrots, and little chunks of beef. It wasn't overly salty, but had a delicate flavor to it.Beef with Chinese broccoli: Beef is pretty standard, wasn't overly impress with the quality of the meat or the flavoring of it. Did enjoy the heaping helping of leafy Chinese broccoli, and stem. We did pick out all of the veggies in this dish. Stir fry lobster: This was my favorite dish. The lobster was sweet, juicy, and tender.  A bit on the small side, but a solid piece of shellfish. The sauce that the lobster was cooked in was decadent in flavor. It was rich and creamy due to the fact that I think cornstarch was added as a thickener. The sauce had egg and pork in it. So if you're a non-pork eater, I would check with the server if they can make it without it, otherwise, it is just delicious and a must order. Just keep in mind that you have to work for your meal here.Spiced salt & pepper pork: I love this dish. It's battered with lightly and seasoned very well. It is "deep fried" in the wok, and the meat is tender and juicy. They garnish this this with some sauteed jalapenos. Hand shredded chicken: We got this dish last. Like after we killed our first 3 dishes, this one came out last. We were already full. I'm not sure if it was because I was full I would this dish to be overly salty in some parts, and under seasoned in other parts. But I think I will have to give this dish another chance the next time I visit.Taro & tapioca dessert soup: Kind of bland and flavorless goop. I've had this at other establishments and it was amazing. Here, not so much. Maybe it was an off day.Overall experience, food, service, cleanliness, etc is a 3 star. I wasn't WOW'd the food was good, but just took way too long.

34.description: Loved this place!!! We ate, small Chinese broccoli, small shrimp and scallops and a large salt and pepper shrimp. It was excellent!! Only thing we did not think was excellent was the egg drop soup.

16.description: My go to place for salt and pepper soft shelled crab! Great service and deliciously authentic Chinese food at a low price point. Favorite place to go in China Town and I think they stay open until 1 am on weekends, so I love coming here after a night of drinking. Make sure to ask for their free chicken soup at the beginning of the meal (although my caucasian boyfriend got a chicken foot in his, which scared the crap out of him haha).

13.description: Actually came to this place after we discovered that MyPlace did not have their special advertised $22 twin lobster. The Golden Bull Restaurant is a tiny, reasonably decorated place. The menu is quite expansive and does have a little but of everything. An appealing factor is that they have set menus for x-number of people, which is more than enough to share. A few qualms I have about the place is that there is only street/meter parking out. You can find additional parking in the lot by where the train tracks are. You have to ask for ice water. It's assumed you will have hot tea with your meal. Service of preparing the food is also slow, even though I know it is fresh and made to order, I would like some speediness to my food. If you are a traditionalist and are looking for the stone pot sticky rice, place that order as soon as you walk in because it takes 40 minutes to prep/cook this dish of deliciousness. We had ordered the dinner for 3, which came with 3 beef & barley soups to start, we decided with the beef with Chinese broccoli, stir fry lobster, and instead of the sweet and sour pork, we went with the spiced salt and pepper pork. Beef & barley soup: clear beef broth, barley beans, carrots, and little chunks of beef. It wasn't overly salty, but had a delicate flavor to it.Beef with Chinese broccoli: Beef is pretty standard, wasn't overly impress with the quality of the meat or the flavoring of it. Did enjoy the heaping helping of leafy Chinese broccoli, and stem. We did pick out all of the veggies in this dish. Stir fry lobster: This was my favorite dish. The lobster was sweet, juicy, and tender.  A bit on the small side, but a solid piece of shellfish. The sauce that the lobster was cooked in was decadent in flavor. It was rich and creamy due to the fact that I think cornstarch was added as a thickener. The sauce had egg and pork in it. So if you're a non-pork eater, I would check with the server if they can make it without it, otherwise, it is just delicious and a must order. Just keep in mind that you have to work for your meal here.Spiced salt & pepper pork: I love this dish. It's battered with lightly and seasoned very well. It is "deep fried" in the wok, and the meat is tender and juicy. They garnish this this with some sauteed jalapenos. Hand shredded chicken: We got this dish last. Like after we killed our first 3 dishes, this one came out last. We were already full. I'm not sure if it was because I was full I would this dish to be overly salty in some parts, and under seasoned in other parts. But I think I will have to give this dish another chance the next time I visit.Taro & tapioca dessert soup: Kind of bland and flavorless goop. I've had this at other establishments and it was amazing. Here, not so much. Maybe it was an off day.Overall experience, food, service, cleanliness, etc is a 3 star. I wasn't WOW'd the food was good, but just took way too long.

11.description: This is best Cantonese food in Chinatown. The food is always fresh and delicious.好吃！

39.description: With great service, sweet location, and best Chinese food ever this is a must while in Chicago!  My top choices are the Egg drop soup, Orange Chicken, & Bok Choy and all get a 10 of 10.  Even the tea is the bomb so get some Golden Bull and enjoy Chicago's China Town!

37.description: Decided to venture over to Chinatown and took a shot at Golden Bull (based on the Yelp reviews).  Had an order of egg rolls, which were fresh and fairly tasty.  The "complimentary soup" was a relatively tasteless broth with a pork bone and some undercooked beans- meh. Tried a variety of dishes (Beef Kow, Sweet & Sour Pork and Combo Fried Rice) which were pretty unexciting, though very fresh tasting.  I would only grade it as passable.  Maybe we should have ordered some seafood items, as most of what was being served at the surrounding tables was crab, shrimp, oysters, and the like- and it all looked very good. Sometimes it just goes that way.  I may stop by again and try something more "exciting".  The Americanized Chinese choices were only average.

0.description: one of the best Cantonese cuisine in Chinatown, the food is very fresh and the environment is good too.especially recommend the rice casserole, which would require 30 minutes to cook, it is best to call ahead and order one before you go there

38.description: Everything Tasted great. Must Should/do is - calling them before heading over to this place if you want Oysters (1/3 of the time they are out).

51.description: Great Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Tan is great! Their food good is always fresh as well! I highly recommend. Also, Sakura Lounge is right next to it so the location is perfect if you want to have a couple drinks afterwards without having to move your car again!

27.description: I went there over the weekend and the place was pretty busy. The food was okay. Some of the dishes were really authentic and delicious were as others are very americanized. Overall, it was a good experience. I would definitely only go back if I have someone who know what is good to order there.

32.description: Stopped in after driving around Chinatown trying to figure out where to eat. Walked in and no one was there as we were leaving the place was packed with people waiting to be seated.Everything was very delicious.  Had wonton soup, egg rolls, pot, stickers...  orange chicken, beef with Chinese broccoli and beef also had beef & vermicelli in satay sauce casserole.  I will be back for dinner!

54.description: The food at Golden Bull is very good. My favorite dish is the spicy salt  soft shell crab and I like their pepper beef. They end the dinner with some dessert soup which helps calm your stomach down after a big dinner. It is a small restaurant and if you want to have a rice casserole dish my best tip is to order that ahead of time before you head to the restaurant because it takes 25 minutes for the dish to be done.

48.description: This is the place I want to bring my family to for the most authentic, delicious Chinese food.  It's a bit of a hole in the wall, the outside is very unassuming unlike some of the big dim sum behemoths of Chinatown.  The decoration inside is very sparse but the food more than makes up for it.  The prices are also quite cheap!

44.description: So I was a bit worried when we walked in here at lunchtime on a beautiful Sunday in Chinatown and the place was completely empty.  That would be my grandfather's cue to bolt ("no crowd? no good!").  But I was with a Chicago native who had been here, so I trusted her, and I'm so glad I did!  The flat wide noodle with beef and onion was the BEST version of this dish I've had in years and the choy sum was fresh and garlicky.  I was a little less impressed with the chicken, but everything came out very quick and very hot.  Prices were reasonable, service was friendly, and we were in and out the door very fast so my friend could make it to the airport on time.  A great Chinatown find!

24.description: Golden Bull is one of my go-to restaurants in Chinatown that consistently offers delicious and quality foods. You really can't go wrong with the menu. Everything is authentically well-executed. I'm a fan of the set family dinners, but ordering a la carte with the option of large/small plates is great, too. Especially if your goal is to try different dishes among smaller groups.Some dishes to definitely try: snow pea pods with garlic sauce; salt & pepper softshell crabs; clams with black bean sauce.

7.description: Ordered several dishes including clams, beef in oyster sauce, sesame chicken and beef Lo mien. All food was really delicious. Best Chinese food I've had. The large plates aren't super big so if you are ordering for many people, make sure to get several entrees. The reason for four stars is not the food, it is the fact that our order was forgotten about for 40 minutes and waitress had to take our order again so we waited a long time for food and were not comped for that on the bill at all. All in all, decent prices and amazing food.

49.description: I gotta say...I've been taking a closer look at those highly reviewed (but not as popular) restaurants and Yelp is giving me faith in the system with Golden Bull. Been here forever and we've never dropped in...just was never on the radar. Was a little nervous this morning when we dropped in for lunch on Saturday at about 12:30 p.m. and the place was empty (we almost thought it was closed). But we took the leap and had a great meal.Place seems very freshly renovated with new furnishings, though one might say it still looks some what plain in a grey/black/white color scheme (some chairs are yellow though!).So what did we get? We got a small portion of the surf clams with vermicelli and cilantro, the shredded farmer's chicken, chives with fish cake and dried tofu aiming off the top of their specials. All very good dishes (though I think we missed the tofu in the chives dish, but there was plenty of fish cake to compensate). They do provide flexibility in portion sizes (small, large, etc) - we went with the large for the chives dish and half chicken - so that gives you flexibility on budget and whether you want some leftovers for home (and a better deal). Thrown in, a house soup starter too, decent rice and tea. Experienced staff person handled everything at the front of the house though admittedly while we were there it was only two tables total (maybe this is more a dinner spot and everyone was somewhere hip - and less tasty - or having dim sum.)I'm assuming because we were there for lunch that dessert soup wasn't offered. Validated parking really tops it off. Two "large" size entrees plus surf clams for two = $30 and taking home half of each of our entrees to boot.

40.description: So lately Lee Wing Wah is just not doing it for me . So I took a chance and tried Golden Bull, thanks Yelp. Started off with hot and sour soup was not very good. To much cornstarch.But everything else was amazing .  Had clams with black bean sauce cooked to perfection Had paper thin slices of Jalapeños.King straw mushroom with Japanese tofuPea pod shoots were ok a little fibrous.Shrimp pan fried with out the shell was really great. Definitely will be back.Now i'll have to get the kids to convert to G.B. a little smaller portions then LWW but sooooo much better. We sat next to a lovely  young Chinese family. Parents were  celebrating their 15 th anniversary and this guy was a  wealth of information when it came to all the local spots and then some.

53.description: Growing up in Chicago, and especially trying nearly every Chinese restaurant for an family get-together, I have to say, this place is by far one of the better places to dine at in Chinatown Chicago. First of all, this place IS CLEAN. Most places such as Triple Crown, Three Happiness, Lee Wing Wah,  and many more are dastardly dirty and such a discouragement to return to even though the food is delicious. Golden Bull however trumps them on food at even more affordable prices and are not skimping out at all on taste.The staff is RESPECTFUL AND COURTEOUS. I cannot stress how grateful and true this statement is. Attending most Chinese restaurants in the Chinatown area, the waiting staff is not fluent in English and get heavily flustered and visibly annoyed when the patrons ask for requests (more napkins, x-amount of cups of ice water all around, forks and knives please, etc.) This place is attentive to everyones needs and graciously accommodates. FOOD:- affordably priced!!!-never lacking in flavor- HUGE PORTIONS (enough to feed 3-4 ppl comfortably)- AUTHENTICI was so impressed with the food. I was expecting to see either really Americanized "Chinese" food and food that was just slopped together, but presentation (which is rare in Chinese restaurants) and taste were definitely met. The chef accidentally misprepared one of our dishes and after bringing it up with management, they were sincerely apologetic and re-prepared the dish and also removed it from our bill! TALK ABOUT CUSTOMER SERVICE. They truly know how to take care of customers (especially since we were a party of 10 ordering over 10 dishes)Overall, I will be going here again and await my next return.

30.description: Simply loved their authentic Chinese food!! Great taste, big portion and quick service! Could not recall most of its menu items, but all of their Specialties on the menu would be surprises!

46.description: OH. EM. GEE. Food here is amazing! I took my parents here who are very picky and fell more in love with every bite. The place is always packed on any given day or time. And icing on the cake - it's BYOB! No corkage fee.

1.description: I've eaten at Golden Bull before and I think their food is outstanding.  After several days touring the south part of the country we returned to Chicago and as usual were ravenous so we stopped by in Chinatown to grab a bite to eat before going home.  Golden Bull is a small restaurant that I feel produces very good quality food.  When we got here the restaurant was packed. We were lucky to be seated without having to wait.  After sitting we ordered 3 half size dishes so we could have some variety.  We were also given a bowl of rice to go with the dishes ordered.  This proved to be more then enough food.  They gave us a beef stock soup for free that was ok, but lacked any real flavor.  After a very short wait our waitress started bringing out our dishes.The first dish we ordered was a fried salt & spicy smelt w/jalapeños, as usual it was very good.  The second dish we ordered was a fish filet with garlic, ginger and Chinese broccoli.  This dish was cooked and seasoned to perfection.  Each bite was savored as the flavor melted in your mouth.  The third dish was a half size dish of shrimp egg foo young.  The flavor was pretty good, but dish was just ok as it was too salty and the egg foo young sauce was gooey with too much corn starch.  After dinner they give a complimentary dessert of sweetened hot red bean & tapioca.  This may not be to the liking of some people, but I enjoyed it.In the past their food is very good prepared seasoned and cooked to perfection.  I have eaten here before and their food is becoming one of my favorites in Chinatown, unfortunately the egg foo young's saltiness and gooey sauce knocked them down a star rating tonight.

55.description: Golden Bull is probably the most authentic Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. The food is excellent and the dinner specials are hearty.  I've been here many times with friends and I will continue to visit regularly. If you're looking for real Chinese food this place is tough to beat.

9.description: This place is consistently delicious and fresh. I've been here 3 times now and it's our favorite. Prices are affordable and you can order half portions of things so you can get a nice variety of dishes. Get the salt and pepper baby octopus, the eggplant casserole, the chicken and mushroom rice casserole (takes 30 minutes), watercress with garlic, steamed oysters with black bean sauce ($4 each), and you will leave happy!

26.description: this is as authentic as it gets not that fake chinese food nowadays like orange chicken and general tso... what is that anyways??? my family has been coming here for years! the soft shell crab is to die for and also try the lobster.please be patient the chef make everything fresh so getting your food might take a bit but its all worth it. Absolutely love it.

25.description: I went with my friend while visiting Chicago. The egg drop soup was good. And that was about it.  I had the fried quail and she had the frog with yellow leeks, we both thought it was ok. Her frog had a lot of bones so it was a pain to eat and my quail was super dry. We also got the crab rangoon which was the most disgusting thing in the world,  not really sure how to describe it but it was super sweet, just horrid. They only gave us white rice, I like fried and the soy sauce was inedible. The service was slow it was like we walked in before they opened but there was another large table seated.

12.description: This was my first trip to china town in Chicago.  I can not wait to go back and try out more places.  We stopped in for a late dinner 9:30 and we were seated without a problem.  The wait staff spoke broken english but they were extremely attentive to our needs.  I ordered beef and Chinese broccoli, pork fried rice and won ton soup.  All the food was great and looking at the other tables that wiped out huge family portions of food I am going to have to say the patrons agree.  The portion sizes are good for one person.  I didn't get very far into my pork fried rice I will have to skip that next time.  We did not order anything off the beaten path but they had a ton of traditional dishes.  I will have to come back when I am feeling more adventurous.

59.description: This place does not look that great from the outside and is about the same when you walk in, but this dive is top notch and far surpasses many of the others around it.  People are really nice and work to make sure I was aware of what was being ordered and not letting the language barrier get in the way. My personal favorite dish is the razor clams and the giant clams that used a combo of garlic, cilantro and  noodles. This place is a real find and after exploring many in the area believe this is a diamond in the rough...

21.description: My go to place for salt and pepper soft shelled crab! Great service and deliciously authentic Chinese food at a low price point. Favorite place to go in China Town and I think they stay open until 1 am on weekends, so I love coming here after a night of drinking. Make sure to ask for their free chicken soup at the beginning of the meal (although my caucasian boyfriend got a chicken foot in his, which scared the crap out of him haha).

17.description: We called several times to make the reservation but they were not opened like they said. Then they never listened to the answering machine, no confirmation. I had to call again to make sure we had a table. We had Oysters and normal charge from any restaurant would be $3.50 each and theirs is $4. Also Lee Wing Wah is running a special for $2.75. When I informed them, they did not care. The dishes looked good but the Salt and Pepper Rib was dry and nothing but bones. We had two dishes of Twin Lobsters and one dish was fresh and the other was not. The Oysters were not big like they claimed to be. The bill came to a few dollars shy of $200. The owner offered to take 10% off if we paid cash. I hate that we restaurants do that because they just want to take the cash and not put it on the book and report their income. Will be not go there again for sure! When people don't appreciate their customers, don't want to take any feedback, that is when I say okay. Not going back again.

10.description: Golden Bull is one of my go-to restaurants in Chinatown that consistently offers delicious and quality foods. You really can't go wrong with the menu. Everything is authentically well-executed. I'm a fan of the set family dinners, but ordering a la carte with the option of large/small plates is great, too. Especially if your goal is to try different dishes among smaller groups.Some dishes to definitely try: snow pea pods with garlic sauce; salt & pepper softshell crabs; clams with black bean sauce.

5.description: I am obsessed with the octopus!!!They have salt n pepper baby octopus that I have pregnant lady cravings for at least once a week (I have never been pregnant but I imagine it's the same feeling). I get it with the cilantro/jalapeño/soy oil that they give with other seafood dishes. The soy sauce here is especially good because they make it themselves. It's not too salty and has a bit of sweetness to it. Long ago they had a late night menu where dishes could be ordered in a smaller size for a special price. This was before the renovations and new decor. However they now offer small and large sizes for most dishes and I prefer it this way because then I am not relegated to coming here only after 10pm lol. I have liked everything I ate here. The only reason for one less star is that when they are very busy and packed I feel the quality of the food goes down a bit. For example, the last time I went was during a dinner rush and my fried rice had hard chunks in it (bottom of the pot rice I'm assuming). If they could be consistently great I would give 5 stars!

3.description: If you want late night chinese food I would recommend coming here.  The Mapo Tofu was tasty and the black bean clams were on point.  We didn't know they had a lobster special but we saw others ordered it.  If you want delicious chinese food come here, instead of the salty bland food at Chi Cafe.

35.description: Really cool find in Chinatown! My boyfriend and I saw this while walking one day and decided to try this place out. We got the walnut shrimp, pea pod shoots stir fried in garlic, and eggplant & salted fish casserole. They even had the traditional canto restaurant style of giving free soup and sweets before & after the meal. Most entrees came in small or large, so we were able to try a lot of dishes. I will definitely love to come back here again with more people just so we can try more food haha

19.description: What can I say? You're just wonderful. Golden bull is simply amazing. We have eaten here at least 30 times, and it has been perfect every single time.  The food is fantastic, the service nice, and clean with great lighting.  This is our go to place.  I can not think of a single bad thing about this place, and if I had to pick, I would say this is one of the best places to eat in Chinatown- probably the best chinese in Chicago as far as taste and value.  You simply can't beat it and I have eaten at quite a many establishments of all kind. I'm so happy you're not more popular because then I'd have to wait!  It's Chinatowns best kept secret!

28.description: I went here for a big birthday dinner for a friend. The food is pretty good and very reasonably priced. Really, I like ridiculously spicy food and this wasn't, but your standard tasty Chinese food and authentic enough.

45.description: I am all about authentic Cantonese food. This place really impresses me. Stir fry beef rice noodle is a staple of Cantonese food. They got this dish right. It is the best version of this dish I have had in Chinatown. They have slow-cooked soup served before dinner and sweet soup served after, bringing back fond memories of how eateries are in Hong Kong. All the dishes we had were great. I like how the place is relaxing, with Chinese music instead of Taylor Swift. It seems very clean and the service is good. We had an 11 month old, who kept banging the choptick on the table, but the servers are all very friendly.

33.description: good service..small restaurant.. good place for family style dinner.. but sometimes they need to adjust the temperature inside.. sometimes it will be tooo hot and sometimes it will be tooo cold..have tried a lot of the food on the menu and they all tasted great! fresh and flavorful.. few of my fave dishes here is the clams and salt and pepper shrimp..also this place is not expensive either so that's a plus in my book!

43.description: I don't know why this place doesn't have 5 stars. This place is incredible. The portions are huge and prices low. The food is fresh and delicious, I had the crab Rangoon, sweet and sour chicken, fried rices, and bbq ribs. (two separate trips :) Fast service, crispy chicken, delicious bbq sauce... amazing. Simply amazing. Ruined every Chinese I will have for ever after. I will only eat Chinese here in Chicago from now on. Everyone seems to celebrate birthdays here. Family- style serving with hufe turntables or smaller seating is available for smaller parties.

2.description: Went there two Sundays in a row in the last two weeks. We are frequent visitors at Golden Bull. The food is extremely delicious and have extremely great value. Their service is very good and tried to take care of every customer's needs. The only setback is that the output of food is a little too fast for me. They can slow it down for a little bit so i can catch up with the delights of their cooking. I highly encourage to come to this restaurant but it has some limited seating so you have to reserve early to get a seat. i definitely would come back.Some of my favorites are: Shrimp, Sweet and succulent; Sauteed Fish Fillet, experiencing the bones and the meat with completely different textures; Pea Sprouts with Garlic; literally melts in your mouth; and finally the Fried fish with salt and pepper; tender meat on the inside and crispy skin on the outside.

18.description: If you are from the East Coast and can't find any good Chinese food in the city of Chicago - go to Golden Bull!  It's worth the trek.

41.description: I love it! They provide a chicken stock soup as a complimentary appetizer AND a warm red bean soup dessert. Their food is decently priced, since they have pretty big portions. It is a little run-down inside, but nothing dirty or unbearable. I've gone twice now, and there were no dishes that weren't very good. I do like their stir fried beef and bean sprout chow fun a lot! Also, their green beans w/ pork is awesome. I would definitely go again the next time I'm in Chinatown!

52.description: After reading the reviews, I decided to give this restaurant a try. I ordered Chicken with Broccoli...It wasn't chicken...Do I need to say more?

50.description: We always come here for the frog legs with rice because that's what they're known for.  It's called "Tian Ji" in Chinese, and I've never tasted it this good anywhere else yet.  The frog legs with rice take awhile to cook, so you should call in to order it in advance.  Not only that, they just so happen to be open after midnight.

4.description: I say ditto on my last review here from 3 years ago, and maybe go a notch higher to 4.5 stars.  Best features are the great value and decent family dinners here.  This time we had the dinner A for six for $73.95 (menu provided in photo).  Starter soup and tapioca dessert are still included as per past practice.  The food comes out quickly here. Also, every table in the place was taken at 6pm on a Saturday, so the place is well known to the value diners in Chinatown.

6.description: Personally i liked the food and the small clean space.....my picky family not so much. We ordered the chicken skewers(very dry no sauce),  broccoli Chicken in white sauce which was pretty good and of course the special Lobster, yum yum but very messy to eat!! The service was quick, waitstaff polite.Maybe will give it another try in a few months.

22.description: I am obsessed with the octopus!!!They have salt n pepper baby octopus that I have pregnant lady cravings for at least once a week (I have never been pregnant but I imagine it's the same feeling). I get it with the cilantro/jalapeño/soy oil that they give with other seafood dishes. The soy sauce here is especially good because they make it themselves. It's not too salty and has a bit of sweetness to it. Long ago they had a late night menu where dishes could be ordered in a smaller size for a special price. This was before the renovations and new decor. However they now offer small and large sizes for most dishes and I prefer it this way because then I am not relegated to coming here only after 10pm lol. I have liked everything I ate here. The only reason for one less star is that when they are very busy and packed I feel the quality of the food goes down a bit. For example, the last time I went was during a dinner rush and my fried rice had hard chunks in it (bottom of the pot rice I'm assuming). If they could be consistently great I would give 5 stars!

15.description: I came here on a Monday at lunch time. The place was empty except for one person eating at a table (this should have been my first warning). There was no hostess, waiter, or any type of employee to be seen when i walked in. After nearly a minute of waiting, i got up to leave when the hostess/waitress finally emerged from the kitchen and noticed me.I ordered the crab rangoon and chicken chow mein. The rangoons were just ok - the wontons were very oily and the filling had virtually no crab flavor. They then brought me the wrong entree. After waiting for them to make me anther meal, i finally got the worst chow mein I've ever had. It was awful. The noodles were stringy and crunchy and there was hardly any chicken to be found in the massive pile of uncooked noodles. The sauce lacked any distinct flavors other than salt. I couldn't eat more than a few bites before giving up even though I was very hungry. Very disappointing.Tl;dr inattentive service, messed up orders, terrible to ok food.

57.description: Amazing BYOB.  Truely Authentic.

20.description: A must for Cantonese cuisine. It's my family's favorite in Chicago for many years now. Get walnut shrimp, ginger and scallion lobster, while steamed sea bass, crock pot, fish filet with leeks, beef and broccoli chow fun. I have yet to find a resto in NYC that's better.

36.description: Slimy, salty, disgusting.  Rubbery chicken.  Not a good option.

14.description: We wanted to bring our less than adventurous food eating teens to Chinatown for the first time. I read the top rated reviews and Golden Bull stood out for a few reasons: the traditional complementary hot tea and pork broth soup, the old style Chinatown exterior but modern interior, and of course, the food ratings.My wife and I are not "foodies" but we certainly appreciate variety and uniqueness. Definitely were not going to go to Chinatown and have Beef and Broccoli or Kung Pao Chicken...and wanted the kids to have an eating experience.Ordered five dishes and amazingly, one came out first (salt and pepper soft-shell crab) and then the other four came out.The crab was the best I've ever had...crunchy and spicy. Even my wife who does not eat seafood tried it and said it was good. The kids of course loved it but might have been a bit hot for them with the jalapeno garnish.Then the Mandarin Pork Chops, French Steaks, Boneless Chicken with Black Mushroom casserole, and Farmer's Chicken arrived.The Farmer's Chicken is a cold dish....the meat of the chicken is shredded and left on top of the carcass. The seasoning was incredible...we noted vinegar and cilantro in the mix. My favorite.Mandarin Pork Chops were meaty in a sweet sour sauce. A bit tricky to pick up with chopsticks so you better be pretty good with them!French Steaks were cubes of steak with a honey sauce.
