My wife's favorite.The Chicken casserole was served in a pot with a medley of Chinese vegetables and was the kids' favorite.There were so many other dishes I would have liked to try but just can't eat that much food!I'd consider food for four and leftovers for $60 plus tip to be a bargain!We did find some free on street parking in the traditional area of the neighborhood and walked two blocks.About the only negative I can think of is no dessert menu...but we walked the area and found some bakeries that were open late afternoon and picked up a few treats.

1.description: Ages ago I took liquid ginseng straight from small glass vials to ward off allergic reactions to cat dander - a friend and fellow Yelper used to get them for me on Maxwell Street.  Later, when my dearest betrothed Kelly B. and her feline friend moved into my pied a terre, I again went looking for that magical elixir.  Thanks to A.S. V.'s review right here on Yelp,  I found them at Sun Sun Tong Company.  See?  It really DOES work!Sun Sun is a great spot for liquid ginseng, goji berry extract, and other similar herbal medications, at a fraction of what you'd pay at GNC, et al.  Highly recommended, and worth a trip from the NW side of Chicago.Coincidentally, I also hear this is where Gob Bluth gets his tea for dong when traveling through the Midwest.

2.description: I'm not an expert of these shops, but I used to buy cases of ginseng that came in little vials of liquid that were pretty cheap, a good energy pickup during long hours at work.

0.description: Definitely one of those stores that you would pass up if you didn't quite understand the concept. Its really simple, its all about Holistic Chinese old school products. The couple who owns it have been here forever and know what they are talking about. If you would like to get tea's that will make you lose weight, help in digestion or just calm your nerves- well here it is. The products are somewhat unusual at times but believe me the products are types they you would normally not find anywhere else. My mom always has backaches and the Salonspas patches work! They come in various packaged amounts but I like to get her the bigger patches that she applies and leaves on. They do work because I have also tried them whenever I have an ache somewhere. Also too the ointment that comes in a little green bottle for less than $5 is also a perfect accompanist to the patches but in liquid form. It has a menthol smell to it and definitely works. You can get the most unusual products here for less than what you would pay your doctor at any given time. Ladies, do you have menstrual problems, ummm yes, he also sells tiny little pellet formed pills that you take and my friends have sworn that their irregular monthly friend is now back on track and less pain than before. Yes, they do sell Ginseng in liquid form, but why stop there? Give them a try and you will see that their products although unusual, do work. Its also advised to the tourist that if you are just here for oddities sake (which is fine), please don't put on the Chinese Straw hats just to take a selfie, as this is using their products and not respecting the store. (Hey I just read the sign don't judge me). But seriously, you will find whatever you need by asking. If you have migraines, let him know and he will give you something for that migraine. And men, if you have problems with "rising to the occasion," ummm yes he has something for that also. A friend that use to have that problem swears by it. Plus while I was there a young guy (yes young) came in and asked and I eavesdropped. What? I am supposed to be colorful, its PRIDE month!

58.description: I waited to write this review until I had tried both Cai and Lao You Ju for dim dum. My favorite is still MingHin in Chinatown Square. 2nd best is Lao You Ju at the moment. I'm only giving this 2 stars for the Yelp definition "Meh. I've had better." I really feel like 1.5.I had some high hopes for this place since it is a popular dim sum spot. it was busy and bustling when we got in. Service was only okay. they did their job. Cai was not good. We ordered a mix of a few favorites from other places and few unique items. In general, when you come in hungry, the food tastes better. Well, in general, this food didn't.  Since it was just the 2 of us, we ordered:-shrimp on steamed tofu - I grew to like this as it was my 1st time trying this but it wasn't anything awesome-wontons in spicy sauce - this was new item for us. wontons were good but the sauce was bitter :(-The steamed soup dumplings with crab - this didn't come with a soup spoon to pick up the soup in the dumpling. the staff was confused as it why we wanted a spoon. they gave us semi big serving spoons. oh well. ultimately this was only okay. the ingredients were different maybe.  -tofu wrapped pork and shrimp - this is a usual favorite at Minghin and it was a let down here. no flavor and the tofu seemed old? -lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice - this was TERRIBLE! I am a pig and I will eat most food in front of me even if it's only semi okay but I actually STOPPED EATING this! it was that bad. the meat had no flavor and didn't seem fresh. it seemed rank.  this is a personal favorite item in most other restaurants. These were great in MingHin and Lao You Ju. -Even the chrysanthemum tea was too strong on the tongue. Unfortunately, this was a disappointing experience and I will not be looking forward to coming here again. though I feel like I will because most other people go and will likely suggest this. Foodwise - this was a stark contrast to the flavorful items at Lao You Ju and the freshness of Minghin.

56.description: This place is five stars, food, ambiance & service!!!  Food s always fresh.  Their dimsum is great.  Watch out though, weekends are extremely busy.

29.description: I am not impressed. I enjoy dim sum all the time. This almost ruined my love for dim sum, almost. Cai is a little more "upscale" and the decor and place looks beautiful. They pack this place to the gills on weekends and you can hardly get by. The chances of getting by a full round table of people are slim to none. The place was so packed that we had to share our table with another party. What the hell? Food was alright but the service was slow. The servers are so busy that you cant get a word in and when I finally flagged someone down to refill my water, I was already almost done with my meal. Pricing was higher than most dim sum places in the area. I hope they punch up the customer service there and reevaluate the foot pricing, but that's just me.

42.description: The food came out fresh and fast.Great dim sum for those trying it for the first time. The prices aren't outrageous and postion size is good. Down side is that it's busy and you have to wait a little.

23.description: Food: 3.5-4 stars Large, authentic menu, but can be inconsistent-sometimes it's super yummy, sometimes it's only okay-but it's usually pretty good!Service: 3.5 starsNice ambiance. Waitstaff are friendly, but can lack attentiveness. This restaurant can get very busy and there is usually a large team of waiters. During busy dining hours I have seen them standing around idly, and it becomes sort of difficult to track someone down if you need anything. Empty dishes tend to be left to pile up on the table during dim sum service. Some dim sum favorites:-Sui Mai-shrimp dumplings-shrimp dumplings with green chives-sticky rice with chicken wrapped in lotus leaf-dry scallops with Chinese dough-beef crepe-baked green choice puff

47.description: Probably more of a 2.5 star review. The food here is good, however the service is something to be desired (which honestly, when I dine out in Chinatown, I never really expect all that great of service). We came here as an alternative to MingHin since the wait there was 45 minutes and the wait at Cai was like... 10. Ordered a plethora of plates off the dim sum menu, most of which were very tasty. It did take a LONG time to get the ball rolling though, we probably sat for 15 minutes before our first dish was brought out (cold I might add) and then another 15 before the remainder started trickling out of the kitchen. Also we didn't have any of the traditional sauces (chili oil, plum sauce) that come with dimsum and we had to repeatedly ask our somewhat put out waiter for them. And it took a very long time to get our check (I think they were setting up for a dinner banquet, they had cleared most of the center of the room and were resetting tables and putting out nice red table clothes) - we nearly just went up to the front to pay after trying to flag down any waiter in the vicinity (and failing, repeatedly).  Again I would probably leave this only as an option if MingHin was way too busy - I think overall the service (while still not spotless hah) and food quality there is a bit better.

8.description: Cai was highly recommended to me by some friends as their favorite dim sum restaurant in Chinatown, and after visiting a few times myself, I couldn't agree more. The food is extremely authentic, reminiscent of the dim sum I often ate with my grandparents back in China. They have a diverse menu with all the staple dim sum dishes listed, complete with pictures and English translations for those who do not speak Chinese. It was also impressive that they had xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and liu sha bao, since those are items rarely found in Chinese restaurants in America. While they weren't nearly as juicy as the ones I've had in China, I was still pretty happy to find them here in Chicago.For first timers, I would definitely recommend the two dishes I listed above, along with egg tarts, the rice wrapped in lotus leaf, rice rolls, shrimp dumplings, and the bbq meat buns. I visited around 1pm on Sunday and the restaurant was crowded and noisy, but that's part of the full, authentic dim sum experience. I had to wait around 20 minutes, but thankfully, my party of 5 got a table to ourselves (I've had to share before, unfortunately). Cai uses a paper ordering system instead of having employees push the traditional carts around, so we couldn't just point to what we wanted and eat it right away. After submitting the order, some of the items came out within minutes, but we had to wait another 15 minutes for the rest of the dishes to come. There was no concept of serving everything at once, which is pretty typical of dim sum meals. However, our servers consistently stopped by and were great with refilling tea and taking away the empty dishes.

31.description: I'm on a mission to find the best dim sum for the price here in Chi(na)town. For my first stop, it was Cai (how do you even pronounce this?), the banquet style hall where carts do not exist, and a menu with photos are given.My friends and I showed up on a Sunday morning and waited half an hour before being seated. Most of the workers there were speaking Mandarin, which I found odd, given that dim sum restaurants are usually filled with Cantonese speakers. Already I was a bit hesitant with what the experience would look like lol.Once we were seated, we got our menus, and checked away at the different dim sum items.Really, the quality and taste of dim sum is going to differ between people. The selection here is  probably second best after MingHin, and is much more reasonably priced. Those that are unfamiliar with dim sum offerings are also at an advantage here due to the fully pic-ed out menus of each item.However, service was pretty meh. Our server did not bring out our food for nearly half an hour (on top of already waiting that long to be seated). I flagged down a boss lady to take out receipt and check the kitchen to see why we hadn't been served yet. A few moments later, some items start coming out, and I had to direct them to the lady to get our receipt back so they could mark what orders were already delivered.On top of that, they did not cut the chern fun in half like most restaurants would.It sounds like a lot of complaints, but really, Cai is fine as a dim sum restaurant and a good place to introduce your friends to the cuisine. There's better spots in Chinatown if you're willing to pay the price, but I'll say this is a solid go-to for future yum cha dates.

34.description: This place lost. Rice is supposed to come with out orders. When we ordered, they said the rice is still cooking. Asked several times for rice. We finished our food already and still no rice. Their service really sucks. We were the only people here too. Waiters were extremely rude. Never coming back here again.

16.description: Not sure why this place has such poor ratings, as I consider Cai to be one of the best in Chicago dim sum. No, you don't get the carts rolling around like more traditional places. No, the service is not very fast because of their made-to-order model. But for any one looking for authentic and traditional tasting dim sum, I would expect there is not many better places than Cai in Chicago's Chinatown. In fact, the made-to-order model is great for those looking for the freshest dim sum because those carts circulate quite a while and the items get cold. A great feature is their menu full of pictures that helps with those unfamiliar with dim sum order with confidence.

13.description: Always a great time at Cai. I've been here several times with a bunch of friends and it never disapoints. Love, love, love their Shumai and mochi. It's always busy, which makes service some time slow with the water and even getting napkins. However, the food is always coming out on good time. I see the waiters work very quick to quickly seat the next people. Whenever I want dim sum - this is the first place I think of and would go with my friends!Quick tip - always bring cash and use their parking accommodation (really love that aspect) but you have to show your receipt

11.description: It's been a little while since we've been here for dim sum, but this must be the current hot spot for Chinatown dim sum.  Seemed like everyone was here for weekday brunch.  I'm now retired and sort of lead a life of leisure, and knew why I was here, but what is everyone else doing here?  Don't they need to work?  Is everyone else also retired or on vacation?  Are they all having long lunch breaks from work?  I pondered these questions as we ordered.  Anyway, it's a little pricier here, but we found it worthwhile for the nice touches - spacious and airy, quick service on sauces and water, and all dishes were steaming fresh and hot.  Some places don't offer all the sauces, and it was nice to get hot mustard for a change, as an example.  In LA, we found they charge for dim sum sauces!  In conclusion, come here if you want to have a good dim sum experience.

39.description: Decent food-- My favorites here are the vegetarian dishes: vegetable dumplings, turnip cake, rice noodle with tofu and egg custard buns. However, it'd be great to see more smiling staff. Service could also be better.

37.description: Fabulous!!! had a 11 AM reservation for four; table was ready, amid a long line; service was above par and all the dim sum items were superbly done; especially, with no fresh steamed oysters but, the fresh in shell sea scallops steamed with garlic, ginger and rice vermicelli was outstanding, seasonal, so you have to inquire. In my opinion, top tier Chinese cuisine in Chicago.

0.description: Good place for dim sum. My favorites are pork dumpling And egg yolk bun. The shrimp dumpling is not very good, the wrapping is too thick and the shrimp is not deveined.Been here for dinner a few times and it is just ok. The sizzling black pepper ribs is too salty. the eggplant and fish casserole had pineapples in it, which is weird. the breading on the deep fried squid was too thick.  we ordered half a chicken and it was, well, chicken. The mushroom and beef was good. The fried pea tips were good. This is one of the nicer and cleaner restaurants in Chinatown. I will recommend this place, especially for dim sum. for dinner there are better places. Note that this place is BYOB.

38.description: This is the worst place to eat, foods is good, prices are fine, but the Hostess are terrible, they make you wait forever and forever, and they by pass the tourist and only take care the regular. We were visiting family in Sept. so we decide to go to this Cai for lunch. when we get there at 10 A.M. we got a number, and they said, it will take an hour to seat. then I stand on the side and waited, then I see the hostess keep giving to their good friends first. all they have to do is tell the hostess they are friends with the owner, then they do not have to wait, get to seat first. so We waited for about 2 hours for our seat. it was heart broken to see people run business like that, We wasted 2 hours for this. When I question the hostess, their answer is the owners friend always seat first. and then after 2 hours waited, and waited another 30 minutes, they still missing two of our orders, it never come. very upset day in Chicago.

51.description: Fine for what it is. Just posting a review to remind myself that I bought too many drinks for too many people, requested Salt 'n' Pepa, and then did a dance called the Mammogram here.

27.description: My go to place for Dim Sum! Love the busy atmosphere in the large dining room! Easy to read and order menu. Always quick service and pretty good food!

32.description: So disappointed with this place...ordered NOT spicy salt n pepper shrimps, gave us shrimps drenched in chili sauce n d manager insists its only "little spicy" , almost refusing to take it back to replace.  Had 8 entrees and never got steamed rice...they kept saying "it's still cooking"...WTH? A Chinese restaurant with only a few customers ran out of steamed rice??? Got done feeding 21 people n they are all pissed...by d time we finished eating, the manager finally asks...do you want the rice now? SERIOUSLY?????

54.description: My grandma loves Cai, so this is the only dim sum place we go to nowadays. It's always really busy during Saturday mornings; they tell you it's a 15 minute wait, but 99% of the time, we end up waiting an hour, especially if it's prime-time (around 11AM-noon) and if we don't want to share a table (if you only have a party of a couple people). Grandma loves the beef rice noodle crepe, steamed tofu with shrimp, and the chicken feet. My dad loves the shu mai and the har gow (shrimp dumplings). Sticky rice wrapped in the leaf is also a good choice. We've gotten their congee on a couple separate occasions and it's usually pretty flavorful and they give you a lot. We usually order some kind of noodle dish from the back of the menu; the szechwan eggplant noodle dish is our current favorite. Shrimp rice noodle crepe is starting to become a regular on our dim sum menu as well. Service is a little choppy, so every time we're here, I embrace my inner-Chinese and just wave down whichever bus boy or waiter is nearby at the time, which is really the only way you're gonna get anything from them. They're great with tea refills but bad with water refills, so just wave them down and ask! Never ask the ladies who bring the food for anything like water refills, they literally ONLY bring food and most of the time they don't even speak English so just be wary! They do validate parking at the parking lot across the street, so 3 hours of parking is only $2. It does get full pretty fast though but if it's still open, definitely park in the huge parking lot and get your parking validated!!

48.description: 3.5 This place is great for being a nicer venue (there was a wedding reception during dinner service), and it had decent food... but that's about where it ends for me. The food was average, but I just seem to expect phenomenal flavors at Chinatown restaurants. In essence, I expect Chinatown Square restaurants to provide the gold standard of what authentic Chinese cuisine has to offer.I came with a party of 14. We had a shmorgasboard (i'm sure i botched that) of plates that kept arrivng, and barely made one pass around the lazy susan.  Surprisingly.... a bowl of rice came 5 plates later, and it was hardly enough for the table (I'm asian. Please don't skimp.)There was a beef and peapod affair with meh-gritty-beef.  There was a pork belly dish that was doused with a hoisin-type sauce, and all i really wished it was, were duck instead. The true winner was the walnut shrimp.Honestly, I feel like I'd give a more accurate review if I were to try their dim sum service.... but based off of this alone, 3.5.  IT's BYOB, seats are clean, cushy, and well-kept.  They serve lumps of sugar for your tea, and give plenty refills on that. Our bill WAS very affordable. We were full, and somehow walked off with a split of $15/person.  That said... pricing is reasonable.

44.description: What a waste of money today. The is good, not greatBeing Chinatown I take my customer service with a grain of salt. And they had a ton of salt today. Today service was horrible. When clearing a table, don't swear in front of my kid. When setting a table, don't slam dishes on the table so loudly I have to yell across my table to talk with my guests. Don't forget my food after asking for the dishes three times. I don't care if the servers are here today and gone tomorrow. Bad service is a reflection on the management. Not that they bothered to ask "how was everything?"There are better options in Chinatown if you want salty dim sum. Don't bother going upstairs to this relic and dirty restaurant who doesn't care.

24.description: Not sure why this place has such poor ratings, as I consider Cai to be one of the best in Chicago dim sum. No, you don't get the carts rolling around like more traditional places. No, the service is not very fast because of their made-to-order model. But for any one looking for authentic and traditional tasting dim sum, I would expect there is not many better places than Cai in Chicago's Chinatown. In fact, the made-to-order model is great for those looking for the freshest dim sum because those carts circulate quite a while and the items get cold. A great feature is their menu full of pictures that helps with those unfamiliar with dim sum order with confidence.

7.description: Dim sum the way it should be.Efficient and discrete service, tasty foodCheap check. What else you need to spend a great brunch on a wintery saturday

49.description: I know most chinese restaurant are not known for service but today's experience had been brutal. We were seated promptly for the morning brunch. After our orders were taken and our tea was served by the staff, we literally had had to drag some of the staff to be served. Servers were standing by the corner talking to themselves and talking on their cellphones. Maybe it's an off day but I doubt it. It seems that there is a lack of supervision, or the management is way to comfortable with lack of effort. The food was not even up to there usual standard, maybe because its a weekday. I would not recommend this restaurant. I will go to another restaurant for dim sum.

40.description: While this place has decent dim sum, the line is terrible and the four hostesses have no idea how to operate a wait. If I could give zero stars, i would. The wait isn't worth the food.

53.description: Cai is a great restaurant and their prices cannot be beat. I am a frequent visitor there. Their ambiance and atmosphere is incredible. Service might be a little disappointing for me but the Dim Sum and prices are the best in the Chinatown for Dim Sum. Some Dim Sum choices include Shu Mai and Har Gao but also some of their new menu options including Rice Cakes, Beef Short Ribs, and Shrimp and Corn Dumplings.Overall, I definitely come back.

30.description: My family has frequent the restaurant since it opened, we will not going there anymore.  I noticed a downtrend of the service.  The last time my family went, we waited for 30 minutes for the dish to arrive.  We waited for another 25 minutes to the second dish that arrived lukewarm. I understand the place gets busy, especially on the weekends.  However, the customers came after us and sit near our table were served at a faster pace.  The attitude of the wait staff was not pleasant.  Needless to say, we were very disappointed.There are other dim sum houses in Chinatown.  We will be taking our business elsewhere.

46.description: I love this place. We go here all the time and I think I've tried almost everything on the dim sum menu. My favorites are the soup dumplings, tofu rice wrap, and corn and mushroom congee. I don't think I've ever had anything bad from here.

1.description: A-OCAI!Dim Sum take 2! have heard many wonderful things about Cai and it has been bookmarked for weeks. I finally decided to visit the restaurant and I was so enthusiastic about the experience...until we walked through the door. I don't know if it was just because It was a Sunday morning at 11, or because the Lunar New Year Parade was in a couple of hours, or if the dim sum is this stellar, or a combination of the three, but I was NOT prepared and I was NOT okay with how many people were packed inside of this restaurant. Standing room only is truly an understatement. Location - Cai is located on floor 2 in the New Chinatown complex. From the Red Line CTA stop closest to the complex, it is definitely not an intuitive entrance. My friend and I ended up talking the employee back entrance into the restaurant and it was sketch major! They should have had a sign on the door informing patrons that the formal entrance was through a different door. The ease of access we received entering the restaurant has me convinced that there have to be many instances of people skipping the lines and jumping into an open table. And because of how PACKED this place was Sunday morning, one would have great trouble convincing me that the staff would even notice.Decor - resembles Phoenix to me. Big wide open space with standard Chinese/Cantonese decor covering the walls. Elegant light fixtures. Plastic tables with cloth coverings and then paper coverings on top of those (a tad ratchet if you ask me...). Carpeted. Which was awkward. How do they keep the floors cleaned?! Service - okay. I have to give Cai the benefit of the doubt. There were a few hundred people in this restaurant Sunday. There is absolutely no possible way to provide A+mazing customer service to this many people in this small of a space...I don't care what anyone says. However, I shouldn't have to get out of my chair to ask for a water refill. Definitely NOT O-Cai! I really wish also that dim sum items were all served at the same time. To me it is so frustrating to have the items coming out at all different times because sometimes I find myself getting full or tired of eating before the rest of the good stuff comes out. At that point I find myself over-eating. And I do this solely because I truly have a hard time believing dim sum to be good eats when reheated. The hostesses were hilarious though. And sassy. Love it.Food - I made sure to do my research on dim sum and what to order before I came to Cai. So I was prepared to do damage major that day! I am going to review each item in order from best to worst (from my point of view). Even though everything was good there were certainly spectacular and not so great dishes.*Siu mai - plump, juicy, perfectly fresh shrimp and pork and delicious skin. Mixed with the sweet chili sauce this was easily my favorite meal because of all of the delicious flavors going on at once. *BBQ Pork Buns - I just really love the pastry from steamed bbq bao. The bbq pork was flavorful. I cared not one bit for the abalone sauce so I ate them plain. They were not a bit warm though. Deduction.*Baked Green Chive Puffs - these were phenom! They have a big plump piece of shrimp in the inside mixed with the chives and other filling. Outside wonton were perfectly crispy and buttery and crunchy*Lo mai gai (sticky rice with chicken wrapped in lotus leaf) - DELICIOUS! First time having and I am a huge fan. the sticky rice was piping hot and the the aroma of the lotus leaf and the soaked flavor from the leaf as well made for good eats. I DO have a huge issue with Cai using the worst and old part of chicken. Had they opted for fresh breast meat, this would have been my favorite. But I CAN tell when old and the bad parts of the chicken are being used. Nice try Cai.*Stuffed bean curd skin with pork and shrimp - LOVED these to be honest. Its like a super soggy eggroll. Im not sure what sauce was soaked this dish, but it tasted something straight from the south...like some sort of chicken and dumpling broth. Its hard to explain but it worked. My only complaint was that it was a bit hard to consume - mess free - with the chopsticks. No worries. No one can help that I guess. Still very tasty.(These next three were not so great. Still following the order from best to worst) *Crispy shrimp rolls - these were the first to reach the table. They were not hot. Nor juicy. Nor fresh. Had they been, they would have been tasty. *Steamed beef meatball - way too much cilantro and the beef was mushy. Had to smother it in sriracha.*Pan fried pot stickers - the worst pot stickers I have ever had to be honest. Price - Just over $19 with tip for two people.

55.description: Meh.The wait was ridiculous, to get a seat and to receive food. Even after the wait, the food was disappointing and subpar. And it's practically impossible to get a waiter to help you. One waiter even walked the other direction after we made eye contact and I waved at him.For the same price and wait time, there are much better deals nearby.

9.description: My new favorite dim sum spot is now 2000 miles away.. *sniff*Came to Cai after reading various reviews etc. Service was alright (typical dim sum restaurant service: great if you're used to waving your arm around to get someone's attention). The setting was nice, white tablecloths and well-lit due to the large windows we were sitting by. The food though, oh the food...LOVED:Custard bun with egg yolk - Everyone's favorite. If there's one thing you must get, it's this. It's your typical steamed bun with custard filling, but the egg yolk really takes it to another level - it adds a savory richness that brings balance to a typically one-note sugar sweet custard.Haw gow - shrimp dumplings in crystal wrapper - tasted fresh with appreciable chunks of shrimp inside and had a "bouncy" texture (it's a good thing!) Curry Squid/cuttlefish - I thought this was fantastic!! The flavor of curry sauce/broth was perfect - not too salty and full of curry flavor. The cuttlefish was cooked just right (ok, maybe a tad on the extra chewy side) but the flavor of the sauce made up for itGood:Xiao long bao - soup dumplings. Thicker skinned, but wonderfully rich with porky broth.Loh mai gai - rice wrapped in lotus leaves with mushrooms, pork, etc. Usually a solid dim sum item. Didn't disappoint here.Congee with preserved egg - Large bowl, so it was pretty filling. It had the right amount of seasoning and was a nice Chinese broccolli - gotta get some greens! Standard vegetable fare. It's nice that they serve the oyster sauce on the side instead of drizzling it over. The broccoli (gai lan) was actually naturally sweet so it was nice to eat it plain.Egg Tarts - yum! Rich and custardy with flaky crust. Okay:Tripe - I'm a bit particular on this dish. This one seemed a little overcooked in that the tripe had no crunch. A wee too soft. For 4 people, we ended up paying 15-20ish. It's a little more than what I'm used to, but totally worth it.

26.description: My favorite place for dim sum, because they have a big menu list. But today, I found a rock in my crispy taro w/ chicken. I'm pretty sure it's a rock; it's black, the shape, and the sound when you drop it on a surface is exactly how a rock is suppose to sound. I can be understandable if there was ever a bug because they can come out of nowhere, but how did a rock end up on a kitchen counter. Makes me wonder where the ingredients were dealt with...

25.description: Every time I stopped here the food always satisfied my taste buds. The dish that I continue to get is their tofu mushroom dish. The roasted duck was nice and crispy. Great place to stop by for a late night dinner!

12.description: I'd say this is one of the best restaurant for dim sum in Chinatown. Phoenix is comparable too. Cai's dim sum are pretty good and has many different varieties. I bought my non-asian friends here for dim sum before and they really loved it. This is definitely my go to place for dim sum. It is definitely very loud, don't come here if you want a deep conversation with your S.O.

59.description: Three Happiness closed down, so I had to find a new place today. 3 bewildered looking white people standing on the sidewalk looking confused as to where to eat yielding a very nice women who offered her advice to eat at Cai instead.The dim sum is great (it's the same Dim Sum as every where else). I ordered a lot of the basics, but found the Durian Turnover to be pretty good and the mango custard to be a good final note. Hint: Order a bunch of food at once on Sundays - you will never get someone to come back and you can always take the good stuff home.The service is horrible. You always have to ask for water and another pot of tea. Nobody will come to take your order or check up on you if you don't wave your hands at one of the many waiters rushing around. The hostesses are snide and allergic to smiling at you.But this is what I always expect in Chinatown. It's great food, bad service - good luck finding parking on a Sunday (the pay lots are validated for $2 for three hours, but always full).

21.description: Low-key environment, quick service, and tasty food. Could have been a little more spicy/flavorful at times, but overall good. We waited 15 minutes at 12:30pm on a Sunday, which is good. Also, brunch for 4 people was under $24 total, which is pretty impressive.

17.description: The food came out fresh and fast.Great dim sum for those trying it for the first time. The prices aren't outrageous and postion size is good. Down side is that it's busy and you have to wait a little.

10.description: I am not impressed. I enjoy dim sum all the time. This almost ruined my love for dim sum, almost. Cai is a little more "upscale" and the decor and place looks beautiful. They pack this place to the gills on weekends and you can hardly get by. The chances of getting by a full round table of people are slim to none. The place was so packed that we had to share our table with another party. What the hell? Food was alright but the service was slow. The servers are so busy that you cant get a word in and when I finally flagged someone down to refill my water, I was already almost done with my meal. Pricing was higher than most dim sum places in the area. I hope they punch up the customer service there and reevaluate the foot pricing, but that's just me.

5.description: This place is always awesome in big groups. The food is fresh but not as fast as other dim sup place. In that case if you plan to chat longer and in no rush to get anywhere. Then this is the spot!

3.description: Sometimes you dim sum, and sometime you win sum!Solid dum sum.But super slow service.If you don't like those carts wandering around, this place is for you since you order everything off the menu. No gimmicks. Prices here are nice. Small dishes start at $2.99!Still have yet to figure out why all dim sum places in Chicago don't serve that hot mustard sauce on the side.Happy Chinese New Year y'all! 'Til next time, cheers!

35.description: Me and a bunch of friends decided to visit Chicago, and what better breakfast than Dim Sum!? We arrived at 9, right on the dot. When we went inside, we were the only ones and it looked like I booked the place to ourselves. They seated us and gave us a menu. What I really like about this place is that their menu have pictures...more places need to do this. We ordered a bunch of things and waited...and waited...and waited. Granted we came right when they opened and were probably steaming all the food. Pretty cool thing is that they use paper instead of cloth to cover their tables, which allowed us to draw on the tables like the children we are.When food arrived, we were so hungry that we pretty much devoured everything. We really only had one item that we had a problem with, but I have no idea what it's called in english. Everything was great, I definitely recommend the lychee egg jello thing and also the mango tapioca pudding. For regular food, everything tasted great, I would say better than most in Boston. Can't really go wrong with dim sum.

19.description: 3.5 This place is great for being a nicer venue (there was a wedding reception during dinner service), and it had decent food... but that's about where it ends for me. The food was average, but I just seem to expect phenomenal flavors at Chinatown restaurants. In essence, I expect Chinatown Square restaurants to provide the gold standard of what authentic Chinese cuisine has to offer.I came with a party of 14. We had a shmorgasboard (i'm sure i botched that) of plates that kept arrivng, and barely made one pass around the lazy susan.  Surprisingly.... a bowl of rice came 5 plates later, and it was hardly enough for the table (I'm asian. Please don't skimp.)There was a beef and peapod affair with meh-gritty-beef.  There was a pork belly dish that was doused with a hoisin-type sauce, and all i really wished it was, were duck instead. The true winner was the walnut shrimp.Honestly, I feel like I'd give a more accurate review if I were to try their dim sum service.... but based off of this alone, 3.5.  IT's BYOB, seats are clean, cushy, and well-kept.  They serve lumps of sugar for your tea, and give plenty refills on that. Our bill WAS very affordable. We were full, and somehow walked off with a split of $15/person.  That said... pricing is reasonable.

28.description: I came here late one night on a whim. I was escorted to the table, handed my menu, and on the very first page is shark fin soup. My boyfriend and I got up and left immediately. I am aware that they are not the only location to sell shark fin; I do not support them either.90% of shark populations have declined in the past 15 years. We all know of the wealthy participating in inhumane activity with the money we, the consumer, fund them with... I kindly ask that we work together as a community to cease the illegal activity by boycotting this restaurant until shark fin is off the menu.

45.description: First I need to say the service sucks!!!   It wasn't even that busy.   They have servers wearing black and ones wearing Marron. They will not help out each other or communicate with one another.  They each had their designated job so when we ask one for water they would say thats not my job you need to find someone in black.  We asked for water at least 5 times before we actually got the water.  I had to go to go over to the hostess area to order and get the check.  What restaurant makes you go hunt down your check?  We sat there for about 30 minutes before i wrote down what we wanted and gave the list to the hostess.  We sat there for that long and no one ever came to our table.  We had piles of finished dishes that they just left on our table.  This use to be one of my favorite places for dimsum.  After that experience I will go back to phoenix restaurant.

33.description: Recommended by a family member - food ok but with lazy waiter hard to understand. Served our main food dishes that comes with rice but the white rice never came after asking 5x. They offered rice after food almost gone. No sense of getting one at the time they offered. We are a big family that eats out and very disappointed how the staff were with the customers. Very bad customer service. Beware if you don't understand what they say or else...

43.description: Word on the street is that the chef here migrated over from Phoenix (across the street). The dim sum items were delectable indeed. You check off what what you want from their dim sum menu and the waitstaff brings everything out to you piping hot from the kitchen. I like it more than the dim sum I've had at MingHin.Decor wise, MingHin still wins with its grandeur and private party rooms. Though this is not to say Cai is poorly dressed, Cai boasts a sizable 2nd floor dining room, which flows a lot better for private functions and weddings. But lacks the mood lighting and intricately staged tea sets inside glass display cases that wow people that walk into MingHin. Will definitely come back for dim sum!

2.description: Terrible. Simply terrible. However, as I reserve one-star reviews for restaurants that give me food poisoning, Cai gets 2.Our group coordinator (we'll call her Nancy) called 3 weeks in advance to reserve a table for 15 people. The host at Cai did not speak English, so Nancy had her Cantonese speaking mother call back to reserve a table for 15 and ensure that we would be able to get dim sum at 6pm on a Saturday night. They said yes.When we arrived last night they had no 15 person table, no dim sum, and stuck us in the back corner, shoving two round tables together. The normal menu food was really bland and boring by Chinatown standards and it took the staff over 45 minutes from the start of bringing out the entrees until the last entree hit the table. This gave me plenty of time to observe the fruit flies buzzing around the table.Decor is 100% stereotypical Chinese restaurant with recessed purple track lighting, overly bright general lighting and Navajo White/Gold Lame paint.Sloppy, disappointing, will not return.

18.description: How was it I have tried others before this?  Much better than Ming Hin. Fresh shrimp dumplings and  very good rice rolls. The dumpling skin is translucent and just the right thickness. No MSG which is amazing. The food is not too salty or greasy.  I knew I had come to the right place when I saw little old ladies braved the steep stairs to get their dim sum. This place is authentic Cantonese dim sum down right to chairs piling in bathroom and boxes spilling out to the stairs, but hey no self respecting Chinese restaurants exists without chaos.  Don't skim on the "chili" sauce it's actually xo chili sauce made with dried shrimp , just delish.  I did say it's on the second floor with no elevator? But come for the food ! You will not regret this. Best dim sum I have had in Chicago (so far)

41.description: The food was great but The service was horrendous. First, I asked the server to bring us some yellow mustard. The server looked at me and walked away. It wasn't because of the language barrier because I am a Chinese. I tried the second time and was told by another server that they didn't have any. It was hard to believe that a Chinese restaurant doesn't have yellow mustard. So I tried the third time, this time the server brought me yellow mustard without any issue. Also, they forgot to put all of our orders in. When I mentioned it to a server he didn't even apologize. I hope the management reads this, because the poor service has to be affecting the business.

52.description: Dim Sum Pricing:Sm $2.99M $3.79L $3.99XL $4.99SP $5.25Easily the best dim sum I have had in Chicago Chinatown! We came in for a late lunch around 2 PM and we stunned to see that the place was still jam packed with people. Considering it was past the prime dim sum hours (and the place is also tucked away upstairs), I had a very good feeling about the place. We were sat after only a fifteen minute wait. The food was fantastic. Normally I find most dim sum to be overly laden with salt and MSG, but Cai's dim sum is perfection. All their plates were willed with a sizable portion of quality meats. I also got the sense that they actually made their dim sum to order. When I have been to Phoenix, we often get thrown all our dim sum dishes at once, which strikes me as a little fishy since different dishes usually take a different amount of time to cook. Here at Cai, everything came in a very nice and steady stream. It made the experience much more enjoyable to eat once plate at a time while it was hot.BBQ Pork Buns (SM) - Delicious, fluffy dough, substantial BBQ pork fillingPork Wrapped in Bean Curd Crepe (L) - Worth a try, never seen this at dim sum beforeCrispy Taro w/ Chicken (M) - Wonderfully rich taro filling with a pillowy crustHar Gow Shrimp Dumplings (L) - One of my favorites, would recommend the ones w/green chive Siu Mai Shrimp and Pork Dumplings (M) - Loved that you could taste the shrimp in these! The best siu mai I have had in ChinatownMy one qualm is they do charge $0.60 pp for tea. I cannot think of any other place in Chinatown that charges.

50.description: Come here for dim sum most of the time. Last time I went was with some friends on Sunday around 2pm. The place was still crowed as ever even at 2. We had to wait 15-20min for a table. When we got a table, the staff only replaced the paper layer from the table. The cloth layer was dirty and had crumbs on it. I pointed out loudly that there's crumbs but all the waiter did was fold the table smaller (we only had 3 people) and let the crumbs fall on the floor. Quality of the dim sum had gone downhill. One of the dim sum dishes we ordered was shrimp dumplings. The outer layer of the dumpling fell apart. The dragon feet dim sum lacks flavor. Even the hoisin sauce was watery. I understand that they are always busy and pack on weekends, but that doesn't mean their food quality and service should go down with it.

4.description: We came here on Christmas night and the place was packed, however we were able to get seated immediately. No matter how packed this place is, I've never had to wait. This restaurant is on the second floor and has a HUGE dining room. Pros: -great dim sum selection-huge menu-fresh seafood-no wait to be seated-service is always quick, friendlyCons: -dungeness crab for $50 market-price was OVERPRICEDI am giving this 3 out of 4 stars just because we felt the crab was overpriced. Other than that, this place is a must-try. Always had pleasant experiences at Cai.

6.description: I'm on a mission to find the best dim sum for the price here in Chi(na)town. For my first stop, it was Cai (how do you even pronounce this?), the banquet style hall where carts do not exist, and a menu with photos are given.My friends and I showed up on a Sunday morning and waited half an hour before being seated. Most of the workers there were speaking Mandarin, which I found odd, given that dim sum restaurants are usually filled with Cantonese speakers. Already I was a bit hesitant with what the experience would look like lol.Once we were seated, we got our menus, and checked away at the different dim sum items.Really, the quality and taste of dim sum is going to differ between people. The selection here is  probably second best after MingHin, and is much more reasonably priced. Those that are unfamiliar with dim sum offerings are also at an advantage here due to the fully pic-ed out menus of each item.However, service was pretty meh. Our server did not bring out our food for nearly half an hour (on top of already waiting that long to be seated). I flagged down a boss lady to take out receipt and check the kitchen to see why we hadn't been served yet. A few moments later, some items start coming out, and I had to direct them to the lady to get our receipt back so they could mark what orders were already delivered.On top of that, they did not cut the chern fun in half like most restaurants would.It sounds like a lot of complaints, but really, Cai is fine as a dim sum restaurant and a good place to introduce your friends to the cuisine. There's better spots in Chinatown if you're willing to pay the price, but I'll say this is a solid go-to for future yum cha dates.

22.description: How was it I have tried others before this?  Much better than Ming Hin. Fresh shrimp dumplings and  very good rice rolls. The dumpling skin is translucent and just the right thickness. No MSG which is amazing. The food is not too salty or greasy.  I knew I had come to the right place when I saw little old ladies braved the steep stairs to get their dim sum. This place is authentic Cantonese dim sum down right to chairs piling in bathroom and boxes spilling out to the stairs, but hey no self respecting Chinese restaurants exists without chaos.  Don't skim on the "chili" sauce it's actually xo chili sauce made with dried shrimp , just delish.  I did say it's on the second floor with no elevator? But come for the food ! You will not regret this. Best dim sum I have had in Chicago (so far)

15.description: When this place initially opened up, it was great.  Food was solid and prices were cheap.  After visiting several times, it became very popular and the food quality began to suffer.  Dim sum would come out cold.  And from day one, the service has been awful.  This is true even when it's not busy.  Much better dim sum places in chinatown exist.

57.description: Pretty good dim sum with large selection but I still prefer it when they push the carts around. I know that's probably less efficient, but I'm a simple visual animal and my neurons process better when there's a 3D image in front of my eyes.

20.description: The best Chinese restaurant in Chicago Chinatown.  It's clean.  Good services.  Very authentic Cantonese food and with high quality.

36.description: It's been a little while since we've been here for dim sum, but this must be the current hot spot for Chinatown dim sum.  Seemed like everyone was here for weekday brunch.  I'm now retired and sort of lead a life of leisure, and knew why I was here, but what is everyone else doing here?  Don't they need to work?  Is everyone else also retired or on vacation?  Are they all having long lunch breaks from work?  I pondered these questions as we ordered.  Anyway, it's a little pricier here, but we found it worthwhile for the nice touches - spacious and airy, quick service on sauces and water, and all dishes were steaming fresh and hot.  Some places don't offer all the sauces, and it was nice to get hot mustard for a change, as an example.  In LA, we found they charge for dim sum sauces!  In conclusion, come here if you want to have a good dim sum experience.

14.description: My Chinese boyfriend's family brought me here to eat dim sum & dinner on more than a few occasions.My dim sum favs are the Lo bak go (turnip cakes) & the Gao choi bao (green leek buns). Those two are my all time favorite at any dim sum place no bias! They prepared them just the way I like. As for dinner my most memorable dish would be Gao wong don (yellow leek w/ scrambled eggs). It's the perfect saltiness to where you can It eat it with or without rice.With that said... it's pretty sad everything else was meh. Goodluck finding parking too. During most hours it's a pain to drive in circles.

0.description: Located at the south end of Chinatown. I come here only if I'm in the area. Not a big place and aisles are tight. They don't have meat or fish. They have veggies and usually dried good stuff.More for the locals.

1.description: This is an all you can eat hot pot joint. $25 per person after tax and tip. This place is BYOB without any corkage fee. Bonus!They have a good variety of meats, seafood, vegetables and noodles. I give this place three stars mainly due to the lack of flavor of the spicy and mild soup base. This is purely a preferential thing. If you prefer milder flavors, this place is for you.If you are a newbie and need to familiarize yourself with the hot pot process, here is a very comprehensible Youtube video. youtu.be/dGZ4RfNtTMQ

9.description: This is my favorite all-you-can-eat Chinese hot pot spot because of the variety of sauces and ingredients they have to make your sauce! This place is located at the very end of the Chinatown strip on the Walgreens end.You have 2 options:$18.99 per person (basic with shrimp, clams and the usual ingredients)$29.99 per person (with lobster, crab legs, scallops and other seafood. You can only order the lobster and crab legs ONCE!)BYOB.

12.description: Have to dock a star here after a bad service experience last night. Like, bad for Chinatown standards. That's a bad sign right there.Usually I come on weekdays, but Friday night was obviously busier, so much so that we had to go to their upstairs dining room. Not a problem, a lot of Chinatown restaurants actually have that. We got up there and were seated promptly. There was a rowdy drunk group there which is something you can't really control, but someone for some reason gave them a microphone? That's just a bad idea.So as I've mentioned, here you get a dim sum style menu for ordering what you want in your pot. This time though, they seemed to always forget two or three things we marked down. My friend marked down for 5 rice servings and we got zero until we asked for it. My girlfriend marked down for noodle bundles each time we sent a menu in, AND she asked the waiter for it, and never got it.At one time, our menu had lamb checked off, and when the waiter brought our other food he said the lamb would take a few minutes. It never arrived.The last straw was at the end of the meal, when the waiter dropped off our check. We gathered our credit cards, talked to ourselves for a good 10-15 minutes, and he still didn't return. Eventually I got our check and was about to walk into the back room to find this guy when a woman from another table stood up and took our ticket - apparently it was staff dinner going on behind us. We never saw our waiter again that night.I don't know if it was because it was a Friday or because we were upstairs, but I had to knock them down a peg.

21.description: $19 all you can eat hotpot. If you pay more, you could also have seafood. (I think its $29/person, I am not sure)Really good dipping sauce comparing with other hotpot places in Chinatown.You could choose to have small pot for each person. You can also share the regular hotpot with other friends. Then you can have both spicy and regular soup for the hotpot.Good service! Fresh vegetables. but they don't serve potato for hotpot, kinda weird for me. Overall good experience.

16.description: My first time here and probably will be my last. The servers can barely speak English, therefore, they do not understand what we want to order. We kept on having to repeat ourselves. It's a buffet hot pot so it's all you can eat but the portion came out in small plates so you would have to reordering and reordering. Gratuity was added to the bill already, but we over tipped them. I asked to see the bills and wanted to talk to the manager but the manager never came out. She was hiding in the back and the servers wouldn't let us see the bill either. Not honest!

17.description: Came here with a total of 5people and they told us we have to at least get 3seafood hotpot. Why on earth can we not decide on what we want to eat? Then as I was eating, I found a STRAW WRAPPER IN the pot! I told the waitress about it, she said "oh",  then sat back down to eat with her co-worker. No intention to change the pot or apologize. This just makes me think how insanitary all of their food is

10.description: Everything was good but the beef and lamb. The meat was frozen and hard. The veggie and seafood was pretty fresh, and the quantity of each serving was good for one person to enjoy the night. I'd visited some all u can eat places where they served the dishes with only one or two pieces of the food, which really made me upset. The broth was wonderful especially the Sichuan spicy broth. If you are a spicy friendly person, u will love it.

5.description: My first visit to a hot-pot restaurant, ever.  I didn't know what to expect, but I'm familiar with the concept of hot pot (I am Asian, after all), and I do like my pots hot.  Anyways, this place is located in Chinatown, where I literally think everyone knows some kind of kung-fu (tiger or crane style), and food is a-plenty.  So what sets this place apart?  Pros:+Food is super-fresh.  I mean like really fresh.  I was really surprised by how fresh the seafood was.  +Loads of veggies.  +Spicy or regular broth options.+Make your own dipping sauce!Cons:+Spicy broth not all that spicy.  I mean, are we or aren't we Asian? Do we not write on our resumes under skills "Can shoot fireballs"?+Dipping sauce offers pepper, but that doesn't even make it spicy.  Even the Jalepenos weren't that hot.  I guess we have to cater to the noobs.I don't know how much this costs, because I didn't pay for it (Thanks Dung!).  It's pretty good, if you're a casual.  If you like it hot (I'm talking 50 shades hot), then bring your own pepper or Scirachia (I hate this word).  Overall, food is fresh and good, what else can a man ask for (besides three names)?

11.description: I love the hot pot here. You get your own little pot and there is a reasonable amount of meat and vegetable selections and the soup base is pretty good too. The only thing that I would complain about is the onions, cilantros, and hot peppers that is provided. Sometimes they are outside for too long that little bugs start to get all over it. I am pretty sure I ate a few!

22.description: This is my favorite all-you-can-eat Chinese hot pot spot because of the variety of sauces and ingredients they have to make your sauce! This place is located at the very end of the Chinatown strip on the Walgreens end.You have 2 options:$18.99 per person (basic with shrimp, clams and the usual ingredients)$29.99 per person (with lobster, crab legs, scallops and other seafood. You can only order the lobster and crab legs ONCE!)BYOB.

0.description: Love this small hotpot place!!!! You get to have your own individual pot. (There is a pot that you can share with your ppl too) Your own broth. Lots of items to choose. All for $19.99 per person. If you want to add seafood, you can for $32.99 per person.Ohhhhh! There is also lunch special until 4 pm - 7 items hotpot for $9.99. Bad side: language barrier. it's really hard to communicate with the waiters/servers or unless you can speak Chinese. Thank god my roommate came with me or else I'll be an unhappy customer.

20.description: This is like 3.5...We were in the mood for hotpot so we figured we would try this place out. My first impression when I walked in here were the floors were dangerously slippery. I think this place needs a vent because with all the hot pots there is a lot of condensation and then the tile floors get all slick. I was like tiptoeing to the sauce station so I woulnd't biff it. So yeah atmosphere/floors/cleanliness aren't the best but teh food was fine.The best thing this place has is a good variety of sauces. We went for the normal 18.99 hot pot. Fish filet is included in this price, but even though we asked for like 4 orders of fish, they only gave a small serving. They were much more generous with the meat, but pretty stingy with the squid and fish. Anyways, this place is fine. Not my favorite but it's good enough. I did really enjoy the taro, lotus root, and wooden ear. I think I'd prefer to go to sweet station and get my sweet soup at the end though.

19.description: The meat and vegetables were fresh (for the most part) but be super cautious when ordering their seafood. My girlfriend ate it and the next morning was in so much pain. Her stomach was upset from the sub par fish. Service was decent as well, but just be careful with what you order.

2.description: If I can give this place ZERO STAR, I would! This place got extremely poor service and I literally had to RISK MY LIFE eating at this place tonight!!! Came to this hotpot place because I have heard that they have added a lot of stuff on their regular hotpot menu which includes 2 free side orders of seafood. Both my husband and I ordered the Alaskan crab legs and dungeness crab and those orders never came. We had to constantly remind them "the seafood is still not here" and after the 3rd try asking them, they told us they were out of dungeness crab and gave us the small blue crab which we didn't want and told them we wanted to exchange it to Alaskan crab legs, which those never came! Also a couple of things I ordered from the regular menu never came either, no matter how many times I have asked for them.So the "best" part was this, half way through the dinner, the lady at one of the hotpot tables screamed because the outlet to the electric tabletop burner made some huge popping noise and was shooting out flares!!! The lady who was sitting there almost got electrocuted and everybody got up and almost had to run out of the door! After that they turned off all the burners at that table and moved the people over to another table. And you would think it's common sense NOT to place anyone at that table again right? Well a waiter decided to put people there again...ooookkkk bad idea! Terrible experience, whatever we requested as simple as ice-water, it never came, so hotpoting with no water throughout the entire dinner (I guess you need to BYOW), waitress never added soup to our pot, so at the end it was all dried up. Never going back there again, even if someone pays me!

18.description: This is like 3.5...We were in the mood for hotpot so we figured we would try this place out. My first impression when I walked in here were the floors were dangerously slippery. I think this place needs a vent because with all the hot pots there is a lot of condensation and then the tile floors get all slick. I was like tiptoeing to the sauce station so I woulnd't biff it. So yeah atmosphere/floors/cleanliness aren't the best but teh food was fine.The best thing this place has is a good variety of sauces. We went for the normal 18.99 hot pot. Fish filet is included in this price, but even though we asked for like 4 orders of fish, they only gave a small serving. They were much more generous with the meat, but pretty stingy with the squid and fish. Anyways, this place is fine. Not my favorite but it's good enough. I did really enjoy the taro, lotus root, and wooden ear. I think I'd prefer to go to sweet station and get my sweet soup at the end though.

13.description: $19 all you can eat hotpot. If you pay more, you could also have seafood. (I think its $29/person, I am not sure)Really good dipping sauce comparing with other hotpot places in Chinatown.You could choose to have small pot for each person. You can also share the regular hotpot with other friends. Then you can have both spicy and regular soup for the hotpot.Good service! Fresh vegetables. but they don't serve potato for hotpot, kinda weird for me. Overall good experience.

4.description: Great experience with awesome company.  There are many meat and vegetables to choose from according to your taste.  Wait staff provided terrific service.  I highly recommend if you never had hot pot.

6.description: This is slowly becoming one of my favorite AYCE hot pot places in CT. They have a decent selection for the $19 AYCE, or you could pay $10 more for the premium stuff like lobsters, crabs etc. I normally go with the $19 one because I am not a huge fan of the premium items when it comes to hot pot. They also have a sauce station where you can stir up your own sauces. Anyway, you really can't go wrong at this hot pot place. The only thing is the service here isn't all that great.

15.description: It was just another typical cold day in December in Chicago area, so the most logical thought would be to hit up a hotpot place to warm up our souls. My brother and I decided to an all-you-can eat place in Chinatown with relatively reasonable price. No lie, I walked in and I literally thought I was in an ice arena for ice skating. No, it was not cold at all. But the floor was slippery beyond belief! It amazes how those servers can carry those soup and food items without having any sort of accidents. The chef is rather generous, I have to say. We came in with seafood in mind, but only to find that no matter how many orders of seafood you place, they almost always give you the same amount. However, if you order like one order of any sort of meat, they would give you two or three orders at once. Provided that maybe because we came close to closing time, but that mere fact alone was rather satisfying. The soup was nothing outstanding, but by all means, it wasn't bad at all either! It definitely gets the job done, though personally I am not a big fan of the spicy soup base (whatever you spell it with English Alphabet).

7.description: Came across this place last night for some AYCE hot pot since it was a chilly outside and needed a little pick me up. The place does not look like much, looks like it has been through some rough stuff on the inside but its all about the food right?We had ordered chinese herb and spicy soup as our soup base for the $19 AYCE hot pot and i can say I definitely got my monies worth. The assortment of meat is limited but a lot of it makes up for it.Overall, the food was alright and had a fairly large assortment of different items to choose from besides the meatTIP: If you plan on doing something after that involves social contact DON't!! Go shower and change after because you are gonna smell funky. The fumes and steam from the boiling pots pretty much fill up the place

8.description: Another hot pot addition to Chinatown Square. How does this one stand out from all the other places? Quite a few things...First off, Premium Seafood charges $18.99 per person for the basic option and it includes the general items such as fatty beef, lamb, fish balls, beef balls, tofu, vegetable, noodles, fish filet, spam, shrimp, taro, mushrooms, sausages, etc. Why is it more than the average Chinatown price of $16.99? There are two items that are not usually included at other hot pot places, mussels and clams.  In addition, if you were in the mood for more seafood, you can choose the $29.99 selection which includes lobster and crab legs. But I believe you may only order each item once per person. We went with the standard option and ordered the divided pot with the spicy and non-spicy broth. The spicy broth was ideal by color but completely off in flavors. It was not even mildly spicy. Mind you, I am Cantonese and it is not in my genes to have a high tolerance. If I find it too mild, imagine what the northern Chinese would think. We were given a one-time use, pictured menu to circle our items. I certainly like the concept, but they did not give us a new menu each time we ordered a new round. Many items were forgotten. Most of the times, we would just tell them what we wanted instead of marking the menu. The serving portions per plate are very small and we constantly had to keep ordering. It will not be a problem as long as you do not find it a hassle. Some complaints with the items would be the lamb was too tough and the clams were puny. Service was not the best or worse. I think some coordination could be done. Barely half of the party had arrived and they kept bombarding us with repetitive questions such as, "What broth would you like? Seafood or standard?" Please slow down and allow us a minute to settle and to take a quick glimpse at the menu. Also, please show us a receipt and not just give us an amount to pay. With beverages, tip, and tax included, nine of us paid $27 each. Overall, there is a lot of improvement to be made especially if they are specializing in one item.

3.description: So much shade being thrown at this place! This is certainly an underrated joint that I think more people need to check out, you just can't expect fancy ass dining because it's Hot Pot!Chinese hot pot consists of a boiling pot of broth situated in front of you, with tons of fresh vegetables, sliced meat, and frozen dumplings for you to enjoy. My friends and I came here for the $19.99 ($22 with tax) AYCE option, which has plenty of meat option and even some seafood (fish filet, mussels, and clams). You order off an illustrated menu so it's easy to pick and choose.Afterwards, go and pick your dipping sauces!! They have a wide variety to choose from. I highly recommend the sesame or peanut sauce with cilantro, or a soy-vinegar with chili concoction. Once you have that, start dropping your food into the hot pot! It'll cook relatively quick, so be on alert to grab anything that's finished.Some good stuff:- Meat was pretty fresh and came out fast. The fatty lamb was my favorite for sure.- Broth was refilled constantly by the service- Tons of utensils to help you grab your food, especially for those that prefer not to share hidden germsThe service here was great for a Chinese restaurant. Yes, it's no Michelin-starred joint, so I don't think it's fair to expect high end up cuisine with the price you pay. There are workers here that speak conversational English, so it's a matter of patience when ordering. If you need anything,  ask and go for it. We were eating for nearly three hours and they didn't mind. I'm sure they were impressed (and a bit upset) that we could put it all away!Remember, this is no sukiyaki or sundubu, so I would not recommend attempting to drink the broth unless you really feelin' thirsty-But that's why there's BYOB! It shouldn't be a shocker since it's Chicago, but definitely drop by the local liquor store to get a bottle or two to enjoy your meal. Beer works well with hot pot!Finally, the BATHROOM was bomb. Seriously! I wish it was "public" just so I could use it every time I'm in Chinatown. Seriously. Legit.

14.description: This place isn't that big of a location. Biggest table can seat up to 7 people. But this location does have a great all you can eat hot pot.For $18.99 you get most of the basic hot pot food such as fatty beef, beef tripe, water chrestnut, clams, fish fillet, beef balls, etc. For $29.00 you can even grt crab, lobster, and crab legs. But for the $18.99 alone is worth it. Get a small bowl to yourself to do the hot pot and all real give you the experience of a hot pot on a cold day.

1.description: This place is probably great if you're Asian. I was the only white person here and I felt really out of place and almost as if the bartender were thinking "What are YOU doing here?"The karaoke selection is interesting in that it has Asian and Western choices, but you can tell the "Western" choices were probably translated by someone whose English wasn't that great, as the words are often inaccurate. Though it's interesting to see videos in the background and not just scrolling words.They've got private karaoke rooms that I didn't experience, I simply participated in the main room with a couple of nice Asian ladies. Though the main room was otherwise unoccupied and a little depressing.The atmosphere would be comfortable - leather chairs, dim lighting, modern-looking bar - if not for this strange aspect I can't quite put my finger on. It could be the neighborhood and the building it's in...makes me feel like I'm in the beginning of an episode of CSI or something, like a sinister crime is about to take place.The thing I was most disappointed in was the fact that a non-alcoholic Shirley Temple (sprite & grenadine) cost me something like $4...which is absolutely crazy.

9.description: November 17I have been here many times and even had my birthday party here.  It's great with a lot of Asian choices.  A lot if modern music hits are available as well.People are definitely fun here and having to see older version of familiar faces from the time I was away is really a surprise for me.Enjoy!

23.description: This place is way over prize ! 100-150 buck min ?omg u thinking u in Asian ,and the severce just meh .... The drink is ok , but $130 for a Jose is just a little higher , and they have food ! $8 for a bowl of sin Raman ! Sigh hopefully they gonna change to more afforable !

25.description: UPDATE:  I went again tonight with friends, excited to be singing at my close-to-home karaoke bar, and what do I find?? They've changed their policy and now the room karaoke has a $100 MINIMUM!  Yes, they have a minimum of  $100 (M-T, Sun) and $150 (Fri and Sat)! I have never heard of a Karaoke place imposing a minimum of essentially 4 hours of singing (rate is still $25/hour).  Also, it's not like the minimum is an overall tab minimum, so including whatever you order, drinks, etc.  The minimum is JUST the singing.  I was so put off by this as my friends and I love just popping in and singing for an hour or two.  (By the way tonight is a Sunday night and the entire place was empty, yet, there was still a minimum?)  I was appalled and I will certainly not come back again unless I am with a large group and I know that we will stay that long anyway.  Ridiculous!In response to the other reviewer: According to the gentleman who worked there, the $100 Minimum applies to JUST the singing and not the overall tab.  We were sure to ask that.

12.description: I've been coming on and off for years, rarely to sing, but mostly just to stop  by for a drink or 2. So yesterday I stop in for my last 3-4 drink for the night with 2 friends(who are by the way done drinking and just tagging along so I can drink some more). Why am I just finding out that there is a $15 drink minimum per person? And Also who has a drink minimum at a bar. So I pay for my 1 drink that I already ordered and left. Next time I want a drink I'll take the extra 3 minute drink to Sakura.

21.description: Whelp,  given the fact we were the only white kids, and our song selection was Melissa Ethridge ... everybody was super cool!  The only bum part was that everything was (I think in Chinese), which I really didn't think about when I convinced everyone to go there, thinking it was a good drunk idea.  Good times nonetheless!

16.description: It is my third time having Chinese style Karaoke in the States but it is my first time to be here.The location...is really bad if you don't have a car. You have to take red line and then bus and then a 10 mins walk. I don't know how they can still survive in such a bad location...Indoor...not fancy, not elite, but I won't say it is not good. They have individual rooms and open bar area. The quality of the microphone was not very good. I'm not a professional singer and I don't do karaoke often but most my friends don't like their microphone and sound system.

17.description: If you ever fell in love with "Lost in Translation" then Zero is a necessity. I can't speak to their policies regarding private rooms, but the main space is sleek, modern, and enormous. Giant windows overlook the street, there's plenty of seating, and drink prices are absurdly low. It's a great place to just hang out even if you don't want to sing, but I'd certainly take a group of friends there and rent out a room for an evening. For whatever reason, this place captures a certain sense of romance that's often lacking in hip/trendy clubs. The crowd is young and cool, the bartenders are very nice, and even if you go alone you'll honestly have a good time just being in the moment.

10.description: I like this place. It's pretty chill. I would prefer to only come there when it's not busy though. It's only my preference because I like how it could feel like you just invited all your friends to your living room. They don't mind if you bring in food either. They shouldn't mind though... because their menu is very limited. One more thing... why were they playing a few chinese songs for us to sing to??? None of us were Chinese. I know it's Chinatown but you gotta cater to the guests.

5.description: My friend bought a groupon, which seemed like a good deal, we were all excited to go karaoke and get some tunes out of our chest. We went in and were greeted by a man, who was very nice, and we told him about the groupon and he pointed at where we could sit and took our drink order. Everything was fine until we decided to go put some music (english). Half way through the song this very rude girl ( who seemed to be friends with the man who greeted us) got up and would change our song, she would not let us finish. And I understand this is a mostly asian karaoke bar and maybe American music is not their thing, but we did pay to go there its not like we went there for free and taking turns to play songs would of have been the adult thing to do. The same man who greeted us and his group of friends said something to us when we would put on a song. We finally gave up on singing anything when the girl and two other guys decided to erase our playlist...Its shame because this place has potential but who wants to go to a place that makes you feel uncomfortable because you do not play their type of music? Everyone, please save your money, and DO NOT buy their groupon, it is the most unwelcoming place. You would think they would be happy to get business especially on a saturday night where the only group of people there, were the managers friends. Don't like writing bad yelp reviews but this one had to be done.

11.description: Confusing charges. When you book a room there is a minimum, if you do not use it when you come back you have credit for your minimum but still a 15 dollars additional minimum. They do not explain and they surprised you with the bill. Will not be back at all.

22.description: 4.5 stars.  only reason i didn't give 5 stars was cuz the english song selection is not as extensive as i'd like.  otherwise i love this place.  will definitely come back.  the rooms are really nice, the drinks are great and who doesn't love singing your heart out with a bunch of friends?as for the price, if you break it down, it really is a deal.  our group of 7 was in a $150 room for 4 hours.  and the $150 INCLUDES food and drink up to $150 worth.  that's $21 per person for at least 2 drinks AND 4 hours worth of singing.  if you don't drink the wings are awesome.  2 cocktails alone are gonna be $20 in chicago so that's already a steal cuz the singing is basically free.  if  you sing longer or bring more ppl, it's even cheaper!where else can u get a really nice, new, private karaoke room in chicago?  you could go to k town, but that's a far drive, the drinks aren't included, the rooms are the same as 10 years ago and the greasy song books are nasty.  zero degrees is definitely the new place for karaoke!

0.description: I called 2 or 3 other karaoke places on Saturday night and found out they were all booked. This was the first place we could find with availability. We were pleasantly surprised by the entire experience. The English song selection was large and up-to-date, the prices were fair, the room was clean, and the service was good. The staff checked in often and addressed our requests. If I lived in the area, I would definitely come back.

20.description: This place was POPPIN' when a friend brought me here late on a Thursday night. It wasn't really my crowd because I'm an ABC and I kinda stood out, but I still had a good time here! Especially after my friends kept feeding me Johnnie Walker...Black Label, then Green Label, then Blue Label, and Black Label again! Eeeeks! I made friends with the bartenders lol. I was impressed by their pretty extensive and updated English song collection, given that this place is right next to Chinatown.Will definitely be back!

19.description: Whelp,  given the fact we were the only white kids, and our song selection was Melissa Ethridge ... everybody was super cool!  The only bum part was that everything was (I think in Chinese), which I really didn't think about when I convinced everyone to go there, thinking it was a good drunk idea.  Good times nonetheless!

2.description: On January 3rd, my friends and I stopped in to sing a few cool tunes, totally on a whim and on my suggestion.
