1.description: Stopped here because waits at dim sum places were too long.   Atmosphere is Chinese divey.   Food was passable.  Service was extremely slow.  Not a joint that specializes in one thing, but has just about anything you can think of on the menu (bowl of noodles, dumplings, sushi....)  With all the other options close, would probably pass on this joint.Note:  They do validate parking for the Chinatown parking lot.

55.description: First experience with chicken soup dumplings and I loved them. The pork, shrimp, and chive dumplings were great also. I'll be coming back here for stacks of dumplings shortly!

9.description: This place has been opened for quite some time now and I'm ashamed that I never gave it a try.  I had friends that said it as good but forty whatever reason,  I was not interested.  Today,  my husband and I decided to give it a try since I was craving soup dumplings and it's supposed to be really good here.  And yes they are. Lots of soup inside and the skin was nice and thin.   I loved it.  Delicious. The handmade noodles were good and fresh.  The squid app we ordered were huge and it was good too. Nicely grilled and great texture. The shrimp, pork and chive dumplings were very flavorful. The handmade pan fried bread was really crunchy but a bit too much oil. But overall,  I loved everything we ordered.I definitely recommend this placeBetter than Din Tai Fung in my opinion.

26.description: This is my first time feeling like leaving comment on a restaurant. I tried this restaurant many times. The food was ok (compared with so called Chinese food restaurant in China town), but the customer service was very disappointing. I ordered two Super Bowl House Special Beef Pho and left a special request (add exact noodles) from their website. The food was delivered after 45 mins. There was only one serving to be found in the bag and no exact noodle. They finally were able to answer my call after 11 attempts. An old lady answered, and I told her what the problem was. She put me on hold, and I could hear she was yelling to her workmates and questioning them. Finally, she got back to me and said they will delivery another order. I asked how long it would take.  She said 25 mins.  I reminded her this was their mistake.  She just replied it took time to prepare the food.  That's it?! There were no apology.

25.description: Great fresh food, with lots of vegetarian options!I was brought here by the fresh noodles and now I have to come back because of the amazing vegetarian selection for such an affordable price!The people were friendly and service was great.

12.description: Came here with my team during lunch during the weekday. Arrived around 1pm and they weren't extremely packed. Food: I ordered the beef cubes in black pepper sauce entree, shrimp fried rice, spicy tuna roll and miso soup. The beef cubes are PHENOMENAL...and this is no exaggeration. Extremely tender, great flavor, and you can definitely taste the pepper throughout every bite, this dish is not extremely sweet which I love about it. This will consistently be my go-to entree any time I come here. The shrimp fried rice was really good as well, decent size shrimp and they weren't stingy on the amount of shrimp they give you. The sushi roll I had was standard, no complaints there. I did not like the miso soup which was a dissapointment b/c I love miso soup. Overall my dish was great.Service:The service was great at first, but then it seemed like we never had a consistent waiter/waitress. Luckily we were able to ask anyone for whatever we needed, but it would have been nice to have one individual who would check on us. But hey that's the only reason I knocked them down 1 star. Overall, I would recommend coming here to eat for lunch!

59.description: The food from Hing Kee is average (not bad, not good), but we ordered for delivery and it took nearly two hours to reach our home. Do NOT order delivery unless you live very close to Chinatown.

21.description: My friends and I loved it here! Compared to the other restaurants in Chinatown, the prices are pretty cheap. I got the Tropical Roll and the pork pot stickers and they were both delicious. My sister got the chicken soup dumplings and my friend got the beef brisket noodles. There were a lot of options with pictures included (which I like because I dont always know what the entree will look like).

17.description: Best on menu : Soup dumplings Like everyone mentioned, an average place but the soups and dumplings makes this place a must try! The sesame chicken was way too sweet for our taste buds and the mushroom noodles missed mushrooms!! Poor service, in fact we were seated on a dirty table. Real hygiene issues. Hoping this improves cuz their dumplings are the best in town!

10.description: I always come here for the hand made noodle soup and soup dumplings. I thought the restaurant downstairs in the Richland building had the best soup dumplings but I was wrong. Hing Kee has the best. Hands down. Highly recommend.

5.description: Big fan. Simple, fast and delicious. The place is slightly disorderly, but who cares when the dumplings are so good. After awkwardly standing for a couple of minutes we were sat down in a little corner where we could people watch. Friend and I got 15 chicken dumplings and teas. The waitress was not particularly friend, but as we were not here for pleasantries, I can't complain much.

3.description: What a perfect little place. The food was authentic, delicious and fast. From you chair you can watch handmade soup dumplings being made . They have a bar where fresh juices and Thai iced teas are made. They also have sushi. Which looked amazing. We had the pork belly, egg tofu and pork soup dumplings, all I would order again. Had a great time but they had to carry us out we were so fullllll

35.description: I've eaten at Hing Kee plenty of times and the food isn't too bad. This time I ordered delivery and it took over 40 minutes for my food to get here. I actually tried their pho for the first time and I can honestly say please leave it to the Vietnamese for the pho ( no offense) the broth didn't taste right and the noodles were soggy. Also they did not give me any Hoison sauce. I also ordered sushi and they did not give me any soy sauce for it and I always eat my sushi with soy sauce so I guess I will be throwing them away. Other than that everything's alright.

19.description: This is one of our favorite beef noodle soup places. They used to have a chef who can shave the authentic Shan Xi style knife shave noodles, but he left.  They still offer hand pulled noodles which is still awesome.  Xiao Long Bao is also authentic and I think is the best around Chicago, with very thin skin and juicy filling (needs to skilled when picking up the steamed bun) They do offer an extensive menu from sushi to pho, just to compete to Joy Yee across from them, but that's just icing on the cake.

28.description: Best on menu : Soup dumplings Like everyone mentioned, an average place but the soups and dumplings makes this place a must try! The sesame chicken was way too sweet for our taste buds and the mushroom noodles missed mushrooms!! Poor service, in fact we were seated on a dirty table. Real hygiene issues. Hoping this improves cuz their dumplings are the best in town!

45.description: Food was yummy. But not enough to give it 5 stars. So 4 stars. Rude service, subtract a star. Unsanitary conditions for a restaurant (chipped plates and spoons. Dirty plate when we arrived. Dirty floor and table) subtract two stars. Chipped plates and utensils are a gigantic NO NO. They have been proven to harbor viruses and bacteria. I will not be returning.

33.description: My boyfriend and I tried this place for the first time today and the experience wasn't great. We ordered: Vietnamese spring rolls 8pieces, sizzling beef, salt and pepper calamari, and sticky fried rice with Chinese Sausage. First of all, the sizzling beef was not sizzling and it was super sweet for our taste bud. The salt and pepper calamari (squid) was very salty and too greasy. The sticky fried rice with Chinese Sausage was very blend; there wasn't any flavor. We need soy sauce and hot sauce. The spring rolls was the only food that was good. The service was pretty terrible. My boyfriend wanted more water and our waitress didn't even bother to come by our table to ask if everything was good or bother to give us more water. She was quick on getting our check and our change. We will not be returning.

43.description: Found this little gem today. I met a friend in Chinatown to get dumplings (I LOVE dumplings!) place 1- smelled funnyPlace2- no good non-pork or Seafood options.Then we happened upon Hing Kee. They have dumplings, yes  it's clean & lucky for us not too packed. let's goWe got a table right by dumpling lady. So we got to see them being made fresh. Awesome !Great selection of dumplings & other traditional fare plus a nice Sushi selection.We got the gyoza & edamame, chicken & cabbage dumplings & eel sushi roll & giant smoothies. So freakin good!! Dumplings were tender & flavorful. Smoothies ( hard to mess up) good. My friend "ate the hell outta the eel"The staff was friendly & attentive.Definitely a place we will return. I would like to keep this place secret(ish) so u can get a table anytime, no lines like Joy Yee please.

2.description: Came in for a good breakfast of xiao long bao and noodle soup. Good price and pretty good food. The noodles weren't great though. Willing to come back again for breakfast as there was no wait and I want to try some of the other noodles they have

18.description: Came here late night during the week the place was empty. We ordered the fried rice and mango chicken came out before anything else the service was horrible the lady kept forgetting things and wouldn't even check up for refills on drinks. The food was good but with bad service it didn't help the situation out. It's probably better to order take out instead of dinning inside.

41.description: The food was good but The service was a toss up. The wait staff was a bit short in replays and since we didn't really have a designated waitress we just had to see whose attention we got. It was Russian roulette depending on who got to our table. I will say that this, the scallion pancakes are a must! The spring rolls were ok but I would have rather tried something else. The dumplings where good but I was hoping for mind blowing dumplings since I was in Chinatown.

52.description: I come to this place often with my husband, it's very good, the service is great. We usually get the noodle soups my favorite one is the fatty beef one and my husband like the oxtail soup. For entrees we get the combination fried rice, beef and broccoli and orange chicken. The sushi there is good and their dumplings as well, the only thing that I don't like is when the ladies making the dumplings in the front, eat in front of everyone! Other than that this place is great.

50.description: My family has been coming to Chinatown for 30+ years and we usually stick to a a handful of restaurants in our rotation. Mostly in "Old Chinatown" south of Cermak and mostly Cantonese-style restaurants. Hing Kee has recently been a new addition to our rotation due mostly to having Xioa Long Bao aka Soup Dumplings on their menu. XLB is a Chinese/Taiwanese soup dumpling that contains warm soup broth with minced meat inside. I like that they serve it the traditional way with fresh sliced ginger and a vinegar/soy dipping sauce. Bonus points. I've had XLB served without the ginger and sauce and trust me, the sharp ginger and acidity from the black vinegar helps cut through the rich fatty pork broth inside for a nicely balanced bite. They also have sushi and Vietnamese cuisine on the menu but we come for one thing: Xiao Long Bao Soup Dumplings.

4.description: Service was really bad. The majority of the table got their food at the same time except one friend who had to wait about 20 mins more. Then when she got her dish she had to ask for and then wait further for rice which came with the dish. Food was pretty mediocre. Would not go back there again.

6.description: My go-to in Chinatown for soup dumplings. Although on my most recent visit, the skin was soggy and almost all of them stuck to the bottom of the steamer, so none of the lovely meat juice made it into my mouth :(Their noodles are good too, but no matter what you order, the soup it comes with is from the same pot and very salty. Another favorite is the pork flapjack rolls. We order this on every visit and it's always crispy & flavorful. Strayed from the wheat-heavy menu once and got the stir-fried rice noodles, which was a big mistake as it was greasy & tasteless. We've learned our lesson and been happy ever since.

22.description: 1. Food ok.2. Service Bad3. Manager the worst!12/11/15 8pmCame with my mother, wanna get quick food b/c of starving. Ordered 2 bowls of noodles and a side dish. The side dish came in 3 mins and my bowls of noodle at 5 mins. and......no more...waited for more than 20 mins, I asked the waitress and response was "wait". When I saw those guys came later than us, they almost finished their meal, so I walked straight back to talk to the manager, he was cold and told me to wait. I went back to my place but I saw the cook just rush out with a noodle to put in the pot (the pot for cooking the noodle where is in the front of the store, behind the window). I was so pissed b/c they completely forgot the food I ordered for my mother.I did not want to wait another 5 mins (total ~~30 mins). I did not say any word. I went straight out to cool down, but the waiter chased me out and asked me to pay, so rude, I demanded to talk to the manager again, he came out the 1st sentence is ask me to pay, just ignored what just happened in his restaurant, without any apology. I was even pissed, and wanted to leave, he then called 911 and asked me to stay. The manager even pushed my shoulder to stop me walking?! WTF! He yelled that I could not go anywhere without paying. OMFG, is it about the money, $20?! No sense of doing business, no care about the your consumer?! Well, so I called 911 also and waited , the polices came, and he even lied to the polices. Well, well, well......... polices asked me to pay for it, fine, paid! Who is really happy now? .............

15.description: Let me first say that I was born in Chicago and I grew up around the Chinatown area. I have ate at almost every restaurant multiple times. When I first went to Hing Kee, I thought it was the best place at the moment. Decent prices, decent food. Now in my most recent visit, I received the WORST customer service in any restaurant that I have been. I went there on a Saturday afternoon with my family as a belated birthday lunch for my uncle. I ordered a plate of sushi and it was decent. My uncle and grandfather both ordered shrimp wonton noodles. When I was done with my sushi plate, their food still has not arrived, and it has been 30 minutes. The other table came after us got their food. What did the other table order? Shrimp wonton noodles. So I asked the waitress. They said that they forgot to put in the order. That's fine. People make mistakes. So we had to wait another 30 minutes to receive our first bowl of shrimp wonton noodles. Guess what? THE SHRIMP WONTON IS RAW! Unbelievable. So they took it back and 20 minutes later came back with another bowl of shrimp wonton noodles. Guess what? IT WAS ALSO RAW! I cannot believe it! They were serving us raw food. Words can NOT explain how embarrassed I was taking my grandfather and uncle out to this restaurant. So what now? We decided to just change our order to beef noodle soup. Everyone else finished eating except my grandfather and uncle. So after another 15 minutes, they came back with 1 bowl. We waited another 20 minutes and the other bowl has not arrived yet. So we asked the waitress. They forgot it again! Unbelievable.. I never experienced such horrible customer service. The only thing quick they done was give us the check. I definitely will NOT be coming back here or recommending anyone.

57.description: Everything I have had here has been good. Favorites are xiao long bao (easily the best I have had in the city), Shanghai style noodles, and spring rolls. Service is always fine. Family style seating. A Chinatown favorite for sure.

20.description: Terrible service.  Wait staff is rude.  Food was mediocre.

36.description: I came here for the all you can eat hotpot last Saturday with five other people. Before I start I must say that I was very impressed with their service. Originally they had us seated at a normal sized circular table but then brought out a larger table for us because we were having hotpot. The original table would have been fine but it was certainly a nice gesture by them.The food itself was very good as well. I was skeptical at first about the variety of food that they would serve but it was a good mix of vegetables, meat, and seafood. Also, the owner/staff were very accommodating with what we wanted refilled. This is definitely a place that I will return to. After spending the summer in Taiwan and eating a ton of hot pot I'm happy to say that I found a hotpot restaurant that does it just as well if not better than the ones in Taiwan.

14.description: I was brought here by a friend who is from the Chicago area. This is one of his family's favorite restaurant and they visit it once a week. Don't be deceived by its run down appearance. We ordered soup dumpling, which is their specialty, oxtail noodle soup, and mapo tofu. The  pork soup dumplings was served first with a black vinegar and ginger. The dough was a little heavy on top of dumpling but the I love the natural  sweetness of pork. The oxtail noodle soup was delicious as well. The noodles were chewy and the meat on oxtail pieces was falling off the bone. I wish the oxtails were cooked longer in the soup since the broth can be a little more umami. I didn't care much for the napa cabbage in the soup since it was bland. I usually do not get mapo tofu when I eat out, but I was pleasantly surprised by this dish at this restaurant. The tofu was so silky and smooth that I could not even pick it up with my chopsticks. The sauce was really flavorful and went really well with white rice.

3.description: Only tried a strawberry smoothie with tapioca. I liked that it wasn't too sweet, but the flavor was a bit faint. Tapioca were nice and soft. Also, for the price, they are a bit smaller in size than other places.Will have to try something else out and I'll update from there.

1.description: Came here for a great Milk tea.  Didn't have any of the bitter taste from the tea being brewed too long.  and at $2.25 plus tax it was a good deal.

2.description: Best milk tea! Not too sugary.  Wife had the strawberry. Also very good. They use real fruits

5.description: On a recent chilly trip to Chinatown for some bakery buns we noticed the sign for a subterranean food court beneath an office building. Sounded quite warm and inviting so we checked it out. It was the Friday after Thanksgiving so only about half of the vendors were open (and several vacant storefronts too) so we obviously weren't hitting this spot on a high-traffic day. My wife was jonesin' for some pan-fried dumplings/potstickers and Grill-N-Chill was the only spot offering such goodness. Looked like a Mom and Son (or Grandson) operation. The wife ordered a strawberry bubble tea to round out her 'snack'. I was initially going to forego a mid-afternoon snack, but I spied an advertisement for a Spam, Fried Egg and Ramen noodle soup bowl for $3.99 with a free soda included. Too intriguing not to try. We paid and seated ourselves at a nearby table for 10-15 minutes while our food was prepared. The potstickers were lukewarm, but still pretty tasty. Served only with a couple packets of soy sauce when proper dumpling sauce would have made a huge difference in taste. The bubble tea was pretty good, but was advertised as 'fresh fruit'. We watched the guy prepare the beverage and he scooped a few strawberry pieces (in syrup?) into the mixture, but it was mostly powdered mix and tasted as such. My warm bowl of pan-fried egg and spammy goodness, however, was pretty great. If I worked in this neighborhood I think I'd often find myself here for breakfast and lunch during the cold winter months. This was simple comfort food and definitely hit the spot.So all in all a good cheap mid-afternoon meal. We'll hit Joy Yee's for our bubble teas from now on, but the tasty ramen bowl inspires me to try some of their other offerings on a future trip!

6.description: This place got awesome fruit smoothie for $3! I was shocked.  They use real fruit and the size is ginormous! If I lived in Chicago, I would definitely come here weekly!

7.description: This place is aight. The spaghetti doe, I guess you can say it's different. Not bad per-se but... well, I'm just used to a different type of spaghetti lol. Their fried chicken doe! Shit's flame! Now I'm not talking about spicy flame. Naw naw, I'm talking bout this here chicken yeah, this chicken, I don't know how they do it. It's nice and crispy on the outside andddd tender and juicy on the inside? Gahhhh damn! Don't even get me started on those scrumptious desserts that I see they'd have on display now and then. A darn shame they don't have them as often as I pass by.So I normally don't eat duck. If it's not a chicken then it's poultry I don't even want to touch. But this one day... I went to grab a quick bite to eat and wanted to check this place out again. Had those amazing wings just sticks in your head ya know what I mean? But I didn't know what exactly I was craving for. I was standing there until that one girl working the register gave me a suggestion. Their soy sauce duck. I wasn't sure about that but since she was cute and she looked like she knew the business about food, I decided to take her word for it and ordered it. Why haven't I ordered this soy sauce duck before in my entire life?!?!?!? Shit's soooo savory in the mouth. A straight mouthgasm. Yeah, I said it. A mouthgasm. In your mouth. As you're eating.So I thanked that girl at the register. Tried hollering at her too cause ya know, shawty is pretty cute. She completely ignored my hollas. Whatever then. Lmfao like that's going to stop me.

0.description: YES YES YES!!!!!!!! I cannot get enough of Chinatown. I love my city! Some of the best authentic Chinese cuisine in the country! But make sure you stop here in the shopping plaza and get this smoothies at booth B-4. She makes the most scrumptous bubble teas. Mango and Watermelon are my favorites.

4.description: I had been to Lao You Ju a few times without realizing that there is a food count underneath it! I came here for a visit on a Monday around 5:30. There were 4-5 restaurant and I decided to give a shot on Grill-N-Chill cafe. I bought chicken wings, spam and egg romen, sticky tart(which they don't sell often) and a milk-tea tapioca.First of all, the romen was exactly what I expected it, so nothing special to write about besides it tastes good. I like my chicken wings that is crispy and juicy at the same time, and I do believe they had done it. Thumbs up on that. There two items I want to emphasis are the sticky tarts and milk tea. I am not sure if I can get sticky tart anywhere else in Chinatown, but I haven't had those in YEARS! It brought back childhood memory while I was still in Hong Kong =) About the milk tea, I had been to many places in Chinatown like chi-cafe, St.Anna and a couple more places here and there, I truly do believe that Grill-N-Chill Cafe serve the best. I do need to go back a few more times to check the consistency of their milk tea, but so far they've earned five stars from me.  At the end, I do wish they have a slightly larger food selections to choose from. I look forward to try their lunch boxes in the near future, maybe tonight! Grill-N-Chill Cafe do not have printed menu, so you/I need to find their menu on Facebook. Prices are affordable. This little hidden gem deserves for everyone to check it out.

28.description: I don't know if you can get much better in terms of taste and value.As of this review, a filling bowl of wonton soup is under 5 bucks and is good enough for a meal for me.Each wonton has a good amount of shrimp and pork in them.The guy's a super nice guy who doesn't judge me for my poor Mandarin to my face.He isn't a dick if you pay with a credit card.Other people like his niu nan a lot but I think it's just ok.  If he just served wontons I wouldn't care.If you want to get super stuffed, get some extra wontons in your soup for 2 bucks more.

1.description: This place will do the deed if you are in the mood for no-frills Wonton noodle soup at a pretty affordable price point. I got the fried fish balls (yummy and not greasy!), garlic yu-choy (tasted fresh; not super garlicky), and 2 shrimp wonton noodle soups. I didn't realize this at the time of ordering and didn't think to ask, but pretty sure the shrimp wonton filling is shrimp, minced pork, and mushroom. It was delicious and fresh tasting, with more mushroom and pork flavor than shrimp but I don't regularly eat pork anymore, so it posed a slight problem for me; my fellow pollo-pescatarians and pescatarians, be aware! It is Chinatown though so I wasn't totally shocked. I believe it is a one man operation: he is really straight to the point but friendly, and so efficient! My order of 2 noodle soups, the fish balls, and yuchoy were ready in 8 minutes, and cost me under $20! Everything was hot and fresh. I will return but may pass on the shrimp wonton noodle soup due to the potential pork inclusion. Highly recommend!

9.description: I remember stumbling down into the Richland Center basement many years ago with my parents who spoke of this place like one would describe an explorer finding a treasure chest on a deserted island. While I did not share their excitement at the time, I frequented this modest, simple, and delicious noodle stand on a normal basis. There are many things I love about going downstairs to patron this spot. First off, it's incredibly quick to order (since there only a few people who dare to venture downstairs). The owner is incredibly nice (and always has special recommendations on daily specialties). The prices are really low for the amount of food that you get. Most importantly, the food is really good and arguably the most authentic HK style noodles in Chinatown. While there are a surprising amount of items on the menu, I would suggest to keep it simple. They make both the best egg noodles and flat rice noodles I've experienced in Chinatown. The egg noodles have a nice chewy consistency, while the rice noodles are smooth and silky. The broth is flavorful without being overpowering, and goes well nicely with either the wonton or beef brisket toppings. My favorite is the combo of wonton and beef brisket. I usually spend around 5-6 dollars on a bowl of noodles there, which is great for my wallet. Unfortunately, there is a very small amount of food traffic in the food court. They do deliver off of Grubhub, but the owner is a very pleasant fellow and I would suggest going down there and saying hi. Especially if you'd like to beat the busy lines happening in the other restaurants upstairs. Quick, cheap, and awesome.

29.description: Having been in multiple Chinatowns in multiple cities, this is by far the best place for won ton. Ever. I make it a point to come here whenever I'm in town. The owner is amazing - I will call ahead and ask in my broken chinese for him to make and freeze 100 wontons so I can take it home to Indianapolis. (Pack it with frozen Vienna beef franks, another Chicago favorite of mine, and it makes it the 3 hour drive with no problems!) I recently moved to San Francisco and need to figure out how to get them through the flight....they're THAT good!!!

23.description: Excellent ramen spot. Broth was great, dumplings were well made.  The crispy wontons were the best I've had. Chickens wings were juicy and had a nice kick. I'd order from here again.

5.description: My friend and I shared spicy beef noodles here (we got the wide noodles). It's a little greasy, but that's just because of the spicy oil that they use. The noodles were pretty much like Xi'an Famous pulled noodles, and the beef was tender and delicious. I think I'll have to order this same bowl again next time and maybe even try a different noodle. Maybe the egg noodles?

31.description: Simple noodle soup done right.  Ordered the brisket and dumplings soup with thin egg noodles.  Traditional broth with bok choy and green onions.  Dumplings were perfectly cooked and flavored, and not breaking apart in the soup.  The soup itself was more than enough but since this was my first time, I also ordered a small beef brisket which was a significant amount of beef in broth (way too much food for small appetites but I will suggest doing so if you are a red meat addict).  I put some extra pieces into my soup and saved the rest for later which I ate with rice and eggs.  Yummy.Disclaimer: I feel brisket in soup should have pieces of fat in it (which this place does) and I loved it.  The brisket was very tender with the smaller pieces and the thicker pieces were not chewy.  Some pieces of fat and the occasional chewy piece of cartilage were in the mix.  I grew up with that kind of stuff, but if you are not into that texture I suggest you stick with the tenderloin.  But really you are missing out on sooooo much flavor ;)So I was torn for half a minute on whether to give this restaurant 4 or 5 stars, but then I realized that I should just judge the place on its namesake: yummy yummy noodles.  I am the dork who wanted the extra chicken wings.  Not bad and the flavor was spot on, but it was a little oily and the wings were small.Note: I ordered through EAT24 and for some reason there is no white rice on the menu.  So when I ordered Brisket Only... they mean it.  No side of rice.  Luckily I always have rice in the house so I was fine with it.  Hmm... anything else.  Oh, for extra kick, the soup works well with siracha.

25.description: Delicious won-ton soup and stir-fried Chinese vegetable soup. The won tons are generously packed with shrimp and pork and well seasoned. Everything was very fresh. The prices are very reasonable and the owners are so so so sweet. If I didn't live or work so far away, I would be here weekly!

12.description: Is there even a zero star for rating? I mean, I came from Asian culture, so I know sometimes people just don't pay much attention to customer service. But, this owner took the wrong order from me and even yelled at me when I tried to explain. He kept asking me "What do you want from me?" in a really rude way. Plus, people here are smoking, regardless of the "No Smoking" sign on the wall.Will never come back again.

21.description: I remember stumbling down into the Richland Center basement many years ago with my parents who spoke of this place like one would describe an explorer finding a treasure chest on a deserted island. While I did not share their excitement at the time, I frequented this modest, simple, and delicious noodle stand on a normal basis. There are many things I love about going downstairs to patron this spot. First off, it's incredibly quick to order (since there only a few people who dare to venture downstairs). The owner is incredibly nice (and always has special recommendations on daily specialties). The prices are really low for the amount of food that you get. Most importantly, the food is really good and arguably the most authentic HK style noodles in Chinatown. While there are a surprising amount of items on the menu, I would suggest to keep it simple. They make both the best egg noodles and flat rice noodles I've experienced in Chinatown. The egg noodles have a nice chewy consistency, while the rice noodles are smooth and silky. The broth is flavorful without being overpowering, and goes well nicely with either the wonton or beef brisket toppings. My favorite is the combo of wonton and beef brisket. I usually spend around 5-6 dollars on a bowl of noodles there, which is great for my wallet. Unfortunately, there is a very small amount of food traffic in the food court. They do deliver off of Grubhub, but the owner is a very pleasant fellow and I would suggest going down there and saying hi. Especially if you'd like to beat the busy lines happening in the other restaurants upstairs. Quick, cheap, and awesome.

16.description: Delicious noodles and fried fish balls. They make their own fish balls, and you won't find that at another restaurant in Chicago chinatown. Quick friendly service all the time.

17.description: The noodles here are very delicious and it deserves the price, which is a great bargain!! I always go there for dinner with my friends. will stop by next week too.

10.description: Solid spot. Got the beef brisket noodles, and my order was ready in just a couple of minutes. Egg noodles were good and had a nice bite to it. Good amount of beef. All was good but nothing outstanding. Wished they offered chili oil, instead of sriracha, but no biggie. Was going to give 3 stars, but for $4.50, you really can't beat this value.

11.description: Imagine my excitement after reading the past string of 4 and 5 star reviews.  I was hyped up for some really Yummy Yummy Noodles!  Despite frequently dining in Chinatown, I had no idea that this place existed until it came up in Yelp search results.  The reason is because it's a stall located in the basement of the Richmond Center.I believe the owner took my order, and he was very nice.  My order was for two Wonton Noodle Soups with extra wontons to-go, and they were ready in 10 minutes.  He packed it so carefully, the containers stayed in tact even though I dropped the package.Being a frigid winter night, I couldn't wait to warm up with the food.  Upon first bite, I noticed a good amount of shrimp and pork filling.  However, both my brother and I agreed that the wontons had an unusual flavor.  I thought that maybe they simply weren't fresh, but my brother said there was almost a fermented bean curd flavor.  The light broth seemed like the standard soup base - I enjoyed that since it was clean soup/not too salty (a lot of places err on this side).  Instead of yau choi, there was cabbage instead, which I think is a cheaper substitute.  Overall, I've had better wontons at particularly any random place in Chinatown so I'm very confused by the amazing reviews for this place.

26.description: For Asian moms who love noodle soup, this is manna from heaven. The aptly named Yummy Yummy Noodles (so tasty you have to moniker it twice) makes delicious bowls of soup with delicious noodles.It's located in the "food court" on one end of the new Chinatown plaza. Walk straight down, and it looks like one of the dilapidated food courts you find in Asia where your cousins take you to get the "proper" Asian food.Two bowls of soup--one wonton, one beef noodle--costs about as much as the El fare for two on the red line to get down here. The soups are Cantonese-based. Heck of a wonton soup, and the signature "light and sweet" beef broth that's closer to pho than my preferred Taiwanese niu rou mien.I'm not quite sure when it opened, but the sparse reviews mean it's either pretty new or located in an absurdly bad spot. I'm also not quite sure how my mother-in-law and aunt stumbled upon it, but they left raving. After a visit, I can vouch for this place being one of the hidden gems in Chicago's Chinatown.

27.description: Wow! I just got a delivery from them and actually not much of food but wow! I am enjoying right now and wouldn't hesitate to do a review while i am eating. Lol, seriously, it is soooo yummy!!! Try their chicken wings (it is tiny and comes 6 wings but good) and their wonton, beef brisket soup, fishball etc so yummy! I will try their other delicious food in the future!  fast delivery too!

0.description: Food Court dive serving excellent flavor, and portion for your $$.  It's rare to find a $5 meal these days.5 NOODLE CHOICES -- thin or wide egg noodle, thin or wide rice noodle, and instant noodles.BEEF BRISKET NOODLE SOUP ($4.50) -- very good brisket and it seems to be his specialty.  Tender tendon.  Slightly salty broth that is balanced with wide noodles.  A good amount of brisket chunks.FRIED CHICKEN WINGS ($3.50) -- small wings, but good enough for the price and portion.DUMPLINGS -- housemade.  Wrapped in between orders and cooking.SERVICE -- a one man crew whose a little rough on the edges. He has a quick, what do you want attitude.  Don't take it personally, he is a busy man.  On his free time, he wraps dumplings.  :-)COMMUNICATION -- Patience is a Virtue.  You may practice your point the pic skill, then glance and nod.  LOLMENU -- limited that serves the general public.  If you don't feel like Chinese food, you have Fried Porkchop or Fried Wings.  Garlic Yu Choy with rice for vegetarians.I look forward to $7 Lamb Noodle.

20.description: Solid spot. Got the beef brisket noodles, and my order was ready in just a couple of minutes. Egg noodles were good and had a nice bite to it. Good amount of beef. All was good but nothing outstanding. Wished they offered chili oil, instead of sriracha, but no biggie. Was going to give 3 stars, but for $4.50, you really can't beat this value.

19.description: Delicious won-ton soup and stir-fried Chinese vegetable soup. The won tons are generously packed with shrimp and pork and well seasoned. Everything was very fresh. The prices are very reasonable and the owners are so so so sweet. If I didn't live or work so far away, I would be here weekly!

33.description: This hidden gem is located in the food court in Chinatown.  Huge noodle soup bowls for a great price.  Made fresh and hot and broth is yummy yummy.  I guess thats where the name came from.  Didn't see too many white people down here but the locals were eating this up so we had to try.  Very good. Worth the price for sure, I couldn't even finish it all. Lots of choices and fast service. If you happen to be visiting the Chinatown area this place is located on the far end of the newer area complex on the other side of Citibank and its downstairs. It says food court on the outside but looks like nothing is there because you have to go down the stairs and then even after that its not a very big place but if you want some good noodles this is the right place, its on the left as soon as you enter. You can get wonton soup as low as $2.99!!!

2.description: This was my first meal in Chicago! It's a cold, rainy day so I was definitely in the mood for something soupy. Menu is simple and only has a few items. The guy helping us was standoffish,  if you're not used to the Chinese fast restaurants then you'd maybe perceive it as rudeness.I got the 5 spice beef noodle soup with wide egg noodles. It was perfectly flavored with a lot of noodles and some lettuce on the bottom. It was only $7, so cheap for the amount of food you get! I'll definitely be coming by this food court for more lunch eats.

32.description: I visit Chicago 2-3 times a year for work and pleasure. I'm so glad I discovered this little gem of a place. The soup is SUPERB. My cousin can't stop raving about it after I took them for lunch. We visited several restaurants during our stay: RPM, David Burke, Carriage House and Lou Malnati's but we can't stop raving about this simple noodle place.

18.description: I don't know if you can get much better in terms of taste and value.As of this review, a filling bowl of wonton soup is under 5 bucks and is good enough for a meal for me.Each wonton has a good amount of shrimp and pork in them.The guy's a super nice guy who doesn't judge me for my poor Mandarin to my face.He isn't a dick if you pay with a credit card.Other people like his niu nan a lot but I think it's just ok.  If he just served wontons I wouldn't care.If you want to get super stuffed, get some extra wontons in your soup for 2 bucks more.

13.description: Small menu but everything is good.  The owner is nice and friendly.  I love his chow fun, best non greasy chow fun in town.  I have been here over 5 times now, food quality is very consistent.  Fast service. Therefore, I give them 5 stars.

4.description: For Asian moms who love noodle soup, this is manna from heaven. The aptly named Yummy Yummy Noodles (so tasty you have to moniker it twice) makes delicious bowls of soup with delicious noodles.It's located in the "food court" on one end of the new Chinatown plaza. Walk straight down, and it looks like one of the dilapidated food courts you find in Asia where your cousins take you to get the "proper" Asian food.Two bowls of soup--one wonton, one beef noodle--costs about as much as the El fare for two on the red line to get down here. The soups are Cantonese-based. Heck of a wonton soup, and the signature "light and sweet" beef broth that's closer to pho than my preferred Taiwanese niu rou mien.I'm not quite sure when it opened, but the sparse reviews mean it's either pretty new or located in an absurdly bad spot. I'm also not quite sure how my mother-in-law and aunt stumbled upon it, but they left raving. After a visit, I can vouch for this place being one of the hidden gems in Chicago's Chinatown.

24.description: Imagine my excitement after reading the past string of 4 and 5 star reviews.  I was hyped up for some really Yummy Yummy Noodles!  Despite frequently dining in Chinatown, I had no idea that this place existed until it came up in Yelp search results.  The reason is because it's a stall located in the basement of the Richmond Center.I believe the owner took my order, and he was very nice.  My order was for two Wonton Noodle Soups with extra wontons to-go, and they were ready in 10 minutes.  He packed it so carefully, the containers stayed in tact even though I dropped the package.Being a frigid winter night, I couldn't wait to warm up with the food.  Upon first bite, I noticed a good amount of shrimp and pork filling.  However, both my brother and I agreed that the wontons had an unusual flavor.  I thought that maybe they simply weren't fresh, but my brother said there was almost a fermented bean curd flavor.  The light broth seemed like the standard soup base - I enjoyed that since it was clean soup/not too salty (a lot of places err on this side).  Instead of yau choi, there was cabbage instead, which I think is a cheaper substitute.  Overall, I've had better wontons at particularly any random place in Chinatown so I'm very confused by the amazing reviews for this place.

6.description: Great food! Very nice people! small local family businesses is where it's at! They make everything fresh for you and make sure you like it! Can't wait to order for delivery!

22.description: It's true! Yummy yummy! I agreed with a fan of it said it's a HIDDEN GEM in chinatown. If you like noodle soup, this one definitely could satisfy you, especially the spicy beef noodle soup, if you like spicy & hot.

15.description: Great noodles at a fair price. They offer 5 varieties of noodles in various styles of soup. It's cafeteria style so nothing fancy. Nice owner who's friendly and a good cook!

7.description: The prices are reasonable. They are in the food court of the Richland building. The flavor is spot one. For a quick meal and no tip needed, it's a great place for pickup. The parking can be tough but if you have someone with you. It may be easier.Calling ahead really makes it quick. I think it's a husband & wife that run the business. They are friendly and the husband speaks enough English to understand your order.

8.description: Very healthy, delicious, and budget-friendly. It might be hard to locate, but it is in on the ground floor of a food court (at the end). But it is worth every bit of finding.I come here a couple of times a month, and I only have one recommendation:Get the beef brisket noodle soup!!!!!The flat rice noodle, combined with generous portions of beef, along with a tasty broth - a winter favorite of mine.The owner is very friendly and likes to get to know his customers.I will be coming back soon as I am busy with school at the moment.

30.description: I love this noodle place, our family is from Hong Kong, so we know our wonton / fish ball soup noodle.This place is small and in a simple food court, but the food is legit, IMO the best soup noodle in the whole Chinatown.According to the owner he make most of the ingredient, the soup, the wonton (awesome wonton), the fish ball and the pot sticker.Price as usual: Cheap, a noodle soup is under 5 bucks.The food court is very simple and there are several other small stores that has fun stuff to try.

3.description: Food court food -- while a restaurant may be considered the hidden gem of a food court, it doesn't necessarily mean that it's actually good food. This is probably the best way to describe Yummy Yummy Noodles -- it's not bad food but it really can't compare to any of the nearby restaurants that serve similar dishes. The only thing keeping this at 3-stars rather than 2-stars is the price, convenience, and that I didn't really hate the dishes although I didn't find anything particularly likeable about them.The Fried Wontons were really the best part of the meal, as they were light and crisp -- but the filling was a bland and completely indistinct. It might be pork with shrimp but it wouldn't have made a difference if it was completely absent from the dish.The Beef Brisket Chow Fun had slightly raw green onion which imparted an unpleasant bitter flavor to the dish. The beef brisket itself had a nice soft texture and the noodles had a fresh feeling to them. The dish itself also wasn't overly saucy.Shrimp Wonton Noodle Soup with Added Dumplings. The wonton noodle soup for a noodle restaurant must really shine as it's the primary dish that most people will judge a restaurant by. The noodles themselves had a nice flavor and bouncy firm texture to them, however the soup lacked any body and pleasant aroma to it. The wonton had a strong mushroom flavor to it that completely overpowered the pork and shrimp that was present. The dumplings were indistinctive, with a light pork flavor but nothing you'd remember soon after eating the meal.Beef Brisket Noodle with Added Beef Offal. The beef brisket was tender but wasn't very meaty or flavorful. The offal had the typical flavor of organs (mostly like liver) and was soft and decently prepared.Yummy Yummy noodles is quick and cheap -- but doesn't have any special or distinct dishes that would make me come back versus going to a slightly pricier restaurant nearby like Chi Cafe, Sweet Station, or Ken Kee.

14.description: whenever people asked me what my favourite chinese place is in chicago, my answer is always like "i don't really have one in chicago...none of them are that good" .but wow...i am glad i tried this place...i love their wontons and their noodles...reminded me of those i had growing up.....well...ok...these may not be the best wontons i have ever had in my life, but this is the best i had in chicago and i would go back for more! It helps that they are on grubhub!

58.description: I've been to Lao Bejing 7 or 8 times now.The food is consistently awesome.The service is cold at best (you go here because you want good food, not good service). The food usually comes out quickly (even when the place is packed).The complimentary spicy/garlicky cabbage that they serve before the meal is pretty good.The boiled Szechuan sauce (with fish) is fantastic... as are the whole fried fish (appetizer), green beans, and the chili chicken.  I have yet to order a dish that wasn't good.I love this place.

56.description: Lao Beijing is one of the let downs in Chinatown the time I went there we were taken to the 2nd floor and there was a large party of collage students. Laughing loudly and ruining are meal. The water was from a disgusting sink that has something black all over it. There was only one waitress taking everyones orders upstairs so we did not get great service.

29.description: I came here to enjoy some stereotypical Chinese food among a couple authentic dishes and had a good meal. They do the Americanized dishes well (orange chicken, fried rice, sweet and sour chicken, egg rolls, mixed vegetables). We also had a mushroom dish and some boiled pork and vegetable dumplings that were delicious. Pretty good standard fare, hope to come back to try some of the signature dishes.

42.description: The best experience in China Town I've had! After frequenting countless restaurants in China Town, this was the only establishment deemed worthy of revisiting. The mom and pop shop has a very warm, friendly vibe, that is absent from most Chinese settings. That said, don't expect a lively, congested scene. This is a quiet, more idle setting than the rest in the vicinity. The food is superb- most notably the duck! We had Mongolian beef (good), eggplant (great!), potstickers (good), crispy duck (favorite!), and the Korean cold noodles (good). The crispy duck was far from gamey, very lean, and bursted with flavor. It is served with a large bread wrap, tomatoes, sprouts, onions, etc. to make a hearty duck wrap. Very good, and the one thing I'd highly recommend here.

23.description: One of the few Beijing style restaurants in Chinatown! My family and I came here   because they we're missing some traditional Beijing cuisine. We ordered the sweet and sour fish and Peking Duck. Both were amazing. The Peking duck takes a while but comes as 3 courses with the crispy duck, a duck soup, and duck and onion dish. Only sad part was that they ran out of You Tiao, which we were craving. Definitely not as good as the crispy duck in China, but it's close.

47.description: Food has gone downhill. Service is horrible! My family and I have gone to Lao Beijin quite often the past couple of years, and the food has gone from reliably good to awful. We ordered the crispy duck and it was too dry, the Pekin style mushu pork, which came without pork and was tasteless. We sent it back and I can only guess that the chef threw the remainer of our food back in the pan, added pork and way too much salt, since the dish came back lacking ingredients and was too salty. Our potstickers came without sauce and to top it all off, the manager on duty took my plate (with food in it) while I took my daughter to the bathroom. All the waiters seemed rushed and they, as well as the chef and manager were making too many mistakes. Good riddance Lao Beijin. We will NOT be going back.

8.description: Had the hotpot buffet here which was delicious! Basically you get to order as many vegetables, meats, sauces, appetizers, and drinks you want for the table and each person pays $17 (on weekdays). To be honest, don't know how necessary that is since I'm usually full from normal non-buffet hotpot. Nonetheless, I was absolutely STUFFED by the end of my meal here and basically didn't need to eat the rest of the day. Recommended for those with large bellies to fill!

31.description: Been here twice now and really happy with it.  Chinatown is sometimes hit or  miss, but this place is reliable.  Unlimited hot tea and reasonable prices.  Two of us ate here for about $36 minus tip.  First time we had the duck pancakes and it was amazing.  Second time one of the highlights was the Northern pancake.  Tastes the way crepes should taste.  And then we got more duck.  Noticing a theme in our visits.  We got dumplings too but probably won't be doing that again.  Would come back anytime or order take out.

34.description: I came here for lunch with my friend and was pleasantly surprised by the food. I did not have high hopes for this restaurant after eating at that "other" szechuan place in Chinatown. Even though this restaurant has the same owner as Lao Sze Chuan, they do not charge for rice, and the dishes are more appropriately priced. I really dislike when Chinese places charge for rice, because the majority of Chinese food is impossible to eat without rice. My friend and I ordered the Napa Cabbage with fried shrimp dish, the twice cooked spicy pork, and the spicy pig ears.  We asked for extra of the hot pepper oil fried napa cabbage appetizer that it came with.  The twice cooked spicy fatty pork was my absolute favorite dish. Prices are reasonable, and we had enough food for 3 people. I will definitely be adding this into my restaurant rotation.

16.description: That lamb with cumin... Oh man is that a dry, spicy, and amazingly unique flavored dish

13.description: Poor service. I've been there for 20 mins haven't serve water. They don't have enough condiments to serve for each table. I don't have other choice but to leave the place.

11.description: Just had a shortened version of the Peking Duck experience - skin, meat, pancakes.  We all enjoyed it tremendously.  The technique of getting rid of the fat is amazing.  The skin was golden brown, shiny and crisp as expected.  The meat was tender and flavorful.  I cook a lot with duck and enjoy this protein so much I didn't want to put Hoisin on it nor roll it in the pancake.  Something this good can just stand on its own.

39.description: We would love to rate 4 or 5 stars. The food is still worth a 3 or 4 star depending on what you order. But the place is turning into a pigsty. The bathroom light switch plates are disgustingly grungy. Petri dishes probably have fewer germs growing in them than those switch plates. Encrusted layers of old food splashes on the wall of our booth over the center of our table showed that the wall probably hasn't been wiped down in a very long time. It was gross and there is no excuse. How sad that Tony's great restaurant chain is living down to the general filth usually found in chinatown restaurants. And that is truly disappointing. Worse than that, it means that the kitchen where the general public doesn't go, is most likely even filthier. Which just took my appetite clean away.

37.description: This is my third Lao restaurant from the Tony Hu Restaurant group. My experience with Chinese food has always been from the neighborhood take out restaurant. After meeting my Mandarin Chinese tutor she explained the different provinces of China and how the style and preparation of the food differs from region to region. If your a fan of Chinese cooking then I would highly recommend trying each of these great restaurants in the group. On to Lao Beijing. The restaurant is situated in the new strip mall along Archer.  On first take the restaurant appears small but they also have upstairs seating so be sure to go in and check. Mike is a server who also doubles as a host at the restaurant. He is fluent in several languages and is quite a character. There is not a thing he can not answer about the preparation or ingredients of the food and on several occasions he has steered me away from some dishes that may require an ACQUIRED taste. Several times he has asked me what I like and has ordered for me and I was not disappointed. The one thing I have learned from both my tutor and Mike is that traditional, authentic, Chinese cooking rarely is soaked in a gravy or sauce much like what we have been accustomed to in the local Chinese Restaurants. Regardless of dish you order the meat or fish will be lightly coated with a sauce and not swimming in it. Some appetizer recommendations include Pancake Northern Style, Salt and Pepper Squid, and the pork pot stickers. You can tell with each entree that fresh ingredients are used consistently throughout the menu. As you can tell I am a fan of the Lao restaurants and would highly recommend them to try out.

0.description: I came here earlier this week with a bunch of friends for AYCE hot pot. Although the menu is a bit limited compared to other restaurants in the area, there were some good highlights such as the crepe (crispy/fried on the inside and egg on the outside), lamb dumplings (cooked and brought to your table, rather than cooked by you, good flavor) and spiciness of the broth. You can create your own sauces. Their broth is better than Sweet Station, but there are so many other AYCE hot pot places in the area, so I'm not inclined to pick this as my favorite.

38.description: All in all only a decent lunch experience. Tried the Northern Style Pancakes, Pork Dumplings, and Hot & Sour soup to start. Pancakes were different but a welcomed break from the norm. Dropped a little chili sauce on them and kicked it up a notch. Pretty good with some duck sauce too. Pork dumplings were solid. Could've been steamed a little longer, but authentic taste and texture rounded them out nicely. Hot & Sour soup was not much to my liking; too sour and not enough hot. Ingredients were spot on though. My entree of Crispy Duck was underwhelming. Hardly crispy and too much work for such little meat. The fatty skin really overwhelmed the whole dish, and bones were riddled throughout. Not a dish I'd order again unfortunately. All told I'll be checking out other Chinatown establishments before a return trip.

51.description: Disgusting!!! This place used to be good, however it changed and we won't be ordering any longer from them!!!. It's the third time now that I received dry, cold and disgusting food.  Today I wanted to give it a chance and same thing happened, we got dry, cold and especially disgusting food!  There was a hair in the soup! I called in to complain and was treated very badly from the manage "Michael " who after an very aggressive behavior towards my explanation,  just hanged up on me.  He said... (screaming ) that he didn't believe that there was a hair in the food and besides that " if I don't like the food I should not order by them" . Well, he got the job well done! I won't be ordering any longer and won't recommend this place to anyone!

27.description: I really like this place. If they were open even close to as late as MingHin, they'd bring in an extra $100/mo in revenue on me alone.This place has 2 somewhat unique dishes, plus one perfectly executed dish, that have a grip on my pre-10pm Chinatown business.Unique: 1) Northern Style Pancake - it's like a savory funnel cake, that you just pull apart and use as a bread to sop up the spicy sauce at the bottom of the Dan Dan (infra) and other items; 2) Lamb Dumplings - serving is about 10 mid-large size dumplings for $7, the filling has more texture than the traditional pork filling, lean meat filling w/ a different flavor (*very good ginger dipping sauce as well).Perfect Execution: Dan Dan Noodles - I think it's listed as a soup, but it's not. It's a good portion of properly cooked long noodles w/ a spicy ground pork chili oil. Just the right amount of spice (I have a high tolerance) without unnecessary tweaks to the dish.Moo shu pork and cumin lamb are my occasional tack-on's. Efficient service, clientele is like 98% Chinese, that should tell you something.

32.description: I will recommend their hot pot set, plenty of food for only $19 each! Great deal! For hot pot beef slices and lamb slices are better than pork slices. Don't miss their lamb dumpling, They are very juicy, even better than those in China!

54.description: A disappointment. This place used to be so much better. The bitter Mellon with beef over cooked and way too much black bean. The pickled vegetable soup served barely hot and cold before we could finish. Don't bother.

48.description: This was an amazing experience.  Best Chinese Food experience I have ever had!!   While many places in China Town serve the same stuff, we went with a friend from Hong Kong who helped us navigate the menu.  Nothing we ordered would have been my first choice but in the end it all was my favorite.  So if you do go, open your mind and try anything on the menu that you never had before.  You wont regret it.

44.description: The food was good but the service was very poor. Ordering takeout is especially frustrating. At least three times since we moved to the South Loop in 2010 I have called and been put on hold but instead of holding they just put the phone down and forgot about me... For 10 minutes. Since the phone is off the hook you cannot call back without getting a busy signal. The last time  I drove up there expecting the place to be busy but there were maybe 3 groups of people dining. Other times I have called and they do not know the dishes by the names given on the menu or by number. If you're in the mood for Chinese food you can do a lot worse for taste but consistently poor service nets this place a single lonely star. With so many other great places for Chinese nearby there's no reason to bother with this place. A shame

24.description: Worst,it said vegetable noodles, and i was delivered chicken, even thought i said nothing else to be added. Also in fried rice i found 2 hairs and too much oil. This place should be shut sown for voilation

7.description: There were sharp bones in the chicken. I had ordered the kung pao chicken, and instead they gave me some chicken and mixed vegetable dish that was bright orange and tasted like buffalo wing sauce. When I called to ask for the right dish, no one answered. I was so hungry I tried to eat it anyway. Again, sharp bones.I had tried this place once a few months ago and found the food very good and authentic. Why the sudden change I don't know, but I will never order here again.

49.description: Had an amazing time with my friends having Chinese dinner. Absolutely loved the food. The service was awesome too! Everything we had was delicious. Moreover, even though some dishes said spicy they were not spicy at all! Just a tiny hint of spice. Definitely recommend this place!

40.description: As one of the "Lao" chain of Chicago's Chinatown restaurants, Lao Beijing probably has enough baseline quality and menu depth to find something suitable for most people. But as someone from a northern Chinese background, I don't think that something is their actual Beijing / northern style dishes, which definitely feel very southern in how they are prepared and flavored. Even though that's typically true of Chinatowns (which are far more Cantonese influenced), I guess I still expected a little more from a restaurant with Beijing in the name.

53.description: Came here for the first time. I usually go to chi cafe a few doors down and was slightly disappointed. They sat us in a corner by the cash register and the phone kept ringing in my ear. The food was decent. The cashew chicken was a little too chewy for my taste. The pork dumplings were very good tho. I've also sampled some mushroom stir fry with beef and that was also pretty good. The inside was pretty dirty. It looked like they haven't dusted or cleaned the floors in a really long time. Overall I would not come back to this place.

30.description: As a person from Beijing I want to say that their food is at best ok, but to be honest I didn't really like their food that much.  Maybe it's from eating food back in Beijing or maybe its all the good food I can find in flushing where fierce competition between restaurants meant you either served the best or you closed down in a few years. I went with a group of people a week ago because I thought this restaurant looked authentic enough to have lots of good food. Out of the 5 dishes we ordered, only 2 of them were around restaurant quality in my expectations of chinese restaurant food. the others were considerably off in seasoning. My friend got the shredded pork with some sort of spicy sauce and athough it had spiciness, was shredded well and came in large portions, the flavor was truly lacking. It was my friend's first time eating at an authentic chinese restaurant though and I think the portion size as well as the natural fat in the shredded pork that won him over. My other friend ordered the lamb, and although it had a taste similar to xinjiang lamb, which is the best tasting lamb kabobs (better than indian or Mediterranean in my opinion), was too salty, I wonder if they even tasted the dish before sending it out? My friend joked he was gonna get hypertension, it literally tasted as salty as seawater. My dish was the worst of the bunch. Northern chinese people have comfort foods like dumplings. I choose the lamb dumpling. I thought theirs was gonna be good because they are suppose to serve northern food. Well, they ended up giving me pork dumplings instead, it did not taste like lamb at all. It wasn't even a good pork dumpling. I buy frozen dumplings from the Chinese supermarket in other cities before and those tasted a lot better. Their dumpling was just a homogenous lump with a bit of cabbage here and there to break up the texture, but it tasted like they used too much flour and it was gross even when I tried to save it by putting in vinegar. The chicken dish was good. it was perfectly tender and the sauce had good flavor. The texture of the meat showed good skill and detail orientation in making the meat, which makes it similar to the way my family used to make it, My other friend got the sizzling beef dish. That was actually pretty good too. Good texture of meat, good sauces. It's a hit or miss.By the way good luck finding parking.

46.description: Terrible! Do not order from here as they took 2 hours on a Monday night to deliver the food. After the food was delivered late the food was cold and stale. They do not care about their customer because they were unwilling to offer anything for their terrible customer service tonight.

1.description: I don't know why Beijing is even in the name of the restaurant, let alone adding the Lao (old/traditional) to the name, when its dishes have nothing to do with the region. For Chinese people, if you are looking for authentic food, turn elsewhere. This place does offer selection of the staple cantonese american dish lineup, so if that's what you are looking for and familiar with, don't feel alarmed by what I have said =P Seeing the people including the soup dumplings/xiaolongbao in the photos, I also tried some. They are utterly pathetic, didn't even put some covering paper down, so all of them were stuck to the steamer, ripped and leaked all the soup out. Food is mediocre objectively, ate here a few times, edible but nothing great. Still really think the name is quite deceiving, and the owners should be ashamed for false advertising. 来这里旅游的朋友不要被这家店名骗了，完全的美式广东餐馆，跟北京基本半毛关系没有。唯一能算上有点京味的烤鸭，味道凄惨，吃惯便宜坊，大董什么的同学们请不要作贱自己舌头。

55.description: Love the lamb dumplings and the beijing noodles and northern pancakes... just like our trips to Beijing!

9.description: Wow. What a meal. Lots of sweat and tears, which means a hard workout or a kick-ass spicy meal. It was the latter here.First, get the lamb dumplings. You can get the pork dumplings anywhere, including frozen in bags at any Asian grocery store. Be a man (or a woman) and get the lamb dumplings. It's got stronger, fuller flavor and is harder to find.Second, get a spicy dish. This isn't Lao Sze Chuan, but the spicy dishes here are great. Spicy fish soup, spicy stir-fried lamb, etc. Lamb is a fairly popular meat for northern Chinese dishes.Third, this is a fairly authentic place. When we went, 100% of the patrons were Chinese or at least Asian - I didn't interrogate them on their ethnicity and just did a visual census. I love white people like you all do, but I get seriously concerned if I go into a Chinese restaurant and everyone in it are as white as Casper the Friendly Ghost or Mitt Romney's family. Restaurants tend to have their targeted demographics in them - it's not rocket science.

26.description: Lot's of Chinese Resto's in this area so it's hard to figure out which one to go to. Go to this one! Service was fast and food was very tasty. I like my stuff spicy so I asked for the chili sauce on the side. Yum!

25.description: Really good and really quick. If I'm ever in the area again and craving Asian I'm definitely heading back there.

12.description: This is a fantastic restaurant for northern Chinese food. This one star is for the Sichuan food on its menu. It is a total disaster! We ordered twice-cooked pork and spicy boiled beef. Neither tastes authentic. The waiter asked the chef to redo the twice-cooked pork for us, but it still turned out to be a huge disappointment.

59.description: Was there last night and felt like if i wasnt chinese i would not get served.  They acted like a Korean restaurant!!Poor service aside, food is pretty good.  We had mongolian beef, eggplant, spinach, and a noodle dish.  I only have been here with big groups in the past, so wasnt sure what to order.Overall, food was better than average but service was awful!

21.description: Chinatown is one of my favorite places to go when visiting Chicago.  And I hope you are a fan of Chinese food.  I'm not of Chinese decent, nor have a traveled to China; however I can tell you that I enjoyed my dinner 100%.  After a short uber ride from downtown, we arrived around 7pm.   We walked through the large red door and into the downstairs dining area.  It was busy and full of activity.  The downstairs dining area was full, so we went upstairs.  Our waitress was at our table with water almost seconds after we sat down.  We ended up ordering 2 entrees. Cummin Flavor Lamb Xinjiang style & Sweet Fried Shrimp. with side orders of crab ragoons & fried rice.  All of the food was great.  I will warn you the Cummin Lamb was super spicy hot.  I tried to eat more , but it was soo hot I could only eat half of it.  The sweet fried shimp was great.  We couldn't seem to eat enough of it.  We did take the left overs back to the hotel, which leads me to the conclusion that it is best eaten when it's temperature is hot/warm.I'm sad that I didn't get a chance to have any authentic teas or beverages.Overall my dinner experience was great!  I left happy and the cost was very reasonable for any major city ($45 for 2 people).

17.description: Great place to enjoy some authentic Chinese food in Chinatown, Chicago. We had some chow mein, fried rice, fried shrimps and mushu. Everything was excellent.

10.description: First of all the server we had was just rude to begin with and just seemed to be annoyed when we asked her questions about the hot pot or anything else. Not a good experience on the service. As the food goes the hot pot from my fellow friends said wasn't bad but it is all you can eat but as they asked to get reloaded with some seafood the waitress said they were all out. I ordered the walnut shrimp my favorite dish but i was disappointed that it was not that great.. The batter was a bit like powdery i never experienced something like that it was a bit weird. I personally would not come back here again since there are places around that I've never had any problems with. But on a good note one friend said they would come back for the hot pot out of 5. The crab ragoon was good too.

5.description: I've only been here for hot pot so I can't comment about anything else yet, but man does this place do an awesome hot pot buffet! I'm not sure you can find hot pot buffet cheaper than $16.95 ($18.95 on Fri/Sat) and they have a large variety of ingredients, including: - Meat: beef (nice and fatty), lamb (a little dry), pork, chicken, tripe- Seafood: head-on shrimp, mussels, squid, fish balls, some sort of white fish (which tastes delicious like sui-zhu-yu in the spicy broth)- Veggies: spinach, cabbage, soft tofu, fried tofu, shitoch mushrooms, woodear mushrooms, you name it. The only thing I don't like is that they charge extra for enoki mushrooms :( Both broths are delicious and I recommend getting the half & half pot so you can try both as well as take a break from the spicy once in a while lol. They also have a bunch of sauces on the side including peanut, garlic, classic seafood plus scallions and cilantro. The buffet includes some appetizers like dumplings (pork or lamb), scallion pancakes, and another type of pancake - just save room for the hot pot! You also get 1 free soda per person. Supposedly they will charge you for leftovers, although they haven't been super strict about it the last few times I've been. I would just try to order as much as you think you can eat initially though, and you can always get another round, plus service is pretty fast!

3.description: The food was not too bad.  I lived in Beijing for a year and a half, and a lot of the foods are truly Beijing.  (Lao Beijing means real Beijing.) The selection is decent with decent flavors.  Prices are about right for size and portion you get, and wait staff is very standard of a Chinese restaurant, where you don't really know who your server is (the flutter in and out depending on who is busy) and they aren't the friendliest or most outgoing, however, one part for a decent Chinese restaurant.

35.description: Great experience ordering from Lao Beijin on GrubHub while I was in Chicago.  I went with the "trending dishes" and it was a big hit!  I had the stewed pork belly with bean noodles, the sauteed green beans, and lamb dumplings.  All flavorful.  It was 10 below zero outside, and yet the food arrived fresh and hot!  I'm impressed.  I will try them again next time I'm staying at the Palmer House Hilton!  Great job!

19.description: This is my favorite place to get the Tianjin Style Snack in Chinatown. They also have super good Fried Dough Sticks. Overall, a great place to have the traditional Chinese breakfast/brunch.

28.description: Favorite place in Chinatown. Actually rather surprised with the weak ratings other people have given this place. The service is standard or above average for Chinatown.The food is great. So many flavors, and the spicy food actually tastes well and not only numbs your mouth. Love the Spicy Garlic Chicken, the double fried duck, and the postickers.

45.description: I went to Lao Beijing once and did not like the experience at all. First of all the waitress has a whatever attitude, she might have acted differently if we were American. The food just okay, nothing really special. But I definitely don't want to go back. Service is very important to me.

33.description: I have been to many restaurants in Chinatown and this is by far the best. It has a great assortment of Northern China entrees. Everything that my family ordered was great. The service was great. You will not be disappointed. I have been to several cities in northern China and was looking  for a restaurant that offered similar dishes and this definitely hit the mark.

43.description: Had the dry chilli chicken which was really good, and the crispy eggplant which was also very good. The third dish, chicken with hot garlic sauce, was the weakest of the three and only okay at best. Also of not, is that they do go a bit heavy with the oil. Unlimited rice is a nice perk, and the service is nice as well. Overall, I was pleased with the experience.

2.description: Came here for the AYCE hot pot. I was honestly a little underwhelmed with the hot pot selection, but the service and price made up for it.The price is not bad (~18$ on the weekend). That seemed pretty cheap especially for AYCE so we just went for it. Their selection is alright - they have all the essentials. Pork, beef, chicken, lamb, as well as a model selection of fishballs and seafood. Veggies I thought were a bit lacking. They didn't have winter melon, for instance, or more than one variety of tofu. Sauces were alright - they give you a huge tub of garlic, sesame, and a leek/sesame mix. The broth selection is pretty good. I didn't really care for the spicy broth - it had way too much spicy oil in it, and it was filled with just too much "stuff" - random flavorings, star anise, herbs, etc, that it was hard to taste any of the food that you were taking out.Huge plus for including unlimited soda (Coke and Sprite) as well as including the flaky pancakes and the DELICIOUS lamb dumplings. Service was surprisingly attentive for what I would expect, but they did forget some of our order at first. Surprisingly, portions were HEAPING. We definitely didn't expect to get so much and were honestly shocked when we got our mountain of meat. Usually these AYCE places are stingy, so props to them for the good portions.Overall, I thought the selection of AYCE was pretty lacking and the spicy soup base was a little wonky, but the service and extras really made up for it.

18.description: ATTENTION!!!  Tony Hu no longer owns this restaurant!!  As a result, the food is not the same under the new ownership.  I visited last week and immediately noticed the changes.  The pork in garlic sauce is now made in a sweet sauce that isn't very good at all.  This was my favorite dish on the menu and I sensed that something was off as soon as I took my first bite.  Sadly, I can no longer endorse Lao Beijing as one of the best Chinatown restaurants.  The new owners should have stuck to the original recipes from when Tony Hu was the owner.  You guys fucked up and it's quite disappointing.

41.description: Once in a great while my co-workers and I like to venture out to China Town for lunch.  I'm pretty positive I hate here once before a few years ago, and since then hit up a few others in the area - there are so many you just don't know which one to go to!Based on a recommendation from a co-worker she suggested this place which is considered "new" China Town as opposed to the "old" China Town.  For starters, the menu is HUGE, it's like a book!!! So take your time and really go through it because there is a LOT to choose from.  They give you spicy cabbage to start out with and tea when you're seated - brought us non chopsticks users forks later on.  My co-workers and I had pot stickers for an appetizer and all ordered entrees to share - all were very good.  The orange chicken I ordered came out a bit longer than the others so I was slightly annoyed by that, and not informed that there would be a delay until we asked.SO decent service, good food...definitely a place to hit up in the area for some food!

52.description: Wanted to try this place since they opened and finally did last night.  What a great disappointment. Especially coming from the famous owner chef Tony.  Most of all, well all of the food was so oily that literally the sauce was the oil itself.  It was so unhealthy and scary, and after dinner you feel like having a stroke anytime soon.  The taste is typical and the same like the take out Chinese restaurant found everywhere in the city. A far cry from trying to bring the real Beijing food to Chicago.  Service is low, doesn't seen like there's a manager and only the waitress runs the restaurant.  And most of the time they seemed lost.  Right after dinner, have to rush home and straight to the bathroom.  Dumped everything I ate and had a bad tummy ache later. Definitely will NOT and NEVER go back to this place.  There should be a sign of "Eat at your own risk."
