50.description: this is my first time here and i will never go back again.we went in at not a busy hour so there were just couple tables but the waiters were talking and totally ignored us so we were standing at the door for like couple min before the waiters finally discover us and pointed at an open table. no greetings, not even a smile!!!!   the food was so awful that i even regret eating it to make my stomach suffer.the service  was even worse ,or to be exact, there was not even service! they didn't come to my table until i called them.the food was extremely slow!!the thing that made me most angry is that they add a 18% service fee to my bill !!!??how dare they? there were only two of us and those two nasty dishes cost us $37, and that is not enough you are forcing me to give you a 18% tip for no service?i knew they did tell from our face that we were not satisfied,but you cant just add tip to my bill for just two of us!? it is not about the money ,the thing annoying me is your attitude! actually we always leave a tip for at least 20% but this time we did not add any thing to that so called"service fee". and when i was complaining this to their manager , they talked in their own language to the manager,and after that the manager just simply turned away in front of us with "sorry i am busy".what the hell is that?!!you have only one table almost finished eating !!  i will never go back again!!

4.description: Chinatown is one of my favorite places to go when visiting Chicago.  And I hope you are a fan of Chinese food.  I'm not of Chinese decent, nor have a traveled to China; however I can tell you that I enjoyed my dinner 100%.  After a short uber ride from downtown, we arrived around 7pm.   We walked through the large red door and into the downstairs dining area.  It was busy and full of activity.  The downstairs dining area was full, so we went upstairs.  Our waitress was at our table with water almost seconds after we sat down.  We ended up ordering 2 entrees. Cummin Flavor Lamb Xinjiang style & Sweet Fried Shrimp. with side orders of crab ragoons & fried rice.  All of the food was great.  I will warn you the Cummin Lamb was super spicy hot.  I tried to eat more , but it was soo hot I could only eat half of it.  The sweet fried shimp was great.  We couldn't seem to eat enough of it.  We did take the left overs back to the hotel, which leads me to the conclusion that it is best eaten when it's temperature is hot/warm.I'm sad that I didn't get a chance to have any authentic teas or beverages.Overall my dinner experience was great!  I left happy and the cost was very reasonable for any major city ($45 for 2 people).

6.description: I came here for lunch with my friend and was pleasantly surprised by the food. I did not have high hopes for this restaurant after eating at that "other" szechuan place in Chinatown. Even though this restaurant has the same owner as Lao Sze Chuan, they do not charge for rice, and the dishes are more appropriately priced. I really dislike when Chinese places charge for rice, because the majority of Chinese food is impossible to eat without rice. My friend and I ordered the Napa Cabbage with fried shrimp dish, the twice cooked spicy pork, and the spicy pig ears.  We asked for extra of the hot pepper oil fried napa cabbage appetizer that it came with.  The twice cooked spicy fatty pork was my absolute favorite dish. Prices are reasonable, and we had enough food for 3 people. I will definitely be adding this into my restaurant rotation.

22.description: This is my favorite place to get the Tianjin Style Snack in Chinatown. They also have super good Fried Dough Sticks. Overall, a great place to have the traditional Chinese breakfast/brunch.

15.description: Came here with my boyfriend on Sunday over Labor Day weekend for dinner. The wait was about 20-25 minutes to be seated. We ordered the 3 course Peking duck and also the Hunan lamb. The lamb came out quickly. It was decent, but pretty gamey and overall not very special. The Peking duck didn't come out for another 30 minutes, which was kind of annoying because we were kind of just waiting around for it. They served the main course first (the actual wraps) and the duck stir fry didn't come out for another 15 minutes. And then it was another 15 minutes after that to get the soup. So overall, our food came out over the course of an hour. By the time our last dish came, we were ready to go home. The duck was unimpressive. It kind of tasted reheated and just not very fresh. They also didn't give us that much scallions. Service was ok - pretty standard for a Chinese restaurant. We were never sure who our server was because different people would bring us different things. I don't mind if servers aren't the friendliest, but I was kind of frustrated with having to wait so long in between each dish. Given how many good restaurants there are in Chinatown, I probably won't be back.

57.description: My friends and I headed to Chinatown Square at 6:30 on a Friday night and it was uncharacteristically quiet. We were able to get seated quickly at Lao Beijing and warmed up with some hot tea while we contemplated our options. It hadn't occurred to me until that evening how extensive Chinese restaurant menus are-- so many options! With Lao Beijing, I feel like their food is a little inconsistent (especially with seafood dishes) but staples like anything with vegetables are always good, granted I could probably make something very similar at home. Of course, the whole reason we go out to eat is because we want to eat food made by someone else, so there's no point complaining about that.While we dined, the restaurant quickly filled up, mostly with people enjoying AYCE hot pot. By the time we left, we could barely squeeze out of the door; we were seated in the far back corner. I probably wouldn't insist on bringing out of town guests here to eat, but it's nice to visit with local friends when we're missing home cooked Chinese meals.

20.description: I've only been here for hot pot so I can't comment about anything else yet, but man does this place do an awesome hot pot buffet! I'm not sure you can find hot pot buffet cheaper than $16.95 ($18.95 on Fri/Sat) and they have a large variety of ingredients, including: - Meat: beef (nice and fatty), lamb (a little dry), pork, chicken, tripe- Seafood: head-on shrimp, mussels, squid, fish balls, some sort of white fish (which tastes delicious like sui-zhu-yu in the spicy broth)- Veggies: spinach, cabbage, soft tofu, fried tofu, shitoch mushrooms, woodear mushrooms, you name it. The only thing I don't like is that they charge extra for enoki mushrooms :( Both broths are delicious and I recommend getting the half & half pot so you can try both as well as take a break from the spicy once in a while lol. They also have a bunch of sauces on the side including peanut, garlic, classic seafood plus scallions and cilantro. The buffet includes some appetizers like dumplings (pork or lamb), scallion pancakes, and another type of pancake - just save room for the hot pot! You also get 1 free soda per person. Supposedly they will charge you for leftovers, although they haven't been super strict about it the last few times I've been. I would just try to order as much as you think you can eat initially though, and you can always get another round, plus service is pretty fast!

36.description: Wow. What a meal. Lots of sweat and tears, which means a hard workout or a kick-ass spicy meal. It was the latter here.First, get the lamb dumplings. You can get the pork dumplings anywhere, including frozen in bags at any Asian grocery store. Be a man (or a woman) and get the lamb dumplings. It's got stronger, fuller flavor and is harder to find.Second, get a spicy dish. This isn't Lao Sze Chuan, but the spicy dishes here are great. Spicy fish soup, spicy stir-fried lamb, etc. Lamb is a fairly popular meat for northern Chinese dishes.Third, this is a fairly authentic place. When we went, 100% of the patrons were Chinese or at least Asian - I didn't interrogate them on their ethnicity and just did a visual census. I love white people like you all do, but I get seriously concerned if I go into a Chinese restaurant and everyone in it are as white as Casper the Friendly Ghost or Mitt Romney's family. Restaurants tend to have their targeted demographics in them - it's not rocket science.

14.description: Their dishes are very traditional and all incredible! Try their scallop dish and duck roast with tea leaf then deep fry. You will fall in love with this place.

58.description: I came here once a month and recommend all my friends over. The staffs are super nice,  and I got 10% discount from them when I pay cash.

56.description: $15.00 kids haircut.  They did a good job, which is no easy feat on a squirming, screaming, 2 year old. Basically, walked right in. Much better than the last place I took my son where the lady cut her finger with the scissors and; well I'll just stop there and spare everyone the details...We will be back.

29.description: Good service. The guy I had was quick and knowledgeable. They got me in pretty fast considering that I didn't have an appointment.

42.description: Never disappointed! Been to Kit twice (try to ask for him for Men's haircuts. He's the best one their in my opinion. Make sure to make a reservation a day in advance for him!).  The others are good (been there a 3rd time, someone else) and she was very good, but not as perfect as the first couple of times. I asked for a typical faded comb over, and it always looks sharp and crisp every time.I live in Kansas City now, and whenever I need a hair cut and happen to be going home to Naperville, I make sure to save my cut for them after a bomb meal at Chinatown. Worth the money and the travel.

23.description: This place is great!  Excellent value for a really great cut. They were quick too, which I'd rarely the case for a haircut like mine (it's quite finicky). Full points to Linda!

47.description: I'm white and don't speak an ounce of Chinese.  I got a better haircut here then I have from english speaking chain salons.  Totally worth the risk. Also really great scalp massage with a wash!

8.description: After trying out every place to cut hair in Hyde Park, and ending up with either a military or black haircut style, I decided to look elsewhere.  And for $27 (10% cash discount), B Square Salon will cut my hair the way I want it, as well as giving good, full service.  My girlfriend will either wait until a trip to LA or China to get a haircut, but B Square Salon is the one place in Chicago that will meet her standards.Every haircut consists a shampoo and scalp massage, then a cut, another wash, and finally a style.  And yet with all this the price is comparable to what you would pay for just a cut at most places in the area and downtown.  The second wash is really useful, it gets all the small, cut pieces of hair out.  I always immediately shower after a haircut, but do not need to for B^2.  The cut itself is usually quick and expertly done.  It helps to speak Chinese, but you can bring pictures on your phone and show them.  I've been twice, had the same stylist, and looked sharp both times.  Yes they excel at cutting asian hair, but they can cut white hair too.

31.description: It was one of those days where I was looking for a haircut and everything was closed. I ended up getting the yelp app just to find a place to go. This place had the best reviews and it was close to where I was at so I gave it a shot. I went in there and the staff was very welcoming. Was given a pre and post haircut  shampoo and condition. Was also given a lengthy deep scalp massage. There was a bit of a language barrier but nothing that prevented us from communication. The stylists did a wonderful job cutting my hair. I think I will be going back again. Service like that is really hard to find and the cost was very affordable.

34.description: I wait for Kit - and never too long of a wait.  I first came here about 2 years ago, looking for something close to my work at Amtrak.  Since the schedules vary widely, I am never able to make an appointment in advance.  He always accommodates me when he can.  My hair is not like Asian hair - it is exceedingly fine and thin (i.e. baby hair).  Somehow he creates the right cut that is carefree and easily maintained.  Best of all I was treated to THE BEST SCALP MASSAGE I have ever encountered last night by a woman named Qing.  She is tiny but mighty with her fingers and hands, as she slid all of the post-work stress out of my head.   She must have spent 10 minutes doing so and I honestly thought this would be the perfect way to spend eternity.   When she was finished, I could actually see red patches on the sides of my temples.  She spared nothing, and of course I tipped her triple what I normally would tip. What a team: Qing and Kit.  Talented, charming and professional.  By the way if you pay in cash you get a discount.

16.description: have got my hair cut with Sharon twice now. I have to say that she is very experienced, fast, and attentive to details. I got Japanese Straightening the second time that I visited. She was very patient to explain the details to me and to inform me what I can and cannot do afterwards with my hair. I am very satisfied with the result and would definitely go back next time!

13.description: Will never go anywhere else for a trim. The shampoo stations cradle you like your childhood puppy and they have a stand to hold up your head so that you don't get a crick in the back of your neck. They have free lockers to store your purse or items.  The trim was professional and cheap - $25 for my long and layered white girl hair.The clientele is mostly Asian men, meaning that the cut has more style to it what you would get in a standard salon for men.  I was the only woman getting a trim when i was there (the stylist explained that women just get their hair cut less frequently). However, my accompanying manfriend got a great short on sides, long on the top hipster hair cut. Highly recommend for any man wanting an affordable, quality trim or wanting to punch up your hairstyle a bit.

11.description: I don't normally go to a salon for a haircut, but I decided to treat myself to brighten up my day. It was hot and muggy out and I was looking to get rid of some of my long hair. It's been in the way lately. I called earlier that day to see if they can give me a haircut in an hour and they said okay. Once I got there, I was taken in within 5 minutes. I got my hair shampooed which felt really good. I just like when people play with my hair in general. Then, I got Sunny who would cut my hair. He asked what I wanted and I showed him a picture of Taylor Swift and wanted a short cut. He put a great effort into my hair, which was awesome. I know my hair, thick and numerous, is a lot of work. I loved it and can't wait to come back.

39.description: I only trust my hair to Kit. I like to change hairstyles and he is my gatekeeper. We discuss what I want and he makes suggestions. As for hair color, I totally let him pick my overall color (got gray hair sssshhhhh) and highlights. I get compliments from lots of people. Other hairdressers in the salon are excellent, too. I'm the type who likes to stick with a person I like. I've recommended friends and friends recommended this salon. They even close their shop to attend conferences so they are not the neighborhood salon with old knowledge and technology.  They really know their stuff as well as the latest trend in cut, color, straightening, etc. I cannot recommend Bsquare enough.

37.description: I was able to walk in without an appointment on a weekday afternoon. I had wanted Kit, but was told he was unavailable. I settled for Linda instead. She didn't exactly spoke fluent English, but was able to get the job done. Hair was washed. Cut. Blow out.

0.description: Love my haircut from here! A few friends recommended Chinatown as the place to get a good haircut for a fraction of the usual salon prices and they were right. There was no wait since I didn't request anyone in particular. I got a wash, cut and blow dry for around $40. Be prepared to spend at least an hour there.They strongly recommended thinning out my hair, which I was opposed to at first (because in Chicago, hair = warmth), but I'm glad I did. They styled it really well and I can still use my hair as a scarf :)It's been almost half a year and the cut still looks really good. Would come back for my next cut!

38.description: A native of Chicago's Northshore, I would take the trip down here just to get my hair done! KIT is an AMAZING hair stylist. I have very long hair and he took the time and effort to get the look that I wanted...not to mention one of the things that bring me back here is the RIDICULOUSLY RELAXING scalp messages before your haircut! I've brought my entire family here and all the staff were very helpful and attentive. A little on the pricey side, but for a heavenly scalp massage, superior cut and service...well worth it!

51.description: Kit has cut my hair the past three times that I have gotten it cut and I don't even live in Chicago. Now that really kind of says something don't you think? Whenever I'm in town I always always make it a point to stop by and get my hair cut by Kit because he always does a really good job. Now I hadn't gotten my hair cut since last October with him and my hair was kind of a mess. He was able to get out all the damaged and split end parts and gave my hair new life. At the end of the cut he styled my hair, added some treatment to my ends and also some shine serum to my hair. It came out to around $29 w/o tip if you pay in cash. Still very reasonable price for a good haircut!!

27.description: All of my coworkers highly recommended B Square Salon. They told me that their entire family comes here to see Sharon. The experience here was everything I expected and more. Once you come into the salon, you can check in to the front desk. They have a designated place to hang up your jacket and lockers to put your purse in so you don't have to lug it around. You will get a 5 minute head massage and shampoo before your hair cut.The chairs are super comfortable, and they don't spray water into your eye. ;) Sharon is amazing! She's super nice and friendly! Not only is she super fast, she has a really good eye for detail. She will check and double check your hair cut. They will even style your hair afterwards, without an additional fee. Girls, don't be intimidated by all the men here. Girls are welcomed too! For $25, this was a great experience!

32.description: Went to B Square for about a year now and yesterday I went with Lee instead of Kit since he was busy. Lee was very remarkable too when it comes to cutting a guy's hair. She makes sure the tiniest part of everything and make sure what you said was applied to your hair.

54.description: The haircut here is superb.  Sharon always does a great job with my hair.  She asks the right questions too.  That really goes a long way - remembering the customer and what the customer needs.  In addition, the customer service at this place is great.  I hadn't been back for a while because of the extreme cold and I still welcomed.  I had three jackets on and the people were helpful.  When I misplaced one of my jackets later on during the day and returned to look for it, they were helpful and remembered I had three.  After I backtracked and found it, I called them to tell them how appreciative I was for their help.  This is just a wonderful place to get a haircut.  :-)

48.description: Linda was amazing. I showed her a photo of the haircut I want and voila! I got it. And As the other reviewers said they still have 10% off when you pay cash!

44.description: First of all guys, I gave this salon two chances. First time I went there Kit cut my hair, and dyed it(the color barely showed), but since I didn't live in Chicago I couldn't really go back to get it redone. The total was $132. Wow. It's only $75 to dye and $32 to cut hair at Headquarters which is way more popular than this salon. Well whatever I liked the haircut. So I gave them a second chance the next time I went to Chicago because the other salon was too busy. I requested Kit again, but he said he was too busy, so I got my haircut from this other lady. The haircut? It was horrible. She thinned my hair to the point where there's flyaway everywhere. My hair is medium length, yet I can't even put it up because it's so damn choppy and there's only a tiny bit of long hair. I told her I only wanted a couple layers, yet instead of the layer I only saw different lengths of hair sticking out here and there. There's no way to style my hair unless I simply straighten my hair out and it looks like a mess if I don't. I specifically asked her to give me a style that doesn't require much maintenance. She had one job to do. Oh and as I looked at Kit, what was he busy doing? Playing on his phone. Very professional.

24.description: I don't normally go to a salon for a haircut, but I decided to treat myself to brighten up my day. It was hot and muggy out and I was looking to get rid of some of my long hair. It's been in the way lately. I called earlier that day to see if they can give me a haircut in an hour and they said okay. Once I got there, I was taken in within 5 minutes. I got my hair shampooed which felt really good. I just like when people play with my hair in general. Then, I got Sunny who would cut my hair. He asked what I wanted and I showed him a picture of Taylor Swift and wanted a short cut. He put a great effort into my hair, which was awesome. I know my hair, thick and numerous, is a lot of work. I loved it and can't wait to come back.

7.description: I made an appointment here because it had good reviews on Yelp and it's reasonably priced.  I asked for subtle and non-chunky highlights. The TWO men who were working on my hair did not speak English very well; however, they assured me that they understood, and knew what they were doing.  After they said that my highlights were ready, they took me to the wash station to rinse out the dye.  I was sitting there, under the faucet, for least twenty minutes while two different people washed my hair.  It wasn't a pleasant massage; no, it was painful.  I was wincing, and said "ow" several times.  One of the guys explained, to the best of his limited ability, that it hurt because my hair was too dry (I've never been told that before).  I had to ask that they stop washing because I wanted to move on to the cut and blow-dry.When I looked in the mirror, I noticed that there were some very noticeable blonde streaks (mind you, my hair was brown before).  I tried not to freak out just then because I thought it might look better when it was dry.  The haircut and blow-dry went smoothly (although it was nothing special), but to my dismay, my highlights looked even worse when dry.  One side had way more highlights than the other, and all of them were streaky and far from the root.  Please see the picture.When I pointed it out to the haircutter, he ran to get the man who spoke better English (the one who told me that my hair was dry).  That man informed me that I have to part my hair a certain way in order for it to look better.  At that point, I went sorta diva.Fortunately, I only had to pay for the haircut.  I won't be coming back ever again though, and suggest that you NEVER let them highlight your hair.

49.description: I have been to this place several times and was pretty happy about their service until they RUINED my hair. I had a gentleman cutting my hair, I wish I could remember his name. I told him to just trim the edges and he told me he have a great idea about my hair and I would look amazing. I guess it was my fault that I was asleep when he cut my hair. He basically give me a super short man haircut and it was a irregular shape. I nearly cryed when I saw his work. I asked him what happened and he insisted I look like a Japanese cartoon character and this is beautiful.  Japanese cartoon??? really??? When did I say I want to look like a cartoon character? After that, I have never went back to this place and each time when I cut my hair in other salons, they would ask me whether I had cut my hair myself before. Nope, I replied, it's a great piece of work from a professional stylist!

40.description: Good haircut place for any Asian guys out there who haven't found a good place yet. Michael was my guy and he was great. He did it exactly like I wanted it and he was super nice. All in all I'm definitely coming here from now on. A little pricey at 27 bucks a cut but what are you gunna do, I'd say it's worth it

53.description: They know what they are doing! I make effort to stop by every time i am in Chicago.

30.description: I got a digital perm here and it was great! I wanted some waves to my hair and my hairstylist, Kit, did a great job! It was just like how I wanted it. The perm lasted soo long too! Usually, perms go away in 3-4 months for me but this one lasted me more than 6 months!

46.description: I've always treated my hair extremely well. I straighten/blow dry my hair about once or twice a month, never colored it, never teased it, etc. I was nervous to get my hair colored for the first time and found this place through yelp. I wanted to go to an Asian hair salon thinking they would know my hair better and what I was looking for. I asked to have color that was noticeable but not extreme. I also strongly feared the look of outgrown roots. We settled on all over that would be brushed into my roots so that when my hair grows, it wouldn't be as obvious. By the end of the session, she asked how I liked it. I was honest and said I didn't really see the difference. The color was still pretty dark. She said it would get lighter throughout the week and that I would notice it more later on. I appreciated the time she spent and the advice she gave. I read really great reviews online about her work as well so trusted her opinion. I tipped heavily ($24 on a $96 job) and left. I went to work, hung out with my friends, saw my sister, etc. and not a single person noticed that I had colored my hair. I tried laying out in the sun for a few days in hopes that it would make it lighter but that failed to work as well. I thought that I might just not have noticed the difference, but everyone I saw, even my roommate, didn't notice anything different. I returned to get my hair colored lighter - after all, if I was going to spend the money on coloring my hair, I wanted it to be noticeable. We agreed on highlights using some bleaching cream because allover would be too damaging for my hair. She said she would comb in the highlights into where the allover color was placed because if it was placed at my roots, it would produce a different color because it was my original hair. I trusted her opinion and thus underwent the new plan. I noticed a difference in service at this point. I was checked in on less frequently. 20 minutes of sitting led to 30 minutes. However I know she took care of me last time thus trusted her. After my hair was washed and dried, I was not pleased. The highlights were significantly lighter and as you can see from the picture. She even said that it came out lighter than expected. It looked like I hadn't gotten my roots touched up for 3 months. I asked about it and she reiterated that it came out according to plan. As you can see by the picture, I'm not sure who exactly would want to plan a 3 month missed root touch up look... I was extremely disappointed and upset. I asked what could be done and she reiterated that if she did highlights at the roots, it would look a different color. She said I could come in for a root touch up later but it looked like I needed one 3 months ago! I felt trapped and when I asked what she would do for the root touch up, if she had to color it with the original allover color then do highlights again, I got a confusing response. She had also quickly moved onto the next customer making it hard to express my concern. I was charged for the full amount of highlights and apprehensively tipped well again thinking I would have to come back again soon. I went home thinking I might be over exaggerating but my roommate and sister were very blunt with me and told me it looked really bad. Even when I had my hair up, you could see the harsh contrast of the 2 inches of original hair color and the highlights. I booked another appointment. I eventually decided that I could not risk it again and booked with another salon. I already felt that the years I've taken such great care of my hair was ruined. I called Bsquare and cancelled my appointment. An hour after cancelling the appointment at Bsquare, I got a call saying that if I came in, the procedure would be complimentary. I said thank you, was respectful, but decided that I could not risk it again. I had already spent over $190 on purely damaging my hair. I wish that the second procedure when I came in unpleased with my hair a week after the first procedure was complimentary especially since after the first allover I expressed that I didn't see a difference and she said to come back in and that we could do highlights if I wasn't pleased. I also wish at the end of my second procedure, she expressed more concern for my horrification of my hair. She too acknowledged that it was lighter than expected. I felt so trapped. Luckily the new salon was able to quickly and easily fix my hair in a manner the stylist at Bsquare didn't mention. I didn't feel so trapped anymore and was so much happier.

1.description: Oh my god. Just had the best experience ever. I'm already a regular, but today was extraordinary. Kit wasn't available, not a Big deal... Had my back up who is still pretty good -- Linda. Linda was a 30 minute wait though so I asked if I could get a massage while I wait.That would totally sound weird if I was a first timer, lol. I think all of their salon assistants realize how much I love a good cranial massage... So I caught myself and said, "I mean, can I get my hair washed while I wait?"They were so ready. She gave me a thorough massage from my forehead, temples, scalp, neck, and shoulders... I was just like, "Yes! Finally!" Haha. I'm so stressed and lots of the pressure are in my forehead.Then my husband came in after running errands, I looked at him and said, "Go get your scalp massaged NOW!" With all of this excitement, I tipped her $45 for the both of us. I could spend every Sunday like this... Not wash my hair and get a scrap massage. Loooooove!

55.description: I'm very picky with my hair and wanted a change. I was very impressed with the service and style. He even took time to teach me to style my new look. I will definitely be coming back!

9.description: B Square Salon is amazing, although kIT is one of the most meticulous craftspeople I have ever come accross. She requires this kind of excellent treatment all the way, from hairwash to colouring to reduce. She will pay focus on what she actually is performing, and she will pay focus on what you really are informing her or requesting her to accomplish. I usually feel at ease and comfortable which i will appear having a wondwerful(and sensible) hairstyle.

26.description: I recently had my hair ombred and I AM OBSESSED with it! Sharon did an AMAZING job and it looks beautiful! No awkward chunks, no brassy orange color, just absolute perfection. The picture doesn't do it justice. SO happy with the amazing outcome. Thank you Sharon!!

25.description: I recently got a hair cut from B spot and my hair stylist is Michael. He is very diligent and listened to what I want and it turned out to be a pleasant surprise. Michael is also a master who has years of styling experience in China.The place is smaller in a sense that you can hear other people's conversations. They get me in for less than 5 minutes without an appointment.

12.description: I love coming to Chinatown to get my Chinese hair cut! For a cut and style, it's $29 if paying cash, a bit more if paying by card. I know I'm always in expert hands here--both with the delightful 10 min shampoo massage and with the hairdressers. These folks know how to cut Asian hair, which can be finicky and stubborn if not treated right. I always get a pretty standard trim with layers, though I've seen other women walk away with really stylish bobs, color treatments, and crazier assymetrical styles.

59.description: Went to B Square today and had another fantastic experience! Definitely my go to spot

21.description: Recently I went with a different hairstylist to this place, I had Sharon instead of Steven and I ended up with a haircut that I was disappointed with. Even though I was slightly pressed for time I requested to have my hair ironed and cut in three hours and I appreciated the fact that she accommodated my time limits but I feel she could have paid more attention to the hair. She just didn't cut my hair with any care, all she did was cut straight lines across instead of intricately taking care of how the layers of the hair worked together and how it would reflect the hair's body. I feel her style might be more suited for men but from a female standpoint I don't feel she did a very good job.

17.description: Despite never living in Chicago (but often myself finding there), I've come back to Kit over and over. He has given me the haircuts of my life. I live in LA now, and when I have a stop-over in Chicago, I see him again.

10.description: All of my coworkers highly recommended B Square Salon. They told me that their entire family comes here to see Sharon. The experience here was everything I expected and more. Once you come into the salon, you can check in to the front desk. They have a designated place to hang up your jacket and lockers to put your purse in so you don't have to lug it around. You will get a 5 minute head massage and shampoo before your hair cut.The chairs are super comfortable, and they don't spray water into your eye. ;) Sharon is amazing! She's super nice and friendly! Not only is she super fast, she has a really good eye for detail. She will check and double check your hair cut. They will even style your hair afterwards, without an additional fee. Girls, don't be intimidated by all the men here. Girls are welcomed too! For $25, this was a great experience!

5.description: I left it to the Yelp universe to find a place to get a haircut and I was not disappointed! I called earlier in the day to make an appointment for 5pm. The receptionist was helpful and asked for my info and what I planned to get done. She asked if there was anyone in particular I wanted to do my hair, I shared just anyone that can cut long layers. I checked in at 5, and only waited a few minutes. I was then led by an attendant to wash my hair. He was super nice and also took my things to put into a locker. It was a spacious locker and you're able to lock it and hang onto the key. Your personal belongings are secured. I thought this was super efficient. . The shampooing was super relaxing. Loved the shampoo and conditioner they used. It was smell good stuff and it was therapeutic. After I washed my hair, I was led to the stylist. Her name was Lee. She was super nice. I showed her examples from Pinterest on what kind of look I was going for. She explained how much she was going to take off and what she was planning to do. Lee was very attentive and I really appreciate her attention to detail. I had her trim and re layered my hair. At the end, she shared how my hair looked like in the back and gave me some tips on how to take care of my hair. (I'm guilty of not properly taking care of hair) This salon also gives you a discount if you pay with cash. My hair wash, cut and style was only $29!! Can't beat that price! I almost paid $50 at another place. I tipped Lee $10 because she did an awesome job.I think I finally found my salon :)

3.description: Having moved here from NYC, I was looking for an Asian salon who knew how to cut thick wavy Asian hair.  Initially, my haircut and dye job was okay as he didn't do much.  But on my 2nd visit, he chopped my hair to smithereens and it took all this time to have my hair grown out.  Just exactly did Kit do?  He took the fish bone scissors that cuts out the fullness in hair, and took 3 chunks of my hair and cut straight across.  My hair was still long but the layers look horrendous.  Why did he do this?  Probably because I had a mass of hair on my head and he was just too lazy to take the time to layer the hair properly.  Never again!

35.description: This salon has become my permanent hair salon. I come here for all my styling and dyeing. Not once was I never satisfied. Everyone there makes me feel comfortable, i'm probably one of those that do not really like to talk much to the hairstylist so them not really checking on me much was not much of a deal to me. When i needed something they would assist. Other than that.... I've always looked for Steven, the one who always styles my hair. He's always been a great help with color selections and trimming my hair at ease. I always recommend friends and family and everyone is always satisfied with their haircut there. And recommend to the ones that read this comment who has stubborn black hair like I do as well. :]

19.description: Have been getting my haircut here for over a year now and they've never disappointed. Kit does a great job cutting hair and knows his stuff. As noted by others, you start with shampoo, conditioner, and a scalp massage before getting your hair cut. Afterwards they'll rinse your hair, dry, and style for you. FYI, they have lockers if needed to store a backpack or other items.

28.description: Will never go anywhere else for a trim. The shampoo stations cradle you like your childhood puppy and they have a stand to hold up your head so that you don't get a crick in the back of your neck. They have free lockers to store your purse or items.  The trim was professional and cheap - $25 for my long and layered white girl hair.The clientele is mostly Asian men, meaning that the cut has more style to it what you would get in a standard salon for men.  I was the only woman getting a trim when i was there (the stylist explained that women just get their hair cut less frequently). However, my accompanying manfriend got a great short on sides, long on the top hipster hair cut. Highly recommend for any man wanting an affordable, quality trim or wanting to punch up your hairstyle a bit.

45.description: Very disappointed. The lady cut minimally and when I asked her to make my hair thinner, she refused and said she can't do that because of the texture of my hair... it seems like I need another hair cut in 2 weeks ...

33.description: I came here to donate my hair- I was very nervous, but this was definitely the right place to go. They were very accomodating and fit us in even though we showed up an hour early. They washed my hair with some great smelling shampoo, and included a very relaxing head massage. Then, Kit went to work on my hair. If you are planning on a drastic change, I would highly recommend Kit. He cut off about 14 inches of my hair, but gave me a style that I am really loving. He cut it in such a way that it sits very nicely. I showed him a couple of pictures of styles I liked, and he was able to emulate them. I thought I would hate short hair but I ended up loving it! If you have asian hair, this is the place to go.The salon itself is very clean and visually appealing. They have lockers for you to store your things, as well as a coat rack. A cut and wash is very fairly priced, and they even offer a cash discount, so make sure you bring some. Definitely worth the trip to chinatown! Unfortunately, they do not validate parking.

43.description: Going into the salon I had a very full and beautiful body of hair but coming out it's like an amateur chopped it up into random pieces and I look like a 14 year old. I am a working professional. I should have known better from the moment when they tried to rush me to get my hair washed without telling me who is cutting my hair. A middle aged woman gave me the terrible haircut that I regret very much.STAY AWAY from the MIDDLE AGE WOMAN! She have no talent and the skills of an apprentice. She is not a stylist.

2.description: I moved to Chicago in August and I have already got my hair cut TWICE at B Square Salon (and it's only November...). When I moved here, I needed a haircut and I had no clue where to begin finding a place so I did end up finding this place through Yelp. I haven't made any appointments yet. I usually just make my way to Chinatown and tell them I'm walking in for a haircut. I have never waited more than 5 minutes yet. They'll give you a locker to put your belongings and here comes the best part...THE HAIR WASH! They give the nicest scalp massage/wash I have ever received in my life. It makes me want to fall asleep sometimes but I just sit there, close my eyes, and soak in the therapeutic feelings.Afterwards, they let me to the salon chair and I was assigned a hair stylist. I'm not Chinese so it almost seemed like we had a language barrier going on but I did bring some photos and a list of what I wanted done on my hair. This helped make the entire haircut experience more reliable and promising. I have never been disappointed with the haircuts I've received from B Square.I usually pay with cash, which comes along with a 10% discount. I am always paying between ~$29-$35 and this includes the tip. In my opinion, I think this is a pretty good deal. I will probably be coming back here for all my future haircuts.

18.description: The first time I went to B-Square Salon, I got a trim and a full dye for my graduation ceremony. I was extremely satisfied with the look and the price. However, I went for the second time in December, a few days before Christmas, and I wasn't satisfied at all. I specifically booked Kit again because he did wonders on my hair last time. I wanted him to dye my hair lighter than the color I had before and give my hair a small trim. When I book someone to help me get my hair done, I expect that person to do everything for my hair and not just pass the work on to someone else later. Kit just trimmed my hair then let another person dyed it. When everything was done, my hair came out to be super dark, darker than before I came in. I wanted to lighten my hair. Not make it even more darker than it already was. So I thought, maybe I'll give it a few weeks to let the color fade, but it only faded a little and I really hair dark hair on me. I like light brown hair. Aside from that, I thought the price would be cheap since last time I only paid 68 dollars for a trim and a color, but I was shocked when my bill turned up to be over 115 dollars without the 10% discount. I can't believe they charged me around 30-40 bucks for a 1 inch trim. I tipped generously, even though I wasn't satisfied with it. And because two people did my hair, I had to give tips to both of them which brings it to about more than 135 dollars for the finished look. I also paid for my sister's color and trim too. Her overall finish was more than my overall look. I had to go to the bank to get more cash because i thought it'll be like 68 dollars for one person. In total I spent around 250 bucks and coming from a poor, college student, it isn't worth it. Anyways, I'll just go back to my friend who also does a good job and charges less. I'll come back to B-Square, just not as frequent.

41.description: Matthew from B Squared is definitely my favorite hair stylist in Chicago!  I have never seen a hair stylist pay so much attention to detail during a cut and style.  Seriously, you can tell he's a perfectionist with his work.  He'll do a preliminary cut, and after seeing how the hair settles from the blowdry, he's back to the shears to perfect the style.  This works great for my hair, which can dry unruly or frizzy.  After his haircuts my hair settles into loose ringlets-- I highly recommend his work for curly hair!He also carries himself with a lot of professionalism, and I always feel super comfortable in his chair.  He'll ask lots of questions about your hair and give you haircare advice if he sees room for improvement, but he won't pressure you into buying products.  And if the conversation dies down, he doesn't try to fill silences with forced small talk.  He'll just let you relax and zone out, which-- let's be real-- is one of the best ways to spend a visit to the salon.

52.description: Pay in cash! 10% discount! :) When I get my hair cut, I don't like when the stylist talks too much, I just want to relax and have her/him concentrate on my hair. Thank goodness for the stylists at B Square. Friendly, yet not overbearing nor talkative. They do a great job at an awesome price ($29 cash). I've had Kit and Linda do my hair so far and I was happy with their work. I'm never going anywhere else!

50.description: Very good service, relatively clean and trendy inside. I wanted my hair thinner, and Sharon did exactly that! My head has never felt so light, but it still looks like normal. Got exactly what I wanted.

4.description: KIT IS YOUR MAN! Make sure to make an appointment with him if you want an awesome haircut! I've recommended 4 friends to him and they have had nothing but praises for him and all loved their haircuts! Definitely come here if you have Asian hair because they get it. Guys and ladies! It feels so good when they wash your hair and Kit is really good at giving you the hair style you want (it really helps if you bring a pic of what you want to show him). Haircuts are around $30 which is a great price! Cheaper if you pay cash. I've tried both B Square and Headquarters (which is across the street), and I would say that B Square is better because they've got Kit (who actually used to work at Headquarters).

6.description: I recently ombre'd my hair and it came out really nice! I dyed my hair a dark color years ago, so the process took about 6 hours to achieve the final look. Sharon and the staff at B Square are great.

22.description: Linda did an amazing job on my hair. I've been getting the same haircut for 10 years and it's a tricky one to get right. She gave me one of the best cuts I've had, in about half the time it sometimes takes - though these guys don't skimp on the scalp massages and shampoo! I felt like I got everything I needed and none of the stuff I didn't, all at an excellent value price. Can't be beat! I'll definitely be back to see Linda.

15.description: They fit me in without an appointment in the same day. Sharon did my up do and was very friendly and detailed in her work. I love my hair do!

57.description: Ask for Sharon! She's very particular and really takes her time to give you a nice haircut (though her English is limited). I'm used to going to Korean salons, and I had a miserable experience at Headquarters, so I didn't think I'd want to try this place out. But, this place is actually awesome (if you get the right stylist). They give you a 10% discount if you pay in cash, so that's $29 (+tip). Super affordable.

20.description: I loved my cut from Sharon! She knew exactly how to get me what I wanted. I'm usually really picky about my hair and stylist but I will definitely be back for one more cut before summer ends. When in doubt...just go with Sharon ;)

36.description: $24 for just a simple men's haircut with no hair washing is ridiculous in Chicago Chinatown. San Francisco Chinatown is only $5-7 for a men's haircut and the standard of living is higher and people there earn much more money. So it really doesn't make any sense at all for a place like this to charge $24 for a haircut that took less than 15 minutes. Also there is no prices shown on a sign or a board so it makes you question whether they are just arbitrarily charging whatever price they want at their own discretion.

14.description: I came here to donate my hair- I was very nervous, but this was definitely the right place to go. They were very accomodating and fit us in even though we showed up an hour early. They washed my hair with some great smelling shampoo, and included a very relaxing head massage. Then, Kit went to work on my hair. If you are planning on a drastic change, I would highly recommend Kit. He cut off about 14 inches of my hair, but gave me a style that I am really loving. He cut it in such a way that it sits very nicely. I showed him a couple of pictures of styles I liked, and he was able to emulate them. I thought I would hate short hair but I ended up loving it! If you have asian hair, this is the place to go.The salon itself is very clean and visually appealing. They have lockers for you to store your things, as well as a coat rack. A cut and wash is very fairly priced, and they even offer a cash discount, so make sure you bring some. Definitely worth the trip to chinatown! Unfortunately, they do not validate parking.

attributes.Hair Types Specialized In: Asian Hair, Curly Hair, Perms, Straight Perms, Coloring, Kids' Hair

1.description: Personally, I thought everything was just okay. The service, food, and decor was fine. I know that everything is pretty fresh because people are coming in and out all the time, which is a nice reminder.I had the pork with rice and soup. For me it wasn't that special, but the price was cheap for a meal. (5.50) I think next time I'll try something new else to see if I will like it more.

0.description: Our family loves the stir-fry eggplant, pork chops with seasoned salt, and the bbq duck and pork. We have been here at least 8 times over the years. It doesn't look like much from the inside, but it a good and consistent place that is low pressure with the kids and family-owned.

29.description: In both the Chinese and English dictionaries, Feida Bakery is simultaneously listed under the definitions of awesome and delicious.  Upon entering this relatively dingy and run down place, you're greeted by a marvelous display of Chinese carbs that will not leave you wanting. The sitting area in the back was filled with primarily Chinese patrons that appeared to be having a good time chatting, however, our mission was up front. Many a baked good was present in the glass case up front! On the left were the standard pork buns, cream buns, coconut buns, etc. All of which contribute to the delicious calorie filled afternoon we had upon leaving! We appreciate the different renditions of pork buns - both baked and steamed, in normal and XL sizes to boot! They're steaming said buns in the back room and often times will grab them for you out of the steamer. On the right side of the magical case lives the sweetness. We enjoyed some baby red bean moon cakes - holy awesome were those little dudes tasty!  Big enough for sharing, but small enough to eat a half dozen if you're down.This place is well worth checking out and leaves little to be desired. They only take cash so make sure you've got your friends Washington and Lincoln in tow. Most buns cost 70-90 cents so you can get plenty to share. Don't let the dilapidated exterior/interior/furniture fool you. this place craps gold! The seleciton is solid, the food delicious and the price fantastic!

42.description: I only come here for one thing only!  Winter melon cake!  In Cantonese, it literally translates to "Wife's pastry".  Feida has the biggest & heartiest winter melon cake out of all the bakeries in Chinatown.  It's a flat and round pastry that has a gooey and sweet center with a thick, doughy, yet flaky crust.  Always my favorite.  I don't eat anything else.

23.description: Stopped here for dessert after DimSum nearby.  My friends had been here before and RAVED about the sponge cakes and we "had to go get some this visit!"I obliged and am very glad we did.  The sponge cakes are amazing.  Light and fluffy but with a bit of crunch texture on the top from the browning!  De-Lish-ious!I also got a few sweet bean cakes which had a nice amount of filling and were incredibly flaky.  I will definitely go back to Feida's the next time I go to Chinatown!

47.description: The pork buns leave me wondering if they misread their recipe.  I ordered a bunch for a party and the sauce surrounding the meat was clumpy and the flavors just missed the mark.  The only reasons why I continue to satiate my bakery cravings at Feida is because the people there are really friendly and they do have pretty decent sesame red bean balls.  They're also slightly cheaper than their competitors (St. Anna's and Chiu Quon).

8.description: Western cakes are delicious without being very sweet.  typical of Asian deserts, which is light on sugar.  Chinese pastries made with bean pastes are really good.  Those BBQ crumble thingys, are oh so good, and still tasty after 30 seconds microwaved.  Don't care for their almond / chocolate cookies, too powdery, it's American cookie and it's obvious they didn't read Martha Stewarts cookbook.  Egg custard look amazing.  Rice and pork wrapped in lotus leaf is amazing, rice melts in your mouth and full flavors.  I heard they have more dim sum items in the back.  Can't wait to try.  Gem of a store.  Most things are under .70 cents.  Price is stuck in the 70's, so is the décor.  But who cares when food tastes this good.I read on Examiner there's a sitting room in the back full of local scenes. And you can order all the basic dimsum items and dine in. Will have to try that experience.  So we tried the back dinning room, selections were meager. Dim sum items not large and average quality. It's cheap though. If you can afford a bit more, go to one of the dim sum restaurants in chinatown. Feida shines in pastry.

31.description: Oh goodness the memories of this place that arise each time I come here. First thing you encounter is a small floor space with patrons ordering what they desire, almost all in Cantonese. They have large displays with all their pastries for display, all for very reasonable prices. Next to the displays is a refrigerator with beverages for purchase. Behind this room is a small dining room, usually frequented by old Chinese men congregating, chatting it up and drinking tea. My family frequent this bakery, and in my opinion they have the best pork buns in Chinatown. The pork filling is thicker, chunkier and has more texture, And the bread has a slightly firmer consistency. They also prepare cakes for special occasions, like weddings for example. In terms of decor, the walls are covered by photos of cakes they offer and a few newspaper articles featuring the bakery. Apart from the aforementioned, the place is pretty no frills, but it definitely harbours a homey/authentic aura. This place is also CASH ONLY!

34.description: Very dangerous place for a sugar addict. It's 10:30pm and I'm having euphoric recall of their baby moon cakes. If I keep this up I'll be 500lbs.

16.description: Stopped here for dessert after DimSum nearby.  My friends had been here before and RAVED about the sponge cakes and we "had to go get some this visit!"I obliged and am very glad we did.  The sponge cakes are amazing.  Light and fluffy but with a bit of crunch texture on the top from the browning!  De-Lish-ious!I also got a few sweet bean cakes which had a nice amount of filling and were incredibly flaky.  I will definitely go back to Feida's the next time I go to Chinatown!

13.description: Restaurant reviewThis was a prior bakery owned by my grandfather so I have many fond memories of this place and eating the food. It has a wide selection of chinese pastry and cakes. Our birthday cakes use to come from here and were made in the typical asian way with fruit cocktail and soft sponge cake. You can also get some dimsum which is made fresh everyday. Overall I am just okay because there is nothing super exciting to eat but maybe I am biasedPro: large selection of chinatown bakery itemCons: noneHidden gem:  none

11.description: I come all the way from Kenosha, Wisconsin. I always call and order ahead so they always have my order ready when I come to pick up. The baked bbq pork buns is on hit!! I have also tried their pinaaple buns which was also very good. Dim sum wise, har gow has always been good here, sui mei too. Pheonix claws aka. chicken feet in black bean sauce is ok. My only gripe was the steam rice rolls.....twice I have gotten them and they barley have any filling in them. The last time they even forgot the speical soy sauce that comes with it. I had gotten 4 orders of beef and four orders of the shrimp, again barley any filling in them and no sauce. You have to understand with out that special soy, its very bland. I should have checked to make sure about the sauce, but barely any filling?? That was the only thing i won't order again, but everything else was excellent. Try the steam rice in lotus leaves....nice!!!

39.description: As a  self appointed Ham and Egg Connoisseur Feida has the best!  Huge thick slice of ham layered with an equally thick layer of egg baked inside a slightly sweet bun with a slight egg wash for shine! YUM!  also try their "Dai Bao" a steam bun with black mushroom, chinese sausage, egg and pork filling.

37.description: This used to be my go to place to stock up on buns before I head back to school. Their buns are ok, best in the morning when fresh (duh).

0.description: This is a must stop for me whenever I'm in Chinatown. I like this place, because their pastries are reasonably priced and fresh. I take so much back each time they always seem surprised I need 3 large boxes. haha My favorites: Sweet Top Bun, Custard Sweet Top Bun, Coconut Sweet Top Bun, BBQ Pork Bun, Egg Tart, Bean Paste Cake, Lotus Paste Cake, and Ham & Onion Bun.** Note CASH ONLY

38.description: I have only had one experience with this bakery: they did the wedding cake for my chinese wedding reception. It was a fairly painless experience considering my mom's Chinese is basic and mine is nonexistent. The woman we worked with was friendly enough and they have a book of photos to choose your cake from. They were able to modify the cake we picked (adding decorative things) and it was no problem. The best part was that they were right across the street from our venue (Triple Crown) so they delivered it before I even arrived for the banquet. It was beautiful... they did a great job. The cake was good... but I prefer the American style cakes; heavy cake, thick frosting as opposed to the very light Chinese style. Trust them with your special occassion.  They do a great job.

27.description: This is my go to bakery when I visit from Milwaukee. This place has amazing baked goods for a reasonable price. They have a good selection to. But remember to bring cash because that's all that they accept!

32.description: Straight up Chinese bakery. You walk in and there is a stack of free Chinese newspapers (no Red Eye here!). Inside there is a glass case with Chinese baked goods. It's not dressed up with cute cupcakes or cookies like contemporary American bakeries. Patrons push their way to the register (mostly speaking Chinese) and place their orders (cash only).There is a refrigerated case with cool beverages. There is a room in the back with tables for eating, but I'm not sure if it's a restaurant or not. I've never looked back there. In my "Joy Luck Club" imagination old, Chinese women play mahjong and gossip.I've been going to Feida Bakery since before I could remember. My mom always got large white boxes filled with barbecue pork buns ($1 each) and I would get a clear, plastic container of sesame balls. Sometimes we would get sweet desserts or fried taro root (a family favorite). It's definitely not a cute or even friendly place, but it feels comfortable and authentic. No frills - just business. Fortunately, Feida Bakery is good at it's business!

48.description: Huge sweet red bean buns and heavenly sponge cakes. Place always reminds me of Robert Deniro in Midnight Run.

44.description: Do not come here for pork buns. Someone in my company brought some in for the Chinese New Year and they are the worst I have ever had. First off the bread tasted too sweet, kind of the Hawaiian Rolls you get at the grocery store. And, the meat was way off. I should have stopped when I saw the color, it was odd and very dull pink (not appetizing), the meat was really chunky, and it had a weird cinnamon flavor. Well, maybe it wasn't cinnamon, but it had one of those sweet/spicy flavors that is not expected when you bite into a pork bun. Just plain icky! I can only speak about the pork buns. I will say that I think may be too afraid to try anything else.

24.description: hamamma buns! the tea here is hotter than any tea served anywhere ever. I always stop in when I'm in Chinatown.

7.description: Great almond cookies, not too sweetEverything else looked delicious

49.description: This bakery is located just a few storefronts from the more renowned Chiu Quon. Feida is perhaps a shade below its neighbor, but they have a pretty decent selection of the Chinese bakery items. The BBQ pork buns and square dinner rolls are mainstays, but I am not as fond of their egg custard tarts.

40.description: Oh Feida, you are fantastic.From the smokey back room filled with elderly Chinese men shooting the breeze, to your homemade signs, the dingy walls, scuffed floors and broken down refrigerator you are what dreams are made of. The pastries are delectable, from the Custard Bun to the BBQ Pork Bun, this is where Bao makes you go "Wow". A "must-try" is that of their "Cocktail Bun". It is an oval bun filled with a creamy coconut mixture that will delight you. (It is typically located to the left of the register on the bottom shelf.)They are also notable for their Dim Sum -- particularly that of their Siu Mai (See-yew My) a tasty ground pork "dumpling" that is mixed with shitake mushrooms and a delicate wonton wrapper. They are best taken to go, and re-steamed at home. If you are adventurous, however -- their spare ribs in black bean sauce and chicken feet are some of the best.People need to realize that the fortune cookie, the almond cookie and cake are all fanciful notions that were not developed in China. If you want to have fantastic Americanized and European pastries, then please take the Red Line away from "China" town. Feida is a must-see for me every time that I make it downtown. They have great prices, incredibly nice workers, and their food is simply fantastic. While you're there be sure to try their homemade soy bean milk. They brew it for hours and it really is a sweet sweet treat.

30.description: This place seems to be the real deal. The front part is chock-full of delicious-looking items, from pastries to meat-filled buns, to breads. In the back is a run-down dining room full of Chinese folks hanging out. I'll be back.

46.description: Extremely small bakery run by an extremely nice lady.  The baked goods are solid, but not the best that Chinatown has to offer.However, if you're going for pure calorie per dollar intake, you can stuff your face with two giant pork buns for just about $2!  Sure beats the dollar menu at Wendy's!

1.description: I came in on a snowy, windy, balls-would-be-frozen-if-I-had-a-pair weather for bubble tea, so this review is strictly for their bubble tea.  They said they served warm bubble tea, so I ordered the regular flavor only to get a lukewarm "bubble tea" of what tasted like a concoction made up of nothing but water and sugar.  The only plus is that the bubbles were chewy and for $3.50 you get get a real big cup (albeit the contents are barely drinkable).I should have listened to the lady next door who recommended going across the street to the strip mall on the other side--but I must reiterate that the weather outside was quite intimidating (and plus I had just walked over from that side after somehow missing the bubble tea shop).  But yeah, dont come here for the bubble tea.  I guess my years of living in Rockville, MD gave me the expectation that all Asian bakeries served not only delicious pasteries, but also tasty bubble tea.  Not the case here.

9.description: Love this place, amazing steamed pork buns for like a dollar each.  Plus if you come in on like a Sunday night, they'll have some left over dim sum items from the day they sell for really cheap

26.description: I love coming to this bakery if I'm on my way back from school and I need a quick and cheap bite to eat. Most of the buns are around a dollar, which is a steal because you can make a meal outta 2 bucks. Some of my favorites are the BBQ pork buns and pork floss buns with green onion and mayo on top. The bakery also sells moon cakes, mousse cakes and a limited selection of dim sum items. One of my favorites are the taro puffs, which are only $0.75 and they're huge! Moral of the story: if you're broke and there isn't a McDonald's value menu available...head to Feida Bakery.

25.description: I prefer the bakery a few buildings down. I've seen some not so fresh items here before.

12.description: Straight up Chinese bakery. You walk in and there is a stack of free Chinese newspapers (no Red Eye here!). Inside there is a glass case with Chinese baked goods. It's not dressed up with cute cupcakes or cookies like contemporary American bakeries. Patrons push their way to the register (mostly speaking Chinese) and place their orders (cash only).There is a refrigerated case with cool beverages. There is a room in the back with tables for eating, but I'm not sure if it's a restaurant or not. I've never looked back there. In my "Joy Luck Club" imagination old, Chinese women play mahjong and gossip.I've been going to Feida Bakery since before I could remember. My mom always got large white boxes filled with barbecue pork buns ($1 each) and I would get a clear, plastic container of sesame balls. Sometimes we would get sweet desserts or fried taro root (a family favorite). It's definitely not a cute or even friendly place, but it feels comfortable and authentic. No frills - just business. Fortunately, Feida Bakery is good at it's business!

21.description: I recently went to Feida for the cheong funn roll and it had fish bones in it. The lady behind the counter thought I was not Chinese until I complained to her. I am not coming back here for any cheong funn( rice flour rolls).

17.description: I prefer the bakery a few buildings down. I've seen some not so fresh items here before.

10.description: The only reason I'm giving Feida, 4 stars is because of not taking credit cards but that's completely the norm in Chinatown. As for the baked goods, it's personal preference for most but this is by far one of the best Chinese bakery/pastry shops I've visited.  I travel to Chicago a few times a year and I make every effort I can to make it to pick up specifically one thing: Wife's Cake (lo poa baing).  My mom has informed me these are some of the best and biggest pastries you'll ever find of this cake and it's better than what she remembers from Hong Kong. I do get many of the other pastries: the bao varieties (cha siu bao, gai mei bao, bo lo bao), egg custard tarts, cake rolls, cookies, moon cakes ( when in season) and they are all consistently good and tasty, every visit.This is a must stop location in Chinatown.

5.description: I don't know if this is normal for bakeries in Chinatown, but this place has the biggest chocolate chip cookies I've ever seen in my life. Unfortunately my sister and I kept tasting things in the cookie that didn't taste like "cookie" lol. At first it kind of tastes like a dinner roll, and then there's a hint of a chicken taste.. I don't know if that was just that particular batch, but I won't be trying any more of their sweets. For 70 cents after tax though, it's worth trying. The smoothies are good, pretty standard. They don't have lychee though.

3.description: I always come here to get Pineaaple buns whenever I'm in Chinatown. I like the butter cookie style topping and the red bean paste filling. The bread is really soft and buttery and not as sweet as western bread. I also love the cream roll, which is filled by sweet and salty butter cream which is I missed a lot fromChina and is different from American whipping cream or the bitter cream topping for cupcakes.However it's cash only and not good for dine-in b/c the seats are usually packed and it's kinda loud inside.

35.description: taro cake, wintermelon cake, etc. for a quick breakfast.

19.description: Their winter melon are big compared to the other bakeries. The fruit tart wasn't too sweet and the fruits were fresh, but majority of it was just whipped cream but the tart tasted burnt. The sugar cake is tasteless to me, but my grandpa would disagree because he think Feida's white sugar cake taste like ''real'' white sugar cake. The éclair was a disappointment and not only was it hard, but there was no cream filling and the whip cream on top was sour! The dark chocolate was the only decent thing about that éclair. I am addicted to their cheesecake. The filling in their apple turnover is sweeter than the apple pie from Chiu Quon, but at least it is not baked too flaky.

28.description: came back last week to pick up 2 wintermelon cakes and a walnut cookie.looks the same.

45.description: The cakes here are pretty and that's it. Most asian cakes are light on the sugar anyways but besides being almost sugar less tasting, it's also flavorless. I dumped all my pretty cake slices in the trash after a bite. Don't bother, it's just eye candy.

33.description: Feida may not necessarily e the best, it depends solely on personal preference. There are plenty of bakeries that offer the same pastries and buns but with it's own touch and uniqueness. My choice in feida stems from their consistency and service. The lady has always been nice and I always know what to expect. The taste is something that I've grown to love, but again, each person's taste is different

43.description: I came here because the restaurant that I went to for lunch didn't give me a fortune cookie. So I saw those huge almond cookies from the window and I had to get some. I also got a couple slices of white chocolate cake. Hmm. I think that I would pass on both. The cake had no taste and it had some kind of gelatin in it? The whip cream on top was hard and the cake was way to spongy. The cookies were also bland. Do you have to pay extra for the taste? The presentation was fantastic though.

2.description: I'll have to keep updates on Feida because of new ownership.I currently like this place because their bakery goods are fresh and reasonably priced. I like their dim sum options too and their Cheong Fun (long rice noodles) are really tasty as their beef meatballs and steamed garlic ribs. My mother who resides in the area is always in the know on the best bakeries and restaurants around and lately she has been recommending me here when I come down. Their BBQ pork buns and egg custard buns are their mainstays. DON'T forget CASH ONLY!!

18.description: This is my mom's favorite bakery so I've been coming here since I was a kid. I love their crystal shrimp dumplings and their shu mai is absolutely the best around. If you love buns, this is the place for you! There are buns everywhere and every kind of bun is equally represented from the traditional hot dog buns to ever popular red bean paste buns. If buns are on your mind, pop in and satisfy your craving. I usually buy at least a dozen of their XL siopao as they basically serve as a meal each. Place is dirt cheap too, $0.90 for a bun and $1.70 for an order of shrimp dumplings= MEAL! If that's not a win, I'm not sure what is anymore...

41.description: Preserved Duck Egg Cakes.  I can't get enough of them, although if you want to eat the entire thing, I'd advise you to go in the morning right after they're put out on the shelf and still warm.  Otherwise, if you have a Western palate you'll probably upchuck.  If I buy them at the end of the day, I'll automatically scoop out the little glob of black egg and just eat the rest.  Also, their Wintermelon Cakes and BBQ Pork Buns are great!  For the people who gave this bakery bad reviews based on failures in conventional Western baked goods--go to Dinkel's.  For anyone looking for really cheap eats and interesting new flavors, this is a decent spot to start.

4.description: Fun real Chinatown experience. We were the only non Chinese there and the server barely spoke English. It was cheap and tasty though most of the menu choices weren't available. The place wasn't too friendly which was the only downside.

6.description: After someone's recommendation, I decided to walk over to Old Chinatown and see what she really liked about Feida. As recommended, I got the coffee and the steamed bun. The bun and coffee was good but not spectacular.Since I really like savory bread, I got some roasted pork bun and curry beef to go. Since I ordered two of each and I gave 2 of them to a friend (who is leaving town) thinking we'd get 2 of each. Nope, I ended up getting two curry beef and my friend ended up getting two roasted pork bun.The amount of meat in my bun was really tiny. It was also a little lopsided. One section completely do not have any meat in it. Anyway, I still gave them another try. I ordered the roast pork bun the next time I went in. Again, same thing happened-- tiny amount of meat that is lopsided. Also, the bread is a little dry too.I really tried liking this place but in the end I went away disappointed. I end up pining for my days where I lived close to Rockville, MD.

22.description: After a great lunch at Triple Crown (yelp.com/biz/triple-crow…), its always best to walk across the street and buy a box-full of pastries from Feida.  You can tell Feida is the best Chinatown bakery completely due to the crowd inside at almost all times.  My favorites are the flaky thin Winter Melon Cakes, the slightly sweet Gai Ma Bao (coconut bun), and the Honey Noodle Cake (a better version of a Rice Crispy Treat).At all times, they have dozens of different bakery items - cookies, bao, cakes, cake rolls, and everything in between.  And!!  Almost everything in the case of pastries is under $1, and you just can't beat that.  At that price, you just have to walk out with a box full of pastries.Simple, delicious, cheap.  A great finish to a meal, and a great way to end a visit to Chinatown in Chicago.Here's another tip:  They actually have some dim sum items as well - we normally pick up a few frozen orders of Siu Mai to take home and steam later that night.

15.description: I can't say that I was impressed by any of my goodies. They just didn't have any flavor. The prices were really cheap,  however.  I wish them the best though.

20.description: hate this place because they don't serve customers in order. very annoyed (I was in the middle of asking for what i wanted and this jerk interrupted me and spoke to the lady in chinese who ended up taking his money and order, after i had already waited through someone else's out-of-turn order) and took it out on their yelp profile.

36.description: This is a good bakery to go to if you can't make it to Archer Ave. and only have time to spend on Wentworth Ave.  Their hot-dog buns are delicious!  Their almond cookies are as big as your head!  Very inexpensive.

14.description: When I'm in the city, I always have to stop by Feida for a box of Char Sui Bao (Roast Pork Buns) to take back home with me. The sweetness of the yeasty roll with the salty sweetness of the roast pork is just about perfect.Nearly every other pastry/roll/cake I've tried here has been lovely. Altogether a great place to stop in.

58.description: Completely awful.  My wife placed an order from lao hunan at 7:15.  At 8:11 the delivery person called and said he was 2 minutes away.  He didn't arrive for 14 minutes.  When the food arrived, there was no sauce for the crab rangoon (usually comes with sweet and sour sauce and mustard sauce, according to the restaurant itself) or the mu shu pork.  She called the restaurant, and they said the delivery person had the sauce in the car and he would turn around and deliver it in 5 minutes.  10 minutes later, my wife called the restaurant again because he hadn't arrived.  The delivery man did not, in fact, have the sauce in the car, but went back to the restaurant to get it.  They then said it would be another 20 minutes at the least to get the sauce.  The manager then blamed the distance from our home to the restaurant for the reason for the delay, told the delivery person not to bring us our sauce, and hung up on her.What we did eat wasn't very good either.  But maybe that was because it was cold and soggy.

56.description: If you're looking for something to satisfy your savory umami cravings, this is the place. While the food is a bit greasy, you may read that this is intentional Hunan style. My family tried several dishes which were shared on a lazy Susan. Chairman Mao's pork belly was a favorite. I like to try new things but the generals chicken was probably the best I've had and a very safe choice. The pot stickers are also excellent.

29.description: We came as a group of 12. The restaurant was really good about accommodating our large group and allowed us to combine two large tables together (instead of all of us sitting at one table).We ordered:Dry Chili String Beans Hunan-StyleEggplant Casserole Sichuan-StyleLamb with Cumin PowderChairman Mao`s Favorite Pork BellyStir-Fried Squid in Black Bean SauceTomato & Green Pepper BeefThe food was delicious. I did not think it was overly greasy however the taste was more on the spicy and salty side. I was very thirsty after the dinner was over.The restaurant is easy to get to via the CTA Red line.

42.description: Not spicy at all, Mao's pork is too sweet!!!

23.description: I ordered takeout when my usual Chinatown spot was closed for remodeling. It was an empty night for the restaurant and my order was quickly ready. Am I ever glad I discovered this spot. I think I may have found my new regular takeout spot. I got lucky with my order and was transported back to my childhood. This was the most delicious beef brisket noodle soup I've found so far in Chicago. I'm no seasoned foodie, but have tried quite a few places in and out of Chinatown. The broth was perfect, not too spicy that I did not find myself distracted by huffing to cool down my tongue. The noodles were tasty and just firm and chewy enough. I was not disappointed. It reminded me of the kiosk on my street when I lived in Harbing and ate beef noodle soup every weekend. I also ordered the spicy wood ear salad and chili beef tendon appetizers. Both were perfectly flavored and delicious. My hunny ordered kung pao chicken and vegetable fried rice as he usually does from any Chinese restaurant we visit. He prefers the kung pao from our usual spot in Chinatown, but Lao Hunan's was a close second. I suppose from this one experience, I could say they score much higher on the authentic Chinese side of the menu. I can't wait t come back and try some more items from the menu. They have a great variety of meats and veggies I don't see often offered at other Chinese places. Thanks for a quick trip down memory lane. I'll be back to do it again soon.
