47.description: Since the rave reviews by TIme Out in 2013, this place has fallen on hard times.  The mural with General Mao is peeling from the wall, the paint is chipping, dishware was mismatched and both the dining room and bathroom were dirty.  Don't leave the kitchen door open so patrons could watch the elderly & barefooted woman sitting on a crate picking through snap peas that she is dropping in a metal bowl positioned on the floor. The food was ok.  The pork belly was tasty but do people really eat wide gelatinous pieces of fat?  I felt as if is the server was blocking our exit while my husband went to the restroom and before we could pay our bill.   My kids liked the lazy susan on the table.  I think overall Chinatown has fallen on hard times, Wentworth street itself was filthy and cluttered with litter and garbage.  Rahm needs to send some garbage trucks over there.

8.description: This is one of, if not the worst, pretty bad restaurants I've ever had food from in a while. About two years ago, I was here and their food was actually good, but after today's meal, no more at this place. Not to mention I had to wait an hour to get my food, the ingredients used in dishes were absolutely disgusting. The place has changed from a 4 star authentic Chinese restaurant to a 1-2 star American Chinese restaurant. Not sure what happened but with many other great choices around the area, why sticking to this place?

31.description: Not fancy, but the best food in Chinatown!  Be sure to try the chili green beans and all of the soups are great.  Be patient as when it's crowded the food may arrive one dish at a time.  But, it's worth the wait.

34.description: Bow down to chairman Mao. The first thing you notice as you enter this small restaurant is a large Mao Zedong plastered on the wall. The waiters all dress in green long sleeve shirts and pants. Our large group was seated immediately, and water & tea were quickly brought out. The waiters were very attentive and always made sure to refill waters and the teapot. We ordered several dishes to share. Our favorites were the walnut shrimp and the spicy, fried chicken. Although the food was not the best, authentic Chinese food I've had, it's tasty and reasonably priced.

16.description: The food was fresh and perfectly prepared.  Our waitress was friendly, attentive, and helpful. She gave great suggestions based on what we were looking for. We will definitely return to further explore the menu.

13.description: The quality has really gone down since the change in ownership. They have the same dishes as before, but they just don't cut it! I now have to find a new go-to Chinese restaurant.

11.description: Lao Hunan does not exist anymore. The number rings the new restaurant and the staff pretends that it is the same but do not let that fool you. Lao Hunan had great, authentic food and I loved going there while it existed. I came here thinking wondering why the name changed and if the management/chefs had actually changed and boy was it different. We had 3 standard dishes that we've gotten a million times: the jade tofu, sichuan style green beans and your fried noodles (basically veggie fried lo-mein). The green beans were edible but not right. The lo-mein had chicken in it which I would think even a bad restaurant can at least get your order right but were just shy of inedible. It had to much soy sauce not much other flavor, almost no veggies and chicken doused in so much soy sauce it didn't have much taste other than salty.  The jade tofu was awful, absolutely dismal, I don't even know what they were trying to do because it tasted nothing like the jade tofu they had in the past. We also tried something new, pork with chayote squash which was also terrible. I don't know how you can ruin chayote squash because it's pretty delicious just sautéed with some oil and salt and pepper but this was over peppered and over cooked. The pork tasted sketchy like it was going off. We left it was so bad even though I was starving and had just gotten to the city from a road trip. In addition when I went to pay they claimed their card machine wasn't working and asked to take my number and run it later. Um no, seemed scammy. Now I feel sick, hope I don't have food poisoning.  Terrible experience.

39.description: On another visit here, some slight changes: the menu situation is better, only the hard cover version remains (there is a small card with specials on the table; no more complimentary small appetizer of pickled veg given this time; and only one large bowl of steamed white rice was given (it accompanied the fish filet dish). I'm certain more rice would have been available if we'd needed it. Since it was a late lunch (3 PM), we stayed with Chairman Mao's Favorite Pork Belly, but this time complimented that with fish filets stir-fried with mixed vegetables. Both were excellent!

37.description: Ordered food because all the good reviews.  We ordered a side of pan fried noodles with our shrimp dish, beef dish and two sides. Delivery driver got here and told us our side of pan fried noodles were 8.95.  Not only were they overpriced but they were greasy and hard to the point of being inedible. I tried to get my money back. Delivery driver called the restaurant. He was told to give me two dollars back. I ended up paying 6.95 for noodles that no human could possibly eat. Woman was rude on the phone. I told her to let the driver take the noodles and refund my money. She refused. That will be the last time we order from there.

0.description: I can't believe that food can be this delicious. The crispy Hunan eggplant is one of the most memorable dishes I've ever tasted. I wanna go here on my birthday.

38.description: This place was alright for my first trip to Chinatown. My Chinese friend from the Hunan province brought me here as this was a taste of his countryside. He ordered for us and got an appetizer of Fu Qi Fei Pian (beef maw, lung, and tendon - served cold), Chairman Mao's Pork Belly, and  Sichuan String Beans. The food overall was satisfying. There was nothing magical about it but it tasted good (even the maw dish though I wouldn't order it again as I'm not a fan of the rubbery texture of those animal parts). The belly was cooked tender with a typical mash up of bell peppers and onions though if fat (cooked very tender not rubbery) is not something you can stomach then you should probably pass as practically every bite is a bit of tender fat and beef (that's pork belly folks!). The green beans were very good, served with yummy bits of sauteed garlic and ginger. So if your looking for a suggestion, I would definitely try the green beans out, after all there veggies so you can eat them guilt free, right? ;)Prices are basically what you typically expect, ~$10 for entrees.Happy eating.

51.description: The service was good and fast, the food was fine. We started with Fu Qi Fei Pian, then ordered Spicy Chicken in Hot Wok, Stir Fried Pork Country Style, and Boiled Fish Fillet in Spicy Sichuan Sauce. I think their flavor was between Sichuan style and Hunan style, neither very spicy or very hot... maybe we need to try some authentic Hunan dishes (such as Famous Steamed Fish Hunan Style)... Well, it's a good place to try, but just for the time I'm carving spicy food and no other choices to go...

27.description: Horrible restaurant.I've been to Lao Hunan TWICE and both times I was extremely disappointed. This time I went with two friends. Right when we stepped into the restaurant, the waitress hurried towards us while screaming: "TWO? TABLE FOR TWO?!", I thought that was not a nice welcome. Once we sat down we realized it was TOO hot, we asked the waitress to adjust the heat but she was like "not bossible, solly!". Few mins later another bothered guest got up and turned the heat off through the central digital thermostat. Really was not that hard!Our waitress hardly spoke any English, which I usually expect when going to an ethnic restaurant but this one LITERALLY did not understand anything we were saying. I wanted to ask about the ingredients and the spiciness, but just ended up pointing at the image and ordering. It took too long for the food to come (while all ordered together, the time difference between the first and last dish was about 35 mins!), so I basically had already finished my food when my friend's food was just being served.Only two waitresses were serving the entire busy restaurant WHILE taking delivery orders over the phone and taking care of carry-outs. No smiling. No patience. Beyond ridiculous.Will never step foot into that place again! Hossam

32.description: Slow delivery with missing food....... When I called to see if I could get my missing food delivered, the lady on the phone tried unbelievably to convince me that the missing food was actually in the bag.  Then she said they were closed and hung up on me.  As a final insult, the food that did actually arrive was cold and soggy.

54.description: We decided to have our Mother's Day brunch here after going to see the Shen Yun Chinese ballet.If you've seen or heard of this ballet, you'll probably see where I'm going with this. The dancers in this ballet have been exiled because it's so risque.  The whole thing is a giant political jab designed to challenge the communistic regime so the irony of going to Lao Hunan was about as off-color as cultural juxtapositions come.Everything here is decorated with images from the Cultural Revolution era in China. Giant images of Chairman Mao grace the walls, while the hosts and waiters are all dressed in era-appropriate getups.  If they weren't selling art and collectibles at the surrounding shops you might even forget that you weren't in the midst of a mass-rejection of cultural and traditional Chinese elements.Awkward!Food-wise, you really can't go wrong with any of the Lao (Tony Gourmet) restaurants. This one seems slightly more laid back - no need to dress up - and best at fried foods. YUM!We ordered the crispy eggplant, which was perfectly seasoned, crispy on the outside, and tender (not mushy) on the inside. If you know someone who doesn't like eggplant, you may want to run this one past them... it might change their mind.We also ordered the pork belly, which was prepared with this really lovely sweetish sauce, that makes my mouth water just thinking about it.TLDR: Mao/Red Army themed. Get the pork belly and crispy eggplant. Lots of fried options. Don't wear a tux.

48.description: Expensive for Chinese therefore some people might be turned off by them but got the Spicy Chicken in Hot Wok and I was very happy. Good spiciness and the lemongrass flavor comes through. Tons of garlic too...I love garlic.My friend got chicken and veges and portion was for two and it was pretty good. Depends what you are looking for but it's a nice place to try and flavors are very good.

44.description: The Great Leap Forward theme is interesting. However the food.... If my dad who is from Hunan knows someone provide Hunan dishes with sugar added, he will def go crazy =.=  I know American people would like Chinese food with sugar, but Hunan cuisine, unlike that of many other parts of China, never ever do that. For the chef: if you want something spicy but sweet, pls do Szechuan, not Hunan. Unlike many other restaurants in Chinatown, Lao Hunan is all the way far from authentic.I had Famous Steamed Fish Hunan Style, Chairman Maos Favorite Pork Belly, and Preserved Beef with Dried White Chili. The fish was awful, it's a strange Cantonese style Hunan dish. The Hunan style chili paste 剁椒酱 is under flavored, not spicy and salty at all (using Hunan standard). I'm not quite sure but my tongue did tell me they even put some Cantonese style steam-fish-soy-sauce 蒸鱼豉油 in it...The pork belly is the worst Chairman Mao's Pork Belly I've ever had. They neither have the meat seared enough nor flavored enough as normal Hunan cuisine, which made this dish oily and plain.The only authentic dish was the beef, though it was below average. Actually one of my Hunan classmates brought some dry white chili from home to the U.S., and it tastes better.

24.description: This is probably one of the best Chinese restaurants in Chicago. I've been here many times including last Saturday.They offer genuine Chinese food which is served in a speedy fashion. I really recommend it. Note most food is quite spicy - just you know.

7.description: I went back after a long time looking for Lao Hunan but it is now called Chef Bao Szechuan, which is also a different cuisine and menu. We decided to give it a try regardless and while it does not disappoint it's not great. The portions are good and the service is great and pleasant. We tried 9 different dishes and all were good except for the pork. All the pork dishes tasted quite strong similar to old meat which left a bad taste at the end and went uneaten by all after a bite. Perhaps next time we will only order chicken and beef.

49.description: The food here is interesting, but the service was awful. Fried duck with chilie and seafood soup with ginger was flavorful but a little potent. The pork belly was a 90% glob of fat; just fat and skin. We also ordered eggplant casserole which had vinegar flavor in it. We asked the lady why it had a vinegar flavor, she just got pissed and told us that everything that says "ground pork" has vinegar (dont know what to say to that, but I dont think it is true). Anyway, service bad. Food okay. Nothing to brag about. There's plenty of other resturant around the corner with similar food and slightly better service.

40.description: I have been to this restaurants three times...  The first two times were ok....  The food were delicious even though the service is awful and the place is dirty. The last time was just  plain disgusting......       We ordered the spicy fish dish, fried vegetable, crawfish and fried rice.... There was a human hair in the spicy fish dish. ...Fried vegetable has sand in it.. (tons of sands in your mouth when you tried to chew )Crawfish has plastic cable ( about six inches ) And, that is not even the worst part. ... The worst part is when  I tired to explain our lovely situation to the waitress, she literally ignored us..  ( she simply left when I was talking to her about the human hair.. ) Oh yeah, she did not forget to add 15 % tip to our bill though...         :) Please, do yourself a favor and don't ever go there... you will hate yourself for doing so....

53.description: I came across this place by searching on yelp. This restaurant is located in Chinatown, a small hole in the wall type of restaurant. But that doesn't mean they can't cook up a mean batch of Chinese goodness. First of all, the portions are HUGE. Secondly, it packs major flavor.  This has to be the best Chinese food I've ever had. Highly recommended.

30.description: Not fancy, but oh so delicious. The "Jade tofu" arrived gratis and was amazing! So flavorful! Tons of garlic. And the cumin beef was over the top. Egg roll, not so much. Green beans Hunan style were well prepared, tasty. So many fabulous looking dishes passed the table that I wanted to stick my fork in each one. (Shrimp is in the plan for next visit!) great layout on the menu, too; easy to understand. Not especially fast service, but it was Christmas Day and the were slammed. I will definitely go back.

46.description: We just ordered take out and it was terrible. Sweet and sour chicken was not crispy. The chicken fried rice was bland.

1.description: I went into Lao Hunan with high expectations. I am not sure if it was the specific dish I ordered or the day, but I was not wowed with this restaurant as I thought I would have been.One thing I can say is that this place is 100% authentic. It reminded me of when I was studying abroad and would have had authentic Chinese food. The rice was perfectly made. The sauces were fresh as well.I ordered a set of pot stickers and spicy pork dish with dry chilis. HOLY SPICY!!First, the pot stickers were piping hot. Which I enjoyed. I loved the seasoning of the inside. I also loved the sauce that came with the dish.The pork dish is what fell a little flat for me. It was not bad by any means, but in comparison of the other restaurants in chinatown I have visited, I was not WOWed. The pork itself was very tender, but there were no other veggies on the dish. And the dish was filled with chillis. I just could not wrap my head around the fact that the pork to chili ratio was underwhelming to say the least. I also was not too thrilled that they gave me one small bowl of rice for a big plate of the entree. My waitress was very nice. And her adorable son also filled the place with laughter and it reminded me again of being back abroad. If I do return I will try something else. I didnt hate my experience but I did not love it.

55.description: I am not a big fun of chinese food. My stomach is very sensitive, and I think it's really greasy, so I  try to avoid it. My friend told me a lot  about this place, and finally she invited me over and ordered ALL  the most popular items (crazy girl). Everything was VERY tasty. I ate a lot, tried as much as I could and felt very good  after lunch. I don't know what is the trick, probably an oil and meat which they use are really high quality. Best chinese food I have ever tried!

9.description: Went here this past Saturday for the first time, and my mind was blown. I knew I would be in for a treat when I saw that Tony Hu was behind this place, and I wasn't dissapointed. A few highlights:1. FYI this place does not say "Lao Hunan" on the outside, I forget what it says but it's definitely not Lao Hunan so it was a little hard to find. We asked the waitresses about the new name and they said it's because they expanded their menu to include food not just from the Hunan region. A tad confusing considering their website still says Lao Hunan, and all their decor inside the restaurant is still Chinese army themed.2. BYOB- this a huge plus, and we seemed to be the only ones in the restaurant who knew this. Again, it's not really advertised.3. We ordered the kung pao chicken, sweet and sour soup, wonton soup, some sort of boiled beef in spicy broth, dry chili beef, Hunan pork belly, and another beef dish which I can't remember but was also good. There wasn't a single bad thing we ordered. They laid out kimchi, peanuts, pickled vegetables, a hot horseradish mustard and sweet and sour sauce for dipping and adding to our dishes. Also ordered crab rangoon appetizer because yes, this is an authentic Chinese restaurant, but who doesn't love crab rangoons?Wait staff was very friendly, we did not have to wait for a table, and the food was very good. We each got an appetizer or soup, and split 5 entrees amongst 5 people and it was only 17$ a person! Very affordable and worth the trip on the red line.

26.description: I came here before the Chinese New Year parade because I read it was one of the best and spiciest Chinese restaurants in Chicago.False.What a disappointment. I knew the second I walked in because there was not a single Chinese person there except for the waitresses. First, they didn't even have my option A and B, so I ended up ordering a fish dish that was basically just bland boiled fish with some vegetables thrown on top. Then, I ordered "spicy squash with tofu" and got a soggy mess of zucchini with no tofu. When I said I had also ordered tofu, the waitress scuttled off with the plate and came back with the same dish with some cold tofu chunks thrown on top. My boyfriend ordered pork stomach lining, which he said was very good. I don't eat meat but I picked at the sauce and vegetables that came with it in hopes to fill my unappeased hunger with that. It wasn't terrible.We then ordered another fish dish (4th times a charm?) which took so long we nearly missed the parade so we ended up just canceling it, paying, and running far, far away.Final verdict? Maybe we ordered the wrong things, but I'm willing to say "never again." I'll just go to Lao Sze Chuan instead.

25.description: love this place. they deliver, and they deliver pretty fast!  when i was in chicago last winter, i basically lived off of their noodles and chicken/lamb dishes.  have not had a bad experience; prices are super budget friendly.  they give you so much rice too!

12.description: Ordered honeydew, coconut and milk tea bubble teas. The tapioca bubbles were too hard and grainy when you chewy them. Also too much ice in the honeydew smoothie making the texture too icey and crunchy not like a smoothie should be. The milk tea was still hot when it was supposed to be served cold. The coconut tasted powdery.

59.description: Date Visited: 10/13/13Have been down to Chinatown many times and most places are pretty decent. I wanted to try a new place and this one was well reviewed on Yelp. They have a very extensive menu with a nice variety in each category (Hot Appetizers, Soups, Poultry, Beef, Seafood, Noodles & Rice, etc...).I had an Egg Roll Cantonese Style, Pot Stickers Beijing Style, Beef Chow Fun and a Diet Coke. The Egg Roll was Good, the Post Stickers were Very Good and the Beef Chow Fun was Very good (could have had a little more beef in there for my liking, but still Very Good).The restaurant itself is plain and simple, but also nice a clean. I took some food to go along with a takeout menu. This is one place I will definitely be returning to again.Finally, the pricing was Excellent! My bill was only $19.00 and I had 2 Appetizers, A Main Course and a Drink. You can't beat that pricing anywhere else...***Its High Ratings Are Well Deserved!***

21.description: Very good authentic Szechuan food. I had the spicy whole fish slices. It was just the right amount of spice for me. Big enough for two.

17.description: At present，they have a new name called "chef bao chinese restaurant"

10.description: Bow down to chairman Mao. The first thing you notice as you enter this small restaurant is a large Mao Zedong plastered on the wall. The waiters all dress in green long sleeve shirts and pants. Our large group was seated immediately, and water & tea were quickly brought out. The waiters were very attentive and always made sure to refill waters and the teapot. We ordered several dishes to share. Our favorites were the walnut shrimp and the spicy, fried chicken. Although the food was not the best, authentic Chinese food I've had, it's tasty and reasonably priced.

5.description: We came as a group of 12. The restaurant was really good about accommodating our large group and allowed us to combine two large tables together (instead of all of us sitting at one table).We ordered:Dry Chili String Beans Hunan-StyleEggplant Casserole Sichuan-StyleLamb with Cumin PowderChairman Mao`s Favorite Pork BellyStir-Fried Squid in Black Bean SauceTomato & Green Pepper BeefThe food was delicious. I did not think it was overly greasy however the taste was more on the spicy and salty side. I was very thirsty after the dinner was over.The restaurant is easy to get to via the CTA Red line.

3.description: Mapo tofu with a bowl of rice, free tea, free small dish of pickled broccoli ends and carrots. So why did I come here? Well, I wanted to him to be happy and choose a place to eat and he wanted Chinese. It was super oily and it really was a waste of space in my stomach. There were so many other restaurants to try!!! Why crave this!? I will never understand. I guess it's because I'm Chinese so I don't like to eat/pay for Chinese food when I can easily make it at home and way healthier. I was dipping the tofu in tea to wash off the excessive amounts of oil. Customer service was spot on though! And I highly recommend it to people that enjoy Chinese food because he sure loved it.

35.description: I was looking for local Chinese delivery and decided to try Lao Hunan. I don't have very high standards but this place still wasn't good. Soup was cold, pot stickers were bland (and sauce was terrible), and lo mein was ok.  It took about an hour, which is what was estimated but still a long time for what I ordered. I don't recommend it but based on ratings for other places in the area, I guess there could be worse options.

19.description: This place used to be our go-to delivery spot. Nice and flavorful, spicy, goodness.  But, the last few times we've ordered, the food has been super bland, spice and tasteless, and very greasy.  I think it might have a new owner :(

28.description: We had Fu Qi Fei Pian (beef maw, lung, and tendon - served cold), Chairman Mao's Pork Belly, pot stickers, Spicy Chicken and  Sichuan String Beans. The rest of my group shied away from the beef maw...guess it was a bit of an acquired taste.  The menu is so varied that it's hard to rate the place on the food alone.  It was all very good.There is not much ambiance to the place except for the Mao mural.  It's small and very bright inside, but reasonably clean (except for the typical Chinatown bathrooms---I think they are allergic to cleaning the bathrooms or using 409/Fantastic Spray cleaner!)The waiters/waitresses didn't have their Mao uniforms on.  I always liked that so was a bit bummed out.

45.description: authentic hu'nan style. spicy lamb was very tasty, big size but I finished all of them. it's a pity that bubble tea was not made from tea but from powder, anyway bubble tea is not hu'nan cuisine...

33.description: Real authentic Chinese food in the heart of Chinatown. I am a big fan of this place, even though the food is spicy so be careful what you order if you are sensitive to spice. Also, go for any of the pork belly dishes, your taste buds will be jumping for joy.

43.description: Service was horrible. They came by 3 times rushing me to order, but when I asked about what was in the dishes they looked at me clueless. They didn't speak much English and messed up my order. The jade tofu is advertised as garnished with cilantro, we'll it came out plain as can be. Then I was rushed to finish my food as the waitress actually grabbed the plate that I was still eating on. They wrapped it up in a minute and had the check and my food ready to go before I could even swallow my food down. Honestly I have NEVER felt so rushed. Had no time to even enjoy the food.

2.description: This was my first time here and we all know first impressions are huge. I was with my two children in China town and decided to try a new Chinese restaurant. Right off the back the place gave a hectic type/busy feeling as the host/server was rushing back and forth (the restaurant was not full or crowded). She proceeded to eventually ask how many in our party. After quickly letting her know it was just the three of us she then walked away fast and never came back to seat us. She just kept tending to the other tables. The kind young lady behind the register eventually came around to greet us and again asked how many in our party. She quickly seated us and and gave us our menus. My children have their favorites; orange chicken and chicken fried rice, both very common dishes. Sad to say my daughter who loves Chinese food wasn't too impressed with the orange chicken (neither was I). Their smoothies however were good as expected! The good: chicken fried rice, chicken egg roll, hot tea, smoothies!The not so good: loud, the Orange chicken and the fact that one of the employees son (about 4-5 years old) was left to entertain himself as his parent(s) worked. Not that there's anything wrong with that except he kept tossing his car/toy figures around, bumping into people and twice threw them at our feet. :-/ First impressions are big, this one fell short on impressing us. I might check them out again with a friend to give them a second chance. Except next time I know not to order the Orange chicken.

18.description: This place was alright for my first trip to Chinatown. My Chinese friend from the Hunan province brought me here as this was a taste of his countryside. He ordered for us and got an appetizer of Fu Qi Fei Pian (beef maw, lung, and tendon - served cold), Chairman Mao's Pork Belly, and  Sichuan String Beans. The food overall was satisfying. There was nothing magical about it but it tasted good (even the maw dish though I wouldn't order it again as I'm not a fan of the rubbery texture of those animal parts). The belly was cooked tender with a typical mash up of bell peppers and onions though if fat (cooked very tender not rubbery) is not something you can stomach then you should probably pass as practically every bite is a bit of tender fat and beef (that's pork belly folks!). The green beans were very good, served with yummy bits of sauteed garlic and ginger. So if your looking for a suggestion, I would definitely try the green beans out, after all there veggies so you can eat them guilt free, right? ;)Prices are basically what you typically expect, ~$10 for entrees.Happy eating.

41.description: We would recommend this to anyone visiting Chinatown. Went with a group of friends, got the pot stickers, beer braised duck, beggars chicken, some kind of magical lamb on cilantro dish and the out of this world green beans. Y'all I could eat their dry chili string beans every day for the rest of my life and be happy as a clam. Everything was wonderful, it came out quick, and while some folks say it's pricy, I actually thought it was really reasonable. I wish we had paid more attention to the spice levels, because almost everything we ordered had chilies and by the end of the night our lips were on FIRE.

52.description: I was excited about trying out this spot because of the high reviews. I was at the Chinatown parade this past weekend and decided to stop in to check it out. The service was decent, food came out quick but I know the staff was overwhelmed. We were lucky enough to score one of the last open tables before the parade rush came in. I will try this place again only because we made a few mistakes when ordering, my fiance ordered a beef dish that looked good but turns out it was a beef salad which meant the beef was cold and the portion was small. That was our mistake. I ordered a chicken dish in a hot pot, it looked so good but was way too salty. It really ruined it for us. Like I said, I would try this place again and order a couple different dishes but for now my experience was just ok.

50.description: Went during Chinese New Years, all the other places in Chinatown were super packed, so we decided to try this place.To be fair, some people may love this food - I came in not knowing what to expect, but down to try something new. I can honestly say this was not my type of cuisine. We ordered 2 entrees and an order of potsickers. The potstickers were awful. Pure oil, no flavor. Honestly felt like I was eating cardboard.The first entree was a pork belly dish, the sauce was delicious, mixing that with rice was amazing, and I actually had to drench my potstickers in there to drowned out the cardboard taste.The 2nd entree was the Hunan Chicken. Im sure people love it, but it was not for me. I could not taste anything but spice, and soon my tongue was numb, so i couldnt event feel taste anything. I was chewing for the sake of chewing, so i packed it up to go after only 3 bites.I would have given it a low review, but again, I realize it was my own taste preference that made me dislike it (with the exception of the potstickers that were just awful) also the pricing wasnt too bad as well.

4.description: I came here before the Chinese New Year parade because I read it was one of the best and spiciest Chinese restaurants in Chicago.False.What a disappointment. I knew the second I walked in because there was not a single Chinese person there except for the waitresses. First, they didn't even have my option A and B, so I ended up ordering a fish dish that was basically just bland boiled fish with some vegetables thrown on top. Then, I ordered "spicy squash with tofu" and got a soggy mess of zucchini with no tofu. When I said I had also ordered tofu, the waitress scuttled off with the plate and came back with the same dish with some cold tofu chunks thrown on top. My boyfriend ordered pork stomach lining, which he said was very good. I don't eat meat but I picked at the sauce and vegetables that came with it in hopes to fill my unappeased hunger with that. It wasn't terrible.We then ordered another fish dish (4th times a charm?) which took so long we nearly missed the parade so we ended up just canceling it, paying, and running far, far away.Final verdict? Maybe we ordered the wrong things, but I'm willing to say "never again." I'll just go to Lao Sze Chuan instead.

6.description: Good night sweet princeGone are the complex spicy flavors of this restaurant under Tony Hu- replaced are written in menu substitutions that the poorly trained staff can't identify. Gone are the mao suits and any familiarity with Hunan cuisines' combinations of salty and spicy. Left only is spice, intense hot flavorless spice. Well meaning transition, but all of the classic flavors of this restaurant have been completely lost.

22.description: At present，they have a new name called "chef bao chinese restaurant"

15.description: On another visit here, some slight changes: the menu situation is better, only the hard cover version remains (there is a small card with specials on the table; no more complimentary small appetizer of pickled veg given this time; and only one large bowl of steamed white rice was given (it accompanied the fish filet dish). I'm certain more rice would have been available if we'd needed it. Since it was a late lunch (3 PM), we stayed with Chairman Mao's Favorite Pork Belly, but this time complimented that with fish filets stir-fried with mixed vegetables. Both were excellent!

57.description: I like the food here, and I took a really short time to get all our dishes.

20.description: This is one of, if not the worst, pretty bad restaurants I've ever had food from in a while. About two years ago, I was here and their food was actually good, but after today's meal, no more at this place. Not to mention I had to wait an hour to get my food, the ingredients used in dishes were absolutely disgusting. The place has changed from a 4 star authentic Chinese restaurant to a 1-2 star American Chinese restaurant. Not sure what happened but with many other great choices around the area, why sticking to this place?

36.description: We were staying near Millennium Park and ordered delivery to satisfy a craving.  Delivery was pretty slow - I don't believe they made the 45-60 minute window they forecasted.Our food was quite varied.  I liked the Cumin Beef Hunan Style, and The Climbing Ants (ma yi shang shu - it's vermicelli noodles with ground pork).  The Chinese Broccoli was pretty limp and oily, and the Hunan Style Cucumber Salad was just okay.  The Chow Fun was just okay.  I didn't like the Beijing-style Potstickers, mostly because the skins were thick and doughy and maybe slightly overcooked.  But, this isn't an item that travels particularly well, so it may be better in the restaurant.Someone in our party ordered the Chicken Satay, and we didn't recognize what it was supposed to be when it came.  Long sticks of chicken, heavily battered and deep fried.

14.description: This is probably one of the best Chinese restaurants in Chicago. I've been here many times including last Saturday.They offer genuine Chinese food which is served in a speedy fashion. I really recommend it. Note most food is quite spicy - just you know.

58.description: Not a place for the non-Asian. I went here with my date and we were not even looked after seating. They served an Asian guy with a missing ear before us, he sat right next to us and had come in significantly later. Had to leave hungry.

56.description: Knee how! A hidden jade in Chinatown. Ken Kee has fabulous, finger lickin Lobster with Ginger lunch for $17.95! Topped with a cup of won ton soup to die for. Listed as "the authentic Hong Kong style restaurant." The menu needs to be eaten through. A must. Zai Chen. Can't wait.

29.description: came here for a late night snack since joy yees was closed at 10:30pm. tried their wonton soup and chicken wings. i dont usually order wonton soup from a restaurant, but wanted just some sort of soup and kinda wanted dumplings too. ended up being better than i expected - shrimp dumplings in a nice clear soup. not anything too special, but it was a good late night snack. chicken wings were AMAZING!! pretty expensive (prob almost $1 a wing) and only comes with 5 wings, but they were super tender and juicy inside. definitely want to come get wings here another time. my husband ordered a mango lychee bubble tea (again, we were hoping to go to joy yees, but it was closed), and he feels that its pretty comparable to joy yees. it was pretty good, but in my opinion, i may still like joy yees bubble tea better. bubble tea is cheaper here at ken kee though, so maybe it's pretty equal. definitely almost to joy yees standard and not just a regular chinese restaurant type of bubble tea (they used fresh fruit).

42.description: Delicious food, decent portions (True, they did reduce the size, but compared to Ming Hin or Joy Yees, it's the same size for less money and better food), and never disappoints. My favorite place in Chinatown-Hong Kong classic beef pan fried wide noodles

23.description: Clean restaurant, fast service, and yummyfood! Bonus, free wifi! :) We had the shrimp in lobster sauce -- delicious and shrimp portion was huge! Staples -- cantonese chow mein and yang chow fried rice DID NOT disappoint!

47.description: The food is amazing, price is reasonable, but service is not the best at all. They had a group of six people waiting RIGHT by our table when we weren't even finished yet. I rarely have time to ever spend time with my family, and I have never experienced this. Might have been minor detail that they didn't care to think twice about, but being rushed when you have children in your group is just plain unpleasant. We had to ask for everything, such as water and bowls for our soups. We didn't mind it until they started rushing us... I mean, cmon we are giving you business, so the least they could have done was give us consideration.

8.description: I ordered this for delivery: Seafood and pineapple fried rice. NOT PLAIN FRIED RICE. I'm pretty sure if I dined in I would'nt have received this shit portion. Never ordering from this place again.

31.description: Authentic Cantonese food! Reasonable price for the quality. It's my to go restaurant every time I make a trip to the Chinatown.

34.description: It's more of a 3.5 star if half star was available. I had the watercress and pork soup (which was light, tasty, and not overly salty) and ong choi with fermented bean curd and jalapeños (which tasted ok, not the best I have had). I give 4 star to the soup and 3 to the sauté greens. I visited them around 4PM and the crowd was light.I would go back to try their other dishes.

16.description: Instead of eating at a restaurant I normally eat at when I'm in Chinatown, I decided to come to KenKee restaurant tonight. When my momma, my sister, and I walked in; we were greeted immediately and were seated in about five minutes. It's a relatively small restaurant so that's quite fast. It was also pretty packed with customers so I was certain that it must have had an element of deliciousness. After looking at the menu, we decided to order some short ribs, Japanese cucumbers, salt and pepper Japanese tofu, seafood & vegetable stir fry, roasted duck with buns, and fried intestine. I really liked that the portion sizes weren't overwhelming abundant. It allowed for us to finish everything we ordered as well as get a taste of everything. It was all so delicious. I highly recommended the Japanese cucumbers and the roasted duck buns. Absolutely - just wow! In addition to how good it tasted, it came out in what felt like ten minutes. Momma ordered a honey lemon iced tea which was also really tasty. All of the plates were roughly 10$ or less as well when averaged out so quite affordable. However, I take one star off because we had to repeat many of our requests. For example, I had to ask for water three times before it was brought out. They didn't refill the water without being asked like most restaurants in Chinatown do. It's a small, fast-moving restaurant and people are constantly coming in and out so I understand it's easy to forget. Overall, I still recommended!

13.description: What's great about this restaurant is the value. For relatively little money, you can buy a lot of decent food. But the food is just that - decent. There's nothing fantastic or bad about the food, it's just your slightly-better-than-your-everyday Chinese food.Service is adequate given moderately fast food preparation and decently fast waiters. The only service related issue is that they wouldn't validate my parking because I didn't buy $20 worth of food.

11.description: Great go to restaurant when relatives are from out of town.  Clean decent service and good food.  HK style milk tea is good here and congee (rice porridge).  Everything else is pretty good too.  Too many things to name.  Just got to try it.  Can get crowded especially on the weekend.  I also like the Japanese tofu with king mushrooms and salt and pepper squid.  These are my standard comfort food.  Try it you'll like it.

39.description: Eating this super dry chicken after initial terrible service as we speak.  Doesn't matter the amount of Kung pao sauce or general tsao sauce, or cut up thin w green beans.  I have a feeling I ate long overdue chicken, the kind you hear in those horror stories

37.description: Food is great. Love mango and peach smoothy also . Service is so so... If they can say THANK YOU  or pay attention to customer ,it would be great.

0.description: Dare i say best Chinese food in Chicago?I will because in my opinion it is the best I've had in Chinatown and in Chicago.We had a large order for pickup on a very busy night and the order was complete and the food was delicious. They were flexible on a menu ute and were able to steam the chicken (vs fried) at my wife's request.Well done Ken Kee. We'll be back.

38.description: Good food, bad service. My friends visited me from Boston and I brought them here for dinner. Everything we had were tasty and my friends really enjoyed it, but the waiter had an attitude.

51.description: We ordered Japanese Tofu with pepper and salt, stir-fried veggie, and stir-fried vermicilli with shrimp and pork. All are awesome! They also gave free rice! I came with my sister and we know that all these dishes will be too much for two persons but it's okay because they are tasty!

27.description: Meh, had better. This place has a ton of choices on a enormous menu and seemed to be Chinese authentic judging by the crowd seated. Not a very large place but packed busy kitchen. We had some kind of soup hot pot with pork and veggies that was OK but sort of bland. I suppose you needed to add your own chili sauce to per it up some. The sizzling beef and veggies was good. The smoothies were pretty good also and were cheap and they would add the little tapioca balls if you wanted. Service was slow, it was very loud and warm in the dining area and getting a turn in the single person restrooms was quite a game of wait and bolt to the door.

32.description: One of the best Chinese food restaurants I have even gone too really good the food is great and good service

54.description: Heard that this place was great and so I was really excited to try the marinated duck with chinese taro, sliced beef congee and the bean tips and the deep fried man-tou...The marinated duck was hard to chew. It tasted like old meat. The sliced beef congee was okay, but the shredded meat made me nervous because it didn't really taste like meat. Bean tips was by far the best. But it was too salty. The deep fried man-tou was significantly better elsewhere in Chinatown.  Nothing was all that impressive. Also, the restaurant itself is just not very clean. The waitress replaced our tea cups twice and they still had food particle/stain on them. The most important aspect of any restaurant is cleanliness, and this place definitely did not feel clean and made me questioned the food I was putting in my stomach. Not all that great. And given all the options in Chinatown, I would recommend going elsewhere.

48.description: Love this place! Tea with all meals. Ridiculous menu variety. Very economic. Vegetarian specific parts of the menu. Delicious bubble drinks (the avocado smoothie with boba is my favorite). Great service. Meals come out quickly. No fuss over taking the rest to go. And of course, the food is delicious. This is definitely my reliable Chinatown lunch spot. It's right of the Cermak redline stop and so I take friends here when we're in a pinch for a good dinner.

44.description: Solid Cantonese-Style cuisine. I regular dishes are scrambled eggs with yellow chives, Singapore noodles, salt & pepper porkchops and ong choy with bean curd sauce.

24.description: What's great about this restaurant is the value. For relatively little money, you can buy a lot of decent food. But the food is just that - decent. There's nothing fantastic or bad about the food, it's just your slightly-better-than-your-everyday Chinese food.Service is adequate given moderately fast food preparation and decently fast waiters. The only service related issue is that they wouldn't validate my parking because I didn't buy $20 worth of food.

7.description: A well-rounded restaurant offering all sorts of Chinese food that never fails to keep me and my family coming back. While Chinatown has endless restaurants this is one of the few we mutually like and for years we've been ordering our favorites and occasionally trying new things. The menu is vast! I really like the peapod tips cooked with garlic as a side and there's no where else I'd have some seafood congee. There's just one problem with the place- for a while they were using two sets of menus with the same items but featured different prices. You have to be careful that your tab matches what you ordered in case they're still using both, otherwise you might find yourself paying for more. Don't be afraid to call them out on it too; we've done it a few times in the past.

49.description: Excellent, much better flavor than most, catering to a heavily upscale Chinese crowd, that knows the difference between authentic and Americanized Chinese food.

40.description: Overall, I will be back here because the food is amazing here. With that being said, don't be surprised if service is awful. Our first server randomly disappeared and the other waitressed missed portions of our order. Cooks here are the true MVP.

53.description: Huge portions. Great prices!  The food is very consistent and I've never had a bad experience while dining in. I always go for their duck stew. Holy crap the stew is amazing. Granted it may not be the correct name of the dish but it is their specialty, so you can't miss it on the menu.Perfect for large group with a small budget. You always leave satisfied.

30.description: The food is good but I had a pretty bad first experience getting delivery from them.  I ordered like 20 bucks of food and I live about half a mile from the restaurant.  There is a built in 4 dollar delivery charge so I figured I'd throw in a buck and change for tip.  After the guy delivered the food.  He looked that the slip and cursed at me in Chinese after I closed the door.  I know because I'm Chinese.  I opened the door and he was basically complaining I didn't give him enough.  So I got 2 more dollars to give to him and he tried to explain the restaurants tip policy.  I don't think as a customer I need to know about how the restaurant operates with their employees.  I just need my food.  Overall, the incident ruined the mood and dining experience.

46.description: Was pumped to see a Cantonese style restaurant but was completely disappointed that it's beef brisket (a signature dish!) was tough and tasteless. The tendons and turnip that came with it were tender but bland. Go to chi cafe to get a much more flavorful version. Buddhists delight vegetable dish was covered with corn starch glaze. Meh. So the environment is clean and sleek but it's food just doesn't match up.I wouldn't come back. If you want Hong Kong food please go to chi cafe

1.description: From the menu, there look to be quite a few HK-styled dishes.  Seems great for take-out or dining in, and they seem to keep pretty busy with solo-diners in a hurry to families and groups sitting down for brunch, lunch, or dinner.Our staples here are usually the congee and soups, although I would probably order some of the same things I'd order from say Chi-Cafe further down the plaza and be reasonably assured that we'd have a good meal.It's decently good value for the soups and congee, and we're happy to stick to these options as the congee is flavorful and the soup almost creamy/buttery with just the right amount of water to rice.  We've gotten a few different kinds of congee with meats or seafoods, with or without the preserved egg, and we've also paired it with the yao-tiu/you-tiao fried dough cruller, and it's a very satisfying meal.

55.description: SOLID. That's all i really have to say. I've been eating Chinese food my entire life and therefore I'm not as critical of the food. It either falls into GOOD or BAD because you won't find me eating at a random Chop Suey place in the suburbs.   All the dishes I have ordered are legit! Ingredients taste great and the execution is spot on. Solid tapioca drinks as well. (the place next door was closed). Ken Kee is doing good for all the tourists! Authentic Chinese food.

9.description: Authentic cantonese style cuisine at a very affordable price.  The beef pan fried noodles are my favorite, meatvis very tender.  Try the salt/pepper fried wings, they are delicious!  The seafood white fried rice is a staple.  Fried fish fillet is super solid.  They recently upgraded the decor, so it's nice and clean.

26.description: My friends and I usually go to Chinatown mainly for the dim sum and the Boba.  Every time we came across this restaurant, it would always be packed. On our last day in Chicago, as we were walking pass this place, we noticed that there was no line. We waited 10 minutes for our table and we ordered 4 dishes: Fried Tofu and Watercress, Shrimp Egg Sauce on Fried Rice Noodles, Steam Chicken w/Garlic Ginger and a beef dish. Asides from the Fried Tofu and Watercress, I was not a fan with the other three dishes. My friends really enjoyed the steam chicken, especially the garlic on top, but I thought it was alright. For my next visit, I will definitely order the fried tofu again along with other dishes that we have not tried yet. Besides from the food, I also ordered myself a watermelon smoothie which was quick delicious and refreshing. I noticed that they use real fruits for their smoothies instead of powder.

25.description: Excellent value.  Comfort food prepared in quality ingredients and precision cooking. HK style means a sprinkle of chili with flour on dish.COFFEE & TEA MIXED DRINK ($1.75) -- refreshing to automatically have less ice by default.  Ecstatic at $1.75.ON-CHOY WITH MALAYSIA SHRIMP PASTE ($7.95) -- the premium kind of a poor man's vegetable.  Simple preparation with flavor.  We love it. SMELT FISH in Spicy HongKong style ($8.95) -- another poor man's food.  In the old country, bones are intact.  In an industrialized country, deboned. Yay!  Another poor man's food.KEN-KEE SPECIAL ($7.95) -- a mixture of squid, chicken, pork skin, Chinese sausage etc.  Good to try but not crazy about it.  CAUTION:  may contain nuts.DEEP FRIED CALAMARI with Spicy Garlic, HongKong style ($8.95) -- the best perfectly fried calamari.  Crunchy, soft and slightly chewy.HONOLULU HEINEKEN CITY EDITION -- brewed and bottled from Amsterdam, Holland.ALCOHOL SELECTION -- a decent selection.  Good reason to hang out.VENUE -- modern, clean and organized.  Wi-Fi available.  Feel free to hang out.SERVICE -- Yoyo is great - personable, charming, friendly, and encourages you to eat slow.  Say "Hello!"  A classy, educated girl.  Pooled tips are distributed equally.

12.description: Worst egg roll I've had in my entire life!!!Other dishes were also poor quality and flavor.

59.description: Instead of eating at a restaurant I normally eat at when I'm in Chinatown, I decided to come to KenKee restaurant tonight. When my momma, my sister, and I walked in; we were greeted immediately and were seated in about five minutes. It's a relatively small restaurant so that's quite fast. It was also pretty packed with customers so I was certain that it must have had an element of deliciousness. After looking at the menu, we decided to order some short ribs, Japanese cucumbers, salt and pepper Japanese tofu, seafood & vegetable stir fry, roasted duck with buns, and fried intestine. I really liked that the portion sizes weren't overwhelming abundant. It allowed for us to finish everything we ordered as well as get a taste of everything. It was all so delicious. I highly recommended the Japanese cucumbers and the roasted duck buns. Absolutely - just wow! In addition to how good it tasted, it came out in what felt like ten minutes. Momma ordered a honey lemon iced tea which was also really tasty. All of the plates were roughly 10$ or less as well when averaged out so quite affordable. However, I take one star off because we had to repeat many of our requests. For example, I had to ask for water three times before it was brought out. They didn't refill the water without being asked like most restaurants in Chinatown do. It's a small, fast-moving restaurant and people are constantly coming in and out so I understand it's easy to forget. Overall, I still recommended!

21.description: Dishes here are ok. I felt the dishes were overly sauced. The food came out very quickly and service here was good also.

17.description: Each time I'm in Chi town all I want is to write reviews. I have 20+ years experience eating all over Chicagoland but I really haven't written all that much about many of the restaurants I frequented or still frequent. I guess this is me catching up.Ken Kee is an old favorite. My old college roommate, Ivan and I always opt to come here to get together for a visit. This has going on since we were students to now him having two children. Ken Kee is located in the new Chinatown of Chicago or Archer Square. It's tiny and at times the wait can be long. However, I got seated right away for lunch since I got there first.We ordered the usual favorites like salt and pepper smelts, Japanese egg tofu with king mushroom, as well as beef fried rice. We also ordered shrimp wontons for his small boy and the broccoli and garlic as the token vegetable. I kinda wanted to order more stuff like fish and the Hainanese chicken but I followed their suit. I was so surprised when the food came, the portion was puny. Then, my friend told me that it had been a well known issue that they reduced their portion size and kept the same price as a measure to be profitable without raising the price. He said he had witnessed a fight between the restaurant and a customer who got upset over the portion size. He also said he hasn't been coming here in awhile because of it as well.I agree.. The portion was way smaller. That made this place quite pricy for a Chinese Chinatown joint. The taste was still great though. I still really enjoyed the food a lot but there wasn't enough to go around. Lol.We also ordered some tapioca pearl drinks: red and green bean drinks, Mango smoothie, and my fave watermelon freeze with tapioca and lychee. All were fantastic as always.It would be too hard to break a habit of coming here after all these years. Next time I know that we need to order more food. Since the taste and service were still as I remember it, I forgave them for getting new smaller serving platters. Usually when a restaurant does this, they tried to be subtle. Ken Kee did it like wham!!!! No way you would miss it. At least, they're upfront about it.

10.description: For me, Ken Kee is in the category of not-the-best but not-the-worst. It's reliable, but it's not somewhere you'd make a special trip to go to. Given lots of other great options around that are only slightly pricier, the best reason to go here might be because you want food similar to Chi Cafe, but they are too busy.With that said, the two categories of items to get here are really the noodle soups and congee. If you don't like either of these, the good news is that you can order pretty much anything on the menu and generally be satisfied with it -- although there's really nothing I've tried here that really stands out at all. But it is a nice restaurant with decent decor that does provide a good number of options with reasonable service at an acceptable price.

5.description: Excellent value.  Comfort food prepared in quality ingredients and precision cooking. HK style means a sprinkle of chili with flour on dish.COFFEE & TEA MIXED DRINK ($1.75) -- refreshing to automatically have less ice by default.  Ecstatic at $1.75.ON-CHOY WITH MALAYSIA SHRIMP PASTE ($7.95) -- the premium kind of a poor man's vegetable.  Simple preparation with flavor.  We love it. SMELT FISH in Spicy HongKong style ($8.95) -- another poor man's food.  In the old country, bones are intact.  In an industrialized country, deboned. Yay!  Another poor man's food.KEN-KEE SPECIAL ($7.95) -- a mixture of squid, chicken, pork skin, Chinese sausage etc.  Good to try but not crazy about it.  CAUTION:  may contain nuts.DEEP FRIED CALAMARI with Spicy Garlic, HongKong style ($8.95) -- the best perfectly fried calamari.  Crunchy, soft and slightly chewy.HONOLULU HEINEKEN CITY EDITION -- brewed and bottled from Amsterdam, Holland.ALCOHOL SELECTION -- a decent selection.  Good reason to hang out.VENUE -- modern, clean and organized.  Wi-Fi available.  Feel free to hang out.SERVICE -- Yoyo is great - personable, charming, friendly, and encourages you to eat slow.  Say "Hello!"  A classy, educated girl.  Pooled tips are distributed equally.

3.description: Cute interior and nice staff. Food was pretty good. Smaller dishes, and we had three dishes with rice and out bellies were content. The only thing was that the fish balls we had seemed to be the premade frozen ones in the package that can be bought at the store instead of the handmade ones.

35.description: The food here is as expected. It's very normal Chinese food. I didn't see anything that stood out. The decor was nice on the wall. The seating arrangements are a bit too crowded for my taste and it feels like your in an institution except for the colored chairs. Service was mediocre too. The waitress brought out the food fast but don't refill my water. She was very quick with the check though. This will not be my go-to place any time soon.

19.description: Stopped by this place for some post-dinner bubble tea. I got the passion fruit iced tea with tapioca balls, and it was refreshing and delightful. My friends got the taro smoothie, strawberry smoothie, and pineapple mango smoothie with tapioca balls. All were well blended and wonderful. If like to go back for a meal some time!

28.description: For me, Ken Kee is in the category of not-the-best but not-the-worst. It's reliable, but it's not somewhere you'd make a special trip to go to. Given lots of other great options around that are only slightly pricier, the best reason to go here might be because you want food similar to Chi Cafe, but they are too busy.With that said, the two categories of items to get here are really the noodle soups and congee. If you don't like either of these, the good news is that you can order pretty much anything on the menu and generally be satisfied with it -- although there's really nothing I've tried here that really stands out at all. But it is a nice restaurant with decent decor that does provide a good number of options with reasonable service at an acceptable price.

45.description: Each time I'm in Chi town all I want is to write reviews. I have 20+ years experience eating all over Chicagoland but I really haven't written all that much about many of the restaurants I frequented or still frequent. I guess this is me catching up.Ken Kee is an old favorite. My old college roommate, Ivan and I always opt to come here to get together for a visit. This has going on since we were students to now him having two children. Ken Kee is located in the new Chinatown of Chicago or Archer Square. It's tiny and at times the wait can be long. However, I got seated right away for lunch since I got there first.We ordered the usual favorites like salt and pepper smelts, Japanese egg tofu with king mushroom, as well as beef fried rice. We also ordered shrimp wontons for his small boy and the broccoli and garlic as the token vegetable. I kinda wanted to order more stuff like fish and the Hainanese chicken but I followed their suit. I was so surprised when the food came, the portion was puny. Then, my friend told me that it had been a well known issue that they reduced their portion size and kept the same price as a measure to be profitable without raising the price. He said he had witnessed a fight between the restaurant and a customer who got upset over the portion size. He also said he hasn't been coming here in awhile because of it as well.I agree.. The portion was way smaller. That made this place quite pricy for a Chinese Chinatown joint. The taste was still great though. I still really enjoyed the food a lot but there wasn't enough to go around. Lol.We also ordered some tapioca pearl drinks: red and green bean drinks, Mango smoothie, and my fave watermelon freeze with tapioca and lychee. All were fantastic as always.It would be too hard to break a habit of coming here after all these years. Next time I know that we need to order more food. Since the taste and service were still as I remember it, I forgave them for getting new smaller serving platters. Usually when a restaurant does this, they tried to be subtle. Ken Kee did it like wham!!!! No way you would miss it. At least, they're upfront about it.

33.description: It's an authentic Chinese restaurant. I like the food here. The food here makes me remind of my home town.

43.description: Ken Kee's is a Hong Kong style diner with a plethora of Cantonese small plates.  All the food I've tried is pretty good.  However, my favorite is their congee, especially the pork century egg and fish fillet.  What a creamy and tasty porridge!  No matter how I've tried to research and experiment, I can't even get close.  Although the price is higher than others, once you've had it, you won't look at congee the same way again - I highly recommend it!

2.description: My boyfriend and I ate here the other day and were very pleased with the service and most of the meal.  We picked the restaurant after walking around looking for places that seemed popular (they had people inside) and had vegetarian options.I had the braised bean curd with black mushrooms (#963).  It was a good serving size and delicious.  I think black mushrooms are the same as shittake.  I disliked the lettuce/cabbage they had with it, but that's just me.  My meat-eating boyfriend liked the tofu.  I'll definitely order this again.I also got the mixed vegetable congee (#021).  I asked to make sure that they didn't use an animal-based broth.  It had lots of mushrooms and was a good value.  The mushrooms weren't just the plain white button, but also included wood ear and others I don't know the name of.  Maybe oyster mushroom and white fungus?  Definitely worth ordering again.My boyfriend got sweet and sour chicken and had no complaints.The taro smoothie was too thin, as if they let the ice melt or added too much liquid.  Neither of us liked the red bean breeze.  It was our first time trying the latter, so this might just reflex our personal tastes.The first floor was crowded and noisy, so we went to the 2nd floor.  It was also noisy, but had more room.  There's little in the way of decor, but with such good food, we didn't care.  Oh, and they had free hot tea.They have large round family tables, so it's good for large groups.

18.description: Clean restaurant, fast service, and yummyfood! Bonus, free wifi! :) We had the shrimp in lobster sauce -- delicious and shrimp portion was huge! Staples -- cantonese chow mein and yang chow fried rice DID NOT disappoint!

41.description: Stopped by this place for some post-dinner bubble tea. I got the passion fruit iced tea with tapioca balls, and it was refreshing and delightful. My friends got the taro smoothie, strawberry smoothie, and pineapple mango smoothie with tapioca balls. All were well blended and wonderful. If like to go back for a meal some time!

52.description: The japanese salt and pepper tofu is really good, as are the fried mantou and the chinese pickled cucumbers. I've come here a number of times, and don't remember ever getting anything that we didn't like. I also hear that the cantonese chicken is great.

50.description: One of the best Chinese places in all of Chicago land!  We go there every 2-3 weeks, it seems.  Their food is always yummy, and they have a good selection.  Some of our favorites are:- butter fish- string beans with dried fish & pork- beef ribs in sweet sake sauce- Japanese tofu- yang chow fried riceThey've redecorated in the last year or two. It looks real nice and inviting.  And very attentive service - not normal for a Chinese place haha.  Ok I'm getting hungry now...

4.description: Great Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.You can look at the pictures of the dishes we ordered - every one was very tasty and authentic. The portions are very good and the prices are amazing (e.g., the large soup for 4 people in the photo was only $6).I read some of the negative reviews. There were a lot of "poor service" reviews. If you want good service don't go for authentic Chinese food in Chinatown - go to PF Chang's.

6.description: My friends and I usually go to Chinatown mainly for the dim sum and the Boba.  Every time we came across this restaurant, it would always be packed. On our last day in Chicago, as we were walking pass this place, we noticed that there was no line. We waited 10 minutes for our table and we ordered 4 dishes: Fried Tofu and Watercress, Shrimp Egg Sauce on Fried Rice Noodles, Steam Chicken w/Garlic Ginger and a beef dish. Asides from the Fried Tofu and Watercress, I was not a fan with the other three dishes. My friends really enjoyed the steam chicken, especially the garlic on top, but I thought it was alright. For my next visit, I will definitely order the fried tofu again along with other dishes that we have not tried yet. Besides from the food, I also ordered myself a watermelon smoothie which was quick delicious and refreshing. I noticed that they use real fruits for their smoothies instead of powder.

22.description: Salt and pepper smelts and fried salt & pepper pork chops were the only yummy dishes out of five dishes we ordered. Gong pao chicken is not recommended.ken kee's fried rice is too bland.fried flat noodle is just average.

15.description: Oh no, Ken Kee! We used to love this fun, little spot in the middle of the Chinatown outside mall. Always had a great meal and a great time, until last night's takeout. The beef Kung Po with peanuts had a little extra...in the form of a wire and some wire coating (?). Not sure if they are doing some work by the cooking, but ick, that could have been painful down the old hatch. Now we'll have to find a new Chinatown spot. Boo.

57.description: It actually deserves NO STARS. So the waiter comes and sit us right away and gave us menus, two minutes later he brings water and ask "are you ready to order" we're like "yes" and just as we are to start ordering he walks away and sat to have lunch with other staff and some one else came back just about 20 min later, (why didn't I walk away? Because I was dumb enough) then never offer drinks, I was so upset, 10-12 min into our meal I gave in and ask for sodas that literally took more than 10 min to bring, then if it wasn't enough me mad my wife were so upset that didn't even finish our food so we ask for it to go, the guy took our food and never came back. Horrible horrible horrible experience.

20.description: Usually get the salt/pepper fish fillet, fried japanese tofu, thousand island pork chop. A lot of the dishes are pretty solid and clean. Portions seemed to have gotten a bit smaller than when I first started going a few years ago. Because of this I've started expanding to other places, but Ken Kee still delivers a quick, fresh, and relatively cheap meal.

36.description: Ken Kee is my go to place to bring friends who want to try genuine Chinese food but would be too scared to eat anything that came out of a grungy, hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant. It's got a contemporary feel to it; the service is great and the decor is modern. The place is clean (for a Chinese place) and they even have wifi! Every time I come here I always order the Deep Fried Japanese Tofu. It's addictingly crunchy with a salt-and-pepper flare and a go-to-dish. I also order the Braised Taro and Duck and have it over rice. All in all, this is a good place for groups and newcomers to Chinese food who want to sample something authentic but not be too daring.

14.description: Not even close to Chi Cafe. Crab rangoons overstuffed (not in a good way), luke warm and chewy. Japanese tofu in a bland sauce was just ok. Hot and sour soup (which came out last) was awful. Very disappointing. Service was nice but inattentive. I got old waiting for my check.

28.description: Really cute stuff here, especially stuffed animals and picture frames, and anime things like Totoro! I think they quality of stuff here is a little better and newer than some of the other gift shops in the vicinity. It's more asian pop cultureish.

1.description: Oh, Giftland. I've been coming to this store since I was a little kid, when going to Chinatown was a big deal and a fun adventure. In adulthood, I have a love-hate relationship with this place. What I love is the sheer volume of Hello Kitty items. I collect Hello Kitty things, so this is my idea of paradise. There's EVERYTHING. Hair accessories, plushies, kitchenware, statues, jewelry, banks, clocks, lunch boxes, candy. You name it, they have it with a kitty slapped on it. However, they're really, really overpriced. They wanted $5 for one pink plastic fork. Not even the set. Really? My dad surprised me with a Hello Kitty ramen bowl set from there, and it works really nicely. He paid something crazy like $40 for it, but I have to admit, it's really cute and it matches my dorm really well.The other issue with this store is that it just looks dated. Stuff has been in there so long it gets dusty. There are still faded Pokemon posters up from when there were only 150 kinds. It's nostalgic for me, since I remember when those posters were new, but it's a bit off-putting now when you walk past it in Chinatown.I still make a point to stop in here each trip, and no doubt I'll continue doing that.

9.description: I like Giftland.  Great place to get little gifts and trinkets for people who like that stuff.  I recently bought a 2" small porcelain Super Lucky Elephant to keep at my desk.  The owner was nice.  He asked me how much the little elephant was since it didn't have a price tag on it.  I shrugged and went to the shelf and found a similar sized item and it said $1.75, so that's what he charged me.  Super Lucky Elephant rules!

29.description: I stumbled upon this place once as I was having lunch. Its a small shop, but has lots of cute items to give as gifts. The store is inexpensive, but the items are all of good quality and look unique.

23.description: I love Giftland!  They have the Anime trinkets I love, Monokoro Boo, various sized Plushies, lots of Hello Kitty, clothes, Sake sets, rice bowls,..I could go on and on!  Prices are pretty much the same as the other gift stores in the area.  I can always find a little something for the children that isn't way expensive!

5.description: Well, this is my go-to place for Cheongsams, the sexy, skintight satin Chinese dresses that all good Dragon Ladies have in their archive. I had a great one for many years, but it eventually split a seam from wearing it. A lot.Yesterday, though, I was sadly disappointed at the selection. The styles seem to have gotten more . . . tacky, and the offerings more limited. I think the way the real Midoris do it is to buy one that's too big, and get it tailored.I was mildly annoyed by the chirpy woman who ran up to me with a tape measure. I know my size. She measured my hips. Um, darling, that's not the measurement you need to go on with me for a dress like this. And, yep. If you want one of these, get it to fit your bust. Which means then it will fall around your hips like a baggy robe, as it did on me. Unattractive. It must be tight! And then get it tailored, which I'm going to do when I go back for one. Hopefully when the place is not mobbed with tourists.There's a bunch of other crap in this store, but go here for Cheongsams and cute satin slippers. And maybe weird Chinese candy, that always amuses.

25.description: I just bought the 4 coolest, badassest temporary tattoos here on Satruday.They have a shitload of bootlegged anime posters and toys. I dont have a probably with bootleggers, and i really love their "interpretations". The prices are kinda high compared to the other stores in chinatown, but who cares! You'd have to go to like 4 different stores up and down the street to find things like the stuff in this store. As for their security....i think it's expected, chinatown is still really sketchy and if you arent stealing dont be worried about it.

12.description: Lot of cute stuff, but don't come here for anime unless you want knockoff merch for the first generation of pokemon or Gundam S--all their anime offerings are about ten years out of date. And forgo the snacks: they're nearly half as expensive at the market near the red line station.

21.description: Hello Kitty coughed up a pink and red furball and they turned it into a gift shop.  Lots of stuff no one really needs, plus a few things you might!It's worth a stop to at least take a peek and see what you or your loved ones could be missing from your home.  Anything here is better than doilies.

16.description: Hello Kitty coughed up a pink and red furball and they turned it into a gift shop.  Lots of stuff no one really needs, plus a few things you might!It's worth a stop to at least take a peek and see what you or your loved ones could be missing from your home.  Anything here is better than doilies.

17.description: This is my favorite gift shop in Chinatown. Basically all the gift shops in Chinatown are the same (With a few exceptions like the knife shop or the book shop) they have a lot useless cheap junk and cutesy things that will probably wind up breaking sooner or later, or just collecting a lot of dust. What makes this one stand out? They have the biggest selection of Hello Kitty and other Sanrio character items out of any of the other shops. Included in that selection of items are some things that will actually probably get some use out of them. They also have a HUGE selection of folding paper. I am a SUCKER for those kits *points ot all the boats and stars on desk and points to the attempts at flowers and cranes that were unsuccessful* If you are too, there is no way to simply walk out of the store without buying any of it. If you are feeling fancy you can even pick out a cute jar to put them in to look nice on your coffee table or give away as a gift. One last thing. They have the biggest collection of anime posters in Chinatown too, also a plus, especially if your an anime nerd like me. (yeah yeah yeah poke fun of me I don't care)

10.description: *Please forgive the overabundance of the word "cute". This is just a fun store. Toys, candy, knick-knacks, clothes, purses, gift bags, cell phone charms, Chicago souvenirs, stuffed animals... Just a jumble of stuff--cute stuff. Yeah, some of it "junky" I guess, but mostly cute. Many a time I've heard someone exclaim, "Oh how cute!" at something they've found. This is a great place to get little gifts--especially for kids. My nieces always enjoy the little purses and toys I've gotten them from Giftland. They like being able to show off new colorful pencils and cute notepads when school season starts. These are not things that you'd expect folks to save forever, the prices of items will contest to that. But if you need a place to browse and enjoy some cutesy things, check it out!

11.description: It was the anime posters in the window that drew me to this place. Lol. Great stop for souvenirs, although we later discovered that most of Chinatown is pretty much souvenir-land. I got my brother a souvenir spoon ($3.99) and a souvenir magnet ($2.99). Lol. He likes those tacky souvenir kinda things. Juan said it was much cheaper here than at the overblown souvenir shops at Navy Pier. Besides the tacky souvenir gifts, they also sell some cute anime stuff here and some beautiful Chinese dresses and traditional Chinese crafts and gifts, like wall scrolls, sculptures, car charms, etc.If you are looking for quick one-stop shopping for affordable souvenirs, this place is great!

26.description: Sometimes I wander in here when I want to blow money on some useless Sanrio crap or fake Chanel earrings.  For a while they even had Hello Kitty PDAs.  A lot of the stuff is overpriced touristy stuff and the lady that works in the clothing department is a little bitchy.

27.description: This place is awesome -- full of Japanese anime inspired toys, purses, plushies, etc. Some of them are as big as a human! Too bad they wouldn't let me take a picture inside.

0.description: Cute little piggys, Even though someone I know bought it from the Christkindlmarkt......

20.description: Growing up..I despised all those cutesie Sanrio toys and hated that my mom forced that type of stuff on me.  Now that I am older, and it is my choice, I secretly love them.  This store sells tons of cool stuff...they sell San X...the line that makes Pucca dolls.  I love that they sell everything under the sun..stuffed animals, candy, slippers, cheong sams, ninja gear, Chicago Souvenirs, things that you didn't know existed but upon seeing them you strangely feel the need to possess them.This is a great place to take your kids..or if you need to buy a gift for a kid...it seriously rocks.  We found a really cute Jack Skellington key chain that flutters?...you pull the string and it moves and a cute stuffed doll as well.  They also have kissing Pucca dolls!!We did have to buy an outfit for my son in back.  The lady that worked there was very nice and accommodating..I am so fortunate that I can still speak some Cantonese!
