19.description: Growing up..I despised all those cutesie Sanrio toys and hated that my mom forced that type of stuff on me.  Now that I am older, and it is my choice, I secretly love them.  This store sells tons of cool stuff...they sell San X...the line that makes Pucca dolls.  I love that they sell everything under the sun..stuffed animals, candy, slippers, cheong sams, ninja gear, Chicago Souvenirs, things that you didn't know existed but upon seeing them you strangely feel the need to possess them.This is a great place to take your kids..or if you need to buy a gift for a kid...it seriously rocks.  We found a really cute Jack Skellington key chain that flutters?...you pull the string and it moves and a cute stuffed doll as well.  They also have kissing Pucca dolls!!We did have to buy an outfit for my son in back.  The lady that worked there was very nice and accommodating..I am so fortunate that I can still speak some Cantonese!

2.description: The place had a lot or cute things like Hello Kitty stuffed animals and kimonos. I think they were a bit overpriced but comparable to other gift stores around the area. I didn't like how the owner was eyeing/ watching me as if we were going to steal from them though. Maybe she has had a bad history of stolen goods in her store, but I don't like being treated like a criminal. There's another gift store in the new Chinatown Plaza that I love because they let me freely browse.

18.description: Welcome to Asian cuteness central! Giftland offers a variety of cute Asian character adorned merchandise from erasers and pens to eating utensils and bowls. When visiting Chinatown this is the place to hit up to get your dose of totally cute merchandise. They have shelves filled with authentic Sanrio products. Unlike other stores the who sells generic Sanrio products where the Hello Kitty is looking questionably unreal this store sells many products of Hello Kitty and her friends. They have a huge collection of chic erasers to choose from. Recently they have a batch of erasers shaped like actual food such as sushi! In the back of the store they sell Chinese kai po dresses, Chinese shoes, and other Chinese attires. The store is all the way at the end of Wentworth, but I would recommend making the trek there to be immersed in the Disney Land of cute Asian merchandise! The ladies that work at Giftland seem like they are always stalking you. Watching your every move to make sure you are not stealing or breaking anything. It's a hostile, unfriendly environment which shouldn't be because they sell light hearted items. Though they do have a lot of extremely cute Asian things lots of the things are useless. It is very cute, but when would I ever use it? Mini rulers that are too small to really measure anything or even draw a long straight line. What is the use of that? But maybe it is the thought of knowing you have something extra adorable that counts. Interesting Note - They sell a wide variety of star folding paper. Pick a package up and learn how to fold paper stars. Once you learn how you can make enough to fill a little bottle with paper stars!

13.description: Likes: A really nice place to purchase cute characters. They pretty much have everything that you want that is related to Hello Kitty /Sanrio and Morning Glory. The staff was friendly. I was able to purchases lots of items to give out for prizes for my daughter's birthday party. Dislike: The store is small and compact. They need to have a bigger basket to put items in. The day that I went in, there was a field trip going on. Kids kicking and screaming because they wanted things from the store.

4.description: It's a good place if you want to browse for cute stuff like Hello Kitty or Sanrio related items. The items are over-priced but if you're willing to overlook the area, it's a good gift shop. This store is pretty small and stocks some outdated anime stuff (posters from Gundam Seed/Wing, some Gunpla, keychains).They accept credit cards with a purchase of $5 or more.

24.description: Awhile back my car was stolen, and I lost a lot of unmentionable laundry in the trunk... (I was on the way to the laundromat). The car turned up two weeks later across the city. The great news was, my CDs were still in the car! It turns out that the plush, cheetah print, turtle-shaped CD cases sold at Giftland are decoys that thieves are tricked by! Too bad they did not sell huge plush cheetah print turtle-shaped hiding cases for my car! I also go to Giftland for gummy raspberry candy, cool embroidered silk Chinese purses and the occasional Sanrio fix.

6.description: Slightly over priced knock-off items. The quality of these items break easily. I can find better deals online but I hate shipping and waiting. I come here to buy gifts for the little girls in my family who likes anime and little cute stationary. One thing I don't think most people know is that the cashier will gladly gift wrap your items if you asked. Also they always have one employee on the floor that watches the customer and it gets a little uncomfortable but It's security and I understand.

22.description: My sister and I shopped at Giftland on our first trip to Chicago's Chinatown.   So many fun little trinkets!   Between the two of us, we took home many unneccessary little goodies such as red satin slippers, a cat-shaped rice bowl, Hello Kitty bubble gum, rose scented soap, a Chinese lantern and zodiac stickers.  They also have gorgeous clothes and handbags, but it seemed a bit over-priced.  If you're into Anime, they have tons of stuff for you, too.

15.description: I just want to elaborate on some of the reviews already made for this place and add a little bit more.1) Yes, this place is Asian Cuteness Central.  Luckily, it's not just your standard seven Hello Kitty pieces of merchandise that are poorly crafted and likely to fall apart if you ever chose to use them, rather than put them in your Hello Kitty shrine of collectibles.  The variety here is amazing, and the kinds of random crap with Asian characters on them is enough to make your head spin.2) Yes, this place sells non-cuteness Asian goodies as well.  There's clothing/shoes in the back, like in most gift-type shops in Chinatown.  You can also find a wide variety of cookware and teapots and sake sets, although I've already got a nice sake set at home and it would be nicer if they sold SAKE here instead of just the sets for drinking it.3) Yes, this place also has RANDOM stuff.  I have never really been in the market for a Kimono-style or Chinese dress cover for my cell phone, but if I ever suffered enough brain damage to be looking for one, I know that it could be cheaply found and purchased at Giftland.  And if cellphone dresses aren't random enough for you, like all gift stores in Chinatown they offer "Mystery Boxes".  That's right, it's a box wrapped in Chinese newspaper and you buy it and the mystery is what you just spent $2 or $4 to get!  (My one attempt at a $2 box led to a scented candle and a scented bar of soap, so it's up to you if you want to go for it.)4) Yea, they've got animé stuff here, too!  This is my one-stop shopping location when I decide my apartment does not have enough animé posters adorning the walls, or if I've discovered a new series and want to find out if they've got a poster for it as well.  And they also have wall scrolls, if flimsy posters aren't badass enough for you when it comes to celebrating your love for Bleach or Inuyasha or whatever.  And check out the register area for keychains and medallions and whatnot as well.5) Yea, you'll likely NEVER use anything you buy here.  Although that's not the case, frankly.  While I can't say I've "gotten much use" out of my collection of posters, other than admiring them and talking to them in broken Japanese like a true fanboy, I can say that my most random purchase at this store has been used multiple times, both for practical use and for silly use.I bought a pink Sailor Moon facemask.  Not like one you use as a costume for Hallowe'en. but the kind that you use to prevent catching disease or spreading disease.  And yes, there were days that I was sick but still required to show up at the office, and I brought along my Sailor Moon facemask and everybody got a laugh at the creepy pink mask I wore all day, but they also were happy I wasn't spreading my germs everywhere.So if you're in Chinatown and you NEED to cruise the giftshops for crappy cheap merchandise - I recommend this one because it's got some of the same crap that's in all the other stores, but this one's got some awesome stuff to look through as well.  You never know when your random purchase will wind up being useful!

7.description: I gotta give a big shout out to the store where I spent hours of my life while in college. It was the perfect place to get cheap, cute housewares, last minute gifts, and, often, some nice clothing and accessories.The staff will watch you like a hawk, probably because they've had a few shoplifting incidences. Nonetheless, take your time to peruse all the shelving, stuff on the walls, and even the shoes on the floor. You'll find some great stuff!

8.description: I'm an asian female type so of course this place got me. It got ME! And sucked me in so I can just take a look. Maybe a new hello kitty pen for when I bank or maybe some new cutesy hello kitty and her friends erasers so I can use it when doing math problems for fun! Or maybe a hello kitty magnetic pencil case that doubles as a hiding place for my rusty knife so I can shank a bitch trying to steal my smart phone in the gold coast.Just kidding! Or am I...  I don't know what happened because I grew up being indifferent to sanrio stuff but then I lived with someone that was OBSESSED with hello kitty and it got to me in my 20's.  Decent selection and random asian trinkets that don't amuse me, although I prefer the sanrio store because it's more concentrated on JUST sanrio items. There's another sanrio type shop in the china plaza that has a comparable selection. Recommended for a quick fix if you happen to be in the area but it's not a destination for the sanrio likers like me.

3.description: I was completely underwhelmed by this little shop after reading the Yelp reviews and visiting the store in person. They have a great assortment of little collectables, but there's nothing here you couldn't find in the Chinatown Square a block away for much less. One example, I purchased green tea pocky for $1.99 at Mayflower Food in the Chinatown Square, and at Giftland it was $2.99.

14.description: They creep around and watch you - wait, they actually don't really 'creep' per se since they don't really make any attempt to hide that they're watching you. Look lady(ies), I'm not planning to steal anything from you - nor are any of the other people (mostly tourists who wouldn't have the heart or the nerve), well, not most of them anyway.Onto the merchandise, it's clear from a marketing level that they've figured out that a whole boatload of Japanophiles flock to Chinatown because it's the closest they can get to anything Asian within the city - as such they stock the store with quite a number of trinkets, toys and eccentricities (Death Note trading cards, Neon Genesis Evangelion and Hellsing action figures, Korean Pucca plushies, etc). They seem to stock general catchall items of Asian etymology all across the board from the aformentioned pop culture pieces to clothing and tea sets. Overall, it's a great place for souvenir purchases  and finding novelties, but maybe not for much anything useful. Keep that in mind and overall you'll find the ten to fifteen minutes you spend browsing in here a worthwhile and fun (if not totally relevant) experience.

3.description: Great place! Excellent techniques! So I was looking for a place to go after my excellent haircut. There being no Mani/pedi spot that was vacant, I remembered this place while passing by. They had very good prices for a massage(28/hr) and I haven't really had a good foot massage since I came to the US. So I was thrilled to check this place out. My masseuse was very experienced and paid attention to my back ( even though it wasn't included in the 28 hour long foot massage) I left feeling sore but better!

1.description: This place sucks! It smells and they have terrible customer service. Its a big rip off their massages dont last the time they should. dont come here. you are better off going to Chicago Bodywork they are the best.

2.description: This was by far the absolute worst place in Chicago. DON'T EVER GOTO THIS PLACE!!!!! IT IS A WASTE OF MONEY BECAUSE YOU WILL BE LESS STRESSED THAN WHEN YOU STARTED! If I could give this place zero stars I would. My boyfriend and I decided to get a couples massage here. First of all, a couple's massage is supposed to be a couple in the same room getting a massage at the same time. It's supposed to be a bonding experience. This place was awful. We were placed in the same room but it had a huge makeshift curtain in between us, which was clearly an old bedsheets.So the whole time we were receiving our hour long massage we were completely separated from each other. then we were also in a room with others so it was not very private. In the next "booth" someone was getting a reflexology massage and he was a big talker. He just kept talking which disrupted my massage. Then one of the therapists' child was running around screaming. They stopped my massage several times to shoo the child away. My boyfriend said they did the same thing with him. Needless to say, I was more stressed than when I started and couldn't wait to get out of there. Then as were walking out the lady at the front desk keep saying "tip" "tip" and would not let us leave. We went to leave a 10%tip to which she said tip again. Then when my boyfriend gave her more money, she looked at him and said "This only for one person, more tip" So we threw more money at her and walked out.

5.description: I bought a groupon for this place just to try it out. The groupon was $35 but at the site they only charge $28, so the groupon is more expansive than the actual cost. that's no deal at all. The location is kind of hidden and you have to really look for it. There was no other customer when I was there, but still had to wait.  The actual massage was indifferent, not horrible but not great. There are many other places in Chicago now that offer the same kind of massage for the same price.

6.description: My cousin and I went into this place for a massage. They advertise foot massage and reflexology in the window. My massage was ok but definitely not a reflexology massage. The room I was in was ice cold and dead silent except for the noise of people walking around and talking outside. The massage  for being  a full body,  they only paid attention to the back and very minimal On the legs. The lady who gave me the massage led me into a room and then left and I was standing there wondering what to do. There was no place to take my cloths of and get under a towel or blankets. My cousins massage was even worse. He said she rubbed his back a little no oil no lotion no hot towel. Just beat his back for 40 minutes when it should have been a hour and then called it a day. Now after getting a horrible message like this no one wants to tip so he didn't. And as we were heading out the door the Chinese women who spoke no English what so ever came running behind us saying. "You tip now . Tip now you". I was like holly shit this is weird so I pulled out a 10 and handed to her so she's leave us alone.

0.description: I really like this place. I've been here a few times and the guy that does my massage is pretty consistent. Feel pretty relaxed afterwards. I'm heavy set so he puts work into it. My husband on the other hand is ok. The ladies there aren't too strong... he would prefer a guy but since we want to go and leave at the same time. My husband is stuck with a lady. We went there for a foot massage that consist of foot, back and head rub for $28. If u buy a package, it's $100 for 4 foot massages. Pretty good deal but will probably need to go separately from now on. Although we are planning to explore other places too.

4.description: I been there a couple of times.  Each time my experience had been excellent.The location is close to where I work..  I like that fact  it is not just massaging the foot,they also massage the back and head..   I am looking forward to my next visit..

3.description: One of the newer restaurants with a nicer looking interior on the older side of Chinatown. The BBQ pork and roast pork rice are pretty good here and the prices are great with generous portions. The other dishes are relatively solid as well.

1.description: First the place is really clean. The Staff are friendly and maybe a little strange.I came in on Feb 6th, 2012 a bit after 1PM. The place was empty but they had a menu in the window. I based my choisce on that! I just want to know they have something I like before I go in.  I saw BBQ Duck!     First, lose the idea if grilled duck. Maybe BBQ Duck in a Chinese Restaurant can be grilled, but it always seemsd more baked. BBQ, I think describes the spice mix. I LOVE BBQ  Duck!     They do the best BBQ Duck I have had since I moved from San Francisco. Be prepared to eat it off the bones with your fingers... yes you get a fork but no knife. I aught to carry on ein my bag!   Very succulent and not at all dried out.. oh so juicy!     I had this with egg rolls which I suspect are home made, and not delivered frozen, very tastey! I never know what to order with BBQ Duck... I had a medium size which is half a duck... so I got Ginger and Scallion Lo Mein. It was a god choice. Very yummy noodles with a bit of bok choy, ginger and green onion. When the duck is nearly done, the noodles dipped in teh duck juices.. is just phenomenal.    I suspect I am eating this wrong. I suspect I aught to be eatingf it on a pancake with sopme green onion and ginger.... but this really wotked!     They gave me a bowl of chicken broth that was really good.     Okay. the staff all seeemed to be having lunch and weer sitting and talking and I seriously like that. I do not want a waiter hovering at my table and bothering me while I chew.... I never felt rushed or ignored! I am certain that if I waived my hand I could hae sidnaled someone. It is really nice to see the staff eat in the restaurant!

2.description: My friends and I wandered into this place after the Chinese New Year Parade.  We were cold, hungry, and ready to eat.I scanned their extensive menu and decided that I would go with something hot and hearty - the shrimp wonton and bbq pork with noodle soup.  My friends ordered similar items plus eggrolls and a noodle dish.My entree was good - a generous portion of bbq pork, shrimp wonton, and long crazy asian noodles in a tasty broth.  This was not the best I've ever had, but it certainly hit the spot.  My friends seemed to enjoy what they ordered - no complaints.The only thing that was a bit disappointing was that we weren't served our entrees at the same time.  If I had waited for everyone to get their food, my soup would have been cold and hypoglycemia would have set in.  Service was otherwise OK considering there was a post-parade crowd.I would come back to see what it's like a on a regular day and to sample the rest of the menu.

5.description: Went here on a Tuesday night, the place was totally empty but we decided to go anyway because of the great ratings on yelp....what a mistake!!! Worst Chinese food I have ever eaten, hands down. I ordered shrimp dumplings with noodle soup and received pork. They were disgusting and dumpling shells were so soggy they fell apart. The noodles made me wish I was eating ramen at home. Would not do again!

6.description: Great Taste House is what it says, and I'm excited to write the first review on Yelp for it!We came in around noon on Feb 14th - an hour before the Lunar New Year parade kicked off.  Even though the streets were packed with people, we were seated right away and were brought a large hot pot of very good tea, which was great as it was very cold outside.The menu is huge - everything you could possibly want to eat in a Chinese restaurant, and even things you hadn't thought of eating.  The prices are excellent - appetizers around (many under) $5, same for soups and noodle/rice dishes.  Meat and seafood dishes averaged around $10 - $12, some more some less.  The prices were misleading, honestly, because since they were so low we figured the portions would also be smaller as well.  NOT THE CASE AT ALL.  We got 6 potstickers (around $4 for 6), each about the size of a fist and full of juicy, delicious pork filling.  The dough is a little thick, but its still very tasty.  They were huge.  We also got 2 soups - he a shrimp wonton with wide noodle, and me a fishball with thin rice noodle.  Each soup was a little over $4 but came in an enormous steaming bowl heaped with fresh noodles, a delicious chickeny broth, and tender vegetables.  This would have been plenty of food for two people, probably would have even resulted in leftovers, but again, the prices were so low that when we were ordering we kind of went a little nuts and ordered a medium-sized BBQ duck.  I had no idea what "medium" meant (as opposed to the small or large options on the menu), but a medium BBQ duck was a few cents over $8.  I figured that since duck is a more premium meat we'd have a few pieces to share but it wouldn't be too much.  WRONG AGAIN.  The duck plate came out hot, piled high with extremely tender, delicious, and savory soft pieces of duck breast and thigh meat, with crispy skin and chewy duck fat intact (the best part of the duck!)  My only complaint with the duck was that there were bone pieces attached to the meat slices, making it a little difficult to maneuver between the chopsticks and my mouth, but I solved that by just putting down the chopsticks and eating with my hands like a heathen.  Whatever works.It was way too much food for two people, but we are not complaining, as we both have at least an entire meal leftover between the duck and remaining soup.  Maybe a meal and a half.  It was a lot of duck and soup.  The bill for 2 people to get 6 potstickers (again, fist-sized and full of pork), 2 huge bowls of soup, and 1 "medium" BBQ duck was $23.  Awesome!The service was harried but friendly, which was absolutely fine considering that the restaurant was quickly packed with parade-going patrons.  This must be one of the busiest days of the year for restaurants in Chinatown, and Great Taste House delivered excellent food and friendly, swift service despite the hectic environment.  We will definitely go back.  Gung hay fat choi!

7.description: I talked my family into Great Taste for their delicious and affordable Peking Duck for a birthday dinner - a regrettable decision. We ended up arriving at 8:30pm and, not only was it was empty, half of what we tried to order was not available. Sorry, no more duck. Uh .. we don't have any of these vegetables. No - that chicken's gone too.  Our "clean" forks on the table had dried rice in between the prongs. We ended up choosing some dishes that were a-okay, but none of which I would have chosen in the first place. Service was okay - at first. After the dishes came out, all the staff disappeared except for one lady who was mopping the floors, whom we had to flag down to get our receipt.

8.description: WOW! This is some great food. The egg rolls are some of the best I've ever had. The Shrimp dumplings w/Noodle Soup was fantastic. Anybody looking for great food should give this place a try.

9.description: What a great find!  This is a bright new addition to the Chinatown scene.  Extensive menu, wonderfully attentive service, clean surroundings, tasteful fresh food, and best of all extremely affordable!  My new favorite!

0.description: Came here when it just opened. great food, good service, reasonable price. they cook really good northern chinese food.updated: Its closed now

4.description: Came here for dinner and ordered off the Chinese-only menu.  The  small stir-fry dishes were only 5.95-6.95 each.  We ordered 1) stir-fried gai-lan with garlic, 2) beef tendon and turnip pot, 3) Peking style pork chop, 4) oyster and roast pork pot, 5) stir-fried XO pig stomach, and 6) stir-fried you choy with oyster sauce.  I'd order them all again, except for the oyster pot; as expected, there was way too much roast pork - which was mostly dry - and too few and small oysters.  Everything else was great.  The dishes aren't huge, but you can't expect a ton given the prices.  Other notes:-Complimentary rice with meal-Kind of an off location given how far away it is from Chinatown Square-Newly furnished and decorated-Very few patrons-Didn't have a lot to choose from on the menu, and even some of the options weren't available that day.  -The BBQ take-out was very busy and looked delish.

58.description: Super delicious dim sum...everything we ordered was better than expected...the pork preserved egg & pork congee, stuffed sticky rice, shu mai, pan fried pot stickers, and bbq pork crepe.  The only problem we experienced was that we ordered the stuffed egg plant and it never came out until we were already done eating.

56.description: I really wanted to like this place more, but I just can't.  Maybe if i come back again I'll be more successful.  We drove from Milwaukee because we wanted good dim sung, and we don't have it up here and loved it when we were in San Francisco's Chinatown.  I know it is a cultural difference, but the service is terrible.  It took 15-20 minutes of us sitting at a table to figure out how to get food.  The cart lady never came by our table and nobody explained anything, even after it was clear we just had a menu on our table, nothing else.  After we finally were able to track someone down, they told us to use the pen they give us to order on the menu, we weren't given a pen until then, perhaps that is why the confusion?  When we were seated we were also asked if we wanted water & tea, we said yes to both and only got tea.  Thankfully I had a water bottle in my purse.Anyway, we ordered a few things, my favorite was the BBQ steamed buns, everything else wasn't anything I enjoyed too much, but my husband did.  I think next time I just need to order different things and hopefully I can up the review  Oh and the bathrooms are a little strange, and by the really gross looking seafood tanks.

29.description: We really enjoyed ourselves here.  It helped a great deal, that we were on a tour and had a guide who explained a lot about the traditions, culture, and food.  The Siu Mai (pork & shrimp dumplings topped with fish roe) were exceptional.  The lightest dough encased a very well seasoned center.  Dipping it in the various sauces just put it over the top.I had never had tarro, so the deep fried tarro puff with pork was a taste sensation.  The lightness and crispness of the puff was amazing as was the intricate delicate design that was achieved with the fry.  I wasn't quite sure I was going to enjoy the steamed bbq bun as the dough to filling ratio was very off balance.  In the end, I ate the whole thing.  Every bite was more intriguing and the addition of the sauces just made it that much more edible.It was nice to see so many Asian families enjoying this fine tradition.  I will definitely return whenever I am in Chicago.

42.description: My mom was in town and we ended up stumbling into this joint later in the evening. She is really the traditional tiger mom in every sense and has strong opinions about food - so really this review was written on her behalf (I guess I am ghost writing?).From my perspective, an ABC (American Born Chinese), the food was great if not a little too sweet. We got three plates between the two of us - the salt/pepper string beans, the sweet and sour pork, and beef with satay sauce. Portion sizes are ridiculously large so we ended up with dinner part deux/breakfast. The mother complained that both the pork and beef dishes were overly sweet with too much sauce and without enough crispiness. It seemed like they were grilled ahead of time and sauced when ordered - which is a big no-no for those with discerning taste. She did commend the string beans being made very well.Service was superb - our tea was topped off twice and the waiter asked us three times if we were 'okay' and if we needed more rice. This was by the the busiest restaurant in Chinatown that evening but they were well staffed (perhaps overly so) for the guests. Food was served immensely quick as well (leading to our speculation that some was pre-made).From my mother's perspective it was probably a 3-star meal but I really must commend the service that was always courteous and always efficient. I'm definitely more inclined to believe this was a pretty good meal in Chinatown - 4-stars.*Note - they have fresh fish and crabs (and perhaps lobster?) in tanks. If you order one of these dishes, know that it is as fresh as can be.

23.description: I really enjoy the teste here. good service. It is an ideal choice if you want to try some Guangdong food

47.description: I pat anyone's back who walks in here without the knowledge of mandarin or Cantonese language... My waiter spoke no English and upon several hand signs I was able to give my order... Then came the task of bringing the wrong food and placing the check up front and so many things that looked totally weird to me... To an outside this place is like you're in a kubrick movie and trying to break the code..... Totally disappointed...

8.description: Located on the historical Chinatown commercial strip on Wentworth Avenue, just south of Cermak.  It's a second-floor room up about 20 steps, not accessible by elevator.  An open, bright room with big windows overlooking Wentworth.  Perhaps half full at the Thursday lunch hour.They offer a dim sum luncheon daily, though the traditional cart service is available only on weekends.  On weekdays, dim sum items are ordered from one side of an illustrated menu sheet (with plated lunch specials on the other side).  Most dim sum choices are $3.75 for three or four pieces, a few higher.  We ordered six dim sum items, plus the special vermicelli noodles (including what appeared to be Spam!) from the other side of the menu.  Everything was well-executed.  Service was prompt and unobtrusive.  Grub Hub delivery is available.Beer selection is a few standard industrials:  Tsing Tao; Heineken; Blue Moon (an industrial masquerading as a microbrew); and the bland but interestingly-packaged Lucky Buddha.Good public transit access:  A block from the Cermak-Chinatown station on the Red Line.  Also on the 24-Wentworth bus line from the Loop.

31.description: Gross.  Got delivery last night, and it was inedible.  Oh, and it look over an hour and a half to arrive, and it arrived cold.  I found big shrimp shells in two of the items (dumplings and fried rice).  The Sesame Chicken was so dry and hard, I couldn't bite through it.  The fried rice was in a liquid from being over seasoned.  And the worst part was that it was almost $40 for Sesame Chicken, Fried Rice, and Shrimp Dumplings!

34.description: This is a perfectly decent place to eat while visiting Chinatown. The decor is nice if a little cheesy, and there's a nice atmosphere to it. There's always people in there, so it's a nice amount of noise without being too loud. You can still easily make conversation with the people at your table.We came by for lunch while exploring Chinatown, and we weren't disappointed. We started out with two Mai Tais, which were okay. They were a little weak, and really just tasted like juice. For my meal, I ordered mango chicken. It was perfectly adequate. It had simple flavors, and it worked pretty well. You could taste both the natural flavors of the chicken, which was well cooked and moist, and the mango. It was refreshing, light, and simple, but a bit boring.I'd come back here again, but it wasn't anything special to rave about. I've had both better and worse food in Chinatown, and this is definitely a satisfying meal that lands somewhere in the middle of the road.

16.description: This is a perfectly decent place to eat while visiting Chinatown. The decor is nice if a little cheesy, and there's a nice atmosphere to it. There's always people in there, so it's a nice amount of noise without being too loud. You can still easily make conversation with the people at your table.We came by for lunch while exploring Chinatown, and we weren't disappointed. We started out with two Mai Tais, which were okay. They were a little weak, and really just tasted like juice. For my meal, I ordered mango chicken. It was perfectly adequate. It had simple flavors, and it worked pretty well. You could taste both the natural flavors of the chicken, which was well cooked and moist, and the mango. It was refreshing, light, and simple, but a bit boring.I'd come back here again, but it wasn't anything special to rave about. I've had both better and worse food in Chinatown, and this is definitely a satisfying meal that lands somewhere in the middle of the road.

13.description: The food is so good! Everyone on the staff is very helpful and explain the different dim sum dishes to you. The eggplant and the sesame balls were my favorite

11.description: First off, Triple Crown is an oldschool, large, banquet hall type Chinese restaurant.  Don't come for the decor, this isn't some hipster, fusion place, the food is the star.  Try to be seated near the window, the restaurant has a good view of the Pui Tak building which is rather ornate and dates to 1927.Came to Triple Crown with two White friends who had never been to Chicago's Chinatown before and had never eaten Dim Sum.  I grew up Chinese and eating mediocre Midwestern Chinese food in Minnesota with my family, so I did all the ordering.  We came on a weekday, late morning so it wasn't too busy and the restaurant was maybe half full.  We were seated immediately and asked what type of tea we'd like.  I chose the chrysanthemum tea and unexpectedly, we were served a small dish of Chinese rock sugar with the tea.  The rock sugar comes in yellowish lumps, the yellow color comes from the honey mixed it--it was the perfect complement to the tea so you could sweeten it to taste.  An unexpected delight.Unlike many dim sum places where carts are pushed around and you flag down a cart so they can tell you randomly what they have, you order off a paper menu.  This was my first time ordering this way but after trying it, I think it's just a better and less chaotic way of getting everything you want.  The menu is nicely printed on glossy paper with color pictures and textual description of the food in both English and Chinese.  This is great if you're like me and grew up simply ordering in Cantonese but can't read Chinese and don't really know what dishes are called when "translated" into English.  I quickly went through the menu and checked off about ten items.The food arrived at our table hot and fast.  I ordered all the standard Dim Sum items.  Har Gow, Lor Mai Gai, Char Siu Bao, Hom Sui Gok, Wu Gohk, Har Cheung, Dja Leung and others.  Most of the items came with three pieces so it was perfectly portioned for our odd table of three to sample a lot of things without filling up on anything in particular.  Everything ordered was on point.  I came to realize the advantage of ordering off a menu vs. random push carts since most of the dishes arrived piping hot and together.  With carts you never really know what's available and often there are dead times when the table is empty and you are waiting for a car to come around--NOT THE CASE HERE!  Triple Crown's Dim Sum service was superb.  We didn't have any single server but instead there were roaming servers who quickly cleared old dishes and kept our teapot full.  I was impressed.I've read some other reviews from worldly Yelpers who compare their experiences to New York, San Francisco Chinatowns or even Hong Kong.  Well you're not in any of those places--you're in Chicago.  For the Midwest USA, Triple Crown in the heart of Chicago's Chinatown is as good as it gets.

39.description: I had heard good reviews and thought I would try it.  Sesame chicken was excellent as was the Sui Mai.I was really disturbed that the Men's bathroom had no soap.   I spoke with an employee who then went and questioned several other employees only to return and tell me that they had no soap!

37.description: There Dim Sum was delish! I always prefer the kinds that has the carts going around.

0.description: Foods are great, with good price. I think I'll recommend to my friends and go here again. But here are some thing I hope can improve.Long before we finished, a madam kept asking us whether we've finished and tried to take the dishes away, while apparently we were not because there were still more than 1/3 foods on each dishes.When we ask for box  to go they only offer one. We have 3 dishes left. Then we ask for one more box. And madam insist one box is enough and squeeze all of our ramen into it.

38.description: Triple Crown is my all time favorite Dim Sum restaurant. I used to come here every morning with my boyfriend when we first met lol. I still come here every week to get Shu Mai, Pot stickers, Steamed hot custard buns, Congee, shrimp dumplings, and shrimp crepes. Everyone is nice and friendly especially Morgan. He makes me want to visit this restaurant every day. Sometimes I order delivery and the drivers arrive at my door step within 30 minutes. The food is always hot and fresh. I wish I could eat Dim Sum from Triple Crown every day.

51.description: It was my first time that I had a family dinner here. We had 13 people and ordered the 10 courses family dinner meal for $168. It was recentable price and the food was excellent!  Really recommended if you have a big family.

27.description: Located on the historical Chinatown commercial strip on Wentworth Avenue, just south of Cermak.  It's a second-floor room up about 20 steps, not accessible by elevator.  An open, bright room with big windows overlooking Wentworth.  Perhaps half full at the Thursday lunch hour.They offer a dim sum luncheon daily, though the traditional cart service is available only on weekends.  On weekdays, dim sum items are ordered from one side of an illustrated menu sheet (with plated lunch specials on the other side).  Most dim sum choices are $3.75 for three or four pieces, a few higher.  We ordered six dim sum items, plus the special vermicelli noodles (including what appeared to be Spam!) from the other side of the menu.  Everything was well-executed.  Service was prompt and unobtrusive.  Grub Hub delivery is available.Beer selection is a few standard industrials:  Tsing Tao; Heineken; Blue Moon (an industrial masquerading as a microbrew); and the bland but interestingly-packaged Lucky Buddha.Good public transit access:  A block from the Cermak-Chinatown station on the Red Line.  Also on the 24-Wentworth bus line from the Loop.

32.description: This place is pretty good for dim sum, hospitality and atmosphere is welcoming. Menu is simple, affordable and a great place to have good talks and food!

54.description: After years of coming in, I really appreciate their consistence food quality and service. I have had dim sum, lunch, diner, midnight snack, and banquet in here. Triple crown have not disappoint me once. Dishes always served hot and tasty. The live seafood is my favorite. Their chef is very talented on seafood, cooking time is perfect. Triple Crown captures my heart, the best restaurant to go for seafood in Chinatown!

48.description: My boyfriend and I have been wanting to get to Chinatown for awhile and finally made it this Sunday afternoon. We had a little trouble finding parking but once we did we headed straight to Triple Crown and were seated upstairs right away. The place was hustling and bustling with dishes being brought out and glasses refilled left and right. We started by ordering sake and a cocktail (the Chinese mule). The server returned with sake but stated that no one knew how to make the mule, which seemed odd, as it was simply ginger beer, vodka and lime... But we stuck with the sake.We ordered 6 dim sum items, and a hot and sour soup to share. The soup was yummy but not much different from PF Changs to me. We loved the shrimp and pork steamed balls and the BBQ pork steamed buns, but all were tasty. The ox tripe steamed with ginger was a surprisingly great addition. Probably would not order the chicken feet or beef short ribs again, but I'm glad we tried them. Stop at a bakery nearby for a treat after your meal!

44.description: Saturday-08/15/15My (our) first time there and the food (dim sum) was Delicious! Although their services was a bit delayed and atmosphere was quite busy, but what could we have expected during lunch time and in China Town? Busy busy busy or in other words "rush hour". Spent roughly $52 on just dim sum and hot tea and it was well worth it! During our first round we were too hungry and forgot to take photos (I got to take one after we were like half way eating our first round of dim sum) and my sister was the one ordering so I was not informed of what she was ordering and I didn't really mind . The second round arrived and we were super full already but we continued and finished our second round meal. It's was like "happiness" in my mouth when I first took a bite out of the selected dim sums that was placed on the table in front of me. I literally was so full of the delicious food and joy that I just couldn't stop my joy from showing! Some customers were probably looking at me all weird but oh well the food was too yummy! I believe my sister and niece also enjoyed their meal as much as I did also. They were all tired and filled with happiness afterwards Lol. I'm definitely going back to visit for my birthday! And just whenever I have the time.

24.description: A nice decent Chinese restaurant. Their dim sums are better than the items on their main menu. One suggestion is to skip their main menu and have just the dim sum.

7.description: My boyfriend and I have been wanting to get to Chinatown for awhile and finally made it this Sunday afternoon. We had a little trouble finding parking but once we did we headed straight to Triple Crown and were seated upstairs right away. The place was hustling and bustling with dishes being brought out and glasses refilled left and right. We started by ordering sake and a cocktail (the Chinese mule). The server returned with sake but stated that no one knew how to make the mule, which seemed odd, as it was simply ginger beer, vodka and lime... But we stuck with the sake.We ordered 6 dim sum items, and a hot and sour soup to share. The soup was yummy but not much different from PF Changs to me. We loved the shrimp and pork steamed balls and the BBQ pork steamed buns, but all were tasty. The ox tripe steamed with ginger was a surprisingly great addition. Probably would not order the chicken feet or beef short ribs again, but I'm glad we tried them. Stop at a bakery nearby for a treat after your meal!

49.description: Nice place for a late dinner in chicago area.

40.description: The food and the proportions are good HOWEVER the waitress we had was extremely rude. She did not attend to the table at all. She took our order and not once asked how everything was or if we needed any drinks. She had an attitude for anything we asked her for. We felt sorry for her and still tipped her well but she didn't seem to appreciate it. The bathrooms were disgusting. There was garbage and sanitary napkins every where.

53.description: In Chinatown Chicago where else? Had to come and find a place for some delicious Chinese food and we found it! We had:  The Triple Crown Shrimp dumplings, Steamed BBQ Pork buns, Pan Fried Pot stickers, the combination fried rice and the chicken with vegetables. A LOT of food, I know, BUT it was sooo GOOD. The plates are really meant to be shared (in my opinion) which is what we did.  Service was good. So glad we came!

30.description: Always my go to spot in Chinatown. I know I get what I order. The food is good and service is not bad. The dining room is nice and clean. The staff is usually attentive. I go for dim sum and dinner. My wife's family love this place and I always end up here with them for birthdays or just to have a large dinner with friends and family.

46.description: Of all the cart dim sum places in Chicago, this one is probably the best. I've been like a dozen times, the most memorable with the head of the Chicago Teachers Union legal team and his "artistic bohemian" son Sam (bitter division rival in my fantasy basketball league). Egg tarts are awesome, as are the creps, siu mai, shrimp dumplings, pork baos, etc. etc. It's a little greasy sometimes, and for food quality alone, MingHin and YumCha have a slight edge. Overall, not bad. Awesome how you can pop in late at night, too, and get dim sum off the menu.

1.description: A-Ok, A-Ok. Compared to Cai down the street the service here is much quicker, but on the couple times we've been here they tend to forget one of the dishes you ordered. So keep an eye on your order!Ordering is done through menu where you mark everything you want and items are brought out, but they also have some carts floating around with additional items you can order. Overall the food is good, but I would prefer the dim sum from Cai as it does taste a bit fresher. As I mentioned before service here is much quicker and by the time we handed over our menu order we had food on our table within the minute.Lastly, can anyone tell me why dim sum places in Chicago don't serve hot mustard sauce on the side? The investigation continues...Anyways, sometimes you win sum and sometimes you dim sum. Til next time, cheers!

55.description: i ordered eggplant w minced pork & salted fish casserole with white rice. What i got had next to none of the salted fish.. in flavor nor crunchy bite ...it was sooo bland. Priced at $10.95 this dish is just a dollar or two difference from other casserole dishes w whole chunks of meat in them so i would not expect them to stint on tiny bits of fish and minced pork. Instead this simple classic came as a pile of mushy eggplants in sauce & not much else. This dish if done right is a fine example of cantonese cuisine with its complex layers of nuanced flavors. what i got was a sad watered down fake, just like the chinese tea they served me too. Lots of room for improvement.

9.description: This review is specifically for delivery.  I love the soups - HOT SOUR, VEGGIE & SEAWEED.  I get the veggie with a handful of raw garlic thrown in to boot - cuz I love garlic.  I've already ordered the COMBO FRIED RICE, POT STICKERS, CRAB RANGOON, SCALLION PANCAKES & STUFFED CRAB CLAWS.  A special mention that the crab rangoon is one of the best I have ever had.  Being in Pilsen delivery direct from the restaurant has been within an hour all times.  The food arrives steaming hot even in cold weather. No pics yet for this one...gotta dine in!!

26.description: This restaurant serves authentic Cantonese food.  I was there on Saturday night and wow was I surprised by their menu selection!  They have large array of fresh seafood (life in display tank) and great dim sum as well.  Ordered 6 different dim sum dishes, a spicy wine clam, and lemongrass oxtail.  The clam reminds me of fresh oyster where it's not overcooked and chewy like most Chinese restaurant.  Lemongrass oxtail was out of the world.  Service was above average comparing to similar Chinese restaurant.  Ambiance was very nice and comfy as well appeared to be slight upscale restaurant.  Overall very impressed and would definitely return!

25.description: This place isn't my first time here, I wouldn't say it's the best nor the worse. The food is good, I've had better shrimp dumplings and sesame balls, and #64 on the menu. Chicken feet was good, it had a powerful flavor of the black bean sauce, the Shanghai soup dumplings were a little weird, and shrimp balls were good! I knocked off a star because we came in at 10am and was seated right away, no cart went in our direction for 10 minutes. We were super hangry. Group of four, bill came to $60 total which isn't bad!

12.description: I love you Triple Crown!!!! Thanks for being the best dim sum place I know in Chicago!My boyfriend & I recently traveled to China & Hong Kong, & there I tried all the original dim sum, but I must say Triple crown holds their own!Lo bok go (turnip cakes) & Gao choi bao (green leek buns) are hands down my favorite here. They both have a crispy exterior with a soft hot interior. The Gao choi buns have a nice thin wrap with lots of filling, I can eat like 20! (Ok maybe 3, they're pretty filling lol)Another unforgettable dim sum here are the Cheong fan (stuffed rice noodles). You get choices of what you want stuffed inside, I like the crispy tofu skin with veggies. You douse them in a sweet soy sauce & just devour them... they're bites of heaven~The Siu mai (steamed shrimp dumplings w/ roe),Ngao yuk kau (steamed meatballs) & Pai gwut (steamed riblets) are regular dim sum dishes we always order as well, sooo good.With three people eating & more than 20 dishes ordered our bill was about $70 Almost like Hong Kong prices, very cheap & yummy!~ They have after hour dim sum specials as well, half the menu but half the price for late night cravings :).

59.description: Everything is perfect. I especially love the pan fried shrimp and chive dumpling, it is so juicy and so tasty. I wish there is such a nice restaurant in the city I live.

21.description: Many of my friends order delivery from here, but I finally made it to the actual restaurant. We arrived for my friends birthday. Serving up dimsum at night, we ordered the typical shumai and shrimp hargow. We also ordered seafood tofu pot that was amazing. The beef flat noodles were also good. I personally love peapod greens and thy cooked them well. Not too crowded, quick service, good traditional Chinese food. What more can you ask for?

17.description: Always my go to spot in Chinatown. I know I get what I order. The food is good and service is not bad. The dining room is nice and clean. The staff is usually attentive. I go for dim sum and dinner. My wife's family love this place and I always end up here with them for birthdays or just to have a large dinner with friends and family.

10.description: My favorite place in Chinatown!!! I've been going here for years and today was the first time I've been for lunch. Get here early it gets packed!! The dim sum menu is phenomenal and they walk around with it on carts during lunch. The specials were good too! I tried the sweet and sour chicken which was delicious!

5.description: I was so pleased with my entire experience at Triple Crown. Boothang and me dined at Triple Crown on a Friday evening at 7 and - even though I made a reservation and didn't need to - there was no wait for a table. We were seated right against the window that overlooked the street and I loved it. It is true that the wait staff speaks very little English but if anyone has an issue with that, they should go to Panda Express. When you enter Chinatown you enter CHINA'S TOWN! don't expect them to understand your advanced Webster's English. That's why they have pictures on the menu.I was so surprised how inexpensive the Dim Sum was. We ordered 2 servings of the BBQ pork buns, pot stickers, beef spare ribs, shrimp and pork dumpling, and fried pork dumpling and all together the check was $23.What I loved , other than the affordability and the freshness of all the food, was how not all the dishes were served at the same time. That way the dishes wouldn't get cold just sitting on the table.The wait staff do not hover...if you want that kind of service you shouldn't come to Chinatown. Asian customer service is very different than American standards of customer service. it should be generally understood that when you come to an area like Chinatown that you conform to THEIR ways not expect them to do the inverse.

3.description: The best dim sum in Chinatown, going on the weekend is a plus no need to wait for your order since the servers are walking around with dim sum on the carts !  Go early before 12 or you will wait in line for quite a while . Trying new things is great when doing dim sum especially when you only pay as little as $3 dollars for some , try the Bbq pork /shrimp crepes , taro balls, shu mai or the sticky rice ....Love this place !

35.description: I'm a New Yorker used to superior Chinatown cuisine in NYC. Triple Crown is the real deal. Great Dim Sum and fantastically cooked dishes. We always do our last night's group feast there when at the Convention Center.

19.description: My mom was in town and we ended up stumbling into this joint later in the evening. She is really the traditional tiger mom in every sense and has strong opinions about food - so really this review was written on her behalf (I guess I am ghost writing?).From my perspective, an ABC (American Born Chinese), the food was great if not a little too sweet. We got three plates between the two of us - the salt/pepper string beans, the sweet and sour pork, and beef with satay sauce. Portion sizes are ridiculously large so we ended up with dinner part deux/breakfast. The mother complained that both the pork and beef dishes were overly sweet with too much sauce and without enough crispiness. It seemed like they were grilled ahead of time and sauced when ordered - which is a big no-no for those with discerning taste. She did commend the string beans being made very well.Service was superb - our tea was topped off twice and the waiter asked us three times if we were 'okay' and if we needed more rice. This was by the the busiest restaurant in Chinatown that evening but they were well staffed (perhaps overly so) for the guests. Food was served immensely quick as well (leading to our speculation that some was pre-made).From my mother's perspective it was probably a 3-star meal but I really must commend the service that was always courteous and always efficient. I'm definitely more inclined to believe this was a pretty good meal in Chinatown - 4-stars.*Note - they have fresh fish and crabs (and perhaps lobster?) in tanks. If you order one of these dishes, know that it is as fresh as can be.

28.description: Great place and good service. I've been there several times and tried almost every kind of dim sun, so my suggestion is, just order anything you like, or do it randomly, cause every dim sum there is tasty!

45.description: I was so pleased with my entire experience at Triple Crown. Boothang and me dined at Triple Crown on a Friday evening at 7 and - even though I made a reservation and didn't need to - there was no wait for a table. We were seated right against the window that overlooked the street and I loved it. It is true that the wait staff speaks very little English but if anyone has an issue with that, they should go to Panda Express. When you enter Chinatown you enter CHINA'S TOWN! don't expect them to understand your advanced Webster's English. That's why they have pictures on the menu.I was so surprised how inexpensive the Dim Sum was. We ordered 2 servings of the BBQ pork buns, pot stickers, beef spare ribs, shrimp and pork dumpling, and fried pork dumpling and all together the check was $23.What I loved , other than the affordability and the freshness of all the food, was how not all the dishes were served at the same time. That way the dishes wouldn't get cold just sitting on the table.The wait staff do not hover...if you want that kind of service you shouldn't come to Chinatown. Asian customer service is very different than American standards of customer service. it should be generally understood that when you come to an area like Chinatown that you conform to THEIR ways not expect them to do the inverse.

33.description: If you want consistent dimsum then come here.  We usually come around 10am that way there is no line.  If you come on a sunday at 10am most of the regulars are at church still. I always come back to this place even after trying other places.

43.description: The food is ok, but service is a mess. My husband ate a metal staple from a squid dish. But the manager just simply cancel that particular dish. That's it...

2.description: The octopus... Is so (insert your expletive here) good.The everything... is so tasty.The Prices... are so appropriate. Please eat here, because if they decide to close down it would break my heart.

18.description: I've been going here since I was a kid! Love this place a lot. The service here is pretty fast. I really like coming here for dim sum, as well as late night dinners leaving work. Their food is pretty tasty! I really enjoy their shrimp crepes. My all time favorite. This is great place to go eat out with family and friends. I'd recommend this place!

41.description: dont ask me why I only gave little tips. Terrible customer service，the waitress even clean up yr table while u still worked on it.

52.description: This is an OK restaurant to eat at, just because there doesn't seem to be anything special with Triple Crown. The food was mediocre. Some items are pretty good, but some of the food was left out on the carts for so long that they had gone cold.The servers aren't fast, but they aren't terribly slow either.The interior design, though, seems a little tacky.

50.description: From the moment you walk trough the front door and step on the dirty carpet, you know you are taking a risk. The atmosphere is loud, and the menus are dirty and worn. The restrooms are very dirty and ill equipped. The pepper flier was chewy, and the lobster was too. The lemon chicken was like eating a sugar costed snack. The room temperature was too warm, and the place was stuffy. We have a nice waitress, but the bus boy was reaching over us I clear the tackle even before we opened our fortune cookies. Would not recommend.

4.description: I am very thankful that this place delivers to those of us who work in the Loop.  Living so far away from Chinatown, I find myself always envying people who can get delicious, authentic Chinese food delivered to them without having to leave their house.  But, at least I can do the same while at work.  Although it's only 2 miles from my building, it took 90 mins for me to get my food.  But Lily F. is patient.  I ordered the beef with Chinese broccoli ($13) and the salt and pepper pork ($11).  I know I should never order anything fried when it's a 90 min wait, but I just couldn't help myself.  The beef arrived just a little warm and the pork was pretty much room temperature but I knew that would happen ahead of time.  The flavor was all there.  The Chinese broccoli wasn't mushy, but still firm and sitting underneath huge slices beef that were flavorful and surprisingly tender.  The sauce it came with was a little thick was lots of ginger and garlic, just the way I like it.  The salty pork, although cold, still tasted great with tons of little chopped up pieces of onion, jalapenos and salty goodness.  I could only imagine what the dishes tastes like in house.  This place is definitely pricey, but the portions are pretty big.  Their menu is quite extensive and they even deliver their dim sum.  I'll have to go there and eat one day.  My fortune cookie said, "Lucky is coming your way."  Misspelling? Or a puppy named 'Lucky'  for Christmas?

6.description: I can't decide if I love this place for the killer dimsum or for nostalgia's sake. We'll go with the dimsum for the sake of this review. The truth is Triple Crown has undergone quite a number of renovations since the first time I came here..... About 8 years ago. The food has stayed amazing the entire time. For me, having a place I can drop by long after I've left the Midwest and know I'm getting a delicious meal without hassle is priceless.I dropped by for Dimsum when I was in town with the boyfriend visiting his family. There was a bit of a wait but that's standard with ANY quality dimsum restaurant. The food was worth the wait. I went with four first timers and they loved everything. Granted I stuck to the tried and true favorites: har kow, Cha siu bao, and various other dumplings and small pies. The thing is, everything is still as delicious as I remember. At least I know that when I make my way back to the bitter cold of the Midwest I have a great meal waiting for me at Triple Crown. I wish I lived closer.... Okay no, I take that back, SoCal treats me really well. I guess I wish there was a Triple Crown where I live now. Regardless, Triple Crown always makes me think of going home and that is nothing but Midwest Love.

22.description: Went with two of my friends, one had never been to China Town. Decided to eat here bc of the great reviews on Yelp. I will have to disagree with the 3 1/2 star rating. The two stars i gave was bc the food was really great. We have the sample platter, crab rangoons, shrimp fried rice,Generals tso, and shrimp chow mien. We sat down and it took about 15min for someone to come say hello to us and ask us what we would like to eat. So we put our entire order in together bc if it took them that long to come to our table, we had a feeling we wouldnt be seeing them much, yet they had a huge staff working , so .... Our sampler came and of course our meals came right after, i cant STAND that!!! And like we predicted, we had to flag someone down for more water and never got more napkins . The bathrooms were GROSS!!!! I wish i would have went in there first bc i would have turned around and left. Bathrooms say a lot about a place and lets you know what the kitchen may look like. A waitress was in there too and didnt take her apron off , nasty!!!

15.description: We really enjoyed ourselves here.  It helped a great deal, that we were on a tour and had a guide who explained a lot about the traditions, culture, and food.  The Siu Mai (pork & shrimp dumplings topped with fish roe) were exceptional.  The lightest dough encased a very well seasoned center.  Dipping it in the various sauces just put it over the top.I had never had tarro, so the deep fried tarro puff with pork was a taste sensation.  The lightness and crispness of the puff was amazing as was the intricate delicate design that was achieved with the fry.  I wasn't quite sure I was going to enjoy the steamed bbq bun as the dough to filling ratio was very off balance.  In the end, I ate the whole thing.  Every bite was more intriguing and the addition of the sauces just made it that much more edible.It was nice to see so many Asian families enjoying this fine tradition.  I will definitely return whenever I am in Chicago.

57.description: Went to check out Chicago Chinatown for the first time and was looking for a place to get some soup.  It was a bit overwhelming with all the shops, but we happened to walk by this one, and the menu in the window looked pretty enticing.  Dim sum, lunch special, and all sorts of Chinese dishes to choose from...  and nice pictures and prices along with the menu, too.  Count us in!The restaurant was actually located upstairs, and it was in a nice, open banquet room overlooking a nice building across the street.  It wasn't too busy for a late lunch on a Tuesday afternoon, and we were promptly seated.The seats were really comfy, and the menu was very easy to read.  I liked how all the dim sum dishes were clearly marked with prices and style (i.e. steamed, fried, dessert, etc.)We settled on egg drop soup, Mongolian beef, shrimp dumpling, and Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce.  Everything was fresh and delicious and very tasty.  Lunch for two only cost just over 20 bucks, and hot tea was even included free of charge.  What a great find;  I'm so glad we found this place for lunch.  :)

20.description: I googled what restaurant to go to eat Dim Sum and this was one of the options. I googled mapped it and I ended up on the other side of Chinatown to find out its literally right in front of the "Welcome to ChinaTown" We went in the morning I thought it was going to be packed, but it was dead. Food was great. I noticed a lot of shrimp in many of the food options. Everything was hot and fresh. I got a pretty good amount of food quantity and the bill was cheaper than I expected!I would definitely go back again!!!

36.description: Five friends for dim sum at one of the few places that serves it all evening, we all left with full happy bellies.  Restaurant was about half full, service was attentive, food arrived quickly.  We spent $75 on dim sum and tea (including tip).We had 2 orders each of pot stickers, dumplings, steamed BBQ buns, egg rolls, eggplant, sesame balls, and one huge order of combination friend rice.  Everything was very flavorful (perhaps from salt or MSG?  Not sure, but was tasty!), hot, and had the right texture.  My only super minor complaint was I didn't love the bun - the BBQ pork was good, but the bun itself was a tad dry and falling apart.  Overall, great!!

14.description: Great Chinese food, but absolutely terrible service. Came here with a couple of friends who were visiting from out of town and wanted to check out some authentic Chinese food. While of us were throughly satisfies with the quality of all the dishes, I don't think I've come across worse service. First,  it took is over 15 minutes just to be acknowledged and served water. We brought our own beer as this place is byob but none of the wait staff seemed to know of the policy and we're given conflicting answers as to if it's OK to drink our own. I strongly recommend bringing your own bottle opener as it took about 25 min just for them to find one we could use. Oh and the waitress was just atrocious. Couldn't speak a lick of English and had a horrible attitude. I'll probably come again, but only for takeout. No chance I'd sit down with that level of service.

3.description: Well, I am going to go ahead and say that my girlfriend and I have found THE GREATEST ITEM IN ALL OF CHICAGO'S CHINATOWN in this store. That's right, we found it and its ours. There was only one of them and we got it. Ours and not yours. In the back of the shelf, covered in twenty years of dust laden with that disinfecting spray that covers all the merchandise that comes over from China lay.... THE GREATEST ITEM IN ALL OF CHICAGO'S CHINATOWN!!!! We looked long and hard for this item, perusing reproductions of Da Vinci's Last Supper, 342 different variations of Buddha in the same position (they one where you're supposed to rub his belly.) 43 different Ipod covers with the likeness of a drunken Super Mario on it, 89 imitation Hello Kitty statuettes, Traditional silk Chinese garb that white people can wear around to feel ethnic, Plastic gun sets (with darts and handcuffs), extremely marked up 'elephant tusks' which you are told are 'ivory' but are really just pieced together bone around a wood form, More buddha statuettes, quaint and tranquil babbling fountains with bamboo shoots growing in them, cheap swords with what white people have recognized as 'traditional' or maybe will throw around the word 'samuri' to describe, and a whole boat full of dragons and geishas and other pan-Asian junk that I dont know will ever sell to find THE GREATEST ITEM IN ALL OF CHICAGO'S CHINATOWN!!!!! AS I SAID BEFORE, on the back of the shelf, behind the ordinary novelty items sat....THE GREATEST ITEM IN ALL OF CHICAGO'S CHINATOWN, a porcelain Collie dog in a pimp outift. Yes, This collie (THE GREATEST ITEM IN ALL OF CHICAGO'S CHINATOWN) is equipped with not only a hat with a feather, but a matching red vest, and is looking his best while he fulfills the needs of other Collies. This AMAZING find was one of a kind, and it is OURS. YES, I repeat THE GREATEST ITEM IN ALL OF CHICAGO'S CHINATOWN IS OURS.Maybe the Pimp collie is on reorder, another barge will be sent across the Pacific, loaded onto a train in Oakland and then shipped to a distributor nearby Pacific Furniture and will thus be soon available for purchase. Either way, there is something magic about Pacific Furniture.

1.description: One of the better Chinatown stores.Everything from bamboo shoots (real) to artificial flowers.Buddha statues + jade + all other such items.Only down side is the tiny cramped spaces/aisles

2.description: Pacific Furniture is the very crowded store at the entrance way to Chinatown at the southwest corner of Cermak and Wentworth Funny. I have been in here several times to look at accent pieces (did you know that the English style of decorating includes Chinese touches? Well, it does and they fit beautifully into my old English home) but I rarely buy anything as this place as it is usually mobbed by tourists. While the word furniture is in the name- this is not a furniture store. Rather- a store full of wholesale import goods from China with everything from commercial tea sets to hand painted ginger jars, canes, statues, balloons, umbrellas and knick knacks of every type pack this store. It actually reminds me of some of the stores that I went into when I was in Schenszen, China. Not for the faint of heart- the pushing and maneuvering through the packed aisles will leave you "head-achy" and irritated- well at least it does me! But then- just as you say you've had enough, you see it. That perfect pot or hand painted accent table set off in the back corner. You look around to see if anyone else is eying it but they are all upfront looking at the cheap souvenir imports. You feign disinterest when the shop owner comes over and starts the sales pitch. But you know that in the end you must have it. And so you do. I wish there was a secret way to get into this store so I only had to look at things that were of some value and not all the "junk" in the front. Ahh . . .a girl can wish. And the next time I am looking for that perfect ginger jar or ceramic garden stool to act as an end table or accent piece, I will be in there looking in all the dusty corners. For it is there that the real treasures are in this store.

0.description: This place has such a wide variety of things.  Items in this store do frequently come with a layer of dust, but the sheer volume and variety is really awesome.  The furniture is upstairs and is not usually obvious it's okay to head up there.  One of the few places that tends to keep Lotus Leaf Bamboo on hand, I head here at least once per year and usually walk away with having found some other treasure that I could not live without.

58.description: the cashier woman still has a stick up her butt -- the shaved ice quality got worse since the last time i got it and is nothing like the typical shaved ice in taiwan or korean bing su.

56.description: Give them another chance after their grand opening experience I have to say they did very well....shabu shabu is excellent and the raman is totally awesome. Just the portion is a little small so the bill can add up fast....their fruit drinks are excellent as usual...will come back again with kids...

29.description: I would love to give this place 5 stars but there are a few things that keep me from doing so.My bf and I have been coming here almost weekly after discovering it about 3 months ago. We have tried their avocado mushroom tempura, it's pretty good. There are a lot of avocado in the mix.We also have tried their chicken wing, beef and squid leg skewers. They are all okay but our favorite is the beef one. Now onto the shabu shabu. They have two different broths. If you get any seafood, you will get the seafood broth. I personally really love their beef broth! The shabu shabu is enough for two people. Their beef quality is okay, a little fatty and comes with an array of fish balls and veggies (cabbage, spinach, Chinese lettuce, enoki mushroom, one carrot, one radish, one corn, glass noodles, and tofu) sometimes the veggies are just not fresh! The tray of sauces are amazing. Sometimes, they are out of some of their sauces and they replace it with other ones. I've also had their shaved ice. I don't recommend it. We always go to the regular joy yee to get boba. Come here on a cold day and you won't be disappointed!

42.description: DO NOT BRING YOUR GOOD LOOKING ASIAN GIRLFRIEND THERE CAUSE THE WAITERS WILL GO CRAZY !!!!I have been going to this place for shabu shabu since freshmen year and loved it.However, I had the worst experience anyone could have in a dinning occasion a few months ago. During the time we were there. Two of the waiters in their 20's would constantly clean the table next to ours and constantly came over to our table to check around not asking any question or provide any services just wandering around checking out my girlfriend and her friend. I have been here enough times to know how they behave  normally.My girlfriend ( winter cloths, not exposing at all) also expressed to me that the waiters kept trying to make eye contact with her and its making her very uncomfortable. One of the waiters who took our order also talked to me in a tone that's very provoking and then turn around talking to my girlfriend and her friends in a very flirty tone and try to tell jokes for no reason....A few mins later, another girl joined us for lunch. We try to make extra order of shabu sbhabu combo and the waiter rudely interrupt us from ordering more saying we cant finish it anyways... he believed we dont need to order an extra combo in such a mad tone that even the manager came out to check out what happened.... we had no idea why he did that and had no idea why we couldnt order more since we werent even wasting food. His facial expression and his tone was in a way that trying to provoke me and trying to get me into an argument with him .... I didnt react to all that and left the restaurant with disappointment.I give them 2 stars for the sake of good experiences i had there before otherwise i would go for 1

23.description: This is my first time trying Joyee's sister restaurant. It's smaller and more intimate. What this restaurant specialize in is hot pots. We weren't sure what to mix and match so we chose a package. It was called the prime rib eye steak shabu shabu. They bring out a pot of beef broth on a burner for you and you throw in your raw ingredients. You're pretty much cooking your own meal. It was fun in my opinion and the broth had good flavor. For me, I used the broth as more of a flavoring tool for my vegetables and meat. I didn't really drink the soup because I noticed oil on the top. I knew I would feel really heavy afterwards if I were to drink it. The experience was very casual but I haven't been to a lot of hot pot restaurants, so it's nice to know I found one nearby my apartment.

47.description: This place by far is my favorite restaurant of all time. I took my husband out for dinner here (first time I ever bought a guy dinner!) for our first date ever and we got married... So I guess it worked!!Shabu shabu here is beyond amazing. I highly recommend the Kobe beef shabu shabu (it's not actually Kobe beef if you know much about Kobe beef and usda stuff but it's still very very marbled and tender beef!) For the set I believe it is about $22, and my husband always orders a la carte salmon and I order extra enoki and potato noodles. The plate you order comes out with raw ingredients, and a boiling hot pot of broth to cook it all in over a portable stove top. You also get a tray of sauces which my husband and I often add to the broth before we add the ingredients to taste. We also bogart 2 of the sauces for dipping everything we cook in (he likes the peanut sauce and I like the satay [aka BBQ] sauce.) Cooking food together is really fun and romantic but don't come here hoping for a private booth and quiet area to have a nice date. The restaurant is very "open" in design and has a very modern feel to it. There's even a koi pond under the floor so you can watch the fish swim around beneath you! Really charming! So this isn't a place for a quiet romantic date, but a fun and engaging one. If you go with friends in a large group it's always a blast. You always try to pair up with someone because the shabu shabu sets serve 2 normally. Almost everyone I have brought here has left singing praises about the food and the atmosphere and it's a great place for lively conversation and merriment-- even with just bubble tea and no alcohol. I'm not sure if they even serve alcohol (they probably do) but the awesome drink selections of bubble tea are way more enticing than alcohol. My personal favorite is the kiwi sprite, it's a very simple drink but I never thought kiwi and sprite would make such a perfect combo. I don't know if they use some sort of sweetening syrup for their kiwis (a lot of bubble tea places do) but I have tried to recreate the drink at home to no avail. It's worth the price and having it as a treat with dinner is great. There are hundreds of drinks and smoothies and I'm pretty sure if you can think of it, it's listed on the menu. As far as the dishes they serve outside of shabu shabu, I have had limited experience with their sushi and not much else. The sushi a couple years ago was to die for, but last year I tried some and it was made completely different from the one I ordered a year prior and I wasn't really impressed. I think they may have gotten yet another sushi chef though since then so maybe the quality has improved again? But if you are going to a shop labeled "shabu shabu" on the front why would you get anything but that?My friends have had some noodle dishes from here before and said they were good but always kinda wistfully watched everyone else cooking their own food. It's all personal taste but the shabu shabu and drinks really are the headlining stars of this place. Never had a bad experience food wise, and the service has never been an issue for me but I am also not afraid to flag down waitresses when I need something. Every now and then there will be a communication error but they always have resolved it and have never been rude to me. However if you don't tip (I've had friends who don't and it is a shame to me) the service will pick up on it and if you come back they seem to just "know". I always have tipped well because I never had anything but great service so your mileage may vary. In summary... This is my favorite place in the world. Fun, friendly (if you can be friendly back), and DELICIOUS. I will continue to be a patron until either I or Chinatown are gone from this earth. 10 out of 5 stars.

8.description: Disclaimer: I'm #teamhotpot, but I guess shabu-shabu is not too bad.The food is pretty good. We ordered a few plates of meat and seafood, with some veggies mixed in. Everything was fresh and yummy. Nobody got food poisoning that night.The place lets you mix your own dipping sauce, with plenty of options like chives, roasted garlic and different types of soy sauce. Pretty cool and convenient for both parties. I liked the spicy anchovies sate sauce a little too much, kept going back for more. Nobody can judge me!They also offer tons of smoothies and drinks. We didn't try any though. Looks good on the menu.Prices were reasonable. We ended paying about $100 after tax/tip for 3 people, and everybody left with a full stomach. However, just FYI, there's an all-you-can-eat hot-pot place a few doors down for $25/person. If you want lots of meat and seafood, I guess that's the way to go.Service was also good.
