The one vegetarian ended up going home 5 minutes after she arrived because there was nothing she could eat.Even though the food wasn't truly exceptional, I found the environment enjoyable and food edible. I was planning to come back until we got the bill. I'm a recent college grad so I'm used to being in large groups with the tip already added onto the bill. Usually it's between 15% and 20% if you're a group larger than 8 so we all planned to pay about $30 bucks including tax and tip. But when we got the check, they charged us 30%. Yes, 30 PERCENT. We asked them about that but never got a straight answer about why such an upcharge. They never told us that in advance.  I don't know at what point do they tack on the 30% but I know I'm not coming back. I would've tipped them more than my 15% I was expecting for dealing with such a large group. But if you don't warn me about the surcharge even though we call in advance, then you've lost me as a customer.

59.description: The hot pot here is mediocre.  Nothing compared to the actually hot pot in Asia or even the ones in Cali.  However for midwest, this may be the only decent hot pot place around.  It's all you can eat which you order from a piece of paper, which is pretty awesome, because it comes straight from the kitchen and not like the buffet where everything's been sitting out.  I only tried the clear broth, which I think could use less salt for a hot pot since you're going to be putting in a whole bunch of ingredients, but it was doable.  Would I come back? Probably...because I really don't have many other options..

21.description: To the people who love this restaurant, When I having Lunch in this restaurant last week, guess what, the RATS came out, not only one, there are THREE!To the vegetarians who love this place, just let you know, they put fish sauce in their dipping sauce and they will never tell you that!The service is not bad, but  the waitress who has the tooth brace on her, she is so rude!!!

17.description: To the people who love this restaurant, When I having Lunch in this restaurant last week, guess what, the RATS came out, not only one, there are THREE!To the vegetarians who love this place, just let you know, they put fish sauce in their dipping sauce and they will never tell you that!The service is not bad, but  the waitress who has the tooth brace on her, she is so rude!!!

10.description: We came here with friends for Thanksgiving dinner.  It was my first trip to this place, which is a pretty small restaurant and plain. But no mater how small, we still had to wait for very long time for our orders. When finally our waiter brought our orders, it was always short, i.e., if we ordered 6 plates, he brought 3 (I thought we Asians are good at math). If we ordered lamb meat, he brought beef, and told us these were lamb. Duh, I don't think I need to use my experiences at over 20 Michelin star restaurants to tell the differences. I felt so guilty that I had to ask waiter again and again for our orders. The lady (owner?) was also trying to push us leave. But don't you think that the faster you feed us, the faster we leave?

5.description: Mandarin Kitchen, you were great... Then you were good, but horrible service... Now you've just spoiled the experience so bad that we won't be coming back!My roommate and I went for dinner one evening to celebrate my birthday.  We were seated promptly and then ignored for 15 minutes despite waving down every server working the restaurant. My roommate had to walk into the kitchen and hand it to the first person he saw who then gave it to our server. After another 20 minutes, people seated some time after us were already receiving food and we were still waiting. Finally our tray of food made its way to us, or so we thought. We were given the "wrong" tray of food. We found this out when a 2nd tray came to our table from another server. Confused, he proceeded to give the 2nd tray to the table next to us. Incidentally, the table next to us ordered similar items which just so happened to be the tray we were given and had already started picking food from. When that table rejected the items the server came back and told us "this is your food... but it's all you can eat" and left two large trays of food without apologising to any of us at both tables for the mistake. It was far too much food for both of us to finish and we tried our best to get through it. Meanwhile, the other table never got their food. They waited for at least 5-10 minutes and walked out without paying. We saw two servers run after them. I flagged our server down for the check and said we could not finish all this food. How could we? It was for two separate parties that was just plopped at our side to sort out?! He was going to charge us for the unfinished items to which we reminded him that it was he that messed up the orders for both tables and left us to eat double the food? We paid our fair share and nothing more. A simple apology to both parties would have done wonders to fix the evening for all, but you have your business practices and we have ours...Mandarin Kitchen, goodbye.

3.description: Worst restaurant ever. Mandatory 15% gratuity for party of 4. Doesn't accept Amex or Discover. No split, only one card accepted for one meal.

35.description: I went back last week and this place is still awesome. Byob. Paid $25 total for hot pot

19.description: Turn the fluorescent lighting down.The food was good, but I felt like I was in a high school cafeteria.

28.description: Out of all the hot pots this is the worst i've ever tasted. I ordered half nutritious half spicy. The spicy food was full with oil we can barely see the soup. The nutritious soup was full with MSG which is really bad for your health. The meats were all frozen like ice cubs which were not fresh at all. I highly recommend you dont waste your money on this shop.

45.description: If you're looking to eat piping hot food on a frigid day in Chicago, then Mandarin Kitchen is the place to be! AYCE hot pot costs only $16 per person, which is a bargain. Make reservations if you're coming in a group of 6+, and bring a proficient Mandarin-speaking friend along to make ordering more efficient.

33.description: This was our first time at a hot pot restaurant and it was a lot of fun!  Good selection of meat/veggies/noodles etc.  Really a fun, relaxing way to do dinner.

43.description: The hot pot was good at Mandarin Kitchen, but the service was not the best and the all you can eat did not have as much of a selection as other places. If you decide to go here for hot pot, be ready to ask the servers for everything you need and sometimes multiple times. The meat and veggies were high quality, which was really nice. I would definitely come back here for hot pot again.

2.description: Terrible Food & Services: We traveled to Chicago for a Conference. Thought that a hot pot could warm us up in this cold, windy and snowy weather in Chicago.- Food: We got half Spicy and half non-spicy broths like other people recommended. Broths were really BAD!!! The spicy one had too much oil and dried chilly, we took out more that one big metal bowl of oil. The non-spicy broth was used with lots of MSG to make the soup tasty, but I can taste it disgusting and not healthy.Other dishes were okay. Most of them are FROZEN, not fresh.- Service: Bad customer service. They threatened you by charging you more money if you could not finish the food. They would weight the left over, even the broth to charge you $10 per pounds. It is all-you-can-eat buffet hot pot but they limited you 2 hours to eat only. In fact, no one would spend two hours to eat their but their attitudes just annoyed me. - Pricing: We spent $43.00 for two of us without beverages. It is not decent with its actual quality and services. I DO NOT recommend this place as it may harm your health with plenty of MSG, Oils and whole bunch of dried chilly. We will not come back here if we visit Chicago again.

18.description: Servers don't speak much English or Cantonese so communication is hard for me here.I came here probably a little more than 5 times.BYOB and all you can eat hot pot for 20 so ish dollars. Not a bad deal.

41.description: It's one of the cleaner restaurants I've been in at Chinatown. Went on a Monday around 11:30 and were the first ones there. By the time we left around 1PM, there were a few more tables filled - all Chinese. The AYCE menu is well organized and definitely do-able for a non-Chinese speaker/reader. I can't really tell if the service was any better or worse since we were the only ones there initially. Ordered in Chinese, though our conversation was in English...so...interpret as you see fit. I haven't actually had hot pot in Chinatown, only at people's homes or in China. Obviously sub par compared to the hot pot in China. But I think it was pretty decent for the Midwest.The broths could use some work, the sauces are a bit weak, and the veggies are not super fresh (mostly the cilantro and chrysanthemum/tonghao). Also, the lamb came out half frozen. But I didn't have super high expectations for lamb...because after you eat lamb in Inner Mongolia, lamb anywhere else isn't going to cut it for you. Oh, and they didn't give us water? or tea? But whatever. Overall it's a decent place for hot pot. Nothing is going to blow your mind though. So don't come with crazy expectations!

52.description: Can't really go wrong. Sometimes there is a long wait. Yea it may seem like they are a little rude, but that's just how some Asians are. There wasn't enough room at the place as me and a buddy came at the dinner rush, but they suggested we share a table with another group of dudes. A little weird at first, but figured what the hell why not. Kinda worked in our favor. They explained stuff a little more for us, and helped as a translator for our waitresses. The service wasn't the greatest, but it was pretty decent, the only thing i can really complain about is that we didn't get water when we first sat down, but in their defence we all ordered the Herbal tea drinks right away. Also I didn't get the Bok Choy till the last round of ordering. Besides that it was all in all good time, made some new friends and luckily didn't get stuck with the already added 15% gratuity problem other people were having. Food: Don't really know what great hot pot should taste like, but this was good to me and my buddy. Service: its an AYCE place so you gotta expect they are gonna be really busy and rushed. So factor that in if you wonder why maybe one thing gets messed up, or you have to ask a second time. One thing i noticed also is a lot of people ordering off menu ( just ordering items at random as servers pass by) so that could also distract them. over all: i dig it.

50.description: It is always good to have hot pot in the freezing weather. The food are fresh, which is the most important. Place is a little too small, so there is always a line. However, I still think it is worthy.

4.description: The food tastes so bad. Each dish is so small to we ask for another one again and again. The waiters here are mean and there are 15% tax included automatically, even though their service cannot worth such much money. The restaurant only accepted one card to pay... Overall, terrible food and service

6.description: Start with I worked in there for almost 4 weeks, besides the lady boss is as mean as a bitch，She actually using the lamb 7 MONTHs  ago!!!(I posted 2 photos, check it out) There are also rats running around in the kitchen. The soup has tons of MSGs in it, that's why it's so "yummy"!Base on the facts above do you still wanna go to the mandarin kitchen?先从我在这家店做了4周左右的服务生说起，老板娘又小气又贱，他们家用的羊肉都有7个月大了，（图片区有我偷拍的照片），而且厨房里经常有老鼠，食物掉地上都是直接装回盘子里送出去，还有他们锅底都是放3勺（是汤勺！）鸡精加一勺味精，这就是为什么汤会感觉那么"好喝"。看完这些你还想去吃小肥羊火锅吗？

22.description: Super bad experience. Slow service. Low quality meat. A rude women just told me you cannot eat that much so I will take this plate of meat away and give to you later... Never come back NEVER

15.description: 0 if possible, never go to this place. First, I thought it is all you can eat, but it is NOT!!! When you ask for refills, they try to ignore you. Not once, but five time. Takes 15 mins for them to bring out my second order of meat. With 15 years of cooking experiences, the lamb they are bring out are definitely smells and taste funky. Not sure if it is real lamb or something else...And there are RATS running all over the place. They also force you to pay 18% tips, WITH NO SERVICE AND WITHOUT TELLING YOU IN ADVANCE!! NEVER go there!

57.description: I've been here twice for AYCE hotpot, first time with friends who introduced the place to me and the second time in March 2013 as an 18th birthday dinner. They have a great selection of veggies, meats, and all the typical hot pot items (fish/shrimp/cuttlefish balls, sauces) and delicious varieties of yummy side dishes/sweets (sweet potato pancake is freakin' AMAZING!). They also have add-ons for an additional price to the AYCE menu. The food is amazing, especially with the spicy broth. I love spicy, and this was perfect. It was a little too hot once you eat about half a bowl, but too spicy in a GOOD way. Plus, Mandarin people generally eat very spicy, so it was expected. I would give Mandarin Kitchen 5* for the food. It is awesome and fresh and yummmmmy! But, based on both of my experiences, the service is worse than gritty fake watery soft serve ice cream. -3* for service...and i'm very generous to give 2*. The waitresses appeared to be very snobbish and unattentive. They walked right past me and ignored my attempts to refill for water or to even pay the bill! I usually see them huddle and chat in the corner by the kitchen entrance and they are very hesitant to come and assist you with you orders (literally takes them a minute to finish their chit chat and slowly zombie-walk over here). They also seem hesitant and unhappy with you reordering large quantities or more than two times. My friends and I can eat a LOT and we LOVE their sweet potato pancakes and xiaolongbaos/Shanghai dumplings, so we ordered 6 orders of each (1 order for each of us, not that much. an order had about 5 dumplings if I remember correctly). When we finally received our food, we were confused. There, on one plate, were 5 dumplings. We asked the waiter where the rest of our order is, and he said that he thought we wanted 6 INDIVIDUAL pieces, when the menu CLEARLY states that 1 order had 5 (?) dumplings. We just let it go and asked him very nicely for the rest, but he never came back with the food. He also commented before that we ordered 2 times already, and in return, we said, yes we eat a lot... and he just laughed it off and left with our third round of ordering.  It's safe to say that service is not one of Mandarin Kitchen's best qualities, but the food is very nice and fresh. Another thing that was a big turn-off is how they clean their tables. They use a suspicious spray and mist the whole table. If you are located within three table distances away, you are bound to cough or maybe die a little from the weird dishwashing disinfectant smell. Totally ruins the food in front of you. Bathrooms aren't as bad as some reviews make it look. They are exactly the same "style" as restaurant bathrooms in NYC, with bathrooms downstairs and the actual restaurant on the main floor. Here's a tip, pay in cash for a small discount on the bill. Many Chinatown restaurants will give cash discounts. For some reason, this restuarant really likes even numbers (they round the bill UP to the next dollar, but never down....sneaky!)

20.description: I came to this place excited. We had spicy and "nutritious" broths and ordered a bunch vegetables and meats. The excitement quickly faded. First red flag was low quality, carb filled, untasty fish balls and shrimp balls. Second, low quality meat. We had beef and chicken. The chicken tasted nothing like chicken and looked nothing like chicken. The beef was more like cheap gross bacon. Third, after the heat was turned down and the broth was no longer boiling, the spicy soup developed an oily layer on top and it was too oily for the soup for me. The biggest red flag of all was my husband started feeling sick. He got watery eye and irritated nose. I noticed my nose felt irritated when the spicy soup was in the proximity to my nose. My tongue was numb and my husband got a headache the rest of the night. It was too much MSG. I am originally from a country where MSG is widely used in restaurants and so I normally don't have a MSG reaction unless there is a lot of it. To sum up, low quality meats, too much MSG, too oily spicy broth with unidentifiable effect to our noses. We will not go back. My husband swears never to eat hot pot again (it was his first time). I am in the process of changing his mind because I still have faith in other hot pot places in Chicago!

36.description: Always been my must-go place in Chicago!  Except that the fish served with the hot pot buffer could be better. Honestly I think there is extra stuff like flavor added into the fish lol

14.description: The first rule about hot pot is that as soon as anyone says "we should get hot pot" out loud, it requires a mandatory trip to Mandarin Kitchen. OK, so it's not the cleanest, and the service is not great, but it's so tasty that it can comfort & cure any bad breakup or catastrophic work situation in the blink of an eye! Bring wine!!! And lots of it!! Uhh... maybe bring your own wine opener, too, since I don't think they will ever replace that one with the wonky handle. Anyhow, in a nutshell, tasty noms. You can pick out whatever it is that suits your needs, so there isn't any reason to be weird about it. It's fun with a crowd of friends. Do it!

3.description: If you are into Asian Beauty products, this place is a great place to visit in the City!The store mainly offers Sieseido products, such as makeup and skincare. However, off to the left hand wall, there are several very popular Japanese products, including Hada Labo, Dolly Wink, and My Beauty Diary sheet masks! Great place to find great products.The interior decor is very beautiful and clean.Accepts credit cards.

1.description: Judy's is cool. Not everything I'm looking for but customer service is kind and very very welcoming. I like to think of it as a great place to get (limited) stuff if you can't get to suburbs or of you only use Sheshido products.

2.description: They carry the latest Korean and Japanese beauty products at market level prices. I was impressed by the selection. They have Dolly Wink lashes and Shiseido hair products. The saleswoman Pat was really nice, friendly, and very approachable. It's great having a local place where you can buy Asian beauty products other than online, where there a ton of fakes! They do not carry everything though, but Pat said they could possibly order some things. Pat speaks English! I know there are some stores in Chinatown where I, a native speaker, have trouble communicating due to differences in dialects and accents. I will definitely be back!

5.description: I didn't buy anything, but came with my friend since she wanted to get something for her mom. The sales lady was nice and answered our questions.

6.description: Very nice and attentive sales persons. They sell guy's stuff here too! so it's not just a store for women. Check it out!

0.description: If you like My Beauty Diary masks, Judy's is the store for you.  It seems like Judy's carry all the latest MBD masks from gift sets, two steps, new black pearl mask (one where it has a neck flap) and black masks.  If you have never tried a specific type and are worried about whether or not you will like it, they can sometimes break open a full box and sell you a single to try it out.  It never hurts to ask.The price is reasonable.  The ladies are helpful.  The couple of times I had questions, they were very willing to chat and provide recommendations.

4.description: My fiancee stops here quite often as it is one of the best places in the city to get the Shiseido products she uses. The woman who runs the store is very kind and has specifically looked into tracking down a couple of items through special order for us. She is also quite knowledgeable when it comes to the products she sells as my fiancee asks her all sorts of questions and she is always able to answer with a detailed explanation :). As with any higher end brand name cosmetics, prices are high, but no higher than anywhere else you'll find equivalent products. All in all a very nice little shop with a nice owner.

29.description: My buddy and I came in not knowing what to expect but we were definitely not disappointed.  I had the Szechuan noodles with pork and they were great! My buddy had the spicy chicken hand pulled noodles and those were even tastier!!! Price is right for the great tasting food. We paid $16.43 (only drank water). The place is really nice with very comfortable chairs and all around just super nice. I highly recommend it to anyone to give it a try.

42.description: Not bad, not bad.  As someone who loves nothing more than a giant bowl of noodle soup, this is decent. Hand pulled noodles made in house. Unfortunately, I was an idiot and sat at a booth next to the wall, unable to see any of the wild noodle-pulling action.The broth and noodles were great. Beef broth is pretty dark and flavorful, and the noodles were righteous.  But the meat was chewy and it came with like one carrot.  However, it was a big portion of meat, so I did like that.It wasn't anything mind-blowing, but I can see myself coming here a lot during Bear Weather season to saddle up to a giant bowl of soup.  I definitely want to try the other bowls in future visits.

23.description: 芝加哥最好的兰州拉面，推荐本楼拉面

47.description: A really cool new restaurant in chinatown. Perfect for a rainy September day. I love their hand pulled noodles. I can definitely taste the difference between hand pulled noodles vs store bought. The noodles were not alike or perfect in shape. No two pieces were the same. I loved the authenticity of the noodle making. You can see the noodle chef making the noodles through a glass viewing area. It was fun watching him. The noodles were hearty, withstood the meaty soup very well. Good pairing. I got the house special beef combo soup- meaty flavorful broth with tender beef pieces, beef tendon and tripe. Everything was well cooked and fall off the bone tender. I am wary of tripe in most restaurants because they normally still smell bad after being cleaned. Here though, it was cleaned and cooked well. I couldn't smell anything weird. Loved it!! Their spicy chicken noodle soup was great as well. The presentation of the soup as well as the taste was great. Their chive and pork dumplings took the longest to come out. They were a little on the pricey side $5.95 for 6 pieces but it was well worth it. They were made fresh and you could taste it. The kitchen looked busy with delivery order and in store customers but they still got our food out quickly.Service: I know Chinatown pretty well. I go there all the time. A lot of places have cringeworthy wait service. Here, it was completely different. Awesome service. Some of the best service I have come across. The waitresses knew enough English to communicate. They even helped me choose. The waitress pointed out the popular dishes and geared me towards things I would like. She came back multiple times to check up on us. Made sure our water was filled and our taste buds were satisfied. Decor: Modern and cool. Can't think of any other way to describe it. It is really beautiful. The store was well light with new modern fixtures and decorations. I love brightly lit places . You have to see it to admire it.Overall: Great taste of China, pretty inexpensive, delicious, great environment and great service.

8.description: Great Hotpot! Great price.While wandering Chinatown trying to find an AYCE hotpot place because Sweet Station couldn't fit our party of six, I stumbled upon Sing's Noodles. Traditionally a noodles restaurant, Sings also has all you can eat hotpot (both individual bowls and group bowls) and they have a variety of ingredients to add. At the higher price point, you also get crab and lobster, but the lower price point also includes fish and shrimp.Slightly disappointed they don't have the traditional milk tea available at most Chinese restaurant, but they do offer a selection of drinks.

31.description: Noodles are fantastic. Truly made by an artisan. The food is fresh and tasty. I just wish that their food had a bit more variety for vegetarian. It was tasty but the flavors were all pretty similar.

34.description: I really wanted to like this place because no one loves fresh hand-pulled noodles as much as I do. Their noodles were good but besides that, everything else was just okay. We tried the beef noodle soup and while the beef was quite tender, the soup was too bland and far from the Taiwanese version. The Dan Dan noodle was better but a tad on the salty side. Fried dumplings were also good until I realized the soup inside I was slurping down was just oil (damn those unnecessary calories!!). We almost ordered the xiao long bao but the waitress warned us they are soupless and it was the "northern" style of making them.

16.description: Sad to see the mixed reviews, but I really enjoyed the noodles here. Seemed to me like the noodles were pulled to order. Impressive. I asked my waitress for a pair of scissors to cut up my noodles, because yes, they will be really long -- the dude just hand-pulled them! The waitress did not look surprised with my request. I'm sure I wasn't the first to ask. If you're concerned if the scissors were clean, then too late, because before I could object, she had already shoved them into the bowl and started cutting. I self-appeased by convincing myself the temperature of the broth would kill any bacteria. Don't worry, I didn't get sick. It's always a risk you take in Chinatown. That's why my mom always "cleans" her chopsticks in Chinatown with the hot tea. I used to get embarrassed, now I will also do it if the place looks like a dubious establishment.I was confused between all the beef noodle soup options (i.e beef vs. beef stew?), however, unless you want intestine, you probably want the "beef noodle soup".  It's beef w/ a little tendon. Perfect. The bite of the noodles really save the dish, the rest of it is good, but not great. They do have an additional sauce on the side you can use to amp up the broth.Dan Dan noodles are like what my mom would make, and not like the overly spicy/oily versions I've had elsewhere.  Win.Ordered a stir-fry noodle as well, with ox-tail and knife cut noodles.  Delicious, made great leftovers.Pork & Chive dumplings, handmade skin, but unfortunately overcooked.Overall, definitely recommended and would come back.

13.description: We tried two noodle dishes here:  the house special (beef tripe, and beef stew) with shaved noodles, and the oxtail with hand pulled noodles.  The oxtail came with some black mushrooms, and a hint of ginger flavor and was a nice change of pace from ordinary.  Overall though, going with an ok three star rating as the noodle soups could both have been hotter, and the oxtail and beef meats were all on chewier, firmer side.  If they took care if both callouts, it would have been more if a delight.

11.description: $19 is a pretty good price all you can eat hot pot. For around $10 more, you can upgrade and get crab, lobster & some other seafoods. The base price includes shrimp, squid, fishballs, and mussels and is plenty unless you really have a taste for crab/lobster. The servers are nice and attentive. You order your hot pot ingredients from a piece of paper with pictures. Not sure what the point is though because they didn't bring everything we marked off.  The restaurant is pretty small and tables are crammed together. It's definitely not great for big groups. On the weekends it gets busy so there might be a wait. Parking is fairly easy on the street with metered parking or in one of the two parking lots.

39.description: Watching noodle show + eating great noodles~ it can't be wrong!The beef noodle soup tastes "pure" because it does not have too much spices compares to other Chinese beef noodle soups.BTW, most Chinese restaurants have dirty restrooms. However, this one has a club style and clean restroom.

37.description: I wanted to try this place right when they opened but all my friends who came did not like it. I waited for them to improve before I tried it for myself. So a couple of months after their grand opening, I came with my gf on a Saturday night and there were only a couple of empty tables. So that's a good sign right? Wrong!! We ordered the xiao long bao (steamed soup dumplings), beef hand pulled noodle and spicy chicken hand pulled noodle. The xiao long bao was barely luke warm AND no soup! That is unheard of, the bao should be so hot that my gf has to wait for it to cool down. The only good thing about this dish is the sauce to dip it in. The beef hand pulled noodle was just ok. The broth was not bad compared to the spicy chicken. The spicy chicken was just ok too. The chicken was good but the broth was so bland. We were dipping the beef and chicken into the xiao long bao sauce to add more flavor. The best part of this meal was the sauce, which will not make me come back anytime soon. Warning! All the servers speak mandarin and I speak Cantonese. Be warned my fellow canto speakers, bring a mandarin speaking friend.

0.description: Recently came in on a cold day from a craving for seafood hotpot. It was delicious and I have to say that I might come back due to the customization of the experience.To start, when we get situated, each person can have the option (table set up) to get their own pot of soup of their choice. However, we are limited from the mixed soup since the pot is bigger. If you're a fan of hot pot, you know that the experience of eating hot pot with others will include others putting in items that you will never put in your own hot pot, so it is crucial to choose the friends who has a similar taste. This place deters that and still allows us to hang out with our friends with different tastes :)Aside from that, I noticed from the menu that there is an option for a lunch special where you can order 7 items for $9.99 (excludes lobster and scallops). It's not a bad deal. The waiter was pretty attentive at times. I am considering coming back since they also have a bar of sauces to choose from. It's limited in the other establishments that I've been to.

38.description: First time, I had the roast duck hand-pulled noodle soup. My dad's lamb pan fried noodles came quickly while mine took a little too long to come. The noodles itself were pretty good as they are home-made. The duck was tasty and had about 6 pieces in my bowl, but only a couple were meaty and fulfilling. The portions were good...not too big or too small like other places in Chinatown. The hot chili sauce on the side I found to actually be spicy (which was rare for me). My dad's lamb noodle was rustic in that they roughly chop the lamb and keep the bones and fat in there (which some may like but he did not). Service was good in the beginning. The guy explained the menu to us as this was our first time there and our teas were constantly refilled. However, he later asked my dad to move around to the other side of the table so the people next to us could all be seated accordingly, as they were somewhat blocking the door and aisle. The waiter was sincere about it but they really should rethink their seating area arrangements, as the place itself is on the small side. Also, it took a long time for someone to come by and give us our check. When they finally did, they did not acknowledge that we probably would want a box for the extra noodles left, so we had to ask them again the next time around.What is supposed to be a quick and simple noodle place turned out to be not so much, especially as they are well-staffed with about 4-5 waiters/waitresses.Next time, I had the spicy dan-dan (dried) noodles that came with ground beef on top and a side soup. My sister had the pan-fried veggie noodles as their broth for the veggie noodle soup is not veggie (i.e. this place is not veggie friendly). I was already annoyed as once we were seated, we waited awhile for them to give us our menus and water/tea. I looked around and saw two of the waitresses just talking while cleaning up one table together, which was completely unnecessary. A waitress finally came to us with the menus and apologized for basically forgetting that we were there. Again, they are well staffed considering the size of the place so their service just sucks. With Chinese places, service usually is not their cup of tea, in terms of friendliness. This place had it reversed, friendly but efficiency and speed were very much lacking in this place. The noodles itself were good and very fresh tasting. However, instead of the dish being spicy, it was rather salty. I added the chili oil from the table and this time, it was rather mild and not spicy. My sister thought her veggie noodles were pretty tasty, but to note, they used cheaper veggies (celery) rather than veggies like mushroom and bok choy.Overall, noodles itself are pretty good but not out of this world and portions and prices are decent. It is cool to see the guy hand-pulling the noodles. However, service is slow and subpar and comfort can be lacking depending on where you are seated. Also wished that their menus are more straightforward with more options.

27.description: Wow! I normally reserve reviews for restaurants I've visited more than once but I have to start with this review.I ordered delivery, via Seamless, for this restaurant and could not be happier. I got the Roast Duck hand made noodles and a Pina Colada (virgin). Holy shit! The noodles are udon style, very fresh and not too gummy as is my normal experience with these noodles. The soup itself included so many chunks of duck on the bone I couldn't even begin to count. I don't know about you but all too often I find duck is poorly prepared. Chefs neglect the greasy nature of the meat and as a result you are left a bit dissatisfied with the heavy meat, drowning in fat. Well, not from Sing's! The duck was so moist and tender and the bones created an exceptional taste in the broth. The soup itself was minimal, some onions, a bit of radish (daikon type - or so I think), and bok choi or chinese broccoli. The amalgam of flavors was just right. The broth offered a savory but not too rich flavor that easily kept up with the great texture of the noodles and fullness of the meat.The delivery driver was very polite and arrived well within the prescribed timeline.I will be revisiting this restaurant in person to offer a more concise review, however they have already earned my seal of approval.

32.description: Noodle tasted great! Authentic and chewy, truly hand pulled. I ate there over 10 times and noodle was always hot and tasty.I love their lamb stew and ox tail noodle. Noodle soup has very little MSG and lamb has skin and fat on it. They added Xiao Long Bao two months after they open. But Bao skin was too thick for me and has no broth inside. I will never order again. Never say never! I went there last Saturday for noodle and saw a couple next to me was eating a super thin skin Xiao Long Bao (XLB). I gave them another chance and ordered a pork one. OMG, I am telling you they are good, good, good! They must got a new XLB chef! Bao skin was thin and fill with broth. I can tell right away they are fresh made to order. A big plus for their clean washroom.

48.description: I was hoping this place would be the same or similar to the hand-pulled noodles place (蘭州拉麵) that I've been to in China. But it's just a place with the same Chinese name. It was Saturday at 1pm on its opening weekend and there was a 10 minute wait for our party of three. The waiting area is very small and cramped so a lot of people stood outside the restaurant after grabbing a number. The beef hand-pulled noodle had the darkest and most flavorful broth. But the broth was also the saltiest and most likely, MSG-influenced. This was evident as I was parched shortly after leaving the restaurant. The beef was also a bit tough. The lamb hand-pulled noodle had a lighter broth. Half of the lamb was fat. Great if you like that extra, buttery texture with your meat. Otherwise, proceed with care. The vegetable hand-pulled noodle had the lightest broth. It's basically the same as the other two noodles minus the meat. It came with picked vegetable, cilantro, snow pea, Chinese cabbage, carrots, and celery. Overall, the noodles had a nice texture but lacked elasticity. The noodle master makes the noodles fresh but the supply ran low with a house full of hungry patrons. He might have made the batches in haste to free up the back orders. The bowls were huge but it was also mostly broth with very little noodles. There are approximately 10 people working in this tiny restaurant: four in the kitchen and six out in the field. The waiters were very courteous novices. It took a long while before I could flag somebody down to bring us water and take our orders. But the check came without us ever asking for it when they noticed we were finished with our lunch.They're definitely worth a visit but they have yet to earn my return (at least not in a long while).

44.description: For what I understood it to be, a hand pulled noodle restaurant, I expected more.  Unfortunately the gimmick is the hand pulled, aside from that you are eating at another run of the mill Chinatown restaurant.  If you've never been go for it, but be prepared to leave not wanting to go again.  I will give credit to the cleanliness given that it is a new opening.  But look for that to drop after 6 months.

24.description: I really enjoy this place the noodle soup just taste very home-y like something your aunt or your mom would cook, it is very authentic. Can't beat $9 for a bowl of beef and oxtail noodle soup. Plus the bathroom is one of the coolest bathrooms ever for a small restaurant in Chinatown, makes one want to turn on some music and dance.

7.description: I wanted to try this place right when they opened but all my friends who came did not like it. I waited for them to improve before I tried it for myself. So a couple of months after their grand opening, I came with my gf on a Saturday night and there were only a couple of empty tables. So that's a good sign right? Wrong!! We ordered the xiao long bao (steamed soup dumplings), beef hand pulled noodle and spicy chicken hand pulled noodle. The xiao long bao was barely luke warm AND no soup! That is unheard of, the bao should be so hot that my gf has to wait for it to cool down. The only good thing about this dish is the sauce to dip it in. The beef hand pulled noodle was just ok. The broth was not bad compared to the spicy chicken. The spicy chicken was just ok too. The chicken was good but the broth was so bland. We were dipping the beef and chicken into the xiao long bao sauce to add more flavor. The best part of this meal was the sauce, which will not make me come back anytime soon. Warning! All the servers speak mandarin and I speak Cantonese. Be warned my fellow canto speakers, bring a mandarin speaking friend.

49.description: Hand pulled noodles: yay! Simple menu: yay! Clean and modern aesthetic: yay!So the menu is simple: appetizers, noodles and dumplings. This is a welcomed change to the usual proclivity of the area restaurants which try and do everything. Ordered pot stickers (okay), spicy cold beef tendon (good and flavorful; almost like spicy jellied bacon), Dan Dan noodles (very simple prep served dry with ground beef with no peanut in a light spicy sauce; not nearly as much gravy as the more American version you can find at Hing Kee), BBQ duck noodle soup (flavorful broth, big chunks of duck and served with mustard greens). Overall noodles were good and chewy but the one complaint my friend and I both had was that the noodles are too long. I wouldn't care normally but not good for trying to share in smaller bowls so we gave up and passed the dishes back and forth.  After only a few days into an opening I would corn back to see what they tweak over time.Oh yeah I forgot the most EPIC part of the visit: check out the bathroom. I took photos but I don't want to ruin it for any of you..ha

40.description: The marinated beef appetizer is so unexpected. It's like a cold roast beef with a sweet garlic onion sauce. It was really good. I also ordered the Beef with Chow Mei Fun and that was perfection. So it was the same beef from the marinated beef appetizer but it was fried with thin clear/ white noodles and veggies. It came with a beef bone broth soup that I am totally in love with. The soup reminds me of a Korean soup that's called bone marrow soup in Hawaii.We have been to this place 3 times in 22 days and it is awesome every single time. The service is fantastic! Everyone speaks English, its super clean, and unbelievably cheap!!! I love love love Chinatown.

30.description: I'm no Szechuan noodle connoisseur. I came in the waitress/hostess asked if I wanted a fork twice, which annoyed me slightly because I lead with an Asian face. In any case, I went for the basic beef noodle soup. Let me tell you, add just a little chili and you bring out the savory flavor another level. This broth, the noodles, pickled cabbage, and beef slices were collectively divine. I ordered steamed pork and chive dumplings to go, ate them three hours later without the sauce and I was so grateful I ordered them! The skin was soft and had the perfect consistency. The stuffing flavor was well balanced by the herbs and spices. Yum!

46.description: Good handmade noodles and broth but the rest of the menu is just okay.The NOODLES:  Definitely the star of the restaurant.  Hand pulled noodles done in house.  Diners get an easy view of all the action through a glass wall.  At the taste & texture lived up to the action - nice, fresh and a little spring to the bite.The SOUP:  The broth had some good flavors and they definitely don't skimp on the meat (nice given the $8 price tag).  Had at least 12-15 pieces in my bowl.  With that said, I love some veggies in the soup and mine had only ~3 pieces of greens. But - Order Carefully:  House special noodle contains beef, tripe and brisket.  The tripe (cow's stomach for those not familiar) although cleaned well was tough and chewy.  I imagine it wouldn't be the best introduction if you've never had tripe before.  Planning to just get the beef cube or beef stew noodles in the future.  Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao/小笼包): weren't soup dumplings in a steamer at all but were large steamed meat buns on a plate.  Dan-Dan noodles (擔擔麵):  Are served dry here vs. with a chili soup like the Shanghai style.  Friend who had it said it was still really good - just not what he expected.

1.description: this place used to be lanzhou noodles, but now is a all you can eat hotpot placethis is probalby one of the only places in chicago where you can have seafood hotpot, quite unique and satisfying when you can have lobster, abalone, and oyster in spicy hotpotthe seafood quality is ok for the price they charge, the meat does not seem as fresh. the good thing is they have a huge selection of things to choose from, so it can definitely satifsy quite a lot of people if you go in a big groupthe sauces are average, but i guess their specialty is seafood

9.description: Walked into the place with my gf this afternoon for hotspot. And I have tasted most well known hotpot places in Chinatown. Here is how I would rate it. Prices are for 2 people.1.  Pricing: 4/5 38 to 60 usd depending on whether you want select seafood items. The 60 dollar version includes lobster/2 kinds of crabs and scallops. The stuff included in the lower version still contains about 18-20 different stuff. I went for the upgraded version though I was looking forward to sample the seafood.2. Deco: 3/5 not a spot for a romantic date. More of a family place. Plays loud Korean music (which isnt bad at all if its your kinda thing). Nothing in particular about the shop really caught my eye. Noisy due to the many families eating around you.3. Portions: 4/5 HUGE portions. The upgraded seafood version we ordered was honestly too much for 2 people to finish (had a small hillock of shells gathered by the time we finished). I never got down to sample the other stuff on the plate simply because there was so much crab/lobster on the plate.4. Quality: 3.5/5I would say the soup (ordered spicy and Chinese herbal) was at par with other shops. Minus points for not offering a single pot with 2 different soups. Instead they offer 2 pots - 1 per person.5. Service: 3.5/5Soup pots were refilled promptly. However the server seemed confused when I asked for an extra plate until my gf spoke to her in mandarin. Staff were polite and non obtrusive. Overall 4/5. Would try again. Skip if on a romantic date. Definitely an option if in a large group.

26.description: I had been looking for hand pulled noodles ever since I came back from China about 10 years ago. These are the real thing and, like in China, they're made right in front of you. You can watch the chef pull your noodles as you wait for your food. Once you've tried these noodles you'll have a hard time accepting anything else. They're the best!

25.description: Sad to see the mixed reviews, but I really enjoyed the noodles here. Seemed to me like the noodles were pulled to order. Impressive. I asked my waitress for a pair of scissors to cut up my noodles, because yes, they will be really long -- the dude just hand-pulled them! The waitress did not look surprised with my request. I'm sure I wasn't the first to ask. If you're concerned if the scissors were clean, then too late, because before I could object, she had already shoved them into the bowl and started cutting. I self-appeased by convincing myself the temperature of the broth would kill any bacteria. Don't worry, I didn't get sick. It's always a risk you take in Chinatown. That's why my mom always "cleans" her chopsticks in Chinatown with the hot tea. I used to get embarrassed, now I will also do it if the place looks like a dubious establishment.I was confused between all the beef noodle soup options (i.e beef vs. beef stew?), however, unless you want intestine, you probably want the "beef noodle soup".  It's beef w/ a little tendon. Perfect. The bite of the noodles really save the dish, the rest of it is good, but not great. They do have an additional sauce on the side you can use to amp up the broth.Dan Dan noodles are like what my mom would make, and not like the overly spicy/oily versions I've had elsewhere.  Win.Ordered a stir-fry noodle as well, with ox-tail and knife cut noodles.  Delicious, made great leftovers.Pork & Chive dumplings, handmade skin, but unfortunately overcooked.Overall, definitely recommended and would come back.

12.description: I used to come here every 2-3 months. It was my favorite but last time I went I was extremely disappointed. The soup was blend. The spicy soup was tasteless. Nothing is fresh.The meat was old and tasteless. I will never come back again. The only great thing is the service!! The food came fast and the servers are super nice- her English was not good but she was trying her best to accommodate us.

21.description: We tried two noodle dishes here:  the house special (beef tripe, and beef stew) with shaved noodles, and the oxtail with hand pulled noodles.  The oxtail came with some black mushrooms, and a hint of ginger flavor and was a nice change of pace from ordinary.  Overall though, going with an ok three star rating as the noodle soups could both have been hotter, and the oxtail and beef meats were all on chewier, firmer side.  If they took care if both callouts, it would have been more if a delight.

17.description: Their hand pulled noodle soup are great. They have one chef that makes the noodles with his hands in front of you. I especially love the Sczchuan chicken noodle soup. It's a little spicy and the chicken pieces are fried so it's a little crunchy and it's awesome! Very good. Or try the beef hand pulled noodle, the beef are so tender with great flavors.Prices of the noodles are range from $6-$8, which is not bad at all and you will be full after.

10.description: I was hoping this place would be the same or similar to the hand-pulled noodles place (蘭州拉麵) that I've been to in China. But it's just a place with the same Chinese name. It was Saturday at 1pm on its opening weekend and there was a 10 minute wait for our party of three. The waiting area is very small and cramped so a lot of people stood outside the restaurant after grabbing a number. The beef hand-pulled noodle had the darkest and most flavorful broth. But the broth was also the saltiest and most likely, MSG-influenced. This was evident as I was parched shortly after leaving the restaurant. The beef was also a bit tough. The lamb hand-pulled noodle had a lighter broth. Half of the lamb was fat. Great if you like that extra, buttery texture with your meat. Otherwise, proceed with care. The vegetable hand-pulled noodle had the lightest broth. It's basically the same as the other two noodles minus the meat. It came with picked vegetable, cilantro, snow pea, Chinese cabbage, carrots, and celery. Overall, the noodles had a nice texture but lacked elasticity. The noodle master makes the noodles fresh but the supply ran low with a house full of hungry patrons. He might have made the batches in haste to free up the back orders. The bowls were huge but it was also mostly broth with very little noodles. There are approximately 10 people working in this tiny restaurant: four in the kitchen and six out in the field. The waiters were very courteous novices. It took a long while before I could flag somebody down to bring us water and take our orders. But the check came without us ever asking for it when they noticed we were finished with our lunch.They're definitely worth a visit but they have yet to earn my return (at least not in a long while).

5.description: 1. We were told by the waitress that the hand pulled noodles are no longer hand pulled... 2. Noodle broth is no longer beef broth...looks like just hot water...

3.description: Back in the day, I barely noticed Sings noodle existed when tucked away next to more glamorous Chinatown offerings like Minghin and LSC, and that shop with giant hello kitties in the window. My friend first recommended their noodle soups to me so I had been on the look out for it every time I went to Chinatown for like a year until someone else took me here for hot pot. Had they not changed their menu recently, I would have given them a higher rating based on that visit alone. Now, they only offer an overpriced $30 ayce hot pot or hot pot items a la carte. No more $20 option (which already included the fish and shrimp). With tax and tip, it's almost 40 per person for mediocre seafood,most of which are pre-cooked and frozen. Their best items are actually fish and shrimp, unfortunately, so you can pay $15 more for the option of having crappy seafood alongside it! I personally don't go to hot pot to eat 50 plates of precooked king crab leg. I go for endless variety and  dipping sauces -  which they have, but so does everywhere else without the shitty seafood surcharge. The one thing that does set them apart is that you can have your own individual shabu shabu style pot or a big one (up to 2 broths in a divided pot) for everyone to share. I like big communal broths so that doesn't really make any difference to me. I think a la carte is by far the better option here if you must eat here... But i don't see why you wouldn't just eat hot pot (maybe alongside some stir fry dishes - you know, for a texture that's not boiled) for cheaper.

35.description: There is nothing better than a hot bowl of noodles on a cold day. Sing's noodles are made in-house. That's true. If you don't believe it, ask the guy in the chef's hat who is pulling noodles all day in front of the customers.You have to have gumption to run a place that just specializes in noodles and nothing else; unless you are in China... noodle shops are found in every other corner in Shanghai or Beijing.But here is a word of advice to the owners:It doesn't matter how much money you spent on interior design (tasteful for Chinatown standards) or on the big placards of noodle pictures in front of your store. In the end, this is still Chinatown. And it is a common fact that Chinese people find it offensive to pay more than $10 with tax + tip for a bowl of noodles bathed in broth made from beef bouillon cubes.You either have to move your store to River North and call it Slurping Turtle, or stay put but lower your prices to $5-$6 like Hing Kee or Potsticker House (all hand-pulled as well).

19.description: THIS PLACE IS NO LONGER A NOODLE SHOP. I never been previously, but after reading the reviews I can tell this is not the place it's has been before. Now, IT'S A YUMMY SEAFOOD HOT POT PLACE!  They offer AYCE seafood hot pot for $29.99 which includes lobsters, shrimps, clams, mussels, different types of crabs, and fish... They also have four kinds of broths, all of which are pretty delicious. Keep in mind one of them are a little spicy! I'm used to Japanese style shabu shabu with a light broth, so I thought these soups were all tasty even on it's own and full of flavors. I think it was their Chinese herbal broth (??), taste really similar to Korean chicken soup (sam gye tang). NOMSSSS. The service can be a little slow but fairly nice (actually great compared to some of my other experiences in Chinatown).It's a small place so you may have to wait. Also, come hungry and expect to spend some time here. First time we came, my friend and I got so excited, over-ordered, and spent like 2 hours on eating. Also, I wouldn't recommend this place for dates unless you want to show your date that you can eat your body weight with seafood by stuffing your face with crab legs while the juices run all over your hands.

28.description: Really good! I can't wait to go again! We has the spicey chicken noodles. The bowl was large enough for my son and I to share. I forget the name of the dish but it was a think noodle with chicken. We asked for it to be medium spice and it was pretty spicey.  We also ordered pot stickers for an appetizer. They were really large and  and we stuffed! I can't wait to come back and try another dish!

45.description: Was a bit wary when I read the lukewarm reviews, but I thought my first visit here was perfectly enjoyable. It was Sunday evening and we had to wait 15min for a table as it was a tiny space. The waitress seemed personally apologetic about the wait...which wasn't that big of a deal. She rushed over as soon as she sat us so we could put in our order in without waiting longer. Very considerate.The noodles had good texture and the broth, while not filled with spices, was totally fine for my taste. Good comfort food when you want something easy on the tummy. Price was just right: there were good amounts of roasted duck in mine and beef tendon in friend's bowl. Glad I got a new Chinatown option now!

33.description: First, I absolutely hate it when I have high expectations for the food from the pictures I see and their humongous banners on the walls of Chinatown Square. The pictures look great, but the food is just mediocre. Even though they have a chef in the back pulling the noodles...sorry, but the noodles taste the same like from the package ones that I can get from any Chinese grocery store (and way cheaper). Thumbs down for the waitresses being unable to speak Cantonese...all my gram asked for was a cup of hot tea..

43.description: First time at Sings noodles.  I came to Chinatown with a few friends and saw the new restaurant completely filled on a Sunday night. I was super impressed and asked my friends to give it a try and was very happy I did!The place was extremely clean. The first place I went was the bathroom to wash my hands and WOW! Sooooo nice! The picture doesn't do it justice. It was like walking into a Las Vegas bathroom. Beautiful. Service was very helpful, smiley and prompt. I like when I see people happy when they work. I feel like management has to be good, when the workers are happy. The chef who made the noodles saw one of my friends struggling to eat the noodles with the chop sticks and came out of the kitchen to show her how to spin them! It was so nice!! loved it!FOOD: It was very cool to see the noodles being hand made by the chef right in the window. I've eaten from a lot of noodles places but these were perfect. The noodles were in everything we ordered and they were the perfect consistency, chewy and flavorful. You can definitely taste how fresh they were!We ordered:Szechuan Dan Dan Mein: the beef was really flavorful and their spicy chili is homemade and really tasty (perfect if you like a little spicy)Spicy Chicken Hand pulled noodle: The lady told us the chicken pieces tasted better by themselves so we tried it with the chicken on the side....by far the best chicken pieces I've ever eaten! the broth and the noodles were delicious as well but the chicken...YUMM!!!Beef Stew: Very hearty and tasty, perfect for a nice cold day, lots of beef! but I wish we would have ordered the beef slices instead of the huge chucks. (If you like the thicker, and tendony pieces this is perfect.)Beef stirfry  noodle: yyuuummmmyyyyy.....all the veggies were nice and crunchy I wish the serving was a tad bit bigger because I just couldn't get enough of it! Awesome! It came with a bowl of chicken broth which was also good.Appetizers: Kelp salad was very refreshing. full of flavor and not super salty like some of the other one that I've had. Fried dumplings: nice and big! was pretty surprised...they were really tasty and the homemade dumpling sauce was so good!VERY PLEASED!!!

2.description: Sometimes you don't need to find food. The food will find you. Great company, great food, great times. Had an issue a month or so back that happened here at sings. They rectified the situation and I'm happy that despite it being Chinatown, the owner and the staff that day really took the time to address out concern. The food has never been an issue here and the service is pretty good for it being Chinatown. We will be back again soon. Cheers.

18.description: Not bad, not bad.  As someone who loves nothing more than a giant bowl of noodle soup, this is decent. Hand pulled noodles made in house. Unfortunately, I was an idiot and sat at a booth next to the wall, unable to see any of the wild noodle-pulling action.The broth and noodles were great. Beef broth is pretty dark and flavorful, and the noodles were righteous.  But the meat was chewy and it came with like one carrot.  However, it was a big portion of meat, so I did like that.It wasn't anything mind-blowing, but I can see myself coming here a lot during Bear Weather season to saddle up to a giant bowl of soup.  I definitely want to try the other bowls in future visits.

41.description: This is one of the the worst noodles shops you can go to in Chinatown.Place is decently decorated and the staff is pleasant, but you can't eat the decor and the food is pure bullshit.  Ordered a beef stew noodles for $10 and the meat is severely overcooked - harder to chew than a ball of rubber bands.  On top of that, the noodles had no taste whatsoever, mainly because everything is a slap on and not cooked together.Want to try this place?  Do yourself a favor and get a Nissin instant noodles instead.

50.description: Tried Sing's today for dinner with my bf. I believe they've been open for 3 or 4 days now. Here's a breakdown of my experience.What we ordered:- Oxtail hand pulled noodle: My first impression was that the oxtail was not piping hot so they probably just plopped it on top at the end and it was not cooked with the broth. But the more I ate the oxtail, the more I liked it. It was pretty good. The noodle had a nice texture and had that nice flour taste. The broth wasn't bad. Overall good.- Beef stew hand pulled noodle: My bf ordered this and said it was meh. The beef was a little tough for him.- Szechuan dan dan noodle: Noodles topped with a spicy chili oil meat sauce. It was good, but not mindblowing. You can get this dish at other restaurants and it's all the same to me. It doesn't stand out here. Service: 1. Right after we were seated. The waiter asked us to move to another table so that they can accommodate a large group. No biggie at all. When we were moving to the new table, they whisked us away to another table. No biggie. What was odd is that the whole time we were waiting we were wondering why they don't seat us at the table they whisked us to since it was open the whole time.....We ended up there anyway....2. The waiters were all friendly, but I think they need to be on the same page. When I asked two different waiters about the menu, they gave me different information on the same items. We also saw that the table next to us had something that looked really good so we asked the waiter what it was. He told us the dish and when we ordered it, it was totally different from the dish we saw.3. I had to wait a long time until I finally could flag someone down to bring us our check. The check was about $27, but when we got the receipt to sign we noticed that they charged us $35. I told the cashier and I think they did not know how to process a refund with the POS system, so they ended up apologizing and just gave us $10 cash back. I think they redeemed themselves by being very polite about it.Overall it's a 3.5 for me.

4.description: NO LONGER JUST SPECIALTY RAMEN SHOP.Now they serve seafood hot pot! I came here last night with family members and their boyfriend for dinner. We decided to pick the $18.99 AYCE hot pot instead of $29.99 AYCE hot pot. Why? You get practically the entire menu (head on shrimp, meat, mussels, clams) except for a few select things (an entire lobster per person, crab legs, etc). For us, the regular AYCE $18.99 deal was more than enough for us. The food was good. I spotted a piece of hair in a piece of beef tripe. There is a sauce station, so you can fill up on whatever you would like. Please ignore the misspellings on the labels. It's the thought that counts! Lots of items available (beef balls, tofu, vermicelli knots, watercress, dumplings, Korean chapchae/japchae noodles, etc)Service was spotty. Good when you could get it. I'm not used to servers snapping their fingers at their coworkers for attention, but it's something they do in China so I guess it's okay. Cleaner than Mandarin Kitchen, but they don't have hot side dishes like scallion pancakes. Free parking by CASL (Chinese American Service League) if you're interested. Or you could park in the lot near the train station and have your ticket validated at the restaurant. $2 for 3 hours of parking!

6.description: They took forever to give me two smoothies and only used a small bit of fruit for it- the rest was two cups od syrup, a ton of water, and a ton of ice. Do not get smoothies from here!!!

22.description: I came here because I'm curious on how their noodles is. So I had the following:Beef Tripe noodleHonestly, the noodle is great by itself. However, their soup has so much MSG that it makes my mouth dry after drinking their soup. So if they switch from MSG based soup to non-MSG based soup, they will be better.

15.description: Sing's just cut their noodle menu back.  We ordered the beef and chicken noodle dishes, and they delivered oxtail and some nasty chicken meat and bones in the order.I'm so disappointed in the noodles here.  The hotpot at other tables looked fine, but the noodles are gone now.

20.description: CLOSED FOR RENOVATIONS At least update your website so people don't waste a trip and $2 on the meter.

36.description: Their hand pulled noodle soup are great. They have one chef that makes the noodles with his hands in front of you. I especially love the Sczchuan chicken noodle soup. It's a little spicy and the chicken pieces are fried so it's a little crunchy and it's awesome! Very good. Or try the beef hand pulled noodle, the beef are so tender with great flavors.Prices of the noodles are range from $6-$8, which is not bad at all and you will be full after.

14.description: What An awesome lobster, geoduck, oysters, crabs buffet. This easily $200 at an American Restaurant, but here in Chinatown at 12:30 pm. It's awesome. I'm sending friends back

1.description: Only reason I did not give this a five was because there is a two dollar fee for credit card. The service in itself was great the masseuse adjusted his pressure as I requested. no complaints. very friendly and clean.

2.description: I've been here a handful of times over the past 2 years. The staff is very friendly. I'm typically able to walk right in and get a foot massage - 30 minutes for $30. They start with a facial and neck massage while soaking your feet. Then onto a deep foot massage. Always a nice treat!

0.description: A wonderful and relaxing foot massage the morning after a concert. Better than hoped for! Going back tomorrow.

12.description: This is great place to get random kitchen supplies for cheap. There were about 5 things that I wanted at the Chopping Block that I found similar items here for a quarter of the price. Pretty sweet. Go to the back and there are pots, pans, and all sorts of  useful utensils. I pass all the touristy nick nack up front though.

3.description: They had a lot of cute bowls and Chinese spoons. I like the nice teapots there. I'm also a huge fan of square bowls so I bought a lot there. The store is really crowded and I do think it is a little pricey because they sell the bowls and plates individually. They have really unique toys too like Marvel characteristics and Hello Kitty. It's a good place to look into.

1.description: I really enjoyed the vast selection of gifts, souvenirs, and housewares.  Although my review would have even been better if the entire staff was polite and the sports apparel authentic.Overall it's a nice place to shop and includes lots of cool products, good prices, and if your in Chinatown a place I'd suggest.

2.description: Small store that is packed with all types of kitchen tools that you can find in an Asian household. Lots of bowls, dishes, silverwares, etc...my friend had to stop by to buy a peeler and they had it. There are some stuff that are pretty expensive and there are some stuff that are really cheap so it depends on what you are looking for.

9.description: 5 stars for the japanese lucky cat selection. large, small, tiny, pink, black, golden, blue,-you name it they have it. i was on the hunt for a replacement lucky cat and AJ's was the only place in chinatown. i also bought some awesomely tall (5 feet) bamboo stalks for $10 each.also, while you're there, try your luck and buy a lotto ticket. they have the tickets of past winners taped to the window.  with all of those lucky cats and lucky bamboo in there, you are bound to win something.

10.description: This is the place to go for super affordable housewares, much of which you can't even find at some overpriced crap store like bed bath & beyond.  OoooOO got a great deal on chopstick sets, a big old plant pot, and a small handy dandy strainer.  Lots of trinkets, tea sets, bamboo plants, rice cookers, bamboo steamers, all kinds of stuff!  Not sure about the quality of the stuff, but it seems worth the price.  Awesome!

13.description: Can you say crazy-crowded-dimly lit-jam packed -be careful every step you take so you don't knock something/someone over packed China Town gift/housewares shop?  Can you come in here without buying something?  I don't think so.I said packed and I honest to goodness meant it - this place is overflowing with....stuff.  Lots and lots of it. I would NOT want to be in here in an earthquake stuff. Stuff - swords, buddahs, Hello Kitty stuff, potholders, bamboo, water fountains, chopsticks, etc., all the usual suspects in a China Town gift store.  Wait, but there's more!  They have a HUGE selection of  dishes, from traditional ceramic and plastic flower/fish motif Chinese dinnerware, to I have to buy you know even though I don't need you dinner sets with monkeys and kittens and bunnys and oh my god, I just bought 6 rice bowls and I'm unemployed but I couldn't leave without them cute as anything you've ever seen stuff.  I'm not to be trusted in here, they always get me.  They also have a nice selection of well priced cleavers and rice makers, including the hard to find, super fantastic Tiger models.  You need Asian cookware and don't want to drive out to Mitsuwa?  They'll probably have it here, even if it takes you an hour to find it in their chaotically organized isles.MUCH more expensive than it used to be, but still not hideously overpriced, unobtrusive almost to the point of negligent staff, a great place to pick up some housewares, gifts, or that something you never knew you needed but can't live without.

16.description: A charmingly crowded gift shop chock full of everything you would expect to find in a Chinatown gift shop. They sell small appliances like rice cookers and housewares like chopsticks and utensils to chicago post cards and clothing and toys.

6.description: Watch your step when you step into AJ's Housewares.  There's a lot of stuff in here. And it's mostly vertical... with narrow little aisles between.Prices have risen oh-so-gradually here, but it's still a great place to shop for Asian placesettings and moderately-priced cookware.  Not everything is a bona fide bargain, but enough of it is so that you don't have to sweat the details.Yeah, they've got the usual Chinatown knick-knacks up near the door, to catch the eye of the merely curious and souvenir-seekers.  Sure.  And the center of the store is shelf upon shelf of Asian plates, fingerbowls, sushi dishes, soy sauce cups, tea pots, sake carafes, rice bowls, tea cups, chopsticks -- if you've seen it in an Asian restaurant, odds are you can find it here.But they've got a section in the back corner I haven't seen anywhere else.  It's Shrine-o-rama.  Everything you could want for the home ancestral shrine; offering dishes, incense by the pound (cheapest anywhere), votive scrip (money), votive lighting (LED-tipped incense sticks or pearlescent lotus blossoms) -- everything up to the big wooden shrines themselves.Tucked away in Chinatown Square, you'll need to find street parking for AJ's and the other unique stores in this great little shopping center.

15.description: This is a very nice Chinese gift shop located in Chinatown.  They sell bamboo plants, dishes, and clothing among other items.

0.description: All kinds of oriental( mostly Chinese, saw some Japanese) house wares, gifts, jewelry, mah-jong sets, mah-jong tables...Fun to browse around.The sales ladies are pretty friendly and helpful.

5.description: This place is great. You could spend hours in there just looking at things. The highlight for me is the aisle of bowls and tea cups. The designs range from classic white to traditional to cute animals for the kiddies. There are knickknacks abound and you'll probably want to paw through everything, even if you have no intention of buying it.Only drawback is that the aisles are so narrow that it's next to impossible to pass someone. You might break a bowl when you attempt, be careful.

11.description: They have another location in the old Chinatown on Wentworth, but this one has more stuff.  I really like this place because it has all sorts of things.  I had to buy some plates/trays used for an engagement/ wedding parade, and the owner gave me a discount for buying lots of them.  He was also very nice and friendly.  I was looking for these everywhere and this was one of the few places that had them and for the lowest price.  They have a nice selection of bamboo plants, plates, and all sorts of knick nacks.  If I'm getting gifts from Chinatown, it will more than likely be here.

8.description: I braved it again and came out completely satisfied.  We visited this store after the tourists, church goers, etc were gone.  For $24, I bought 6 Chinese spoons, 6 round soup spoons, a pair of nun chucks,a kata sword, a necklace, and lucky red envelopes.  Totally worth visiting when there are no crowds!

4.description: So many cute things. Plenty of kitsch and useful objects from all over Asia.I found a super cute Lucky Cat ceramic piggy bank and had to have it. It was only $5! I also picked up a resin red dragon for my boyfriend's cousin in honor of his recent engagement. We wanted to give him something to bring him luck. I purchased a new charm for my cellphone as well.The first aisle had mini statues. The second aisle was mostly full of plates, cups and dishes. I didn't spend too much time in the other aisles because I didn't have much extra money, but what I did see was enough to make me want to return and purchase presents for other people.They sell lottery tickets and we purchased a couple with the lucky numbers we got in our fortune cookies from Lao You Ju. Unfortunately, they weren't winners; therefore, minus one star... just kidding.

14.description: This shop complements the ones across the street that focus more on art. This is more utilitarian stuff for the kitchen and such.

7.description: Keep your hands to yourself, watch where you're going and make sure you're going side-ways.  Oh and take your time to look around.  There are sooooooooooooooooo much stuff there and it's everywhere somewhat organized.  But the good news is, the price is pretty good.  Just don't break anything.Oh and ignore the occasion follow and stare by the staff, it's less and less since they have surveillance cameras now, but still, they do stare from time to time.
